Marseilles\xe2\x80\x94The Arrival\r\n\r\nOn the 24th of February, 1815, the look-out at Notre-Dame de la Garde\r\nsignalled the three-master, the _Pharaon_ from Smyrna, Trieste, and\r\nNaples.\r\n\r\nAs usual, a pilot put off immediately, and rounding the Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If,\r\ngot on board the vessel between Cape Morgiou and Rion island.\r\n\r\nImmediately, and according to custom, the ramparts of Fort Saint-Jean\r\nwere covered with spectators; it is always an event at Marseilles for a\r\nship to come into port, especially when this ship, like the _Pharaon_,\r\nhas been built, rigged, and laden at the old Phocee docks, and belongs\r\nto an owner of the city.\r\n\r\nThe ship drew on and had safely passed the strait, which some volcanic\r\nshock has made between the Calasareigne and Jaros islands; had doubled\r\nPom\xc3\xa8gue, and approached the harbor under topsails, jib, and spanker,\r\nbut so slowly and sedately that the idlers, with that instinct which is\r\nthe forerunner of evil, asked one another what misfortune could have\r\nhappened on board. However, those experienced in navigation saw plainly\r\nthat if any accident had occurred, it was not to the vessel herself,\r\nfor she bore down with all the evidence of being skilfully handled, the\r\nanchor a-cockbill, the jib-boom guys already eased off, and standing by\r\nthe side of the pilot, who was steering the _Pharaon_ towards the\r\nnarrow entrance of the inner port, was a young man, who, with activity\r\nand vigilant eye, watched every motion of the ship, and repeated each\r\ndirection of the pilot.\r\n\r\nThe vague disquietude which prevailed among the spectators had so much\r\naffected one of the crowd that he did not await the arrival of the\r\nvessel in harbor, but jumping into a small skiff, desired to be pulled\r\nalongside the _Pharaon_, which he reached as she rounded into La\r\nR\xc3\xa9serve basin.\r\n\r\nWhen the young man on board saw this person approach, he left his\r\nstation by the pilot, and, hat in hand, leaned over the ship\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbulwarks.\r\n\r\nHe was a fine, tall, slim young fellow of eighteen or twenty, with\r\nblack eyes, and hair as dark as a raven\xe2\x80\x99s wing; and his whole\r\nappearance bespoke that calmness and resolution peculiar to men\r\naccustomed from their cradle to contend with danger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, is it you, Dant\xc3\xa8s?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the man in the skiff. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\nmatter? and why have you such an air of sadness aboard?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA great misfortune, M. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man, \xe2\x80\x9ca great\r\nmisfortune, for me especially! Off Civita Vecchia we lost our brave\r\nCaptain Leclere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the cargo?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the owner, eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs all safe, M. Morrel; and I think you will be satisfied on that\r\nhead. But poor Captain Leclere\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat happened to him?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the owner, with an air of considerable\r\nresignation. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat happened to the worthy captain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe died.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFell into the sea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir, he died of brain-fever in dreadful agony.\xe2\x80\x9d Then turning to\r\nthe crew, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cBear a hand there, to take in sail!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll hands obeyed, and at once the eight or ten seamen who composed the\r\ncrew, sprang to their respective stations at the spanker brails and\r\nouthaul, topsail sheets and halyards, the jib downhaul, and the topsail\r\nclewlines and buntlines. The young sailor gave a look to see that his\r\norders were promptly and accurately obeyed, and then turned again to\r\nthe owner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how did this misfortune occur?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the latter, resuming the\r\ninterrupted conversation.\r\n\r\n0023m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, sir, in the most unexpected manner. After a long talk with the\r\nharbor-master, Captain Leclere left Naples greatly disturbed in mind.\r\nIn twenty-four hours he was attacked by a fever, and died three days\r\nafterwards. We performed the usual burial service, and he is at his\r\nrest, sewn up in his hammock with a thirty-six-pound shot at his head\r\nand his heels, off El Giglio island. We bring to his widow his sword\r\nand cross of honor. It was worth while, truly,\xe2\x80\x9d added the young man\r\nwith a melancholy smile, \xe2\x80\x9cto make war against the English for ten\r\nyears, and to die in his bed at last, like everybody else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you see, Edmond,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the owner, who appeared more comforted\r\nat every moment, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are all mortal, and the old must make way for the\r\nyoung. If not, why, there would be no promotion; and since you assure\r\nme that the cargo\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs all safe and sound, M. Morrel, take my word for it; and I advise\r\nyou not to take 25,000 francs for the profits of the voyage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen, as they were just passing the Round Tower, the young man shouted:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand by there to lower the topsails and jib; brail up the spanker!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe order was executed as promptly as it would have been on board a\r\nman-of-war.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet go\xe2\x80\x94and clue up!\xe2\x80\x9d At this last command all the sails were lowered,\r\nand the vessel moved almost imperceptibly onwards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, if you will come on board, M. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s, observing the\r\nowner\xe2\x80\x99s impatience, \xe2\x80\x9chere is your supercargo, M. Danglars, coming out\r\nof his cabin, who will furnish you with every particular. As for me, I\r\nmust look after the anchoring, and dress the ship in mourning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe owner did not wait for a second invitation. He seized a rope which\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s flung to him, and with an activity that would have done credit\r\nto a sailor, climbed up the side of the ship, while the young man,\r\ngoing to his task, left the conversation to Danglars, who now came\r\ntowards the owner. He was a man of twenty-five or twenty-six years of\r\nage, of unprepossessing countenance, obsequious to his superiors,\r\ninsolent to his subordinates; and this, in addition to his position as\r\nresponsible agent on board, which is always obnoxious to the sailors,\r\nmade him as much disliked by the crew as Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s was beloved by\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, M. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have heard of the misfortune\r\nthat has befallen us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94yes: poor Captain Leclere! He was a brave and an honest man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd a first-rate seaman, one who had seen long and honorable service,\r\nas became a man charged with the interests of a house so important as\r\nthat of Morrel & Son,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the owner, glancing after Dant\xc3\xa8s, who was watching the\r\nanchoring of his vessel, \xe2\x80\x9cit seems to me that a sailor needs not be so\r\nold as you say, Danglars, to understand his business, for our friend\r\nEdmond seems to understand it thoroughly, and not to require\r\ninstruction from anyone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, darting at Edmond a look gleaming with hate.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he is young, and youth is invariably self-confident. Scarcely was\r\nthe captain\xe2\x80\x99s breath out of his body when he assumed the command\r\nwithout consulting anyone, and he caused us to lose a day and a half at\r\nthe Island of Elba, instead of making for Marseilles direct.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0025m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to taking command of the vessel,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cthat was his\r\nduty as captain\xe2\x80\x99s mate; as to losing a day and a half off the Island of\r\nElba, he was wrong, unless the vessel needed repairs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe vessel was in as good condition as I am, and as, I hope you are,\r\nM. Morrel, and this day and a half was lost from pure whim, for the\r\npleasure of going ashore, and nothing else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDant\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x9d said the shipowner, turning towards the young man, \xe2\x80\x9ccome this\r\nway!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn a moment, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\xe2\x80\x99m with you.\xe2\x80\x9d Then calling\r\nto the crew, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cLet go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe anchor was instantly dropped, and the chain ran rattling through\r\nthe port-hole. Dant\xc3\xa8s continued at his post in spite of the presence of\r\nthe pilot, until this man\xc5\x93uvre was completed, and then he added,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf-mast the colors, and square the yards!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9che fancies himself captain already, upon my\r\nword.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so, in fact, he is,\xe2\x80\x9d said the owner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcept your signature and your partner\xe2\x80\x99s, M. Morrel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why should he not have this?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the owner; \xe2\x80\x9che is young, it is\r\ntrue, but he seems to me a thorough seaman, and of full experience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA cloud passed over Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 brow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour pardon, M. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s, approaching, \xe2\x80\x9cthe vessel now\r\nrides at anchor, and I am at your service. You hailed me, I think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars retreated a step or two. \xe2\x80\x9cI wished to inquire why you stopped\r\nat the Island of Elba?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know, sir; it was to fulfil the last instructions of Captain\r\nLeclere, who, when dying, gave me a packet for Marshal Bertrand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen did you see him, Edmond?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe marshal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel looked around him, and then, drawing Dant\xc3\xa8s on one side, he said\r\nsuddenly\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how is the emperor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, as far as I could judge from the sight of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou saw the emperor, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe entered the marshal\xe2\x80\x99s apartment while I was there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you spoke to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it was he who spoke to me, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s, with a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did he say to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsked me questions about the vessel, the time she left Marseilles, the\r\ncourse she had taken, and what was her cargo. I believe, if she had not\r\nbeen laden, and I had been her master, he would have bought her. But I\r\ntold him I was only mate, and that she belonged to the firm of Morrel &\r\nSon. \xe2\x80\x98Ah, yes,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98I know them. The Morrels have been shipowners\r\nfrom father to son; and there was a Morrel who served in the same\r\nregiment with me when I was in garrison at Valence.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_ and that is true!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the owner, greatly delighted. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nthat was Policar Morrel, my uncle, who was afterwards a captain.\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s, you must tell my uncle that the emperor remembered him, and you\r\nwill see it will bring tears into the old soldier\xe2\x80\x99s eyes. Come, come,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued he, patting Edmond\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder kindly, \xe2\x80\x9cyou did very right,\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s, to follow Captain Leclere\xe2\x80\x99s instructions, and touch at Elba,\r\nalthough if it were known that you had conveyed a packet to the\r\nmarshal, and had conversed with the emperor, it might bring you into\r\ntrouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0027m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow could that bring me into trouble, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Dant\xc3\xa8s; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I did\r\nnot even know of what I was the bearer; and the emperor merely made\r\nsuch inquiries as he would of the first comer. But, pardon me, here are\r\nthe health officers and the customs inspectors coming alongside.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nthe young man went to the gangway. As he departed, Danglars approached,\r\nand said,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it appears that he has given you satisfactory reasons for his\r\nlanding at Porto-Ferrajo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, most satisfactory, my dear Danglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, so much the better,\xe2\x80\x9d said the supercargo; \xe2\x80\x9cfor it is not\r\npleasant to think that a comrade has not done his duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDant\xc3\xa8s has done his,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the owner, \xe2\x80\x9cand that is not saying much.\r\nIt was Captain Leclere who gave orders for this delay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTalking of Captain Leclere, has not Dant\xc3\xa8s given you a letter from\r\nhim?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo me?\xe2\x80\x94no\xe2\x80\x94was there one?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe that, besides the packet, Captain Leclere confided a letter\r\nto his care.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf what packet are you speaking, Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that which Dant\xc3\xa8s left at Porto-Ferrajo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know he had a packet to leave at Porto-Ferrajo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars turned very red.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was passing close to the door of the captain\xe2\x80\x99s cabin, which was half\r\nopen, and I saw him give the packet and letter to Dant\xc3\xa8s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe did not speak to me of it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the shipowner; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if there be\r\nany letter he will give it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars reflected for a moment. \xe2\x80\x9cThen, M. Morrel, I beg of you,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nhe, \xe2\x80\x9cnot to say a word to Dant\xc3\xa8s on the subject. I may have been\r\nmistaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment the young man returned; Danglars withdrew.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear Dant\xc3\xa8s, are you now free?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the owner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have not been long detained.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. I gave the custom-house officers a copy of our bill of lading; and\r\nas to the other papers, they sent a man off with the pilot, to whom I\r\ngave them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have nothing more to do here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94everything is all right now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you can come and dine with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI really must ask you to excuse me, M. Morrel. My first visit is due\r\nto my father, though I am not the less grateful for the honor you have\r\ndone me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0029m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRight, Dant\xc3\xa8s, quite right. I always knew you were a good son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd,\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Dant\xc3\xa8s, with some hesitation, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know how my\r\nfather is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I believe, my dear Edmond, though I have not seen him lately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he likes to keep himself shut up in his little room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat proves, at least, that he has wanted for nothing during your\r\nabsence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cMy father is proud, sir, and if he had not a meal left,\r\nI doubt if he would have asked anything from anyone, except from\r\nHeaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, after this first visit has been made we shall count on\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must again excuse myself, M. Morrel, for after this first visit has\r\nbeen paid I have another which I am most anxious to pay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, Dant\xc3\xa8s, I forgot that there was at the Catalans someone who\r\nexpects you no less impatiently than your father\xe2\x80\x94the lovely Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s blushed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ha,\xe2\x80\x9d said the shipowner, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not in the least surprised, for she\r\nhas been to me three times, inquiring if there were any news of the\r\n_Pharaon_. _Peste!_ Edmond, you have a very handsome mistress!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is not my mistress,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young sailor, gravely; \xe2\x80\x9cshe is my\r\nbetrothed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSometimes one and the same thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, with a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot with us, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well, my dear Edmond,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the owner, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t let me detain\r\nyou. You have managed my affairs so well that I ought to allow you all\r\nthe time you require for your own. Do you want any money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir; I have all my pay to take\xe2\x80\x94nearly three months\xe2\x80\x99 wages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a careful fellow, Edmond.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay I have a poor father, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, I know how good a son you are, so now hasten away to see\r\nyour father. I have a son too, and I should be very wroth with those\r\nwho detained him from me after a three months\xe2\x80\x99 voyage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I have your leave, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, if you have nothing more to say to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Leclere did not, before he died, give you a letter for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was unable to write, sir. But that reminds me that I must ask your\r\nleave of absence for some days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo get married?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, first, and then to go to Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good; have what time you require, Dant\xc3\xa8s. It will take quite six\r\nweeks to unload the cargo, and we cannot get you ready for sea until\r\nthree months after that; only be back again in three months, for the\r\n_Pharaon_,\xe2\x80\x9d added the owner, patting the young sailor on the back,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccannot sail without her captain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout her captain!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Dant\xc3\xa8s, his eyes sparkling with animation;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cpray mind what you say, for you are touching on the most secret wishes\r\nof my heart. Is it really your intention to make me captain of the\r\n_Pharaon_?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I were sole owner we\xe2\x80\x99d shake hands on it now, my dear Dant\xc3\xa8s, and\r\ncall it settled; but I have a partner, and you know the Italian\r\nproverb\xe2\x80\x94_Chi ha compagno ha padrone_\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98He who has a partner has a\r\nmaster.\xe2\x80\x99 But the thing is at least half done, as you have one out of\r\ntwo votes. Rely on me to procure you the other; I will do my best.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, M. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the young seaman, with tears in his eyes,\r\nand grasping the owner\xe2\x80\x99s hand, \xe2\x80\x9cM. Morrel, I thank you in the name of\r\nmy father and of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all right, Edmond. There\xe2\x80\x99s a providence that watches over the\r\ndeserving. Go to your father; go and see Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, and afterwards come\r\nto me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I row you ashore?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, thank you; I shall remain and look over the accounts with\r\nDanglars. Have you been satisfied with him this voyage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is according to the sense you attach to the question, sir. Do you\r\nmean is he a good comrade? No, for I think he never liked me since the\r\nday when I was silly enough, after a little quarrel we had, to propose\r\nto him to stop for ten minutes at the island of Monte Cristo to settle\r\nthe dispute\xe2\x80\x94a proposition which I was wrong to suggest, and he quite\r\nright to refuse. If you mean as responsible agent when you ask me the\r\nquestion, I believe there is nothing to say against him, and that you\r\nwill be content with the way in which he has performed his duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut tell me, Dant\xc3\xa8s, if you had command of the _Pharaon_ should you be\r\nglad to see Danglars remain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCaptain or mate, M. Morrel, I shall always have the greatest respect\r\nfor those who possess the owners\xe2\x80\x99 confidence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right, that\xe2\x80\x99s right, Dant\xc3\xa8s! I see you are a thoroughly good\r\nfellow, and will detain you no longer. Go, for I see how impatient you\r\nare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I have leave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, I tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I have the use of your skiff?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, for the present, M. Morrel, farewell, and a thousand thanks!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope soon to see you again, my dear Edmond. Good luck to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young sailor jumped into the skiff, and sat down in the stern\r\nsheets, with the order that he be put ashore at La Canebi\xc3\xa8re. The two\r\noarsmen bent to their work, and the little boat glided away as rapidly\r\nas possible in the midst of the thousand vessels which choke up the\r\nnarrow way which leads between the two rows of ships from the mouth of\r\nthe harbor to the Quai d\xe2\x80\x99Orl\xc3\xa9ans.\r\n\r\nThe shipowner, smiling, followed him with his eyes until he saw him\r\nspring out on the quay and disappear in the midst of the throng, which\r\nfrom five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning until nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock at night, swarms in\r\nthe famous street of La Canebi\xc3\xa8re,\xe2\x80\x94a street of which the modern\r\nPhoc\xc3\xa9ens are so proud that they say with all the gravity in the world,\r\nand with that accent which gives so much character to what is said, \xe2\x80\x9cIf\r\nParis had La Canebi\xc3\xa8re, Paris would be a second Marseilles.\xe2\x80\x9d On turning\r\nround the owner saw Danglars behind him, apparently awaiting orders,\r\nbut in reality also watching the young sailor,\xe2\x80\x94but there was a great\r\ndifference in the expression of the two men who thus followed the\r\nmovements of Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 2. Father and Son\r\n\r\nWe will leave Danglars struggling with the demon of hatred, and\r\nendeavoring to insinuate in the ear of the shipowner some evil\r\nsuspicions against his comrade, and follow Dant\xc3\xa8s, who, after having\r\ntraversed La Canebi\xc3\xa8re, took the Rue de Noailles, and entering a small\r\nhouse, on the left of the All\xc3\xa9es de Meilhan, rapidly ascended four\r\nflights of a dark staircase, holding the baluster with one hand, while\r\nwith the other he repressed the beatings of his heart, and paused\r\nbefore a half-open door, from which he could see the whole of a small\r\nroom.\r\n\r\nThis room was occupied by Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 father. The news of the arrival of\r\nthe _Pharaon_ had not yet reached the old man, who, mounted on a chair,\r\nwas amusing himself by training with trembling hand the nasturtiums and\r\nsprays of clematis that clambered over the trellis at his window.\r\nSuddenly, he felt an arm thrown around his body, and a well-known voice\r\nbehind him exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cFather\xe2\x80\x94dear father!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old man uttered a cry, and turned round; then, seeing his son, he\r\nfell into his arms, pale and trembling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat ails you, my dearest father? Are you ill?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the young\r\nman, much alarmed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, my dear Edmond\xe2\x80\x94my boy\xe2\x80\x94my son!\xe2\x80\x94no; but I did not expect you;\r\nand joy, the surprise of seeing you so suddenly\xe2\x80\x94Ah, I feel as if I were\r\ngoing to die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, cheer up, my dear father! \xe2\x80\x99Tis I\xe2\x80\x94really I! They say joy\r\nnever hurts, and so I came to you without any warning. Come now, do\r\nsmile, instead of looking at me so solemnly. Here I am back again, and\r\nwe are going to be happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, my boy, so we will\xe2\x80\x94so we will,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the old man; \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nhow shall we be happy? Shall you never leave me again? Come, tell me\r\nall the good fortune that has befallen you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod forgive me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cfor rejoicing at happiness\r\nderived from the misery of others, but, Heaven knows, I did not seek\r\nthis good fortune; it has happened, and I really cannot pretend to\r\nlament it. The good Captain Leclere is dead, father, and it is probable\r\nthat, with the aid of M. Morrel, I shall have his place. Do you\r\nunderstand, father? Only imagine me a captain at twenty, with a hundred\r\nlouis pay, and a share in the profits! Is this not more than a poor\r\nsailor like me could have hoped for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my dear boy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the old man, \xe2\x80\x9cit is very fortunate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, with the first money I touch, I mean you to have a small\r\nhouse, with a garden in which to plant clematis, nasturtiums, and\r\nhoneysuckle. But what ails you, father? Are you not well?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis nothing, nothing; it will soon pass away\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and as he said so the\r\nold man\xe2\x80\x99s strength failed him, and he fell backwards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, \xe2\x80\x9ca glass of wine, father, will revive\r\nyou. Where do you keep your wine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no; thanks. You need not look for it; I do not want it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nold man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, father, tell me where it is,\xe2\x80\x9d and he opened two or three\r\ncupboards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is no use,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is no wine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, no wine?\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s, turning pale, and looking alternately at\r\nthe hollow cheeks of the old man and the empty cupboards. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat, no\r\nwine? Have you wanted money, father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want nothing now that I have you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Dant\xc3\xa8s, wiping the perspiration from his brow,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyet I\r\ngave you two hundred francs when I left, three months ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, Edmond, that is true, but you forgot at that time a little\r\ndebt to our neighbor, Caderousse. He reminded me of it, telling me if I\r\ndid not pay for you, he would be paid by M. Morrel; and so, you see,\r\nlest he might do you an injury\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I paid him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cit was a hundred and forty francs I owed\r\nCaderousse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you paid him out of the two hundred francs I left you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old man nodded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that you have lived for three months on sixty francs,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered\r\nEdmond.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know how little I require,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeaven pardon me,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Edmond, falling on his knees before his\r\nfather.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have wounded me to the heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind it, for I see you once more,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man; \xe2\x80\x9cand now\r\nit\xe2\x80\x99s all over\xe2\x80\x94everything is all right again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0035m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, here I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cwith a promising future and a\r\nlittle money. Here, father, here!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9ctake this\xe2\x80\x94take it, and\r\nsend for something immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d And he emptied his pockets on the\r\ntable, the contents consisting of a dozen gold pieces, five or six\r\nfive-franc pieces, and some smaller coin. The countenance of old Dant\xc3\xa8s\r\nbrightened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom does this belong to?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo me, to you, to us! Take it; buy some provisions; be happy, and\r\ntomorrow we shall have more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGently, gently,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man, with a smile; \xe2\x80\x9cand by your leave I\r\nwill use your purse moderately, for they would say, if they saw me buy\r\ntoo many things at a time, that I had been obliged to await your\r\nreturn, in order to be able to purchase them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo as you please; but, first of all, pray have a servant, father. I\r\nwill not have you left alone so long. I have some smuggled coffee and\r\nmost capital tobacco, in a small chest in the hold, which you shall\r\nhave tomorrow. But, hush, here comes somebody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis Caderousse, who has heard of your arrival, and no doubt comes to\r\ncongratulate you on your fortunate return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, lips that say one thing, while the heart thinks another,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured\r\nEdmond. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, never mind, he is a neighbor who has done us a service on\r\na time, so he\xe2\x80\x99s welcome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs Edmond paused, the black and bearded head of Caderousse appeared at\r\nthe door. He was a man of twenty-five or six, and held a piece of\r\ncloth, which, being a tailor, he was about to make into a coat-lining.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, is it you, Edmond, back again?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with a broad\r\nMarseillaise accent, and a grin that displayed his ivory-white teeth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, as you see, neighbor Caderousse; and ready to be agreeable to you\r\nin any and every way,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s, but ill-concealing his coldness\r\nunder this cloak of civility.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks\xe2\x80\x94thanks; but, fortunately, I do not want for anything; and it\r\nchances that at times there are others who have need of me.\xe2\x80\x9d Dant\xc3\xa8s\r\nmade a gesture. \xe2\x80\x9cI do not allude to you, my boy. No!\xe2\x80\x94no! I lent you\r\nmoney, and you returned it; that\xe2\x80\x99s like good neighbors, and we are\r\nquits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are never quits with those who oblige us,\xe2\x80\x9d was Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 reply; \xe2\x80\x9cfor\r\nwhen we do not owe them money, we owe them gratitude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the use of mentioning that? What is done is done. Let us talk\r\nof your happy return, my boy. I had gone on the quay to match a piece\r\nof mulberry cloth, when I met friend Danglars. \xe2\x80\x98You at\r\nMarseilles?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 says he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I thought you were at Smyrna.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I was; but am now back again.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98And where is the dear boy, our little Edmond?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Why, with his father, no doubt,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Danglars. And so I came,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nadded Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cas fast as I could to have the pleasure of shaking\r\nhands with a friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0037m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWorthy Caderousse!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man, \xe2\x80\x9che is so much attached to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, to be sure I am. I love and esteem you, because honest folks are\r\nso rare. But it seems you have come back rich, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the\r\ntailor, looking askance at the handful of gold and silver which Dant\xc3\xa8s\r\nhad thrown on the table.\r\n\r\nThe young man remarked the greedy glance which shone in the dark eyes\r\nof his neighbor. \xe2\x80\x9cEh,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, negligently, \xe2\x80\x9cthis money is not mine. I\r\nwas expressing to my father my fears that he had wanted many things in\r\nmy absence, and to convince me he emptied his purse on the table. Come,\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x9d added Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cput this money back in your box\xe2\x80\x94unless neighbor\r\nCaderousse wants anything, and in that case it is at his service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my boy, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cI am not in any want, thank God, my\r\nliving is suited to my means. Keep your money\xe2\x80\x94keep it, I say;\xe2\x80\x94one never\r\nhas too much;\xe2\x80\x94but, at the same time, my boy, I am as much obliged by\r\nyour offer as if I took advantage of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was offered with good will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt, my boy; no doubt. Well, you stand well with M. Morrel I\r\nhear,\xe2\x80\x94you insinuating dog, you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Morrel has always been exceedingly kind to me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you were wrong to refuse to dine with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, did you refuse to dine with him?\xe2\x80\x9d said old Dant\xc3\xa8s; \xe2\x80\x9cand did he\r\ninvite you to dine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my dear father,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Edmond, smiling at his father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nastonishment at the excessive honor paid to his son.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why did you refuse, my son?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I might the sooner see you again, my dear father,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\nyoung man. \xe2\x80\x9cI was most anxious to see you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it must have vexed M. Morrel, good, worthy man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when you are looking forward to be captain, it was wrong to annoy\r\nthe owner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I explained to him the cause of my refusal,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nI hope he fully understood it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but to be captain one must do a little flattery to one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npatrons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope to be captain without that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better\xe2\x80\x94so much the better! Nothing will give greater\r\npleasure to all your old friends; and I know one down there behind the\r\nSaint Nicolas citadel who will not be sorry to hear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s?\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my dear father, and with your permission, now I have seen you,\r\nand know you are well and have all you require, I will ask your consent\r\nto go and pay a visit to the Catalans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, my dear boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said old Dant\xc3\xa8s; \xe2\x80\x9cand Heaven bless you in your wife,\r\nas it has blessed me in my son!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis wife!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cwhy, how fast you go on, father Dant\xc3\xa8s;\r\nshe is not his wife yet, as it seems to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but according to all probability she soon will be,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nEdmond.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you were right to return as soon as\r\npossible, my boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s is a very fine girl, and fine girls never lack\r\nfollowers; she particularly has them by dozens.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally?\xe2\x80\x9d answered Edmond, with a smile which had in it traces of\r\nslight uneasiness.\r\n\r\n0039m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cand capital offers, too; but you\r\nknow, you will be captain, and who could refuse you then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMeaning to say,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s, with a smile which but ill-concealed\r\nhis trouble, \xe2\x80\x9cthat if I were not a captain\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh\xe2\x80\x94eh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, shaking his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, \xe2\x80\x9cI have a better opinion than you of\r\nwomen in general, and of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s in particular; and I am certain that,\r\ncaptain or not, she will remain ever faithful to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better\xe2\x80\x94so much the better,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen one is\r\ngoing to be married, there is nothing like implicit confidence; but\r\nnever mind that, my boy,\xe2\x80\x94go and announce your arrival, and let her know\r\nall your hopes and prospects.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go directly,\xe2\x80\x9d was Edmond\xe2\x80\x99s reply; and, embracing his father,\r\nand nodding to Caderousse, he left the apartment.\r\n\r\nCaderousse lingered for a moment, then taking leave of old Dant\xc3\xa8s, he\r\nwent downstairs to rejoin Danglars, who awaited him at the corner of\r\nthe Rue Senac.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cdid you see him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have just left him,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he allude to his hope of being captain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe spoke of it as a thing already decided.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9che is in too much hurry, it appears to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it seems M. Morrel has promised him the thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that he is quite elated about it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, yes, he is actually insolent over the matter\xe2\x80\x94has already offered\r\nme his patronage, as if he were a grand personage, and proffered me a\r\nloan of money, as though he were a banker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich you refused?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost assuredly; although I might easily have accepted it, for it was I\r\nwho put into his hands the first silver he ever earned; but now M.\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s has no longer any occasion for assistance\xe2\x80\x94he is about to become\r\na captain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPooh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9che is not one yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi!_ it will be as well if he is not,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cfor\r\nif he should be, there will be really no speaking to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we choose,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9che will remain what he is; and\r\nperhaps become even less than he is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing\xe2\x80\x94I was speaking to myself. And is he still in love with the\r\nCatalane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOver head and ears; but, unless I am much mistaken, there will be a\r\nstorm in that quarter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0041m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is more important than you think, perhaps. You do not like Dant\xc3\xa8s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never like upstarts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen tell me all you know about the Catalane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know nothing for certain; only I have seen things which induce me to\r\nbelieve, as I told you, that the future captain will find some\r\nannoyance in the vicinity of the Vieilles Infirmeries.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you seen?\xe2\x80\x94come, tell me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, every time I have seen Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s come into the city she has been\r\naccompanied by a tall, strapping, black-eyed Catalan, with a red\r\ncomplexion, brown skin, and fierce air, whom she calls cousin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally; and you think this cousin pays her attentions?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only suppose so. What else can a strapping chap of twenty-one mean\r\nwith a fine wench of seventeen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you say that Dant\xc3\xa8s has gone to the Catalans?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe went before I came down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go the same way; we will stop at La R\xc3\xa9serve, and we can drink a\r\nglass of La Malgue, whilst we wait for news.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome along,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you pay the score.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars; and going quickly to the designated\r\nplace, they called for a bottle of wine, and two glasses.\r\n\r\nP\xc3\xa8re Pamphile had seen Dant\xc3\xa8s pass not ten minutes before; and assured\r\nthat he was at the Catalans, they sat down under the budding foliage of\r\nthe planes and sycamores, in the branches of which the birds were\r\nsinging their welcome to one of the first days of spring.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 3. The Catalans\r\n\r\nBeyond a bare, weather-worn wall, about a hundred paces from the spot\r\nwhere the two friends sat looking and listening as they drank their\r\nwine, was the village of the Catalans. Long ago this mysterious colony\r\nquitted Spain, and settled on the tongue of land on which it is to this\r\nday. Whence it came no one knew, and it spoke an unknown tongue. One of\r\nits chiefs, who understood Proven\xc3\xa7al, begged the commune of Marseilles\r\nto give them this bare and barren promontory, where, like the sailors\r\nof old, they had run their boats ashore. The request was granted; and\r\nthree months afterwards, around the twelve or fifteen small vessels\r\nwhich had brought these gypsies of the sea, a small village sprang up.\r\nThis village, constructed in a singular and picturesque manner, half\r\nMoorish, half Spanish, still remains, and is inhabited by descendants\r\nof the first comers, who speak the language of their fathers. For three\r\nor four centuries they have remained upon this small promontory, on\r\nwhich they had settled like a flight of seabirds, without mixing with\r\nthe Marseillaise population, intermarrying, and preserving their\r\noriginal customs and the costume of their mother-country as they have\r\npreserved its language.\r\n\r\nOur readers will follow us along the only street of this little\r\nvillage, and enter with us one of the houses, which is sunburned to the\r\nbeautiful dead-leaf color peculiar to the buildings of the country, and\r\nwithin coated with whitewash, like a Spanish posada. A young and\r\nbeautiful girl, with hair as black as jet, her eyes as velvety as the\r\ngazelle\xe2\x80\x99s, was leaning with her back against the wainscot, rubbing in\r\nher slender delicately moulded fingers a bunch of heath blossoms, the\r\nflowers of which she was picking off and strewing on the floor; her\r\narms, bare to the elbow, brown, and modelled after those of the\r\nArlesian Venus, moved with a kind of restless impatience, and she\r\ntapped the earth with her arched and supple foot, so as to display the\r\npure and full shape of her well-turned leg, in its red cotton, gray and\r\nblue clocked, stocking. At three paces from her, seated in a chair\r\nwhich he balanced on two legs, leaning his elbow on an old worm-eaten\r\ntable, was a tall young man of twenty, or two-and-twenty, who was\r\nlooking at her with an air in which vexation and uneasiness were\r\nmingled. He questioned her with his eyes, but the firm and steady gaze\r\nof the young girl controlled his look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, \xe2\x80\x9chere is Easter come round\r\nagain; tell me, is this the moment for a wedding?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have answered you a hundred times, Fernand, and really you must be\r\nvery stupid to ask me again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, repeat it,\xe2\x80\x94repeat it, I beg of you, that I may at last believe\r\nit! Tell me for the hundredth time that you refuse my love, which had\r\nyour mother\xe2\x80\x99s sanction. Make me understand once for all that you are\r\ntrifling with my happiness, that my life or death are nothing to you.\r\nAh, to have dreamed for ten years of being your husband, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, and\r\nto lose that hope, which was the only stay of my existence!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt least it was not I who ever encouraged you in that hope, Fernand,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s; \xe2\x80\x9cyou cannot reproach me with the slightest coquetry.\r\nI have always said to you, \xe2\x80\x98I love you as a brother; but do not ask\r\nfrom me more than sisterly affection, for my heart is another\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x99 Is\r\nnot this true, Fernand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is very true, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cYes, you\r\nhave been cruelly frank with me; but do you forget that it is among the\r\nCatalans a sacred law to intermarry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0045m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mistake, Fernand; it is not a law, but merely a custom, and, I\r\npray of you, do not cite this custom in your favor. You are included in\r\nthe conscription, Fernand, and are only at liberty on sufferance,\r\nliable at any moment to be called upon to take up arms. Once a soldier,\r\nwhat would you do with me, a poor orphan, forlorn, without fortune,\r\nwith nothing but a half-ruined hut and a few ragged nets, the miserable\r\ninheritance left by my father to my mother, and by my mother to me? She\r\nhas been dead a year, and you know, Fernand, I have subsisted almost\r\nentirely on public charity. Sometimes you pretend I am useful to you,\r\nand that is an excuse to share with me the produce of your fishing, and\r\nI accept it, Fernand, because you are the son of my father\xe2\x80\x99s brother,\r\nbecause we were brought up together, and still more because it would\r\ngive you so much pain if I refuse. But I feel very deeply that this\r\nfish which I go and sell, and with the produce of which I buy the flax\r\nI spin,\xe2\x80\x94I feel very keenly, Fernand, that this is charity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if it were, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, poor and lone as you are, you suit me as\r\nwell as the daughter of the first shipowner or the richest banker of\r\nMarseilles! What do such as we desire but a good wife and careful\r\nhousekeeper, and where can I look for these better than in you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFernand,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, shaking her head, \xe2\x80\x9ca woman becomes a bad\r\nmanager, and who shall say she will remain an honest woman, when she\r\nloves another man better than her husband? Rest content with my\r\nfriendship, for I say once more that is all I can promise, and I will\r\npromise no more than I can bestow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Fernand, \xe2\x80\x9cyou can endure your own wretchedness\r\npatiently, but you are afraid to share mine. Well, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, beloved by\r\nyou, I would tempt fortune; you would bring me good luck, and I should\r\nbecome rich. I could extend my occupation as a fisherman, might get a\r\nplace as clerk in a warehouse, and become in time a dealer myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou could do no such thing, Fernand; you are a soldier, and if you\r\nremain at the Catalans it is because there is no war; so remain a\r\nfisherman, and contented with my friendship, as I cannot give you\r\nmore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will do better, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s. I will be a sailor; instead of the\r\ncostume of our fathers, which you despise, I will wear a varnished hat,\r\na striped shirt, and a blue jacket, with an anchor on the buttons.\r\nWould not that dress please you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, with an angry glance,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you\r\nmean? I do not understand you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, that you are thus harsh and cruel with me, because\r\nyou are expecting someone who is thus attired; but perhaps he whom you\r\nawait is inconstant, or if he is not, the sea is so to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFernand,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cI believed you were good-hearted, and I was\r\nmistaken! Fernand, you are wicked to call to your aid jealousy and the\r\nanger of God! Yes, I will not deny it, I do await, and I do love him of\r\nwhom you speak; and, if he does not return, instead of accusing him of\r\nthe inconstancy which you insinuate, I will tell you that he died\r\nloving me and me only.\xe2\x80\x9d The young girl made a gesture of rage. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nunderstand you, Fernand; you would be revenged on him because I do not\r\nlove you; you would cross your Catalan knife with his dirk. What end\r\nwould that answer? To lose you my friendship if he were conquered, and\r\nsee that friendship changed into hate if you were victor. Believe me,\r\nto seek a quarrel with a man is a bad method of pleasing the woman who\r\nloves that man. No, Fernand, you will not thus give way to evil\r\nthoughts. Unable to have me for your wife, you will content yourself\r\nwith having me for your friend and sister; and besides,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, her\r\neyes troubled and moistened with tears, \xe2\x80\x9cwait, wait, Fernand; you said\r\njust now that the sea was treacherous, and he has been gone four\r\nmonths, and during these four months there have been some terrible\r\nstorms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFernand made no reply, nor did he attempt to check the tears which\r\nflowed down the cheeks of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, although for each of these tears he\r\nwould have shed his heart\xe2\x80\x99s blood; but these tears flowed for another.\r\nHe arose, paced a while up and down the hut, and then, suddenly\r\nstopping before Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, with his eyes glowing and his hands\r\nclenched,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSay, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9conce for all, is this your final\r\ndetermination?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x9d the young girl calmly replied, \xe2\x80\x9cand none but\r\nEdmond shall ever be my husband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will always love him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs long as I live.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFernand let fall his head like a defeated man, heaved a sigh that was\r\nlike a groan, and then suddenly looking her full in the face, with\r\nclenched teeth and expanded nostrils, said,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBut if he is dead\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he is dead, I shall die too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he has forgotten you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s!\xe2\x80\x9d called a joyous voice from without,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the young girl, blushing with delight, and fairly\r\nleaping in excess of love, \xe2\x80\x9cyou see he has not forgotten me, for here\r\nhe is!\xe2\x80\x9d And rushing towards the door, she opened it, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cHere,\r\nEdmond, here I am!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFernand, pale and trembling, drew back, like a traveller at the sight\r\nof a serpent, and fell into a chair beside him. Edmond and Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s\r\nwere clasped in each other\xe2\x80\x99s arms. The burning Marseilles sun, which\r\nshot into the room through the open door, covered them with a flood of\r\nlight. At first they saw nothing around them. Their intense happiness\r\nisolated them from all the rest of the world, and they only spoke in\r\nbroken words, which are the tokens of a joy so extreme that they seem\r\nrather the expression of sorrow. Suddenly Edmond saw the gloomy, pale,\r\nand threatening countenance of Fernand, as it was defined in the\r\nshadow. By a movement for which he could scarcely account to himself,\r\nthe young Catalan placed his hand on the knife at his belt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, your pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s, frowning in his turn; \xe2\x80\x9cI did not\r\nperceive that there were three of us.\xe2\x80\x9d Then, turning to Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, he\r\ninquired, \xe2\x80\x9cWho is this gentleman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne who will be your best friend, Dant\xc3\xa8s, for he is my friend, my\r\ncousin, my brother; it is Fernand\xe2\x80\x94the man whom, after you, Edmond, I\r\nlove the best in the world. Do you not remember him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s, and without relinquishing Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 hand clasped in\r\none of his own, he extended the other to the Catalan with a cordial\r\nair. But Fernand, instead of responding to this amiable gesture,\r\nremained mute and trembling. Edmond then cast his eyes scrutinizingly\r\nat the agitated and embarrassed Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, and then again on the gloomy\r\nand menacing Fernand. This look told him all, and his anger waxed hot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not know, when I came with such haste to you, that I was to meet\r\nan enemy here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn enemy!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, with an angry look at her cousin. \xe2\x80\x9cAn enemy\r\nin my house, do you say, Edmond! If I believed that, I would place my\r\narm under yours and go with you to Marseilles, leaving the house to\r\nreturn to it no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFernand\xe2\x80\x99s eye darted lightning. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd should any misfortune occur to\r\nyou, dear Edmond,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued with the same calmness which proved to\r\nFernand that the young girl had read the very innermost depths of his\r\nsinister thought, \xe2\x80\x9cif misfortune should occur to you, I would ascend\r\nthe highest point of the Cape de Morgiou and cast myself headlong from\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFernand became deadly pale. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you are deceived, Edmond,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\ncontinued. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have no enemy here\xe2\x80\x94there is no one but Fernand, my\r\nbrother, who will grasp your hand as a devoted friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd at these words the young girl fixed her imperious look on the\r\nCatalan, who, as if fascinated by it, came slowly towards Edmond, and\r\noffered him his hand. His hatred, like a powerless though furious wave,\r\nwas broken against the strong ascendancy which Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s exercised over\r\nhim. Scarcely, however, had he touched Edmond\xe2\x80\x99s hand when he felt he\r\nhad done all he could do, and rushed hastily out of the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, running furiously and tearing his hair\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cOh, who\r\nwill deliver me from this man? Wretched\xe2\x80\x94wretched that I am!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHallo, Catalan! Hallo, Fernand! where are you running to?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed a\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\nThe young man stopped suddenly, looked around him, and perceived\r\nCaderousse sitting at table with Danglars, under an arbor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell\xe2\x80\x9d, said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you come? Are you really in such a\r\nhurry that you have no time to pass the time of day with your friends?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cParticularly when they have still a full bottle before them,\xe2\x80\x9d added\r\nDanglars. Fernand looked at them both with a stupefied air, but did not\r\nsay a word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe seems besotted,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, pushing Caderousse with his knee.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre we mistaken, and is Dant\xc3\xa8s triumphant in spite of all we have\r\nbelieved?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, we must inquire into that,\xe2\x80\x9d was Caderousse\xe2\x80\x99s reply; and turning\r\ntowards the young man, said, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, Catalan, can\xe2\x80\x99t you make up your\r\nmind?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFernand wiped away the perspiration steaming from his brow, and slowly\r\nentered the arbor, whose shade seemed to restore somewhat of calmness\r\nto his senses, and whose coolness somewhat of refreshment to his\r\nexhausted body.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-day,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cYou called me, didn\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d And he fell, rather\r\nthan sat down, on one of the seats which surrounded the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI called you because you were running like a madman, and I was afraid\r\nyou would throw yourself into the sea,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, laughing.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, when a man has friends, they are not only to offer him a glass of\r\nwine, but, moreover, to prevent his swallowing three or four pints of\r\nwater unnecessarily!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFernand gave a groan, which resembled a sob, and dropped his head into\r\nhis hands, his elbows leaning on the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Fernand, I must say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, beginning the\r\nconversation, with that brutality of the common people in which\r\ncuriosity destroys all diplomacy, \xe2\x80\x9cyou look uncommonly like a rejected\r\nlover;\xe2\x80\x9d and he burst into a hoarse laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9ca lad of his make was not born to be unhappy in\r\nlove. You are laughing at him, Caderousse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, \xe2\x80\x9conly hark how he sighs! Come, come, Fernand,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCaderousse, \xe2\x80\x9chold up your head, and answer us. It\xe2\x80\x99s not polite not to\r\nreply to friends who ask news of your health.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy health is well enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fernand, clenching his hands without\r\nraising his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you see, Danglars,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, winking at his friend, \xe2\x80\x9cthis\r\nis how it is; Fernand, whom you see here, is a good and brave Catalan,\r\none of the best fishermen in Marseilles, and he is in love with a very\r\nfine girl, named Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s; but it appears, unfortunately, that the fine\r\ngirl is in love with the mate of the _Pharaon_; and as the _Pharaon_\r\narrived today\xe2\x80\x94why, you understand!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I do not understand,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Fernand has been dismissed,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and what then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fernand, lifting up his head, and looking\r\nat Caderousse like a man who looks for someone on whom to vent his\r\nanger; \xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s is not accountable to any person, is she? Is she not\r\nfree to love whomsoever she will?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if you take it in that sense,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cit is another\r\nthing. But I thought you were a Catalan, and they told me the Catalans\r\nwere not men to allow themselves to be supplanted by a rival. It was\r\neven told me that Fernand, especially, was terrible in his vengeance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFernand smiled piteously. \xe2\x80\x9cA lover is never terrible,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Danglars, affecting to pity the young man from\r\nthe bottom of his heart. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you see, he did not expect to see Dant\xc3\xa8s\r\nreturn so suddenly\xe2\x80\x94he thought he was dead, perhaps; or perchance\r\nfaithless! These things always come on us more severely when they come\r\nsuddenly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, _ma foi_, under any circumstances!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, who drank as\r\nhe spoke, and on whom the fumes of the wine began to take\r\neffect,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cunder any circumstances Fernand is not the only person put out\r\nby the fortunate arrival of Dant\xc3\xa8s; is he, Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you are right\xe2\x80\x94and I should say that would bring him ill-luck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, never mind,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Caderousse, pouring out a glass of wine\r\nfor Fernand, and filling his own for the eighth or ninth time, while\r\nDanglars had merely sipped his. \xe2\x80\x9cNever mind\xe2\x80\x94in the meantime he marries\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x94the lovely Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x94at least he returns to do that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDuring this time Danglars fixed his piercing glance on the young man,\r\non whose heart Caderousse\xe2\x80\x99s words fell like molten lead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when is the wedding to be?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is not yet fixed!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Fernand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but it will be,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cas surely as Dant\xc3\xa8s will be\r\ncaptain of the _Pharaon_\xe2\x80\x94eh, Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars shuddered at this unexpected attack, and turned to Caderousse,\r\nwhose countenance he scrutinized, to try and detect whether the blow\r\nwas premeditated; but he read nothing but envy in a countenance already\r\nrendered brutal and stupid by drunkenness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, filling the glasses, \xe2\x80\x9clet us drink to Captain Edmond\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s, husband of the beautiful Catalane!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse raised his glass to his mouth with unsteady hand, and\r\nswallowed the contents at a gulp. Fernand dashed his on the ground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, eh, eh!\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do I see down there by the\r\nwall, in the direction of the Catalans? Look, Fernand, your eyes are\r\nbetter than mine. I believe I see double. You know wine is a deceiver;\r\nbut I should say it was two lovers walking side by side, and hand in\r\nhand. Heaven forgive me, they do not know that we can see them, and\r\nthey are actually embracing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars did not lose one pang that Fernand endured.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know them, Fernand?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply, in a low voice. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is Edmond and Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, see there, now!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cand I did not recognize them!\r\nHallo, Dant\xc3\xa8s! hello, lovely damsel! Come this way, and let us know\r\nwhen the wedding is to be, for Fernand here is so obstinate he will not\r\ntell us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, pretending to restrain\r\nCaderousse, who, with the tenacity of drunkards, leaned out of the\r\narbor. \xe2\x80\x9cTry to stand upright, and let the lovers make love without\r\ninterruption. See, look at Fernand, and follow his example; he is\r\nwell-behaved!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0051m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFernand, probably excited beyond bearing, pricked by Danglars, as the\r\nbull is by the bandilleros, was about to rush out; for he had risen\r\nfrom his seat, and seemed to be collecting himself to dash headlong\r\nupon his rival, when Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, smiling and graceful, lifted up her\r\nlovely head, and looked at them with her clear and bright eyes. At this\r\nFernand recollected her threat of dying if Edmond died, and dropped\r\nagain heavily on his seat. Danglars looked at the two men, one after\r\nthe other, the one brutalized by liquor, the other overwhelmed with\r\nlove.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall get nothing from these fools,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered; \xe2\x80\x9cand I am very\r\nmuch afraid of being here between a drunkard and a coward. Here\xe2\x80\x99s an\r\nenvious fellow making himself boozy on wine when he ought to be nursing\r\nhis wrath, and here is a fool who sees the woman he loves stolen from\r\nunder his nose and takes on like a big baby. Yet this Catalan has eyes\r\nthat glisten like those of the vengeful Spaniards, Sicilians, and\r\nCalabrians, and the other has fists big enough to crush an ox at one\r\nblow. Unquestionably, Edmond\xe2\x80\x99s star is in the ascendant, and he will\r\nmarry the splendid girl\xe2\x80\x94he will be captain, too, and laugh at us all,\r\nunless\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a sinister smile passed over Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 lips\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cunless I take a\r\nhand in the affair,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHallo!\xe2\x80\x9d continued Caderousse, half-rising, and with his fist on the\r\ntable, \xe2\x80\x9challo, Edmond! do you not see your friends, or are you too\r\nproud to speak to them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my dear fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not proud, but I am happy,\r\nand happiness blinds, I think, more than pride.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, very well, that\xe2\x80\x99s an explanation!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cHow do you\r\ndo, Madame Dant\xc3\xa8s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s courtesied gravely, and said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not my name, and in my\r\ncountry it bodes ill fortune, they say, to call a young girl by the\r\nname of her betrothed before he becomes her husband. So call me\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must excuse our worthy neighbor, Caderousse,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9che is\r\nso easily mistaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, then, the wedding is to take place immediately, M. Dant\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nDanglars, bowing to the young couple.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs soon as possible, M. Danglars; today all preliminaries will be\r\narranged at my father\xe2\x80\x99s, and tomorrow, or next day at latest, the\r\nwedding festival here at La R\xc3\xa9serve. My friends will be there, I hope;\r\nthat is to say, you are invited, M. Danglars, and you, Caderousse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Fernand,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse with a chuckle; \xe2\x80\x9cFernand, too, is\r\ninvited!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy wife\xe2\x80\x99s brother is my brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edmond; \xe2\x80\x9cand we, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s and\r\nI, should be very sorry if he were absent at such a time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFernand opened his mouth to reply, but his voice died on his lips, and\r\nhe could not utter a word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToday the preliminaries, tomorrow or next day the ceremony! You are in\r\na hurry, captain!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDanglars,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edmond, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cI will say to you as Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s said\r\njust now to Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x98Do not give me a title which does not belong\r\nto me\xe2\x80\x99; that may bring me bad luck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI merely said you seemed in a hurry,\r\nand we have lots of time; the _Pharaon_ cannot be under weigh again in\r\nless than three months.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are always in a hurry to be happy, M. Danglars; for when we have\r\nsuffered a long time, we have great difficulty in believing in good\r\nfortune. But it is not selfishness alone that makes me thus in haste; I\r\nmust go to Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, really?\xe2\x80\x94to Paris! and will it be the first time you have ever been\r\nthere, Dant\xc3\xa8s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you business there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot of my own; the last commission of poor Captain Leclere; you know\r\nto what I allude, Danglars\xe2\x80\x94it is sacred. Besides, I shall only take the\r\ntime to go and return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, I understand,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, and then in a low tone, he\r\nadded, \xe2\x80\x9cTo Paris, no doubt to deliver the letter which the grand\r\nmarshal gave him. Ah, this letter gives me an idea\xe2\x80\x94a capital idea! Ah;\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s, my friend, you are not yet registered number one on board the\r\ngood ship _Pharaon_;\xe2\x80\x9d then turning towards Edmond, who was walking\r\naway, \xe2\x80\x9cA pleasant journey,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edmond with a friendly nod, and the two lovers\r\ncontinued on their way, as calm and joyous as if they were the very\r\nelect of heaven.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 4. Conspiracy\r\n\r\nDanglars followed Edmond and Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s with his eyes until the two\r\nlovers disappeared behind one of the angles of Fort Saint Nicolas;\r\nthen, turning round, he perceived Fernand, who had fallen, pale and\r\ntrembling, into his chair, while Caderousse stammered out the words of\r\na drinking-song.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars to Fernand, \xe2\x80\x9chere is a marriage\r\nwhich does not appear to make everybody happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt drives me to despair,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fernand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you, then, love Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI adore her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor long?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs long as I have known her\xe2\x80\x94always.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you sit there, tearing your hair, instead of seeking to remedy\r\nyour condition; I did not think that was the way of your people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have me do?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fernand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do I know? Is it my affair? I am not in love with Mademoiselle\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s; but for you\xe2\x80\x94in the words of the gospel, seek, and you shall\r\nfind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have found already.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would stab the man, but the woman told me that if any misfortune\r\nhappened to her betrothed, she would kill herself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPooh! Women say those things, but never do them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not know Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s; what she threatens she will do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIdiot!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cwhether she kill herself or not, what\r\nmatter, provided Dant\xc3\xa8s is not captain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBefore Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s should die,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Fernand, with the accents of\r\nunshaken resolution, \xe2\x80\x9cI would die myself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s what I call love!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse with a voice more tipsy than\r\never. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s love, or I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what love is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cyou appear to me a good sort of fellow, and\r\nhang me, I should like to help you, but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cbut how?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are three parts drunk; finish\r\nthe bottle, and you will be completely so. Drink then, and do not\r\nmeddle with what we are discussing, for that requires all one\xe2\x80\x99s wit and\r\ncool judgment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x94drunk!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cwell that\xe2\x80\x99s a good one! I could drink four\r\nmore such bottles; they are no bigger than cologne flasks. P\xc3\xa8re\r\nPamphile, more wine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Caderousse rattled his glass upon the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were saying, sir\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said Fernand, awaiting with great anxiety the\r\nend of this interrupted remark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was I saying? I forget. This drunken Caderousse has made me lose\r\nthe thread of my sentence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrunk, if you like; so much the worse for those who fear wine, for it\r\nis because they have bad thoughts which they are afraid the liquor will\r\nextract from their hearts;\xe2\x80\x9d and Caderousse began to sing the two last\r\nlines of a song very popular at the time:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tous les m\xc3\xa9chants sont buveurs d\xe2\x80\x99eau;\r\n\r\nC\xe2\x80\x99est bien prouv\xc3\xa9 par le d\xc3\xa9luge.\xe2\x80\x991\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said, sir, you would like to help me, but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but I added, to help you it would be sufficient that Dant\xc3\xa8s did\r\nnot marry her you love; and the marriage may easily be thwarted,\r\nmethinks, and yet Dant\xc3\xa8s need not die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeath alone can separate them,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Fernand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou talk like a noodle, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cand here is\r\nDanglars, who is a wide-awake, clever, deep fellow, who will prove to\r\nyou that you are wrong. Prove it, Danglars. I have answered for you.\r\nSay there is no need why Dant\xc3\xa8s should die; it would, indeed, be a pity\r\nhe should. Dant\xc3\xa8s is a good fellow; I like Dant\xc3\xa8s. Dant\xc3\xa8s, your\r\nhealth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFernand rose impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cLet him run on,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, restraining\r\nthe young man; \xe2\x80\x9cdrunk as he is, he is not much out in what he says.\r\nAbsence severs as well as death, and if the walls of a prison were\r\nbetween Edmond and Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s they would be as effectually separated as\r\nif he lay under a tombstone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0056m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but one gets out of prison,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, who, with what\r\nsense was left him, listened eagerly to the conversation, \xe2\x80\x9cand when one\r\ngets out and one\xe2\x80\x99s name is Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s, one seeks revenge\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat matters that?\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Fernand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why, I should like to know,\xe2\x80\x9d persisted Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cshould they\r\nput Dant\xc3\xa8s in prison? he has neither robbed, nor killed, nor murdered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue!\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t hold my tongue!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cI say I want to know why\r\nthey should put Dant\xc3\xa8s in prison; I like Dant\xc3\xa8s; Dant\xc3\xa8s, your health!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand he swallowed another glass of wine.\r\n\r\n0057m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDanglars saw in the muddled look of the tailor the progress of his\r\nintoxication, and turning towards Fernand, said, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, you understand\r\nthere is no need to kill him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not, if, as you said just now, you have the means of having\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s arrested. Have you that means?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is to be found for the searching. But why should I meddle in the\r\nmatter? it is no affair of mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know not why you meddle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fernand, seizing his arm; \xe2\x80\x9cbut this I\r\nknow, you have some motive of personal hatred against Dant\xc3\xa8s, for he\r\nwho himself hates is never mistaken in the sentiments of others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI! motives of hatred against Dant\xc3\xa8s? None, on my word! I saw you were\r\nunhappy, and your unhappiness interested me; that\xe2\x80\x99s all; but since you\r\nbelieve I act for my own account, adieu, my dear friend, get out of the\r\naffair as best you may;\xe2\x80\x9d and Danglars rose as if he meant to depart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fernand, restraining him, \xe2\x80\x9cstay! It is of very little\r\nconsequence to me at the end of the matter whether you have any angry\r\nfeeling or not against Dant\xc3\xa8s. I hate him! I confess it openly. Do you\r\nfind the means, I will execute it, provided it is not to kill the man,\r\nfor Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s has declared she will kill herself if Dant\xc3\xa8s is killed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse, who had let his head drop on the table, now raised it, and\r\nlooking at Fernand with his dull and fishy eyes, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cKill Dant\xc3\xa8s!\r\nwho talks of killing Dant\xc3\xa8s? I won\xe2\x80\x99t have him killed\xe2\x80\x94I won\xe2\x80\x99t! He\xe2\x80\x99s my\r\nfriend, and this morning offered to share his money with me, as I\r\nshared mine with him. I won\xe2\x80\x99t have Dant\xc3\xa8s killed\xe2\x80\x94I won\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who has said a word about killing him, muddlehead?\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nDanglars. \xe2\x80\x9cWe were merely joking; drink to his health,\xe2\x80\x9d he added,\r\nfilling Caderousse\xe2\x80\x99s glass, \xe2\x80\x9cand do not interfere with us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 good health!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, emptying his glass,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chere\xe2\x80\x99s to his health! his health\xe2\x80\x94hurrah!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the means\xe2\x80\x94the means?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fernand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you not hit upon any?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x94you undertook to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cthe French have the superiority over the\r\nSpaniards, that the Spaniards ruminate, while the French invent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you invent, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fernand impatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWaiter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cpen, ink, and paper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPen, ink, and paper,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Fernand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I am a supercargo; pen, ink, and paper are my tools, and without\r\nmy tools I am fit for nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPen, ink, and paper, then,\xe2\x80\x9d called Fernand loudly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s what you want on that table,\xe2\x80\x9d said the waiter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBring them here.\xe2\x80\x9d The waiter did as he was desired.\r\n\r\n0059m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen one thinks,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, letting his hand drop on the paper,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthere is here wherewithal to kill a man more sure than if we waited at\r\nthe corner of a wood to assassinate him!
