I have always had more dread\r\nof a pen, a bottle of ink, and a sheet of paper, than of a sword or\r\npistol.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fellow is not so drunk as he appears to be,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars. \xe2\x80\x9cGive\r\nhim some more wine, Fernand.\xe2\x80\x9d Fernand filled Caderousse\xe2\x80\x99s glass, who,\r\nlike the confirmed toper he was, lifted his hand from the paper and\r\nseized the glass.\r\n\r\nThe Catalan watched him until Caderousse, almost overcome by this fresh\r\nassault on his senses, rested, or rather dropped, his glass upon the\r\ntable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the Catalan, as he saw the final glimmer of\r\nCaderousse\xe2\x80\x99s reason vanishing before the last glass of wine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, I should say, for instance,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthat if\r\nafter a voyage such as Dant\xc3\xa8s has just made, in which he touched at the\r\nIsland of Elba, someone were to denounce him to the king\xe2\x80\x99s procureur as\r\na Bonapartist agent\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will denounce him!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the young man hastily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but they will make you then sign your declaration, and confront\r\nyou with him you have denounced; I will supply you with the means of\r\nsupporting your accusation, for I know the fact well. But Dant\xc3\xa8s cannot\r\nremain forever in prison, and one day or other he will leave it, and\r\nthe day when he comes out, woe betide him who was the cause of his\r\nincarceration!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I should wish nothing better than that he would come and seek a\r\nquarrel with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s! Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, who will detest you if you have only the\r\nmisfortune to scratch the skin of her dearly beloved Edmond!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue!\xe2\x80\x9d said Fernand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cif we resolve on such a step, it would\r\nbe much better to take, as I now do, this pen, dip it into this ink,\r\nand write with the left hand (that the writing may not be recognized)\r\nthe denunciation we propose.\xe2\x80\x9d And Danglars, uniting practice with\r\ntheory, wrote with his left hand, and in a writing reversed from his\r\nusual style, and totally unlike it, the following lines, which he\r\nhanded to Fernand, and which Fernand read in an undertone:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe honorable, the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney, is informed by a friend of the\r\nthrone and religion, that one Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s, mate of the ship\r\n_Pharaon_, arrived this morning from Smyrna, after having touched at\r\nNaples and Porto-Ferrajo, has been intrusted by Murat with a letter for\r\nthe usurper, and by the usurper with a letter for the Bonapartist\r\ncommittee in Paris. Proof of this crime will be found on arresting him,\r\nfor the letter will be found upon him, or at his father\xe2\x80\x99s, or in his\r\ncabin on board the _Pharaon_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cnow your revenge looks like common\r\nsense, for in no way can it revert to yourself, and the matter will\r\nthus work its own way; there is nothing to do now but fold the letter\r\nas I am doing, and write upon it, \xe2\x80\x98To the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney,\xe2\x80\x99 and that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nall settled.\xe2\x80\x9d And Danglars wrote the address as he spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and that\xe2\x80\x99s all settled!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Caderousse, who, by a last\r\neffort of intellect, had followed the reading of the letter, and\r\ninstinctively comprehended all the misery which such a denunciation\r\nmust entail. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, and that\xe2\x80\x99s all settled; only it will be an infamous\r\nshame;\xe2\x80\x9d and he stretched out his hand to reach the letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, taking it from beyond his reach; \xe2\x80\x9cand as what I\r\nsay and do is merely in jest, and I, amongst the first and foremost,\r\nshould be sorry if anything happened to Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x94the worthy Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x94look\r\nhere!\xe2\x80\x9d And taking the letter, he squeezed it up in his hands and threw\r\nit into a corner of the arbor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cDant\xc3\xa8s is my friend, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t have\r\nhim ill-used.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who thinks of using him ill? Certainly neither I nor Fernand,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Danglars, rising and looking at the young man, who still remained\r\nseated, but whose eye was fixed on the denunciatory sheet of paper\r\nflung into the corner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn this case,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9clet\xe2\x80\x99s have some more wine. I wish\r\nto drink to the health of Edmond and the lovely Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have had too much already, drunkard,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cand if you\r\ncontinue, you will be compelled to sleep here, because unable to stand\r\non your legs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, rising with all the offended dignity of a drunken\r\nman, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t keep on my legs? Why, I\xe2\x80\x99ll wager I can go up into the\r\nbelfry of the Accoules, and without staggering, too!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDone!\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take your bet; but tomorrow\xe2\x80\x94today it is\r\ntime to return. Give me your arm, and let us go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, let us go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I don\xe2\x80\x99t want your arm at\r\nall. Come, Fernand, won\xe2\x80\x99t you return to Marseilles with us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fernand; \xe2\x80\x9cI shall return to the Catalans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re wrong. Come with us to Marseilles\xe2\x80\x94come along.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean? you will not? Well, just as you like, my prince;\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s liberty for all the world. Come along, Danglars, and let the\r\nyoung gentleman return to the Catalans if he chooses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars took advantage of Caderousse\xe2\x80\x99s temper at the moment, to take\r\nhim off towards Marseilles by the Porte Saint-Victor, staggering as he\r\nwent.\r\n\r\nWhen they had advanced about twenty yards, Danglars looked back and saw\r\nFernand stoop, pick up the crumpled paper, and putting it into his\r\npocket then rush out of the arbor towards Pillon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy, what a lie he told! He said he was going\r\nto the Catalans, and he is going to the city. Hallo, Fernand! You are\r\ncoming, my boy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you don\xe2\x80\x99t see straight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s gone right by the\r\nroad to the Vieilles Infirmeries.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cI should have sworn that he turned to the\r\nright\xe2\x80\x94how treacherous wine is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cnow the thing is at work and\r\nit will effect its purpose unassisted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 5. The Marriage Feast\r\n\r\nThe morning\xe2\x80\x99s sun rose clear and resplendent, touching the foamy waves\r\ninto a network of ruby-tinted light.\r\n\r\nThe feast had been made ready on the second floor at La R\xc3\xa9serve, with\r\nwhose arbor the reader is already familiar. The apartment destined for\r\nthe purpose was spacious and lighted by a number of windows, over each\r\nof which was written in golden letters for some inexplicable reason the\r\nname of one of the principal cities of France; beneath these windows a\r\nwooden balcony extended the entire length of the house. And although\r\nthe entertainment was fixed for twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock, an hour previous to\r\nthat time the balcony was filled with impatient and expectant guests,\r\nconsisting of the favored part of the crew of the _Pharaon_, and other\r\npersonal friends of the bridegroom, the whole of whom had arrayed\r\nthemselves in their choicest costumes, in order to do greater honor to\r\nthe occasion.\r\n\r\nVarious rumors were afloat to the effect that the owners of the\r\n_Pharaon_ had promised to attend the nuptial feast; but all seemed\r\nunanimous in doubting that an act of such rare and exceeding\r\ncondescension could possibly be intended.\r\n\r\nDanglars, however, who now made his appearance, accompanied by\r\nCaderousse, effectually confirmed the report, stating that he had\r\nrecently conversed with M. Morrel, who had himself assured him of his\r\nintention to dine at La R\xc3\xa9serve.\r\n\r\nIn fact, a moment later M. Morrel appeared and was saluted with an\r\nenthusiastic burst of applause from the crew of the _Pharaon_, who\r\nhailed the visit of the shipowner as a sure indication that the man\r\nwhose wedding feast he thus delighted to honor would ere long be first\r\nin command of the ship; and as Dant\xc3\xa8s was universally beloved on board\r\nhis vessel, the sailors put no restraint on their tumultuous joy at\r\nfinding that the opinion and choice of their superiors so exactly\r\ncoincided with their own.\r\n\r\nWith the entrance of M. Morrel, Danglars and Caderousse were despatched\r\nin search of the bridegroom to convey to him the intelligence of the\r\narrival of the important personage whose coming had created such a\r\nlively sensation, and to beseech him to make haste.\r\n\r\nDanglars and Caderousse set off upon their errand at full speed; but\r\nere they had gone many steps they perceived a group advancing towards\r\nthem, composed of the betrothed pair, a party of young girls in\r\nattendance on the bride, by whose side walked Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 father; the whole\r\nbrought up by Fernand, whose lips wore their usual sinister smile.\r\n\r\nNeither Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s nor Edmond observed the strange expression of his\r\ncountenance; they were so happy that they were conscious only of the\r\nsunshine and the presence of each other.\r\n\r\nHaving acquitted themselves of their errand, and exchanged a hearty\r\nshake of the hand with Edmond, Danglars and Caderousse took their\r\nplaces beside Fernand and old Dant\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x94the latter of whom attracted\r\nuniversal notice.\r\n\r\nThe old man was attired in a suit of glistening watered silk, trimmed\r\nwith steel buttons, beautifully cut and polished. His thin but wiry\r\nlegs were arrayed in a pair of richly embroidered clocked stockings,\r\nevidently of English manufacture, while from his three-cornered hat\r\ndepended a long streaming knot of white and blue ribbons. Thus he came\r\nalong, supporting himself on a curiously carved stick, his aged\r\ncountenance lit up with happiness, looking for all the world like one\r\nof the aged dandies of 1796, parading the newly opened gardens of the\r\nLuxembourg and Tuileries.\r\n\r\nBeside him glided Caderousse, whose desire to partake of the good\r\nthings provided for the wedding party had induced him to become\r\nreconciled to the Dant\xc3\xa8s, father and son, although there still lingered\r\nin his mind a faint and unperfect recollection of the events of the\r\npreceding night; just as the brain retains on waking in the morning the\r\ndim and misty outline of a dream.\r\n\r\n0065m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAs Danglars approached the disappointed lover, he cast on him a look of\r\ndeep meaning, while Fernand, as he slowly paced behind the happy pair,\r\nwho seemed, in their own unmixed content, to have entirely forgotten\r\nthat such a being as himself existed, was pale and abstracted;\r\noccasionally, however, a deep flush would overspread his countenance,\r\nand a nervous contraction distort his features, while, with an agitated\r\nand restless gaze, he would glance in the direction of Marseilles, like\r\none who either anticipated or foresaw some great and important event.\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s himself was simply, but becomingly, clad in the dress peculiar\r\nto the merchant service\xe2\x80\x94a costume somewhat between a military and a\r\ncivil garb; and with his fine countenance, radiant with joy and\r\nhappiness, a more perfect specimen of manly beauty could scarcely be\r\nimagined.\r\n\r\nLovely as the Greek girls of Cyprus or Chios, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s boasted the same\r\nbright flashing eyes of jet, and ripe, round, coral lips. She moved\r\nwith the light, free step of an Arlesienne or an Andalusian. One more\r\npracticed in the arts of great cities would have hid her blushes\r\nbeneath a veil, or, at least, have cast down her thickly fringed\r\nlashes, so as to have concealed the liquid lustre of her animated eyes;\r\nbut, on the contrary, the delighted girl looked around her with a smile\r\nthat seemed to say: \xe2\x80\x9cIf you are my friends, rejoice with me, for I am\r\nvery happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs soon as the bridal party came in sight of La R\xc3\xa9serve, M. Morrel\r\ndescended and came forth to meet it, followed by the soldiers and\r\nsailors there assembled, to whom he had repeated the promise already\r\ngiven, that Dant\xc3\xa8s should be the successor to the late Captain Leclere.\r\nEdmond, at the approach of his patron, respectfully placed the arm of\r\nhis affianced bride within that of M. Morrel, who, forthwith conducting\r\nher up the flight of wooden steps leading to the chamber in which the\r\nfeast was prepared, was gayly followed by the guests, beneath whose\r\nheavy tread the slight structure creaked and groaned for the space of\r\nseveral minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather,\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, stopping when she had reached the centre of\r\nthe table, \xe2\x80\x9csit, I pray you, on my right hand; on my left I will place\r\nhim who has ever been as a brother to me,\xe2\x80\x9d pointing with a soft and\r\ngentle smile to Fernand; but her words and look seemed to inflict the\r\ndirest torture on him, for his lips became ghastly pale, and even\r\nbeneath the dark hue of his complexion the blood might be seen\r\nretreating as though some sudden pang drove it back to the heart.\r\n\r\nDuring this time, Dant\xc3\xa8s, at the opposite side of the table, had been\r\noccupied in similarly placing his most honored guests. M. Morrel was\r\nseated at his right hand, Danglars at his left; while, at a sign from\r\nEdmond, the rest of the company ranged themselves as they found it most\r\nagreeable.\r\n\r\nThen they began to pass around the dusky, piquant, Arlesian sausages,\r\nand lobsters in their dazzling red cuirasses, prawns of large size and\r\nbrilliant color, the echinus with its prickly outside and dainty morsel\r\nwithin, the clovis, esteemed by the epicures of the South as more than\r\nrivalling the exquisite flavor of the oyster, North. All the\r\ndelicacies, in fact, that are cast up by the wash of waters on the\r\nsandy beach, and styled by the grateful fishermen \xe2\x80\x9cfruits of the sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA pretty silence truly!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old father of the bridegroom, as he\r\ncarried to his lips a glass of wine of the hue and brightness of the\r\ntopaz, and which had just been placed before Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s herself. \xe2\x80\x9cNow,\r\nwould anybody think that this room contained a happy, merry party, who\r\ndesire nothing better than to laugh and dance the hours away?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d sighed Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9ca man cannot always feel happy because he is\r\nabout to be married.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe truth is,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I am too happy for noisy mirth;\r\nif that is what you meant by your observation, my worthy friend, you\r\nare right; joy takes a strange effect at times, it seems to oppress us\r\nalmost the same as sorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars looked towards Fernand, whose excitable nature received and\r\nbetrayed each fresh impression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what ails you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he of Edmond. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you fear any approaching\r\nevil? I should say that you were the happiest man alive at this\r\ninstant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that is the very thing that alarms me,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Dant\xc3\xa8s. \xe2\x80\x9cMan does\r\nnot appear to me to be intended to enjoy felicity so unmixed; happiness\r\nis like the enchanted palaces we read of in our childhood, where\r\nfierce, fiery dragons defend the entrance and approach; and monsters of\r\nall shapes and kinds, requiring to be overcome ere victory is ours. I\r\nown that I am lost in wonder to find myself promoted to an honor of\r\nwhich I feel myself unworthy\xe2\x80\x94that of being the husband of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, nay!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Caderousse, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have not attained that\r\nhonor yet. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s is not yet your wife. Just assume the tone and\r\nmanner of a husband, and see how she will remind you that your hour is\r\nnot yet come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe bride blushed, while Fernand, restless and uneasy, seemed to start\r\nat every fresh sound, and from time to time wiped away the large drops\r\nof perspiration that gathered on his brow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, never mind that, neighbor Caderousse; it is not worthwhile to\r\ncontradict me for such a trifle as that. \xe2\x80\x99Tis true that Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s is not\r\nactually my wife; but,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, drawing out his watch, \xe2\x80\x9cin an hour\r\nand a half she will be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA general exclamation of surprise ran round the table, with the\r\nexception of the elder Dant\xc3\xa8s, whose laugh displayed the still perfect\r\nbeauty of his large white teeth. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s looked pleased and gratified,\r\nwhile Fernand grasped the handle of his knife with a convulsive clutch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn an hour?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Danglars, turning pale. \xe2\x80\x9cHow is that, my\r\nfriend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, thus it is,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s. \xe2\x80\x9cThanks to the influence of M.\r\nMorrel, to whom, next to my father, I owe every blessing I enjoy, every\r\ndifficulty has been removed. We have purchased permission to waive the\r\nusual delay; and at half-past two o\xe2\x80\x99clock the Mayor of Marseilles will\r\nbe waiting for us at the city hall. Now, as a quarter-past one has\r\nalready struck, I do not consider I have asserted too much in saying,\r\nthat, in another hour and thirty minutes Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s will have become\r\nMadame Dant\xc3\xa8s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0069m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFernand closed his eyes, a burning sensation passed across his brow,\r\nand he was compelled to support himself by the table to prevent his\r\nfalling from his chair; but in spite of all his efforts, he could not\r\nrefrain from uttering a deep groan, which, however, was lost amid the\r\nnoisy felicitations of the company.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the old man, \xe2\x80\x9cyou make short work of this kind of\r\naffair. Arrived here only yesterday morning, and married today at three\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock! Commend me to a sailor for going the quick way to work!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Danglars, in a timid tone, \xe2\x80\x9chow did you manage about the\r\nother formalities\xe2\x80\x94the contract\xe2\x80\x94the settlement?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe contract,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Dant\xc3\xa8s, laughingly, \xe2\x80\x9cit didn\xe2\x80\x99t take long to\r\nfix that. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s has no fortune; I have none to settle on her. So,\r\nyou see, our papers were quickly written out, and certainly do not come\r\nvery expensive.\xe2\x80\x9d This joke elicited a fresh burst of applause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that what we presumed to be merely the betrothal feast turns out to\r\nbe the actual wedding dinner!\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Dant\xc3\xa8s; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t imagine I am going to put you off in\r\nthat shabby manner. Tomorrow morning I start for Paris; four days to\r\ngo, and the same to return, with one day to discharge the commission\r\nentrusted to me, is all the time I shall be absent. I shall be back\r\nhere by the first of March, and on the second I give my real marriage\r\nfeast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis prospect of fresh festivity redoubled the hilarity of the guests\r\nto such a degree, that the elder Dant\xc3\xa8s, who, at the commencement of\r\nthe repast, had commented upon the silence that prevailed, now found it\r\ndifficult, amid the general din of voices, to obtain a moment\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntranquillity in which to drink to the health and prosperity of the\r\nbride and bridegroom.\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s, perceiving the affectionate eagerness of his father, responded\r\nby a look of grateful pleasure; while Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s glanced at the clock and\r\nmade an expressive gesture to Edmond.\r\n\r\nAround the table reigned that noisy hilarity which usually prevails at\r\nsuch a time among people sufficiently free from the demands of social\r\nposition not to feel the trammels of etiquette. Such as at the\r\ncommencement of the repast had not been able to seat themselves\r\naccording to their inclination rose unceremoniously, and sought out\r\nmore agreeable companions. Everybody talked at once, without waiting\r\nfor a reply and each one seemed to be contented with expressing his or\r\nher own thoughts.\r\n\r\nFernand\xe2\x80\x99s paleness appeared to have communicated itself to Danglars. As\r\nfor Fernand himself, he seemed to be enduring the tortures of the\r\ndamned; unable to rest, he was among the first to quit the table, and,\r\nas though seeking to avoid the hilarious mirth that rose in such\r\ndeafening sounds, he continued, in utter silence, to pace the farther\r\nend of the salon.\r\n\r\nCaderousse approached him just as Danglars, whom Fernand seemed most\r\nanxious to avoid, had joined him in a corner of the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, from whose mind the friendly treatment\r\nof Dant\xc3\xa8s, united with the effect of the excellent wine he had partaken\r\nof, had effaced every feeling of envy or jealousy at Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 good\r\nfortune,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cupon my word, Dant\xc3\xa8s is a downright good fellow, and when I\r\nsee him sitting there beside his pretty wife that is so soon to be. I\r\ncannot help thinking it would have been a great pity to have served him\r\nthat trick you were planning yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, there was no harm meant,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cat first I certainly\r\ndid feel somewhat uneasy as to what Fernand might be tempted to do; but\r\nwhen I saw how completely he had mastered his feelings, even so far as\r\nto become one of his rival\xe2\x80\x99s attendants, I knew there was no further\r\ncause for apprehension.\xe2\x80\x9d Caderousse looked full at Fernand\xe2\x80\x94he was\r\nghastly pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthe sacrifice was no trifling one,\r\nwhen the beauty of the bride is concerned. Upon my soul, that future\r\ncaptain of mine is a lucky dog! Gad! I only wish he would let me take\r\nhis place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we not set forth?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sweet, silvery voice of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ctwo o\xe2\x80\x99clock has just struck, and you know we are expected in a quarter\r\nof an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0071m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure!\xe2\x80\x94to be sure!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Dant\xc3\xa8s, eagerly quitting the table;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clet us go directly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis words were re-echoed by the whole party, with vociferous cheers.\r\n\r\nAt this moment Danglars, who had been incessantly observing every\r\nchange in Fernand\xe2\x80\x99s look and manner, saw him stagger and fall back,\r\nwith an almost convulsive spasm, against a seat placed near one of the\r\nopen windows. At the same instant his ear caught a sort of indistinct\r\nsound on the stairs, followed by the measured tread of soldiery, with\r\nthe clanking of swords and military accoutrements; then came a hum and\r\nbuzz as of many voices, so as to deaden even the noisy mirth of the\r\nbridal party, among whom a vague feeling of curiosity and apprehension\r\nquelled every disposition to talk, and almost instantaneously the most\r\ndeathlike stillness prevailed.\r\n\r\nThe sounds drew nearer. Three blows were struck upon the panel of the\r\ndoor. The company looked at each other in consternation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI demand admittance,\xe2\x80\x9d said a loud voice outside the room, \xe2\x80\x9cin the name\r\nof the law!\xe2\x80\x9d As no attempt was made to prevent it, the door was opened,\r\nand a magistrate, wearing his official scarf, presented himself,\r\nfollowed by four soldiers and a corporal. Uneasiness now yielded to the\r\nmost extreme dread on the part of those present.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I venture to inquire the reason of this unexpected visit?\xe2\x80\x9d said M.\r\nMorrel, addressing the magistrate, whom he evidently knew; \xe2\x80\x9cthere is\r\ndoubtless some mistake easily explained.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it be so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the magistrate, \xe2\x80\x9crely upon every reparation\r\nbeing made; meanwhile, I am the bearer of an order of arrest, and\r\nalthough I most reluctantly perform the task assigned me, it must,\r\nnevertheless, be fulfilled. Who among the persons here assembled\r\nanswers to the name of Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEvery eye was turned towards the young man who, spite of the agitation\r\nhe could not but feel, advanced with dignity, and said, in a firm\r\nvoice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am he; what is your pleasure with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdmond Dant\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the magistrate, \xe2\x80\x9cI arrest you in the name of\r\nthe law!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Edmond, slightly changing color, \xe2\x80\x9cand wherefore, I\r\npray?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot inform you, but you will be duly acquainted with the reasons\r\nthat have rendered such a step necessary at the preliminary\r\nexamination.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. Morrel felt that further resistance or remonstrance was useless. He\r\nsaw before him an officer delegated to enforce the law, and perfectly\r\nwell knew that it would be as unavailing to seek pity from a magistrate\r\ndecked with his official scarf, as to address a petition to some cold\r\nmarble effigy. Old Dant\xc3\xa8s, however, sprang forward. There are\r\nsituations which the heart of a father or a mother cannot be made to\r\nunderstand. He prayed and supplicated in terms so moving, that even the\r\nofficer was touched, and, although firm in his duty, he kindly said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy worthy friend, let me beg of you to calm your apprehensions. Your\r\nson has probably neglected some prescribed form or attention in\r\nregistering his cargo, and it is more than probable he will be set at\r\nliberty directly he has given the information required, whether\r\ntouching the health of his crew, or the value of his freight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the meaning of all this?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Caderousse, frowningly, of\r\nDanglars, who had assumed an air of utter surprise.\r\n\r\n0073m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I tell you?\xe2\x80\x9d replied he; \xe2\x80\x9cI am, like yourself, utterly\r\nbewildered at all that is going on, and cannot in the least make out\r\nwhat it is about.\xe2\x80\x9d Caderousse then looked around for Fernand, but he\r\nhad disappeared.\r\n\r\nThe scene of the previous night now came back to his mind with\r\nstartling clearness. The painful catastrophe he had just witnessed\r\nappeared effectually to have rent away the veil which the intoxication\r\nof the evening before had raised between himself and his memory.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, so,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in a hoarse and choking voice, to Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthis,\r\nthen, I suppose, is a part of the trick you were concerting yesterday?\r\nAll I can say is, that if it be so, \xe2\x80\x99tis an ill turn, and well deserves\r\nto bring double evil on those who have projected it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI tell you again I have nothing\r\nwhatever to do with it; besides, you know very well that I tore the\r\npaper to pieces.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you did not!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cyou merely threw it by\xe2\x80\x94I saw\r\nit lying in a corner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, you fool!\xe2\x80\x94what should you know about it?\xe2\x80\x94why, you\r\nwere drunk!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is Fernand?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do I know?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cgone, as every prudent man ought to\r\nbe, to look after his own affairs, most likely. Never mind where he is,\r\nlet you and I go and see what is to be done for our poor friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDuring this conversation, Dant\xc3\xa8s, after having exchanged a cheerful\r\nshake of the hand with all his sympathizing friends, had surrendered\r\nhimself to the officer sent to arrest him, merely saying, \xe2\x80\x9cMake\r\nyourselves quite easy, my good fellows, there is some little mistake to\r\nclear up, that\xe2\x80\x99s all, depend upon it; and very likely I may not have to\r\ngo so far as the prison to effect that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0075m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, to be sure!\xe2\x80\x9d responded Danglars, who had now approached the group,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnothing more than a mistake, I feel quite certain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s descended the staircase, preceded by the magistrate, and\r\nfollowed by the soldiers. A carriage awaited him at the door; he got\r\nin, followed by two soldiers and the magistrate, and the vehicle drove\r\noff towards Marseilles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, adieu, dearest Edmond!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, stretching out her arms\r\nto him from the balcony.\r\n\r\nThe prisoner heard the cry, which sounded like the sob of a broken\r\nheart, and leaning from the coach he called out, \xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x94we\r\nshall soon meet again!\xe2\x80\x9d Then the vehicle disappeared round one of the\r\nturnings of Fort Saint Nicholas.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait for me here, all of you!\xe2\x80\x9d cried M. Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cI will take the first\r\nconveyance I find, and hurry to Marseilles, whence I will bring you\r\nword how all is going on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed a multitude of voices, \xe2\x80\x9cgo, and return as\r\nquickly as you can!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis second departure was followed by a long and fearful state of\r\nterrified silence on the part of those who were left behind. The old\r\nfather and Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s remained for some time apart, each absorbed in\r\ngrief; but at length the two poor victims of the same blow raised their\r\neyes, and with a simultaneous burst of feeling rushed into each other\xe2\x80\x99s\r\narms.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile Fernand made his appearance, poured out for himself a glass\r\nof water with a trembling hand; then hastily swallowing it, went to sit\r\ndown at the first vacant place, and this was, by mere chance, placed\r\nnext to the seat on which poor Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s had fallen half fainting, when\r\nreleased from the warm and affectionate embrace of old Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\nInstinctively Fernand drew back his chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is the cause of all this misery\xe2\x80\x94I am quite sure of it,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered\r\nCaderousse, who had never taken his eyes off Fernand, to Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the other; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s too stupid to imagine\r\nsuch a scheme. I only hope the mischief will fall upon the head of\r\nwhoever wrought it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t mention those who aided and abetted the deed,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCaderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cone cannot be held responsible for every\r\nchance arrow shot into the air.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can, indeed, when the arrow lights point downward on somebody\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMeantime the subject of the arrest was being canvassed in every\r\ndifferent form.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat think you, Danglars,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the party, turning towards him,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cof this event?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, \xe2\x80\x9cI think it just possible Dant\xc3\xa8s may have been\r\ndetected with some trifling article on board ship considered here as\r\ncontraband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how could he have done so without your knowledge, Danglars, since\r\nyou are the ship\xe2\x80\x99s supercargo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, as for that, I could only know what I was told respecting the\r\nmerchandise with which the vessel was laden. I know she was loaded with\r\ncotton, and that she took in her freight at Alexandria from Pastret\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwarehouse, and at Smyrna from Pascal\xe2\x80\x99s; that is all I was obliged to\r\nknow, and I beg I may not be asked for any further particulars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I recollect,\xe2\x80\x9d said the afflicted old father; \xe2\x80\x9cmy poor boy told me\r\nyesterday he had got a small case of coffee, and another of tobacco for\r\nme!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, you see,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Danglars. \xe2\x80\x9cNow the mischief is out; depend\r\nupon it the custom-house people went rummaging about the ship in our\r\nabsence, and discovered poor Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 hidden treasures.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, however, paid no heed to this explanation of her lover\xe2\x80\x99s\r\narrest. Her grief, which she had hitherto tried to restrain, now burst\r\nout in a violent fit of hysterical sobbing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man, \xe2\x80\x9cbe comforted, my poor child; there is\r\nstill hope!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHope!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHope!\xe2\x80\x9d faintly murmured Fernand, but the word seemed to die away on\r\nhis pale agitated lips, and a convulsive spasm passed over his\r\ncountenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood news! good news!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted forth one of the party stationed in the\r\nbalcony on the lookout. \xe2\x80\x9cHere comes M. Morrel back. No doubt, now, we\r\nshall hear that our friend is released!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s and the old man rushed to meet the shipowner and greeted him\r\nat the door. He was very pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat news?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed a general burst of voices.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. Morrel, with a mournful shake of his\r\nhead, \xe2\x80\x9cthe thing has assumed a more serious aspect than I expected.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, indeed\xe2\x80\x94indeed, sir, he is innocent!\xe2\x80\x9d sobbed forth Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I believe!\xe2\x80\x9d answered M. Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cbut still he is charged\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith what?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the elder Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith being an agent of the Bonapartist faction!\xe2\x80\x9d Many of our readers\r\nmay be able to recollect how formidable such an accusation became in\r\nthe period at which our story is dated.\r\n\r\nA despairing cry escaped the pale lips of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s; the old man sank\r\ninto a chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Danglars!\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have deceived me\xe2\x80\x94the trick\r\nyou spoke of last night has been played; but I cannot suffer a poor old\r\nman or an innocent girl to die of grief through your fault. I am\r\ndetermined to tell them all about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe silent, you simpleton!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Danglars, grasping him by the arm,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cor I will not answer even for your own safety. Who can tell whether\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s be innocent or guilty? The vessel did touch at Elba, where he\r\nquitted it, and passed a whole day in the island. Now, should any\r\nletters or other documents of a compromising character be found upon\r\nhim, will it not be taken for granted that all who uphold him are his\r\naccomplices?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith the rapid instinct of selfishness, Caderousse readily perceived\r\nthe solidity of this mode of reasoning; he gazed, doubtfully,\r\nwistfully, on Danglars, and then caution supplanted generosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose we wait a while, and see what comes of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, casting a\r\nbewildered look on his companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Danglars. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us wait, by all means. If he be\r\ninnocent, of course he will be set at liberty; if guilty, why, it is no\r\nuse involving ourselves in a conspiracy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go, then. I cannot stay here any longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith all my heart!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars, pleased to find the other so\r\ntractable. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us take ourselves out of the way, and leave things for\r\nthe present to take their course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter their departure, Fernand, who had now again become the friend and\r\nprotector of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, led the girl to her home, while some friends of\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s conducted his father, nearly lifeless, to the All\xc3\xa9es de Meilhan.\r\n\r\nThe rumor of Edmond\xe2\x80\x99s arrest as a Bonapartist agent was not slow in\r\ncirculating throughout the city.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCould you ever have credited such a thing, my dear Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d asked M.\r\nMorrel, as, on his return to the port for the purpose of gleaning fresh\r\ntidings of Dant\xc3\xa8s, from M. de Villefort, the assistant procureur, he\r\novertook his supercargo and Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cCould you have believed such a\r\nthing possible?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you know I told you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I considered the\r\ncircumstance of his having anchored at the Island of Elba as a very\r\nsuspicious circumstance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did you mention these suspicions to any person beside myself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0079m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not!\xe2\x80\x9d returned Danglars. Then added in a low whisper, \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nunderstand that, on account of your uncle, M. Policar Morrel, who\r\nserved under the _other_ government, and who does not altogether\r\nconceal what he thinks on the subject, you are strongly suspected of\r\nregretting the abdication of Napoleon. I should have feared to injure\r\nboth Edmond and yourself, had I divulged my own apprehensions to a\r\nsoul. I am too well aware that though a subordinate, like myself, is\r\nbound to acquaint the shipowner with everything that occurs, there are\r\nmany things he ought most carefully to conceal from all else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis well, Danglars\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99tis well!\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. Morrel. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are a worthy\r\nfellow; and I had already thought of your interests in the event of\r\npoor Edmond having become captain of the _Pharaon_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible you were so kind?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed; I had previously inquired of Dant\xc3\xa8s what was his opinion\r\nof you, and if he should have any reluctance to continue you in your\r\npost, for somehow I have perceived a sort of coolness between you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what was his reply?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat he certainly did think he had given you offence in an affair\r\nwhich he merely referred to without entering into particulars, but that\r\nwhoever possessed the good opinion and confidence of the ship\xe2\x80\x99s owners\r\nwould have his preference also.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe hypocrite!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Dant\xc3\xa8s!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cNo one can deny his being a\r\nnoble-hearted young fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut meanwhile,\xe2\x80\x9d continued M. Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9chere is the _Pharaon_ without a\r\ncaptain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9csince we cannot leave this port for the next\r\nthree months, let us hope that ere the expiration of that period Dant\xc3\xa8s\r\nwill be set at liberty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt; but in the meantime?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am entirely at your service, M. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Danglars. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nknow that I am as capable of managing a ship as the most experienced\r\ncaptain in the service; and it will be so far advantageous to you to\r\naccept my services, that upon Edmond\xe2\x80\x99s release from prison no further\r\nchange will be requisite on board the _Pharaon_ than for Dant\xc3\xa8s and\r\nmyself each to resume our respective posts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, Danglars\xe2\x80\x94that will smooth over all difficulties. I fully\r\nauthorize you at once to assume the command of the _Pharaon_, and look\r\ncarefully to the unloading of her freight. Private misfortunes must\r\nnever be allowed to interfere with business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe easy on that score, M. Morrel; but do you think we shall be\r\npermitted to see our poor Edmond?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will let you know that directly I have seen M. de Villefort, whom I\r\nshall endeavor to interest in Edmond\xe2\x80\x99s favor. I am aware he is a\r\nfurious royalist; but, in spite of that, and of his being king\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattorney, he is a man like ourselves, and I fancy not a bad sort of\r\none.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I hear that he is ambitious, and\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s rather against him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d returned M. Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall see. But now hasten on\r\nboard, I will join you there ere long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, the worthy shipowner quitted the two allies, and proceeded\r\nin the direction of the Palais de Justice.\r\n\r\n0081m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, addressing Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cthe turn things have\r\ntaken. Do you still feel any desire to stand up in his defence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot the slightest, but yet it seems to me a shocking thing that a mere\r\njoke should lead to such consequences.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who perpetrated that joke, let me ask? neither you nor myself, but\r\nFernand; you knew very well that I threw the paper into a corner of the\r\nroom\xe2\x80\x94indeed, I fancied I had destroyed it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I can answer for, you did not. I\r\nonly wish I could see it now as plainly as I saw it lying all crushed\r\nand crumpled in a corner of the arbor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, if you did, depend upon it, Fernand picked it up, and\r\neither copied it or caused it to be copied; perhaps, even, he did not\r\ntake the trouble of recopying it. And now I think of it, by Heavens, he\r\nmay have sent the letter itself! Fortunately, for me, the handwriting\r\nwas disguised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you were aware of Dant\xc3\xa8s being engaged in a conspiracy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot I. As I before said, I thought the whole thing was a joke, nothing\r\nmore. It seems, however, that I have unconsciously stumbled upon the\r\ntruth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill,\xe2\x80\x9d argued Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cI would give a great deal if nothing of\r\nthe kind had happened; or, at least, that I had had no hand in it. You\r\nwill see, Danglars, that it will turn out an unlucky job for both of\r\nus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense! If any harm come of it, it should fall on the guilty person;\r\nand that, you know, is Fernand. How can we be implicated in any way?\r\nAll we have got to do is, to keep our own counsel, and remain perfectly\r\nquiet, not breathing a word to any living soul; and you will see that\r\nthe storm will pass away without in the least affecting us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen!\xe2\x80\x9d responded Caderousse, waving his hand in token of adieu to\r\nDanglars, and bending his steps towards the All\xc3\xa9es de Meilhan, moving\r\nhis head to and fro, and muttering as he went, after the manner of one\r\nwhose mind was overcharged with one absorbing idea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo far, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, mentally, \xe2\x80\x9call has gone as I would have\r\nit. I am, temporarily, commander of the _Pharaon_, with the certainty\r\nof being permanently so, if that fool of a Caderousse can be persuaded\r\nto hold his tongue. My only fear is the chance of Dant\xc3\xa8s being\r\nreleased. But, there, he is in the hands of Justice; and,\xe2\x80\x9d added he\r\nwith a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cshe will take her own.\xe2\x80\x9d So saying, he leaped into a\r\nboat, desiring to be rowed on board the _Pharaon_, where M. Morrel had\r\nagreed to meet him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 6. The Deputy Procureur du Roi\r\n\r\nIn one of the aristocratic mansions built by Puget in the Rue du Grand\r\nCours opposite the Medusa fountain, a second marriage feast was being\r\ncelebrated, almost at the same hour with the nuptial repast given by\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s. In this case, however, although the occasion of the\r\nentertainment was similar, the company was strikingly dissimilar.\r\nInstead of a rude mixture of sailors, soldiers, and those belonging to\r\nthe humblest grade of life, the present assembly was composed of the\r\nvery flower of Marseilles society,\xe2\x80\x94magistrates who had resigned their\r\noffice during the usurper\xe2\x80\x99s reign; officers who had deserted from the\r\nimperial army and joined forces with Cond\xc3\xa9; and younger members of\r\nfamilies, brought up to hate and execrate the man whom five years of\r\nexile would convert into a martyr, and fifteen of restoration elevate\r\nto the rank of a god.\r\n\r\nThe guests were still at table, and the heated and energetic\r\nconversation that prevailed betrayed the violent and vindictive\r\npassions that then agitated each dweller of the South, where unhappily,\r\nfor five centuries religious strife had long given increased bitterness\r\nto the violence of party feeling.\r\n\r\nThe emperor, now king of the petty Island of Elba, after having held\r\nsovereign sway over one-half of the world, counting as his subjects a\r\nsmall population of five or six thousand souls,\xe2\x80\x94after having been\r\naccustomed to hear the \xe2\x80\x9c_Vive Napol\xc3\xa9ons_\xe2\x80\x9d of a hundred and twenty\r\nmillions of human beings, uttered in ten different languages,\xe2\x80\x94was\r\nlooked upon here as a ruined man, separated forever from any fresh\r\nconnection with France or claim to her throne.\r\n\r\nThe magistrates freely discussed their political views; the military\r\npart of the company talked unreservedly of Moscow and Leipsic, while\r\nthe women commented on the divorce of Josephine. It was not over the\r\ndownfall of the man, but over the defeat of the Napoleonic idea, that\r\nthey rejoiced, and in this they foresaw for themselves the bright and\r\ncheering prospect of a revivified political existence.\r\n\r\nAn old man, decorated with the cross of Saint Louis, now rose and\r\nproposed the health of King Louis XVIII. It was the Marquis de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran. This toast, recalling at once the patient exile of\r\nHartwell and the peace-loving King of France, excited universal\r\nenthusiasm; glasses were elevated in the air _\xc3\xa0 l\xe2\x80\x99Anglaise_, and the\r\nladies, snatching their bouquets from their fair bosoms, strewed the\r\ntable with their floral treasures. In a word, an almost poetical fervor\r\nprevailed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Marquise de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, a woman with a stern,\r\nforbidding eye, though still noble and distinguished in appearance,\r\ndespite her fifty years\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cah, these revolutionists, who have driven us\r\nfrom those very possessions they afterwards purchased for a mere trifle\r\nduring the Reign of Terror, would be compelled to own, were they here,\r\nthat all true devotion was on our side, since we were content to follow\r\nthe fortunes of a falling monarch, while they, on the contrary, made\r\ntheir fortune by worshipping the rising sun; yes, yes, they could not\r\nhelp admitting that the king, for whom we sacrificed rank, wealth, and\r\nstation was truly our \xe2\x80\x98Louis the well-beloved,\xe2\x80\x99 while their wretched\r\nusurper has been, and ever will be, to them their evil genius, their\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Napoleon the accursed.\xe2\x80\x99 Am I not right, Villefort?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, madame. I really must pray you to excuse me, but\xe2\x80\x94in\r\ntruth\xe2\x80\x94I was not attending to the conversation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarquise, marquise!\xe2\x80\x9d interposed the old nobleman who had proposed the\r\ntoast, \xe2\x80\x9clet the young people alone; let me tell you, on one\xe2\x80\x99s wedding\r\nday there are more agreeable subjects of conversation than dry\r\npolitics.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind, dearest mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said a young and lovely girl, with a\r\nprofusion of light brown hair, and eyes that seemed to float in liquid\r\ncrystal, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99tis all my fault for seizing upon M. de Villefort, so as to\r\nprevent his listening to what you said. But there\xe2\x80\x94now take him\xe2\x80\x94he is\r\nyour own for as long as you like. M. Villefort, I beg to remind you my\r\nmother speaks to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf the marquise will deign to repeat the words I but imperfectly\r\ncaught, I shall be delighted to answer,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind, Ren\xc3\xa9e,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the marquise, with a look of tenderness\r\nthat seemed out of keeping with her harsh dry features; but, however\r\nall other feelings may be withered in a woman\xe2\x80\x99s nature, there is always\r\none bright smiling spot in the desert of her heart, and that is the\r\nshrine of maternal love. \xe2\x80\x9cI forgive you. What I was saying, Villefort,\r\nwas, that the Bonapartists had not our sincerity, enthusiasm, or\r\ndevotion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey had, however, what supplied the place of those fine qualities,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cand that was fanaticism. Napoleon is the\r\nMahomet of the West, and is worshipped by his commonplace but ambitious\r\nfollowers, not only as a leader and lawgiver, but also as the\r\npersonification of equality.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the marquise: \xe2\x80\x9cNapoleon the type of equality! For mercy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsake, then, what would you call Robespierre? Come, come, do not strip\r\nthe latter of his just rights to bestow them on the Corsican, who, to\r\nmy mind, has usurped quite enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0085m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, madame; I would place each of these heroes on his right\r\npedestal\xe2\x80\x94that of Robespierre on his scaffold in the Place Louis Quinze;\r\nthat of Napoleon on the column of the Place Vend\xc3\xb4me. The only\r\ndifference consists in the opposite character of the equality advocated\r\nby these two men; one is the equality that elevates, the other is the\r\nequality that degrades; one brings a king within reach of the\r\nguillotine, the other elevates the people to a level with the throne.\r\nObserve,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not mean to deny that both\r\nthese men were revolutionary scoundrels, and that the 9th Thermidor and\r\nthe 4th of April, in the year 1814, were lucky days for France, worthy\r\nof being gratefully remembered by every friend to monarchy and civil\r\norder; and that explains how it comes to pass that, fallen, as I trust\r\nhe is forever, Napoleon has still retained a train of parasitical\r\nsatellites. Still, marquise, it has been so with other\r\nusurpers\xe2\x80\x94Cromwell, for instance, who was not half so bad as Napoleon,\r\nhad his partisans and advocates.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, Villefort, that you are talking in a most dreadfully\r\nrevolutionary strain? But I excuse it, it is impossible to expect the\r\nson of a Girondin to be free from a small spice of the old leaven.\xe2\x80\x9d A\r\ndeep crimson suffused the countenance of Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis true, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d answered he, \xe2\x80\x9cthat my father was a Girondin, but\r\nhe was not among the number of those who voted for the king\xe2\x80\x99s death; he\r\nwas an equal sufferer with yourself during the Reign of Terror, and had\r\nwell-nigh lost his head on the same scaffold on which your father\r\nperished.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the marquise, without wincing in the slightest degree\r\nat the tragic remembrance thus called up; \xe2\x80\x9cbut bear in mind, if you\r\nplease, that our respective parents underwent persecution and\r\nproscription from diametrically opposite principles; in proof of which\r\nI may remark, that while my family remained among the staunchest\r\nadherents of the exiled princes, your father lost no time in joining\r\nthe new government; and that while the Citizen Noirtier was a Girondin,\r\nthe Count Noirtier became a senator.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear mother,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Ren\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know very well it was agreed that\r\nall these disagreeable reminiscences should forever be laid aside.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuffer me, also, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cto add my earnest\r\nrequest to Mademoiselle de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s, that you will kindly allow\r\nthe veil of oblivion to cover and conceal the past. What avails\r\nrecrimination over matters wholly past recall? For my own part, I have\r\nlaid aside even the name of my father, and altogether disown his\r\npolitical principles. He was\xe2\x80\x94nay, probably may still be\xe2\x80\x94a Bonapartist,\r\nand is called Noirtier; I, on the contrary, am a staunch royalist, and\r\nstyle myself de Villefort. Let what may remain of revolutionary sap\r\nexhaust itself and die away with the old trunk, and condescend only to\r\nregard the young shoot which has started up at a distance from the\r\nparent tree, without having the power, any more than the wish, to\r\nseparate entirely from the stock from which it sprung.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo, Villefort!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the marquis; \xe2\x80\x9cexcellently well said! Come,\r\nnow, I have hopes of obtaining what I have been for years endeavoring\r\nto persuade the marquise to promise; namely, a perfect amnesty and\r\nforgetfulness of the past.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith all my heart,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the marquise; \xe2\x80\x9clet the past be forever\r\nforgotten. I promise you it affords _me_ as little pleasure to revive\r\nit as it does you. All I ask is, that Villefort will be firm and\r\ninflexible for the future in his political principles. Remember, also,\r\nVillefort, that we have pledged ourselves to his majesty for your\r\nfealty and strict loyalty, and that at our recommendation the king\r\nconsented to forget the past, as I do\xe2\x80\x9d (and here she extended to him\r\nher hand)\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cas I now do at your entreaty. But bear in mind, that should\r\nthere fall in your way anyone guilty of conspiring against the\r\ngovernment, you will be so much the more bound to visit the offence\r\nwith rigorous punishment, as it is known you belong to a suspected\r\nfamily.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cmy profession, as well as the\r\ntimes in which we live, compels me to be severe. I have already\r\nsuccessfully conducted several public prosecutions, and brought the\r\noffenders to merited punishment. But we have not done with the thing\r\nyet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0087m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you, indeed, think so?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the marquise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am, at least, fearful of it. Napoleon, in the Island of Elba, is too\r\nnear France, and his proximity keeps up the hopes of his partisans.\r\nMarseilles is filled with half-pay officers, who are daily, under one\r\nfrivolous pretext or other, getting up quarrels with the royalists;\r\nfrom hence arise continual and fatal duels among the higher classes of\r\npersons, and assassinations in the lower.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have heard, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Comte de Salvieux, one of M. de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s oldest friends, and chamberlain to the Comte d\xe2\x80\x99Artois,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat the Holy Alliance purpose removing him from thence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; they were talking about it when we left Paris,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran; \xe2\x80\x9cand where is it decided to transfer him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Saint Helena.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake, where is that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the marquise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn island situated on the other side of the equator, at least two\r\nthousand leagues from here,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better. As Villefort observes, it is a great act of folly\r\nto have left such a man between Corsica, where he was born, and Naples,\r\nof which his brother-in-law is king, and face to face with Italy, the\r\nsovereignty of which he coveted for his son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnfortunately,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthere are the treaties of 1814, and\r\nwe cannot molest Napoleon without breaking those compacts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, well, we shall find some way out of it,\xe2\x80\x9d responded M. de Salvieux.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere wasn\xe2\x80\x99t any trouble over treaties when it was a question of\r\nshooting the poor Duc d\xe2\x80\x99Enghien.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the marquise, \xe2\x80\x9cit seems probable that, by the aid of the\r\nHoly Alliance, we shall be rid of Napoleon; and we must trust to the\r\nvigilance of M. de Villefort to purify Marseilles of his partisans. The\r\nking is either a king or no king; if he be acknowledged as sovereign of\r\nFrance, he should be upheld in peace and tranquillity; and this can\r\nbest be effected by employing the most inflexible agents to put down\r\nevery attempt at conspiracy\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99tis the best and surest means of\r\npreventing mischief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnfortunately, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthe strong arm of the law\r\nis not called upon to interfere until the evil has taken place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen all he has got to do is to endeavor to repair it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, madame, the law is frequently powerless to effect this; all it\r\ncan do is to avenge the wrong done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, M. de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d cried a beautiful young creature, daughter to\r\nthe Comte de Salvieux, and the cherished friend of Mademoiselle de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran, \xe2\x80\x9cdo try and get up some famous trial while we are at\r\nMarseilles. I never was in a law-court; I am told it is so very\r\namusing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmusing, certainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cinasmuch as, instead of\r\nshedding tears as at the fictitious tale of woe produced at a theatre,\r\nyou behold in a law-court a case of real and genuine distress\xe2\x80\x94a drama\r\nof life. The prisoner whom you there see pale, agitated, and alarmed,\r\ninstead of\xe2\x80\x94as is the case when a curtain falls on a tragedy\xe2\x80\x94going home\r\nto sup peacefully with his family, and then retiring to rest, that he\r\nmay recommence his mimic woes on the morrow,\xe2\x80\x94is removed from your sight\r\nmerely to be reconducted to his prison and delivered up to the\r\nexecutioner. I leave you to judge how far your nerves are calculated to\r\nbear you through such a scene. Of this, however, be assured, that\r\nshould any favorable opportunity present itself, I will not fail to\r\noffer you the choice of being present.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor shame, M. de Villefort!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ren\xc3\xa9e, becoming quite pale; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou see how you are frightening us?\xe2\x80\x94and yet you laugh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have? \xe2\x80\x99Tis like a duel. I have already recorded\r\nsentence of death, five or six times, against the movers of political\r\nconspiracies, and who can say how many daggers may be ready sharpened,\r\nand only waiting a favorable opportunity to be buried in my heart?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGracious heavens, M. de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ren\xc3\xa9e, becoming more and more\r\nterrified; \xe2\x80\x9cyou surely are not in earnest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed I am,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young magistrate with a smile; \xe2\x80\x9cand in the\r\ninteresting trial that young lady is anxious to witness, the case would\r\nonly be still more aggravated. Suppose, for instance, the prisoner, as\r\nis more than probable, to have served under Napoleon\xe2\x80\x94well, can you\r\nexpect for an instant, that one accustomed, at the word of his\r\ncommander, to rush fearlessly on the very bayonets of his foe, will\r\nscruple more to drive a stiletto into the heart of one he knows to be\r\nhis personal enemy, than to slaughter his fellow-creatures, merely\r\nbecause bidden to do so by one he is bound to obey? Besides, one\r\nrequires the excitement of being hateful in the eyes of the accused, in\r\norder to lash one\xe2\x80\x99s self into a state of sufficient vehemence and\r\npower. I would not choose to see the man against whom I pleaded smile,\r\nas though in mockery of my words. No; my pride is to see the accused\r\npale, agitated, and as though beaten out of all composure by the fire\r\nof my eloquence.\xe2\x80\x9d Ren\xc3\xa9e uttered a smothered exclamation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried one of the guests; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is what I call talking to some\r\npurpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust the person we require at a time like the present,\xe2\x80\x9d said a second.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a splendid business that last case of yours was, my dear\r\nVillefort!\xe2\x80\x9d remarked a third; \xe2\x80\x9cI mean the trial of the man for\r\nmurdering his father. Upon my word, you killed him ere the executioner\r\nhad laid his hand upon him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, as for parricides, and such dreadful people as that,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed\r\nRen\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x9cit matters very little what is done to them; but as regards\r\npoor unfortunate creatures whose only crime consists in having mixed\r\nthemselves up in political intrigues\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that is the very worst offence they could possibly commit; for,\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t you see, Ren\xc3\xa9e, the king is the father of his people, and he who\r\nshall plot or contrive aught against the life and safety of the parent\r\nof thirty-two millions of souls, is a parricide upon a fearfully great\r\nscale?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ren\xc3\xa9e; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, M. de\r\nVillefort, you have promised me\xe2\x80\x94have you not?\xe2\x80\x94always to show mercy to\r\nthose I plead for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMake yourself quite easy on that point,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Villefort, with one\r\nof his sweetest smiles; \xe2\x80\x9cyou and I will always consult upon our\r\nverdicts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy love,\xe2\x80\x9d said the marquise, \xe2\x80\x9cattend to your doves, your lap-dogs, and\r\nembroidery, but do not meddle with what you do not understand. Nowadays\r\nthe military profession is in abeyance and the magisterial robe is the\r\nbadge of honor. There is a wise Latin proverb that is very much in\r\npoint.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Cedant arma tog\xc3\xa6_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort with a bow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot speak Latin,\xe2\x80\x9d responded the marquise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ren\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot help regretting you had not chosen some\r\nother profession than your own\xe2\x80\x94a physician, for instance. Do you know I\r\nalways felt a shudder at the idea of even a _destroying_ angel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear, good Ren\xc3\xa9e,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Villefort, as he gazed with unutterable\r\ntenderness on the lovely speaker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us hope, my child,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the marquis, \xe2\x80\x9cthat M. de Villefort may\r\nprove the moral and political physician of this province; if so, he\r\nwill have achieved a noble work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd one which will go far to efface the recollection of his father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconduct,\xe2\x80\x9d added the incorrigible marquise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, with a mournful smile, \xe2\x80\x9cI have already had\r\nthe honor to observe that my father has\xe2\x80\x94at least, I hope so\xe2\x80\x94abjured his\r\npast errors, and that he is, at the present moment, a firm and zealous\r\nfriend to religion and order\xe2\x80\x94a better royalist, possibly, than his son;\r\nfor he has to atone for past dereliction, while I have no other impulse\r\nthan warm, decided preference and conviction.\xe2\x80\x9d Having made this\r\nwell-turned speech, Villefort looked carefully around to mark the\r\neffect of his oratory, much as he would have done had he been\r\naddressing the bench in open court.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, my dear Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Comte de Salvieux, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is\r\nexactly what I myself said the other day at the Tuileries, when\r\nquestioned by his majesty\xe2\x80\x99s principal chamberlain touching the\r\nsingularity of an alliance between the son of a Girondin and the\r\ndaughter of an officer of the Duc de Cond\xc3\xa9; and I assure you he seemed\r\nfully to comprehend that this mode of reconciling political differences\r\nwas based upon sound and excellent principles. Then the king, who,\r\nwithout our suspecting it, had overheard our conversation, interrupted\r\nus by saying, \xe2\x80\x98Villefort\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94observe that the king did not pronounce the\r\nword Noirtier, but, on the contrary, placed considerable emphasis on\r\nthat of Villefort\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Villefort,\xe2\x80\x99 said his majesty, \xe2\x80\x98is a young man of\r\ngreat judgment and discretion, who will be sure to make a figure in his\r\nprofession; I like him much, and it gave me great pleasure to hear that\r\nhe was about to become the son-in-law of the Marquis and Marquise de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran. I should myself have recommended the match, had not the\r\nnoble marquis anticipated my wishes by requesting my consent to it.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible the king could have condescended so far as to express\r\nhimself so favorably of me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the enraptured Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give you his very words; and if the marquis chooses to be candid, he\r\nwill confess that they perfectly agree with what his majesty said to\r\nhim, when he went six months ago to consult him upon the subject of\r\nyour espousing his daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0091m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the marquis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much do I owe this gracious prince! What is there I would not do\r\nto evince my earnest gratitude!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is right,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the marquise. \xe2\x80\x9cI love to see you thus. Now,\r\nthen, were a conspirator to fall into your hands, he would be most\r\nwelcome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor my part, dear mother,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Ren\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x9cI trust your wishes will\r\nnot prosper, and that Providence will only permit petty offenders, poor\r\ndebtors, and miserable cheats to fall into M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhands,\xe2\x80\x94then I shall be contented.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust the same as though you prayed that a physician might only be\r\ncalled upon to prescribe for headaches, measles, and the stings of\r\nwasps, or any other slight affection of the epidermis. If you wish to\r\nsee me the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney, you must desire for me some of those\r\nviolent and dangerous diseases from the cure of which so much honor\r\nredounds to the physician.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment, and as though the utterance of Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s wish had\r\nsufficed to effect its accomplishment, a servant entered the room, and\r\nwhispered a few words in his ear. Villefort immediately rose from table\r\nand quitted the room upon the plea of urgent business; he soon,\r\nhowever, returned, his whole face beaming with delight. Ren\xc3\xa9e regarded\r\nhim with fond affection; and certainly his handsome features, lit up as\r\nthey then were with more than usual fire and animation, seemed formed\r\nto excite the innocent admiration with which she gazed on her graceful\r\nand intelligent lover.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were wishing just now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, addressing her, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I\r\nwere a doctor instead of a lawyer. Well, I at least resemble the\r\ndisciples of Esculapius in one thing [people spoke in this style in\r\n1815], that of not being able to call a day my own, not even that of my\r\nbetrothal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd wherefore were you called away just now?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mademoiselle de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran, with an air of deep interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor a very serious matter, which bids fair to make work for the\r\nexecutioner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow dreadful!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ren\xc3\xa9e, turning pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible?\xe2\x80\x9d burst simultaneously from all who were near enough to\r\nthe magistrate to hear his words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, if my information prove correct, a sort of Bonapartist conspiracy\r\nhas just been discovered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan I believe my ears?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the marquise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will read you the letter containing the accusation, at least,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nVillefort:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney is informed by a friend to the throne and the\r\nreligious institutions of his country, that one named Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s,\r\nmate of the ship _Pharaon_, this day arrived from Smyrna, after having\r\ntouched at Naples and Porto-Ferrajo, has been the bearer of a letter\r\nfrom Murat to the usurper, and again taken charge of another letter\r\nfrom the usurper to the Bonapartist club in Paris. Ample corroboration\r\nof this statement may be obtained by arresting the above-mentioned\r\nEdmond Dant\xc3\xa8s, who either carries the letter for Paris about with him,\r\nor has it at his father\xe2\x80\x99s abode. Should it not be found in the\r\npossession of father or son, then it will assuredly be discovered in\r\nthe cabin belonging to the said Dant\xc3\xa8s on board the _Pharaon_.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ren\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x9cthis letter, which, after all, is but an anonymous\r\nscrawl, is not even addressed to you, but to the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0093m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue; but that gentleman being absent, his secretary, by his orders,\r\nopened his letters; thinking this one of importance, he sent for me,\r\nbut not finding me, took upon himself to give the necessary orders for\r\narresting the accused party.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the guilty person is absolutely in custody?\xe2\x80\x9d said the marquise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, dear mother, say the accused person. You know we cannot yet\r\npronounce him guilty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is in safe custody,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cand rely upon it, if the\r\nletter is found, he will not be likely to be trusted abroad again,\r\nunless he goes forth under the especial protection of the headsman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where is the unfortunate being?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ren\xc3\xa9e.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is at my house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the marquise, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not neglect your\r\nduty to linger with us. You are the king\xe2\x80\x99s servant, and must go\r\nwherever that service calls you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Villefort!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ren\xc3\xa9e, clasping her hands, and looking towards\r\nher lover with piteous earnestness, \xe2\x80\x9cbe merciful on this the day of our\r\nbetrothal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young man passed round to the side of the table where the fair\r\npleader sat, and leaning over her chair said tenderly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo give you pleasure, my sweet Ren\xc3\xa9e, I promise to show all the lenity\r\nin my power; but if the charges brought against this Bonapartist hero\r\nprove correct, why, then, you really must give me leave to order his\r\nhead to be cut off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRen\xc3\xa9e shuddered at the word _cut_, for the growth in question had a\r\nhead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind that foolish girl, Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d said the marquise. \xe2\x80\x9cShe will\r\nsoon get over these things.\xe2\x80\x9d So saying, Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran extended\r\nher dry bony hand to Villefort, who, while imprinting a son-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nrespectful salute on it, looked at Ren\xc3\xa9e, as much as to say, \xe2\x80\x9cI must\r\ntry and fancy \xe2\x80\x99tis your dear hand I kiss, as it should have been.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese are mournful auspices to accompany a betrothal,\xe2\x80\x9d sighed poor\r\nRen\xc3\xa9e.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word, child!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the angry marquise, \xe2\x80\x9cyour folly\r\nexceeds all bounds. I should be glad to know what connection there can\r\npossibly be between your sickly sentimentality and the affairs of the\r\nstate!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mother!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Ren\xc3\xa9e.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, madame, I pray you pardon this little traitor. I promise you that\r\nto make up for her want of loyalty, I will be most inflexibly severe;\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthen casting an expressive glance at his betrothed, which seemed to\r\nsay, \xe2\x80\x9cFear not, for your dear sake my justice shall be tempered with\r\nmercy,\xe2\x80\x9d and receiving a sweet and approving smile in return, Villefort\r\ndeparted with paradise in his heart.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 7. The Examination\r\n\r\nNo sooner had Villefort left the salon, than he assumed the grave air\r\nof a man who holds the balance of life and death in his hands. Now, in\r\nspite of the nobility of his countenance, the command of which, like a\r\nfinished actor, he had carefully studied before the glass, it was by no\r\nmeans easy for him to assume an air of judicial severity. Except the\r\nrecollection of the line of politics his father had adopted, and which\r\nmight interfere, unless he acted with the greatest prudence, with his\r\nown career, G\xc3\xa9rard de Villefort was as happy as a man could be. Already\r\nrich, he held a high official situation, though only twenty-seven. He\r\nwas about to marry a young and charming woman, whom he loved, not\r\npassionately, but reasonably, as became a deputy attorney of the king;\r\nand besides her personal attractions, which were very great,\r\nMademoiselle de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s family possessed considerable political\r\ninfluence, which they would, of course, exert in his favor. The dowry\r\nof his wife amounted to fifty thousand crowns, and he had, besides, the\r\nprospect of seeing her fortune increased to half a million at her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s death. These considerations naturally gave Villefort a feeling\r\nof such complete felicity that his mind was fairly dazzled in its\r\ncontemplation.\r\n\r\nAt the door he met the commissary of police, who was waiting for him.\r\nThe sight of this officer recalled Villefort from the third heaven to\r\nearth; he composed his face, as we have before described, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nhave read the letter, sir, and you have acted rightly in arresting this\r\nman; now inform me what you have discovered concerning him and the\r\nconspiracy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe know nothing as yet of the conspiracy, monsieur; all the papers\r\nfound have been sealed up and placed on your desk. The prisoner himself\r\nis named Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s, mate on board the three-master the _Pharaon_,\r\ntrading in cotton with Alexandria and Smyrna, and belonging to Morrel &\r\nSon, of Marseilles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBefore he entered the merchant service, had he ever served in the\r\nmarines?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, monsieur, he is very young.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow old?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNineteen or twenty at the most.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment, and as Villefort had arrived at the corner of the Rue\r\ndes Conseils, a man, who seemed to have been waiting for him,\r\napproached; it was M. Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, M. de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, \xe2\x80\x9cI am delighted to see you. Some of\r\nyour people have committed the strangest mistake\xe2\x80\x94they have just\r\narrested Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s, mate of my vessel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cand I am now going to\r\nexamine him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, carried away by his friendship, \xe2\x80\x9cyou do not know\r\nhim, and I do. He is the most estimable, the most trustworthy creature\r\nin the world, and I will venture to say, there is not a better seaman\r\nin all the merchant service. Oh, M. de Villefort, I beseech your\r\nindulgence for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort, as we have seen, belonged to the aristocratic party at\r\nMarseilles, Morrel to the plebeian; the first was a royalist, the other\r\nsuspected of Bonapartism. Villefort looked disdainfully at Morrel, and\r\nreplied coldly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are aware, monsieur, that a man may be estimable and trustworthy\r\nin private life, and the best seaman in the merchant service, and yet\r\nbe, politically speaking, a great criminal.
