Is it not true?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe magistrate laid emphasis on these words, as if he wished to apply\r\nthem to the owner himself, while his eyes seemed to plunge into the\r\nheart of one who, interceding for another, had himself need of\r\nindulgence. Morrel reddened, for his own conscience was not quite clear\r\non politics; besides, what Dant\xc3\xa8s had told him of his interview with\r\nthe grand-marshal, and what the emperor had said to him, embarrassed\r\nhim. He replied, however, in a tone of deep interest:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI entreat you, M. de Villefort, be, as you always are, kind and\r\nequitable, and give him back to us soon.\xe2\x80\x9d This _give us_ sounded\r\nrevolutionary in the deputy\xe2\x80\x99s ears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he, \xe2\x80\x9cis Dant\xc3\xa8s then a member of some Carbonari\r\nsociety, that his protector thus employs the collective form? He was,\r\nif I recollect, arrested in a tavern, in company with a great many\r\nothers.\xe2\x80\x9d Then he added, \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, you may rest assured I shall perform\r\nmy duty impartially, and that if he be innocent you shall not have\r\nappealed to me in vain; should he, however, be guilty, in this present\r\nepoch, impunity would furnish a dangerous example, and I must do my\r\nduty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0097m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAs he had now arrived at the door of his own house, which adjoined the\r\nPalais de Justice, he entered, after having, coldly saluted the\r\nshipowner, who stood, as if petrified, on the spot where Villefort had\r\nleft him. The antechamber was full of police agents and gendarmes, in\r\nthe midst of whom, carefully watched, but calm and smiling, stood the\r\nprisoner. Villefort traversed the antechamber, cast a side glance at\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s, and taking a packet which a gendarme offered him, disappeared,\r\nsaying, \xe2\x80\x9cBring in the prisoner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRapid as had been Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s glance, it had served to give him an idea\r\nof the man he was about to interrogate. He had recognized intelligence\r\nin the high forehead, courage in the dark eye and bent brow, and\r\nfrankness in the thick lips that showed a set of pearly teeth.\r\nVillefort\xe2\x80\x99s first impression was favorable; but he had been so often\r\nwarned to mistrust first impulses, that he applied the maxim to the\r\nimpression, forgetting the difference between the two words. He\r\nstifled, therefore, the feelings of compassion that were rising,\r\ncomposed his features, and sat down, grim and sombre, at his desk. An\r\ninstant after Dant\xc3\xa8s entered. He was pale, but calm and collected, and\r\nsaluting his judge with easy politeness, looked round for a seat, as if\r\nhe had been in M. Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s salon. It was then that he encountered for\r\nthe first time Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s look,\xe2\x80\x94that look peculiar to the magistrate,\r\nwho, while seeming to read the thoughts of others, betrays nothing of\r\nhis own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho and what are you?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Villefort, turning over a pile of\r\npapers, containing information relative to the prisoner, that a police\r\nagent had given to him on his entry, and that, already, in an hour\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntime, had swelled to voluminous proportions, thanks to the corrupt\r\nespionage of which \xe2\x80\x9cthe accused\xe2\x80\x9d is always made the victim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy name is Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man calmly; \xe2\x80\x9cI am mate of\r\nthe _Pharaon_, belonging to Messrs. Morrel & Son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour age?\xe2\x80\x9d continued Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNineteen,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat were you doing at the moment you were arrested?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was at the festival of my marriage, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man,\r\nhis voice slightly tremulous, so great was the contrast between that\r\nhappy moment and the painful ceremony he was now undergoing; so great\r\nwas the contrast between the sombre aspect of M. de Villefort and the\r\nradiant face of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were at the festival of your marriage?\xe2\x80\x9d said the deputy,\r\nshuddering in spite of himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur; I am on the point of marrying a young girl I have been\r\nattached to for three years.\xe2\x80\x9d Villefort, impassive as he was, was\r\nstruck with this coincidence; and the tremulous voice of Dant\xc3\xa8s,\r\nsurprised in the midst of his happiness, struck a sympathetic chord in\r\nhis own bosom\xe2\x80\x94he also was on the point of being married, and he was\r\nsummoned from his own happiness to destroy that of another. \xe2\x80\x9cThis\r\nphilosophic reflection,\xe2\x80\x9d thought he, \xe2\x80\x9cwill make a great sensation at M.\r\nde Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s;\xe2\x80\x9d and he arranged mentally, while Dant\xc3\xa8s awaited\r\nfurther questions, the antithesis by which orators often create a\r\nreputation for eloquence. When this speech was arranged, Villefort\r\nturned to Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n0099m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have me say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive all the information in your power.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me on which point you desire information, and I will tell all I\r\nknow; only,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cI warn you I know very little.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you served under the usurper?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was about to be mustered into the Royal Marines when he fell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is reported your political opinions are extreme,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort,\r\nwho had never heard anything of the kind, but was not sorry to make\r\nthis inquiry, as if it were an accusation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy political opinions!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s. \xe2\x80\x9cAlas, sir, I never had any\r\nopinions. I am hardly nineteen; I know nothing; I have no part to play.\r\nIf I obtain the situation I desire, I shall owe it to M. Morrel. Thus\r\nall my opinions\xe2\x80\x94I will not say public, but private\xe2\x80\x94are confined to\r\nthese three sentiments,\xe2\x80\x94I love my father, I respect M. Morrel, and I\r\nadore Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s. This, sir, is all I can tell you, and you see how\r\nuninteresting it is.\xe2\x80\x9d As Dant\xc3\xa8s spoke, Villefort gazed at his ingenuous\r\nand open countenance, and recollected the words of Ren\xc3\xa9e, who, without\r\nknowing who the culprit was, had besought his indulgence for him. With\r\nthe deputy\xe2\x80\x99s knowledge of crime and criminals, every word the young man\r\nuttered convinced him more and more of his innocence. This lad, for he\r\nwas scarcely a man,\xe2\x80\x94simple, natural, eloquent with that eloquence of\r\nthe heart never found when sought for; full of affection for everybody,\r\nbecause he was happy, and because happiness renders even the wicked\r\ngood\xe2\x80\x94extended his affection even to his judge, spite of Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsevere look and stern accent. Dant\xc3\xa8s seemed full of kindness.\r\n\r\n_\xe2\x80\x9cPardieu!\xe2\x80\x9d_ said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9che is a noble fellow. I hope I shall gain\r\nRen\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x99s favor easily by obeying the first command she ever imposed on\r\nme. I shall have at least a pressure of the hand in public, and a sweet\r\nkiss in private.\xe2\x80\x9d Full of this idea, Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s face became so joyous,\r\nthat when he turned to Dant\xc3\xa8s, the latter, who had watched the change\r\non his physiognomy, was smiling also.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9chave you any enemies, at least, that you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have enemies?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s; \xe2\x80\x9cmy position is not sufficiently\r\nelevated for that. As for my disposition, that is, perhaps, somewhat\r\ntoo hasty; but I have striven to repress it. I have had ten or twelve\r\nsailors under me, and if you question them, they will tell you that\r\nthey love and respect me, not as a father, for I am too young, but as\r\nan elder brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you may have excited jealousy. You are about to become captain at\r\nnineteen\xe2\x80\x94an elevated post; you are about to marry a pretty girl, who\r\nloves you; and these two pieces of good fortune may have excited the\r\nenvy of someone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right; you know men better than I do, and what you say may\r\npossibly be the case, I confess; but if such persons are among my\r\nacquaintances I prefer not to know it, because then I should be forced\r\nto hate them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are wrong; you should always strive to see clearly around you. You\r\nseem a worthy young man; I will depart from the strict line of my duty\r\nto aid you in discovering the author of this accusation. Here is the\r\npaper; do you know the writing?\xe2\x80\x9d As he spoke, Villefort drew the letter\r\nfrom his pocket, and presented it to Dant\xc3\xa8s. Dant\xc3\xa8s read it. A cloud\r\npassed over his brow as he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur, I do not know the writing, and yet it is tolerably\r\nplain. Whoever did it writes well. I am very fortunate,\xe2\x80\x9d added he,\r\nlooking gratefully at Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cto be examined by such a man as you;\r\nfor this envious person is a real enemy.\xe2\x80\x9d And by the rapid glance that\r\nthe young man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes shot forth, Villefort saw how much energy lay hid\r\nbeneath this mildness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the deputy, \xe2\x80\x9canswer me frankly, not as a prisoner to a\r\njudge, but as one man to another who takes an interest in him, what\r\ntruth is there in the accusation contained in this anonymous letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd Villefort threw disdainfully on his desk the letter Dant\xc3\xa8s had just\r\ngiven back to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone at all. I will tell you the real facts. I swear by my honor as a\r\nsailor, by my love for Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, by the life of my father\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort. Then, internally, \xe2\x80\x9cIf Ren\xc3\xa9e could\r\nsee me, I hope she would be satisfied, and would no longer call me a\r\ndecapitator.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, when we quitted Naples, Captain Leclere was attacked with a\r\nbrain fever. As we had no doctor on board, and he was so anxious to\r\narrive at Elba, that he would not touch at any other port, his disorder\r\nrose to such a height, that at the end of the third day, feeling he was\r\ndying, he called me to him. \xe2\x80\x98My dear Dant\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98swear to\r\nperform what I am going to tell you, for it is a matter of the deepest\r\nimportance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I swear, captain,\xe2\x80\x99 replied I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Well, as after my death the command devolves on you as mate, assume\r\nthe command, and bear up for the Island of Elba, disembark at\r\nPorto-Ferrajo, ask for the grand-marshal, give him this letter\xe2\x80\x94perhaps\r\nthey will give you another letter, and charge you with a commission.\r\nYou will accomplish what I was to have done, and derive all the honor\r\nand profit from it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I will do it, captain; but perhaps I shall not be admitted to the\r\ngrand-marshal\xe2\x80\x99s presence as easily as you expect?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Here is a ring that will obtain audience of him, and remove every\r\ndifficulty,\xe2\x80\x99 said the captain. At these words he gave me a ring. It was\r\ntime\xe2\x80\x94two hours after he was delirious; the next day he died.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did you do then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I ought to have done, and what everyone would have done in my\r\nplace. Everywhere the last requests of a dying man are sacred; but with\r\na sailor the last requests of his superior are commands. I sailed for\r\nthe Island of Elba, where I arrived the next day; I ordered everybody\r\nto remain on board, and went on shore alone. As I had expected, I found\r\nsome difficulty in obtaining access to the grand-marshal; but I sent\r\nthe ring I had received from the captain to him, and was instantly\r\nadmitted. He questioned me concerning Captain Leclere\xe2\x80\x99s death; and, as\r\nthe latter had told me, gave me a letter to carry on to a person in\r\nParis. I undertook it because it was what my captain had bade me do. I\r\nlanded here, regulated the affairs of the vessel, and hastened to visit\r\nmy affianced bride, whom I found more lovely than ever. Thanks to M.\r\nMorrel, all the forms were got over; in a word I was, as I told you, at\r\nmy marriage feast; and I should have been married in an hour, and\r\ntomorrow I intended to start for Paris, had I not been arrested on this\r\ncharge which you as well as I now see to be unjust.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthis seems to me the truth. If you have been\r\nculpable, it was imprudence, and this imprudence was in obedience to\r\nthe orders of your captain. Give up this letter you have brought from\r\nElba, and pass your word you will appear should you be required, and go\r\nand rejoin your friends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am free, then, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Dant\xc3\xa8s joyfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but first give me this letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have it already, for it was taken from me with some others which I\r\nsee in that packet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said the deputy, as Dant\xc3\xa8s took his hat and gloves.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo whom is it addressed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n_\xe2\x80\x9cTo Monsieur Noirtier, Rue Coq-H\xc3\xa9ron, Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d_ Had a thunderbolt\r\nfallen into the room, Villefort could not have been more stupefied. He\r\nsank into his seat, and hastily turning over the packet, drew forth the\r\nfatal letter, at which he glanced with an expression of terror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Noirtier, Rue Coq-H\xc3\xa9ron, No. 13,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he, growing still paler.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s; \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9ca faithful servant of the king does not know\r\nconspirators.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0103m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a conspiracy, then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Dant\xc3\xa8s, who after believing himself\r\nfree, now began to feel a tenfold alarm. \xe2\x80\x9cI have, however, already told\r\nyou, sir, I was entirely ignorant of the contents of the letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but you knew the name of the person to whom it was addressed,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was forced to read the address to know to whom to give it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you shown this letter to anyone?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Villefort, becoming still\r\nmore pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo no one, on my honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverybody is ignorant that you are the bearer of a letter from the\r\nIsland of Elba, and addressed to M. Noirtier?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverybody, except the person who gave it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that was too much, far too much,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Villefort. Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbrow darkened more and more, his white lips and clenched teeth filled\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s with apprehension. After reading the letter, Villefort covered\r\nhis face with his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s timidly, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d Villefort made no\r\nanswer, but raised his head at the expiration of a few seconds, and\r\nagain perused the letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you say that you are ignorant of the contents of this letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give you my word of honor, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s; \xe2\x80\x9cbut what is the\r\nmatter? You are ill\xe2\x80\x94shall I ring for assistance?\xe2\x80\x94shall I call?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, rising hastily; \xe2\x80\x9cstay where you are. It is for me\r\nto give orders here, and not you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s proudly, \xe2\x80\x9cit was only to summon assistance\r\nfor you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want none; it was a temporary indisposition. Attend to yourself;\r\nanswer me.\xe2\x80\x9d Dant\xc3\xa8s waited, expecting a question, but in vain. Villefort\r\nfell back on his chair, passed his hand over his brow, moist with\r\nperspiration, and, for the third time, read the letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if he knows the contents of this!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he, \xe2\x80\x9cand that Noirtier\r\nis the father of Villefort, I am lost!\xe2\x80\x9d And he fixed his eyes upon\r\nEdmond as if he would have penetrated his thoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is impossible to doubt it,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn heaven\xe2\x80\x99s name!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the unhappy young man, \xe2\x80\x9cif you doubt me,\r\nquestion me; I will answer you.\xe2\x80\x9d Villefort made a violent effort, and\r\nin a tone he strove to render firm:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI am no longer able, as I had hoped, to restore you\r\nimmediately to liberty; before doing so, I must consult the trial\r\njustice; what my own feeling is you already know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have been rather a friend than a\r\njudge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0105m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I must detain you some time longer, but I will strive to make it\r\nas short as possible. The principal charge against you is this letter,\r\nand you see\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d Villefort approached the fire, cast it in, and waited\r\nuntil it was entirely consumed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, I destroy it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are goodness itself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cyou can now have confidence in me after\r\nwhat I have done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, command, and I will obey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen; this is not a command, but advice I give you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, and I will follow your advice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall detain you until this evening in the Palais de Justice. Should\r\nanyone else interrogate you, say to him what you have said to me, but\r\ndo not breathe a word of this letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promise.\xe2\x80\x9d It was Villefort who seemed to entreat, and the prisoner\r\nwho reassured him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, glancing toward the grate, where fragments of\r\nburnt paper fluttered in the flames, \xe2\x80\x9cthe letter is destroyed; you and\r\nI alone know of its existence; should you, therefore, be questioned,\r\ndeny all knowledge of it\xe2\x80\x94deny it boldly, and you are saved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied; I will deny it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was the only letter you had?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSwear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI swear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort rang. A police agent entered. Villefort whispered some words\r\nin his ear, to which the officer replied by a motion of his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFollow him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort to Dant\xc3\xa8s. Dant\xc3\xa8s saluted Villefort and\r\nretired. Hardly had the door closed when Villefort threw himself\r\nhalf-fainting into a chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, alas,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he, \xe2\x80\x9cif the procureur himself had been at\r\nMarseilles I should have been ruined. This accursed letter would have\r\ndestroyed all my hopes. Oh, my father, must your past career always\r\ninterfere with my successes?\xe2\x80\x9d Suddenly a light passed over his face, a\r\nsmile played round his set mouth, and his haggard eyes were fixed in\r\nthought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis will do,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cand from this letter, which might have ruined\r\nme, I will make my fortune. Now to the work I have in hand.\xe2\x80\x9d And after\r\nhaving assured himself that the prisoner was gone, the deputy procureur\r\nhastened to the house of his betrothed.\r\n\r\n0107m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 8. The Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If\r\n\r\nThe commissary of police, as he traversed the antechamber, made a sign\r\nto two gendarmes, who placed themselves one on Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 right and the\r\nother on his left. A door that communicated with the Palais de Justice\r\nwas opened, and they went through a long range of gloomy corridors,\r\nwhose appearance might have made even the boldest shudder. The Palais\r\nde Justice communicated with the prison,\xe2\x80\x94a sombre edifice, that from\r\nits grated windows looks on the clock-tower of the Accoules. After\r\nnumberless windings, Dant\xc3\xa8s saw a door with an iron wicket. The\r\ncommissary took up an iron mallet and knocked thrice, every blow\r\nseeming to Dant\xc3\xa8s as if struck on his heart. The door opened, the two\r\ngendarmes gently pushed him forward, and the door closed with a loud\r\nsound behind him. The air he inhaled was no longer pure, but thick and\r\nmephitic,\xe2\x80\x94he was in prison.\r\n\r\nHe was conducted to a tolerably neat chamber, but grated and barred,\r\nand its appearance, therefore, did not greatly alarm him; besides, the\r\nwords of Villefort, who seemed to interest himself so much, resounded\r\nstill in his ears like a promise of freedom. It was four o\xe2\x80\x99clock when\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s was placed in this chamber. It was, as we have said, the 1st of\r\nMarch, and the prisoner was soon buried in darkness. The obscurity\r\naugmented the acuteness of his hearing; at the slightest sound he rose\r\nand hastened to the door, convinced they were about to liberate him,\r\nbut the sound died away, and Dant\xc3\xa8s sank again into his seat. At last,\r\nabout ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and just as Dant\xc3\xa8s began to despair, steps were\r\nheard in the corridor, a key turned in the lock, the bolts creaked, the\r\nmassy oaken door flew open, and a flood of light from two torches\r\npervaded the apartment.\r\n\r\nBy the torchlight Dant\xc3\xa8s saw the glittering sabres and carbines of four\r\ngendarmes. He had advanced at first, but stopped at the sight of this\r\ndisplay of force.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you come to fetch me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied a gendarme.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the orders of the deputy procureur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe so.\xe2\x80\x9d The conviction that they came from M. de Villefort\r\nrelieved all Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 apprehensions; he advanced calmly, and placed\r\nhimself in the centre of the escort. A carriage waited at the door, the\r\ncoachman was on the box, and a police officer sat beside him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this carriage for me?\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is for you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied a gendarme.\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s was about to speak; but feeling himself urged forward, and\r\nhaving neither the power nor the intention to resist, he mounted the\r\nsteps, and was in an instant seated inside between two gendarmes; the\r\ntwo others took their places opposite, and the carriage rolled heavily\r\nover the stones.\r\n\r\nThe prisoner glanced at the windows\xe2\x80\x94they were grated; he had changed\r\nhis prison for another that was conveying him he knew not whither.\r\nThrough the grating, however, Dant\xc3\xa8s saw they were passing through the\r\nRue Caisserie, and by the Rue Saint-Laurent and the Rue Taramis, to the\r\nquay. Soon he saw the lights of La Consigne.\r\n\r\nThe carriage stopped, the officer descended, approached the guardhouse,\r\na dozen soldiers came out and formed themselves in order; Dant\xc3\xa8s saw\r\nthe reflection of their muskets by the light of the lamps on the quay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan all this force be summoned on my account?\xe2\x80\x9d thought he.\r\n\r\nThe officer opened the door, which was locked, and, without speaking a\r\nword, answered Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 question; for he saw between the ranks of the\r\nsoldiers a passage formed from the carriage to the port. The two\r\ngendarmes who were opposite to him descended first, then he was ordered\r\nto alight and the gendarmes on each side of him followed his example.\r\nThey advanced towards a boat, which a custom-house officer held by a\r\nchain, near the quay.\r\n\r\nThe soldiers looked at Dant\xc3\xa8s with an air of stupid curiosity. In an\r\ninstant he was placed in the stern-sheets of the boat, between the\r\ngendarmes, while the officer stationed himself at the bow; a shove sent\r\nthe boat adrift, and four sturdy oarsmen impelled it rapidly towards\r\nthe Pilon. At a shout from the boat, the chain that closes the mouth of\r\nthe port was lowered and in a second they were, as Dant\xc3\xa8s knew, in the\r\nFrioul and outside the inner harbor.\r\n\r\nThe prisoner\xe2\x80\x99s first feeling was of joy at again breathing the pure\r\nair\xe2\x80\x94for air is freedom; but he soon sighed, for he passed before La\r\nR\xc3\xa9serve, where he had that morning been so happy, and now through the\r\nopen windows came the laughter and revelry of a ball. Dant\xc3\xa8s folded his\r\nhands, raised his eyes to heaven, and prayed fervently.\r\n\r\n0111m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe boat continued her voyage. They had passed the T\xc3\xaate de Mort, were\r\nnow off the Anse du Pharo, and about to double the battery. This\r\nman\xc5\x93uvre was incomprehensible to Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhither are you taking me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will soon know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut still\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are forbidden to give you any explanation.\xe2\x80\x9d Dant\xc3\xa8s, trained in\r\ndiscipline, knew that nothing would be more absurd than to question\r\nsubordinates, who were forbidden to reply; and so he remained silent.\r\n\r\nThe most vague and wild thoughts passed through his mind. The boat they\r\nwere in could not make a long voyage; there was no vessel at anchor\r\noutside the harbor; he thought, perhaps, they were going to leave him\r\non some distant point. He was not bound, nor had they made any attempt\r\nto handcuff him; this seemed a good augury. Besides, had not the\r\ndeputy, who had been so kind to him, told him that provided he did not\r\npronounce the dreaded name of Noirtier, he had nothing to apprehend?\r\nHad not Villefort in his presence destroyed the fatal letter, the only\r\nproof against him?\r\n\r\nHe waited silently, striving to pierce through the darkness.\r\n\r\nThey had left the Ile Ratonneau, where the lighthouse stood, on the\r\nright, and were now opposite the Point des Catalans. It seemed to the\r\nprisoner that he could distinguish a feminine form on the beach, for it\r\nwas there Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s dwelt. How was it that a presentiment did not warn\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s that her lover was within three hundred yards of her?\r\n\r\nOne light alone was visible; and Dant\xc3\xa8s saw that it came from Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99\r\nchamber. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s was the only one awake in the whole settlement. A\r\nloud cry could be heard by her. But pride restrained him and he did not\r\nutter it. What would his guards think if they heard him shout like a\r\nmadman?\r\n\r\nHe remained silent, his eyes fixed upon the light; the boat went on,\r\nbut the prisoner thought only of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s. An intervening elevation of\r\nland hid the light. Dant\xc3\xa8s turned and perceived that they had got out\r\nto sea. While he had been absorbed in thought, they had shipped their\r\noars and hoisted sail; the boat was now moving with the wind.\r\n\r\nIn spite of his repugnance to address the guards, Dant\xc3\xa8s turned to the\r\nnearest gendarme, and taking his hand,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cComrade,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI adjure you, as a Christian and a soldier, to\r\ntell me where we are going. I am Captain Dant\xc3\xa8s, a loyal Frenchman,\r\nthought accused of treason; tell me where you are conducting me, and I\r\npromise you on my honor I will submit to my fate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe gendarme looked irresolutely at his companion, who returned for\r\nanswer a sign that said, \xe2\x80\x9cI see no great harm in telling him now,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nthe gendarme replied:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a native of Marseilles, and a sailor, and yet you do not know\r\nwhere you are going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my honor, I have no idea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you no idea whatever?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI swear to you it is true. Tell me, I entreat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut my orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour orders do not forbid your telling me what I must know in ten\r\nminutes, in half an hour, or an hour. You see I cannot escape, even if\r\nI intended.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnless you are blind, or have never been outside the harbor, you must\r\nknow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook round you then.\xe2\x80\x9d Dant\xc3\xa8s rose and looked forward, when he saw rise\r\nwithin a hundred yards of him the black and frowning rock on which\r\nstands the Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If. This gloomy fortress, which has for more than\r\nthree hundred years furnished food for so many wild legends, seemed to\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s like a scaffold to a malefactor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If?\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat are we going there for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe gendarme smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not going there to be imprisoned,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s; \xe2\x80\x9cit is only used\r\nfor political prisoners. I have committed no crime. Are there any\r\nmagistrates or judges at the Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are only,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gendarme, \xe2\x80\x9ca governor, a garrison, turnkeys,\r\nand good thick walls. Come, come, do not look so astonished, or you\r\nwill make me think you are laughing at me in return for my good\r\nnature.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s pressed the gendarme\xe2\x80\x99s hand as though he would crush it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I am taken to the Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If to be\r\nimprisoned there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is probable; but there is no occasion to squeeze so hard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout any inquiry, without any formality?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll the formalities have been gone through; the inquiry is already\r\nmade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so, in spite of M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s promises?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know what M. de Villefort promised you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gendarme,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut I know we are taking you to the Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If. But what are you\r\ndoing? Help, comrades, help!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy a rapid movement, which the gendarme\xe2\x80\x99s practiced eye had perceived,\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s sprang forward to precipitate himself into the sea; but four\r\nvigorous arms seized him as his feet quitted the bottom of the boat. He\r\nfell back cursing with rage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d said the gendarme, placing his knee on his chest; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is the\r\nway you keep your word as a sailor! Believe soft-spoken gentlemen\r\nagain! Hark ye, my friend, I have disobeyed my first order, but I will\r\nnot disobey the second; and if you move, I will blow your brains out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd he levelled his carbine at Dant\xc3\xa8s, who felt the muzzle against his\r\ntemple.\r\n\r\nFor a moment the idea of struggling crossed his mind, and of so ending\r\nthe unexpected evil that had overtaken him. But he bethought him of M.\r\nde Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s promise; and, besides, death in a boat from the hand of\r\na gendarme seemed too terrible. He remained motionless, but gnashing\r\nhis teeth and wringing his hands with fury.\r\n\r\nAt this moment the boat came to a landing with a violent shock. One of\r\nthe sailors leaped on shore, a cord creaked as it ran through a pulley,\r\nand Dant\xc3\xa8s guessed they were at the end of the voyage, and that they\r\nwere mooring the boat.\r\n\r\nHis guards, taking him by the arms and coat-collar, forced him to rise,\r\nand dragged him towards the steps that lead to the gate of the\r\nfortress, while the police officer carrying a musket with fixed bayonet\r\nfollowed behind.\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s made no resistance; he was like a man in a dream; he saw\r\nsoldiers drawn up on the embankment; he knew vaguely that he was\r\nascending a flight of steps; he was conscious that he passed through a\r\ndoor, and that the door closed behind him; but all this indistinctly as\r\nthrough a mist. He did not even see the ocean, that terrible barrier\r\nagainst freedom, which the prisoners look upon with utter despair.\r\n\r\nThey halted for a minute, during which he strove to collect his\r\nthoughts. He looked around; he was in a court surrounded by high walls;\r\nhe heard the measured tread of sentinels, and as they passed before the\r\nlight he saw the barrels of their muskets shine.\r\n\r\nThey waited upwards of ten minutes. Certain Dant\xc3\xa8s could not escape,\r\nthe gendarmes released him. They seemed awaiting orders. The orders\r\ncame.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the prisoner?\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the gendarmes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him follow me; I will take him to his cell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo!\xe2\x80\x9d said the gendarmes, thrusting Dant\xc3\xa8s forward.\r\n\r\nThe prisoner followed his guide, who led him into a room almost under\r\nground, whose bare and reeking walls seemed as though impregnated with\r\ntears; a lamp placed on a stool illumined the apartment faintly, and\r\nshowed Dant\xc3\xa8s the features of his conductor, an under-jailer,\r\nill-clothed, and of sullen appearance.\r\n\r\n0113m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is your chamber for tonight,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is late, and the\r\ngovernor is asleep. Tomorrow, perhaps, he may change you. In the\r\nmeantime there is bread, water, and fresh straw; and that is all a\r\nprisoner can wish for. Goodnight.\xe2\x80\x9d And before Dant\xc3\xa8s could open his\r\nmouth\xe2\x80\x94before he had noticed where the jailer placed his bread or the\r\nwater\xe2\x80\x94before he had glanced towards the corner where the straw was, the\r\njailer disappeared, taking with him the lamp and closing the door,\r\nleaving stamped upon the prisoner\xe2\x80\x99s mind the dim reflection of the\r\ndripping walls of his dungeon.\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s was alone in darkness and in silence\xe2\x80\x94cold as the shadows that he\r\nfelt breathe on his burning forehead. With the first dawn of day the\r\njailer returned, with orders to leave Dant\xc3\xa8s where he was. He found the\r\nprisoner in the same position, as if fixed there, his eyes swollen with\r\nweeping. He had passed the night standing, and without sleep. The\r\njailer advanced; Dant\xc3\xa8s appeared not to perceive him. He touched him on\r\nthe shoulder. Edmond started.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you not slept?\xe2\x80\x9d said the jailer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s. The jailer stared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you hungry?\xe2\x80\x9d continued he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you wish for anything?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish to see the governor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe jailer shrugged his shoulders and left the chamber.\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s followed him with his eyes, and stretched forth his hands\r\ntowards the open door; but the door closed. All his emotion then burst\r\nforth; he cast himself on the ground, weeping bitterly, and asking\r\nhimself what crime he had committed that he was thus punished.\r\n\r\nThe day passed thus; he scarcely tasted food, but walked round and\r\nround the cell like a wild beast in its cage. One thought in particular\r\ntormented him: namely, that during his journey hither he had sat so\r\nstill, whereas he might, a dozen times, have plunged into the sea, and,\r\nthanks to his powers of swimming, for which he was famous, have gained\r\nthe shore, concealed himself until the arrival of a Genoese or Spanish\r\nvessel, escaped to Spain or Italy, where Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s and his father could\r\nhave joined him. He had no fears as to how he should live\xe2\x80\x94good seamen\r\nare welcome everywhere. He spoke Italian like a Tuscan, and Spanish\r\nlike a Castilian; he would have been free, and happy with Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s and\r\nhis father, whereas he was now confined in the Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If, that\r\nimpregnable fortress, ignorant of the future destiny of his father and\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s; and all this because he had trusted to Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s promise.\r\nThe thought was maddening, and Dant\xc3\xa8s threw himself furiously down on\r\nhis straw. The next morning at the same hour, the jailer came again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the jailer, \xe2\x80\x9care you more reasonable today?\xe2\x80\x9d Dant\xc3\xa8s made\r\nno reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, cheer up; is there anything that I can do for you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish to see the governor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have already told you it was impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause it is against prison rules, and prisoners must not even ask\r\nfor it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is allowed, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter fare, if you pay for it, books, and leave to walk about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not want books, I am satisfied with my food, and do not care to\r\nwalk about; but I wish to see the governor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you worry me by repeating the same thing, I will not bring you any\r\nmore to eat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edmond, \xe2\x80\x9cif you do not, I shall die of hunger\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nis all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe jailer saw by his tone he would be happy to die; and as every\r\nprisoner is worth ten sous a day to his jailer, he replied in a more\r\nsubdued tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you ask is impossible; but if you are very well behaved you will\r\nbe allowed to walk about, and some day you will meet the governor, and\r\nif he chooses to reply, that is his affair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9chow long shall I have to wait?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, a month\xe2\x80\x94six months\xe2\x80\x94a year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is too long a time. I wish to see him at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the jailer, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not always brood over what is impossible, or\r\nyou will be mad in a fortnight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; we have an instance here; it was by always offering a million of\r\nfrancs to the governor for his liberty that an abb\xc3\xa9 became mad, who was\r\nin this chamber before you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0119m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long has he left it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas he liberated, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; he was put in a dungeon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen!\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s. \xe2\x80\x9cI am not an abb\xc3\xa9, I am not mad; perhaps I shall\r\nbe, but at present, unfortunately, I am not. I will make you another\r\noffer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not offer you a million, because I have it not; but I will give\r\nyou a hundred crowns if, the first time you go to Marseilles, you will\r\nseek out a young girl named Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, at the Catalans, and give her two\r\nlines from me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0120m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I took them, and were detected, I should lose my place, which is\r\nworth two thousand francs a year; so that I should be a great fool to\r\nrun such a risk for three hundred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cmark this; if you refuse at least to tell\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s I am here, I will some day hide myself behind the door, and\r\nwhen you enter I will dash out your brains with this stool.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThreats!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the jailer, retreating and putting himself on the\r\ndefensive; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are certainly going mad. The abb\xc3\xa9 began like you, and\r\nin three days you will be like him, mad enough to tie up; but,\r\nfortunately, there are dungeons here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s whirled the stool round his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right, all right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the jailer; \xe2\x80\x9call right, since you will\r\nhave it so. I will send word to the governor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Dant\xc3\xa8s, dropping the stool and sitting on it as\r\nif he were in reality mad. The jailer went out, and returned in an\r\ninstant with a corporal and four soldiers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the governor\xe2\x80\x99s orders,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cconduct the prisoner to the tier\r\nbeneath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the dungeon, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the corporal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; we must put the madman with the madmen.\xe2\x80\x9d The soldiers seized\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s, who followed passively.\r\n\r\nHe descended fifteen steps, and the door of a dungeon was opened, and\r\nhe was thrust in. The door closed, and Dant\xc3\xa8s advanced with\r\noutstretched hands until he touched the wall; he then sat down in the\r\ncorner until his eyes became accustomed to the darkness. The jailer was\r\nright; Dant\xc3\xa8s wanted but little of being utterly mad.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 9. The Evening of the Betrothal\r\n\r\nVillefort had, as we have said, hastened back to Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s in the Place du Grand Cours, and on entering the house\r\nfound that the guests whom he had left at table were taking coffee in\r\nthe salon. Ren\xc3\xa9e was, with all the rest of the company, anxiously\r\nawaiting him, and his entrance was followed by a general exclamation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Decapitator, Guardian of the State, Royalist, Brutus, what is\r\nthe matter?\xe2\x80\x9d said one. \xe2\x80\x9cSpeak out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre we threatened with a fresh Reign of Terror?\xe2\x80\x9d asked another.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas the Corsican ogre broken loose?\xe2\x80\x9d cried a third.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarquise,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, approaching his future mother-in-law, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nrequest your pardon for thus leaving you. Will the marquis honor me by\r\na few moments\xe2\x80\x99 private conversation?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, it is really a serious matter, then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the marquis, remarking\r\nthe cloud on Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s brow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo serious that I must take leave of you for a few days; so,\xe2\x80\x9d added\r\nhe, turning to Ren\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x9cjudge for yourself if it be not important.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are going to leave us?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ren\xc3\xa9e, unable to hide her emotion at\r\nthis unexpected announcement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cI must!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere, then, are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the marquise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat, madame, is an official secret; but if you have any commissions\r\nfor Paris, a friend of mine is going there tonight, and will with\r\npleasure undertake them.\xe2\x80\x9d The guests looked at each other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wish to speak to me alone?\xe2\x80\x9d said the marquis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, let us go to the library, please.\xe2\x80\x9d The marquis took his arm, and\r\nthey left the salon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, as soon as they were by themselves, \xe2\x80\x9ctell me what it\r\nis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn affair of the greatest importance, that demands my immediate\r\npresence in Paris. Now, excuse the indiscretion, marquis, but have you\r\nany landed property?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll my fortune is in the funds; seven or eight hundred thousand\r\nfrancs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen sell out\xe2\x80\x94sell out, marquis, or you will lose it all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0123m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how can I sell out here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a broker, have you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen give me a letter to him, and tell him to sell out without an\r\ninstant\xe2\x80\x99s delay, perhaps even now I shall arrive too late.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe deuce you say!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the marquis, \xe2\x80\x9clet us lose no time, then!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, sitting down, he wrote a letter to his broker, ordering him to\r\nsell out at the market price.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, placing the letter in his pocketbook, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nmust have another!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the king.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the king?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare not write to his majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not ask you to write to his majesty, but ask M. de Salvieux to do\r\nso. I want a letter that will enable me to reach the king\xe2\x80\x99s presence\r\nwithout all the formalities of demanding an audience; that would\r\noccasion a loss of precious time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut address yourself to the keeper of the seals; he has the right of\r\nentry at the Tuileries, and can procure you audience at any hour of the\r\nday or night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless; but there is no occasion to divide the honors of my\r\ndiscovery with him. The keeper would leave me in the background, and\r\ntake all the glory to himself. I tell you, marquis, my fortune is made\r\nif I only reach the Tuileries the first, for the king will not forget\r\nthe service I do him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case go and get ready. I will call Salvieux and make him write\r\nthe letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe as quick as possible, I must be on the road in a quarter of an\r\nhour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell your coachman to stop at the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will present my excuses to the marquise and Mademoiselle Ren\xc3\xa9e,\r\nwhom I leave on such a day with great regret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will find them both here, and can make your farewells in person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA thousand thanks\xe2\x80\x94and now for the letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe marquis rang, a servant entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay to the Comte de Salvieux that I would like to see him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, then, go,\xe2\x80\x9d said the marquis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be gone only a few moments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort hastily quitted the apartment, but reflecting that the sight\r\nof the deputy procureur running through the streets would be enough to\r\nthrow the whole city into confusion, he resumed his ordinary pace. At\r\nhis door he perceived a figure in the shadow that seemed to wait for\r\nhim. It was Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, who, hearing no news of her lover, had come\r\nunobserved to inquire after him.\r\n\r\nAs Villefort drew near, she advanced and stood before him. Dant\xc3\xa8s had\r\nspoken of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, and Villefort instantly recognized her. Her beauty\r\nand high bearing surprised him, and when she inquired what had become\r\nof her lover, it seemed to him that she was the judge, and he the\r\naccused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe young man you speak of,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort abruptly, \xe2\x80\x9cis a great\r\ncriminal, and I can do nothing for him, mademoiselle.\xe2\x80\x9d Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s burst\r\ninto tears, and, as Villefort strove to pass her, again addressed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, at least, tell me where he is, that I may know whether he is\r\nalive or dead,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n0125m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know; he is no longer in my hands,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort.\r\n\r\nAnd desirous of putting an end to the interview, he pushed by her, and\r\nclosed the door, as if to exclude the pain he felt. But remorse is not\r\nthus banished; like Virgil\xe2\x80\x99s wounded hero, he carried the arrow in his\r\nwound, and, arrived at the salon, Villefort uttered a sigh that was\r\nalmost a sob, and sank into a chair.\r\n\r\nThen the first pangs of an unending torture seized upon his heart. The\r\nman he sacrificed to his ambition, that innocent victim immolated on\r\nthe altar of his father\xe2\x80\x99s faults, appeared to him pale and threatening,\r\nleading his affianced bride by the hand, and bringing with him remorse,\r\nnot such as the ancients figured, furious and terrible, but that slow\r\nand consuming agony whose pangs are intensified from hour to hour up to\r\nthe very moment of death. Then he had a moment\xe2\x80\x99s hesitation. He had\r\nfrequently called for capital punishment on criminals, and owing to his\r\nirresistible eloquence they had been condemned, and yet the slightest\r\nshadow of remorse had never clouded Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s brow, because they were\r\nguilty; at least, he believed so; but here was an innocent man whose\r\nhappiness he had destroyed. In this case he was not the judge, but the\r\nexecutioner.\r\n\r\nAs he thus reflected, he felt the sensation we have described, and\r\nwhich had hitherto been unknown to him, arise in his bosom, and fill\r\nhim with vague apprehensions. It is thus that a wounded man trembles\r\ninstinctively at the approach of the finger to his wound until it be\r\nhealed, but Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s was one of those that never close, or if they\r\ndo, only close to reopen more agonizing than ever. If at this moment\r\nthe sweet voice of Ren\xc3\xa9e had sounded in his ears pleading for mercy, or\r\nthe fair Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s had entered and said, \xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of God, I conjure\r\nyou to restore me my affianced husband,\xe2\x80\x9d his cold and trembling hands\r\nwould have signed his release; but no voice broke the stillness of the\r\nchamber, and the door was opened only by Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s valet, who came to\r\ntell him that the travelling carriage was in readiness.\r\n\r\nVillefort rose, or rather sprang, from his chair, hastily opened one of\r\nthe drawers of his desk, emptied all the gold it contained into his\r\npocket, stood motionless an instant, his hand pressed to his head,\r\nmuttered a few inarticulate sounds, and then, perceiving that his\r\nservant had placed his cloak on his shoulders, he sprang into the\r\ncarriage, ordering the postilions to drive to M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s. The\r\nhapless Dant\xc3\xa8s was doomed.\r\n\r\nAs the marquis had promised, Villefort found the marquise and Ren\xc3\xa9e in\r\nwaiting. He started when he saw Ren\xc3\xa9e, for he fancied she was again\r\nabout to plead for Dant\xc3\xa8s. Alas, her emotions were wholly personal: she\r\nwas thinking only of Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s departure.\r\n\r\nShe loved Villefort, and he left her at the moment he was about to\r\nbecome her husband. Villefort knew not when he should return, and\r\nRen\xc3\xa9e, far from pleading for Dant\xc3\xa8s, hated the man whose crime\r\nseparated her from her lover.\r\n\r\n0127m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMeanwhile what of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s? She had met Fernand at the corner of the\r\nRue de la Loge; she had returned to the Catalans, and had despairingly\r\ncast herself on her couch. Fernand, kneeling by her side, took her\r\nhand, and covered it with kisses that Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s did not even feel. She\r\npassed the night thus. The lamp went out for want of oil, but she paid\r\nno heed to the darkness, and dawn came, but she knew not that it was\r\nday. Grief had made her blind to all but one object\xe2\x80\x94that was Edmond.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you are there,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, at length, turning towards Fernand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not quitted you since yesterday,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Fernand sorrowfully.\r\n\r\nM. Morrel had not readily given up the fight. He had learned that\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s had been taken to prison, and he had gone to all his friends,\r\nand the influential persons of the city; but the report was already in\r\ncirculation that Dant\xc3\xa8s was arrested as a Bonapartist agent; and as the\r\nmost sanguine looked upon any attempt of Napoleon to remount the throne\r\nas impossible, he met with nothing but refusal, and had returned home\r\nin despair, declaring that the matter was serious and that nothing more\r\ncould be done.\r\n\r\nCaderousse was equally restless and uneasy, but instead of seeking,\r\nlike M. Morrel, to aid Dant\xc3\xa8s, he had shut himself up with two bottles\r\nof black currant brandy, in the hope of drowning reflection. But he did\r\nnot succeed, and became too intoxicated to fetch any more drink, and\r\nyet not so intoxicated as to forget what had happened. With his elbows\r\non the table he sat between the two empty bottles, while spectres\r\ndanced in the light of the unsnuffed candle\xe2\x80\x94spectres such as Hoffmann\r\nstrews over his punch-drenched pages, like black, fantastic dust.\r\n\r\nDanglars alone was content and joyous\xe2\x80\x94he had got rid of an enemy and\r\nmade his own situation on the _Pharaon_ secure. Danglars was one of\r\nthose men born with a pen behind the ear, and an inkstand in place of a\r\nheart. Everything with him was multiplication or subtraction. The life\r\nof a man was to him of far less value than a numeral, especially when,\r\nby taking it away, he could increase the sum total of his own desires.\r\nHe went to bed at his usual hour, and slept in peace.\r\n\r\nVillefort, after having received M. de Salvieux\xe2\x80\x99s letter, embraced\r\nRen\xc3\xa9e, kissed the marquise\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and shaken that of the marquis,\r\nstarted for Paris along the Aix road.\r\n\r\nOld Dant\xc3\xa8s was dying with anxiety to know what had become of Edmond.\r\nBut we know very well what had become of Edmond.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 10. The King\xe2\x80\x99s Closet at the Tuileries\r\n\r\nWe will leave Villefort on the road to Paris, travelling\xe2\x80\x94thanks to\r\ntrebled fees\xe2\x80\x94with all speed, and passing through two or three\r\napartments, enter at the Tuileries the little room with the arched\r\nwindow, so well known as having been the favorite closet of Napoleon\r\nand Louis XVIII., and now of Louis Philippe.\r\n\r\nThere, seated before a walnut table he had brought with him from\r\nHartwell, and to which, from one of those fancies not uncommon to great\r\npeople, he was particularly attached, the king, Louis XVIII., was\r\ncarelessly listening to a man of fifty or fifty-two years of age, with\r\ngray hair, aristocratic bearing, and exceedingly gentlemanly attire,\r\nand meanwhile making a marginal note in a volume of Gryphius\xe2\x80\x99s rather\r\ninaccurate, but much sought-after, edition of Horace\xe2\x80\x94a work which was\r\nmuch indebted to the sagacious observations of the philosophical\r\nmonarch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say, sir\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I am exceedingly disquieted, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, have you had a vision of the seven fat kine and the seven lean\r\nkine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sire, for that would only betoken for us seven years of plenty and\r\nseven years of scarcity; and with a king as full of foresight as your\r\nmajesty, scarcity is not a thing to be feared.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen of what other scourge are you afraid, my dear Blacas?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, I have every reason to believe that a storm is brewing in the\r\nsouth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear duke,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Louis XVIII., \xe2\x80\x9cI think you are wrongly\r\ninformed, and know positively that, on the contrary, it is very fine\r\nweather in that direction.\xe2\x80\x9d Man of ability as he was, Louis XVIII.\r\nliked a pleasant jest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d continued M. de Blacas, \xe2\x80\x9cif it only be to reassure a faithful\r\nservant, will your majesty send into Languedoc, Provence, and Dauphin\xc3\xa9,\r\ntrusty men, who will bring you back a faithful report as to the feeling\r\nin these three provinces?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Canimus surdis_,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the king, continuing the annotations in his\r\nHorace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the courtier, laughing, in order that he might seem to\r\ncomprehend the quotation, \xe2\x80\x9cyour majesty may be perfectly right in\r\nrelying on the good feeling of France, but I fear I am not altogether\r\nwrong in dreading some desperate attempt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Bonaparte, or, at least, by his adherents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Blacas,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, \xe2\x80\x9cyou with your alarms prevent me from\r\nworking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, sire, prevent me from sleeping with your security.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait, my dear sir, wait a moment; for I have such a delightful note on\r\nthe _Pastor quum traheret_\xe2\x80\x94wait, and I will listen to you afterwards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a brief pause, during which Louis XVIII. wrote, in a hand as\r\nsmall as possible, another note on the margin of his Horace, and then\r\nlooking at the duke with the air of a man who thinks he has an idea of\r\nhis own, while he is only commenting upon the idea of another, said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, my dear duke, go on\xe2\x80\x94I listen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d said Blacas, who had for a moment the hope of sacrificing\r\nVillefort to his own profit, \xe2\x80\x9cI am compelled to tell you that these are\r\nnot mere rumors destitute of foundation which thus disquiet me; but a\r\nserious-minded man, deserving all my confidence, and charged by me to\r\nwatch over the south\xe2\x80\x9d (the duke hesitated as he pronounced these\r\nwords), \xe2\x80\x9chas arrived by post to tell me that a great peril threatens\r\nthe king, and so I hastened to you, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Mala ducis avi domum_,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Louis XVIII., still annotating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes your majesty wish me to drop the subject?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy no means, my dear duke; but just stretch out your hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhichever you please\xe2\x80\x94there to the left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, sire?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you to the left, and you are looking to the right; I mean on my\r\nleft\xe2\x80\x94yes, there. You will find yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s report of the minister of\r\npolice. But here is M. Dandr\xc3\xa9 himself;\xe2\x80\x9d and M. Dandr\xc3\xa9, announced by the\r\nchamberlain-in-waiting, entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis XVIII., with repressed smile, \xe2\x80\x9ccome in, Baron,\r\nand tell the duke all you know\xe2\x80\x94the latest news of M. de Bonaparte; do\r\nnot conceal anything, however serious,\xe2\x80\x94let us see, the Island of Elba\r\nis a volcano, and we may expect to have issuing thence flaming and\r\nbristling war\xe2\x80\x94_bella, horrida bella_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. Dandr\xc3\xa9 leaned very respectfully on the back of a chair with his two\r\nhands, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas your majesty perused yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s report?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes; but tell the duke himself, who cannot find anything, what\r\nthe report contains\xe2\x80\x94give him the particulars of what the usurper is\r\ndoing in his islet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the baron to the duke, \xe2\x80\x9call the servants of his\r\nmajesty must approve of the latest intelligence which we have from the\r\nIsland of Elba. Bonaparte\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. Dandr\xc3\xa9 looked at Louis XVIII., who, employed in writing a note, did\r\nnot even raise his head. \xe2\x80\x9cBonaparte,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the baron, \xe2\x80\x9cis mortally\r\nwearied, and passes whole days in watching his miners at work at\r\nPorto-Longone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd scratches himself for amusement,\xe2\x80\x9d added the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cScratches himself?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the duke, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat does your majesty mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed, my dear duke. Did you forget that this great man, this\r\nhero, this demigod, is attacked with a malady of the skin which worries\r\nhim to death, _prurigo_?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, moreover, my dear duke,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the minister of police, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\r\nare almost assured that, in a very short time, the usurper will be\r\ninsane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInsane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRaving mad; his head becomes weaker. Sometimes he weeps bitterly,\r\nsometimes laughs boisterously, at other time he passes hours on the\r\nseashore, flinging stones in the water and when the flint makes\r\n\xe2\x80\x98duck-and-drake\xe2\x80\x99 five or six times, he appears as delighted as if he\r\nhad gained another Marengo or Austerlitz. Now, you must agree that\r\nthese are indubitable symptoms of insanity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr of wisdom, my dear baron\xe2\x80\x94or of wisdom,\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis XVIII.,\r\nlaughing; \xe2\x80\x9cthe greatest captains of antiquity amused themselves by\r\ncasting pebbles into the ocean\xe2\x80\x94see Plutarch\xe2\x80\x99s life of Scipio\r\nAfricanus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Blacas pondered deeply between the confident monarch and the\r\ntruthful minister. Villefort, who did not choose to reveal the whole\r\nsecret, lest another should reap all the benefit of the disclosure, had\r\nyet communicated enough to cause him the greatest uneasiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well, Dandr\xc3\xa9,\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis XVIII., \xe2\x80\x9cBlacas is not yet convinced;\r\nlet us proceed, therefore, to the usurper\xe2\x80\x99s conversion.\xe2\x80\x9d The minister\r\nof police bowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe usurper\xe2\x80\x99s conversion!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the duke, looking at the king and\r\nDandr\xc3\xa9, who spoke alternately, like Virgil\xe2\x80\x99s shepherds. \xe2\x80\x9cThe usurper\r\nconverted!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDecidedly, my dear duke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what way converted?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo good principles. Tell him all about it, baron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, this is the way of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the minister, with the gravest air\r\nin the world: \xe2\x80\x9cNapoleon lately had a review, and as two or three of his\r\nold veterans expressed a desire to return to France, he gave them their\r\ndismissal, and exhorted them to \xe2\x80\x98serve the good king.\xe2\x80\x99 These were his\r\nown words, of that I am certain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Blacas, what think you of this?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the king triumphantly,\r\nand pausing for a moment from the voluminous scholiast before him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, sire, that the minister of police is greatly deceived or I am;\r\nand as it is impossible it can be the minister of police as he has the\r\nguardianship of the safety and honor of your majesty, it is probable\r\nthat I am in error. However, sire, if I might advise, your majesty will\r\ninterrogate the person of whom I spoke to you, and I will urge your\r\nmajesty to do him this honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost willingly, duke; under your auspices I will receive any person\r\nyou please, but you must not expect me to be too confiding. Baron, have\r\nyou any report more recent than this, dated the 20th February, and this\r\nis the 3rd of March?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sire, but I am hourly expecting one; it may have arrived since I\r\nleft my office.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo thither, and if there be none\xe2\x80\x94well, well,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Louis XVIII.,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmake one; that is the usual way, is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d and the king laughed\r\nfacetiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the minister, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have no occasion to invent any;\r\nevery day our desks are loaded with most circumstantial denunciations,\r\ncoming from hosts of people who hope for some return for services which\r\nthey seek to render, but cannot; they trust to fortune, and rely upon\r\nsome unexpected event in some way to justify their predictions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir, go\xe2\x80\x9d; said Louis XVIII., \xe2\x80\x9cand remember that I am waiting for\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will but go and return, sire; I shall be back in ten minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Blacas, \xe2\x80\x9cwill go and find my messenger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait, sir, wait,\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis XVIII. \xe2\x80\x9cReally, M. de Blacas, I must\r\nchange your armorial bearings; I will give you an eagle with\r\noutstretched wings, holding in its claws a prey which tries in vain to\r\nescape, and bearing this device\xe2\x80\x94_Tenax_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0133m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, I listen,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Blacas, biting his nails with impatience.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish to consult you on this passage, \xe2\x80\x98_Molli fugiens anhelitu_,\xe2\x80\x99 you\r\nknow it refers to a stag flying from a wolf. Are you not a sportsman\r\nand a great wolf-hunter? Well, then, what do you think of the _molli\r\nanhelitu_?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdmirable, sire; but my messenger is like the stag you refer to, for\r\nhe has posted two hundred and twenty leagues in scarcely three days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich is undergoing great fatigue and anxiety, my dear duke, when we\r\nhave a telegraph which transmits messages in three or four hours, and\r\nthat without getting in the least out of breath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, sire, you recompense but badly this poor young man, who has come\r\nso far, and with so much ardor, to give your majesty useful\r\ninformation. If only for the sake of M. de Salvieux, who recommends him\r\nto me, I entreat your majesty to receive him graciously.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Salvieux, my brother\xe2\x80\x99s chamberlain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is at Marseilles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd writes me thence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes he speak to you of this conspiracy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but strongly recommends M. de Villefort, and begs me to present\r\nhim to your majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Villefort!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the king, \xe2\x80\x9cis the messenger\xe2\x80\x99s name M. de\r\nVillefort?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he comes from Marseilles?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you not mention his name at once?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the king, betraying\r\nsome uneasiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, I thought his name was unknown to your majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, Blacas; he is a man of strong and elevated understanding,\r\nambitious, too, and, _pardieu!_ you know his father\xe2\x80\x99s name!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Noirtier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNoirtier the Girondin?\xe2\x80\x94Noirtier the senator?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd your majesty has employed the son of such a man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlacas, my friend, you have but limited comprehension. I told you\r\nVillefort was ambitious, and to attain this ambition Villefort would\r\nsacrifice everything, even his father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, sire, may I present him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis instant, duke! Where is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWaiting below, in my carriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeek him at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hasten to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe duke left the royal presence with the speed of a young man; his\r\nreally sincere royalism made him youthful again. Louis XVIII. remained\r\nalone, and turning his eyes on his half-opened Horace, muttered:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Justum et tenacem propositi virum_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Blacas returned as speedily as he had departed, but in the\r\nantechamber he was forced to appeal to the king\xe2\x80\x99s authority.\r\nVillefort\xe2\x80\x99s dusty garb, his costume, which was not of courtly cut,\r\nexcited the susceptibility of M. de Brez\xc3\xa9, who was all astonishment at\r\nfinding that this young man had the audacity to enter before the king\r\nin such attire. The duke, however, overcame all difficulties with a\r\nword\xe2\x80\x94his majesty\xe2\x80\x99s order; and, in spite of the protestations which the\r\nmaster of ceremonies made for the honor of his office and principles,\r\nVillefort was introduced.\r\n\r\nThe king was seated in the same place where the duke had left him. On\r\nopening the door, Villefort found himself facing him, and the young\r\nmagistrate\xe2\x80\x99s first impulse was to pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in, M. de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, \xe2\x80\x9ccome in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort bowed, and advancing a few steps, waited until the king\r\nshould interrogate him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis XVIII., \xe2\x80\x9cthe Duc de Blacas assures me you\r\nhave some interesting information to communicate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, the duke is right, and I believe your majesty will think it\r\nequally important.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0137m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first place, and before everything else, sir, is the news as\r\nbad in your opinion as I am asked to believe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, I believe it to be most urgent, but I hope, by the speed I have\r\nused, that it is not irreparable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak as fully as you please, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, who began to give\r\nway to the emotion which had showed itself in Blacas\xe2\x80\x99s face and\r\naffected Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s voice. \xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, sir, and pray begin at the\r\nbeginning; I like order in everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cI will render a faithful report to your\r\nmajesty, but I must entreat your forgiveness if my anxiety leads to\r\nsome obscurity in my language.\xe2\x80\x9d A glance at the king after this\r\ndiscreet and subtle exordium, assured Villefort of the benignity of his\r\naugust auditor, and he went on:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, I have come as rapidly to Paris as possible, to inform your\r\nmajesty that I have discovered, in the exercise of my duties, not a\r\ncommonplace and insignificant plot, such as is every day got up in the\r\nlower ranks of the people and in the army, but an actual conspiracy\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nstorm which menaces no less than your majesty\xe2\x80\x99s throne. Sire, the\r\nusurper is arming three ships, he meditates some project, which,\r\nhowever mad, is yet, perhaps, terrible. At this moment he will have\r\nleft Elba, to go whither I know not, but assuredly to attempt a landing\r\neither at Naples, or on the coast of Tuscany, or perhaps on the shores\r\nof France. Your majesty is well aware that the sovereign of the Island\r\nof Elba has maintained his relations with Italy and France?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, much agitated; \xe2\x80\x9cand recently we have had\r\ninformation that the Bonapartist clubs have had meetings in the Rue\r\nSaint-Jacques. But proceed, I beg of you. How did you obtain these\r\ndetails?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, they are the results of an examination which I have made of a\r\nman of Marseilles, whom I have watched for some time, and arrested on\r\nthe day of my departure. This person, a sailor, of turbulent character,\r\nand whom I suspected of Bonapartism, has been secretly to the Island of\r\nElba. There he saw the grand-marshal, who charged him with an oral\r\nmessage to a Bonapartist in Paris, whose name I could not extract from\r\nhim; but this mission was to prepare men\xe2\x80\x99s minds for a return (it is\r\nthe man who says this, sire)\xe2\x80\x94a return which will soon occur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where is this man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn prison, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the matter seems serious to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo serious, sire, that when the circumstance surprised me in the midst\r\nof a family festival, on the very day of my betrothal, I left my bride\r\nand friends, postponing everything, that I might hasten to lay at your\r\nmajesty\xe2\x80\x99s feet the fears which impressed me, and the assurance of my\r\ndevotion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis XVIII., \xe2\x80\x9cwas there not a marriage engagement between\r\nyou and Mademoiselle de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDaughter of one of your majesty\xe2\x80\x99s most faithful servants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes; but let us talk of this plot, M. de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, I fear it is more than a plot; I fear it is a conspiracy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA conspiracy in these times,\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis XVIII., smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cis a thing\r\nvery easy to meditate, but more difficult to conduct to an end,\r\ninasmuch as, re-established so recently on the throne of our ancestors,\r\nwe have our eyes open at once upon the past, the present, and the\r\nfuture. For the last ten months my ministers have redoubled their\r\nvigilance, in order to watch the shore of the Mediterranean. If\r\nBonaparte landed at Naples, the whole coalition would be on foot before\r\nhe could even reach Piombino; if he land in Tuscany, he will be in an\r\nunfriendly territory; if he land in France, it must be with a handful\r\nof men, and the result of that is easily foretold, execrated as he is\r\nby the population. Take courage, sir; but at the same time rely on our\r\nroyal gratitude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, here is M. Dandr\xc3\xa9!\xe2\x80\x9d cried de Blacas. At this instant the minister\r\nof police appeared at the door, pale, trembling, and as if ready to\r\nfaint. Villefort was about to retire, but M. de Blacas, taking his\r\nhand, restrained him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 11. The Corsican Ogre\r\n\r\nAt the sight of this agitation Louis XVIII. pushed from him violently\r\nthe table at which he was sitting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat ails you, baron?\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cYou appear quite aghast. Has\r\nyour uneasiness anything to do with what M. de Blacas has told me, and\r\nM. de Villefort has just confirmed?\xe2\x80\x9d M. de Blacas moved suddenly\r\ntowards the baron, but the fright of the courtier pleaded for the\r\nforbearance of the statesman; and besides, as matters were, it was much\r\nmore to his advantage that the prefect of police should triumph over\r\nhim than that he should humiliate the prefect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d stammered the baron.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what is it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Louis XVIII. The minister of police, giving\r\nway to an impulse of despair, was about to throw himself at the feet of\r\nLouis XVIII., who retreated a step and frowned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you speak?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sire, what a dreadful misfortune! I am, indeed, to be pitied. I\r\ncan never forgive myself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis XVIII., \xe2\x80\x9cI command you to speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sire, the usurper left Elba on the 26th February, and landed on\r\nthe 1st of March.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where? In Italy?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the king eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn France, sire,\xe2\x80\x94at a small port, near Antibes, in the Gulf of Juan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe usurper landed in France, near Antibes, in the Gulf of Juan, two\r\nhundred and fifty leagues from Paris, on the 1st of March, and you only\r\nacquired this information today, the 3rd of March! Well, sir, what you\r\ntell me is impossible. You must have received a false report, or you\r\nhave gone mad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, sire, it is but too true!\xe2\x80\x9d Louis made a gesture of indescribable\r\nanger and alarm, and then drew himself up as if this sudden blow had\r\nstruck him at the same moment in heart and countenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn France!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, \xe2\x80\x9cthe usurper in France! Then they did not watch\r\nover this man. Who knows? they were, perhaps, in league with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Duc de Blacas, \xe2\x80\x9cM. Dandr\xc3\xa9 is not a man to be\r\naccused of treason! Sire, we have all been blind, and the minister of\r\npolice has shared the general blindness, that is all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, and then suddenly checking himself, he was\r\nsilent; then he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cYour pardon, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, bowing, \xe2\x80\x9cmy\r\nzeal carried me away.
