Will your majesty deign to excuse me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, sir, speak boldly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Louis. \xe2\x80\x9cYou alone forewarned us of\r\nthe evil; now try and aid us with the remedy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthe usurper is detested in the south; and it\r\nseems to me that if he ventured into the south, it would be easy to\r\nraise Languedoc and Provence against him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, assuredly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the minister; \xe2\x80\x9cbut he is advancing by Gap and\r\nSisteron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdvancing\xe2\x80\x94he is advancing!\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis XVIII. \xe2\x80\x9cIs he then advancing on\r\nParis?\xe2\x80\x9d The minister of police maintained a silence which was\r\nequivalent to a complete avowal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Dauphin\xc3\xa9, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the king, of Villefort. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think it\r\npossible to rouse that as well as Provence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, I am sorry to tell your majesty a cruel fact; but the feeling in\r\nDauphin\xc3\xa9 is quite the reverse of that in Provence or Languedoc. The\r\nmountaineers are Bonapartists, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Louis, \xe2\x80\x9che was well informed. And how many men had he\r\nwith him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the minister of police.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, you do not know! Have you neglected to obtain information on\r\nthat point? Of course it is of no consequence,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, with a\r\nwithering smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, it was impossible to learn; the despatch simply stated the fact\r\nof the landing and the route taken by the usurper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how did this despatch reach you?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the king. The minister\r\nbowed his head, and while a deep color overspread his cheeks, he\r\nstammered out:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the telegraph, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d Louis XVIII. advanced a step, and folded his\r\narms over his chest as Napoleon would have done.\r\n\r\n0141m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo then,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, turning pale with anger, \xe2\x80\x9cseven conjoined and\r\nallied armies overthrew that man. A miracle of heaven replaced me on\r\nthe throne of my fathers after five-and-twenty years of exile. I have,\r\nduring those five-and-twenty years, spared no pains to understand the\r\npeople of France and the interests which were confided to me; and now,\r\nwhen I see the fruition of my wishes almost within reach, the power I\r\nhold in my hands bursts and shatters me to atoms!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, it is fatality!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the minister, feeling that the\r\npressure of circumstances, however light a thing to destiny, was too\r\nmuch for any human strength to endure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat our enemies say of us is then true. We have learnt nothing,\r\nforgotten nothing! If I were betrayed as he was, I would console\r\nmyself; but to be in the midst of persons elevated by myself to places\r\nof honor, who ought to watch over me more carefully than over\r\nthemselves,\xe2\x80\x94for my fortune is theirs\xe2\x80\x94before me they were nothing\xe2\x80\x94after\r\nme they will be nothing, and perish miserably from\r\nincapacity\xe2\x80\x94ineptitude! Oh, yes, sir, you are right\xe2\x80\x94it is fatality!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe minister quailed before this outburst of sarcasm. M. de Blacas\r\nwiped the moisture from his brow. Villefort smiled within himself, for\r\nhe felt his increased importance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo fall,\xe2\x80\x9d continued King Louis, who at the first glance had sounded\r\nthe abyss on which the monarchy hung suspended,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cto fall, and learn of\r\nthat fall by telegraph! Oh, I would rather mount the scaffold of my\r\nbrother, Louis XVI., than thus descend the staircase at the Tuileries\r\ndriven away by ridicule. Ridicule, sir\xe2\x80\x94why, you know not its power in\r\nFrance, and yet you ought to know it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the minister, \xe2\x80\x9cfor pity\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cApproach, M. de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the king, addressing the young\r\nman, who, motionless and breathless, was listening to a conversation on\r\nwhich depended the destiny of a kingdom. \xe2\x80\x9cApproach, and tell monsieur\r\nthat it is possible to know beforehand all that he has not known.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, it was really impossible to learn secrets which that man\r\nconcealed from all the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally impossible! Yes\xe2\x80\x94that is a great word, sir. Unfortunately, there\r\nare great words, as there are great men; I have measured them. Really\r\nimpossible for a minister who has an office, agents, spies, and fifteen\r\nhundred thousand francs for secret service money, to know what is going\r\non at sixty leagues from the coast of France! Well, then, see, here is\r\na gentleman who had none of these resources at his disposal\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ngentleman, only a simple magistrate, who learned more than you with all\r\nyour police, and who would have saved my crown, if, like you, he had\r\nthe power of directing a telegraph.\xe2\x80\x9d The look of the minister of police\r\nwas turned with concentrated spite on Villefort, who bent his head in\r\nmodest triumph.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not mean that for you, Blacas,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Louis XVIII.; \xe2\x80\x9cfor if\r\nyou have discovered nothing, at least you have had the good sense to\r\npersevere in your suspicions. Any other than yourself would have\r\nconsidered the disclosure of M. de Villefort insignificant, or else\r\ndictated by venal ambition.\xe2\x80\x9d These words were an allusion to the\r\nsentiments which the minister of police had uttered with so much\r\nconfidence an hour before.\r\n\r\nVillefort understood the king\xe2\x80\x99s intent. Any other person would,\r\nperhaps, have been overcome by such an intoxicating draught of praise;\r\nbut he feared to make for himself a mortal enemy of the police\r\nminister, although he saw that Dandr\xc3\xa9 was irrevocably lost. In fact,\r\nthe minister, who, in the plenitude of his power, had been unable to\r\nunearth Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s secret, might in despair at his own downfall\r\ninterrogate Dant\xc3\xa8s and so lay bare the motives of Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s plot.\r\nRealizing this, Villefort came to the rescue of the crest-fallen\r\nminister, instead of aiding to crush him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthe suddenness of this event must prove to\r\nyour majesty that the issue is in the hands of Providence; what your\r\nmajesty is pleased to attribute to me as profound perspicacity is\r\nsimply owing to chance, and I have profited by that chance, like a good\r\nand devoted servant\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all. Do not attribute to me more than I\r\ndeserve, sire, that your majesty may never have occasion to recall the\r\nfirst opinion you have been pleased to form of me.\xe2\x80\x9d The minister of\r\npolice thanked the young man by an eloquent look, and Villefort\r\nunderstood that he had succeeded in his design; that is to say, that\r\nwithout forfeiting the gratitude of the king, he had made a friend of\r\none on whom, in case of necessity, he might rely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis well,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the king. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued,\r\nturning towards M. de Blacas and the minister of police, \xe2\x80\x9cI have no\r\nfurther occasion for you, and you may retire; what now remains to do is\r\nin the department of the minister of war.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFortunately, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Blacas, \xe2\x80\x9cwe can rely on the army; your\r\nmajesty knows how every report confirms their loyalty and attachment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not mention reports, duke, to me, for I know now what confidence to\r\nplace in them. Yet, speaking of reports, baron, what have you learned\r\nwith regard to the affair in the Rue Saint-Jacques?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe affair in the Rue Saint-Jacques!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Villefort, unable to\r\nrepress an exclamation. Then, suddenly pausing, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cYour pardon,\r\nsire, but my devotion to your majesty has made me forget, not the\r\nrespect I have, for that is too deeply engraved in my heart, but the\r\nrules of etiquette.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, go on, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the king; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have today earned the right\r\nto make inquiries here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed the minister of police, \xe2\x80\x9cI came a moment ago to give\r\nyour majesty fresh information which I had obtained on this head, when\r\nyour majesty\xe2\x80\x99s attention was attracted by the terrible event that has\r\noccurred in the gulf, and now these facts will cease to interest your\r\nmajesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, sir,\xe2\x80\x94on the contrary,\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis XVIII., \xe2\x80\x9cthis\r\naffair seems to me to have a decided connection with that which\r\noccupies our attention, and the death of General Quesnel will, perhaps,\r\nput us on the direct track of a great internal conspiracy.\xe2\x80\x9d At the name\r\nof General Quesnel, Villefort trembled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverything points to the conclusion, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d said the minister of\r\npolice, \xe2\x80\x9cthat death was not the result of suicide, as we first\r\nbelieved, but of assassination. General Quesnel, it appears, had just\r\nleft a Bonapartist club when he disappeared. An unknown person had been\r\nwith him that morning, and made an appointment with him in the Rue\r\nSaint-Jacques; unfortunately, the general\xe2\x80\x99s valet, who was dressing his\r\nhair at the moment when the stranger entered, heard the street\r\nmentioned, but did not catch the number.\xe2\x80\x9d As the police minister\r\nrelated this to the king, Villefort, who looked as if his very life\r\nhung on the speaker\xe2\x80\x99s lips, turned alternately red and pale. The king\r\nlooked towards him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you not think with me, M. de Villefort, that General Quesnel, whom\r\nthey believed attached to the usurper, but who was really entirely\r\ndevoted to me, has perished the victim of a Bonapartist ambush?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is probable, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort. \xe2\x80\x9cBut is this all that is\r\nknown?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are on the track of the man who appointed the meeting with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn his track?\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the servant has given his description. He is a man of from fifty\r\nto fifty-two years of age, dark, with black eyes covered with shaggy\r\neyebrows, and a thick moustache. He was dressed in a blue frock-coat,\r\nbuttoned up to the chin, and wore at his button-hole the rosette of an\r\nofficer of the Legion of Honor. Yesterday a person exactly\r\ncorresponding with this description was followed, but he was lost sight\r\nof at the corner of the Rue de la Jussienne and the Rue Coq-H\xc3\xa9ron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nVillefort leaned on the back of an armchair, for as the minister of\r\npolice went on speaking he felt his legs bend under him; but when he\r\nlearned that the unknown had escaped the vigilance of the agent who\r\nfollowed him, he breathed again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cContinue to seek for this man, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king to the minister of\r\npolice; \xe2\x80\x9cfor if, as I am all but convinced, General Quesnel, who would\r\nhave been so useful to us at this moment, has been murdered, his\r\nassassins, Bonapartists or not, shall be cruelly punished.\xe2\x80\x9d It required\r\nall Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s coolness not to betray the terror with which this\r\ndeclaration of the king inspired him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow strange,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the king, with some asperity; \xe2\x80\x9cthe police\r\nthink that they have disposed of the whole matter when they say, \xe2\x80\x98A\r\nmurder has been committed,\xe2\x80\x99 and especially so when they can add, \xe2\x80\x98And\r\nwe are on the track of the guilty persons.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, your majesty will, I trust, be amply satisfied on this point at\r\nleast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see. I will no longer detain you, M. de Villefort, for you\r\nmust be fatigued after so long a journey; go and rest. Of course you\r\nstopped at your father\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d A feeling of faintness came over Villefort.\r\n\r\n0145m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cI alighted at the Hotel de Madrid, in the Rue\r\nde Tournon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have seen him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, I went straight to the Duc de Blacas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you will see him, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think not, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, I forgot,\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis, smiling in a manner which proved that all\r\nthese questions were not made without a motive; \xe2\x80\x9cI forgot you and M.\r\nNoirtier are not on the best terms possible, and that is another\r\nsacrifice made to the royal cause, and for which you should be\r\nrecompensed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, the kindness your majesty deigns to evince towards me is a\r\nrecompense which so far surpasses my utmost ambition that I have\r\nnothing more to ask for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind, sir, we will not forget you; make your mind easy. In the\r\nmeanwhile\xe2\x80\x9d (the king here detached the cross of the Legion of Honor\r\nwhich he usually wore over his blue coat, near the cross of St. Louis,\r\nabove the order of Notre-Dame-du-Mont-Carmel and St. Lazare, and gave\r\nit to Villefort)\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cin the meanwhile take this cross.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cyour majesty mistakes; this is an officer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncross.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Louis XVIII., \xe2\x80\x9ctake it, such as it is, for I have not\r\nthe time to procure you another. Blacas, let it be your care to see\r\nthat the brevet is made out and sent to M. de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s\r\neyes were filled with tears of joy and pride; he took the cross and\r\nkissed it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmay I inquire what are the orders with which your\r\nmajesty deigns to honor me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake what rest you require, and remember that if you are not able to\r\nserve me here in Paris, you may be of the greatest service to me at\r\nMarseilles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, bowing, \xe2\x80\x9cin an hour I shall have quitted\r\nParis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king; \xe2\x80\x9cand should I forget you (kings\xe2\x80\x99 memories are\r\nshort), do not be afraid to bring yourself to my recollection. Baron,\r\nsend for the minister of war. Blacas, remain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the minister of police to Villefort, as they left the\r\nTuileries, \xe2\x80\x9cyou entered by luck\xe2\x80\x99s door\xe2\x80\x94your fortune is made.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill it be long first?\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Villefort, saluting the minister,\r\nwhose career was ended, and looking about him for a hackney-coach. One\r\npassed at the moment, which he hailed; he gave his address to the\r\ndriver, and springing in, threw himself on the seat, and gave loose to\r\ndreams of ambition.\r\n\r\nTen minutes afterwards Villefort reached his hotel, ordered horses to\r\nbe ready in two hours, and asked to have his breakfast brought to him.\r\nHe was about to begin his repast when the sound of the bell rang sharp\r\nand loud. The valet opened the door, and Villefort heard someone speak\r\nhis name.\r\n\r\n0147m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho could know that I was here already?\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man. The valet\r\nentered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is it?\xe2\x80\x94Who rang?\xe2\x80\x94Who asked for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA stranger who will not send in his name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA stranger who will not send in his name! What can he want with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe wishes to speak to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he mention my name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat sort of person is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, sir, a man of about fifty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShort or tall?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout your own height, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDark or fair?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDark,\xe2\x80\x94very dark; with black eyes, black hair, black eyebrows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how dressed?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Villefort quickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn a blue frock-coat, buttoned up close, decorated with the Legion of\r\nHonor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is he!\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, turning pale.\r\n\r\n0148m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, _pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said the individual whose description we have twice\r\ngiven, entering the door, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a great deal of ceremony! Is it the\r\ncustom in Marseilles for sons to keep their fathers waiting in their\r\nanterooms?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthen I was not deceived; I felt sure it\r\nmust be you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, if you felt so sure,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the new-comer, putting his\r\ncane in a corner and his hat on a chair, \xe2\x80\x9callow me to say, my dear\r\nG\xc3\xa9rard, that it was not very filial of you to keep me waiting at the\r\ndoor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave us, Germain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort. The servant quitted the apartment\r\nwith evident signs of astonishment.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 12. Father and Son\r\n\r\nM. Noirtier\xe2\x80\x94for it was, indeed, he who entered\xe2\x80\x94looked after the servant\r\nuntil the door was closed, and then, fearing, no doubt, that he might\r\nbe overheard in the antechamber, he opened the door again, nor was the\r\nprecaution useless, as appeared from the rapid retreat of Germain, who\r\nproved that he was not exempt from the sin which ruined our first\r\nparents. M. Noirtier then took the trouble to close and bolt the\r\nantechamber door, then that of the bedchamber, and then extended his\r\nhand to Villefort, who had followed all his motions with surprise which\r\nhe could not conceal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, my dear G\xc3\xa9rard,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the young man, with a very\r\nsignificant look, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know, you seem as if you were not very glad\r\nto see me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cI am, on the contrary, delighted;\r\nbut I so little expected your visit, that it has somewhat overcome me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. Noirtier, seating himself, \xe2\x80\x9cI might\r\nsay the same thing to you, when you announce to me your wedding for the\r\n28th of February, and on the 3rd of March you turn up here in Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if I have come, my dear father,\xe2\x80\x9d said G\xc3\xa9rard, drawing closer to M.\r\nNoirtier, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not complain, for it is for you that I came, and my\r\njourney will be your salvation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said M. Noirtier, stretching himself out at his ease in\r\nthe chair. \xe2\x80\x9cReally, pray tell me all about it, for it must be\r\ninteresting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather, you have heard speak of a certain Bonapartist club in the Rue\r\nSaint-Jacques?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. 53; yes, I am vice-president.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather, your coolness makes me shudder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, my dear boy, when a man has been proscribed by the mountaineers,\r\nhas escaped from Paris in a hay-cart, been hunted over the plains of\r\nBordeaux by Robespierre\xe2\x80\x99s bloodhounds, he becomes accustomed to most\r\nthings. But go on, what about the club in the Rue Saint-Jacques?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, they induced General Quesnel to go there, and General Quesnel,\r\nwho quitted his own house at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening, was found the\r\nnext day in the Seine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0151m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who told you this fine story?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe king himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, in return for your story,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Noirtier, \xe2\x80\x9cI will\r\ntell you another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear father, I think I already know what you are about to tell me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you have heard of the landing of the emperor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so loud, father, I entreat of you\xe2\x80\x94for your own sake as well as\r\nmine. Yes, I heard this news, and knew it even before you could; for\r\nthree days ago I posted from Marseilles to Paris with all possible\r\nspeed, half-desperate at the enforced delay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree days ago? You are crazy. Why, three days ago the emperor had not\r\nlanded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo matter, I was aware of his intention.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did you know about it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy a letter addressed to you from the Island of Elba.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo you; and which I discovered in the pocket-book of the messenger.\r\nHad that letter fallen into the hands of another, you, my dear father,\r\nwould probably ere this have been shot.\xe2\x80\x9d Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s father laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwill the Restoration adopt imperial methods so\r\npromptly? Shot, my dear boy? What an idea! Where is the letter you\r\nspeak of? I know you too well to suppose you would allow such a thing\r\nto pass you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI burnt it, for fear that even a fragment should remain; for that\r\nletter must have led to your condemnation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the destruction of your future prospects,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Noirtier; \xe2\x80\x9cyes,\r\nI can easily comprehend that. But I have nothing to fear while I have\r\nyou to protect me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do better than that, sir\xe2\x80\x94I save you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do? Why, really, the thing becomes more and more dramatic\xe2\x80\x94explain\r\nyourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must refer again to the club in the Rue Saint-Jacques.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears that this club is rather a bore to the police. Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthey search more vigilantly? they would have found\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have not found; but they are on the track.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that the usual phrase; I am quite familiar with it. When the\r\npolice is at fault, it declares that it is on the track; and the\r\ngovernment patiently awaits the day when it comes to say, with a\r\nsneaking air, that the track is lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but they have found a corpse; the general has been killed, and in\r\nall countries they call that a murder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA murder do you call it? why, there is nothing to prove that the\r\ngeneral was murdered. People are found every day in the Seine, having\r\nthrown themselves in, or having been drowned from not knowing how to\r\nswim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather, you know very well that the general was not a man to drown\r\nhimself in despair, and people do not bathe in the Seine in the month\r\nof January. No, no, do not be deceived; this was murder in every sense\r\nof the word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who thus designated it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe king himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe king! I thought he was philosopher enough to allow that there was\r\nno murder in politics. In politics, my dear fellow, you know, as well\r\nas I do, there are no men, but ideas\xe2\x80\x94no feelings, but interests; in\r\npolitics we do not kill a man, we only remove an obstacle, that is all.\r\nWould you like to know how matters have progressed? Well, I will tell\r\nyou. It was thought reliance might be placed in General Quesnel; he was\r\nrecommended to us from the Island of Elba; one of us went to him, and\r\ninvited him to the Rue Saint-Jacques, where he would find some friends.\r\nHe came there, and the plan was unfolded to him for leaving Elba, the\r\nprojected landing, etc. When he had heard and comprehended all to the\r\nfullest extent, he replied that he was a royalist. Then all looked at\r\neach other,\xe2\x80\x94he was made to take an oath, and did so, but with such an\r\nill grace that it was really tempting Providence to swear thus, and\r\nyet, in spite of that, the general was allowed to depart free\xe2\x80\x94perfectly\r\nfree. Yet he did not return home. What could that mean? why, my dear\r\nfellow, that on leaving us he lost his way, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. A murder?\r\nreally, Villefort, you surprise me. You, a deputy procureur, to found\r\nan accusation on such bad premises! Did I ever say to you, when you\r\nwere fulfilling your character as a royalist, and cut off the head of\r\none of my party, \xe2\x80\x98My son, you have committed a murder?\xe2\x80\x99 No, I said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Very well, sir, you have gained the victory; tomorrow, perchance, it\r\nwill be our turn.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, father, take care; when our turn comes, our revenge will be\r\nsweeping.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not understand you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou rely on the usurper\xe2\x80\x99s return?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken; he will not advance two leagues into the interior of\r\nFrance without being followed, tracked, and caught like a wild beast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow, the emperor is at this moment on the way to Grenoble;\r\non the 10th or 12th he will be at Lyons, and on the 20th or 25th at\r\nParis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe people will rise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, to go and meet him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has but a handful of men with him, and armies will be despatched\r\nagainst him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, to escort him into the capital. Really, my dear G\xc3\xa9rard, you are\r\nbut a child; you think yourself well informed because the telegraph has\r\ntold you, three days after the landing, \xe2\x80\x98The usurper has landed at\r\nCannes with several men. He is pursued.\xe2\x80\x99 But where is he? what is he\r\ndoing? You do not know at all, and in this way they will chase him to\r\nParis, without drawing a trigger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrenoble and Lyons are faithful cities, and will oppose to him an\r\nimpassable barrier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrenoble will open her gates to him with enthusiasm\xe2\x80\x94all Lyons will\r\nhasten to welcome him. Believe me, we are as well informed as you, and\r\nour police are as good as your own. Would you like a proof of it? well,\r\nyou wished to conceal your journey from me, and yet I knew of your\r\narrival half an hour after you had passed the barrier. You gave your\r\ndirection to no one but your postilion, yet I have your address, and in\r\nproof I am here the very instant you are going to sit at table. Ring,\r\nthen, if you please, for a second knife, fork, and plate, and we will\r\ndine together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, looking at his father with astonishment,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou really do seem very well informed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh? the thing is simple enough. You who are in power have only the\r\nmeans that money produces\xe2\x80\x94we who are in expectation, have those which\r\ndevotion prompts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDevotion!\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, with a sneer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, devotion; for that is, I believe, the phrase for hopeful\r\nambition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s father extended his hand to the bell-rope, to summon\r\nthe servant whom his son had not called. Villefort caught his arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait, my dear father,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cone word more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHowever stupid the royalist police may be, they do know one terrible\r\nthing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe description of the man who, on the morning of the day when General\r\nQuesnel disappeared, presented himself at his house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the admirable police have found that out, have they? And what may\r\nbe that description?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDark complexion; hair, eyebrows, and whiskers black; blue frock-coat,\r\nbuttoned up to the chin; rosette of an officer of the Legion of Honor\r\nin his button-hole; a hat with wide brim, and a cane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ha, that\xe2\x80\x99s it, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Noirtier; \xe2\x80\x9cand why, then, have they\r\nnot laid hands on him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause yesterday, or the day before, they lost sight of him at the\r\ncorner of the Rue Coq-H\xc3\xa9ron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidn\xe2\x80\x99t I say that your police were good for nothing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but they may catch him yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noirtier, looking carelessly around him, \xe2\x80\x9ctrue, if this\r\nperson were not on his guard, as he is;\xe2\x80\x9d and he added with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cHe\r\nwill consequently make a few changes in his personal appearance.\xe2\x80\x9d At\r\nthese words he rose, and put off his frock-coat and cravat, went\r\ntowards a table on which lay his son\xe2\x80\x99s toilet articles, lathered his\r\nface, took a razor, and, with a firm hand, cut off the compromising\r\nwhiskers. Villefort watched him with alarm not devoid of admiration.\r\n\r\nHis whiskers cut off, Noirtier gave another turn to his hair; took,\r\ninstead of his black cravat, a colored neckerchief which lay at the top\r\nof an open portmanteau; put on, in lieu of his blue and high-buttoned\r\nfrock-coat, a coat of Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s of dark brown, and cut away in front;\r\ntried on before the glass a narrow-brimmed hat of his son\xe2\x80\x99s, which\r\nappeared to fit him perfectly, and, leaving his cane in the corner\r\nwhere he had deposited it, he took up a small bamboo switch, cut the\r\nair with it once or twice, and walked about with that easy swagger\r\nwhich was one of his principal characteristics.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, turning towards his wondering son, when this disguise\r\nwas completed, \xe2\x80\x9cwell, do you think your police will recognize me now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, father,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cat least, I hope not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, my dear boy,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Noirtier, \xe2\x80\x9cI rely on your prudence to\r\nremove all the things which I leave in your care.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, rely on me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes; and now I believe you are right, and that you have really\r\nsaved my life; be assured I will return the favor hereafter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are not convinced yet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope at least, that you may be mistaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall you see the king again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you pass in his eyes for a prophet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProphets of evil are not in favor at the court, father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, but some day they do them justice; and supposing a second\r\nrestoration, you would then pass for a great man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what should I say to the king?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay this to him: \xe2\x80\x98Sire, you are deceived as to the feeling in France,\r\nas to the opinions of the towns, and the prejudices of the army; he\r\nwhom in Paris you call the Corsican ogre, who at Nevers is styled the\r\nusurper, is already saluted as Bonaparte at Lyons, and emperor at\r\nGrenoble. You think he is tracked, pursued, captured; he is advancing\r\nas rapidly as his own eagles. The soldiers you believe to be dying with\r\nhunger, worn out with fatigue, ready to desert, gather like atoms of\r\nsnow about the rolling ball as it hastens onward. Sire, go, leave\r\nFrance to its real master, to him who acquired it, not by purchase, but\r\nby right of conquest; go, sire, not that you incur any risk, for your\r\nadversary is powerful enough to show you mercy, but because it would be\r\nhumiliating for a grandson of Saint Louis to owe his life to the man of\r\nArcola, Marengo, Austerlitz.\xe2\x80\x99 Tell him this, G\xc3\xa9rard; or, rather, tell\r\nhim nothing. Keep your journey a secret; do not boast of what you have\r\ncome to Paris to do, or have done; return with all speed; enter\r\nMarseilles at night, and your house by the back-door, and there remain,\r\nquiet, submissive, secret, and, above all, inoffensive; for this time,\r\nI swear to you, we shall act like powerful men who know their enemies.\r\nGo, my son\xe2\x80\x94go, my dear G\xc3\xa9rard, and by your obedience to my paternal\r\norders, or, if you prefer it, friendly counsels, we will keep you in\r\nyour place. This will be,\xe2\x80\x9d added Noirtier, with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cone means by\r\nwhich you may a second time save me, if the political balance should\r\nsome day take another turn, and cast you aloft while hurling me down.\r\nAdieu, my dear G\xc3\xa9rard, and at your next journey alight at my door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier left the room when he had finished, with the same calmness\r\nthat had characterized him during the whole of this remarkable and\r\ntrying conversation. Villefort, pale and agitated, ran to the window,\r\nput aside the curtain, and saw him pass, cool and collected, by two or\r\nthree ill-looking men at the corner of the street, who were there,\r\nperhaps, to arrest a man with black whiskers, and a blue frock-coat,\r\nand hat with broad brim.\r\n\r\nVillefort stood watching, breathless, until his father had disappeared\r\nat the Rue Bussy. Then he turned to the various articles he had left\r\nbehind him, put the black cravat and blue frock-coat at the bottom of\r\nthe portmanteau, threw the hat into a dark closet, broke the cane into\r\nsmall bits and flung it in the fire, put on his travelling-cap, and\r\ncalling his valet, checked with a look the thousand questions he was\r\nready to ask, paid his bill, sprang into his carriage, which was ready,\r\nlearned at Lyons that Bonaparte had entered Grenoble, and in the midst\r\nof the tumult which prevailed along the road, at length reached\r\nMarseilles, a prey to all the hopes and fears which enter into the\r\nheart of man with ambition and its first successes.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 13. The Hundred Days\r\n\r\nM. Noirtier was a true prophet, and things progressed rapidly, as he\r\nhad predicted. Everyone knows the history of the famous return from\r\nElba, a return which was unprecedented in the past, and will probably\r\nremain without a counterpart in the future.\r\n\r\nLouis XVIII. made but a faint attempt to parry this unexpected blow;\r\nthe monarchy he had scarcely reconstructed tottered on its precarious\r\nfoundation, and at a sign from the emperor the incongruous structure of\r\nancient prejudices and new ideas fell to the ground. Villefort,\r\ntherefore, gained nothing save the king\xe2\x80\x99s gratitude (which was rather\r\nlikely to injure him at the present time) and the cross of the Legion\r\nof Honor, which he had the prudence not to wear, although M. de Blacas\r\nhad duly forwarded the brevet.\r\n\r\nNapoleon would, doubtless, have deprived Villefort of his office had it\r\nnot been for Noirtier, who was all powerful at court, and thus the\r\nGirondin of \xe2\x80\x9993 and the Senator of 1806 protected him who so lately had\r\nbeen his protector. All Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s influence barely enabled him to\r\nstifle the secret Dant\xc3\xa8s had so nearly divulged. The king\xe2\x80\x99s procureur\r\nalone was deprived of his office, being suspected of royalism.\r\n\r\nHowever, scarcely was the imperial power established\xe2\x80\x94that is, scarcely\r\nhad the emperor re-entered the Tuileries and begun to issue orders from\r\nthe closet into which we have introduced our readers,\xe2\x80\x94he found on the\r\ntable there Louis XVIII.\xe2\x80\x99s half-filled snuff-box,\xe2\x80\x94scarcely had this\r\noccurred when Marseilles began, in spite of the authorities, to\r\nrekindle the flames of civil war, always smouldering in the south, and\r\nit required but little to excite the populace to acts of far greater\r\nviolence than the shouts and insults with which they assailed the\r\nroyalists whenever they ventured abroad.\r\n\r\n0159m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOwing to this change, the worthy shipowner became at that moment\xe2\x80\x94we\r\nwill not say all powerful, because Morrel was a prudent and rather a\r\ntimid man, so much so, that many of the most zealous partisans of\r\nBonaparte accused him of \xe2\x80\x9cmoderation\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94but sufficiently influential to\r\nmake a demand in favor of Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\nVillefort retained his place, but his marriage was put off until a more\r\nfavorable opportunity. If the emperor remained on the throne, G\xc3\xa9rard\r\nrequired a different alliance to aid his career; if Louis XVIII.\r\nreturned, the influence of M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, like his own, could be\r\nvastly increased, and the marriage be still more suitable. The deputy\r\nprocureur was, therefore, the first magistrate of Marseilles, when one\r\nmorning his door opened, and M. Morrel was announced.\r\n\r\nAnyone else would have hastened to receive him; but Villefort was a man\r\nof ability, and he knew this would be a sign of weakness. He made\r\nMorrel wait in the antechamber, although he had no one with him, for\r\nthe simple reason that the king\xe2\x80\x99s procureur always makes everyone wait,\r\nand after passing a quarter of an hour in reading the papers, he\r\nordered M. Morrel to be admitted.\r\n\r\nMorrel expected Villefort would be dejected; he found him as he had\r\nfound him six weeks before, calm, firm, and full of that glacial\r\npoliteness, that most insurmountable barrier which separates the\r\nwell-bred from the vulgar man.\r\n\r\nHe had entered Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s office expecting that the magistrate would\r\ntremble at the sight of him; on the contrary, he felt a cold shudder\r\nall over him when he saw Villefort sitting there with his elbow on his\r\ndesk, and his head leaning on his hand. He stopped at the door;\r\nVillefort gazed at him as if he had some difficulty in recognizing him;\r\nthen, after a brief interval, during which the honest shipowner turned\r\nhis hat in his hands,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Morrel, I believe?\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome nearer,\xe2\x80\x9d said the magistrate, with a patronizing wave of the\r\nhand, \xe2\x80\x9cand tell me to what circumstance I owe the honor of this visit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you not guess, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot in the least; but if I can serve you in any way I shall be\r\ndelighted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverything depends on you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain yourself, pray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, recovering his assurance as he proceeded, \xe2\x80\x9cdo\r\nyou recollect that a few days before the landing of his majesty the\r\nemperor, I came to intercede for a young man, the mate of my ship, who\r\nwas accused of being concerned in correspondence with the Island of\r\nElba? What was the other day a crime is today a title to favor. You\r\nthen served Louis XVIII., and you did not show any favor\xe2\x80\x94it was your\r\nduty; today you serve Napoleon, and you ought to protect him\xe2\x80\x94it is\r\nequally your duty; I come, therefore, to ask what has become of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0161m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVillefort by a strong effort sought to control himself. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is his\r\nname?\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cTell me his name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdmond Dant\xc3\xa8s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort would probably have rather stood opposite the muzzle of a\r\npistol at five-and-twenty paces than have heard this name spoken; but\r\nhe did not blanch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDant\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated he, \xe2\x80\x9cEdmond Dant\xc3\xa8s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d Villefort opened a large register, then went to a\r\ntable, from the table turned to his registers, and then, turning to\r\nMorrel,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you quite sure you are not mistaken, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in the\r\nmost natural tone in the world.\r\n\r\nHad Morrel been a more quick-sighted man, or better versed in these\r\nmatters, he would have been surprised at the king\xe2\x80\x99s procureur answering\r\nhim on such a subject, instead of referring him to the governors of the\r\nprison or the prefect of the department. But Morrel, disappointed in\r\nhis expectations of exciting fear, was conscious only of the other\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncondescension. Villefort had calculated rightly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cI am not mistaken. I have known him for ten years,\r\nthe last four of which he was in my service. Do not you recollect, I\r\ncame about six weeks ago to plead for clemency, as I come today to\r\nplead for justice. You received me very coldly. Oh, the royalists were\r\nvery severe with the Bonapartists in those days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cI was then a royalist, because I\r\nbelieved the Bourbons not only the heirs to the throne, but the chosen\r\nof the nation. The miraculous return of Napoleon has conquered me, the\r\nlegitimate monarch is he who is loved by his people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morrel. \xe2\x80\x9cI like to hear you speak thus, and I\r\naugur well for Edmond from it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, turning over the leaves of a register;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have it\xe2\x80\x94a sailor, who was about to marry a young Catalan girl. I\r\nrecollect now; it was a very serious charge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know that when he left here he was taken to the Palais de\r\nJustice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI made my report to the authorities at Paris, and a week after he was\r\ncarried off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarried off!\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat can they have done with him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he has been taken to Fenestrelles, to Pignerol, or to the\r\nSainte-Margu\xc3\xa9rite islands. Some fine morning he will return to take\r\ncommand of your vessel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome when he will, it shall be kept for him. But how is it he is not\r\nalready returned? It seems to me the first care of government should be\r\nto set at liberty those who have suffered for their adherence to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not be too hasty, M. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort. \xe2\x80\x9cThe order of\r\nimprisonment came from high authority, and the order for his liberation\r\nmust proceed from the same source; and, as Napoleon has scarcely been\r\nreinstated a fortnight, the letters have not yet been forwarded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cis there no way of expediting all these\r\nformalities\xe2\x80\x94of releasing him from arrest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere has been no arrest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is sometimes essential to government to cause a man\xe2\x80\x99s disappearance\r\nwithout leaving any traces, so that no written forms or documents may\r\ndefeat their wishes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt might be so under the Bourbons, but at present\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt has always been so, my dear Morrel, since the reign of Louis XIV.\r\nThe emperor is more strict in prison discipline than even Louis\r\nhimself, and the number of prisoners whose names are not on the\r\nregister is incalculable.\xe2\x80\x9d Had Morrel even any suspicions, so much\r\nkindness would have dispelled them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, M. de Villefort, how would you advise me to act?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPetition the minister.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I know what that is; the minister receives two hundred petitions\r\nevery day, and does not read three.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true; but he will read a petition countersigned and presented\r\nby me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd will you undertake to deliver it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith the greatest pleasure. Dant\xc3\xa8s was then guilty, and now he is\r\ninnocent, and it is as much my duty to free him as it was to condemn\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d Villefort thus forestalled any danger of an inquiry, which,\r\nhowever improbable it might be, if it did take place would leave him\r\ndefenceless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how shall I address the minister?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, giving up his place to Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nwrite what I dictate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you be so good?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly. But lose no time; we have lost too much already.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true. Only think what the poor fellow may even now be\r\nsuffering.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort shuddered at the suggestion; but he had gone too far to draw\r\nback. Dant\xc3\xa8s must be crushed to gratify Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s ambition.\r\n\r\nVillefort dictated a petition, in which, from an excellent intention,\r\nno doubt, Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 patriotic services were exaggerated, and he was made\r\nout one of the most active agents of Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s return. It was evident\r\nthat at the sight of this document the minister would instantly release\r\nhim. The petition finished, Villefort read it aloud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will do,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cleave the rest to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill the petition go soon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCountersigned by you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe best thing I can do will be to certify the truth of the contents\r\nof your petition.\xe2\x80\x9d And, sitting down, Villefort wrote the certificate\r\nat the bottom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat more is to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do whatever is necessary.\xe2\x80\x9d This assurance delighted Morrel, who\r\ntook leave of Villefort, and hastened to announce to old Dant\xc3\xa8s that he\r\nwould soon see his son.\r\n\r\nAs for Villefort, instead of sending to Paris, he carefully preserved\r\nthe petition that so fearfully compromised Dant\xc3\xa8s, in the hopes of an\r\nevent that seemed not unlikely,\xe2\x80\x94that is, a second restoration. Dant\xc3\xa8s\r\nremained a prisoner, and heard not the noise of the fall of Louis\r\nXVIII.\xe2\x80\x99s throne, or the still more tragic destruction of the empire.\r\n\r\nTwice during the Hundred Days had Morrel renewed his demand, and twice\r\nhad Villefort soothed him with promises. At last there was Waterloo,\r\nand Morrel came no more; he had done all that was in his power, and any\r\nfresh attempt would only compromise himself uselessly.\r\n\r\nLouis XVIII. remounted the throne; Villefort, to whom Marseilles had\r\nbecome filled with remorseful memories, sought and obtained the\r\nsituation of king\xe2\x80\x99s procureur at Toulouse, and a fortnight afterwards\r\nhe married Mademoiselle de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, whose father now stood higher\r\nat court than ever.\r\n\r\nAnd so Dant\xc3\xa8s, after the Hundred Days and after Waterloo, remained in\r\nhis dungeon, forgotten of earth and heaven.\r\n\r\nDanglars comprehended the full extent of the wretched fate that\r\noverwhelmed Dant\xc3\xa8s; and, when Napoleon returned to France, he, after\r\nthe manner of mediocre minds, termed the coincidence, _a decree of\r\nProvidence_. But when Napoleon returned to Paris, Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 heart\r\nfailed him, and he lived in constant fear of Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 return on a\r\nmission of vengeance. He therefore informed M. Morrel of his wish to\r\nquit the sea, and obtained a recommendation from him to a Spanish\r\nmerchant, into whose service he entered at the end of March, that is,\r\nten or twelve days after Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s return. He then left for Madrid,\r\nand was no more heard of.\r\n\r\nFernand understood nothing except that Dant\xc3\xa8s was absent. What had\r\nbecome of him he cared not to inquire. Only, during the respite the\r\nabsence of his rival afforded him, he reflected, partly on the means of\r\ndeceiving Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s as to the cause of his absence, partly on plans of\r\nemigration and abduction, as from time to time he sat sad and\r\nmotionless on the summit of Cape Pharo, at the spot from whence\r\nMarseilles and the Catalans are visible, watching for the apparition of\r\na young and handsome man, who was for him also the messenger of\r\nvengeance. Fernand\xe2\x80\x99s mind was made up; he would shoot Dant\xc3\xa8s, and then\r\nkill himself. But Fernand was mistaken; a man of his disposition never\r\nkills himself, for he constantly hopes.\r\n\r\nDuring this time the empire made its last conscription, and every man\r\nin France capable of bearing arms rushed to obey the summons of the\r\nemperor. Fernand departed with the rest, bearing with him the terrible\r\nthought that while he was away, his rival would perhaps return and\r\nmarry Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s. Had Fernand really meant to kill himself, he would have\r\ndone so when he parted from Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s. His devotion, and the compassion\r\nhe showed for her misfortunes, produced the effect they always produce\r\non noble minds\xe2\x80\x94Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s had always had a sincere regard for Fernand,\r\nand this was now strengthened by gratitude.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, as she placed his knapsack on his shoulders,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbe careful of yourself, for if you are killed, I shall be alone in the\r\nworld.\xe2\x80\x9d These words carried a ray of hope into Fernand\xe2\x80\x99s heart. Should\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s not return, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s might one day be his.\r\n\r\n0165m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s was left alone face to face with the vast plain that had never\r\nseemed so barren, and the sea that had never seemed so vast. Bathed in\r\ntears she wandered about the Catalan village. Sometimes she stood mute\r\nand motionless as a statue, looking towards Marseilles, at other times\r\ngazing on the sea, and debating as to whether it were not better to\r\ncast herself into the abyss of the ocean, and thus end her woes. It was\r\nnot want of courage that prevented her putting this resolution into\r\nexecution; but her religious feelings came to her aid and saved her.\r\n\r\nCaderousse was, like Fernand, enrolled in the army, but, being married\r\nand eight years older, he was merely sent to the frontier. Old Dant\xc3\xa8s,\r\nwho was only sustained by hope, lost all hope at Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s downfall.\r\nFive months after he had been separated from his son, and almost at the\r\nhour of his arrest, he breathed his last in Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 arms. M. Morrel\r\npaid the expenses of his funeral, and a few small debts the poor old\r\nman had contracted.\r\n\r\nThere was more than benevolence in this action; there was courage; the\r\nsouth was aflame, and to assist, even on his death-bed, the father of\r\nso dangerous a Bonapartist as Dant\xc3\xa8s, was stigmatized as a crime.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 14. The Two Prisoners\r\n\r\nA year after Louis XVIII.\xe2\x80\x99s restoration, a visit was made by the\r\ninspector-general of prisons. Dant\xc3\xa8s in his cell heard the noise of\r\npreparation,\xe2\x80\x94sounds that at the depth where he lay would have been\r\ninaudible to any but the ear of a prisoner, who could hear the splash\r\nof the drop of water that every hour fell from the roof of his dungeon.\r\nHe guessed something uncommon was passing among the living; but he had\r\nso long ceased to have any intercourse with the world, that he looked\r\nupon himself as dead.\r\n\r\nThe inspector visited, one after another, the cells and dungeons of\r\nseveral of the prisoners, whose good behavior or stupidity recommended\r\nthem to the clemency of the government. He inquired how they were fed,\r\nand if they had any request to make. The universal response was, that\r\nthe fare was detestable, and that they wanted to be set free.\r\n\r\nThe inspector asked if they had anything else to ask for. They shook\r\ntheir heads. What could they desire beyond their liberty? The inspector\r\nturned smilingly to the governor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know what reason government can assign for these useless\r\nvisits; when you see one prisoner, you see all,\xe2\x80\x94always the same\r\nthing,\xe2\x80\x94ill fed and innocent. Are there any others?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; the dangerous and mad prisoners are in the dungeons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us visit them,\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector with an air of fatigue. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\r\nmust play the farce to the end. Let us see the dungeons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us first send for two soldiers,\xe2\x80\x9d said the governor. \xe2\x80\x9cThe prisoners\r\nsometimes, through mere uneasiness of life, and in order to be\r\nsentenced to death, commit acts of useless violence, and you might fall\r\na victim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake all needful precautions,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the inspector.\r\n\r\nTwo soldiers were accordingly sent for, and the inspector descended a\r\nstairway, so foul, so humid, so dark, as to be loathsome to sight,\r\nsmell, and respiration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the inspector, \xe2\x80\x9cwho can live here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA most dangerous conspirator, a man we are ordered to keep the most\r\nstrict watch over, as he is daring and resolute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long has he been there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNearly a year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas he placed here when he first arrived?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; not until he attempted to kill the turnkey, who took his food to\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo kill the turnkey?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the very one who is lighting us. Is it not true, Antoine?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nthe governor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue enough; he wanted to kill me!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the turnkey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must be mad,\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is worse than that,\xe2\x80\x94he is a devil!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the turnkey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I complain of him?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no; it is useless. Besides, he is almost mad now, and in another\r\nyear he will be quite so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better for him,\xe2\x80\x94he will suffer less,\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector.\r\nHe was, as this remark shows, a man full of philanthropy, and in every\r\nway fit for his office.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the governor; \xe2\x80\x9cand this remark proves\r\nthat you have deeply considered the subject. Now we have in a dungeon\r\nabout twenty feet distant, and to which you descend by another stair,\r\nan old abb\xc3\xa9, formerly leader of a party in Italy, who has been here\r\nsince 1811, and in 1813 he went mad, and the change is astonishing. He\r\nused to weep, he now laughs; he grew thin, he now grows fat. You had\r\nbetter see him, for his madness is amusing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will see them both,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the inspector; \xe2\x80\x9cI must conscientiously\r\nperform my duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was the inspector\xe2\x80\x99s first visit; he wished to display his\r\nauthority.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us visit this one first,\xe2\x80\x9d added he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy all means,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the governor, and he signed to the turnkey to\r\nopen the door. At the sound of the key turning in the lock, and the\r\ncreaking of the hinges, Dant\xc3\xa8s, who was crouched in a corner of the\r\ndungeon, whence he could see the ray of light that came through a\r\nnarrow iron grating above, raised his head. Seeing a stranger, escorted\r\nby two turnkeys holding torches and accompanied by two soldiers, and to\r\nwhom the governor spoke bareheaded, Dant\xc3\xa8s, who guessed the truth, and\r\nthat the moment to address himself to the superior authorities was\r\ncome, sprang forward with clasped hands.\r\n\r\nThe soldiers interposed their bayonets, for they thought that he was\r\nabout to attack the inspector, and the latter recoiled two or three\r\nsteps. Dant\xc3\xa8s saw that he was looked upon as dangerous. Then, infusing\r\nall the humility he possessed into his eyes and voice, he addressed the\r\ninspector, and sought to inspire him with pity.\r\n\r\nThe inspector listened attentively; then, turning to the governor,\r\nobserved, \xe2\x80\x9cHe will become religious\xe2\x80\x94he is already more gentle; he is\r\nafraid, and retreated before the bayonets\xe2\x80\x94madmen are not afraid of\r\nanything; I made some curious observations on this at Charenton.\xe2\x80\x9d Then,\r\nturning to the prisoner, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it you want?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to know what crime I have committed\xe2\x80\x94to be tried; and if I am\r\nguilty, to be shot; if innocent, to be set at liberty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you well fed?\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe so; I don\xe2\x80\x99t know; it\xe2\x80\x99s of no consequence. What matters\r\nreally, not only to me, but to officers of justice and the king, is\r\nthat an innocent man should languish in prison, the victim of an\r\ninfamous denunciation, to die here cursing his executioners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very humble today,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the governor; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are not so\r\nalways; the other day, for instance, when you tried to kill the\r\nturnkey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true, sir, and I beg his pardon, for he has always been very\r\ngood to me, but I was mad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are not so any longer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; captivity has subdued me\xe2\x80\x94I have been here so long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo long?\xe2\x80\x94when were you arrested, then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe 28th of February, 1815, at half-past two in the afternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToday is the 30th of July, 1816,\xe2\x80\x94why, it is but seventeen months.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly seventeen months,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Dant\xc3\xa8s. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, you do not know what is\r\nseventeen months in prison!\xe2\x80\x94seventeen ages rather, especially to a man\r\nwho, like me, had arrived at the summit of his ambition\xe2\x80\x94to a man, who,\r\nlike me, was on the point of marrying a woman he adored, who saw an\r\nhonorable career opened before him, and who loses all in an instant\xe2\x80\x94who\r\nsees his prospects destroyed, and is ignorant of the fate of his\r\naffianced wife, and whether his aged father be still living! Seventeen\r\nmonths\xe2\x80\x99 captivity to a sailor accustomed to the boundless ocean, is a\r\nworse punishment than human crime ever merited. Have pity on me, then,\r\nand ask for me, not intelligence, but a trial; not pardon, but a\r\nverdict\xe2\x80\x94a trial, sir, I ask only for a trial; that, surely, cannot be\r\ndenied to one who is accused!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see,\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector; then, turning to the governor, \xe2\x80\x9cOn\r\nmy word, the poor devil touches me. You must show me the proofs against\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; but you will find terrible charges.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cI know it is not in your power to\r\nrelease me; but you can plead for me\xe2\x80\x94you can have me tried\xe2\x80\x94and that is\r\nall I ask. Let me know my crime, and the reason why I was condemned.\r\nUncertainty is worse than all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on with the lights,\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cI can tell by your voice you are touched\r\nwith pity; tell me at least to hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot tell you that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the inspector; \xe2\x80\x9cI can only promise to\r\nexamine into your case.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I am free\xe2\x80\x94then I am saved!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho arrested you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Villefort. See him, and hear what he says.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Villefort is no longer at Marseilles; he is now at Toulouse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am no longer surprised at my detention,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Dant\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9csince my\r\nonly protector is removed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad M. de Villefort any cause of personal dislike to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone; on the contrary, he was very kind to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can, then, rely on the notes he has left concerning you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEntirely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is well; wait patiently, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s fell on his knees, and prayed earnestly. The door closed; but\r\nthis time a fresh inmate was left with Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x94Hope.\r\n\r\n0173m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you see the register at once,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the governor, \xe2\x80\x9cor proceed to\r\nthe other cell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us visit them all,\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I once went up those\r\nstairs. I should never have the courage to come down again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, this one is not like the other, and his madness is less affecting\r\nthan this one\xe2\x80\x99s display of reason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is his folly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe fancies he possesses an immense treasure. The first year he offered\r\ngovernment a million of francs for his release; the second, two; the\r\nthird, three; and so on progressively. He is now in his fifth year of\r\ncaptivity; he will ask to speak to you in private, and offer you five\r\nmillions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow curious!\xe2\x80\x94what is his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Abb\xc3\xa9 Faria.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. 27,\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is here; unlock the door, Antoine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe turnkey obeyed, and the inspector gazed curiously into the chamber\r\nof the _mad abb\xc3\xa9_, as the prisoner was usually called.\r\n\r\nIn the centre of the cell, in a circle traced with a fragment of\r\nplaster detached from the wall, sat a man whose tattered garments\r\nscarcely covered him. He was drawing in this circle geometrical lines,\r\nand seemed as much absorbed in his problem as Archimedes was when the\r\nsoldier of Marcellus slew him. He did not move at the sound of the\r\ndoor, and continued his calculations until the flash of the torches\r\nlighted up with an unwonted glare the sombre walls of his cell; then,\r\nraising his head, he perceived with astonishment the number of persons\r\npresent. He hastily seized the coverlet of his bed, and wrapped it\r\nround him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it you want?\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the abb\xc3\xa9 with an air of surprise,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI want\r\nnothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not understand,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the inspector; \xe2\x80\x9cI am sent here by\r\ngovernment to visit the prison, and hear the requests of the\r\nprisoners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that is different,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the abb\xc3\xa9; \xe2\x80\x9cand we shall understand each\r\nother, I hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, now,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the governor, \xe2\x80\x9cit is just as I told you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the prisoner, \xe2\x80\x9cI am the Abb\xc3\xa9 Faria, born at Rome.\r\nI was for twenty years Cardinal Spada\xe2\x80\x99s secretary; I was arrested, why,\r\nI know not, toward the beginning of the year 1811; since then I have\r\ndemanded my liberty from the Italian and French government.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy from the French government?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I was arrested at Piombino, and I presume that, like Milan and\r\nFlorence, Piombino has become the capital of some French department.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have not the latest news from Italy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy information dates from the day on which I was arrested,\xe2\x80\x9d returned\r\nthe Abb\xc3\xa9 Faria; \xe2\x80\x9cand as the emperor had created the kingdom of Rome for\r\nhis infant son, I presume that he has realized the dream of Machiavelli\r\nand C\xc3\xa6sar Borgia, which was to make Italy a united kingdom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the inspector, \xe2\x80\x9cProvidence has changed this\r\ngigantic plan you advocate so warmly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the only means of rendering Italy strong, happy, and\r\nindependent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery possibly; only I am not come to discuss politics, but to inquire\r\nif you have anything to ask or to complain of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe food is the same as in other prisons,\xe2\x80\x94that is, very bad; the\r\nlodging is very unhealthful, but, on the whole, passable for a dungeon;\r\nbut it is not that which I wish to speak of, but a secret I have to\r\nreveal of the greatest importance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are coming to the point,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the governor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is for that reason I am delighted to see you,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the abb\xc3\xa9,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9calthough you have disturbed me in a most important calculation, which,\r\nif it succeeded, would possibly change Newton\xe2\x80\x99s system. Could you allow\r\nme a few words in private.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did I tell you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the governor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou knew him,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the inspector with a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you ask is impossible, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, addressing Faria.\r\n\r\n0175m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, \xe2\x80\x9cI would speak to you of a large sum, amounting\r\nto five millions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe very sum you named,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the inspector in his turn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHowever,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Faria, seeing that the inspector was about to\r\ndepart, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not absolutely necessary for us to be alone; the\r\ngovernor can be present.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnfortunately,\xe2\x80\x9d said the governor, \xe2\x80\x9cI know beforehand what you are\r\nabout to say; it concerns your treasures, does it not?\xe2\x80\x9d Faria fixed his\r\neyes on him with an expression that would have convinced anyone else of\r\nhis sanity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cof what else should I speak?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Inspector,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the governor, \xe2\x80\x9cI can tell you the story as\r\nwell as he, for it has been dinned in my ears for the last four or five\r\nyears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat proves,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the abb\xc3\xa9, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you are like those of Holy\r\nWrit, who having eyes see not, and having ears hear not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear sir, the government is rich and does not want your treasures,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied the inspector; \xe2\x80\x9ckeep them until you are liberated.\xe2\x80\x9d The abb\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x99s\r\neyes glistened; he seized the inspector\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what if I am not liberated,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, \xe2\x80\x9cand am detained here until\r\nmy death? this treasure will be lost. Had not government better profit\r\nby it? I will offer six millions, and I will content myself with the\r\nrest, if they will only give me my liberty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my word,\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector in a low tone, \xe2\x80\x9chad I not been told\r\nbeforehand that this man was mad, I should believe what he says.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not mad,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Faria, with that acuteness of hearing peculiar\r\nto prisoners. \xe2\x80\x9cThe treasure I speak of really exists, and I offer to\r\nsign an agreement with you, in which I promise to lead you to the spot\r\nwhere you shall dig; and if I deceive you, bring me here again,\xe2\x80\x94I ask\r\nno more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe governor laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cIs the spot far from here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hundred leagues.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not ill-planned,\xe2\x80\x9d said the governor. \xe2\x80\x9cIf all the prisoners took\r\nit into their heads to travel a hundred leagues, and their guardians\r\nconsented to accompany them, they would have a capital chance of\r\nescaping.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe scheme is well known,\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector; \xe2\x80\x9cand the abb\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x99s plan\r\nhas not even the merit of originality.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen turning to Faria, \xe2\x80\x9cI inquired if you are well fed?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSwear to me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Faria, \xe2\x80\x9cto free me if what I tell you prove\r\ntrue, and I will stay here while you go to the spot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you well fed?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, you run no risk, for, as I told you, I will stay here; so\r\nthere is no chance of my escaping.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not reply to my question,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the inspector impatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor you to mine,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the abb\xc3\xa9. \xe2\x80\x9cYou will not accept my gold; I will\r\nkeep it for myself. You refuse me my liberty; God will give it me.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nthe abb\xc3\xa9, casting away his coverlet, resumed his place, and continued\r\nhis calculations.\r\n\r\n0177m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is he doing there?\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCounting his treasures,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the governor.\r\n\r\nFaria replied to this sarcasm with a glance of profound contempt. They\r\nwent out. The turnkey closed the door behind them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was wealthy once, perhaps?\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr dreamed he was, and awoke mad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter all,\xe2\x80\x9d said the inspector, \xe2\x80\x9cif he had been rich, he would not\r\nhave been here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo the matter ended for the Abb\xc3\xa9 Faria. He remained in his cell, and\r\nthis visit only increased the belief in his insanity.\r\n\r\nCaligula or Nero, those treasure-seekers, those desirers of the\r\nimpossible, would have accorded to the poor wretch, in exchange for his\r\nwealth, the liberty he so earnestly prayed for. But the kings of modern\r\ntimes, restrained by the limits of mere probability, have neither\r\ncourage nor desire. They fear the ear that hears their orders, and the\r\neye that scrutinizes their actions. Formerly they believed themselves\r\nsprung from Jupiter, and shielded by their birth; but nowadays they are\r\nnot inviolable.\r\n\r\nIt has always been against the policy of despotic governments to suffer\r\nthe victims of their persecutions to reappear. As the Inquisition\r\nrarely allowed its victims to be seen with their limbs distorted and\r\ntheir flesh lacerated by torture, so madness is always concealed in its\r\ncell, from whence, should it depart, it is conveyed to some gloomy\r\nhospital, where the doctor has no thought for man or mind in the\r\nmutilated being the jailer delivers to him. The very madness of the\r\nAbb\xc3\xa9 Faria, gone mad in prison, condemned him to perpetual captivity.\r\n\r\nThe inspector kept his word with Dant\xc3\xa8s; he examined the register, and\r\nfound the following note concerning him:\r\n\r\n_Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s:_\r\n\r\nViolent Bonapartist; took an active part in the return from Elba.\r\n\r\nThe greatest watchfulness and care to be exercised.\r\n\r\nThis note was in a different hand from the rest, which showed that it\r\nhad been added since his confinement. The inspector could not contend\r\nagainst this accusation; he simply wrote, _Nothing to be done._\r\n\r\nThis visit had infused new vigor into Dant\xc3\xa8s; he had, till then,\r\nforgotten the date; but now, with a fragment of plaster, he wrote the\r\ndate, 30th July, 1816, and made a mark every day, in order not to lose\r\nhis reckoning again. Days and weeks passed away, then months\xe2\x80\x94Dant\xc3\xa8s\r\nstill waited; he at first expected to be freed in a fortnight. This\r\nfortnight expired, he decided that the inspector would do nothing until\r\nhis return to Paris, and that he would not reach there until his\r\ncircuit was finished, he therefore fixed three months; three months\r\npassed away, then six more. Finally ten months and a half had gone by\r\nand no favorable change had taken place, and Dant\xc3\xa8s began to fancy the\r\ninspector\xe2\x80\x99s visit but a dream, an illusion of the brain.\r\n\r\nAt the expiration of a year the governor was transferred; he had\r\nobtained charge of the fortress at Ham. He took with him several of his\r\nsubordinates, and amongst them Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 jailer. A new governor arrived;\r\nit would have been too tedious to acquire the names of the prisoners;\r\nhe learned their numbers instead. This horrible place contained fifty\r\ncells; their inhabitants were designated by the numbers of their cell,\r\nand the unhappy young man was no longer called Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x94he was now\r\nnumber 34.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 15. Number 34 and Number 27\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s passed through all the stages of torture natural to prisoners in\r\nsuspense. He was sustained at first by that pride of conscious\r\ninnocence which is the sequence to hope; then he began to doubt his own\r\ninnocence, which justified in some measure the governor\xe2\x80\x99s belief in his\r\nmental alienation; and then, relaxing his sentiment of pride, he\r\naddressed his supplications, not to God, but to man. God is always the\r\nlast resource. Unfortunates, who ought to begin with God, do not have\r\nany hope in him till they have exhausted all other means of\r\ndeliverance.\r\n\r\nDant\xc3\xa8s asked to be removed from his present dungeon into another, even\r\nif it were darker and deeper, for a change, however disadvantageous,\r\nwas still a change, and would afford him some amusement. He entreated\r\nto be allowed to walk about, to have fresh air, books, and writing\r\nmaterials. His requests were not granted, but he went on asking all the\r\nsame. He accustomed himself to speaking to the new jailer, although the\r\nlatter was, if possible, more taciturn than the old one; but still, to\r\nspeak to a man, even though mute, was something. Dant\xc3\xa8s spoke for the\r\nsake of hearing his own voice; he had tried to speak when alone, but\r\nthe sound of his voice terrified him.\r\n\r\nOften, before his captivity, Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 mind had revolted at the idea of\r\nassemblages of prisoners, made up of thieves, vagabonds, and murderers.\r\nHe now wished to be amongst them, in order to see some other face\r\nbesides that of his jailer; he sighed for the galleys, with the\r\ninfamous costume, the chain, and the brand on the shoulder. The\r\ngalley-slaves breathed the fresh air of heaven, and saw each other.\r\nThey were very happy.\r\n\r\nHe besought the jailer one day to let him have a companion, were it\r\neven the mad abb\xc3\xa9. The jailer, though rough and hardened by the\r\nconstant sight of so much suffering, was yet a man. At the bottom of\r\nhis heart he had often had a feeling of pity for this unhappy young man\r\nwho suffered so; and he laid the request of number 34 before the\r\ngovernor; but the latter sapiently imagined that Dant\xc3\xa8s wished to\r\nconspire or attempt an escape, and refused his request. Dant\xc3\xa8s had\r\nexhausted all human resources, and he then turned to God.\r\n\r\nAll the pious ideas that had been so long forgotten, returned; he\r\nrecollected the prayers his mother had taught him, and discovered a new\r\nmeaning in every word; for in prosperity prayers seem but a mere medley\r\nof words, until misfortune comes and the unhappy sufferer first\r\nunderstands the meaning of the sublime language in which he invokes the\r\npity of heaven! He prayed, and prayed aloud, no longer terrified at the\r\nsound of his own voice, for he fell into a sort of ecstasy. He laid\r\nevery action of his life before the Almighty, proposed tasks to\r\naccomplish, and at the end of every prayer introduced the entreaty\r\noftener addressed to man than to God: \xe2\x80\x9cForgive us our trespasses as we\r\nforgive them that trespass against us.\xe2\x80\x9d Yet in spite of his earnest\r\nprayers, Dant\xc3\xa8s remained a prisoner.\r\n\r\nThen gloom settled heavily upon him.
