The jewel is worth at least fifty thousand\r\nfrancs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, what a magnificent jewel!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the astonished woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fifth part of the profits from this stone belongs to us then, does\r\nit not?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt does,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the abb\xc3\xa9; \xe2\x80\x9cwith the addition of an equal division of\r\nthat part intended for the elder Dant\xc3\xa8s, which I believe myself at\r\nliberty to divide equally with the four survivors.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why among us four?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs being the friends Edmond esteemed most faithful and devoted to\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t call those friends who betray and ruin you,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the wife\r\nin her turn, in a low, muttering voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course not!\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Caderousse quickly; \xe2\x80\x9cno more do I, and that\r\nwas what I was observing to this gentleman just now. I said I looked\r\nupon it as a sacrilegious profanation to reward treachery, perhaps\r\ncrime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the abb\xc3\xa9 calmly, as he replaced the jewel and its\r\ncase in the pocket of his cassock, \xe2\x80\x9cit is your fault, not mine, that I\r\ndo so. You will have the goodness to furnish me with the address of\r\nboth Fernand and Danglars, in order that I may execute Edmond\xe2\x80\x99s last\r\nwishes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe agitation of Caderousse became extreme, and large drops of\r\nperspiration rolled from his heated brow. As he saw the abb\xc3\xa9 rise from\r\nhis seat and go towards the door, as though to ascertain if his horse\r\nwere sufficiently refreshed to continue his journey, Caderousse and his\r\nwife exchanged looks of deep meaning.\r\n\r\n0335m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, you see, wife,\xe2\x80\x9d said the former, \xe2\x80\x9cthis splendid diamond might\r\nall be ours, if we chose!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you believe it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, surely a man of his holy profession would not deceive us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied La Carconte, \xe2\x80\x9cdo as you like. For my part, I wash my\r\nhands of the affair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, she once more climbed the staircase leading to her chamber,\r\nher body convulsed with chills, and her teeth rattling in her head, in\r\nspite of the intense heat of the weather. Arrived at the top stair, she\r\nturned round, and called out, in a warning tone, to her husband,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGaspard, consider well what you are about to do!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have both reflected and decided,\xe2\x80\x9d answered he.\r\n\r\nLa Carconte then entered her chamber, the flooring of which creaked\r\nbeneath her heavy, uncertain tread, as she proceeded towards her\r\narmchair, into which she fell as though exhausted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the abb\xc3\xa9, as he returned to the apartment below, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\r\nhave you made up your mind to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo tell you all I know,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI certainly think you act wisely in so doing,\xe2\x80\x9d said the priest. \xe2\x80\x9cNot\r\nbecause I have the least desire to learn anything you may please to\r\nconceal from me, but simply that if, through your assistance, I could\r\ndistribute the legacy according to the wishes of the testator, why, so\r\nmuch the better, that is all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope it may be so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Caderousse, his face flushed with\r\ncupidity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am all attention,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop a minute,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cwe might be interrupted in the\r\nmost interesting part of my story, which would be a pity; and it is as\r\nwell that your visit hither should be made known only to ourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these words he went stealthily to the door, which he closed, and,\r\nby way of still greater precaution, bolted and barred it, as he was\r\naccustomed to do at night.\r\n\r\nDuring this time the abb\xc3\xa9 had chosen his place for listening at his\r\nease. He removed his seat into a corner of the room, where he himself\r\nwould be in deep shadow, while the light would be fully thrown on the\r\nnarrator; then, with head bent down and hands clasped, or rather\r\nclenched together, he prepared to give his whole attention to\r\nCaderousse, who seated himself on the little stool, exactly opposite to\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember, this is no affair of mine,\xe2\x80\x9d said the trembling voice of La\r\nCarconte, as though through the flooring of her chamber she viewed the\r\nscene that was enacting below.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough, enough!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9csay no more about it; I will\r\ntake all the consequences upon myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he began his story.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 27. The Story\r\n\r\nFirst, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must make me a promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, if you ever make use of the details I am about to give you, that\r\nyou will never let anyone know that it was I who supplied them; for the\r\npersons of whom I am about to talk are rich and powerful, and if they\r\nonly laid the tips of their fingers on me, I should break to pieces\r\nlike glass.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMake yourself easy, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the abb\xc3\xa9. \xe2\x80\x9cI am a priest, and\r\nconfessions die in my breast. Recollect, our only desire is to carry\r\nout, in a fitting manner, the last wishes of our friend. Speak, then,\r\nwithout reserve, as without hatred; tell the truth, the whole truth; I\r\ndo not know, never may know, the persons of whom you are about to\r\nspeak; besides, I am an Italian, and not a Frenchman, and belong to\r\nGod, and not to man, and I shall shortly retire to my convent, which I\r\nhave only quitted to fulfil the last wishes of a dying man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis positive assurance seemed to give Caderousse a little courage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, under these circumstances,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cI will, I\r\neven believe I ought to undeceive you as to the friendship which poor\r\nEdmond thought so sincere and unquestionable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBegin with his father, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9; \xe2\x80\x9cEdmond talked\r\nto me a great deal about the old man for whom he had the deepest love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe history is a sad one, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, shaking his head;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cperhaps you know all the earlier part of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d answered the abb\xc3\xa9; \xe2\x80\x9cEdmond related to me everything until the\r\nmoment when he was arrested in a small cabaret close to Marseilles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt La R\xc3\xa9serve! Oh, yes; I can see it all before me this moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it not his betrothal feast?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was and the feast that began so gayly had a very sorrowful ending;\r\na police commissary, followed by four soldiers, entered, and Dant\xc3\xa8s was\r\narrested.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and up to this point I know all,\xe2\x80\x9d said the priest. \xe2\x80\x9cDant\xc3\xa8s\r\nhimself only knew that which personally concerned him, for he never\r\nbeheld again the five persons I have named to you, or heard mention of\r\nanyone of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, when Dant\xc3\xa8s was arrested, Monsieur Morrel hastened to obtain the\r\nparticulars, and they were very sad. The old man returned alone to his\r\nhome, folded up his wedding suit with tears in his eyes, and paced up\r\nand down his chamber the whole day, and would not go to bed at all, for\r\nI was underneath him and heard him walking the whole night; and for\r\nmyself, I assure you I could not sleep either, for the grief of the\r\npoor father gave me great uneasiness, and every step he took went to my\r\nheart as really as if his foot had pressed against my breast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe next day Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s came to implore the protection of M. de\r\nVillefort; she did not obtain it, however, and went to visit the old\r\nman; when she saw him so miserable and heart-broken, having passed a\r\nsleepless night, and not touched food since the previous day, she\r\nwished him to go with her that she might take care of him; but the old\r\nman would not consent. \xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 was the old man\xe2\x80\x99s reply, \xe2\x80\x98I will not leave\r\nthis house, for my poor dear boy loves me better than anything in the\r\nworld; and if he gets out of prison he will come and see me the first\r\nthing, and what would he think if I did not wait here for him?\xe2\x80\x99 I heard\r\nall this from the window, for I was anxious that Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s should\r\npersuade the old man to accompany her, for his footsteps over my head\r\nnight and day did not leave me a moment\xe2\x80\x99s repose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut did you not go upstairs and try to console the poor old man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nasked the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cwe cannot console those who will not be\r\nconsoled, and he was one of these; besides, I know not why, but he\r\nseemed to dislike seeing me. One night, however, I heard his sobs, and\r\nI could not resist my desire to go up to him, but when I reached his\r\ndoor he was no longer weeping but praying. I cannot now repeat to you,\r\nsir, all the eloquent words and imploring language he made use of; it\r\nwas more than piety, it was more than grief, and I, who am no canter,\r\nand hate the Jesuits, said then to myself, \xe2\x80\x98It is really well, and I am\r\nvery glad that I have not any children; for if I were a father and felt\r\nsuch excessive grief as the old man does, and did not find in my memory\r\nor heart all he is now saying, I should throw myself into the sea at\r\nonce, for I could not bear it.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor father!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the priest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom day to day he lived on alone, and more and more solitary. M.\r\nMorrel and Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s came to see him, but his door was closed; and,\r\nalthough I was certain he was at home, he would not make any answer.\r\nOne day, when, contrary to his custom, he had admitted Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, and\r\nthe poor girl, in spite of her own grief and despair, endeavored to\r\nconsole him, he said to her,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Be assured, my dear daughter, he is dead;\r\nand instead of expecting him, it is he who is awaiting us; I am quite\r\nhappy, for I am the oldest, and of course shall see him first.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHowever well disposed a person may be, why, you see we leave off after\r\na time seeing persons who are in sorrow, they make one melancholy; and\r\nso at last old Dant\xc3\xa8s was left all to himself, and I only saw from time\r\nto time strangers go up to him and come down again with some bundle\r\nthey tried to hide; but I guessed what these bundles were, and that he\r\nsold by degrees what he had to pay for his subsistence. At length the\r\npoor old fellow reached the end of all he had; he owed three quarters\xe2\x80\x99\r\nrent, and they threatened to turn him out; he begged for another week,\r\nwhich was granted to him. I know this, because the landlord came into\r\nmy apartment when he left his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the first three days I heard him walking about as usual, but, on\r\nthe fourth I heard nothing. I then resolved to go up to him at all\r\nrisks. The door was closed, but I looked through the keyhole, and saw\r\nhim so pale and haggard, that believing him very ill, I went and told\r\nM. Morrel and then ran on to Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s. They both came immediately, M.\r\nMorrel bringing a doctor, and the doctor said it was inflammation of\r\nthe bowels, and ordered him a limited diet. I was there, too, and I\r\nnever shall forget the old man\xe2\x80\x99s smile at this prescription.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom that time he received all who came; he had an excuse for not\r\neating any more; the doctor had put him on a diet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe abb\xc3\xa9 uttered a kind of groan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe story interests you, does it not, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the abb\xc3\xa9, \xe2\x80\x9cit is very affecting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s came again, and she found him so altered that she was even\r\nmore anxious than before to have him taken to her own home. This was M.\r\nMorrel\xe2\x80\x99s wish also, who would fain have conveyed the old man against\r\nhis consent; but the old man resisted, and cried so that they were\r\nactually frightened. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s remained, therefore, by his bedside, and\r\nM. Morrel went away, making a sign to the Catalan that he had left his\r\npurse on the chimney-piece; but, availing himself of the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s\r\norder, the old man would not take any sustenance; at length (after nine\r\ndays of despair and fasting), the old man died, cursing those who had\r\ncaused his misery, and saying to Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x98If you ever see my Edmond\r\nagain, tell him I die blessing him.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe abb\xc3\xa9 rose from his chair, made two turns round the chamber, and\r\npressed his trembling hand against his parched throat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you believe he died\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf hunger, sir, of hunger,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cI am as certain of it as\r\nthat we two are Christians.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe abb\xc3\xa9, with a shaking hand, seized a glass of water that was\r\nstanding by him half-full, swallowed it at one gulp, and then resumed\r\nhis seat, with red eyes and pale cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis was, indeed, a horrid event,\xe2\x80\x9d said he in a hoarse voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe more so, sir, as it was men\xe2\x80\x99s and not God\xe2\x80\x99s doing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me of those men,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, \xe2\x80\x9cand remember too,\xe2\x80\x9d he added in\r\nan almost menacing tone, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have promised to tell me everything. Tell\r\nme, therefore, who are these men who killed the son with despair, and\r\nthe father with famine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo men jealous of him, sir; one from love, and the other from\r\nambition,\xe2\x80\x94Fernand and Danglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was this jealousy manifested? Speak on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey denounced Edmond as a Bonapartist agent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich of the two denounced him? Which was the real delinquent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoth, sir; one with a letter, and the other put it in the post.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where was this letter written?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt La R\xc3\xa9serve, the day before the betrothal feast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Twas so, then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99twas so, then,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the abb\xc3\xa9. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, Faria, Faria,\r\nhow well did you judge men and things!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you please to say, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the priest; \xe2\x80\x9cgo on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was Danglars who wrote the denunciation with his left hand, that\r\nhis writing might not be recognized, and Fernand who put it in the\r\npost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the abb\xc3\xa9 suddenly, \xe2\x80\x9cyou were there yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, astonished; \xe2\x80\x9cwho told you I was there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe abb\xc3\xa9 saw he had overshot the mark, and he added quickly,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cNo one;\r\nbut in order to have known everything so well, you must have been an\r\neye-witness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, true!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse in a choking voice, \xe2\x80\x9cI was there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did you not remonstrate against such infamy?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the abb\xc3\xa9; \xe2\x80\x9cif\r\nnot, you were an accomplice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cthey had made me drink to such an excess\r\nthat I nearly lost all perception. I had only an indistinct\r\nunderstanding of what was passing around me. I said all that a man in\r\nsuch a state could say; but they both assured me that it was a jest\r\nthey were carrying on, and perfectly harmless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNext day\xe2\x80\x94next day, sir, you must have seen plain enough what they had\r\nbeen doing, yet you said nothing, though you were present when Dant\xc3\xa8s\r\nwas arrested.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, I was there, and very anxious to speak; but Danglars\r\nrestrained me. \xe2\x80\x98If he should really be guilty,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98and did\r\nreally put in to the Island of Elba; if he is really charged with a\r\nletter for the Bonapartist committee at Paris, and if they find this\r\nletter upon him, those who have supported him will pass for his\r\naccomplices.\xe2\x80\x99 I confess I had my fears, in the state in which politics\r\nthen were, and I held my tongue. It was cowardly, I confess, but it was\r\nnot criminal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0341m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand\xe2\x80\x94you allowed matters to take their course, that was all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cand remorse preys on me night and\r\nday. I often ask pardon of God, I swear to you, because this action,\r\nthe only one with which I have seriously to reproach myself in all my\r\nlife, is no doubt the cause of my abject condition. I am expiating a\r\nmoment of selfishness, and so I always say to La Carconte, when she\r\ncomplains, \xe2\x80\x98Hold your tongue, woman; it is the will of God.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nCaderousse bowed his head with every sign of real repentance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have spoken unreservedly; and thus to\r\naccuse yourself is to deserve pardon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnfortunately, Edmond is dead, and has not pardoned me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe did not know,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he knows it all now,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cthey say the dead\r\nknow everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a brief silence; the abb\xc3\xa9 rose and paced up and down\r\npensively, and then resumed his seat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have two or three times mentioned a M. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cwho was\r\nhe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe owner of the _Pharaon_ and patron of Dant\xc3\xa8s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what part did he play in this sad drama?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe part of an honest man, full of courage and real regard. Twenty\r\ntimes he interceded for Edmond. When the emperor returned, he wrote,\r\nimplored, threatened, and so energetically, that on the second\r\nrestoration he was persecuted as a Bonapartist. Ten times, as I told\r\nyou, he came to see Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 father, and offered to receive him in his\r\nown house; and the night or two before his death, as I have already\r\nsaid, he left his purse on the mantelpiece, with which they paid the\r\nold man\xe2\x80\x99s debts, and buried him decently; and so Edmond\xe2\x80\x99s father died,\r\nas he had lived, without doing harm to anyone. I have the purse still\r\nby me\xe2\x80\x94a large one, made of red silk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the abb\xc3\xa9, \xe2\x80\x9cis M. Morrel still alive?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the abb\xc3\xa9, \xe2\x80\x9che should be a man blessed of God,\r\nrich, happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse smiled bitterly. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, happy as myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! M. Morrel unhappy?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is reduced almost to the last extremity\xe2\x80\x94nay, he is almost at the\r\npoint of dishonor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cso it is; after five-and-twenty years of\r\nlabor, after having acquired a most honorable name in the trade of\r\nMarseilles, M. Morrel is utterly ruined; he has lost five ships in two\r\nyears, has suffered by the bankruptcy of three large houses, and his\r\nonly hope now is in that very _Pharaon_ which poor Dant\xc3\xa8s commanded,\r\nand which is expected from the Indies with a cargo of cochineal and\r\nindigo. If this ship founders, like the others, he is a ruined man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd has the unfortunate man wife or children?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he has a wife, who through everything has behaved like an angel;\r\nhe has a daughter, who was about to marry the man she loved, but whose\r\nfamily now will not allow him to wed the daughter of a ruined man; he\r\nhas, besides, a son, a lieutenant in the army; and, as you may suppose,\r\nall this, instead of lessening, only augments his sorrows. If he were\r\nalone in the world he would blow out his brains, and there would be an\r\nend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHorrible!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated the priest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it is thus heaven recompenses virtue, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d added Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nsee, I, who never did a bad action but that I have told you of\xe2\x80\x94am in\r\ndestitution, with my poor wife dying of fever before my very eyes, and\r\nI unable to do anything in the world for her; I shall die of hunger, as\r\nold Dant\xc3\xa8s did, while Fernand and Danglars are rolling in wealth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause their deeds have brought them good fortune, while honest men\r\nhave been reduced to misery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has become of Danglars, the instigator, and therefore the most\r\nguilty?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has become of him? Why, he left Marseilles, and was taken, on the\r\nrecommendation of M. Morrel, who did not know his crime, as cashier\r\ninto a Spanish bank. During the war with Spain he was employed in the\r\ncommissariat of the French army, and made a fortune; then with that\r\nmoney he speculated in the funds, and trebled or quadrupled his\r\ncapital; and, having first married his banker\xe2\x80\x99s daughter, who left him\r\na widower, he has married a second time, a widow, a Madame de Nargonne,\r\ndaughter of M. de Servieux, the king\xe2\x80\x99s chamberlain, who is in high\r\nfavor at court. He is a millionaire, and they have made him a baron,\r\nand now he is the Baron Danglars, with a fine residence in the Rue du\r\nMont-Blanc, with ten horses in his stables, six footmen in his\r\nantechamber, and I know not how many millions in his strongbox.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, in a peculiar tone, \xe2\x80\x9che is happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHappy? Who can answer for that? Happiness or unhappiness is the secret\r\nknown but to one\xe2\x80\x99s self and the walls\xe2\x80\x94walls have ears but no tongue;\r\nbut if a large fortune produces happiness, Danglars is happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Fernand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFernand? Why, much the same story.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how could a poor Catalan fisher-boy, without education or\r\nresources, make a fortune? I confess this staggers me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it has staggered everybody. There must have been in his life some\r\nstrange secret that no one knows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, then, by what visible steps has he attained this high fortune or\r\nhigh position?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoth, sir\xe2\x80\x94he has both fortune and position\xe2\x80\x94both.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis must be impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would seem so; but listen, and you will understand. Some days\r\nbefore the return of the emperor, Fernand was drafted. The Bourbons\r\nleft him quietly enough at the Catalans, but Napoleon returned, a\r\nspecial levy was made, and Fernand was compelled to join. I went too;\r\nbut as I was older than Fernand, and had just married my poor wife, I\r\nwas only sent to the coast. Fernand was enrolled in the active army,\r\nwent to the frontier with his regiment, and was at the battle of Ligny.\r\nThe night after that battle he was sentry at the door of a general who\r\ncarried on a secret correspondence with the enemy. That same night the\r\ngeneral was to go over to the English. He proposed to Fernand to\r\naccompany him; Fernand agreed to do so, deserted his post, and followed\r\nthe general.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFernand would have been court-martialed if Napoleon had remained on\r\nthe throne, but his action was rewarded by the Bourbons. He returned to\r\nFrance with the epaulet of sub-lieutenant, and as the protection of the\r\ngeneral, who is in the highest favor, was accorded to him, he was a\r\ncaptain in 1823, during the Spanish war\xe2\x80\x94that is to say, at the time\r\nwhen Danglars made his early speculations. Fernand was a Spaniard, and\r\nbeing sent to Spain to ascertain the feeling of his fellow-countrymen,\r\nfound Danglars there, got on very intimate terms with him, won over the\r\nsupport of the royalists at the capital and in the provinces, received\r\npromises and made pledges on his own part, guided his regiment by paths\r\nknown to himself alone through the mountain gorges which were held by\r\nthe royalists, and, in fact, rendered such services in this brief\r\ncampaign that, after the taking of Trocadero, he was made colonel, and\r\nreceived the title of count and the cross of an officer of the Legion\r\nof Honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDestiny! destiny!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but listen: this was not all. The war with Spain being ended,\r\nFernand\xe2\x80\x99s career was checked by the long peace which seemed likely to\r\nendure throughout Europe. Greece only had risen against Turkey, and had\r\nbegun her war of independence; all eyes were turned towards Athens\xe2\x80\x94it\r\nwas the fashion to pity and support the Greeks. The French government,\r\nwithout protecting them openly, as you know, gave countenance to\r\nvolunteer assistance. Fernand sought and obtained leave to go and serve\r\nin Greece, still having his name kept on the army roll.\r\n\r\n0345m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSome time after, it was stated that the Comte de Morcerf (this was the\r\nname he bore) had entered the service of Ali Pasha with the rank of\r\ninstructor-general. Ali Pasha was killed, as you know, but before he\r\ndied he recompensed the services of Fernand by leaving him a\r\nconsiderable sum, with which he returned to France, when he was\r\ngazetted lieutenant-general.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that now\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that now,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9che owns a magnificent house\xe2\x80\x94No.\r\n27, Rue du Helder, Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe abb\xc3\xa9 opened his mouth, hesitated for a moment, then, making an\r\neffort at self-control, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x94they tell me that she\r\nhas disappeared?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDisappeared,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cyes, as the sun disappears, to rise\r\nthe next day with still more splendor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas she made a fortune also?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the abb\xc3\xa9, with an ironical\r\nsmile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s is at this moment one of the greatest ladies in Paris,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9; \xe2\x80\x9cit seems as if I were listening to the story\r\nof a dream. But I have seen things so extraordinary, that what you tell\r\nme seems less astonishing than it otherwise might.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s was at first in the deepest despair at the blow which\r\ndeprived her of Edmond. I have told you of her attempts to propitiate\r\nM. de Villefort, her devotion to the elder Dant\xc3\xa8s. In the midst of her\r\ndespair, a new affliction overtook her. This was the departure of\r\nFernand\xe2\x80\x94of Fernand, whose crime she did not know, and whom she regarded\r\nas her brother. Fernand went, and Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s remained alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree months passed and still she wept\xe2\x80\x94no news of Edmond, no news of\r\nFernand, no companionship save that of an old man who was dying with\r\ndespair. One evening, after a day of accustomed vigil at the angle of\r\ntwo roads leading to Marseilles from the Catalans, she returned to her\r\nhome more depressed than ever. Suddenly she heard a step she knew,\r\nturned anxiously around, the door opened, and Fernand, dressed in the\r\nuniform of a sub-lieutenant, stood before her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was not the one she wished for most, but it seemed as if a part of\r\nher past life had returned to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s seized Fernand\xe2\x80\x99s hands with a transport which he took for\r\nlove, but which was only joy at being no longer alone in the world, and\r\nseeing at last a friend, after long hours of solitary sorrow. And then,\r\nit must be confessed, Fernand had never been hated\xe2\x80\x94he was only not\r\nprecisely loved. Another possessed all Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 heart; that other was\r\nabsent, had disappeared, perhaps was dead. At this last thought\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s burst into a flood of tears, and wrung her hands in agony; but\r\nthe thought, which she had always repelled before when it was suggested\r\nto her by another, came now in full force upon her mind; and then, too,\r\nold Dant\xc3\xa8s incessantly said to her, \xe2\x80\x98Our Edmond is dead; if he were\r\nnot, he would return to us.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe old man died, as I have told you; had he lived, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s,\r\nperchance, had not become the wife of another, for he would have been\r\nthere to reproach her infidelity. Fernand saw this, and when he learned\r\nof the old man\xe2\x80\x99s death he returned. He was now a lieutenant. At his\r\nfirst coming he had not said a word of love to Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s; at the second\r\nhe reminded her that he loved her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s begged for six months more in which to await and mourn for\r\nEdmond.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, with a bitter smile, \xe2\x80\x9cthat makes eighteen\r\nmonths in all. What more could the most devoted lover desire?\xe2\x80\x9d Then he\r\nmurmured the words of the English poet, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Frailty, thy name is woman.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSix months afterwards,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cthe marriage took place\r\nin the church of Accoules.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe very church in which she was to have married Edmond,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the\r\npriest; \xe2\x80\x9cthere was only a change of bridegrooms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s was married,\xe2\x80\x9d proceeded Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cbut although in\r\nthe eyes of the world she appeared calm, she nearly fainted as she\r\npassed La R\xc3\xa9serve, where, eighteen months before, the betrothal had\r\nbeen celebrated with him whom she might have known she still loved, had\r\nshe looked to the bottom of her heart. Fernand, more happy, but not\r\nmore at his ease\xe2\x80\x94for I saw at this time he was in constant dread of\r\nEdmond\xe2\x80\x99s return\xe2\x80\x94Fernand was very anxious to get his wife away, and to\r\ndepart himself. There were too many unpleasant possibilities associated\r\nwith the Catalans, and eight days after the wedding they left\r\nMarseilles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever see Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s again?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the priest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, during the Spanish war, at Perpignan, where Fernand had left her;\r\nshe was attending to the education of her son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe abb\xc3\xa9 started. \xe2\x80\x9cHer son?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9clittle Albert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, then, to be able to instruct her child,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the abb\xc3\xa9, \xe2\x80\x9cshe\r\nmust have received an education herself. I understood from Edmond that\r\nshe was the daughter of a simple fisherman, beautiful but uneducated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cdid he know so little of his lovely\r\nbetrothed? Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s might have been a queen, sir, if the crown were to\r\nbe placed on the heads of the loveliest and most intelligent. Fernand\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfortune was already waxing great, and she developed with his growing\r\nfortune. She learned drawing, music\xe2\x80\x94everything. Besides, I believe,\r\nbetween ourselves, she did this in order to distract her mind, that she\r\nmight forget; and she only filled her head in order to alleviate the\r\nweight on her heart. But now her position in life is assured,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cno doubt fortune and honors have comforted her;\r\nshe is rich, a countess, and yet\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet what?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet, I am sure, she is not happy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes you believe this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, when I found myself utterly destitute, I thought my old friends\r\nwould, perhaps, assist me. So I went to Danglars, who would not even\r\nreceive me. I called on Fernand, who sent me a hundred francs by his\r\nvalet-de-chambre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you did not see either of them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but Madame de Morcerf saw me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I went away a purse fell at my feet\xe2\x80\x94it contained five-and-twenty\r\nlouis; I raised my head quickly, and saw Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, who at once shut the\r\nblind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd M. de Villefort?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he never was a friend of mine, I did not know him, and I had\r\nnothing to ask of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you not know what became of him, and the share he had in Edmond\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmisfortunes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I only know that some time after Edmond\xe2\x80\x99s arrest, he married\r\nMademoiselle de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, and soon after left Marseilles; no doubt\r\nhe has been as lucky as the rest; no doubt he is as rich as Danglars,\r\nas high in station as Fernand. I only, as you see, have remained poor,\r\nwretched, and forgotten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the abb\xc3\xa9; \xe2\x80\x9cGod may seem\r\nsometimes to forget for a time, while his justice reposes, but there\r\nalways comes a moment when he remembers\xe2\x80\x94and behold\xe2\x80\x94a proof!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he spoke, the abb\xc3\xa9 took the diamond from his pocket, and giving it\r\nto Caderousse, said, \xe2\x80\x9cHere, my friend, take this diamond, it is yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, for me only?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cah, sir, do not jest with me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis diamond was to have been shared among his friends. Edmond had one\r\nfriend only, and thus it cannot be divided. Take the diamond, then, and\r\nsell it; it is worth fifty thousand francs, and I repeat my wish that\r\nthis sum may suffice to release you from your wretchedness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0351m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, putting out one hand timidly, and with the\r\nother wiping away the perspiration which bedewed his brow,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sir, do\r\nnot make a jest of the happiness or despair of a man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know what happiness and what despair are, and I never make a jest of\r\nsuch feelings. Take it, then, but in exchange\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse, who touched the diamond, withdrew his hand.\r\n\r\nThe abb\xc3\xa9 smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn exchange,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cgive me the red silk purse that M. Morrel\r\nleft on old Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 chimney-piece, and which you tell me is still in\r\nyour hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse, more and more astonished, went toward a large oaken\r\ncupboard, opened it, and gave the abb\xc3\xa9 a long purse of faded red silk,\r\nround which were two copper runners that had once been gilt. The abb\xc3\xa9\r\ntook it, and in return gave Caderousse the diamond.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you are a man of God, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cfor no one knew\r\nthat Edmond had given you this diamond, and you might have kept it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9 to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cyou would have done.\xe2\x80\x9d The abb\xc3\xa9\r\nrose, took his hat and gloves. \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9call you have told me\r\nis perfectly true, then, and I may believe it in every particular.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cin this corner is a crucifix in holy\r\nwood\xe2\x80\x94here on this shelf is my wife\xe2\x80\x99s testament; open this book, and I\r\nwill swear upon it with my hand on the crucifix. I will swear to you by\r\nmy soul\xe2\x80\x99s salvation, my faith as a Christian, I have told everything to\r\nyou as it occurred, and as the recording angel will tell it to the ear\r\nof God at the day of the last judgment!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, convinced by his manner and tone that\r\nCaderousse spoke the truth. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis well, and may this money profit you!\r\nAdieu; I go far from men who thus so bitterly injure each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe abb\xc3\xa9 with difficulty got away from the enthusiastic thanks of\r\nCaderousse, opened the door himself, got out and mounted his horse,\r\nonce more saluted the innkeeper, who kept uttering his loud farewells,\r\nand then returned by the road he had travelled in coming.\r\n\r\nWhen Caderousse turned around, he saw behind him La Carconte, paler and\r\ntrembling more than ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs, then, all that I have heard really true?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? That he has given the diamond to us only?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Caderousse,\r\nhalf bewildered with joy; \xe2\x80\x9cyes, nothing more true! See, here it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe woman gazed at it a moment, and then said, in a gloomy voice,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose it\xe2\x80\x99s false?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse started and turned pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFalse!\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered. \xe2\x80\x9cFalse! Why should that man give me a false\r\ndiamond?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n0349m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo get your secret without paying for it, you blockhead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse remained for a moment aghast under the weight of such an\r\nidea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, taking up his hat, which he placed on the red\r\nhandkerchief tied round his head, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will soon find out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, the fair is on at Beaucaire, there are always jewellers from\r\nParis there, and I will show it to them. Look after the house, wife,\r\nand I shall be back in two hours,\xe2\x80\x9d and Caderousse left the house in\r\nhaste, and ran rapidly in the direction opposite to that which the\r\npriest had taken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFifty thousand francs!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered La Carconte when left alone; \xe2\x80\x9cit is a\r\nlarge sum of money, but it is not a fortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nVOLUME TWO\r\n\r\n20009m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n20011m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n20019m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 28. The Prison Register\r\n\r\nThe day after that in which the scene we have just described had taken\r\nplace on the road between Bellegarde and Beaucaire, a man of about\r\nthirty or two-and-thirty, dressed in a bright blue frock coat, nankeen\r\ntrousers, and a white waistcoat, having the appearance and accent of an\r\nEnglishman, presented himself before the mayor of Marseilles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI am chief clerk of the house of Thomson & French, of\r\nRome. We are, and have been these ten years, connected with the house\r\nof Morrel & Son, of Marseilles. We have a hundred thousand francs or\r\nthereabouts loaned on their securities, and we are a little uneasy at\r\nreports that have reached us that the firm is on the brink of ruin. I\r\nhave come, therefore, express from Rome, to ask you for information.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the mayor. \xe2\x80\x9cI know very well that during the last four\r\nor five years misfortune has seemed to pursue M. Morrel. He has lost\r\nfour or five vessels, and suffered by three or four bankruptcies; but\r\nit is not for me, although I am a creditor myself to the amount of ten\r\nthousand francs, to give any information as to the state of his\r\nfinances. Ask of me, as mayor, what is my opinion of M. Morrel, and I\r\nshall say that he is a man honorable to the last degree, and who has up\r\nto this time fulfilled every engagement with scrupulous punctuality.\r\nThis is all I can say, sir; if you wish to learn more, address yourself\r\nto M. de Boville, the inspector of prisons, No. 15, Rue de Nouailles;\r\nhe has, I believe, two hundred thousand francs in Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s hands, and\r\nif there be any grounds for apprehension, as this is a greater amount\r\nthan mine, you will most probably find him better informed than\r\nmyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Englishman seemed to appreciate this extreme delicacy, made his bow\r\nand went away, proceeding with a characteristic British stride towards\r\nthe street mentioned.\r\n\r\nM. de Boville was in his private room, and the Englishman, on\r\nperceiving him, made a gesture of surprise, which seemed to indicate\r\nthat it was not the first time he had been in his presence. As to M. de\r\nBoville, he was in such a state of despair, that it was evident all the\r\nfaculties of his mind, absorbed in the thought which occupied him at\r\nthe moment, did not allow either his memory or his imagination to stray\r\nto the past.\r\n\r\nThe Englishman, with the coolness of his nation, addressed him in terms\r\nnearly similar to those with which he had accosted the mayor of\r\nMarseilles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed M. de Boville, \xe2\x80\x9cyour fears are unfortunately but\r\ntoo well founded, and you see before you a man in despair. I had two\r\nhundred thousand francs placed in the hands of Morrel & Son; these two\r\nhundred thousand francs were the dowry of my daughter, who was to be\r\nmarried in a fortnight, and these two hundred thousand francs were\r\npayable, half on the 15th of this month, and the other half on the 15th\r\nof next month. I had informed M. Morrel of my desire to have these\r\npayments punctually, and he has been here within the last half-hour to\r\ntell me that if his ship, the _Pharaon_, did not come into port on the\r\n15th, he would be wholly unable to make this payment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman, \xe2\x80\x9cthis looks very much like a suspension of\r\npayment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt looks more like bankruptcy!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed M. de Boville despairingly.\r\n\r\nThe Englishman appeared to reflect a moment, and then said, \xe2\x80\x9cFrom which\r\nit would appear, sir, that this credit inspires you with considerable\r\napprehension?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo tell you the truth, I consider it lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, I will buy it of you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut at a tremendous discount, of course?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, for two hundred thousand francs. Our house,\xe2\x80\x9d added the Englishman\r\nwith a laugh, \xe2\x80\x9cdoes not do things in that way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will pay\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReady money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20023m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd the Englishman drew from his pocket a bundle of bank-notes, which\r\nmight have been twice the sum M. de Boville feared to lose. A ray of\r\njoy passed across M. de Boville\xe2\x80\x99s countenance, yet he made an effort at\r\nself-control, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, I ought to tell you that, in all probability, you will not\r\nrealize six per cent of this sum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s no affair of mine,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Englishman, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is the affair\r\nof the house of Thomson & French, in whose name I act. They have,\r\nperhaps, some motive to serve in hastening the ruin of a rival firm.\r\nBut all I know, sir, is, that I am ready to hand you over this sum in\r\nexchange for your assignment of the debt. I only ask a brokerage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course, that is perfectly just,\xe2\x80\x9d cried M. de Boville. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\ncommission is usually one and a half; will you have two\xe2\x80\x94three\xe2\x80\x94five per\r\ncent, or even more? Whatever you say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Englishman, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cI am like my house, and do\r\nnot do such things\xe2\x80\x94no, the commission I ask is quite different.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cName it, sir, I beg.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are the inspector of prisons?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been so these fourteen years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou keep the registers of entries and departures?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo these registers there are added notes relative to the prisoners?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are special reports on every prisoner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir, I was educated at Rome by a poor devil of an abb\xc3\xa9, who\r\ndisappeared suddenly. I have since learned that he was confined in the\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If, and I should like to learn some particulars of his\r\ndeath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Abb\xc3\xa9 Faria.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I recollect him perfectly,\xe2\x80\x9d cried M. de Boville; \xe2\x80\x9che was crazy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo they said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he was, decidedly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery possibly; but what sort of madness was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe pretended to know of an immense treasure, and offered vast sums to\r\nthe government if they would liberate him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor devil!\xe2\x80\x94and he is dead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, five or six months ago, last February.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a good memory, sir, to recollect dates so well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI recollect this, because the poor devil\xe2\x80\x99s death was accompanied by a\r\nsingular incident.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I ask what that was?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman with an expression of\r\ncuriosity, which a close observer would have been astonished at\r\ndiscovering in his phlegmatic countenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh dear, yes, sir; the abb\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x99s dungeon was forty or fifty feet distant\r\nfrom that of one of Bonaparte\xe2\x80\x99s emissaries,\xe2\x80\x94one of those who had\r\ncontributed the most to the return of the usurper in 1815, a very\r\nresolute and very dangerous man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. de Boville; \xe2\x80\x9cI myself had occasion to see this man in\r\n1816 or 1817, and we could only go into his dungeon with a file of\r\nsoldiers. That man made a deep impression on me; I shall never forget\r\nhis countenance!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20025m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Englishman smiled imperceptibly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you say, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d he interposed, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the two dungeons\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere separated by a distance of fifty feet; but it appears that this\r\nEdmond Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis dangerous man\xe2\x80\x99s name was\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdmond Dant\xc3\xa8s. It appears, sir, that this Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s had procured\r\ntools, or made them, for they found a tunnel through which the\r\nprisoners held communication with one another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis tunnel was dug, no doubt, with an intention of escape?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt; but unfortunately for the prisoners, the Abb\xc3\xa9 Faria had an\r\nattack of catalepsy, and died.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat must have cut short the projects of escape.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the dead man, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. de Boville, \xe2\x80\x9cbut not for the\r\nsurvivor; on the contrary, this Dant\xc3\xa8s saw a means of accelerating his\r\nescape. He, no doubt, thought that prisoners who died in the Ch\xc3\xa2teau\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99If were interred in an ordinary burial-ground, and he conveyed the\r\ndead man into his own cell, took his place in the sack in which they\r\nhad sewed up the corpse, and awaited the moment of interment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was a bold step, and one that showed some courage,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the\r\nEnglishman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I have already told you, sir, he was a very dangerous man; and,\r\nfortunately, by his own act disembarrassed the government of the fears\r\nit had on his account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow? Do you not comprehend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If has no cemetery, and they simply throw the dead into\r\nthe sea, after fastening a thirty-six-pound cannon-ball to their feet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d observed the Englishman as if he were slow of comprehension.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, they fastened a thirty-six-pound ball to his feet, and threw him\r\ninto the sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Englishman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the inspector of prisons. \xe2\x80\x9cYou may imagine the\r\namazement of the fugitive when he found himself flung headlong over the\r\nrocks! I should like to have seen his face at that moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would have been difficult.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo matter,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Boville, in supreme good-humor at the certainty\r\nof recovering his two hundred thousand francs,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cno matter, I can fancy\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d And he shouted with laughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo can I,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman, and he laughed too; but he laughed as\r\nthe English do, \xe2\x80\x9cat the end of his teeth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the Englishman who first gained his composure, \xe2\x80\x9che\r\nwas drowned?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnquestionably.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that the governor got rid of the dangerous and the crazy prisoner\r\nat the same time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20027m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut some official document was drawn up as to this affair, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ninquired the Englishman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, the mortuary deposition. You understand, Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 relations,\r\nif he had any, might have some interest in knowing if he were dead or\r\nalive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that now, if there were anything to inherit from him, they may do\r\nso with easy conscience. He is dead, and no mistake about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes; and they may have the fact attested whenever they please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo be it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman. \xe2\x80\x9cBut to return to these registers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, this story has diverted our attention from them. Excuse me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse you for what? For the story? By no means; it really seems to me\r\nvery curious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed. So, sir, you wish to see all relating to the poor abb\xc3\xa9,\r\nwho really was gentleness itself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you will much oblige me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo into my study here, and I will show it to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd they both entered M. de Boville\xe2\x80\x99s study. Everything was here\r\narranged in perfect order; each register had its number, each file of\r\npapers its place. The inspector begged the Englishman to seat himself\r\nin an armchair, and placed before him the register and documents\r\nrelative to the Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If, giving him all the time he desired for\r\nthe examination, while De Boville seated himself in a corner, and began\r\nto read his newspaper. The Englishman easily found the entries relative\r\nto the Abb\xc3\xa9 Faria; but it seemed that the history which the inspector\r\nhad related interested him greatly, for after having perused the first\r\ndocuments he turned over the leaves until he reached the deposition\r\nrespecting Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s. There he found everything arranged in due\r\norder,\xe2\x80\x94the accusation, examination, Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s petition, M. de\r\nVillefort\xe2\x80\x99s marginal notes. He folded up the accusation quietly, and\r\nput it as quietly in his pocket; read the examination, and saw that the\r\nname of Noirtier was not mentioned in it; perused, too, the application\r\ndated 10th April, 1815, in which Morrel, by the deputy procureur\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nadvice, exaggerated with the best intentions (for Napoleon was then on\r\nthe throne) the services Dant\xc3\xa8s had rendered to the imperial\r\ncause\xe2\x80\x94services which Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s certificates rendered indisputable.\r\nThen he saw through the whole thing. This petition to Napoleon, kept\r\nback by Villefort, had become, under the second restoration, a terrible\r\nweapon against him in the hands of the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney. He was no\r\nlonger astonished when he searched on to find in the register this\r\nnote, placed in a bracket against his name:\r\n\r\nEdmond Dant\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\nAn inveterate Bonapartist; took an active part in the return from the\r\nIsland of Elba.\r\n\r\nTo be kept in strict solitary confinement, and to be closely watched\r\nand guarded.\r\n\r\nBeneath these lines was written in another hand: \xe2\x80\x9cSee note\r\nabove\xe2\x80\x94nothing can be done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe compared the writing in the bracket with the writing of the\r\ncertificate placed beneath Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s petition, and discovered that the\r\nnote in the bracket was the same writing as the certificate\xe2\x80\x94that is to\r\nsay, was in Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s handwriting.\r\n\r\n20029m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAs to the note which accompanied this, the Englishman understood that\r\nit might have been added by some inspector who had taken a momentary\r\ninterest in Dant\xc3\xa8s\xe2\x80\x99 situation, but who had, from the remarks we have\r\nquoted, found it impossible to give any effect to the interest he had\r\nfelt.\r\n\r\nAs we have said, the inspector, from discretion, and that he might not\r\ndisturb the Abb\xc3\xa9 Faria\xe2\x80\x99s pupil in his researches, had seated himself in\r\na corner, and was reading _Le Drapeau Blanc_. He did not see the\r\nEnglishman fold up and place in his pocket the accusation written by\r\nDanglars under the arbor of La R\xc3\xa9serve, and which had the postmark,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarseilles, 27th February, delivery 6 o\xe2\x80\x99clock, P.M.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut it must be said that if he had seen it, he attached so little\r\nimportance to this scrap of paper, and so much importance to his two\r\nhundred thousand francs, that he would not have opposed whatever the\r\nEnglishman might do, however irregular it might be.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, closing the register with a slam, \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\nall I want; now it is for me to perform my promise. Give me a simple\r\nassignment of your debt; acknowledge therein the receipt of the cash,\r\nand I will hand you over the money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe rose, gave his seat to M. de Boville, who took it without ceremony,\r\nand quickly drew up the required assignment, while the Englishman\r\ncounted out the bank-notes on the other side of the desk.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 29. The House of Morrel & Son\r\n\r\nAnyone who had quitted Marseilles a few years previously, well\r\nacquainted with the interior of Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s warehouse, and had returned at\r\nthis date, would have found a great change. Instead of that air of\r\nlife, of comfort, and of happiness that permeates a flourishing and\r\nprosperous business establishment\xe2\x80\x94instead of merry faces at the\r\nwindows, busy clerks hurrying to and fro in the long corridors\xe2\x80\x94instead\r\nof the court filled with bales of goods, re-echoing with the cries and\r\nthe jokes of porters, one would have immediately perceived all aspect\r\nof sadness and gloom. Out of all the numerous clerks that used to fill\r\nthe deserted corridor and the empty office, but two remained. One was a\r\nyoung man of three or four-and-twenty, who was in love with M. Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndaughter, and had remained with him in spite of the efforts of his\r\nfriends to induce him to withdraw; the other was an old one-eyed\r\ncashier, called \xe2\x80\x9cCocles,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cCock-eye,\xe2\x80\x9d a nickname given him by the\r\nyoung men who used to throng this vast now almost deserted bee-hive,\r\nand which had so completely replaced his real name that he would not,\r\nin all probability, have replied to anyone who addressed him by it.\r\n\r\nCocles remained in M. Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s service, and a most singular change had\r\ntaken place in his position; he had at the same time risen to the rank\r\nof cashier, and sunk to the rank of a servant. He was, however, the\r\nsame Cocles, good, patient, devoted, but inflexible on the subject of\r\narithmetic, the only point on which he would have stood firm against\r\nthe world, even against M. Morrel; and strong in the\r\nmultiplication-table, which he had at his fingers\xe2\x80\x99 ends, no matter what\r\nscheme or what trap was laid to catch him.\r\n\r\nIn the midst of the disasters that befell the house, Cocles was the\r\nonly one unmoved. But this did not arise from a want of affection; on\r\nthe contrary, from a firm conviction. Like the rats that one by one\r\nforsake the doomed ship even before the vessel weighs anchor, so all\r\nthe numerous clerks had by degrees deserted the office and the\r\nwarehouse. Cocles had seen them go without thinking of inquiring the\r\ncause of their departure. Everything was as we have said, a question of\r\narithmetic to Cocles, and during twenty years he had always seen all\r\npayments made with such exactitude, that it seemed as impossible to him\r\nthat the house should stop payment, as it would to a miller that the\r\nriver that had so long turned his mill should cease to flow.\r\n\r\nNothing had as yet occurred to shake Cocles\xe2\x80\x99 belief; the last month\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npayment had been made with the most scrupulous exactitude; Cocles had\r\ndetected an overbalance of fourteen sous in his cash, and the same\r\nevening he had brought them to M. Morrel, who, with a melancholy smile,\r\nthrew them into an almost empty drawer, saying:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, Cocles; you are the pearl of cashiers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCocles went away perfectly happy, for this eulogium of M. Morrel,\r\nhimself the pearl of the honest men of Marseilles, flattered him more\r\nthan a present of fifty crowns. But since the end of the month M.\r\nMorrel had passed many an anxious hour.\r\n\r\nIn order to meet the payments then due; he had collected all his\r\nresources, and, fearing lest the report of his distress should get\r\nbruited abroad at Marseilles when he was known to be reduced to such an\r\nextremity, he went to the Beaucaire fair to sell his wife\xe2\x80\x99s and\r\ndaughter\xe2\x80\x99s jewels and a portion of his plate. By this means the end of\r\nthe month was passed, but his resources were now exhausted. Credit,\r\nowing to the reports afloat, was no longer to be had; and to meet the\r\none hundred thousand francs due on the 15th of the present month, and\r\nthe one hundred thousand francs due on the 15th of the next month to M.\r\nde Boville, M. Morrel had, in reality, no hope but the return of the\r\n_Pharaon_, of whose departure he had learnt from a vessel which had\r\nweighed anchor at the same time, and which had already arrived in\r\nharbor.\r\n\r\nBut this vessel which, like the _Pharaon_, came from Calcutta, had been\r\nin for a fortnight, while no intelligence had been received of the\r\n_Pharaon_.\r\n\r\n20033m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSuch was the state of affairs when, the day after his interview with M.\r\nde Boville, the confidential clerk of the house of Thomson & French of\r\nRome, presented himself at M. Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\nEmmanuel received him; this young man was alarmed by the appearance of\r\nevery new face, for every new face might be that of a new creditor,\r\ncome in anxiety to question the head of the house. The young man,\r\nwishing to spare his employer the pain of this interview, questioned\r\nthe new-comer; but the stranger declared that he had nothing to say to\r\nM. Emmanuel, and that his business was with M. Morrel in person.\r\n\r\nEmmanuel sighed, and summoned Cocles. Cocles appeared, and the young\r\nman bade him conduct the stranger to M. Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s apartment. Cocles went\r\nfirst, and the stranger followed him. On the staircase they met a\r\nbeautiful girl of sixteen or seventeen, who looked with anxiety at the\r\nstranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Morrel is in his room, is he not, Mademoiselle Julie?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ncashier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I think so, at least,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young girl hesitatingly. \xe2\x80\x9cGo and\r\nsee, Cocles, and if my father is there, announce this gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be useless to announce me, mademoiselle,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the\r\nEnglishman. \xe2\x80\x9cM. Morrel does not know my name; this worthy gentleman has\r\nonly to announce the confidential clerk of the house of Thomson &\r\nFrench of Rome, with whom your father does business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young girl turned pale and continued to descend, while the stranger\r\nand Cocles continued to mount the staircase. She entered the office\r\nwhere Emmanuel was, while Cocles, by the aid of a key he possessed,\r\nopened a door in the corner of a landing-place on the second staircase,\r\nconducted the stranger into an antechamber, opened a second door, which\r\nhe closed behind him, and after having left the clerk of the house of\r\nThomson & French alone, returned and signed to him that he could enter.\r\n\r\nThe Englishman entered, and found Morrel seated at a table, turning\r\nover the formidable columns of his ledger, which contained the list of\r\nhis liabilities. At the sight of the stranger, M. Morrel closed the\r\nledger, arose, and offered a seat to the stranger; and when he had seen\r\nhim seated, resumed his own chair. Fourteen years had changed the\r\nworthy merchant, who, in his thirty-sixth year at the opening of this\r\nhistory, was now in his fiftieth; his hair had turned white, time and\r\nsorrow had ploughed deep furrows on his brow, and his look, once so\r\nfirm and penetrating, was now irresolute and wandering, as if he feared\r\nbeing forced to fix his attention on some particular thought or person.\r\n\r\nThe Englishman looked at him with an air of curiosity, evidently\r\nmingled with interest. \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, whose uneasiness was\r\nincreased by this examination, \xe2\x80\x9cyou wish to speak to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur; you are aware from whom I come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe house of Thomson & French; at least, so my cashier tells me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has told you rightly. The house of Thomson & French had 300,000 or\r\n400,000 francs to pay this month in France; and, knowing your strict\r\npunctuality, have collected all the bills bearing your signature, and\r\ncharged me as they became due to present them, and to employ the money\r\notherwise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel sighed deeply, and passed his hand over his forehead, which was\r\ncovered with perspiration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo then, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cyou hold bills of mine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and for a considerable sum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the amount?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel with a voice he strove to render\r\nfirm.\r\n\r\n20035m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman, taking a quantity of papers from his\r\npocket, \xe2\x80\x9can assignment of 200,000 francs to our house by M. de Boville,\r\nthe inspector of prisons, to whom they are due. You acknowledge, of\r\ncourse, that you owe this sum to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; he placed the money in my hands at four and a half per cent\r\nnearly five years ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen are you to pay?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf the 15th of this month, half the 15th of next.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust so; and now here are 32,500 francs payable shortly; they are all\r\nsigned by you, and assigned to our house by the holders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI recognize them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, whose face was suffused, as he thought\r\nthat, for the first time in his life, he would be unable to honor his\r\nown signature. \xe2\x80\x9cIs this all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I have for the end of the month these bills which have been\r\nassigned to us by the house of Pascal, and the house of Wild & Turner\r\nof Marseilles, amounting to nearly 55,000 francs; in all, 287,500\r\nfrancs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt is impossible to describe what Morrel suffered during this\r\nenumeration. \xe2\x80\x9cTwo hundred and eighty-seven thousand five hundred\r\nfrancs,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Englishman. \xe2\x80\x9cI will not,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, after a\r\nmoment\xe2\x80\x99s silence, \xe2\x80\x9cconceal from you, that while your probity and\r\nexactitude up to this moment are universally acknowledged, yet the\r\nreport is current in Marseilles that you are not able to meet your\r\nliabilities.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this almost brutal speech Morrel turned deathly pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cup to this time\xe2\x80\x94and it is now more than\r\nfour-and-twenty years since I received the direction of this house from\r\nmy father, who had himself conducted it for five-and-thirty years\xe2\x80\x94never\r\nhas anything bearing the signature of Morrel & Son been dishonored.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Englishman. \xe2\x80\x9cBut as a man of honor should\r\nanswer another, tell me fairly, shall you pay these with the same\r\npunctuality?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel shuddered, and looked at the man, who spoke with more assurance\r\nthan he had hitherto shown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo questions frankly put,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9ca straightforward answer should\r\nbe given. Yes, I shall pay, if, as I hope, my vessel arrives safely;\r\nfor its arrival will again procure me the credit which the numerous\r\naccidents, of which I have been the victim, have deprived me; but if\r\nthe _Pharaon_ should be lost, and this last resource be gone\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe poor man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes filled with tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other, \xe2\x80\x9cif this last resource fail you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cit is a cruel thing to be forced to say, but,\r\nalready used to misfortune, I must habituate myself to shame. I fear I\r\nshall be forced to suspend payment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you no friends who could assist you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel smiled mournfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn business, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cone has no friends, only correspondents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the Englishman; \xe2\x80\x9cthen you have but one hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe last?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that if this fail\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am ruined,\xe2\x80\x94completely ruined!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I was on my way here, a vessel was coming into port.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it, sir; a young man, who still adheres to my fallen fortunes,\r\npasses a part of his time in a belvedere at the top of the house, in\r\nhopes of being the first to announce good news to me; he has informed\r\nme of the arrival of this ship.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it is not yours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, she is a Bordeaux vessel, _La Gironde_; she comes from India also;\r\nbut she is not mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps she has spoken to the _Pharaon_, and brings you some tidings\r\nof her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I tell you plainly one thing, sir? I dread almost as much to\r\nreceive any tidings of my vessel as to remain in doubt. Uncertainty is\r\nstill hope.\xe2\x80\x9d Then in a low voice Morrel added,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThis delay is not\r\nnatural. The _Pharaon_ left Calcutta the 5th of February; she ought to\r\nhave been here a month ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the meaning of that\r\nnoise?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morrel, turning pale, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA loud noise was heard on the stairs of people moving hastily, and\r\nhalf-stifled sobs. Morrel rose and advanced to the door; but his\r\nstrength failed him and he sank into a chair. The two men remained\r\nopposite one another, Morrel trembling in every limb, the stranger\r\ngazing at him with an air of profound pity. The noise had ceased; but\r\nit seemed that Morrel expected something\xe2\x80\x94something had occasioned the\r\nnoise, and something must follow. The stranger fancied he heard\r\nfootsteps on the stairs; and that the footsteps, which were those of\r\nseveral persons, stopped at the door. A key was inserted in the lock of\r\nthe first door, and the creaking of hinges was audible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are only two persons who have the key to that door,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured\r\nMorrel, \xe2\x80\x9cCocles and Julie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this instant the second door opened, and the young girl, her eyes\r\nbathed with tears, appeared. Morrel rose tremblingly, supporting\r\nhimself by the arm of the chair. He would have spoken, but his voice\r\nfailed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, father!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, clasping her hands, \xe2\x80\x9cforgive your child for\r\nbeing the bearer of evil tidings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel again changed color. Julie threw herself into his arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, father, father!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured she, \xe2\x80\x9ccourage!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe _Pharaon_ has gone down, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel in a hoarse voice. The\r\nyoung girl did not speak; but she made an affirmative sign with her\r\nhead as she lay on her father\xe2\x80\x99s breast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the crew?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaved,\xe2\x80\x9d said the girl; \xe2\x80\x9csaved by the crew of the vessel that has just\r\nentered the harbor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel raised his two hands to heaven with an expression of resignation\r\nand sublime gratitude.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, my God,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cat least thou strikest but me alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA tear moistened the eye of the phlegmatic Englishman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in, come in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cfor I presume you are all at the\r\ndoor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nScarcely had he uttered those words when Madame Morrel entered weeping\r\nbitterly. Emmanuel followed her, and in the antechamber were visible\r\nthe rough faces of seven or eight half-naked sailors. At the sight of\r\nthese men the Englishman started and advanced a step; then restrained\r\nhimself, and retired into the farthest and most obscure corner of the\r\napartment. Madame Morrel sat down by her husband and took one of his\r\nhands in hers, Julie still lay with her head on his shoulder, Emmanuel\r\nstood in the centre of the chamber and seemed to form the link between\r\nMorrel\xe2\x80\x99s family and the sailors at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did this happen?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDraw nearer, Penelon,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cand tell us all about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn old seaman, bronzed by the tropical sun, advanced, twirling the\r\nremains of a hat between his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-day, M. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as if he had just quitted Marseilles\r\nthe previous evening, and had just returned from Aix or Toulon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-day, Penelon,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Morrel, who could not refrain from\r\nsmiling through his tears, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere is the captain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe captain, M. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x94he has stayed behind sick at Palma; but please\r\nGod, it won\xe2\x80\x99t be much, and you will see him in a few days all alive and\r\nhearty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now tell your story, Penelon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20039m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nPenelon rolled his quid in his cheek, placed his hand before his mouth,\r\nturned his head, and sent a long jet of tobacco-juice into the\r\nantechamber, advanced his foot, balanced himself, and began.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, M. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwe were somewhere between Cape Blanc\r\nand Cape Boyador, sailing with a fair breeze, south-south-west after a\r\nweek\xe2\x80\x99s calm, when Captain Gaumard comes up to me\xe2\x80\x94I was at the helm I\r\nshould tell you\xe2\x80\x94and says, \xe2\x80\x98Penelon, what do you think of those clouds\r\ncoming up over there?\xe2\x80\x99 I was just then looking at them myself. \xe2\x80\x98What do\r\nI think, captain? Why I think that they are rising faster than they\r\nhave any business to do, and that they would not be so black if they\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t mean mischief.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98That\xe2\x80\x99s my opinion too,\xe2\x80\x99 said the captain, \xe2\x80\x98and\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll take precautions accordingly. We are carrying too much canvas.\r\nAvast, there, all hands! Take in the studding-sails and stow the flying\r\njib.\xe2\x80\x99 It was time; the squall was on us, and the vessel began to heel.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said the captain, \xe2\x80\x98we have still too much canvas set; all hands\r\nlower the mainsail!\xe2\x80\x99 Five minutes after, it was down; and we sailed\r\nunder mizzen-topsails and top-gallant sails. \xe2\x80\x98Well, Penelon,\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\ncaptain, \xe2\x80\x98what makes you shake your head?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 I says, \xe2\x80\x98I still\r\nthink you\xe2\x80\x99ve got too much on.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98I think you\xe2\x80\x99re right,\xe2\x80\x99 answered he, \xe2\x80\x98we\r\nshall have a gale.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98A gale? More than that, we shall have a tempest,\r\nor I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what\xe2\x80\x99s what.\xe2\x80\x99 You could see the wind coming like the\r\ndust at Montredon; luckily the captain understood his business. \xe2\x80\x98Take\r\nin two reefs in the top-sails,\xe2\x80\x99 cried the captain; \xe2\x80\x98let go the\r\nbowlin\xe2\x80\x99s, haul the brace, lower the top-gallant sails, haul out the\r\nreef-tackles on the yards.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20041m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was not enough for those latitudes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nshould have taken four reefs in the topsails and furled the spanker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis firm, sonorous, and unexpected voice made everyone start.
