Scarcely had they\r\nentered, when she motioned to Franz to assume the seat of honor.\r\nAlbert, in his turn, sat behind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, hardly giving Franz time to sit down, \xe2\x80\x9cit seems you\r\nhave nothing better to do than to make the acquaintance of this new\r\nLord Ruthven, and you are already the best friends in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout being so far advanced as that, my dear countess,\xe2\x80\x9d returned\r\nFranz, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot deny that we have abused his good nature all day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; this morning we breakfasted with him; we rode in his carriage all\r\nday, and now we have taken possession of his box.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know him, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and no.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a long story.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would frighten you too much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the more reason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt least wait until the story has a conclusion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well; I prefer complete histories; but tell me how you made his\r\nacquaintance? Did anyone introduce you to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; it was he who introduced himself to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLast night, after we left you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThrough what medium?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe very prosaic one of our landlord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is staying, then, at the H\xc3\xb4tel de Londres with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot only in the same hotel, but on the same floor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is his name; for, of course, you know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Count of Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not a family name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it is the name of the island he has purchased.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he is a count?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Tuscan count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we must put up with that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, who was herself\r\nfrom one of the oldest Venetian families. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat sort of a man is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsk the Vicomte de Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou hear, M. de Morcerf, I am referred to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe should be very hard to please, madam,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cdid we not\r\nthink him delightful. A friend of ten years\xe2\x80\x99 standing could not have\r\ndone more for us, or with a more perfect courtesy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the countess, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cI see my vampire is only some\r\nmillionaire, who has taken the appearance of Lara in order to avoid\r\nbeing confounded with M. de Rothschild; and you have seen her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20183m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe beautiful Greek of yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; we heard, I think, the sound of her _guzla_, but she remained\r\nperfectly invisible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you say invisible,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cit is only to keep up\r\nthe mystery; for whom do you take the blue domino at the window with\r\nthe white curtains?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere was this window with white hangings?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the Rospoli Palace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count had three windows at the Rospoli Palace?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Did you pass through the Corso?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, did you notice two windows hung with yellow damask, and one with\r\nwhite damask with a red cross? Those were the count\xe2\x80\x99s windows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, he must be a nabob. Do you know what those three windows were\r\nworth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo or three hundred Roman crowns?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo or three thousand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe deuce!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes his island produce him such a revenue?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt does not bring him a bajocco.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen why did he purchase it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor a whim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is an original, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn reality,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Albert, \xe2\x80\x9che seemed to me somewhat eccentric;\r\nwere he at Paris, and a frequenter of the theatres, I should say he was\r\na poor devil literally mad. This morning he made two or three exits\r\nworthy of Didier or Anthony.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment a fresh visitor entered, and, according to custom, Franz\r\ngave up his seat to him. This circumstance had, moreover, the effect of\r\nchanging the conversation; an hour afterwards the two friends returned\r\nto their hotel.\r\n\r\nSignor Pastrini had already set about procuring their disguises for the\r\nmorrow; and he assured them that they would be perfectly satisfied. The\r\nnext morning, at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock, he entered Franz\xe2\x80\x99s room, followed by a\r\ntailor, who had eight or ten Roman peasant costumes on his arm; they\r\nselected two exactly alike, and charged the tailor to sew on each of\r\ntheir hats about twenty yards of ribbon, and to procure them two of the\r\nlong silk sashes of different colors with which the lower orders\r\ndecorate themselves on f\xc3\xaate days.\r\n\r\nAlbert was impatient to see how he looked in his new dress\xe2\x80\x94a jacket and\r\nbreeches of blue velvet, silk stockings with clocks, shoes with\r\nbuckles, and a silk waistcoat. This picturesque attire set him off to\r\ngreat advantage; and when he had bound the scarf around his waist, and\r\nwhen his hat, placed coquettishly on one side, let fall on his shoulder\r\na stream of ribbons, Franz was forced to confess that costume has much\r\nto do with the physical superiority we accord to certain nations. The\r\nTurks used to be so picturesque with their long and flowing robes, but\r\nare they not now hideous with their blue frocks buttoned up to the\r\nchin, and their red caps, which make them look like a bottle of wine\r\nwith a red seal? Franz complimented Albert, who looked at himself in\r\nthe glass with an unequivocal smile of satisfaction. They were thus\r\nengaged when the Count of Monte Cristo entered.\r\n\r\n20185m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9calthough a companion is agreeable, perfect\r\nfreedom is sometimes still more agreeable. I come to say that today,\r\nand for the remainder of the Carnival, I leave the carriage entirely at\r\nyour disposal. The host will tell you I have three or four more, so\r\nthat you will not inconvenience me in any way. Make use of it, I pray\r\nyou, for your pleasure or your business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young men wished to decline, but they could find no good reason for\r\nrefusing an offer which was so agreeable to them. The Count of Monte\r\nCristo remained a quarter of an hour with them, conversing on all\r\nsubjects with the greatest ease. He was, as we have already said,\r\nperfectly well acquainted with the literature of all countries. A\r\nglance at the walls of his salon proved to Franz and Albert that he was\r\na connoisseur of pictures. A few words he let fall showed them that he\r\nwas no stranger to the sciences, and he seemed much occupied with\r\nchemistry. The two friends did not venture to return the count the\r\nbreakfast he had given them; it would have been too absurd to offer him\r\nin exchange for his excellent table the very inferior one of Signor\r\nPastrini. They told him so frankly, and he received their excuses with\r\nthe air of a man who appreciated their delicacy. Albert was charmed\r\nwith the count\xe2\x80\x99s manners, and he was only prevented from recognizing\r\nhim for a perfect gentleman by reason of his varied knowledge.\r\n\r\nThe permission to do what he liked with the carriage pleased him above\r\nall, for the fair peasants had appeared in a most elegant carriage the\r\npreceding evening, and Albert was not sorry to be upon an equal footing\r\nwith them. At half-past one they descended, the coachman and footman\r\nhad put on their livery over their disguises, which gave them a more\r\nridiculous appearance than ever, and which gained them the applause of\r\nFranz and Albert. Albert had fastened the faded bunch of violets to his\r\nbutton-hole. At the first sound of the bell they hastened into the\r\nCorso by the Via Vittoria.\r\n\r\nAt the second turn, a bunch of fresh violets, thrown from a carriage\r\nfilled with harlequins, indicated to Albert that, like himself and his\r\nfriend, the peasants had changed their costume also; and whether it was\r\nthe result of chance, or whether a similar feeling had possessed them\r\nboth, while he had donned their costume, they had assumed his.\r\n\r\nAlbert placed the fresh bouquet in his button-hole, but he kept the\r\nfaded one in his hand; and when he again met the calash, he raised it\r\nto his lips, an action which seemed greatly to amuse not only the fair\r\nlady who had thrown it, but her joyous companions also. The day was as\r\ngay as the preceding one, perhaps even more animated and noisy; the\r\ncount appeared for an instant at his window, but when they again passed\r\nhe had disappeared. It is almost needless to say that the flirtation\r\nbetween Albert and the fair peasant continued all day.\r\n\r\nIn the evening, on his return, Franz found a letter from the embassy,\r\ninforming him that he would have the honor of being received by his\r\nholiness the next day. At each previous visit he had made to Rome, he\r\nhad solicited and obtained the same favor; and incited as much by a\r\nreligious feeling as by gratitude, he was unwilling to quit the capital\r\nof the Christian world without laying his respectful homage at the feet\r\nof one of St. Peter\xe2\x80\x99s successors who has set the rare example of all\r\nthe virtues. He did not then think of the Carnival, for in spite of his\r\ncondescension and touching kindness, one cannot incline one\xe2\x80\x99s self\r\nwithout awe before the venerable and noble old man called Gregory XVI.\r\n\r\nOn his return from the Vatican, Franz carefully avoided the Corso; he\r\nbrought away with him a treasure of pious thoughts, to which the mad\r\ngayety of the maskers would have been profanation.\r\n\r\nAt ten minutes past five Albert entered overjoyed. The harlequin had\r\nreassumed her peasant\xe2\x80\x99s costume, and as she passed she raised her mask.\r\nShe was charming. Franz congratulated Albert, who received his\r\ncongratulations with the air of a man conscious that they are merited.\r\nHe had recognized by certain unmistakable signs, that his fair\r\n_incognita_ belonged to the aristocracy. He had made up his mind to\r\nwrite to her the next day.\r\n\r\nFranz remarked, while he gave these details, that Albert seemed to have\r\nsomething to ask of him, but that he was unwilling to ask it. He\r\ninsisted upon it, declaring beforehand that he was willing to make any\r\nsacrifice the other wished.\r\n\r\nAlbert let himself be pressed just as long as friendship required, and\r\nthen avowed to Franz that he would do him a great favor by allowing him\r\nto occupy the carriage alone the next day. Albert attributed to Franz\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nabsence the extreme kindness of the fair peasant in raising her mask.\r\nFranz was not sufficiently egotistical to stop Albert in the middle of\r\nan adventure that promised to prove so agreeable to his curiosity and\r\nso flattering to his vanity. He felt assured that the perfect\r\nindiscretion of his friend would duly inform him of all that happened;\r\nand as, during three years that he had travelled all over Italy, a\r\nsimilar piece of good fortune had never fallen to his share, Franz was\r\nby no means sorry to learn how to act on such an occasion. He therefore\r\npromised Albert that he would content himself the morrow with\r\nwitnessing the Carnival from the windows of the Rospoli Palace.\r\n\r\nThe next morning he saw Albert pass and repass, holding an enormous\r\nbouquet, which he doubtless meant to make the bearer of his amorous\r\nepistle. This belief was changed into certainty when Franz saw the\r\nbouquet (conspicuous by a circle of white camellias) in the hand of a\r\ncharming harlequin dressed in rose-colored satin.\r\n\r\nThe evening was no longer joy, but delirium. Albert nothing doubted but\r\nthat the fair unknown would reply in the same manner. Franz anticipated\r\nhis wishes by saying that the noise fatigued him, and that he should\r\npass the next day in writing and looking over his journal. Albert was\r\nnot deceived, for the next evening Franz saw him enter triumphantly\r\nshaking a folded paper which he held by one corner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwas I mistaken?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has answered you!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis word was pronounced in a manner impossible to describe. Franz took\r\nthe letter, and read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTuesday evening, at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, descend from your carriage opposite\r\nthe Via dei Pontefici, and follow the Roman peasant who snatches your\r\ntorch from you. When you arrive at the first step of the church of San\r\nGiacomo, be sure to fasten a knot of rose-colored ribbons to the\r\nshoulder of your harlequin costume, in order that you may be\r\nrecognized. Until then you will not see me. \xe2\x80\x94Constancy and Discretion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, when Franz had finished, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you think of that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think that the adventure is assuming a very agreeable appearance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so, also,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cand I very much fear you will go\r\nalone to the Duke of Bracciano\xe2\x80\x99s ball.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz and Albert had received that morning an invitation from the\r\ncelebrated Roman banker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care, Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz. \xe2\x80\x9cAll the nobility of Rome will be\r\npresent, and if your fair _incognita_ belong to the higher class of\r\nsociety, she must go there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhether she goes there or not, my opinion is still the same,\xe2\x80\x9d returned\r\nAlbert. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have read the letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know how imperfectly the women of the _mezzo cito_ are educated in\r\nItaly?\xe2\x80\x9d (This is the name of the lower class.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, read the letter again. Look at the writing, and find if you can,\r\nany blemish in the language or orthography.\xe2\x80\x9d The writing was, in\r\nreality, charming, and the orthography irreproachable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are born to good fortune,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, as he returned the letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaugh as much as you will,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI am in love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou alarm me,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Franz. \xe2\x80\x9cI see that I shall not only go alone to\r\nthe Duke of Bracciano\xe2\x80\x99s, but also return to Florence alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf my unknown be as amiable as she is beautiful,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nshall fix myself at Rome for six weeks, at least. I adore Rome, and I\r\nhave always had a great taste for arch\xc3\xa6ology.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20189m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, two or three more such adventures, and I do not despair of\r\nseeing you a member of the Academy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDoubtless Albert was about to discuss seriously his right to the\r\nacademic chair when they were informed that dinner was ready. Albert\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlove had not taken away his appetite. He hastened with Franz to seat\r\nhimself, free to recommence the discussion after dinner. After dinner,\r\nthe Count of Monte Cristo was announced. They had not seen him for two\r\ndays. Signor Pastrini informed them that business had called him to\r\nCivita Vecchia. He had started the previous evening, and had only\r\nreturned an hour since. He was charming. Whether he kept a watch over\r\nhimself, or whether by accident he did not sound the acrimonious chords\r\nthat in other circumstances had been touched, he was tonight like\r\neverybody else.\r\n\r\nThe man was an enigma to Franz. The count must feel sure that Franz\r\nrecognized him; and yet he had not let fall a single word indicating\r\nany previous acquaintance between them. On his side, however great\r\nFranz\xe2\x80\x99s desire was to allude to their former interview, the fear of\r\nbeing disagreeable to the man who had loaded him and his friend with\r\nkindness prevented him from mentioning it.\r\n\r\nThe count had learned that the two friends had sent to secure a box at\r\nthe Argentina Theatre, and were told they were all let. In consequence,\r\nhe brought them the key of his own\xe2\x80\x94at least such was the apparent\r\nmotive of his visit. Franz and Albert made some difficulty, alleging\r\ntheir fear of depriving him of it; but the count replied that, as he\r\nwas going to the Palli Theatre, the box at the Argentina Theatre would\r\nbe lost if they did not profit by it. This assurance determined the two\r\nfriends to accept it.\r\n\r\nFranz had by degrees become accustomed to the count\xe2\x80\x99s pallor, which had\r\nso forcibly struck him at their first meeting. He could not refrain\r\nfrom admiring the severe beauty of his features, the only defect, or\r\nrather the principal quality of which was the pallor. Truly, a Byronic\r\nhero! Franz could not, we will not say see him, but even think of him\r\nwithout imagining his stern head upon Manfred\xe2\x80\x99s shoulders, or beneath\r\nLara\xe2\x80\x99s helmet. His forehead was marked with the line that indicates the\r\nconstant presence of bitter thoughts; he had the fiery eyes that seem\r\nto penetrate to the very soul, and the haughty and disdainful upper lip\r\nthat gives to the words it utters a peculiar character that impresses\r\nthem on the minds of those to whom they are addressed.\r\n\r\nThe count was no longer young. He was at least forty; and yet it was\r\neasy to understand that he was formed to rule the young men with whom\r\nhe associated at present. And, to complete his resemblance with the\r\nfantastic heroes of the English poet, the count seemed to have the\r\npower of fascination. Albert was constantly expatiating on their good\r\nfortune in meeting such a man. Franz was less enthusiastic; but the\r\ncount exercised over him also the ascendency a strong mind always\r\nacquires over a mind less domineering. He thought several times of the\r\nproject the count had of visiting Paris; and he had no doubt but that,\r\nwith his eccentric character, his characteristic face, and his colossal\r\nfortune, he would produce a great effect there. And yet he did not wish\r\nto be at Paris when the count was there.\r\n\r\nThe evening passed as evenings mostly pass at Italian theatres; that\r\nis, not in listening to the music, but in paying visits and conversing.\r\nThe Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 wished to revive the subject of the count, but Franz\r\nannounced he had something far newer to tell her, and, in spite of\r\nAlbert\xe2\x80\x99s demonstrations of false modesty, he informed the countess of\r\nthe great event which had preoccupied them for the last three days. As\r\nsimilar intrigues are not uncommon in Italy, if we may credit\r\ntravellers, the comtess did not manifest the least incredulity, but\r\ncongratulated Albert on his success. They promised, upon separating, to\r\nmeet at the Duke of Bracciano\xe2\x80\x99s ball, to which all Rome was invited.\r\n\r\nThe heroine of the bouquet kept her word; she gave Albert no sign of\r\nher existence the morrow or the day after.\r\n\r\nAt length Tuesday came, the last and most tumultuous day of the\r\nCarnival. On Tuesday, the theatres open at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning,\r\nas Lent begins after eight at night. On Tuesday, all those who through\r\nwant of money, time, or enthusiasm, have not been to see the Carnival\r\nbefore, mingle in the gayety, and contribute to the noise and\r\nexcitement. From two o\xe2\x80\x99clock till five Franz and Albert followed in the\r\n_f\xc3\xaate_, exchanging handfuls of _confetti_ with the other carriages and\r\nthe pedestrians, who crowded amongst the horses\xe2\x80\x99 feet and the carriage\r\nwheels without a single accident, a single dispute, or a single fight.\r\n\r\nThe _f\xc3\xaates_ are veritable pleasure days to the Italians. The author of\r\nthis history, who has resided five or six years in Italy, does not\r\nrecollect to have ever seen a ceremony interrupted by one of those\r\nevents so common in other countries. Albert was triumphant in his\r\nharlequin costume. A knot of rose-colored ribbons fell from his\r\nshoulder almost to the ground. In order that there might be no\r\nconfusion, Franz wore his peasant\xe2\x80\x99s costume.\r\n\r\nAs the day advanced, the tumult became greater. There was not on the\r\npavement, in the carriages, at the windows, a single tongue that was\r\nsilent, a single arm that did not move. It was a human storm, made up\r\nof a thunder of cries, and a hail of sweetmeats, flowers, eggs,\r\noranges, and nosegays.\r\n\r\nAt three o\xe2\x80\x99clock the sound of fireworks, let off on the Piazza del\r\nPopolo and the Piazza di Venezia (heard with difficulty amid the din\r\nand confusion) announced that the races were about to begin.\r\n\r\nThe races, like the _moccoli_, are one of the episodes peculiar to the\r\nlast days of the Carnival. At the sound of the fireworks the carriages\r\ninstantly broke ranks, and retired by the adjacent streets. All these\r\nevolutions are executed with an inconceivable address and marvellous\r\nrapidity, without the police interfering in the matter. The pedestrians\r\nranged themselves against the walls; then the trampling of horses and\r\nthe clashing of steel were heard. A detachment of carbineers, fifteen\r\nabreast, galloped up the Corso in order to clear it for the _barberi_.\r\nWhen the detachment arrived at the Piazza di Venezia, a second volley\r\nof fireworks was discharged, to announce that the street was clear.\r\n\r\nAlmost instantly, in the midst of a tremendous and general outcry,\r\nseven or eight horses, excited by the shouts of three hundred thousand\r\nspectators, passed by like lightning. Then the Castle of Saint Angelo\r\nfired three cannon to indicate that number three had won.\r\n\r\nImmediately, without any other signal, the carriages moved on, flowing\r\non towards the Corso, down all the streets, like torrents pent up for a\r\nwhile, which again flow into the parent river; and the immense stream\r\nagain continued its course between its two granite banks.\r\n\r\nA new source of noise and movement was added to the crowd. The sellers\r\nof _moccoletti_ entered on the scene. The _moccoli_, or _moccoletti_,\r\nare candles which vary in size from the pascal taper to the rushlight,\r\nand which give to each actor in the great final scene of the Carnival\r\ntwo very serious problems to grapple with,\xe2\x80\x94first, how to keep his own\r\n_moccoletto_ alight; and secondly, how to extinguish the _moccoletti_\r\nof others. The _moccoletto_ is like life: man has found but one means\r\nof transmitting it, and that one comes from God. But he has discovered\r\na thousand means of taking it away, and the devil has somewhat aided\r\nhim. The _moccoletto_ is kindled by approaching it to a light. But who\r\ncan describe the thousand means of extinguishing the _moccoletto_?\xe2\x80\x94the\r\ngigantic bellows, the monstrous extinguishers, the superhuman fans.\r\nEveryone hastened to purchase _moccoletti_\xe2\x80\x94Franz and Albert among the\r\nrest.\r\n\r\nThe night was rapidly approaching; and already, at the cry of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Moccoletti_!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated by the shrill voices of a thousand vendors,\r\ntwo or three stars began to burn among the crowd. It was a signal. At\r\nthe end of ten minutes fifty thousand lights glittered, descending from\r\nthe Palazzo di Venezia to the Piazza del Popolo, and mounting from the\r\nPiazza del Popolo to the Palazzo di Venezia. It seemed like the _f\xc3\xaate_\r\nof Jack-o\xe2\x80\x99-lanterns.\r\n\r\nIt is impossible to form any idea of it without having seen it. Suppose\r\nthat all the stars had descended from the sky and mingled in a wild\r\ndance on the face of the earth; the whole accompanied by cries that\r\nwere never heard in any other part of the world. The _facchino_ follows\r\nthe prince, the Transteverin the citizen, everyone blowing,\r\nextinguishing, relighting. Had old \xc3\x86olus appeared at this moment, he\r\nwould have been proclaimed king of the _moccoli_, and Aquilo the\r\nheir-presumptive to the throne.\r\n\r\nThis battle of folly and flame continued for two hours; the Corso was\r\nlight as day; the features of the spectators on the third and fourth\r\nstories were visible.\r\n\r\nEvery five minutes Albert took out his watch; at length it pointed to\r\nseven. The two friends were in the Via dei Pontefici. Albert sprang\r\nout, bearing his _moccoletto_ in his hand. Two or three masks strove to\r\nknock his _moccoletto_ out of his hand; but Albert, a first-rate\r\npugilist, sent them rolling in the street, one after the other, and\r\ncontinued his course towards the church of San Giacomo.\r\n\r\nThe steps were crowded with masks, who strove to snatch each other\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntorches. Franz followed Albert with his eyes, and saw him mount the\r\nfirst step.\r\n\r\nInstantly a mask, wearing the well-known costume of a peasant woman,\r\nsnatched his _moccoletto_ from him without his offering any resistance.\r\nFranz was too far off to hear what they said; but, without doubt,\r\nnothing hostile passed, for he saw Albert disappear arm-in-arm with the\r\npeasant girl. He watched them pass through the crowd for some time, but\r\nat length he lost sight of them in the Via Macello.\r\n\r\nSuddenly the bell that gives the signal for the end of the Carnival\r\nsounded, and at the same instant all the _moccoletti_ were extinguished\r\nas if by enchantment. It seemed as though one immense blast of the wind\r\nhad extinguished everyone.\r\n\r\nFranz found himself in utter darkness. No sound was audible save that\r\nof the carriages that were carrying the maskers home; nothing was\r\nvisible save a few lights that burnt behind the windows.\r\n\r\nThe Carnival was over.\r\n\r\n20193m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 37. The Catacombs of Saint Sebastian\r\n\r\nIn his whole life, perhaps, Franz had never before experienced so\r\nsudden an impression, so rapid a transition from gayety to sadness, as\r\nin this moment. It seemed as though Rome, under the magic breath of\r\nsome demon of the night, had suddenly changed into a vast tomb. By a\r\nchance, which added yet more to the intensity of the darkness, the\r\nmoon, which was on the wane, did not rise until eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and the\r\nstreets which the young man traversed were plunged in the deepest\r\nobscurity.\r\n\r\nThe distance was short, and at the end of ten minutes his carriage, or\r\nrather the count\xe2\x80\x99s, stopped before the H\xc3\xb4tel de Londres.\r\n\r\nDinner was waiting, but as Albert had told him that he should not\r\nreturn so soon, Franz sat down without him. Signor Pastrini, who had\r\nbeen accustomed to see them dine together, inquired into the cause of\r\nhis absence, but Franz merely replied that Albert had received on the\r\nprevious evening an invitation which he had accepted.\r\n\r\nThe sudden extinction of the _moccoletti_, the darkness which had\r\nreplaced the light, and the silence which had succeeded the turmoil,\r\nhad left in Franz\xe2\x80\x99s mind a certain depression which was not free from\r\nuneasiness. He therefore dined very silently, in spite of the officious\r\nattention of his host, who presented himself two or three times to\r\ninquire if he wanted anything.\r\n\r\nFranz resolved to wait for Albert as late as possible. He ordered the\r\ncarriage, therefore, for eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, desiring Signor Pastrini to\r\ninform him the moment that Albert returned to the hotel.\r\n\r\nAt eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock Albert had not come back. Franz dressed himself, and\r\nwent out, telling his host that he was going to pass the night at the\r\nDuke of Bracciano\xe2\x80\x99s. The house of the Duke of Bracciano is one of the\r\nmost delightful in Rome, the duchess, one of the last heiresses of the\r\nColonnas, does its honors with the most consummate grace, and thus\r\ntheir _f\xc3\xaates_ have a European celebrity.\r\n\r\nFranz and Albert had brought to Rome letters of introduction to them,\r\nand their first question on his arrival was to inquire the whereabouts\r\nof his travelling companion. Franz replied that he had left him at the\r\nmoment they were about to extinguish the _moccoli_, and that he had\r\nlost sight of him in the Via Macello.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he has not returned?\xe2\x80\x9d said the duke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI waited for him until this hour,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you know whither he went?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not precisely; however, I think it was something very like a\r\nrendezvous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Diavolo!_\xe2\x80\x9d said the duke, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is a bad day, or rather a bad night,\r\nto be out late; is it not, countess?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese words were addressed to the Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, who had just arrived,\r\nand was leaning on the arm of Signor Torlonia, the duke\xe2\x80\x99s brother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think, on the contrary, that it is a charming night,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\ncountess, \xe2\x80\x9cand those who are here will complain of but one thing, that\r\nof its too rapid flight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not speaking,\xe2\x80\x9d said the duke with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cof the persons who\r\nare here; the men run no other danger than that of falling in love with\r\nyou, and the women of falling ill of jealousy at seeing you so lovely;\r\nI meant persons who were out in the streets of Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess, \xe2\x80\x9cwho is out in the streets of Rome at this\r\nhour, unless it be to go to a ball?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur friend, Albert de Morcerf, countess, whom I left in pursuit of his\r\nunknown about seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock this evening,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cand whom I have\r\nnot seen since.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd don\xe2\x80\x99t you know where he is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he armed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is in masquerade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should not have allowed him to go,\xe2\x80\x9d said the duke to Franz; \xe2\x80\x9cyou,\r\nwho know Rome better than he does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might as well have tried to stop number three of the _barberi_,\r\nwho gained the prize in the race today,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz; \xe2\x80\x9cand then\r\nmoreover, what could happen to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho can tell? The night is gloomy, and the Tiber is very near the Via\r\nMacello.\xe2\x80\x9d Franz felt a shudder run through his veins at observing that\r\nthe feeling of the duke and the countess was so much in unison with his\r\nown personal disquietude.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI informed them at the hotel that I had the honor of passing the night\r\nhere, duke,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cand desired them to come and inform me of his\r\nreturn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the duke, \xe2\x80\x9chere I think, is one of my servants who is\r\nseeking you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe duke was not mistaken; when he saw Franz, the servant came up to\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe master of the H\xc3\xb4tel de Londres has\r\nsent to let you know that a man is waiting for you with a letter from\r\nthe Viscount of Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA letter from the viscount!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who is the man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did he not bring it to me here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe messenger did not say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where is the messenger?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe went away directly he saw me enter the ball-room to find you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess to Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cgo with all speed\xe2\x80\x94poor young man!\r\nPerhaps some accident has happened to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will hasten,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we see you again to give us any information?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the\r\ncountess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, if it is not any serious affair, otherwise I cannot answer as to\r\nwhat I may do myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe prudent, in any event,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! pray be assured of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz took his hat and went away in haste. He had sent away his\r\ncarriage with orders for it to fetch him at two o\xe2\x80\x99clock; fortunately\r\nthe Palazzo Bracciano, which is on one side in the Corso, and on the\r\nother in the Square of the Holy Apostles, is hardly ten minutes\xe2\x80\x99 walk\r\nfrom the H\xc3\xb4tel de Londres.\r\n\r\nAs he came near the hotel, Franz saw a man in the middle of the street.\r\nHe had no doubt that it was the messenger from Albert. The man was\r\nwrapped up in a large cloak. He went up to him, but, to his extreme\r\nastonishment, the stranger first addressed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat wants your excellency of me?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the man, retreating a step\r\nor two, as if to keep on his guard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre not you the person who brought me a letter,\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cfrom\r\nthe Viscount of Morcerf?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency lodges at Pastrini\xe2\x80\x99s hotel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency is the travelling companion of the viscount?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency\xe2\x80\x99s name\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the Baron Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20199m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it is to your excellency that this letter is addressed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there any answer?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Franz, taking the letter from him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94your friend at least hopes so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome upstairs with me, and I will give it to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI prefer waiting here,\xe2\x80\x9d said the messenger, with a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency will know when you have read the letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I find you here, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz entered the hotel. On the staircase he met Signor Pastrini.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said the landlord.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell\xe2\x80\x94what?\xe2\x80\x9d responded Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have seen the man who desired to speak with you from your friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe asked of Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have seen him,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cand he has handed this letter to\r\nme. Light the candles in my apartment, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe innkeeper gave orders to a servant to go before Franz with a light.\r\nThe young man had found Signor Pastrini looking very much alarmed, and\r\nthis had only made him the more anxious to read Albert\xe2\x80\x99s letter; and so\r\nhe went instantly towards the waxlight, and unfolded it. It was written\r\nand signed by Albert. Franz read it twice before he could comprehend\r\nwhat it contained. It was thus worded:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Fellow,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe moment you have received this, have the kindness to take the\r\nletter of credit from my pocket-book, which you will find in the square\r\ndrawer of the _secr\xc3\xa9taire_; add your own to it, if it be not\r\nsufficient. Run to Torlonia, draw from him instantly four thousand\r\npiastres, and give them to the bearer. It is urgent that I should have\r\nthis money without delay. I do not say more, relying on you as you may\r\nrely on me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour friend,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert de Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cP.S.\xe2\x80\x94I now believe in Italian _banditti_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBelow these lines were written, in a strange hand, the following in\r\nItalian:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Se alle sei della mattina le quattro mille piastre non sono nelle mie\r\nmani, alla sette il Conte Alberto avr\xc3\xa0 cessato di vivere_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLuigi Vampa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_If by six in the morning the four thousand piastres are not in my\r\nhands, by seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock the Count Albert will have ceased to live_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis second signature explained everything to Franz, who now understood\r\nthe objection of the messenger to coming up into the apartment; the\r\nstreet was safer for him. Albert, then, had fallen into the hands of\r\nthe famous bandit chief, in whose existence he had for so long a time\r\nrefused to believe.\r\n\r\nThere was no time to lose. He hastened to open the _secr\xc3\xa9taire_, and\r\nfound the pocket-book in the drawer, and in it the letter of credit.\r\nThere were in all six thousand piastres, but of these six thousand\r\nAlbert had already expended three thousand.\r\n\r\nAs to Franz, he had no letter of credit, as he lived at Florence, and\r\nhad only come to Rome to pass seven or eight days; he had brought but a\r\nhundred louis, and of these he had not more than fifty left. Thus seven\r\nor eight hundred piastres were wanting to them both to make up the sum\r\nthat Albert required. True, he might in such a case rely on the\r\nkindness of Signor Torlonia. He was, therefore, about to return to the\r\nPalazzo Bracciano without loss of time, when suddenly a luminous idea\r\ncrossed his mind.\r\n\r\nHe remembered the Count of Monte Cristo. Franz was about to ring for\r\nSignor Pastrini, when that worthy presented himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear sir,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, hastily, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know if the count is within?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your excellency; he has this moment returned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he in bed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should say no.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen ring at his door, if you please, and request him to be so kind as\r\nto give me an audience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSignor Pastrini did as he was desired, and returning five minutes\r\nafter, he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count awaits your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz went along the corridor, and a servant introduced him to the\r\ncount. He was in a small room which Franz had not yet seen, and which\r\nwas surrounded with divans. The count came towards him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what good wind blows you hither at this hour?\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9chave\r\nyou come to sup with me? It would be very kind of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I have come to speak to you of a very serious matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA serious matter,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, looking at Franz with the\r\nearnestness usual to him; \xe2\x80\x9cand what may it be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre we alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, going to the door, and returning. Franz gave\r\nhim Albert\xe2\x80\x99s letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead that,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThe count read it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you see the postscript?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did, indeed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_\xe2\x80\x98Se alle sei della mattina le quattro mille piastre non sono nelle\r\nmie mani, alla sette il conte Alberto avr\xc3\xa0 cessato di vivere. _\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Luigi Vampa.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat think you of that?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you the money he demands?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, all but eight hundred piastres.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count went to his _secr\xc3\xa9taire_, opened it, and pulling out a drawer\r\nfilled with gold, said to Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cI hope you will not offend me by\r\napplying to anyone but myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, on the contrary, I come to you first and instantly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nFranz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I thank you; have what you will;\xe2\x80\x9d and he made a sign to Franz to\r\ntake what he pleased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it absolutely necessary, then, to send the money to Luigi Vampa?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nasked the young man, looking fixedly in his turn at the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJudge for yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he. \xe2\x80\x9cThe postscript is explicit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think that if you would take the trouble of reflecting, you could\r\nfind a way of simplifying the negotiation,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count, with surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we were to go together to Luigi Vampa, I am sure he would not\r\nrefuse you Albert\xe2\x80\x99s freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat influence can I possibly have over a bandit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you not just rendered him a service that can never be forgotten?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you not saved Peppino\xe2\x80\x99s life?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cwho told you that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo matter; I know it.\xe2\x80\x9d The count knit his brows, and remained silent\r\nan instant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if I went to seek Vampa, would you accompany me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf my society would not be disagreeable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so. It is a lovely night, and a walk without Rome will do us\r\nboth good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I take any arms?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor what purpose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is useless. Where is the man who brought the letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the street.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe awaits the answer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must learn where we are going. I will summon him hither.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is useless; he would not come up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo your apartments, perhaps; but he will not make any difficulty at\r\nentering mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count went to the window of the apartment that looked on to the\r\nstreet, and whistled in a peculiar manner. The man in the mantle\r\nquitted the wall, and advanced into the middle of the street.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Salite!_\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, in the same tone in which he would have\r\ngiven an order to his servant. The messenger obeyed without the least\r\nhesitation, but rather with alacrity, and, mounting the steps at a\r\nbound, entered the hotel; five seconds afterwards he was at the door of\r\nthe room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, it is you, Peppino,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count. But Peppino, instead of\r\nanswering, threw himself on his knees, seized the count\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and\r\ncovered it with kisses. \xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have, then, not\r\nforgotten that I saved your life; that is strange, for it is a week\r\nago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20203m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, excellency; and never shall I forget it,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Peppino, with\r\nan accent of profound gratitude.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever? That is a long time; but it is something that you believe so.\r\nRise and answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPeppino glanced anxiously at Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you may speak before his excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9che is one of my\r\nfriends. You allow me to give you this title?\xe2\x80\x9d continued the count in\r\nFrench, \xe2\x80\x9cit is necessary to excite this man\xe2\x80\x99s confidence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can speak before me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz; \xe2\x80\x9cI am a friend of the count\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d returned Peppino. \xe2\x80\x9cI am ready to answer any questions your\r\nexcellency may address to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did the Viscount Albert fall into Luigi\xe2\x80\x99s hands?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcellency, the Frenchman\xe2\x80\x99s carriage passed several times the one in\r\nwhich was Teresa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe chief\xe2\x80\x99s mistress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. The Frenchman threw her a bouquet; Teresa returned it\xe2\x80\x94all this\r\nwith the consent of the chief, who was in the carriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cwas Luigi Vampa in the carriage with the Roman\r\npeasants?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was he who drove, disguised as the coachman,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Peppino.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, the Frenchman took off his mask; Teresa, with the chief\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconsent, did the same. The Frenchman asked for a rendezvous; Teresa\r\ngave him one\xe2\x80\x94only, instead of Teresa, it was Beppo who was on the steps\r\nof the church of San Giacomo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cthe peasant girl who snatched his _mocoletto_\r\nfrom him\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas a lad of fifteen,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Peppino. \xe2\x80\x9cBut it was no disgrace to\r\nyour friend to have been deceived; Beppo has taken in plenty of\r\nothers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Beppo led him outside the walls?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so; a carriage was waiting at the end of the Via Macello.\r\nBeppo got in, inviting the Frenchman to follow him, and he did not wait\r\nto be asked twice. He gallantly offered the right-hand seat to Beppo,\r\nand sat by him. Beppo told him he was going to take him to a villa a\r\nleague from Rome; the Frenchman assured him he would follow him to the\r\nend of the world. The coachman went up the Via di Ripetta and the Porta\r\nSan Paolo; and when they were two hundred yards outside, as the\r\nFrenchman became somewhat too forward, Beppo put a brace of pistols to\r\nhis head, the coachman pulled up and did the same. At the same time,\r\nfour of the band, who were concealed on the banks of the Almo,\r\nsurrounded the carriage. The Frenchman made some resistance, and nearly\r\nstrangled Beppo; but he could not resist five armed men, and was forced\r\nto yield. They made him get out, walk along the banks of the river, and\r\nthen brought him to Teresa and Luigi, who were waiting for him in the\r\ncatacombs of St. Sebastian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, turning towards Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cit seems to me that\r\nthis is a very likely story. What do you say to it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that I should think it very amusing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cif it had\r\nhappened to anyone but poor Albert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, in truth, if you had not found me here,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cit\r\nmight have proved a gallant adventure which would have cost your friend\r\ndear; but now, be assured, his alarm will be the only serious\r\nconsequence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd shall we go and find him?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, decidedly, sir. He is in a very picturesque place\xe2\x80\x94do you know the\r\ncatacombs of St. Sebastian?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was never in them; but I have often resolved to visit them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, here is an opportunity made to your hand, and it would be\r\ndifficult to contrive a better. Have you a carriage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is of no consequence; I always have one ready, day and night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlways ready?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. I am a very capricious being, and I should tell you that\r\nsometimes when I rise, or after my dinner, or in the middle of the\r\nnight, I resolve on starting for some particular point, and away I go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count rang, and a footman appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOrder out the carriage,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand remove the pistols which are in\r\nthe holsters. You need not awaken the coachman; Ali will drive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn a very short time the noise of wheels was heard, and the carriage\r\nstopped at the door. The count took out his watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf-past twelve,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe might start at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock and be in\r\ntime, but the delay may cause your friend to pass an uneasy night, and\r\ntherefore we had better go with all speed to extricate him from the\r\nhands of the infidels. Are you still resolved to accompany me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMore determined than ever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, come along.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz and the count went downstairs, accompanied by Peppino. At the\r\ndoor they found the carriage. Ali was on the box, in whom Franz\r\nrecognized the dumb slave of the grotto of Monte Cristo. Franz and the\r\ncount got into the carriage. Peppino placed himself beside Ali, and\r\nthey set off at a rapid pace. Ali had received his instructions, and\r\nwent down the Corso, crossed the Campo Vaccino, went up the Strada San\r\nGregorio, and reached the gates of St. Sebastian. Then the porter\r\nraised some difficulties, but the Count of Monte Cristo produced a\r\npermit from the governor of Rome, allowing him to leave or enter the\r\ncity at any hour of the day or night; the portcullis was therefore\r\nraised, the porter had a louis for his trouble, and they went on their\r\nway.\r\n\r\nThe road which the carriage now traversed was the ancient Appian Way,\r\nand bordered with tombs. From time to time, by the light of the moon,\r\nwhich began to rise, Franz imagined that he saw something like a\r\nsentinel appear at various points among the ruins, and suddenly retreat\r\ninto the darkness on a signal from Peppino.\r\n\r\nA short time before they reached the Baths of Caracalla the carriage\r\nstopped, Peppino opened the door, and the count and Franz alighted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn ten minutes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count to his companion, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall be there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then took Peppino aside, gave him an order in a low voice, and\r\nPeppino went away, taking with him a torch, brought with them in the\r\ncarriage. Five minutes elapsed, during which Franz saw the shepherd\r\ngoing along a narrow path that led over the irregular and broken\r\nsurface of the Campagna; and finally he disappeared in the midst of the\r\ntall red herbage, which seemed like the bristling mane of an enormous\r\nlion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9clet us follow him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz and the count in their turn then advanced along the same path,\r\nwhich, at the distance of a hundred paces, led them over a declivity to\r\nthe bottom of a small valley. They then perceived two men conversing in\r\nthe obscurity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOught we to go on?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Franz of the count; \xe2\x80\x9cor should we pause?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go on; Peppino will have warned the sentry of our coming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne of the two men was Peppino, and the other a bandit on the lookout.\r\nFranz and the count advanced, and the bandit saluted them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peppino, addressing the count, \xe2\x80\x9cif you will\r\nfollow me, the opening of the catacombs is close at hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, then,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count. They came to an opening behind a\r\nclump of bushes and in the midst of a pile of rocks, by which a man\r\ncould scarcely pass. Peppino glided first into this crevice; after they\r\ngot along a few paces the passage widened. Peppino passed, lighted his\r\ntorch, and turned to see if they came after him. The count first\r\nreached an open space and Franz followed him closely. The passageway\r\nsloped in a gentle descent, enlarging as they proceeded; still Franz\r\nand the count were compelled to advance in a stooping posture, and were\r\nscarcely able to proceed abreast of one another. They went on a hundred\r\nand fifty paces in this way, and then were stopped by, \xe2\x80\x9cWho comes\r\nthere?\xe2\x80\x9d At the same time they saw the reflection of a torch on a\r\ncarbine barrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA friend!\xe2\x80\x9d responded Peppino; and, advancing alone towards the sentry,\r\nhe said a few words to him in a low tone; and then he, like the first,\r\nsaluted the nocturnal visitors, making a sign that they might proceed.\r\n\r\nBehind the sentinel was a staircase with twenty steps. Franz and the\r\ncount descended these, and found themselves in a mortuary chamber. Five\r\ncorridors diverged like the rays of a star, and the walls, dug into\r\nniches, which were arranged one above the other in the shape of\r\ncoffins, showed that they were at last in the catacombs. Down one of\r\nthe corridors, whose extent it was impossible to determine, rays of\r\nlight were visible. The count laid his hand on Franz\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you like to see a camp of bandits in repose?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExceedingly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome with me, then. Peppino, put out the torch.\xe2\x80\x9d Peppino obeyed, and\r\nFranz and the count were in utter darkness, except that fifty paces in\r\nadvance of them a reddish glare, more evident since Peppino had put out\r\nhis torch, was visible along the wall.\r\n\r\nThey advanced silently, the count guiding Franz as if he had the\r\nsingular faculty of seeing in the dark. Franz himself, however, saw his\r\nway more plainly in proportion as he went on towards the light, which\r\nserved in some manner as a guide. Three arcades were before them, and\r\nthe middle one was used as a door. These arcades opened on one side\r\ninto the corridor where the count and Franz were, and on the other into\r\na large square chamber, entirely surrounded by niches similar to those\r\nof which we have spoken.\r\n\r\nIn the midst of this chamber were four stones, which had formerly\r\nserved as an altar, as was evident from the cross which still\r\nsurmounted them. A lamp, placed at the base of a pillar, lighted up\r\nwith its pale and flickering flame the singular scene which presented\r\nitself to the eyes of the two visitors concealed in the shadow.\r\n\r\nA man was seated with his elbow leaning on the column, and was reading\r\nwith his back turned to the arcades, through the openings of which the\r\nnew-comers contemplated him. This was the chief of the band, Luigi\r\nVampa. Around him, and in groups, according to their fancy, lying in\r\ntheir mantles, or with their backs against a sort of stone bench, which\r\nwent all round the columbarium, were to be seen twenty brigands or\r\nmore, each having his carbine within reach. At the other end, silent,\r\nscarcely visible, and like a shadow, was a sentinel, who was walking up\r\nand down before a grotto, which was only distinguishable because in\r\nthat spot the darkness seemed more dense than elsewhere.\r\n\r\nWhen the count thought Franz had gazed sufficiently on this picturesque\r\ntableau, he raised his finger to his lips, to warn him to be silent,\r\nand, ascending the three steps which led to the corridor of the\r\ncolumbarium, entered the chamber by the middle arcade, and advanced\r\ntowards Vampa, who was so intent on the book before him that he did not\r\nhear the noise of his footsteps.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho comes there?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sentinel, who was less abstracted, and who\r\nsaw by the lamp-light a shadow approaching his chief. At this\r\nchallenge, Vampa rose quickly, drawing at the same moment a pistol from\r\nhis girdle. In a moment all the bandits were on their feet, and twenty\r\ncarbines were levelled at the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he in a voice perfectly calm, and no muscle of his\r\ncountenance disturbed, \xe2\x80\x9cwell, my dear Vampa, it appears to me that you\r\nreceive a friend with a great deal of ceremony.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20207m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGround arms,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the chief, with an imperative sign of the\r\nhand, while with the other he took off his hat respectfully; then,\r\nturning to the singular personage who had caused this scene, he said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour pardon, your excellency, but I was so far from expecting the\r\nhonor of a visit, that I did not really recognize you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems that your memory is equally short in everything, Vampa,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe count, \xe2\x80\x9cand that not only do you forget people\xe2\x80\x99s faces, but also\r\nthe conditions you make with them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat conditions have I forgotten, your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the\r\nbandit, with the air of a man who, having committed an error, is\r\nanxious to repair it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it not agreed,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count, \xe2\x80\x9cthat not only my person, but\r\nalso that of my friends, should be respected by you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how have I broken that treaty, your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have this evening carried off and conveyed hither the Viscount\r\nAlbert de Morcerf. Well,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the count, in a tone that made\r\nFranz shudder, \xe2\x80\x9cthis young gentleman is one of _my friends_\xe2\x80\x94this young\r\ngentleman lodges in the same hotel as myself\xe2\x80\x94this young gentleman has\r\nbeen up and down the Corso for eight hours in my private carriage, and\r\nyet, I repeat to you, you have carried him off, and conveyed him\r\nhither, and,\xe2\x80\x9d added the count, taking the letter from his pocket, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nhave set a ransom on him, as if he were an utter stranger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you not tell me all this\xe2\x80\x94you?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the brigand chief,\r\nturning towards his men, who all retreated before his look. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy have\r\nyou caused me thus to fail in my word towards a gentleman like the\r\ncount, who has all our lives in his hands? By heavens! if I thought one\r\nof you knew that the young gentleman was the friend of his excellency,\r\nI would blow his brains out with my own hand!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20211m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, turning towards Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cI told you there was\r\nsome mistake in this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you not alone?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Vampa with uneasiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am with the person to whom this letter was addressed, and to whom I\r\ndesired to prove that Luigi Vampa was a man of his word. Come, your\r\nexcellency,\xe2\x80\x9d the count added, turning to Franz, \xe2\x80\x9chere is Luigi Vampa,\r\nwho will himself express to you his deep regret at the mistake he has\r\ncommitted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz approached, the chief advancing several steps to meet him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWelcome among us, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to him; \xe2\x80\x9cyou heard what\r\nthe count just said, and also my reply; let me add that I would not for\r\nthe four thousand piastres at which I had fixed your friend\xe2\x80\x99s ransom,\r\nthat this had happened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, looking round him uneasily, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere is the\r\nviscount?\xe2\x80\x94I do not see him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing has happened to him, I hope,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count frowningly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe prisoner is there,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Vampa, pointing to the hollow space in\r\nfront of which the bandit was on guard, \xe2\x80\x9cand I will go myself and tell\r\nhim he is free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe chief went towards the place he had pointed out as Albert\xe2\x80\x99s prison,\r\nand Franz and the count followed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the prisoner doing?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Vampa of the sentinel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi_, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the sentry, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not know; for the last\r\nhour I have not heard him stir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Vampa. The count and Franz ascended\r\nseven or eight steps after the chief, who drew back a bolt and opened a\r\ndoor. Then, by the gleam of a lamp, similar to that which lighted the\r\ncolumbarium, Albert was to be seen wrapped up in a cloak which one of\r\nthe bandits had lent him, lying in a corner in profound slumber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, smiling with his own peculiar smile, \xe2\x80\x9cnot so\r\nbad for a man who is to be shot at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock tomorrow morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVampa looked at Albert with a kind of admiration; he was not insensible\r\nto such a proof of courage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cthis must be one of your\r\nfriends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen going to Albert, he touched him on the shoulder, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cWill\r\nyour excellency please to awaken?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert stretched out his arms, rubbed his eyelids, and opened his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cis it you, captain? You should have allowed me to\r\nsleep. I had such a delightful dream. I was dancing the galop at\r\nTorlonia\xe2\x80\x99s with the Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94.\xe2\x80\x9d Then he drew his watch from his\r\npocket, that he might see how time sped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf-past one only?\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy the devil do you rouse me at this\r\nhour?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo tell you that you are free, your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, with perfect ease of mind, \xe2\x80\x9cremember,\r\nfor the future, Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s maxim, \xe2\x80\x98Never awaken me but for bad news;\xe2\x80\x99\r\nif you had let me sleep on, I should have finished my galop, and have\r\nbeen grateful to you all my life. So, then, they have paid my ransom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, how am I free?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA person to whom I can refuse nothing has come to demand you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome hither?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, hither.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally? Then that person is a most amiable person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert looked around and perceived Franz. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cis it you,\r\nmy dear Franz, whose devotion and friendship are thus displayed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not I,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cbut our neighbor, the Count of Monte\r\nCristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert gayly, arranging his cravat and\r\nwristbands, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are really most kind, and I hope you will consider me\r\nas under eternal obligations to you, in the first place for the\r\ncarriage, and in the next for this visit,\xe2\x80\x9d and he put out his hand to\r\nthe count, who shuddered as he gave his own, but who nevertheless did\r\ngive it.\r\n\r\nThe bandit gazed on this scene with amazement; he was evidently\r\naccustomed to see his prisoners tremble before him, and yet here was\r\none whose gay temperament was not for a moment altered; as for Franz,\r\nhe was enchanted at the way in which Albert had sustained the national\r\nhonor in the presence of the bandit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cif you will make haste, we shall yet have\r\ntime to finish the night at Torlonia\xe2\x80\x99s. You may conclude your\r\ninterrupted galop, so that you will owe no ill-will to Signor Luigi,\r\nwho has, indeed, throughout this whole affair acted like a gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are decidedly right, and we may reach the Palazzo by two o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\r\nSignor Luigi,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cis there any formality to fulfil\r\nbefore I take leave of your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the bandit, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are as free as air.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, a happy and merry life to you. Come, gentlemen, come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Albert, followed by Franz and the count, descended the staircase,\r\ncrossed the square chamber, where stood all the bandits, hat in hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeppino,\xe2\x80\x9d said the brigand chief, \xe2\x80\x9cgive me the torch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you going to do?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will show you the way back myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is the\r\nleast honor that I can render to your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd taking the lighted torch from the hands of the herdsman, he\r\npreceded his guests, not as a servant who performs an act of civility,\r\nbut like a king who precedes ambassadors. On reaching the door, he\r\nbowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, \xe2\x80\x9callow me to repeat my apologies,\r\nand I hope you will not entertain any resentment at what has occurred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my dear Vampa,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count; \xe2\x80\x9cbesides, you compensate for\r\nyour mistakes in so gentlemanly a way, that one almost feels obliged to\r\nyou for having committed them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20214m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d added the chief, turning towards the young men, \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps\r\nthe offer may not appear very tempting to you; but if you should ever\r\nfeel inclined to pay me a second visit, wherever I may be, you shall be\r\nwelcome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz and Albert bowed. The count went out first, then Albert. Franz\r\npaused for a moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas your excellency anything to ask me?\xe2\x80\x9d said Vampa with a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz; \xe2\x80\x9cI am curious to know what work you were\r\nperusing with so much attention as we entered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cC\xc3\xa6sar\xe2\x80\x99s _Commentaries_,\xe2\x80\x9d said the bandit, \xe2\x80\x9cit is my favorite work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, are you coming?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz, \xe2\x80\x9chere I am,\xe2\x80\x9d and he, in his turn, left the caves.\r\nThey advanced to the plain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, your pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, turning round; \xe2\x80\x9cwill you allow me,\r\ncaptain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he lighted his cigar at Vampa\xe2\x80\x99s torch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, my dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9clet us on with all the speed we may. I\r\nam enormously anxious to finish my night at the Duke of Bracciano\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey found the carriage where they had left it. The count said a word\r\nin Arabic to Ali, and the horses went on at great speed.\r\n\r\nIt was just two o\xe2\x80\x99clock by Albert\xe2\x80\x99s watch when the two friends entered\r\ninto the dancing-room. Their return was quite an event, but as they\r\nentered together, all uneasiness on Albert\xe2\x80\x99s account ceased instantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Viscount of Morcerf, advancing towards the countess,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyesterday you were so condescending as to promise me a galop; I am\r\nrather late in claiming this gracious promise, but here is my friend,\r\nwhose character for veracity you well know, and he will assure you the\r\ndelay arose from no fault of mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd as at this moment the orchestra gave the signal for the waltz,\r\nAlbert put his arm round the waist of the countess, and disappeared\r\nwith her in the whirl of dancers.\r\n\r\nIn the meanwhile Franz was considering the singular shudder that had\r\npassed over the Count of Monte Cristo at the moment when he had been,\r\nin some sort, forced to give his hand to Albert.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 38. The Rendezvous\r\n\r\nThe first words that Albert uttered to his friend, on the following\r\nmorning, contained a request that Franz would accompany him on a visit\r\nto the count; true, the young man had warmly and energetically thanked\r\nthe count on the previous evening; but services such as he had rendered\r\ncould never be too often acknowledged. Franz, who seemed attracted by\r\nsome invisible influence towards the count, in which terror was\r\nstrangely mingled, felt an extreme reluctance to permit his friend to\r\nbe exposed alone to the singular fascination that this mysterious\r\npersonage seemed to exercise over him, and therefore made no objection\r\nto Albert\xe2\x80\x99s request, but at once accompanied him to the desired spot,\r\nand, after a short delay, the count joined them in the salon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, advancing to meet him, \xe2\x80\x9cpermit me to\r\nrepeat the poor thanks I offered last night, and to assure you that the\r\nremembrance of all I owe to you will never be effaced from my memory;\r\nbelieve me, as long as I live, I shall never cease to dwell with\r\ngrateful recollection on the prompt and important service you rendered\r\nme; and also to remember that to you I am indebted even for my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy very good friend and excellent neighbor,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, with a\r\nsmile, \xe2\x80\x9cyou really exaggerate my trifling exertions. You owe me nothing\r\nbut some trifle of 20,000 francs, which you have been saved out of your\r\ntravelling expenses, so that there is not much of a score between\r\nus;\xe2\x80\x94but you must really permit me to congratulate you on the ease and\r\nunconcern with which you resigned yourself to your fate, and the\r\nperfect indifference you manifested as to the turn events might take.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI deserve no credit for what I could not\r\nhelp, namely, a determination to take everything as I found it, and to\r\nlet those bandits see, that although men get into troublesome scrapes\r\nall over the world, there is no nation but the French that can smile\r\neven in the face of grim Death himself. All that, however, has nothing\r\nto do with my obligations to you, and I now come to ask you whether, in\r\nmy own person, my family, or connections, I can in any way serve you?\r\nMy father, the Comte de Morcerf, although of Spanish origin, possesses\r\nconsiderable influence, both at the court of France and Madrid, and I\r\nunhesitatingly place the best services of myself, and all to whom my\r\nlife is dear, at your disposal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur de Morcerf,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, \xe2\x80\x9cyour offer, far from\r\nsurprising me, is precisely what I expected from you, and I accept it\r\nin the same spirit of hearty sincerity with which it is made;\xe2\x80\x94nay, I\r\nwill go still further, and say that I had previously made up my mind to\r\nask a great favor at your hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, pray name it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am wholly a stranger to Paris\xe2\x80\x94it is a city I have never yet seen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you have reached your present\r\nage without visiting the finest capital in the world? I can scarcely\r\ncredit it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless, it is quite true; still, I agree with you in thinking\r\nthat my present ignorance of the first city in Europe is a reproach to\r\nme in every way, and calls for immediate correction; but, in all\r\nprobability, I should have performed so important, so necessary a duty,\r\nas that of making myself acquainted with the wonders and beauties of\r\nyour justly celebrated capital, had I known any person who would have\r\nintroduced me into the fashionable world, but unfortunately I possessed\r\nno acquaintance there, and, of necessity, was compelled to abandon the\r\nidea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo distinguished an individual as yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Albert, \xe2\x80\x9ccould\r\nscarcely have required an introduction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are most kind; but as regards myself, I can find no merit I\r\npossess, save that, as a millionaire, I might have become a partner in\r\nthe speculations of M. Aguado and M. Rothschild; but as my motive in\r\ntravelling to your capital would not have been for the pleasure of\r\ndabbling in stocks, I stayed away till some favorable chance should\r\npresent itself of carrying my wish into execution. Your offer, however,\r\nsmooths all difficulties, and I have only to ask you, my dear M. de\r\nMorcerf\xe2\x80\x9d (these words were accompanied by a most peculiar smile),\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhether you undertake, upon my arrival in France, to open to me the\r\ndoors of that fashionable world of which I know no more than a Huron or\r\na native of Cochin-China?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that I do, and with infinite pleasure,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cand so\r\nmuch the more readily as a letter received this morning from my father\r\nsummons me to Paris, in consequence of a treaty of marriage (my dear\r\nFranz, do not smile, I beg of you) with a family of high standing, and\r\nconnected with the very cream of Parisian society.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConnected by marriage, you mean,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, laughingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, never mind how it is,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cit comes to the same\r\nthing in the end. Perhaps by the time you return to Paris, I shall be\r\nquite a sober, staid father of a family! A most edifying representative\r\nI shall make of all the domestic virtues\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t you think so? But as\r\nregards your wish to visit our fine city, my dear count, I can only say\r\nthat you may command me and mine to any extent you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it is settled,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cand I give you my solemn\r\nassurance that I only waited an opportunity like the present to realize\r\nplans that I have long meditated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz did not doubt that these plans were the same concerning which the\r\ncount had dropped a few words in the grotto of Monte Cristo, and while\r\nthe count was speaking the young man watched him closely, hoping to\r\nread something of his purpose in his face, but his countenance was\r\ninscrutable especially when, as in the present case, it was veiled in a\r\nsphinx-like smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut tell me now, count,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Albert, delighted at the idea of\r\nhaving to chaperon so distinguished a person as Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9ctell me\r\ntruly whether you are in earnest, or if this project of visiting Paris\r\nis merely one of the chimerical and uncertain air castles of which we\r\nmake so many in the course of our lives, but which, like a house built\r\non the sand, is liable to be blown over by the first puff of wind?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pledge you my honor,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I mean to do as I\r\nhave said; both inclination and positive necessity compel me to visit\r\nParis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen do you propose going thither?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you made up your mind when you shall be there yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly I have; in a fortnight or three weeks\xe2\x80\x99 time, that is to say,\r\nas fast as I can get there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Count; \xe2\x80\x9cI will give you three months ere I join you;\r\nyou see I make an ample allowance for all delays and difficulties.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd in three months\xe2\x80\x99 time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will be at my house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we make a positive appointment for a particular day and hour?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ninquired the count; \xe2\x80\x9conly let me warn you that I am proverbial for my\r\npunctilious exactitude in keeping my engagements.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDay for day, hour for hour,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cthat will suit me to a\r\ndot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo be it, then,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, and extending his hand towards a\r\ncalendar, suspended near the chimney-piece, he said, \xe2\x80\x9ctoday is the 21st\r\nof February;\xe2\x80\x9d and drawing out his watch, added, \xe2\x80\x9cit is exactly\r\nhalf-past ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock. Now promise me to remember this, and expect me\r\nthe 21st of May at the same hour in the forenoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapital!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cyour breakfast shall be waiting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere do you live?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. 27, Rue du Helder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s apartments there? I hope my coming will not put\r\nyou to any inconvenience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI reside in my father\xe2\x80\x99s house, but occupy a pavilion at the farther\r\nside of the courtyard, entirely separated from the main building.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite sufficient,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, as, taking out his tablets, he\r\nwrote down \xe2\x80\x9cNo. 27, Rue du Helder, 21st May, half-past ten in the\r\nmorning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, returning his tablets to his pocket, \xe2\x80\x9cmake\r\nyourself perfectly easy; the hand of your time-piece will not be more\r\naccurate in marking the time than myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I see you again ere my departure?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat depends; when do you leave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow evening, at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case I must say adieu to you, as I am compelled to go to\r\nNaples, and shall not return hither before Saturday evening or Sunday\r\nmorning.
