And you, baron,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued the count, addressing Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you\r\nalso depart tomorrow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor France?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, for Venice; I shall remain in Italy for another year or two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen we shall not meet in Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fear I shall not have that honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, since we must part,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, holding out a hand to each\r\nof the young men, \xe2\x80\x9callow me to wish you both a safe and pleasant\r\njourney.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was the first time the hand of Franz had come in contact with that\r\nof the mysterious individual before him, and unconsciously he shuddered\r\nat its touch, for it felt cold and icy as that of a corpse.\r\n\r\n20219m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us understand each other,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cit is agreed\xe2\x80\x94is it\r\nnot?\xe2\x80\x94that you are to be at No. 27, in the Rue du Helder, on the 21st of\r\nMay, at half-past ten in the morning, and your word of honor passed for\r\nyour punctuality?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe 21st of May, at half-past ten in the morning, Rue du Helder, No.\r\n27,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count.\r\n\r\nThe young men then rose, and bowing to the count, quitted the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Albert of Franz, when they had returned to\r\ntheir own apartments; \xe2\x80\x9cyou seem more than commonly thoughtful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will confess to you, Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cthe count is a very\r\nsingular person, and the appointment you have made to meet him in Paris\r\nfills me with a thousand apprehensions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat can there possibly be in that\r\nto excite uneasiness? Why, you must have lost your senses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhether I am in my senses or not,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is the way I\r\nfeel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen to me, Franz,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cI am glad that the occasion has\r\npresented itself for saying this to you, for I have noticed how cold\r\nyou are in your bearing towards the count, while he, on the other hand,\r\nhas always been courtesy itself to us. Have you anything particular\r\nagainst him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever meet him previously to coming hither?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you promise me not to repeat a single word of what I am about to\r\ntell you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon your honor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen listen to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz then related to his friend the history of his excursion to the\r\nIsland of Monte Cristo and of his finding a party of smugglers there,\r\nand the two Corsican bandits with them. He dwelt with considerable\r\nforce and energy on the almost magical hospitality he had received from\r\nthe count, and the magnificence of his entertainment in the grotto of\r\nthe _Thousand and One Nights_.\r\n\r\nHe recounted, with circumstantial exactitude, all the particulars of\r\nthe supper, the hashish, the statues, the dream, and how, at his\r\nawakening, there remained no proof or trace of all these events, save\r\nthe small yacht, seen in the distant horizon driving under full sail\r\ntoward Porto-Vecchio.\r\n\r\nThen he detailed the conversation overheard by him at the Colosseum,\r\nbetween the count and Vampa, in which the count had promised to obtain\r\nthe release of the bandit Peppino,\xe2\x80\x94an engagement which, as our readers\r\nare aware, he most faithfully fulfilled.\r\n\r\nAt last he arrived at the adventure of the preceding night, and the\r\nembarrassment in which he found himself placed by not having sufficient\r\ncash by six or seven hundred piastres to make up the sum required, and\r\nfinally of his application to the count and the picturesque and\r\nsatisfactory result that followed. Albert listened with the most\r\nprofound attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, when Franz had concluded, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you find to object\r\nto in all you have related? The count is fond of travelling, and, being\r\nrich, possesses a vessel of his own. Go but to Portsmouth or\r\nSouthampton, and you will find the harbors crowded with the yachts\r\nbelonging to such of the English as can afford the expense, and have\r\nthe same liking for this amusement. Now, by way of having a\r\nresting-place during his excursions, avoiding the wretched\r\ncookery\xe2\x80\x94which has been trying its best to poison me during the last\r\nfour months, while you have manfully resisted its effects for as many\r\nyears,\xe2\x80\x94and obtaining a bed on which it is possible to slumber, Monte\r\nCristo has furnished for himself a temporary abode where you first\r\nfound him; but, to prevent the possibility of the Tuscan government\r\ntaking a fancy to his enchanted palace, and thereby depriving him of\r\nthe advantages naturally expected from so large an outlay of capital,\r\nhe has wisely enough purchased the island, and taken its name. Just ask\r\nyourself, my good fellow, whether there are not many persons of our\r\nacquaintance who assume the names of lands and properties they never in\r\ntheir lives were masters of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Corsican bandits that were among the crew of\r\nhis vessel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, really the thing seems to me simple enough. Nobody knows better\r\nthan yourself that the bandits of Corsica are not rogues or thieves,\r\nbut purely and simply fugitives, driven by some sinister motive from\r\ntheir native town or village, and that their fellowship involves no\r\ndisgrace or stigma; for my own part, I protest that, should I ever go\r\nto Corsica, my first visit, ere even I presented myself to the mayor or\r\nprefect, should be to the bandits of Colomba, if I could only manage to\r\nfind them; for, on my conscience, they are a race of men I admire\r\ngreatly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill,\xe2\x80\x9d persisted Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you will allow that such men as\r\nVampa and his band are regular villains, who have no other motive than\r\nplunder when they seize your person. How do you explain the influence\r\nthe count evidently possessed over those ruffians?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy good friend, as in all probability I own my present safety to that\r\ninfluence, it would ill become me to search too closely into its\r\nsource; therefore, instead of condemning him for his intimacy with\r\noutlaws, you must give me leave to excuse any little irregularity there\r\nmay be in such a connection; not altogether for preserving my life, for\r\nmy own idea was that it never was in much danger, but certainly for\r\nsaving me 4,000 piastres, which, being translated, means neither more\r\nnor less than 24,000 livres of our money\xe2\x80\x94a sum at which, most\r\nassuredly, I should never have been estimated in France, proving most\r\nindisputably,\xe2\x80\x9d added Albert with a laugh, \xe2\x80\x9cthat no prophet is honored\r\nin his own country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTalking of countries,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cof what country is the count,\r\nwhat is his native tongue, whence does he derive his immense fortune,\r\nand what were those events of his early life\xe2\x80\x94a life as marvellous as\r\nunknown\xe2\x80\x94that have tinctured his succeeding years with so dark and\r\ngloomy a misanthropy? Certainly these are questions that, in your\r\nplace, I should like to have answered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Franz,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen, upon receipt of my letter, you\r\nfound the necessity of asking the count\xe2\x80\x99s assistance, you promptly went\r\nto him, saying, \xe2\x80\x98My friend Albert de Morcerf is in danger; help me to\r\ndeliver him.\xe2\x80\x99 Was not that nearly what you said?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20222m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, did he ask you, \xe2\x80\x98Who is M. Albert de Morcerf? how does he\r\ncome by his name\xe2\x80\x94his fortune? what are his means of existence? what is\r\nhis birthplace? of what country is he a native?\xe2\x80\x99 Tell me, did he put\r\nall these questions to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI confess he asked me none.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; he merely came and freed me from the hands of Signor Vampa, where,\r\nI can assure you, in spite of all my outward appearance of ease and\r\nunconcern, I did not very particularly care to remain. Now, then,\r\nFranz, when, for services so promptly and unhesitatingly rendered, he\r\nbut asks me in return to do for him what is done daily for any Russian\r\nprince or Italian nobleman who may pass through Paris\xe2\x80\x94merely to\r\nintroduce him into society\xe2\x80\x94would you have me refuse? My good fellow,\r\nyou must have lost your senses to think it possible I could act with\r\nsuch cold-blooded policy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd this time it must be confessed that, contrary to the usual state of\r\naffairs in discussions between the young men, the effective arguments\r\nwere all on Albert\xe2\x80\x99s side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz with a sigh, \xe2\x80\x9cdo as you please my dear viscount, for\r\nyour arguments are beyond my powers of refutation. Still, in spite of\r\nall, you must admit that this Count of Monte Cristo is a most singular\r\npersonage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a philanthropist,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the other; \xe2\x80\x9cand no doubt his motive\r\nin visiting Paris is to compete for the Monthyon prize, given, as you\r\nare aware, to whoever shall be proved to have most materially advanced\r\nthe interests of virtue and humanity. If my vote and interest can\r\nobtain it for him, I will readily give him the one and promise the\r\nother. And now, my dear Franz, let us talk of something else. Come,\r\nshall we take our luncheon, and then pay a last visit to St. Peter\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz silently assented; and the following afternoon, at half-past five\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock, the young men parted. Albert de Morcerf to return to Paris,\r\nand Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay to pass a fortnight at Venice.\r\n\r\nBut, ere he entered his travelling carriage, Albert, fearing that his\r\nexpected guest might forget the engagement he had entered into, placed\r\nin the care of a waiter at the hotel a card to be delivered to the\r\nCount of Monte Cristo, on which, beneath the name of Viscount Albert de\r\nMorcerf, he had written in pencil:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c27, _Rue du Helder, on the_ 21_st May, half-past ten_ A.M.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 39. The Guests\r\n\r\nIn the house in the Rue du Helder, where Albert had invited the Count\r\nof Monte Cristo, everything was being prepared on the morning of the\r\n21st of May to do honor to the occasion. Albert de Morcerf inhabited a\r\npavilion situated at the corner of a large court, and directly opposite\r\nanother building, in which were the servants\xe2\x80\x99 apartments. Two windows\r\nonly of the pavilion faced the street; three other windows looked into\r\nthe court, and two at the back into the garden.\r\n\r\nBetween the court and the garden, built in the heavy style of the\r\nimperial architecture, was the large and fashionable dwelling of the\r\nCount and Countess of Morcerf.\r\n\r\nA high wall surrounded the whole of the property, surmounted at\r\nintervals by vases filled with flowers, and broken in the centre by a\r\nlarge gate of gilded iron, which served as the carriage entrance. A\r\nsmall door, close to the lodge of the _concierge_, gave ingress and\r\negress to the servants and masters when they were on foot.\r\n\r\nIt was easy to discover that the delicate care of a mother, unwilling\r\nto part from her son, and yet aware that a young man of the viscount\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nage required the full exercise of his liberty, had chosen this\r\nhabitation for Albert. There were not lacking, however, evidences of\r\nwhat we may call the intelligent egoism of a youth who is charmed with\r\nthe indolent, careless life of an only son, and who lives as it were in\r\na gilded cage. By means of the two windows looking into the street,\r\nAlbert could see all that passed; the sight of what is going on is\r\nnecessary to young men, who always want to see the world traverse their\r\nhorizon, even if that horizon is only a public thoroughfare. Then,\r\nshould anything appear to merit a more minute examination, Albert de\r\nMorcerf could follow up his researches by means of a small gate,\r\nsimilar to that close to the _concierge\xe2\x80\x99s_ door, and which merits a\r\nparticular description.\r\n\r\nIt was a little entrance that seemed never to have been opened since\r\nthe house was built, so entirely was it covered with dust and dirt; but\r\nthe well-oiled hinges and locks told quite another story. This door was\r\na mockery to the _concierge_, from whose vigilance and jurisdiction it\r\nwas free, and, like that famous portal in the _Arabian Nights_, opening\r\nat the \xe2\x80\x9c_Sesame_\xe2\x80\x9d of Ali Baba, it was wont to swing backward at a\r\ncabalistic word or a concerted tap from without from the sweetest\r\nvoices or whitest fingers in the world.\r\n\r\nAt the end of a long corridor, with which the door communicated, and\r\nwhich formed the antechamber, was, on the right, Albert\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbreakfast-room, looking into the court, and on the left the salon,\r\nlooking into the garden. Shrubs and creeping plants covered the\r\nwindows, and hid from the garden and court these two apartments, the\r\nonly rooms into which, as they were on the ground floor, the prying\r\neyes of the curious could penetrate.\r\n\r\nOn the floor above were similar rooms, with the addition of a third,\r\nformed out of the antechamber; these three rooms were a salon, a\r\nboudoir, and a bedroom. The salon downstairs was only an Algerian\r\ndivan, for the use of smokers. The boudoir upstairs communicated with\r\nthe bedchamber by an invisible door on the staircase; it was evident\r\nthat every precaution had been taken. Above this floor was a large\r\n_atelier_, which had been increased in size by pulling down the\r\npartitions\xe2\x80\x94a pandemonium, in which the artist and the dandy strove for\r\npre-eminence.\r\n\r\nThere were collected and piled up all Albert\xe2\x80\x99s successive caprices,\r\nhunting-horns, bass-viols, flutes\xe2\x80\x94a whole orchestra, for Albert had had\r\nnot a taste but a fancy for music; easels, palettes, brushes,\r\npencils\xe2\x80\x94for music had been succeeded by painting; foils, boxing-gloves,\r\nbroadswords, and single-sticks\xe2\x80\x94for, following the example of the\r\nfashionable young men of the time, Albert de Morcerf cultivated, with\r\nfar more perseverance than music and drawing, the three arts that\r\ncomplete a dandy\xe2\x80\x99s education, i.e., fencing, boxing, and single-stick;\r\nand it was here that he received Grisier, Cooks, and Charles Leboucher.\r\n\r\nThe rest of the furniture of this privileged apartment consisted of old\r\ncabinets, filled with Chinese porcelain and Japanese vases, Lucca della\r\nRobbia _fa\xc3\xafences_, and Palissy platters; of old armchairs, in which\r\nperhaps had sat Henry IV. or Sully, Louis XIII. or Richelieu\xe2\x80\x94for two of\r\nthese armchairs, adorned with a carved shield, on which were engraved\r\nthe fleur-de-lis of France on an azure field, evidently came from the\r\nLouvre, or, at least, some royal residence.\r\n\r\nOver these dark and sombre chairs were thrown splendid stuffs, dyed\r\nbeneath Persia\xe2\x80\x99s sun, or woven by the fingers of the women of Calcutta\r\nor of Chandernagor. What these stuffs did there, it was impossible to\r\nsay; they awaited, while gratifying the eyes, a destination unknown to\r\ntheir owner himself; in the meantime they filled the place with their\r\ngolden and silky reflections.\r\n\r\nIn the centre of the room was a Roller and Blanchet \xe2\x80\x9cbaby grand\xe2\x80\x9d piano\r\nin rosewood, but holding the potentialities of an orchestra in its\r\nnarrow and sonorous cavity, and groaning beneath the weight of the\r\n_chefs-d\xe2\x80\x99\xc5\x93uvre_ of Beethoven, Weber, Mozart, Haydn, Gr\xc3\xa9try, and\r\nPorpora.\r\n\r\nOn the walls, over the doors, on the ceiling, were swords, daggers,\r\nMalay creeses, maces, battle-axes; gilded, damasked, and inlaid suits\r\nof armor; dried plants, minerals, and stuffed birds, their\r\nflame-colored wings outspread in motionless flight, and their beaks\r\nforever open. This was Albert\xe2\x80\x99s favorite lounging place.\r\n\r\nHowever, the morning of the appointment, the young man had established\r\nhimself in the small salon downstairs. There, on a table, surrounded at\r\nsome distance by a large and luxurious divan, every species of tobacco\r\nknown,\xe2\x80\x94from the yellow tobacco of Petersburg to the black of Sinai, and\r\nso on along the scale from Maryland and Porto Rico, to Latakia,\xe2\x80\x94was\r\nexposed in pots of crackled earthenware of which the Dutch are so fond;\r\nbeside them, in boxes of fragrant wood, were ranged, according to their\r\nsize and quality, puros, regalias, havanas, and manillas; and, in an\r\nopen cabinet, a collection of German pipes, of chibouques, with their\r\namber mouth-pieces ornamented with coral, and of narghiles, with their\r\nlong tubes of morocco, awaiting the caprice or the sympathy of the\r\nsmokers.\r\n\r\nAlbert had himself presided at the arrangement, or, rather, the\r\nsymmetrical derangement, which, after coffee, the guests at a breakfast\r\nof modern days love to contemplate through the vapor that escapes from\r\ntheir mouths, and ascends in long and fanciful wreaths to the ceiling.\r\n\r\nAt a quarter to ten, a valet entered; he composed, with a little groom\r\nnamed John, and who only spoke English, all Albert\xe2\x80\x99s establishment,\r\nalthough the cook of the hotel was always at his service, and on great\r\noccasions the count\xe2\x80\x99s _chasseur_ also. This valet, whose name was\r\nGermain, and who enjoyed the entire confidence of his young master,\r\nheld in one hand a number of papers, and in the other a packet of\r\nletters, which he gave to Albert. Albert glanced carelessly at the\r\ndifferent missives, selected two written in a small and delicate hand,\r\nand enclosed in scented envelopes, opened them and perused their\r\ncontents with some attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did these letters come?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne by the post, Madame Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 footman left the other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet Madame Danglars know that I accept the place she offers me in her\r\nbox. Wait; then, during the day, tell Rosa that when I leave the Opera\r\nI will sup with her as she wishes. Take her six bottles of different\r\nwine\xe2\x80\x94Cyprus, sherry, and Malaga, and a barrel of Ostend oysters; get\r\nthem at Borel\xe2\x80\x99s, and be sure you say they are for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt what o\xe2\x80\x99clock, sir, do you breakfast?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20227m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat time is it now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA quarter to ten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, at half past ten. Debray will, perhaps, be obliged to go to\r\nthe minister\xe2\x80\x94and besides\xe2\x80\x9d (Albert looked at his tablets), \xe2\x80\x9cit is the\r\nhour I told the count, 21st May, at half past ten; and though I do not\r\nmuch rely upon his promise, I wish to be punctual. Is the countess up\r\nyet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you wish, I will inquire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, ask her for one of her _liqueur_ cellarets, mine is incomplete;\r\nand tell her I shall have the honor of seeing her about three o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\r\nand that I request permission to introduce someone to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe valet left the room. Albert threw himself on the divan, tore off\r\nthe cover of two or three of the papers, looked at the theatre\r\nannouncements, made a face seeing they gave an opera, and not a ballet;\r\nhunted vainly amongst the advertisements for a new tooth-powder of\r\nwhich he had heard, and threw down, one after the other, the three\r\nleading papers of Paris, muttering,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese papers become more and more stupid every day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA moment after, a carriage stopped before the door, and the servant\r\nannounced M. Lucien Debray. A tall young man, with light hair, clear\r\ngray eyes, and thin and compressed lips, dressed in a blue coat with\r\nbeautifully carved gold buttons, a white neckcloth, and a tortoiseshell\r\neye-glass suspended by a silken thread, and which, by an effort of the\r\nsuperciliary and zygomatic muscles, he fixed in his eye, entered, with\r\na half-official air, without smiling or speaking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-morning, Lucien, good-morning,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cyour punctuality\r\nreally alarms me. What do I say? punctuality! You, whom I expected\r\nlast, you arrive at five minutes to ten, when the time fixed was\r\nhalf-past! Has the ministry resigned?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the young man, seating himself on the\r\ndivan; \xe2\x80\x9creassure yourself; we are tottering always, but we never fall,\r\nand I begin to believe that we shall pass into a state of immobility,\r\nand then the affairs of the Peninsula will completely consolidate us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, true; you drive Don Carlos out of Spain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, my dear fellow, do not confound our plans. We take him to the\r\nother side of the French frontier, and offer him hospitality at\r\nBourges.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Bourges?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he has not much to complain of; Bourges is the capital of Charles\r\nVII. Do you not know that all Paris knew it yesterday, and the day\r\nbefore it had already transpired on the Bourse, and M. Danglars (I do\r\nnot know by what means that man contrives to obtain intelligence as\r\nsoon as we do) made a million!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you another order, for I see you have a blue ribbon at your\r\nbutton-hole.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; they sent me the order of Charles III.,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Debray\r\ncarelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, do not affect indifference, but confess you were pleased to have\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is very well as a finish to the toilet. It looks very neat on a\r\nblack coat buttoned up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd makes you resemble the Prince of Wales or the Duke of Reichstadt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is for that reason you see me so early.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you have the order of Charles III., and you wish to announce\r\nthe good news to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, because I passed the night writing letters,\xe2\x80\x94five-and-twenty\r\ndespatches. I returned home at daybreak, and strove to sleep; but my\r\nhead ached and I got up to have a ride for an hour. At the Bois de\r\nBoulogne, _ennui_ and hunger attacked me at once,\xe2\x80\x94two enemies who\r\nrarely accompany each other, and who are yet leagued against me, a sort\r\nof Carlo-republican alliance. I then recollected you gave a breakfast\r\nthis morning, and here I am. I am hungry, feed me; I am bored, amuse\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is my duty as your host,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Albert, ringing the bell, while\r\nLucien turned over, with his gold-mounted cane, the papers that lay on\r\nthe table. \xe2\x80\x9cGermain, a glass of sherry and a biscuit. In the meantime,\r\nmy dear Lucien, here are cigars\xe2\x80\x94contraband, of course\xe2\x80\x94try them, and\r\npersuade the minister to sell us such instead of poisoning us with\r\ncabbage leaves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Peste!_ I will do nothing of the kind; the moment they come from\r\ngovernment you would find them execrable. Besides, that does not\r\nconcern the home but the financial department. Address yourself to M.\r\nHumann, section of the indirect contributions, corridor A., No. 26.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my word,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cyou astonish me by the extent of your\r\nknowledge. Take a cigar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, my dear Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Lucien, lighting a manilla at a\r\nrose-colored taper that burnt in a beautifully enamelled stand\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9chow\r\nhappy you are to have nothing to do. You do not know your own good\r\nfortune!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what would you do, my dear diplomatist,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morcerf, with a\r\nslight degree of irony in his voice, \xe2\x80\x9cif you did nothing? What? private\r\nsecretary to a minister, plunged at once into European cabals and\r\nParisian intrigues; having kings, and, better still, queens, to\r\nprotect, parties to unite, elections to direct; making more use of your\r\ncabinet with your pen and your telegraph than Napoleon did of his\r\nbattle-fields with his sword and his victories; possessing\r\nfive-and-twenty thousand francs a year, besides your place; a horse,\r\nfor which Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud offered you four hundred louis, and which you\r\nwould not part with; a tailor who never disappoints you; with the\r\nopera, the jockey-club, and other diversions, can you not amuse\r\nyourself? Well, I will amuse you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy introducing to you a new acquaintance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man or a woman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know so many men already.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you do not know this man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere does he come from\xe2\x80\x94the end of the world?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarther still, perhaps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe deuce! I hope he does not bring our breakfast with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no; our breakfast comes from my father\xe2\x80\x99s kitchen. Are you hungry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumiliating as such a confession is, I am. But I dined at M. de\r\nVillefort\xe2\x80\x99s, and lawyers always give you very bad dinners. You would\r\nthink they felt some remorse; did you ever remark that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, depreciate other persons\xe2\x80\x99 dinners; you ministers give such\r\nsplendid ones.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but we do not invite people of fashion. If we were not forced to\r\nentertain a parcel of country boobies because they think and vote with\r\nus, we should never dream of dining at home, I assure you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, take another glass of sherry and another biscuit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWillingly. Your Spanish wine is excellent. You see we were quite right\r\nto pacify that country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but Don Carlos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Don Carlos will drink Bordeaux, and in ten years we will marry\r\nhis son to the little queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will then obtain the Golden Fleece, if you are still in the\r\nministry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think, Albert, you have adopted the system of feeding me on smoke\r\nthis morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you must allow it is the best thing for the stomach; but I hear\r\nBeauchamp in the next room; you can dispute together, and that will\r\npass away the time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout the papers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucien with an air of sovereign contempt, \xe2\x80\x9cdo I\r\never read the papers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you will dispute the more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Beauchamp,\xe2\x80\x9d announced the servant. \xe2\x80\x9cCome in, come in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert,\r\nrising and advancing to meet the young man. \xe2\x80\x9cHere is Debray, who\r\ndetests you without reading you, so he says.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is quite right,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I criticise him without\r\nknowing what he does. Good-day, commander!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you know that already,\xe2\x80\x9d said the private secretary, smiling and\r\nshaking hands with him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what do they say of it in the world?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn which world? we have so many worlds in the year of grace 1838.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the entire political world, of which you are one of the leaders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey say that it is quite fair, and that sowing so much red, you ought\r\nto reap a little blue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, that is not bad!\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucien. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you not join our\r\nparty, my dear Beauchamp? With your talents you would make your fortune\r\nin three or four years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only await one thing before following your advice; that is, a\r\nminister who will hold office for six months. My dear Albert, one word,\r\nfor I must give poor Lucien a respite. Do we breakfast or dine? I must\r\ngo to the Chamber, for our life is not an idle one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou only breakfast; I await two persons, and the instant they arrive\r\nwe shall sit down to table.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 40. The Breakfast\r\n\r\nAnd what sort of persons do you expect to breakfast?\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA gentleman, and a diplomatist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen we shall have to wait two hours for the gentleman, and three for\r\nthe diplomatist. I shall come back to dessert; keep me some\r\nstrawberries, coffee, and cigars. I shall take a cutlet on my way to\r\nthe Chamber.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not do anything of the sort; for were the gentleman a Montmorency,\r\nand the diplomatist a Metternich, we will breakfast at eleven; in the\r\nmeantime, follow Debray\xe2\x80\x99s example, and take a glass of sherry and a\r\nbiscuit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so; I will stay; I must do something to distract my thoughts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are like Debray, and yet it seems to me that when the minister is\r\nout of spirits, the opposition ought to be joyous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you do not know with what I am threatened. I shall hear this\r\nmorning that M. Danglars make a speech at the Chamber of Deputies, and\r\nat his wife\xe2\x80\x99s this evening I shall hear the tragedy of a peer of\r\nFrance. The devil take the constitutional government, and since we had\r\nour choice, as they say, at least, how could we choose that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand; you must lay in a stock of hilarity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not run down M. Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 speeches,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray; \xe2\x80\x9che votes for\r\nyou, for he belongs to the opposition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu_, that is exactly the worst of all. I am waiting until you\r\nsend him to speak at the Luxembourg, to laugh at my ease.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert to Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cit is plain that the\r\naffairs of Spain are settled, for you are most desperately out of humor\r\nthis morning. Recollect that Parisian gossip has spoken of a marriage\r\nbetween myself and Mlle. Eug\xc3\xa9nie Danglars; I cannot in conscience,\r\ntherefore, let you run down the speeches of a man who will one day say\r\nto me, \xe2\x80\x98Vicomte, you know I give my daughter two millions.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, this marriage will never take place,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp. \xe2\x80\x9cThe king\r\nhas made him a baron, and can make him a peer, but he cannot make him a\r\ngentleman, and the Count of Morcerf is too aristocratic to consent, for\r\nthe paltry sum of two million francs, to a _m\xc3\xa9salliance_. The Viscount\r\nof Morcerf can only wed a marchioness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut two million francs make a nice little sum,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the social capital of a theatre on the boulevard, or a railroad\r\nfrom the Jardin des Plantes to La R\xc3\xa2p\xc3\xa9e.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind what he says, Morcerf,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you marry her. You\r\nmarry a money-bag label, it is true; well, but what does that matter?\r\nIt is better to have a blazon less and a figure more on it. You have\r\nseven martlets on your arms; give three to your wife, and you will\r\nstill have four; that is one more than M. de Guise had, who so nearly\r\nbecame King of France, and whose cousin was Emperor of Germany.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my word, I think you are right, Lucien,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert absently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure; besides, every millionaire is as noble as a bastard\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nis, he can be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not say that, Debray,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Beauchamp, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cfor here is\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, who, to cure you of your mania for paradoxes, will pass\r\nthe sword of Renaud de Montauban, his ancestor, through your body.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will sully it then,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Lucien; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I am low\xe2\x80\x94very low.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, heavens,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cthe minister quotes B\xc3\xa9ranger, what\r\nshall we come to next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud\xe2\x80\x94M. Maximilian Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said the servant,\r\nannouncing two fresh guests.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, then, to breakfast,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9cfor, if I remember, you\r\ntold me you only expected two persons, Albert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMorrel,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Albert\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMorrel\xe2\x80\x94who is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut before he had finished, M. de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, a handsome young man\r\nof thirty, gentleman all over,\xe2\x80\x94that is, with the figure of a Guiche and\r\nthe wit of a Mortemart,\xe2\x80\x94took Albert\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9clet me introduce to you M. Maximilian\r\nMorrel, captain of Spahis, my friend; and what is more\xe2\x80\x94however the man\r\nspeaks for himself\xe2\x80\x94my preserver. Salute my hero, viscount.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he stepped on one side to give place to a young man of refined and\r\ndignified bearing, with large and open brow, piercing eyes, and black\r\nmoustache, whom our readers have already seen at Marseilles, under\r\ncircumstances sufficiently dramatic not to be forgotten. A rich\r\nuniform, half French, half Oriental, set off his graceful and stalwart\r\nfigure, and his broad chest was decorated with the order of the Legion\r\nof Honor. The young officer bowed with easy and elegant politeness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert with affectionate courtesy, \xe2\x80\x9cthe count of\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud knew how much pleasure this introduction would give me;\r\nyou are his friend, be ours also.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell said,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9cand pray that, if you should\r\never be in a similar predicament, he may do as much for you as he did\r\nfor me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has he done?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing worth speaking of,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cM. de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud\r\nexaggerates.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot worth speaking of?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9clife is not worth\r\nspeaking of!\xe2\x80\x94that is rather too philosophical, on my word, Morrel. It\r\nis very well for you, who risk your life every day, but for me, who\r\nonly did so once\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe gather from all this, baron, that Captain Morrel saved your life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn what occasion?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeauchamp, my good fellow, you know I am starving,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray: \xe2\x80\x9cdo\r\nnot set him off on some long story.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I do not prevent your sitting down to table,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Beauchamp,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud can tell us while we eat our breakfast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cit is only a quarter past ten, and I expect\r\nsomeone else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, true, a diplomatist!\xe2\x80\x9d observed Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDiplomat or not, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know; I only know that he charged himself on\r\nmy account with a mission, which he terminated so entirely to my\r\nsatisfaction, that had I been king, I should have instantly created him\r\nknight of all my orders, even had I been able to offer him the Golden\r\nFleece and the Garter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, since we are not to sit down to table,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9ctake a\r\nglass of sherry, and tell us all about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou all know that I had the fancy of going to Africa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a road your ancestors have traced for you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert\r\ngallantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes? but I doubt that your object was like theirs\xe2\x80\x94to rescue the Holy\r\nSepulchre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are quite right, Beauchamp,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the young aristocrat. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\nwas only to fight as an amateur. I cannot bear duelling ever since two\r\nseconds, whom I had chosen to arrange an affair, forced me to break the\r\narm of one of my best friends, one whom you all know\xe2\x80\x94poor Franz\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cyou did fight some time ago; about what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20235m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil take me, if I remember,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I\r\nrecollect perfectly one thing, that, being unwilling to let such\r\ntalents as mine sleep, I wished to try upon the Arabs the new pistols\r\nthat had been given to me. In consequence I embarked for Oran, and went\r\nfrom thence to Constantine, where I arrived just in time to witness the\r\nraising of the siege. I retreated with the rest, for eight-and-forty\r\nhours. I endured the rain during the day, and the cold during the night\r\ntolerably well, but the third morning my horse died of cold. Poor\r\nbrute\xe2\x80\x94accustomed to be covered up and to have a stove in the stable,\r\nthe Arabian finds himself unable to bear ten degrees of cold in\r\nArabia.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s why you want to purchase my English horse,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nthink he will bear the cold better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken, for I have made a vow never to return to Africa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were very much frightened, then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, yes, and I had good reason to be so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwas retreating on foot, for my horse was dead. Six Arabs came up, full\r\ngallop, to cut off my head. I shot two with my double-barrelled gun,\r\nand two more with my pistols, but I was then disarmed, and two were\r\nstill left; one seized me by the hair (that is why I now wear it so\r\nshort, for no one knows what may happen), the other swung a yataghan,\r\nand I already felt the cold steel on my neck, when this gentleman whom\r\nyou see here charged them, shot the one who held me by the hair, and\r\ncleft the skull of the other with his sabre. He had assigned himself\r\nthe task of saving a man\xe2\x80\x99s life that day; chance caused that man to be\r\nmyself. When I am rich I will order a statue of Chance from Klagmann or\r\nMarochetti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cit was the 5th of September, the\r\nanniversary of the day on which my father was miraculously preserved;\r\ntherefore, as far as it lies in my power, I endeavor to celebrate it by\r\nsome\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20237m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeroic action,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. \xe2\x80\x9cI was chosen. But that is\r\nnot all\xe2\x80\x94after rescuing me from the sword, he rescued me from the cold,\r\nnot by sharing his cloak with me, like St. Martin, but by giving me the\r\nwhole; then from hunger by sharing with me\xe2\x80\x94guess what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Strasbourg pie?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, his horse; of which we each of us ate a slice with a hearty\r\nappetite. It was very hard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe horse?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, the sacrifice,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9cask Debray if he would\r\nsacrifice his English steed for a stranger?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot for a stranger,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cbut for a friend I might, perhaps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI divined that you would become mine, count,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbesides, as I had the honor to tell you, heroism or not, sacrifice or\r\nnot, that day I owed an offering to bad fortune in recompense for the\r\nfavors good fortune had on other days granted to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe history to which M. Morrel alludes,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cis\r\nan admirable one, which he will tell you some day when you are better\r\nacquainted with him; today let us fill our stomachs, and not our\r\nmemories. What time do you breakfast, Albert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt half-past ten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Debray, taking out his watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you will give me five minutes\xe2\x80\x99 grace,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cfor I\r\nalso expect a preserver.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf myself,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9c_parbleu!_ do you think I cannot be saved\r\nas well as anyone else, and that there are only Arabs who cut off\r\nheads? Our breakfast is a philanthropic one, and we shall have at\r\ntable\xe2\x80\x94at least, I hope so\xe2\x80\x94two benefactors of humanity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall we do?\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray; \xe2\x80\x9cwe have only one Monthyon prize.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it will be given to someone who has done nothing to deserve it,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is the way the Academy mostly escapes from the\r\ndilemma.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where does he come from?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Debray. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have already answered\r\nthe question once, but so vaguely that I venture to put it a second\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not know; when I invited him three months\r\nago, he was then at Rome, but since that time who knows where he may\r\nhave gone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you think him capable of being exact?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think him capable of everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, with the five minutes\xe2\x80\x99 grace, we have only ten left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will profit by them to tell you something about my guest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9care there any materials for an\r\narticle in what you are going to tell us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and for a most curious one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, then, for I see I shall not get to the Chamber this morning,\r\nand I must make up for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was at Rome during the last Carnival.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe know that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but what you do not know is that I was carried off by bandits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are no bandits,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes there are, and most hideous, or rather most admirable ones, for I\r\nfound them ugly enough to frighten me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, my dear Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cconfess that your cook is\r\nbehindhand, that the oysters have not arrived from Ostend or Marennes,\r\nand that, like Madame de Maintenon, you are going to replace the dish\r\nby a story. Say so at once; we are sufficiently well-bred to excuse\r\nyou, and to listen to your history, fabulous as it promises to be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I say to you, fabulous as it may seem, I tell it as a true one\r\nfrom beginning to end. The brigands had carried me off, and conducted\r\nme to a gloomy spot, called the Catacombs of Saint Sebastian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9cI narrowly escaped catching a fever\r\nthere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I did more than that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cfor I caught one. I was\r\ninformed that I was prisoner until I paid the sum of 4,000 Roman\r\ncrowns\xe2\x80\x94about 24,000 francs. Unfortunately, I had not above 1,500. I was\r\nat the end of my journey and of my credit. I wrote to Franz\xe2\x80\x94and were he\r\nhere he would confirm every word\xe2\x80\x94I wrote then to Franz that if he did\r\nnot come with the four thousand crowns before six, at ten minutes past\r\nI should have gone to join the blessed saints and glorious martyrs in\r\nwhose company I had the honor of being; and Signor Luigi Vampa, such\r\nwas the name of the chief of these bandits, would have scrupulously\r\nkept his word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Franz did come with the four thousand crowns,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. \xe2\x80\x9cA man whose name is Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay or Albert de\r\nMorcerf has not much difficulty in procuring them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he arrived accompanied simply by the guest I am going to present\r\nto you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, this gentleman is a Hercules killing Cacus, a Perseus freeing\r\nAndromeda.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he is a man about my own size.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArmed to the teeth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe had not even a knitting-needle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he paid your ransom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe said two words to the chief and I was free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they apologized to him for having carried you off?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nBeauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, he is a second Ariosto.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, his name is the Count of Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no Count of Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think so,\xe2\x80\x9d added Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, with the air of a man who\r\nknows the whole of the European nobility perfectly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes anyone know anything of a Count of Monte Cristo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe comes possibly from the Holy Land, and one of his ancestors\r\npossessed Calvary, as the Mortemarts did the Dead Sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I can assist your researches,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian. \xe2\x80\x9cMonte Cristo\r\nis a little island I have often heard spoken of by the old sailors my\r\nfather employed\xe2\x80\x94a grain of sand in the centre of the Mediterranean, an\r\natom in the infinite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Albert. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, he of whom I speak is the lord and\r\nmaster of this grain of sand, of this atom; he has purchased the title\r\nof count somewhere in Tuscany.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is rich, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that ought to be visible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is what deceives you, Debray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not understand you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you read the _Arabian Nights_?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a question!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, do you know if the persons you see there are rich or poor, if\r\ntheir sacks of wheat are not rubies or diamonds? They seem like poor\r\nfishermen, and suddenly they open some mysterious cavern filled with\r\nthe wealth of the Indies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich means?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich means that my Count of Monte Cristo is one of those fishermen.\r\nHe has even a name taken from the book, since he calls himself Sinbad\r\nthe Sailor, and has a cave filled with gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have seen this cavern, Morcerf?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but Franz has; for heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake, not a word of this before him.\r\nFranz went in with his eyes blindfolded, and was waited on by mutes and\r\nby women to whom Cleopatra was a painted strumpet. Only he is not quite\r\nsure about the women, for they did not come in until after he had taken\r\nhashish, so that what he took for women might have been simply a row of\r\nstatues.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two young men looked at Morcerf as if to say,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAre you mad, or are\r\nyou laughing at us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I also,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel thoughtfully, \xe2\x80\x9chave heard something like this\r\nfrom an old sailor named Penelon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cit is very lucky that M. Morrel comes to aid me;\r\nyou are vexed, are you not, that he thus gives a clew to the\r\nlabyrinth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat you tell us is so extraordinary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, because your ambassadors and your consuls do not tell you of\r\nthem\xe2\x80\x94they have no time. They are too much taken up with interfering in\r\nthe affairs of their countrymen who travel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow you get angry, and attack our poor agents. How will you have them\r\nprotect you? The Chamber cuts down their salaries every day, so that\r\nnow they have scarcely any. Will you be ambassador, Albert? I will send\r\nyou to Constantinople.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, lest on the first demonstration I make in favor of Mehemet Ali,\r\nthe Sultan send me the bowstring, and make my secretaries strangle me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say very true,\xe2\x80\x9d responded Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cbut this has nothing to do with the existence of\r\nthe Count of Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_ everyone exists.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless, but not in the same way; everyone has not black slaves, a\r\nprincely retinue, an arsenal of weapons that would do credit to an\r\nArabian fortress, horses that cost six thousand francs apiece, and\r\nGreek mistresses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you seen the Greek mistress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have both seen and heard her. I saw her at the theatre, and heard\r\nher one morning when I breakfasted with the count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe eats, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but so little, it can hardly be called eating.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must be a vampire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaugh, if you will; the Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, who knew Lord Ruthven, declared\r\nthat the count was a vampire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, capital,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp. \xe2\x80\x9cFor a man not connected with\r\nnewspapers, here is the pendant to the famous sea-serpent of the\r\n_Constitutionnel_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWild eyes, the iris of which contracts or dilates at pleasure,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nDebray; \xe2\x80\x9cfacial angle strongly developed, magnificent forehead, livid\r\ncomplexion, black beard, sharp and white teeth, politeness\r\nunexceptionable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust so, Lucien,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have described him feature\r\nfor feature. Yes, keen and cutting politeness. This man has often made\r\nme shudder; and one day when we were viewing an execution, I thought I\r\nshould faint, more from hearing the cold and calm manner in which he\r\nspoke of every description of torture, than from the sight of the\r\nexecutioner and the culprit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he not conduct you to the ruins of the Colosseum and suck your\r\nblood?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr, having delivered you, make you sign a flaming parchment,\r\nsurrendering your soul to him as Esau did his birth-right?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRail on, rail on at your ease, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, somewhat\r\npiqued. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I look at you Parisians, idlers on the Boulevard de Gand\r\nor the Bois de Boulogne, and think of this man, it seems to me we are\r\nnot of the same race.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am highly flattered,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the same time,\xe2\x80\x9d added Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cyour Count of Monte Cristo\r\nis a very fine fellow, always excepting his little arrangements with\r\nthe Italian banditti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are no Italian banditti,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo vampire,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo Count of Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x9d added Debray. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is half-past ten\r\nstriking, Albert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20243m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConfess you have dreamed this, and let us sit down to breakfast,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued Beauchamp.\r\n\r\nBut the sound of the clock had not died away when Germain announced,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis excellency the Count of Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d The involuntary start\r\neveryone gave proved how much Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s narrative had impressed them,\r\nand Albert himself could not wholly refrain from manifesting sudden\r\nemotion. He had not heard a carriage stop in the street, or steps in\r\nthe antechamber; the door had itself opened noiselessly. The count\r\nappeared, dressed with the greatest simplicity, but the most fastidious\r\ndandy could have found nothing to cavil at in his toilet. Every article\r\nof dress\xe2\x80\x94hat, coat, gloves, and boots\xe2\x80\x94was from the first makers. He\r\nseemed scarcely five-and-thirty. But what struck everybody was his\r\nextreme resemblance to the portrait Debray had drawn. The count\r\nadvanced, smiling, into the centre of the room, and approached Albert,\r\nwho hastened towards him holding out his hand in a ceremonial manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPunctuality,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cis the politeness of kings,\r\naccording to one of your sovereigns, I think; but it is not the same\r\nwith travellers. However, I hope you will excuse the two or three\r\nseconds I am behindhand; five hundred leagues are not to be\r\naccomplished without some trouble, and especially in France, where, it\r\nseems, it is forbidden to beat the postilions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI was announcing your visit to some\r\nof my friends, whom I had invited in consequence of the promise you did\r\nme the honor to make, and whom I now present to you. They are the Count\r\nof Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, whose nobility goes back to the twelve peers, and\r\nwhose ancestors had a place at the Round Table; M. Lucien Debray,\r\nprivate secretary to the minister of the interior; M. Beauchamp, an\r\neditor of a paper, and the terror of the French government, but of\r\nwhom, in spite of his national celebrity, you perhaps have not heard in\r\nItaly, since his paper is prohibited there; and M. Maximilian Morrel,\r\ncaptain of Spahis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this name the count, who had hitherto saluted everyone with\r\ncourtesy, but at the same time with coldness and formality, stepped a\r\npace forward, and a slight tinge of red colored his pale cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wear the uniform of the new French conquerors, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said he;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cit is a handsome uniform.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo one could have said what caused the count\xe2\x80\x99s voice to vibrate so\r\ndeeply, and what made his eye flash, which was in general so clear,\r\nlustrous, and limpid when he pleased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have never seen our Africans, count?\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, who was by this time perfectly master of\r\nhimself again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, beneath this uniform beats one of the bravest and noblest hearts\r\nin the whole army.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, M. de Morcerf,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me go on, captain. And we have just heard,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cof\r\na new deed of his, and so heroic a one, that, although I have seen him\r\ntoday for the first time, I request you to allow me to introduce him as\r\nmy friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words it was still possible to observe in Monte Cristo the\r\nconcentrated look, changing color, and slight trembling of the eyelid\r\nthat show emotion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you have a noble heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cso much the better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis exclamation, which corresponded to the count\xe2\x80\x99s own thought rather\r\nthan to what Albert was saying, surprised everybody, and especially\r\nMorrel, who looked at Monte Cristo with wonder. But, at the same time,\r\nthe intonation was so soft that, however strange the speech might seem,\r\nit was impossible to be offended at it.\r\n\r\n20245m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should he doubt it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp to Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn reality,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the latter, who, with his aristocratic glance and\r\nhis knowledge of the world, had penetrated at once all that was\r\npenetrable in Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cAlbert has not deceived us, for the count\r\nis a most singular being. What say you, Morrel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi_, he has an open look about him that pleases me, in spite of\r\nthe singular remark he has made about me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cGermain informs me that breakfast is ready.\r\nMy dear count, allow me to show you the way.\xe2\x80\x9d They passed silently into\r\nthe breakfast-room, and everyone took his place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, seating himself, \xe2\x80\x9cpermit me to make a\r\nconfession which must form my excuse for any improprieties I may\r\ncommit. I am a stranger, and a stranger to such a degree, that this is\r\nthe first time I have ever been at Paris. The French way of living is\r\nutterly unknown to me, and up to the present time I have followed the\r\nEastern customs, which are entirely in contrast to the Parisian. I beg\r\nyou, therefore, to excuse if you find anything in me too Turkish, too\r\nItalian, or too Arabian. Now, then, let us breakfast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith what an air he says all this,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9cdecidedly he\r\nis a great man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA great man in his own country,\xe2\x80\x9d added Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA great man in every country, M. Debray,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\nThe count was, it may be remembered, a most temperate guest. Albert\r\nremarked this, expressing his fears lest, at the outset, the Parisian\r\nmode of life should displease the traveller in the most essential\r\npoint.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI fear one thing, and that is, that the fare\r\nof the Rue du Helder is not so much to your taste as that of the Piazza\r\ndi Spagna. I ought to have consulted you on the point, and have had\r\nsome dishes prepared expressly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you know me better,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cyou would not\r\ngive one thought of such a thing for a traveller like myself, who has\r\nsuccessively lived on macaroni at Naples, polenta at Milan, olla\r\npodrida at Valencia, pilau at Constantinople, curry in India, and\r\nswallows\xe2\x80\x99 nests in China. I eat everywhere, and of everything, only I\r\neat but little; and today, that you reproach me with my want of\r\nappetite, is my day of appetite, for I have not eaten since yesterday\r\nmorning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat,\xe2\x80\x9d cried all the guests, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have not eaten for four-and-twenty\r\nhours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count; \xe2\x80\x9cI was forced to go out of my road to obtain\r\nsome information near N\xc3\xaemes, so that I was somewhat late, and therefore\r\nI did not choose to stop.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you ate in your carriage?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I slept, as I generally do when I am weary without having the\r\ncourage to amuse myself, or when I am hungry without feeling inclined\r\nto eat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you can sleep when you please, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a recipe for it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn infallible one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would be invaluable to us in Africa, who have not always any food\r\nto eat, and rarely anything to drink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, unfortunately, a recipe excellent for a\r\nman like myself would be very dangerous applied to an army, which might\r\nnot awake when it was needed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay we inquire what is this recipe?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI make no secret of it. It is a\r\nmixture of excellent opium, which I fetched myself from Canton in order\r\nto have it pure, and the best hashish which grows in the East\xe2\x80\x94that is,\r\nbetween the Tigris and the Euphrates. These two ingredients are mixed\r\nin equal proportions, and formed into pills. Ten minutes after one is\r\ntaken, the effect is produced. Ask Baron Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay; I think he\r\ntasted them one day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9che said something about it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, who, as became a journalist, was very\r\nincredulous, \xe2\x80\x9cyou always carry this drug about you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlways.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould it be an indiscretion to ask to see those precious pills?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued Beauchamp, hoping to take him at a disadvantage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count; and he drew from his pocket a\r\nmarvellous casket, formed out of a single emerald and closed by a\r\ngolden lid which unscrewed and gave passage to a small greenish colored\r\npellet about the size of a pea. This ball had an acrid and penetrating\r\nodor. There were four or five more in the emerald, which would contain\r\nabout a dozen. The casket passed around the table, but it was more to\r\nexamine the admirable emerald than to see the pills that it passed from\r\nhand to hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is it your cook who prepares these pills?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI do not thus betray my\r\nenjoyments to the vulgar. I am a tolerable chemist, and prepare my\r\npills myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a magnificent emerald, and the largest I have ever seen,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9calthough my mother has some remarkable family jewels.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had three similar ones,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cI gave one to the\r\nSultan, who mounted it in his sabre; another to our holy father the\r\nPope, who had it set in his tiara, opposite to one nearly as large,\r\nthough not so fine, given by the Emperor Napoleon to his predecessor,\r\nPius VII. I kept the third for myself, and I had it hollowed out, which\r\nreduced its value, but rendered it more commodious for the purpose I\r\nintended.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEveryone looked at Monte Cristo with astonishment; he spoke with so\r\nmuch simplicity that it was evident he spoke the truth, or that he was\r\nmad. However, the sight of the emerald made them naturally incline to\r\nthe former belief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did these two sovereigns give you in exchange for these\r\nmagnificent presents?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Sultan, the liberty of a woman,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Count; \xe2\x80\x9cthe Pope, the\r\nlife of a man; so that once in my life I have been as powerful as if\r\nheaven had brought me into the world on the steps of a throne.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it was Peppino you saved, was it not?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cit was for\r\nhim that you obtained pardon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear count, you have no idea what pleasure it gives me to hear you\r\nspeak thus,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf. \xe2\x80\x9cI had announced you beforehand to my\r\nfriends as an enchanter of the _Arabian Nights_, a wizard of the Middle\r\nAges; but the Parisians are so subtle in paradoxes that they mistake\r\nfor caprices of the imagination the most incontestable truths, when\r\nthese truths do not form a part of their daily existence. For example,\r\nhere is Debray who reads, and Beauchamp who prints, every day, \xe2\x80\x98A\r\nmember of the Jockey Club has been stopped and robbed on the\r\nBoulevard;\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98four persons have been assassinated in the Rue St. Denis\xe2\x80\x99\r\nor \xe2\x80\x98the Faubourg St. Germain;\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98ten, fifteen, or twenty thieves, have\r\nbeen arrested in a _caf\xc3\xa9_ on the Boulevard du Temple, or in the Thermes\r\nde Julien,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94and yet these same men deny the existence of the bandits in\r\nthe Maremma, the Campagna di Romana, or the Pontine Marshes. Tell them\r\nyourself that I was taken by bandits, and that without your generous\r\nintercession I should now have been sleeping in the Catacombs of St.\r\nSebastian, instead of receiving them in my humble abode in the Rue du\r\nHelder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cyou promised me never to mention that\r\ncircumstance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was not I who made that promise,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cit must have been\r\nsomeone else whom you have rescued in the same manner, and whom you\r\nhave forgotten. Pray speak of it, for I shall not only, I trust, relate\r\nthe little I do know, but also a great deal I do not know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you played a\r\nsufficiently important part to know as well as myself what happened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20249m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you promise me, if I tell all I know, to relate, in your turn,\r\nall that I do not know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is but fair,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cfor three days I believed myself the object of\r\nthe attentions of a masque, whom I took for a descendant of Tullia or\r\nPopp\xc3\xa6a, while I was simply the object of the attentions of a\r\n_contadina_, and I say _contadina_ to avoid saying peasant girl. What I\r\nknow is, that, like a fool, a greater fool than he of whom I spoke just\r\nnow, I mistook for this peasant girl a young bandit of fifteen or\r\nsixteen, with a beardless chin and slim waist, and who, just as I was\r\nabout to imprint a chaste salute on his lips, placed a pistol to my\r\nhead, and, aided by seven or eight others, led, or rather dragged me,\r\nto the Catacombs of St. Sebastian, where I found a highly educated\r\nbrigand chief perusing C\xc3\xa6sar\xe2\x80\x99s _Commentaries_, and who deigned to leave\r\noff reading to inform me, that unless the next morning, before six\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock, four thousand piastres were paid into his account at his\r\nbanker\xe2\x80\x99s, at a quarter past six I should have ceased to exist. The\r\nletter is still to be seen, for it is in Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay\xe2\x80\x99s possession,\r\nsigned by me, and with a postscript of M. Luigi Vampa. This is all I\r\nknow, but I know not, count, how you contrived to inspire so much\r\nrespect in the bandits of Rome who ordinarily have so little respect\r\nfor anything. I assure you, Franz and I were lost in admiration.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing more simple,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count. \xe2\x80\x9cI had known the famous\r\nVampa for more than ten years. When he was quite a child, and only a\r\nshepherd, I gave him a few gold pieces for showing me my way, and he,\r\nin order to repay me, gave me a poniard, the hilt of which he had\r\ncarved with his own hand, and which you may have seen in my collection\r\nof arms. In after years, whether he had forgotten this interchange of\r\npresents, which ought to have cemented our friendship, or whether he\r\ndid not recollect me, he sought to take me, but, on the contrary, it\r\nwas I who captured him and a dozen of his band. I might have handed him\r\nover to Roman justice, which is somewhat expeditious, and which would\r\nhave been particularly so with him; but I did nothing of the sort\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nsuffered him and his band to depart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith the condition that they should sin no more,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp,\r\nlaughing. \xe2\x80\x9cI see they kept their promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cupon the simple condition that\r\nthey should respect myself and my friends. Perhaps what I am about to\r\nsay may seem strange to you, who are socialists, and vaunt humanity and\r\nyour duty to your neighbor, but I never seek to protect a society which\r\ndoes not protect me, and which I will even say, generally occupies\r\nitself about me only to injure me; and thus by giving them a low place\r\nin my esteem, and preserving a neutrality towards them, it is society\r\nand my neighbor who are indebted to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are the first man I ever met\r\nsufficiently courageous to preach egotism. Bravo, count, bravo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is frank, at least,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I am sure that the count\r\ndoes not regret having once deviated from the principles he has so\r\nboldly avowed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow have I deviated from those principles, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte\r\nCristo, who could not help looking at Morrel with so much intensity,\r\nthat two or three times the young man had been unable to sustain that\r\nclear and piercing glance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it seems to me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cthat in delivering M. de\r\nMorcerf, whom you did not know, you did good to your neighbor and to\r\nsociety.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf which he is the brightest ornament,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, drinking off a\r\nglass of champagne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are at fault\xe2\x80\x94you, one of the most\r\nformidable logicians I know\xe2\x80\x94and you must see it clearly proved that\r\ninstead of being an egotist, you are a philanthropist. Ah, you call\r\nyourself Oriental, a Levantine, Maltese, Indian, Chinese; your family\r\nname is Monte Cristo; Sinbad the Sailor is your baptismal appellation,\r\nand yet the first day you set foot in Paris you instinctively display\r\nthe greatest virtue, or rather the chief defect, of us eccentric\r\nParisians,\xe2\x80\x94that is, you assume the vices you have not, and conceal the\r\nvirtues you possess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear vicomte,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not see, in all I have\r\ndone, anything that merits, either from you or these gentlemen, the\r\npretended eulogies I have received. You were no stranger to me, for I\r\nknew you from the time I gave up two rooms to you, invited you to\r\nbreakfast with me, lent you one of my carriages, witnessed the Carnival\r\nin your company, and saw with you from a window in the Piazza del\r\nPopolo the execution that affected you so much that you nearly fainted.\r\nI will appeal to any of these gentlemen, could I leave my guest in the\r\nhands of a hideous bandit, as you term him? Besides, you know, I had\r\nthe idea that you could introduce me into some of the Paris salons when\r\nI came to France. You might some time ago have looked upon this\r\nresolution as a vague project, but today you see it was a reality, and\r\nyou must submit to it under penalty of breaking your word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will keep it,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I fear that you will be much\r\ndisappointed, accustomed as you are to picturesque events and fantastic\r\nhorizons. Amongst us you will not meet with any of those episodes with\r\nwhich your adventurous existence has so familiarized you; our\r\nChimborazo is Mortmartre, our Himalaya is Mount Val\xc3\xa9rien, our Great\r\nDesert is the plain of Grenelle, where they are now boring an artesian\r\nwell to water the caravans. We have plenty of thieves, though not so\r\nmany as is said; but these thieves stand in far more dread of a\r\npoliceman than a lord. France is so prosaic, and Paris so civilized a\r\ncity, that you will not find in its eighty-five departments\xe2\x80\x94I say\r\neighty-five, because I do not include Corsica\xe2\x80\x94you will not find, then,\r\nin these eighty-five departments a single hill on which there is not a\r\ntelegraph, or a grotto in which the commissary of police has not put up\r\na gaslamp. There is but one service I can render you, and for that I\r\nplace myself entirely at your orders, that is, to present, or make my\r\nfriends present, you everywhere; besides, you have no need of anyone to\r\nintroduce you\xe2\x80\x94with your name, and your fortune, and your talent\xe2\x80\x9d (Monte\r\nCristo bowed with a somewhat ironical smile) \xe2\x80\x9cyou can present yourself\r\neverywhere, and be well received. I can be useful in one way only\xe2\x80\x94if\r\nknowledge of Parisian habits, of the means of rendering yourself\r\ncomfortable, or of the bazaars, can assist, you may depend upon me to\r\nfind you a fitting dwelling here. I do not dare offer to share my\r\napartments with you, as I shared yours at Rome\xe2\x80\x94I, who do not profess\r\negotism, but am yet egotist _par excellence_; for, except myself, these\r\nrooms would not hold a shadow more, unless that shadow were feminine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is a most conjugal reservation; I recollect\r\nthat at Rome you said something of a projected marriage. May I\r\ncongratulate you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe affair is still in projection.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he who says in \xe2\x80\x98projection,\xe2\x80\x99 means already decided,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cmy father is most anxious about it; and I hope,\r\nere long, to introduce you, if not to my wife, at least to my\r\nbetrothed\xe2\x80\x94Mademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie Danglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEug\xc3\xa9nie Danglars,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9ctell me, is not her father\r\nBaron Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9ca baron of a new creation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat matter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cif he has rendered the State services\r\nwhich merit this distinction?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnormous ones,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Beauchamp. \xe2\x80\x9cAlthough in reality a Liberal, he\r\nnegotiated a loan of six millions for Charles X., in 1829, who made him\r\na baron and chevalier of the Legion of Honor; so that he wears the\r\nribbon, not, as you would think, in his waistcoat-pocket, but at his\r\nbutton-hole.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Morcerf, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cBeauchamp, Beauchamp, keep that\r\nfor the _Corsaire_ or the _Charivari_, but spare my future\r\nfather-in-law before me.\xe2\x80\x9d Then, turning to Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cYou just now\r\nspoke his name as if you knew the baron?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know him,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I shall probably soon\r\nmake his acquaintance, for I have a credit opened with him by the house\r\nof Richard & Blount, of London, Arstein & Eskeles of Vienna, and\r\nThomson & French at Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d As he pronounced the two last names, the\r\ncount glanced at Maximilian Morrel. If the stranger expected to produce\r\nan effect on Morrel, he was not mistaken\xe2\x80\x94Maximilian started as if he\r\nhad been electrified.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThomson & French,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know this house, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20253m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are my bankers in the capital of the Christian world,\xe2\x80\x9d returned\r\nthe count quietly. \xe2\x80\x9cCan my influence with them be of any service to\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, count, you could assist me perhaps in researches which have been,\r\nup to the present, fruitless. This house, in past years, did ours a\r\ngreat service, and has, I know not for what reason, always denied\r\nhaving rendered us this service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be at your orders,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo bowing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9c_\xc3\xa0 propos_ of Danglars,\xe2\x80\x94we have strangely\r\nwandered from the subject. We were speaking of a suitable habitation\r\nfor the Count of Monte Cristo. Come, gentlemen, let us all propose some\r\nplace.
