Where shall we lodge this new guest in our great capital?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFaubourg Saint-Germain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. \xe2\x80\x9cThe count will find\r\nthere a charming hotel, with a court and garden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah! Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cyou only know your dull and\r\ngloomy Faubourg Saint-Germain; do not pay any attention to him,\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x94live in the Chauss\xc3\xa9e d\xe2\x80\x99Antin, that\xe2\x80\x99s the real centre of Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoulevard de l\xe2\x80\x99Op\xc3\xa9ra,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9cthe second floor\xe2\x80\x94a house with\r\na balcony. The count will have his cushions of silver cloth brought\r\nthere, and as he smokes his chibouque, see all Paris pass before him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have no idea, then, Morrel?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9cyou do not\r\npropose anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the young man, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9con the contrary, I have\r\none, but I expected the count would be tempted by one of the brilliant\r\nproposals made him, yet as he has not replied to any of them, I will\r\nventure to offer him a suite of apartments in a charming hotel, in the\r\nPompadour style, that my sister has inhabited for a year, in the Rue\r\nMeslay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a sister?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur, a most excellent sister.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarried?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNearly nine years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHappy?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs happy as it is permitted to a human creature to be,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nMaximilian. \xe2\x80\x9cShe married the man she loved, who remained faithful to us\r\nin our fallen fortunes\xe2\x80\x94Emmanuel Herbaut.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo smiled imperceptibly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI live there during my leave of absence,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Maximilian; \xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\nshall be, together with my brother-in-law Emmanuel, at the disposition\r\nof the Count, whenever he thinks fit to honor us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne minute,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Albert, without giving Monte Cristo the time to\r\nreply. \xe2\x80\x9cTake care, you are going to immure a traveller, Sinbad the\r\nSailor, a man who comes to see Paris; you are going to make a patriarch\r\nof him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20255m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cmy sister is five-and-twenty, my brother-in-law\r\nis thirty, they are gay, young, and happy. Besides, the count will be\r\nin his own house, and only see them when he thinks fit to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI shall content myself with\r\nbeing presented to your sister and her husband, if you will do me the\r\nhonor to introduce me; but I cannot accept the offer of anyone of these\r\ngentlemen, since my habitation is already prepared.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are, then, going to a hotel\xe2\x80\x94that will be\r\nvery dull for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas I so badly lodged at Rome?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Parbleu!_ at Rome you spent fifty thousand piastres in furnishing\r\nyour apartments, but I presume that you are not disposed to spend a\r\nsimilar sum every day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not that which deterred me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut as I\r\ndetermined to have a house to myself, I sent on my valet de chambre,\r\nand he ought by this time to have bought the house and furnished it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have, then, a valet de chambre who knows Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nBeauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the first time he has ever been in Paris. He is black, and\r\ncannot speak,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Ali!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Albert, in the midst of the general surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Ali himself, my Nubian mute, whom you saw, I think, at Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cI recollect him perfectly. But how could\r\nyou charge a Nubian to purchase a house, and a mute to furnish it?\xe2\x80\x94he\r\nwill do everything wrong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUndeceive yourself, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI am quite sure,\r\nthat, on the contrary, he will choose everything as I wish. He knows my\r\ntastes, my caprices, my wants. He has been here a week, with the\r\ninstinct of a hound, hunting by himself. He will arrange everything for\r\nme. He knew, that I should arrive today at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock; he was waiting\r\nfor me at nine at the Barri\xc3\xa8re de Fontainebleau. He gave me this paper;\r\nit contains the number of my new abode; read it yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d and Monte\r\nCristo passed a paper to Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that is really original,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd very princely,\xe2\x80\x9d added Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, do you not know your house?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI told you I did not wish to be behind my\r\ntime; I dressed myself in the carriage, and descended at the viscount\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndoor.\xe2\x80\x9d The young men looked at each other; they did not know if it was\r\na comedy Monte Cristo was playing, but every word he uttered had such\r\nan air of simplicity, that it was impossible to suppose what he said\r\nwas false\xe2\x80\x94besides, why should he tell a falsehood?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must content ourselves, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cwith rendering the\r\ncount all the little services in our power. I, in my quality of\r\njournalist, open all the theatres to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cmy steward has orders to\r\ntake a box at each theatre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs your steward also a Nubian?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he is a countryman of yours, if a Corsican is a countryman of\r\nanyone\xe2\x80\x99s. But you know him, M. de Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it that excellent M. Bertuccio, who understands hiring windows so\r\nwell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you saw him the day I had the honor of receiving you; he has been\r\na soldier, a smuggler\xe2\x80\x94in fact, everything. I would not be quite sure\r\nthat he has not been mixed up with the police for some trifle\xe2\x80\x94a stab\r\nwith a knife, for instance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have chosen this honest citizen for your steward,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nDebray. \xe2\x80\x9cOf how much does he rob you every year?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my word,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, \xe2\x80\x9cnot more than another. I am sure he\r\nanswers my purpose, knows no impossibility, and so I keep him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9csince you have an establishment, a\r\nsteward, and a hotel in the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es, you only want a mistress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAlbert smiled. He thought of the fair Greek he had seen in the count\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbox at the Argentina and Valle theatres.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have something better than that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI have a\r\nslave. You procure your mistresses from the opera, the Vaudeville, or\r\nthe Vari\xc3\xa9t\xc3\xa9s; I purchased mine at Constantinople; it cost me more, but\r\nI have nothing to fear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you forget,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Debray, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we are Franks by name\r\nand franks by nature, as King Charles said, and that the moment she\r\nputs her foot in France your slave becomes free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho will tell her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe first person who sees her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe only speaks Romaic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is different.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut at least we shall see her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cor do you keep\r\neunuchs as well as mutes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI do not carry brutalism so far.\r\nEveryone who surrounds me is free to quit me, and when they leave me\r\nwill no longer have any need of me or anyone else; it is for that\r\nreason, perhaps, that they do not quit me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey had long since passed to dessert and cigars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, rising, \xe2\x80\x9cit is half-past two. Your guest\r\nis charming, but you leave the best company to go into the worst\r\nsometimes. I must return to the minister\xe2\x80\x99s. I will tell him of the\r\ncount, and we shall soon know who he is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cno one has been able to accomplish\r\nthat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, we have three millions for our police; it is true they are almost\r\nalways spent beforehand, but, no matter, we shall still have fifty\r\nthousand francs to spend for this purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when you know, will you tell me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promise you. _Au revoir_, Albert. Gentlemen, good morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he left the room, Debray called out loudly, \xe2\x80\x9cMy carriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp to Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cI shall not go to the Chamber, but\r\nI have something better to offer my readers than a speech of M.\r\nDanglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake, Beauchamp,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not deprive me of\r\nthe merit of introducing him everywhere. Is he not peculiar?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is more than that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9che is one of the most\r\nextraordinary men I ever saw in my life. Are you coming, Morrel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDirectly I have given my card to the count, who has promised to pay us\r\na visit at Rue Meslay, No. 14.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe sure I shall not fail to do so,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count, bowing.\r\n\r\nAnd Maximilian Morrel left the room with the Baron de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud,\r\nleaving Monte Cristo alone with Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 41. The Presentation\r\n\r\nWhen Albert found himself alone with Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid he, \xe2\x80\x9callow me to commence my services as _cicerone_ by showing you\r\na specimen of a bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s apartment. You, who are accustomed to the\r\npalaces of Italy, can amuse yourself by calculating in how many square\r\nfeet a young man who is not the worst lodged in Paris can live. As we\r\npass from one room to another, I will open the windows to let you\r\nbreathe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo had already seen the breakfast-room and the salon on the\r\nground floor. Albert led him first to his _atelier_, which was, as we\r\nhave said, his favorite apartment. Monte Cristo quickly appreciated all\r\nthat Albert had collected here\xe2\x80\x94old cabinets, Japanese porcelain,\r\nOriental stuffs, Venetian glass, arms from all parts of the\r\nworld\xe2\x80\x94everything was familiar to him; and at the first glance he\r\nrecognized their date, their country, and their origin.\r\n\r\nMorcerf had expected he should be the guide; on the contrary, it was he\r\nwho, under the count\xe2\x80\x99s guidance, followed a course of arch\xc3\xa6ology,\r\nmineralogy, and natural history.\r\n\r\nThey descended to the first floor; Albert led his guest into the salon.\r\nThe salon was filled with the works of modern artists; there were\r\nlandscapes by Dupr\xc3\xa9, with their long reeds and tall trees, their lowing\r\noxen and marvellous skies; Delacroix\xe2\x80\x99s Arabian cavaliers, with their\r\nlong white burnouses, their shining belts, their damasked arms, their\r\nhorses, who tore each other with their teeth while their riders\r\ncontended fiercely with their maces; _aquarelles_ of Boulanger,\r\nrepresenting Notre Dame de Paris with that vigor that makes the artist\r\nthe rival of the poet; there were paintings by Diaz, who makes his\r\nflowers more beautiful than flowers, his suns more brilliant than the\r\nsun; designs by Decamp, as vividly colored as those of Salvator Rosa,\r\nbut more poetic; _pastels_ by Giraud and M\xc3\xbcller, representing children\r\nlike angels and women with the features of a virgin; sketches torn from\r\nthe album of Dauzats\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cTravels in the East,\xe2\x80\x9d that had been made in a\r\nfew seconds on the saddle of a camel, or beneath the dome of a\r\nmosque\xe2\x80\x94in a word, all that modern art can give in exchange and as\r\nrecompense for the art lost and gone with ages long since past.\r\n\r\nAlbert expected to have something new this time to show to the\r\ntraveller, but, to his great surprise, the latter, without seeking for\r\nthe signatures, many of which, indeed, were only initials, named\r\ninstantly the author of every picture in such a manner that it was easy\r\nto see that each name was not only known to him, but that each style\r\nassociated with it had been appreciated and studied by him. From the\r\nsalon they passed into the bedchamber; it was a model of taste and\r\nsimple elegance. A single portrait, signed by L\xc3\xa9opold Robert, shone in\r\nits carved and gilded frame. This portrait attracted the Count of Monte\r\nCristo\xe2\x80\x99s attention, for he made three rapid steps in the chamber, and\r\nstopped suddenly before it.\r\n\r\nIt was the portrait of a young woman of five or six-and-twenty, with a\r\ndark complexion, and light and lustrous eyes, veiled beneath long\r\nlashes. She wore the picturesque costume of the Catalan fisherwomen, a\r\nred and black bodice, and golden pins in her hair. She was looking at\r\nthe sea, and her form was outlined on the blue ocean and sky. The light\r\nwas so faint in the room that Albert did not perceive the pallor that\r\nspread itself over the count\xe2\x80\x99s visage, or the nervous heaving of his\r\nchest and shoulders. Silence prevailed for an instant, during which\r\nMonte Cristo gazed intently on the picture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have there a most charming mistress, viscount,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count in\r\na perfectly calm tone; \xe2\x80\x9cand this costume\xe2\x80\x94a ball costume,\r\ndoubtless\xe2\x80\x94becomes her admirably.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI would never forgive you this\r\nmistake if you had seen another picture beside this. You do not know my\r\nmother; she it is whom you see here. She had her portrait painted thus\r\nsix or eight years ago. This costume is a fancy one, it appears, and\r\nthe resemblance is so great that I think I still see my mother the same\r\nas she was in 1830. The countess had this portrait painted during the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s absence. She doubtless intended giving him an agreeable\r\nsurprise; but, strange to say, this portrait seemed to displease my\r\nfather, and the value of the picture, which is, as you see, one of the\r\nbest works of L\xc3\xa9opold Robert, could not overcome his dislike to it. It\r\nis true, between ourselves, that M. de Morcerf is one of the most\r\nassiduous peers at the Luxembourg, a general renowned for theory, but a\r\nmost mediocre amateur of art. It is different with my mother, who\r\npaints exceedingly well, and who, unwilling to part with so valuable a\r\npicture, gave it to me to put here, where it would be less likely to\r\ndisplease M. de Morcerf, whose portrait, by Gros, I will also show you.\r\nExcuse my talking of family matters, but as I shall have the honor of\r\nintroducing you to the count, I tell you this to prevent you making any\r\nallusions to this picture. The picture seems to have a malign\r\ninfluence, for my mother rarely comes here without looking at it, and\r\nstill more rarely does she look at it without weeping. This\r\ndisagreement is the only one that has ever taken place between the\r\ncount and countess, who are still as much united, although married more\r\nthan twenty years, as on the first day of their wedding.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20261m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo glanced rapidly at Albert, as if to seek a hidden meaning\r\nin his words, but it was evident the young man uttered them in the\r\nsimplicity of his heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you have seen all my treasures, allow me to\r\noffer them to you, unworthy as they are. Consider yourself as in your\r\nown house, and to put yourself still more at your ease, pray accompany\r\nme to the apartments of M. de Morcerf, he whom I wrote from Rome an\r\naccount of the services you rendered me, and to whom I announced your\r\npromised visit, and I may say that both the count and countess\r\nanxiously desire to thank you in person. You are somewhat _blas\xc3\xa9_ I\r\nknow, and family scenes have not much effect on Sinbad the Sailor, who\r\nhas seen so many others. However, accept what I propose to you as an\r\ninitiation into Parisian life\xe2\x80\x94a life of politeness, visiting, and\r\nintroductions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo bowed without making any answer; he accepted the offer\r\nwithout enthusiasm and without regret, as one of those conventions of\r\nsociety which every gentleman looks upon as a duty. Albert summoned his\r\nservant, and ordered him to acquaint M. and Madame de Morcerf of the\r\narrival of the Count of Monte Cristo. Albert followed him with the\r\ncount. When they arrived at the antechamber, above the door was visible\r\na shield, which, by its rich ornaments and its harmony with the rest of\r\nthe furniture, indicated the importance the owner attached to this\r\nblazon. Monte Cristo stopped and examined it attentively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAzure seven merlets, or, placed bender,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cThese are,\r\ndoubtless, your family arms? Except the knowledge of blazons, that\r\nenables me to decipher them, I am very ignorant of heraldry\xe2\x80\x94I, a count\r\nof a fresh creation, fabricated in Tuscany by the aid of a commandery\r\nof St. Stephen, and who would not have taken the trouble had I not been\r\ntold that when you travel much it is necessary. Besides, you must have\r\nsomething on the panels of your carriage, to escape being searched by\r\nthe custom-house officers. Excuse my putting such a question to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not indiscreet,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Morcerf, with the simplicity of\r\nconviction. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have guessed rightly. These are our arms, that is,\r\nthose of my father, but they are, as you see, joined to another shield,\r\nwhich has gules, a silver tower, which are my mother\xe2\x80\x99s. By her side I\r\nam Spanish, but the family of Morcerf is French, and, I have heard, one\r\nof the oldest of the south of France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cthese blazons prove that. Almost all the\r\narmed pilgrims that went to the Holy Land took for their arms either a\r\ncross, in honor of their mission, or birds of passage, in sign of the\r\nlong voyage they were about to undertake, and which they hoped to\r\naccomplish on the wings of faith. One of your ancestors had joined the\r\nCrusades, and supposing it to be only that of St. Louis, that makes you\r\nmount to the thirteenth century, which is tolerably ancient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is possible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cmy father has in his study a\r\ngenealogical tree which will tell you all that, and on which I made\r\ncommentaries that would have greatly edified d\xe2\x80\x99Hozier and Jaucourt. At\r\npresent I no longer think of it, and yet I must tell you that we are\r\nbeginning to occupy ourselves greatly with these things under our\r\npopular government.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, your government would do well to choose from the past\r\nsomething better than the things that I have noticed on your monuments,\r\nand which have no heraldic meaning whatever. As for you, viscount,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued Monte Cristo to Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are more fortunate than the\r\ngovernment, for your arms are really beautiful, and speak to the\r\nimagination. Yes, you are at once from Provence and Spain; that\r\nexplains, if the portrait you showed me be like, the dark hue I so much\r\nadmired on the visage of the noble Catalan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt would have required the penetration of \xc5\x92dipus or the Sphinx to have\r\ndivined the irony the count concealed beneath these words, apparently\r\nuttered with the greatest politeness. Morcerf thanked him with a smile,\r\nand pushed open the door above which were his arms, and which, as we\r\nhave said, opened into the salon. In the most conspicuous part of the\r\nsalon was another portrait. It was that of a man, from five to\r\neight-and-thirty, in the uniform of a general officer, wearing the\r\ndouble epaulet of heavy bullion, that indicates superior rank, the\r\nribbon of the Legion of Honor around his neck, which showed he was a\r\ncommander, and on the right breast, the star of a grand officer of the\r\norder of the Saviour, and on the left that of the grand cross of\r\nCharles III., which proved that the person represented by the picture\r\nhad served in the wars of Greece and Spain, or, what was just the same\r\nthing as regarded decorations, had fulfilled some diplomatic mission in\r\nthe two countries.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo was engaged in examining this portrait with no less care\r\nthan he had bestowed upon the other, when another door opened, and he\r\nfound himself opposite to the Count of Morcerf in person.\r\n\r\nHe was a man of forty to forty-five years, but he seemed at least\r\nfifty, and his black moustache and eyebrows contrasted strangely with\r\nhis almost white hair, which was cut short, in the military fashion. He\r\nwas dressed in plain clothes, and wore at his button-hole the ribbons\r\nof the different orders to which he belonged.\r\n\r\nHe entered with a tolerably dignified step, and some little haste.\r\nMonte Cristo saw him advance towards him without making a single step.\r\nIt seemed as if his feet were rooted to the ground, and his eyes on the\r\nCount of Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cI have the honor of presenting to you\r\nthe Count of Monte Cristo, the generous friend whom I had the good\r\nfortune to meet in the critical situation of which I have told you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are most welcome, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Count of Morcerf, saluting\r\nMonte Cristo with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cand monsieur has rendered our house, in\r\npreserving its only heir, a service which insures him our eternal\r\ngratitude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he said these words, the count of Morcerf pointed to a chair, while\r\nhe seated himself in another opposite the window.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo, in taking the seat Morcerf offered him, placed himself in\r\nsuch a manner as to remain concealed in the shadow of the large velvet\r\ncurtains, and read on the careworn and livid features of the count a\r\nwhole history of secret griefs written in each wrinkle time had planted\r\nthere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe countess,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cwas at her toilet when she was informed\r\nof the visit she was about to receive. She will, however, be in the\r\nsalon in ten minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a great honor to me,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cto be thus, on the\r\nfirst day of my arrival in Paris, brought in contact with a man whose\r\nmerit equals his reputation, and to whom fortune has for once been\r\nequitable, but has she not still on the plains of Mitidja, or in the\r\nmountains of Atlas, a marshal\xe2\x80\x99s staff to offer you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morcerf, reddening slightly, \xe2\x80\x9cI have left the service,\r\nmonsieur. Made a peer at the Restoration, I served through the first\r\ncampaign under the orders of Marshal Bourmont. I could, therefore,\r\nexpect a higher rank, and who knows what might have happened had the\r\nelder branch remained on the throne? But the Revolution of July was, it\r\nseems, sufficiently glorious to allow itself to be ungrateful, and it\r\nwas so for all services that did not date from the imperial period. I\r\ntendered my resignation, for when you have gained your epaulets on the\r\nbattle-field, you do not know how to man\xc5\x93uvre on the slippery grounds\r\nof the salons. I have hung up my sword, and cast myself into politics.\r\nI have devoted myself to industry; I study the useful arts. During the\r\ntwenty years I served, I often wished to do so, but I had not the\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese are the ideas that render your nation superior to any other,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreturned Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cA gentleman of high birth, possessor of an\r\nample fortune, you have consented to gain your promotion as an obscure\r\nsoldier, step by step\xe2\x80\x94this is uncommon; then become general, peer of\r\nFrance, commander of the Legion of Honor, you consent to again commence\r\na second apprenticeship, without any other hope or any other desire\r\nthan that of one day becoming useful to your fellow-creatures; this,\r\nindeed, is praiseworthy,\xe2\x80\x94nay, more, it is sublime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20265m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAlbert looked on and listened with astonishment; he was not used to see\r\nMonte Cristo give vent to such bursts of enthusiasm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the stranger, doubtless to dispel the slight cloud\r\nthat covered Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s brow, \xe2\x80\x9cwe do not act thus in Italy; we grow\r\naccording to our race and our species, and we pursue the same lines,\r\nand often the same uselessness, all our lives.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Count of Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cfor a man of your merit,\r\nItaly is not a country, and France opens her arms to receive you;\r\nrespond to her call. France will not, perhaps, be always ungrateful.\r\nShe treats her children ill, but she always welcomes strangers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cit is evident you do not know\r\nthe Count of Monte Cristo; he despises all honors, and contents himself\r\nwith those written on his passport.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the most just remark,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the stranger, \xe2\x80\x9cI ever heard\r\nmade concerning myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have been free to choose your career,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the Count of\r\nMorcerf, with a sigh; \xe2\x80\x9cand you have chosen the path strewed with\r\nflowers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo with one of those smiles\r\nthat a painter could never represent or a physiologist analyze.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I did not fear to fatigue you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the general, evidently charmed\r\nwith the count\xe2\x80\x99s manners, \xe2\x80\x9cI would have taken you to the Chamber; there\r\nis a debate very curious to those who are strangers to our modern\r\nsenators.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be most grateful, monsieur, if you will, at some future time,\r\nrenew your offer, but I have been flattered with the hope of being\r\nintroduced to the countess, and I will therefore wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, here is my mother,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the viscount.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo, turned round hastily, and saw Madame de Morcerf at the\r\nentrance of the salon, at the door opposite to that by which her\r\nhusband had entered, pale and motionless; when Monte Cristo turned\r\nround, she let fall her arm, which for some unknown reason had been\r\nresting on the gilded door-post. She had been there some moments, and\r\nhad heard the last words of the visitor. The latter rose and bowed to\r\nthe countess, who inclined herself without speaking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! good heavens, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9care you ill, or is it the\r\nheat of the room that affects you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you ill, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the viscount, springing towards her.\r\n\r\nShe thanked them both with a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d returned she, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I feel some emotion on seeing, for the first\r\ntime, the man without whose intervention we should have been in tears\r\nand desolation. Monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the countess, advancing with the\r\nmajesty of a queen, \xe2\x80\x9cI owe to you the life of my son, and for this I\r\nbless you. Now, I thank you for the pleasure you give me in thus\r\naffording me the opportunity of thanking you as I have blessed you,\r\nfrom the bottom of my heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count bowed again, but lower than before; he was even paler than\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe count and yourself recompense too generously a\r\nsimple action. To save a man, to spare a father\xe2\x80\x99s feelings, or a\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s sensibility, is not to do a good action, but a simple deed of\r\nhumanity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words, uttered with the most exquisite sweetness and\r\npoliteness, Madame de Morcerf replied:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very fortunate for my son, monsieur, that he found such a\r\nfriend, and I thank God that things are thus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s raised her fine eyes to heaven with so fervent an\r\nexpression of gratitude, that the count fancied he saw tears in them.\r\nM. de Morcerf approached her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cI have already made my excuses to the count for\r\nquitting him, and I pray you to do so also. The sitting commences at\r\ntwo; it is now three, and I am to speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, then, and monsieur and I will strive our best to forget your\r\nabsence,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the countess, with the same tone of deep feeling.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d continued she, turning to Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you do us the\r\nhonor of passing the rest of the day with us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBelieve me, madame, I feel most grateful for your kindness, but I got\r\nout of my travelling carriage at your door this morning, and I am\r\nignorant how I am installed in Paris, which I scarcely know; this is\r\nbut a trifling inquietude, I know, but one that may be appreciated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall have the pleasure another time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\npromise that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo inclined himself without answering, but the gesture might\r\npass for assent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not detain you, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the countess; \xe2\x80\x9cI would not\r\nhave our gratitude become indiscreet or importunate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI will endeavor to return your\r\npoliteness at Rome, and place my coup\xc3\xa9 at your disposal until your own\r\nbe ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA thousand thanks for your kindness, viscount,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the Count of\r\nMonte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cbut I suppose that M. Bertuccio has suitably employed the\r\nfour hours and a half I have given him, and that I shall find a\r\ncarriage of some sort ready at the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert was used to the count\xe2\x80\x99s manner of proceeding; he knew that, like\r\nNero, he was in search of the impossible, and nothing astonished him,\r\nbut wishing to judge with his own eyes how far the count\xe2\x80\x99s orders had\r\nbeen executed, he accompanied him to the door of the house. Monte\r\nCristo was not deceived. As soon as he appeared in the Count of\r\nMorcerf\xe2\x80\x99s antechamber, a footman, the same who at Rome had brought the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s card to the two young men, and announced his visit, sprang into\r\nthe vestibule, and when he arrived at the door the illustrious\r\ntraveller found his carriage awaiting him. It was a _coup\xc3\xa9_ of Koller\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbuilding, and with horses and harness for which Drake had, to the\r\nknowledge of all the lions of Paris, refused on the previous day seven\r\nhundred guineas.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count to Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not ask you to accompany me\r\nto my house, as I can only show you a habitation fitted up in a hurry,\r\nand I have, as you know, a reputation to keep up as regards not being\r\ntaken by surprise. Give me, therefore, one more day before I invite\r\nyou; I shall then be certain not to fail in my hospitality.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you ask me for a day, count, I know what to anticipate; it will not\r\nbe a house I shall see, but a palace. You have decidedly some genius at\r\nyour control.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi_, spread that idea,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Count of Monte Cristo,\r\nputting his foot on the velvet-lined steps of his splendid carriage,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand that will be worth something to me among the ladies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he spoke, he sprang into the vehicle, the door was closed, but not\r\nso rapidly that Monte Cristo failed to perceive the almost\r\nimperceptible movement which stirred the curtains of the apartment in\r\nwhich he had left Madame de Morcerf.\r\n\r\nWhen Albert returned to his mother, he found her in the boudoir\r\nreclining in a large velvet armchair, the whole room so obscure that\r\nonly the shining spangle, fastened here and there to the drapery, and\r\nthe angles of the gilded frames of the pictures, showed with some\r\ndegree of brightness in the gloom. Albert could not see the face of the\r\ncountess, as it was covered with a thin veil she had put on her head,\r\nand which fell over her features in misty folds, but it seemed to him\r\nas though her voice had altered. He could distinguish amid the perfumes\r\nof the roses and heliotropes in the flower-stands, the sharp and\r\nfragrant odor of volatile salts, and he noticed in one of the chased\r\ncups on the mantle-piece the countess\xe2\x80\x99s smelling-bottle, taken from its\r\nshagreen case, and exclaimed in a tone of uneasiness, as he entered:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear mother, have you been ill during my absence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, Albert, but you know these roses, tuberoses, and\r\norange-flowers throw out at first, before one is used to them, such\r\nviolent perfumes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, my dear mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, putting his hand to the bell,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthey must be taken into the antechamber. You are really ill, and just\r\nnow were so pale as you came into the room\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas I pale, Albert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; a pallor that suits you admirably, mother, but which did not the\r\nless alarm my father and myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid your father speak of it?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, madame; but do you not remember that he spoke of the fact to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20269m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I do remember,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the countess.\r\n\r\nA servant entered, summoned by Albert\xe2\x80\x99s ring of the bell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake these flowers into the anteroom or dressing-room,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nviscount; \xe2\x80\x9cthey make the countess ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe footman obeyed his orders. A long pause ensued, which lasted until\r\nall the flowers were removed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this name of Monte Cristo?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the countess, when the\r\nservant had taken away the last vase of flowers, \xe2\x80\x9cis it a family name,\r\nor the name of the estate, or a simple title?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe, mother, it is merely a title. The count purchased an island\r\nin the Tuscan archipelago, and, as he told you today, has founded a\r\ncommandery. You know the same thing was done for Saint Stephen of\r\nFlorence, Saint George Constantinian of Parma, and even for the Order\r\nof Malta. Except this, he has no pretension to nobility, and calls\r\nhimself a chance count, although the general opinion at Rome is that\r\nthe count is a man of very high distinction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis manners are admirable,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, \xe2\x80\x9cat least, as far as I\r\ncould judge in the few minutes he remained here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are perfect mother, so perfect, that they surpass by far all I\r\nhave known in the leading aristocracy of the three proudest nobilities\r\nof Europe\xe2\x80\x94the English, the Spanish, and the German.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe countess paused a moment; then, after a slight hesitation, she\r\nresumed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have seen, my dear Albert\xe2\x80\x94I ask the question as a mother\xe2\x80\x94you have\r\nseen M. de Monte Cristo in his house, you are quicksighted, have much\r\nknowledge of the world, more tact than is usual at your age, do you\r\nthink the count is really what he appears to be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does he appear to be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you have just said,\xe2\x80\x94a man of high distinction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told you, my dear mother, he was esteemed such.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what is your own opinion, Albert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must tell you that I have not come to any decided opinion respecting\r\nhim, but I think him a Maltese.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not ask you of his origin but what he is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! what he is; that is quite another thing. I have seen so many\r\nremarkable things in him, that if you would have me really say what I\r\nthink, I shall reply that I really do look upon him as one of Byron\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nheroes, whom misery has marked with a fatal brand; some Manfred, some\r\nLara, some Werner, one of those wrecks, as it were, of some ancient\r\nfamily, who, disinherited of their patrimony, have achieved one by the\r\nforce of their adventurous genius, which has placed them above the laws\r\nof society.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say that Monte Cristo is an island in the midst of the\r\nMediterranean, without inhabitants or garrison, the resort of smugglers\r\nof all nations, and pirates of every flag. Who knows whether or not\r\nthese industrious worthies do not pay to their feudal lord some dues\r\nfor his protection?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is possible,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, reflecting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the young man, \xe2\x80\x9csmuggler or not, you must\r\nagree, mother dear, as you have seen him, that the Count of Monte\r\nCristo is a remarkable man, who will have the greatest success in the\r\nsalons of Paris. Why, this very morning, in my rooms, he made his\r\n_entr\xc3\xa9e_ amongst us by striking every man of us with amazement, not\r\neven excepting Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what do you suppose is the count\xe2\x80\x99s age?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s,\r\nevidently attaching great importance to this question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThirty-five or thirty-six, mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo young,\xe2\x80\x94it is impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, replying at the same time\r\nto what Albert said as well as to her own private reflection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the truth, however. Three or four times he has said to me, and\r\ncertainly without the slightest premeditation, \xe2\x80\x98at such a period I was\r\nfive years old, at another ten years old, at another twelve,\xe2\x80\x99 and I,\r\ninduced by curiosity, which kept me alive to these details, have\r\ncompared the dates, and never found him inaccurate. The age of this\r\nsingular man, who is of no age, is then, I am certain, thirty-five.\r\nBesides, mother, remark how vivid his eye, how raven-black his hair,\r\nand his brow, though so pale, is free from wrinkles,\xe2\x80\x94he is not only\r\nvigorous, but also young.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe countess bent her head, as if beneath a heavy wave of bitter\r\nthoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd has this man displayed a friendship for you, Albert?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked\r\nwith a nervous shudder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am inclined to think so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd\xe2\x80\x94do\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x94like\xe2\x80\x94him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, he pleases me in spite of Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, who tries to convince\r\nme that he is a being returned from the other world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe countess shuddered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, in a voice which was altered by emotion, \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\nalways put you on your guard against new acquaintances. Now you are a\r\nman, and are able to give me advice; yet I repeat to you, Albert, be\r\nprudent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, my dear mother, it is necessary, in order to make your advice\r\nturn to account, that I should know beforehand what I have to distrust.\r\nThe count never plays, he only drinks pure water tinged with a little\r\nsherry, and is so rich that he cannot, without intending to laugh at\r\nme, try to borrow money. What, then, have I to fear from him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, \xe2\x80\x9cand my fears are weakness,\r\nespecially when directed against a man who has saved your life. How did\r\nyour father receive him, Albert? It is necessary that we should be more\r\nthan complaisant to the count. M. de Morcerf is sometimes occupied, his\r\nbusiness makes him reflective, and he might, without intending it\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing could be in better taste than my father\xe2\x80\x99s demeanor, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cnay, more, he seemed greatly flattered at two or three\r\ncompliments which the count very skilfully and agreeably paid him with\r\nas much ease as if he had known him these thirty years. Each of these\r\nlittle tickling arrows must have pleased my father,\xe2\x80\x9d added Albert with\r\na laugh. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd thus they parted the best possible friends, and M. de\r\nMorcerf even wished to take him to the Chamber to hear the speakers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe countess made no reply. She fell into so deep a reverie that her\r\neyes gradually closed. The young man, standing up before her, gazed\r\nupon her with that filial affection which is so tender and endearing\r\nwith children whose mothers are still young and handsome. Then, after\r\nseeing her eyes closed, and hearing her breathe gently, he believed she\r\nhad dropped asleep, and left the apartment on tiptoe, closing the door\r\nafter him with the utmost precaution.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis devil of a fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, shaking his head; \xe2\x80\x9cI said at the\r\ntime he would create a sensation here, and I measure his effect by an\r\ninfallible thermometer. My mother has noticed him, and he must\r\ntherefore, perforce, be remarkable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went down to the stables, not without some slight annoyance, when he\r\nremembered that the Count of Monte Cristo had laid his hands on a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cturnout\xe2\x80\x9d which sent his bays down to second place in the opinion of\r\nconnoisseurs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost decidedly,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cmen are not equal, and I must beg my father\r\nto develop this theorem in the Chamber of Peers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 42. Monsieur Bertuccio\r\n\r\nMeanwhile the count had arrived at his house; it had taken him six\r\nminutes to perform the distance, but these six minutes were sufficient\r\nto induce twenty young men who knew the price of the equipage they had\r\nbeen unable to purchase themselves, to put their horses in a gallop in\r\norder to see the rich foreigner who could afford to give 20,000 francs\r\napiece for his horses.\r\n\r\nThe house Ali had chosen, and which was to serve as a town residence to\r\nMonte Cristo, was situated on the right hand as you ascend the\r\nChamps-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es. A thick clump of trees and shrubs rose in the centre,\r\nand masked a portion of the front; around this shrubbery two alleys,\r\nlike two arms, extended right and left, and formed a carriage-drive\r\nfrom the iron gates to a double portico, on every step of which stood a\r\nporcelain vase, filled with flowers. This house, isolated from the\r\nrest, had, besides the main entrance, another in the Rue de Ponthieu.\r\nEven before the coachman had hailed the _concierge_, the massy gates\r\nrolled on their hinges\xe2\x80\x94they had seen the Count coming, and at Paris, as\r\neverywhere else, he was served with the rapidity of lightning. The\r\ncoachman entered and traversed the half-circle without slackening his\r\nspeed, and the gates were closed ere the wheels had ceased to sound on\r\nthe gravel. The carriage stopped at the left side of the portico, two\r\nmen presented themselves at the carriage-window; the one was Ali, who,\r\nsmiling with an expression of the most sincere joy, seemed amply repaid\r\nby a mere look from Monte Cristo. The other bowed respectfully, and\r\noffered his arm to assist the count in descending.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, M. Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, springing lightly up the three\r\nsteps of the portico; \xe2\x80\x9cand the notary?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is in the small salon, excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Bertuccio.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the cards I ordered to be engraved as soon as you knew the number\r\nof the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency, it is done already. I have been myself to the best\r\nengraver of the Palais Royal, who did the plate in my presence. The\r\nfirst card struck off was taken, according to your orders, to the Baron\r\nDanglars, Rue de la Chauss\xc3\xa9e d\xe2\x80\x99Antin, No. 7; the others are on the\r\nmantle-piece of your excellency\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood; what o\xe2\x80\x99clock is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFour o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo gave his hat, cane, and gloves to the same French footman\r\nwho had called his carriage at the Count of Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s, and then he\r\npassed into the small salon, preceded by Bertuccio, who showed him the\r\nway.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese are but indifferent marbles in this antechamber,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte\r\nCristo. \xe2\x80\x9cI trust all this will soon be taken away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio bowed. As the steward had said, the notary awaited him in the\r\nsmall salon. He was a simple-looking lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s clerk, elevated to the\r\nextraordinary dignity of a provincial scrivener.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are the notary empowered to sell the country house that I wish to\r\npurchase, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, count,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the notary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the deed of sale ready?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you brought it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well; and where is this house that I purchase?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count\r\ncarelessly, addressing himself half to Bertuccio, half to the notary.\r\nThe steward made a gesture that signified, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not know.\xe2\x80\x9d The notary\r\nlooked at the count with astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cdoes not the count know where the house he purchases\r\nis situated?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count does not know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow should I know? I have arrived from Cadiz this morning. I have\r\nnever before been at Paris, and it is the first time I have ever even\r\nset my foot in France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that is different; the house you purchase is at Auteuil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words Bertuccio turned pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where is Auteuil?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cClose by here, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the notary\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ca little beyond Passy; a\r\ncharming situation, in the heart of the Bois de Boulogne.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo near as that?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Count; \xe2\x80\x9cbut that is not in the country.\r\nWhat made you choose a house at the gates of Paris, M. Bertuccio?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the steward with a strange expression. \xe2\x80\x9cHis excellency did\r\nnot charge me to purchase this house. If his excellency will\r\nrecollect\xe2\x80\x94if he will think\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, true,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI recollect now. I read the\r\nadvertisement in one of the papers, and was tempted by the false title,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98a country house.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not yet too late,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bertuccio, eagerly; \xe2\x80\x9cand if your\r\nexcellency will intrust me with the commission, I will find you a\r\nbetter at Enghien, at Fontenay-aux-Roses, or at Bellevue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo negligently; \xe2\x80\x9csince I have this, I will\r\nkeep it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are quite right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the notary, who feared to lose his fee.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a charming place, well supplied with spring-water and fine\r\ntrees; a comfortable habitation, although abandoned for a long time,\r\nwithout reckoning the furniture, which, although old, is yet valuable,\r\nnow that old things are so much sought after. I suppose the count has\r\nthe tastes of the day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cit is very convenient, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is more\xe2\x80\x94it is magnificent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Peste!_ let us not lose such an opportunity,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe deed, if you please, Mr. Notary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he signed it rapidly, after having first run his eye over that part\r\nof the deed in which were specified the situation of the house and the\r\nnames of the proprietors.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cgive fifty-five thousand francs to monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe steward left the room with a faltering step, and returned with a\r\nbundle of bank-notes, which the notary counted like a man who never\r\ngives a receipt for money until after he is sure it is all there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the count, \xe2\x80\x9care all the forms complied with?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you the keys?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are in the hands of the concierge, who takes care of the house,\r\nbut here is the order I have given him to install the count in his new\r\npossessions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well;\xe2\x80\x9d and Monte Cristo made a sign with his hand to the notary,\r\nwhich said, \xe2\x80\x9cI have no further need of you; you may go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the honest notary, \xe2\x80\x9cthe count is, I think, mistaken; it\r\nis only fifty thousand francs, everything included.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd your fee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs included in this sum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut have you not come from Auteuil here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, certainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, it is but fair that you should be paid for your loss of\r\ntime and trouble,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; and he made a gesture of polite\r\ndismissal.\r\n\r\nThe notary left the room backwards, and bowing down to the ground; it\r\nwas the first time he had ever met a similar client.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee this gentleman out,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count to Bertuccio. And the steward\r\nfollowed the notary out of the room.\r\n\r\nScarcely was the count alone, when he drew from his pocket a book\r\nclosed with a lock, and opened it with a key which he wore round his\r\nneck, and which never left him. After having sought for a few minutes,\r\nhe stopped at a leaf which had several notes, and compared them with\r\nthe deed of sale, which lay on the table, and recalling his\r\n_souvenirs_\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Auteuil, Rue de la Fontaine, No. 28;\xe2\x80\x99 it is indeed the same,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nhe; \xe2\x80\x9cand now, am I to rely upon an avowal extorted by religious or\r\nphysical terror? However, in an hour I shall know all. Bertuccio!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncried he, striking a light hammer with a pliant handle on a small gong.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBertuccio!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe steward appeared at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cdid you never tell me that you\r\nhad travelled in France?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn some parts of France\xe2\x80\x94yes, excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know the environs of Paris, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, excellency, no,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the steward, with a sort of nervous\r\ntrembling, which Monte Cristo, a connoisseur in all emotions, rightly\r\nattributed to great disquietude.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is unfortunate,\xe2\x80\x9d returned he, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you have never visited the\r\nenvirons, for I wish to see my new property this evening, and had you\r\ngone with me, you could have given me some useful information.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Auteuil!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bertuccio, whose copper complexion became livid\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ngo to Auteuil?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what is there surprising in that? When I live at Auteuil, you\r\nmust come there, as you belong to my service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio hung down his head before the imperious look of his master,\r\nand remained motionless, without making any answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what has happened to you?\xe2\x80\x94are you going to make me ring a second\r\ntime for the carriage?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo, in the same tone that Louis\r\nXIV. pronounced the famous, \xe2\x80\x9cI have been almost obliged to wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nBertuccio made but one bound to the antechamber, and cried in a hoarse\r\nvoice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis excellency\xe2\x80\x99s horses!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo wrote two or three notes, and, as he sealed the last, the\r\nsteward appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency\xe2\x80\x99s carriage is at the door,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, take your hat and gloves,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I to accompany you, your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bertuccio.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, you must give the orders, for I intend residing at the\r\nhouse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20277m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was unexampled for a servant of the count\xe2\x80\x99s to dare to dispute an\r\norder of his, so the steward, without saying a word, followed his\r\nmaster, who got into the carriage, and signed to him to follow, which\r\nhe did, taking his place respectfully on the front seat.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 43. The House at Auteuil\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo noticed, as they descended the staircase, that Bertuccio\r\nsigned himself in the Corsican manner; that is, had formed the sign of\r\nthe cross in the air with his thumb, and as he seated himself in the\r\ncarriage, muttered a short prayer. Anyone but a man of exhaustless\r\nthirst for knowledge would have had pity on seeing the steward\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nextraordinary repugnance for the count\xe2\x80\x99s projected drive without the\r\nwalls; but the count was too curious to let Bertuccio off from this\r\nlittle journey. In twenty minutes they were at Auteuil; the steward\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nemotion had continued to augment as they entered the village.\r\nBertuccio, crouched in the corner of the carriage, began to examine\r\nwith a feverish anxiety every house they passed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell them to stop at Rue de la Fontaine, No. 28,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count,\r\nfixing his eyes on the steward, to whom he gave this order.\r\n\r\nBertuccio\xe2\x80\x99s forehead was covered with perspiration; however, he obeyed,\r\nand, leaning out of the window, he cried to the coachman,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cRue de la\r\nFontaine, No. 28.\xe2\x80\x9d No. 28 was situated at the extremity of the village;\r\nduring the drive night had set in, and darkness gave the surroundings\r\nthe artificial appearance of a scene on the stage. The carriage\r\nstopped, the footman sprang off the box and opened the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cyou do not get out, M. Bertuccio\xe2\x80\x94you are going\r\nto stay in the carriage, then? What are you thinking of this evening?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio sprang out, and offered his shoulder to the count, who, this\r\ntime, leaned upon it as he descended the three steps of the carriage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnock,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cand announce me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio knocked, the door opened, and the concierge appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is your new master, my good fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the footman. And he held\r\nout to the concierge the notary\xe2\x80\x99s order.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe house is sold, then?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the concierge; \xe2\x80\x9cand this gentleman\r\nis coming to live here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count; \xe2\x80\x9cand I will endeavor to give you\r\nno cause to regret your old master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the concierge, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall not have much cause to\r\nregret him, for he came here but seldom; it is five years since he was\r\nhere last, and he did well to sell the house, for it did not bring him\r\nin anything at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was the name of your old master?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Marquis of Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran. Ah, I am sure he has not sold the house\r\nfor what he gave for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Marquis of Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count. \xe2\x80\x9cThe name is not\r\nunknown to me; the Marquis of Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran!\xe2\x80\x9d and he appeared to\r\nmeditate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn old gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the concierge, \xe2\x80\x9ca staunch follower of the\r\nBourbons; he had an only daughter, who married M. de Villefort, who had\r\nbeen the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney at N\xc3\xaemes, and afterwards at Versailles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo glanced at Bertuccio, who became whiter than the wall\r\nagainst which he leaned to prevent himself from falling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is not this daughter dead?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI fancy I have\r\nheard so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur, one-and-twenty years ago; and since then we have not\r\nseen the poor marquis three times.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, thanks,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, judging from the steward\xe2\x80\x99s utter\r\nprostration that he could not stretch the cord further without danger\r\nof breaking it. \xe2\x80\x9cGive me a light.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I accompany you, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it is unnecessary; Bertuccio will show me a light.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Monte Cristo accompanied these words by the gift of two gold\r\npieces, which produced a torrent of thanks and blessings from the\r\nconcierge.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, after having vainly searched on the\r\nmantle-piece and the shelves, \xe2\x80\x9cI have not got any candles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake one of the carriage-lamps, Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cand show\r\nme the apartments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe steward obeyed in silence, but it was easy to see, from the manner\r\nin which the hand that held the light trembled, how much it cost him to\r\nobey. They went over a tolerably large ground floor; a first floor\r\nconsisted of a salon, a bathroom, and two bedrooms; near one of the\r\nbedrooms they came to a winding staircase that led down to the garden.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, here is a private staircase,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is convenient.\r\nLight me, M. Bertuccio, and go first; we will see where it leads to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bertuccio, \xe2\x80\x9cit leads to the garden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, pray, how do you know that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt ought to do so, at least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, let us be sure of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio sighed, and went on first; the stairs did, indeed, lead to\r\nthe garden. At the outer door the steward paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, Monsieur Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\nBut he who was addressed stood there, stupefied, bewildered, stunned;\r\nhis haggard eyes glanced around, as if in search of the traces of some\r\nterrible event, and with his clenched hands he seemed striving to shut\r\nout horrible recollections.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d insisted the Count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bertuccio, setting down the lantern at the angle of the\r\ninterior wall. \xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur, it is impossible; I can go no farther.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does this mean?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the irresistible voice of Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you must see, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the steward, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this is\r\nnot natural; that, having a house to purchase, you purchase it exactly\r\nat Auteuil, and that, purchasing it at Auteuil, this house should be\r\nNo. 28, Rue de la Fontaine. Oh, why did I not tell you all? I am sure\r\nyou would not have forced me to come. I hoped your house would have\r\nbeen some other one than this; as if there was not another house at\r\nAuteuil than that of the assassination!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, what!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Monte Cristo, stopping suddenly, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat words do you\r\nutter? Devil of a man, Corsican that you are\xe2\x80\x94always mysteries or\r\nsuperstitions. Come, take the lantern, and let us visit the garden; you\r\nare not afraid of ghosts with me, I hope?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio raised the lantern, and obeyed. The door, as it opened,\r\ndisclosed a gloomy sky, in which the moon strove vainly to struggle\r\nthrough a sea of clouds that covered her with billows of vapor which\r\nshe illumined for an instant, only to sink into obscurity. The steward\r\nwished to turn to the left.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the use of following\r\nthe alleys? Here is a beautiful lawn; let us go on straight forwards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio wiped the perspiration from his brow, but obeyed; however, he\r\ncontinued to take the left hand. Monte Cristo, on the contrary, took\r\nthe right hand; arrived near a clump of trees, he stopped. The steward\r\ncould not restrain himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMove, monsieur\xe2\x80\x94move away, I entreat you; you are exactly in the spot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat spot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere he fell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n20281m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Monsieur Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9ccontrol\r\nyourself; we are not at Sart\xc3\xa8ne or at Corte. This is not a Corsican\r\n_maquis_ but an English garden; badly kept, I own, but still you must\r\nnot calumniate it for that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, I implore you do not stay there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think you are going mad, Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count coldly. \xe2\x80\x9cIf that\r\nis the case, I warn you, I shall have you put in a lunatic asylum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas! excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Bertuccio, joining his hands, and shaking\r\nhis head in a manner that would have excited the count\xe2\x80\x99s laughter, had\r\nnot thoughts of a superior interest occupied him, and rendered him\r\nattentive to the least revelation of this timorous conscience. \xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\r\nexcellency, the evil has arrived!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cI am very glad to tell you, that while\r\nyou gesticulate, you wring your hands and roll your eyes like a man\r\npossessed by a devil who will not leave him; and I have always\r\nobserved, that the devil most obstinate to be expelled is a secret. I\r\nknew you were a Corsican. I knew you were gloomy, and always brooding\r\nover some old history of the vendetta; and I overlooked that in Italy,\r\nbecause in Italy those things are thought nothing of. But in France\r\nthey are considered in very bad taste; there are gendarmes who occupy\r\nthemselves with such affairs, judges who condemn, and scaffolds which\r\navenge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio clasped his hands, and as, in all these evolutions, he did\r\nnot let fall the lantern, the light showed his pale and altered\r\ncountenance. Monte Cristo examined him with the same look that, at\r\nRome, he had bent upon the execution of Andrea, and then, in a tone\r\nthat made a shudder pass through the veins of the poor steward\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni, then told me an untruth,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen, after his\r\njourney in France, in 1829, he sent you to me, with a letter of\r\nrecommendation, in which he enumerated all your valuable qualities.\r\nWell, I shall write to the abb\xc3\xa9; I shall hold him responsible for his\r\n_prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x99s_ misconduct, and I shall soon know all about this\r\nassassination. Only I warn you, that when I reside in a country, I\r\nconform to all its code, and I have no wish to put myself within the\r\ncompass of the French laws for your sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do not do that, excellency; I have always served you faithfully,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncried Bertuccio, in despair. \xe2\x80\x9cI have always been an honest man, and, as\r\nfar as lay in my power, I have done good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not deny it,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count; \xe2\x80\x9cbut why are you thus agitated.\r\nIt is a bad sign; a quiet conscience does not occasion such paleness in\r\nthe cheeks, and such fever in the hands of a man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bertuccio hesitatingly, \xe2\x80\x9cdid not the\r\nAbb\xc3\xa9 Busoni, who heard my confession in the prison at N\xc3\xaemes, tell you\r\nthat I had a heavy burden upon my conscience?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but as he said you would make an excellent steward, I concluded\r\nyou had stolen\xe2\x80\x94that was all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, your excellency!\xe2\x80\x9d returned Bertuccio in deep contempt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr, as you are a Corsican, that you had been unable to resist the\r\ndesire of making a \xe2\x80\x98stiff,\xe2\x80\x99 as you call it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my good master,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bertuccio, casting himself at the count\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfeet, \xe2\x80\x9cit was simply vengeance\xe2\x80\x94nothing else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand that, but I do not understand what it is that galvanizes\r\nyou in this manner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, monsieur, it is very natural,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Bertuccio, \xe2\x80\x9csince it was\r\nin this house that my vengeance was accomplished.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! my house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, your excellency, it was not yours, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhose, then? The Marquis de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, I think, the concierge said.\r\nWhat had you to revenge on the Marquis de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it was not on him, monsieur; it was on another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is strange,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo, seeming to yield to his\r\nreflections, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you should find yourself without any preparation in\r\na house where the event happened that causes you so much remorse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the steward, \xe2\x80\x9cit is fatality, I am sure. First, you\r\npurchase a house at Auteuil\xe2\x80\x94this house is the one where I have\r\ncommitted an assassination; you descend to the garden by the same\r\nstaircase by which he descended; you stop at the spot where he received\r\nthe blow; and two paces farther is the grave in which he had just\r\nburied his child. This is not chance, for chance, in this case, is too\r\nmuch like Providence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, amiable Corsican, let us suppose it is Providence. I always\r\nsuppose anything people please, and, besides, you must concede\r\nsomething to diseased minds. Come, collect yourself, and tell me all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have related it but once, and that was to the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni. Such\r\nthings,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Bertuccio, shaking his head, \xe2\x80\x9care only related under\r\nthe seal of confession.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cI refer you to your confessor. Turn Chartreux\r\nor Trappist, and relate your secrets, but, as for me, I do not like\r\nanyone who is alarmed by such phantasms, and I do not choose that my\r\nservants should be afraid to walk in the garden of an evening. I\r\nconfess I am not very desirous of a visit from the commissary of\r\npolice, for, in Italy, justice is only paid when silent\xe2\x80\x94in France she\r\nis paid only when she speaks. _Peste!_ I thought you somewhat Corsican,\r\na great deal smuggler, and an excellent steward; but I see you have\r\nother strings to your bow. You are no longer in my service, Monsieur\r\nBertuccio.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, your excellency, your excellency!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the steward, struck with\r\nterror at this threat, \xe2\x80\x9cif that is the only reason I cannot remain in\r\nyour service, I will tell all, for if I quit you, it will only be to go\r\nto the scaffold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is different,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if you intend to tell\r\nan untruth, reflect it were better not to speak at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur, I swear to you, by my hopes of salvation, I will tell\r\nyou all, for the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni himself only knew a part of my secret;\r\nbut, I pray you, go away from that plane-tree. The moon is just\r\nbursting through the clouds, and there, standing where you do, and\r\nwrapped in that cloak that conceals your figure, you remind me of M. de\r\nVillefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cit was M. de Villefort?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency knows him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe former royal attorney at N\xc3\xaemes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho married the Marquis of Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s daughter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho enjoyed the reputation of being the most severe, the most upright,\r\nthe most rigid magistrate on the bench?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bertuccio, \xe2\x80\x9cthis man with this spotless\r\nreputation\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas a villain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cimpossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is as I tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, really,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you proof of this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have lost it; how stupid!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but by careful search it might be recovered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the count, \xe2\x80\x9crelate it to me, for it begins to\r\ninterest me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the count, humming an air from _Lucia_, went to sit down on a\r\nbench, while Bertuccio followed him, collecting his thoughts. Bertuccio\r\nremained standing before him.\r\n\r\n20285m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 44. The Vendetta\r\n\r\nAt what point shall I begin my story, your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nBertuccio.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere you please,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9csince I know nothing at all\r\nof it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni had told your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome particulars, doubtless, but that is seven or eight years ago, and\r\nI have forgotten them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I can speak without fear of tiring your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, M. Bertuccio; you will supply the want of the evening papers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe story begins in 1815.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9c1815 is not yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur, and yet I recollect all things as clearly as if they had\r\nhappened but then. I had a brother, an elder brother, who was in the\r\nservice of the emperor; he had become lieutenant in a regiment composed\r\nentirely of Corsicans. This brother was my only friend; we became\r\norphans\xe2\x80\x94I at five, he at eighteen. He brought me up as if I had been\r\nhis son, and in 1814 he married. When the emperor returned from the\r\nIsland of Elba, my brother instantly joined the army, was slightly\r\nwounded at Waterloo, and retired with the army beyond the Loire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that is the history of the Hundred Days, M. Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ncount; \xe2\x80\x9cunless I am mistaken, it has been already written.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, excellency, but these details are necessary, and you\r\npromised to be patient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on; I will keep my word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne day we received a letter. I should tell you that we lived in the\r\nlittle village of Rogliano, at the extremity of Cap Corse. This letter\r\nwas from my brother. He told us that the army was disbanded, and that\r\nhe should return by Ch\xc3\xa2teauroux, Clermont-Ferrand, Le Puy, and N\xc3\xaemes;\r\nand, if I had any money, he prayed me to leave it for him at N\xc3\xaemes,\r\nwith an innkeeper with whom I had dealings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the smuggling line?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, your excellency? Everyone must live.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI loved my brother tenderly, as I told your excellency, and I resolved\r\nnot to send the money, but to take it to him myself. I possessed a\r\nthousand francs. I left five hundred with Assunta, my sister-in-law,\r\nand with the other five hundred I set off for N\xc3\xaemes. It was easy to do\r\nso, and as I had my boat and a lading to take in at sea, everything\r\nfavored my project. But, after we had taken in our cargo, the wind\r\nbecame contrary, so that we were four or five days without being able\r\nto enter the Rh\xc3\xb4ne. At last, however, we succeeded, and worked up to\r\nArles. I left the boat between Bellegarde and Beaucaire, and took the\r\nroad to N\xc3\xaemes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are getting to the story now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your excellency; excuse me, but, as you will see, I only tell you\r\nwhat is absolutely necessary. Just at this time the famous massacres\r\ntook place in the south of France. Three brigands, called Trestaillon,\r\nTruphemy, and Graffan, publicly assassinated everybody whom they\r\nsuspected of Bonapartism. You have doubtless heard of these massacres,\r\nyour excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVaguely; I was far from France at that period. Go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I entered N\xc3\xaemes, I literally waded in blood; at every step you\r\nencountered dead bodies and bands of murderers, who killed, plundered,\r\nand burned. At the sight of this slaughter and devastation I became\r\nterrified, not for myself\xe2\x80\x94for I, a simple Corsican fisherman, had\r\nnothing to fear; on the contrary, that time was most favorable for us\r\nsmugglers\xe2\x80\x94but for my brother, a soldier of the empire, returning from\r\nthe army of the Loire, with his uniform and his epaulets, there was\r\neverything to apprehend. I hastened to the innkeeper. My misgivings had\r\nbeen but too true. My brother had arrived the previous evening at\r\nN\xc3\xaemes, and, at the very door of the house where he was about to demand\r\nhospitality, he had been assassinated. I did all in my power to\r\ndiscover the murderers, but no one durst tell me their names, so much\r\nwere they dreaded. I then thought of that French justice of which I had\r\nheard so much, and which feared nothing, and I went to the king\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattorney.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney was named Villefort?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo\r\ncarelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your excellency; he came from Marseilles, where he had been\r\ndeputy procureur.
