For I have no friend\r\nbut yourself upon earth, who am neglected and forgotten by my father,\r\nharassed and persecuted by my mother-in-law, and left to the sole\r\ncompanionship of a paralyzed and speechless old man, whose withered\r\nhand can no longer press mine, and who can speak to me with the eye\r\nalone, although there still lingers in his heart the warmest tenderness\r\nfor his poor grandchild. Oh, how bitter a fate is mine, to serve either\r\nas a victim or an enemy to all who are stronger than myself, while my\r\nonly friend and supporter is a living corpse! Indeed, indeed,\r\nMaximilian, I am very miserable, and if you love me it must be out of\r\npity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man, deeply affected, \xe2\x80\x9cI will not say\r\nyou are all I love in the world, for I dearly prize my sister and\r\nbrother-in-law; but my affection for them is calm and tranquil, in no\r\nmanner resembling what I feel for you. When I think of you my heart\r\nbeats fast, the blood burns in my veins, and I can hardly breathe; but\r\nI solemnly promise you to restrain all this ardor, this fervor and\r\nintensity of feeling, until you yourself shall require me to render\r\nthem available in serving or assisting you. M. Franz is not expected to\r\nreturn home for a year to come, I am told; in that time many favorable\r\nand unforeseen chances may befriend us. Let us, then, hope for the\r\nbest; hope is so sweet a comforter. Meanwhile, Valentine, while\r\nreproaching me with selfishness, think a little what you have been to\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94the beautiful but cold resemblance of a marble Venus. What promise\r\nof future reward have you made me for all the submission and obedience\r\nI have evinced?\xe2\x80\x94none whatever. What granted me?\xe2\x80\x94scarcely more. You tell\r\nme of M. Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, your betrothed lover, and you shrink from the\r\nidea of being his wife; but tell me, Valentine, is there no other\r\nsorrow in your heart? You see me devoted to you, body and soul, my life\r\nand each warm drop that circles round my heart are consecrated to your\r\nservice; you know full well that my existence is bound up in yours\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nwere I to lose you I would not outlive the hour of such crushing\r\nmisery; yet you speak with calmness of the prospect of your being the\r\nwife of another! Oh, Valentine, were I in your place, and did I feel\r\nconscious, as you do, of being worshipped, adored, with such a love as\r\nmine, a hundred times at least should I have passed my hand between\r\nthese iron bars, and said, \xe2\x80\x98Take this hand, dearest Maximilian, and\r\nbelieve that, living or dead, I am yours\xe2\x80\x94yours only, and forever!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe poor girl made no reply, but her lover could plainly hear her sobs\r\nand tears. A rapid change took place in the young man\xe2\x80\x99s feelings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDearest, dearest Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed he, \xe2\x80\x9cforgive me if I have\r\noffended you, and forget the words I spoke if they have unwittingly\r\ncaused you pain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Maximilian, I am not offended,\xe2\x80\x9d answered she, \xe2\x80\x9cbut do you not see\r\nwhat a poor, helpless being I am, almost a stranger and an outcast in\r\nmy father\xe2\x80\x99s house, where even he is seldom seen; whose will has been\r\nthwarted, and spirits broken, from the age of ten years, beneath the\r\niron rod so sternly held over me; oppressed, mortified, and persecuted,\r\nday by day, hour by hour, minute by minute, no person has cared for,\r\neven observed my sufferings, nor have I ever breathed one word on the\r\nsubject save to yourself. Outwardly and in the eyes of the world, I am\r\nsurrounded by kindness and affection; but the reverse is the case. The\r\ngeneral remark is, \xe2\x80\x98Oh, it cannot be expected that one of so stern a\r\ncharacter as M. Villefort could lavish the tenderness some fathers do\r\non their daughters. What though she has lost her own mother at a tender\r\nage, she has had the happiness to find a second mother in Madame de\r\nVillefort.\xe2\x80\x99 The world, however, is mistaken; my father abandons me from\r\nutter indifference, while my mother-in-law detests me with a hatred so\r\nmuch the more terrible because it is veiled beneath a continual smile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHate you, sweet Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the young man; \xe2\x80\x9chow is it\r\npossible for anyone to do that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the weeping girl, \xe2\x80\x9cI am obliged to own that my\r\nmother-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s aversion to me arises from a very natural source\xe2\x80\x94her\r\noverweening love for her own child, my brother Edward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why should it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know; but, though unwilling to introduce money matters into\r\nour present conversation, I will just say this much\xe2\x80\x94that her extreme\r\ndislike to me has its origin there; and I much fear she envies me the\r\nfortune I enjoy in right of my mother, and which will be more than\r\ndoubled at the death of M. and Mme. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, whose sole heiress\r\nI am. Madame de Villefort has nothing of her own, and hates me for\r\nbeing so richly endowed. Alas, how gladly would I exchange the half of\r\nthis wealth for the happiness of at least sharing my father\xe2\x80\x99s love. God\r\nknows, I would prefer sacrificing the whole, so that it would obtain me\r\na happy and affectionate home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Valentine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI seem to myself as though living a life of bondage, yet at the same\r\ntime am so conscious of my own weakness that I fear to break the\r\nrestraint in which I am held, lest I fall utterly helpless. Then, too,\r\nmy father is not a person whose orders may be infringed with impunity;\r\nprotected as he is by his high position and firmly established\r\nreputation for talent and unswerving integrity, no one could oppose\r\nhim; he is all-powerful even with the king; he would crush you at a\r\nword. Dear Maximilian, believe me when I assure you that if I do not\r\nattempt to resist my father\xe2\x80\x99s commands it is more on your account than\r\nmy own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why, Valentine, do you persist in anticipating the worst,\xe2\x80\x94why\r\npicture so gloomy a future?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I judge it from the past.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill, consider that although I may not be, strictly speaking, what is\r\ntermed an illustrious match for you, I am, for many reasons, not\r\naltogether so much beneath your alliance. The days when such\r\ndistinctions were so nicely weighed and considered no longer exist in\r\nFrance, and the first families of the monarchy have intermarried with\r\nthose of the empire. The aristocracy of the lance has allied itself\r\nwith the nobility of the cannon. Now I belong to this last-named class;\r\nand certainly my prospects of military preferment are most encouraging\r\nas well as certain. My fortune, though small, is free and unfettered,\r\nand the memory of my late father is respected in our country,\r\nValentine, as that of the most upright and honorable merchant of the\r\ncity; I say our country, because you were born not far from\r\nMarseilles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t speak of Marseilles, I beg of you, Maximilian; that one word\r\nbrings back my mother to my recollection\xe2\x80\x94my angel mother, who died too\r\nsoon for myself and all who knew her; but who, after watching over her\r\nchild during the brief period allotted to her in this world, now, I\r\nfondly hope, watches from her home in heaven. Oh, if my mother were\r\nstill living, there would be nothing to fear, Maximilian, for I would\r\ntell her that I loved you, and she would protect us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fear, Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the lover, \xe2\x80\x9cthat were she living I should\r\nnever have had the happiness of knowing you; you would then have been\r\ntoo happy to have stooped from your grandeur to bestow a thought on\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow it is you who are unjust, Maximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cbut there\r\nis one thing I wish to know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is that?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the young man, perceiving that Valentine\r\nhesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me truly, Maximilian, whether in former days, when our fathers\r\ndwelt at Marseilles, there was ever any misunderstanding between them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot that I am aware of,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cunless, indeed, any\r\nill-feeling might have arisen from their being of opposite parties\xe2\x80\x94your\r\nfather was, as you know, a zealous partisan of the Bourbons, while mine\r\nwas wholly devoted to the emperor; there could not possibly be any\r\nother difference between them. But why do you ask?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young girl, \xe2\x80\x9cfor it is but right you\r\nshould know. Well, on the day when your appointment as an officer of\r\nthe Legion of Honor was announced in the papers, we were all sitting\r\nwith my grandfather, M. Noirtier; M. Danglars was there also\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nrecollect M. Danglars, do you not, Maximilian, the banker, whose horses\r\nran away with my mother-in-law and little brother, and very nearly\r\nkilled them? While the rest of the company were discussing the\r\napproaching marriage of Mademoiselle Danglars, I was reading the paper\r\nto my grandfather; but when I came to the paragraph about you, although\r\nI had done nothing else but read it over to myself all the morning (you\r\nknow you had told me all about it the previous evening), I felt so\r\nhappy, and yet so nervous, at the idea of speaking your name aloud, and\r\nbefore so many people, that I really think I should have passed it\r\nover, but for the fear that my doing so might create suspicions as to\r\nthe cause of my silence; so I summoned up all my courage, and read it\r\nas firmly and as steadily as I could.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30059m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Valentine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, would you believe it? directly my father caught the sound of\r\nyour name he turned round quite hastily, and, like a poor silly thing,\r\nI was so persuaded that everyone must be as much affected as myself by\r\nthe utterance of your name, that I was not surprised to see my father\r\nstart, and almost tremble; but I even thought (though that surely must\r\nhave been a mistake) that M. Danglars trembled too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Morrel, Morrel,\xe2\x80\x99 cried my father, \xe2\x80\x98stop a bit;\xe2\x80\x99 then knitting his\r\nbrows into a deep frown, he added, \xe2\x80\x98surely this cannot be one of the\r\nMorrel family who lived at Marseilles, and gave us so much trouble from\r\ntheir violent Bonapartism\xe2\x80\x94I mean about the year 1815.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 replied M. Though it\r\ncertainly does cost France somewhat dear to assert her rights in that\r\nuncivilized country.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrutal politics, I must confess.\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian; \xe2\x80\x9cbut don\xe2\x80\x99t attach\r\nany serious importance, dear, to what your father said. My father was\r\nnot a bit behind yours in that sort of talk. \xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98does not\r\nthe emperor, who has devised so many clever and efficient modes of\r\nimproving the art of war, organize a regiment of lawyers, judges and\r\nlegal practitioners, sending them in the hottest fire the enemy could\r\nmaintain, and using them to save better men?\xe2\x80\x99 You see, my dear, that\r\nfor picturesque expression and generosity of spirit there is not much\r\nto choose between the language of either party. But what did M.\r\nDanglars say to this outburst on the part of the procureur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he laughed, and in that singular manner so peculiar to\r\nhimself\xe2\x80\x94half-malicious, half-ferocious; he almost immediately got up\r\nand took his leave; then, for the first time, I observed the agitation\r\nof my grandfather, and I must tell you, Maximilian, that I am the only\r\nperson capable of discerning emotion in his paralyzed frame. And I\r\nsuspected that the conversation that had been carried on in his\r\npresence (for they always say and do what they like before the dear old\r\nman, without the smallest regard for his feelings) had made a strong\r\nimpression on his mind; for, naturally enough, it must have pained him\r\nto hear the emperor he so devotedly loved and served spoken of in that\r\ndepreciating manner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe name of M. Noirtier,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cis celebrated\r\nthroughout Europe; he was a statesman of high standing, and you may or\r\nmay not know, Valentine, that he took a leading part in every\r\nBonapartist conspiracy set on foot during the restoration of the\r\nBourbons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I have often heard whispers of things that seem to me most\r\nstrange\xe2\x80\x94the father a Bonapartist, the son a Royalist; what can have\r\nbeen the reason of so singular a difference in parties and politics?\r\nBut to resume my story; I turned towards my grandfather, as though to\r\nquestion him as to the cause of his emotion; he looked expressively at\r\nthe newspaper I had been reading. \xe2\x80\x98What is the matter, dear\r\ngrandfather?\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98are you pleased?\xe2\x80\x99 He gave me a sign in the\r\naffirmative. \xe2\x80\x98With what my father said just now?\xe2\x80\x99 He returned a sign in\r\nthe negative. \xe2\x80\x98Perhaps you liked what M. Danglars said?\xe2\x80\x99 Another sign\r\nin the negative. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, then, you were glad to hear that M. Morrel (I\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t dare to say Maximilian) had been made an officer of the Legion\r\nof Honor?\xe2\x80\x99 He signified assent; only think of the poor old man\xe2\x80\x99s being\r\nso pleased to think that you, who were a perfect stranger to him, had\r\nbeen made an officer of the Legion of Honor! Perhaps it was a mere whim\r\non his part, for he is falling, they say, into second childhood, but I\r\nlove him for showing so much interest in you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow singular,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Maximilian; \xe2\x80\x9cyour father hates me, while your\r\ngrandfather, on the contrary\xe2\x80\x94What strange feelings are aroused by\r\npolitics.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Valentine, suddenly; \xe2\x80\x9csomeone is coming!\xe2\x80\x9d Maximilian\r\nleaped at one bound into his crop of lucern, which he began to pull up\r\nin the most ruthless way, under the pretext of being occupied in\r\nweeding it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle, mademoiselle!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed a voice from behind the trees.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame is searching for you everywhere; there is a visitor in the\r\ndrawing-room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA visitor?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Valentine, much agitated; \xe2\x80\x9cwho is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome grand personage\xe2\x80\x94a prince I believe they said\xe2\x80\x94the Count of Monte\r\nCristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will come directly,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Valentine aloud.\r\n\r\nThe name of Monte Cristo sent an electric shock through the young man\r\non the other side of the iron gate, to whom Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s _\xe2\x80\x9cI am coming\xe2\x80\x9d_\r\nwas the customary signal of farewell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, leaning on the handle of his spade, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwould give a good deal to know how it comes about that the Count of\r\nMonte Cristo is acquainted with M. de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 52. Toxicology\r\n\r\nIt was really the Count of Monte Cristo who had just arrived at Madame\r\nde Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s for the purpose of returning the procureur\xe2\x80\x99s visit, and\r\nat his name, as may be easily imagined, the whole house was in\r\nconfusion.\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort, who was alone in her drawing-room when the count\r\nwas announced, desired that her son might be brought thither instantly\r\nto renew his thanks to the count; and Edward, who heard this great\r\npersonage talked of for two whole days, made all possible haste to come\r\nto him, not from obedience to his mother, or out of any feeling of\r\ngratitude to the count, but from sheer curiosity, and that some chance\r\nremark might give him the opportunity for making one of the impertinent\r\nspeeches which made his mother say:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that naughty child! But I can\xe2\x80\x99t be severe with him, he is really\r\n_so_ bright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter the usual civilities, the count inquired after M. de Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy husband dines with the chancellor,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young lady; \xe2\x80\x9che has\r\njust gone, and I am sure he\xe2\x80\x99ll be exceedingly sorry not to have had the\r\npleasure of seeing you before he went.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTwo visitors who were there when the count arrived, having gazed at him\r\nwith all their eyes, retired after that reasonable delay which\r\npoliteness admits and curiosity requires.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your sister Valentine doing?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Madame de Villefort of\r\nEdward; \xe2\x80\x9ctell someone to bid her come here, that I may have the honor\r\nof introducing her to the count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a daughter, then, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the count; \xe2\x80\x9cvery young, I\r\npresume?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe daughter of M. de Villefort by his first marriage,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\nyoung wife, \xe2\x80\x9ca fine well-grown girl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut melancholy,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Master Edward, snatching the feathers out\r\nof the tail of a splendid paroquet that was screaming on its gilded\r\nperch, in order to make a plume for his hat.\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort merely cried, \xe2\x80\x9cBe still, Edward!\xe2\x80\x9d She then added,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis young madcap is, however, very nearly right, and merely re-echoes\r\nwhat he has heard me say with pain a hundred times; for Mademoiselle de\r\nVillefort is, in spite of all we can do to rouse her, of a melancholy\r\ndisposition and taciturn habit, which frequently injure the effect of\r\nher beauty. But what detains her? Go, Edward, and see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause they are looking for her where she is not to be found.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where are they looking for her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith grandpapa Noirtier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you think she is not there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, no, no, no, she is not there,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Edward, singing his\r\nwords.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where is she, then? If you know, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you tell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is under the big chestnut-tree,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the spoiled brat, as he\r\ngave, in spite of his mother\xe2\x80\x99s commands, live flies to the parrot,\r\nwhich seemed keenly to relish such fare.\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort stretched out her hand to ring, intending to direct\r\nher waiting-maid to the spot where she would find Valentine, when the\r\nyoung lady herself entered the apartment. She appeared much dejected;\r\nand any person who considered her attentively might have observed the\r\ntraces of recent tears in her eyes.\r\n\r\nValentine, whom we have in the rapid march of our narrative presented\r\nto our readers without formally introducing her, was a tall and\r\ngraceful girl of nineteen, with bright chestnut hair, deep blue eyes,\r\nand that reposeful air of quiet distinction which characterized her\r\nmother. Her white and slender fingers, her pearly neck, her cheeks\r\ntinted with varying hues reminded one of the lovely Englishwomen who\r\nhave been so poetically compared in their manner to the gracefulness of\r\na swan.\r\n\r\nShe entered the apartment, and seeing near her stepmother the stranger\r\nof whom she had already heard so much, saluted him without any girlish\r\nawkwardness, or even lowering her eyes, and with an elegance that\r\nredoubled the count\xe2\x80\x99s attention.\r\n\r\nHe rose to return the salutation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle de Villefort, my step-daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort\r\nto Monte Cristo, leaning back on her sofa and motioning towards\r\nValentine with her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd M. de Monte Cristo, King of China, Emperor of Cochin-China,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe young imp, looking slyly towards his sister.\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort at this really did turn pale, and was very nearly\r\nangry with this household plague, who answered to the name of Edward;\r\nbut the count, on the contrary, smiled, and appeared to look at the boy\r\ncomplacently, which caused the maternal heart to bound again with joy\r\nand enthusiasm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, continuing the conversation, and\r\nlooking by turns at Madame de Villefort and Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9chave I not\r\nalready had the honor of meeting yourself and mademoiselle before? I\r\ncould not help thinking so just now; the idea came over my mind, and as\r\nmademoiselle entered the sight of her was an additional ray of light\r\nthrown on a confused remembrance; excuse the remark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think it likely, sir; Mademoiselle de Villefort is not very\r\nfond of society, and we very seldom go out,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it was not in society that I met with mademoiselle or yourself,\r\nmadame, or this charming little merry boy. Besides, the Parisian world\r\nis entirely unknown to me, for, as I believe I told you, I have been in\r\nParis but very few days. No,\xe2\x80\x94but, perhaps, you will permit me to call\r\nto mind\xe2\x80\x94stay!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Count placed his hand on his brow as if to collect his thoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94it was somewhere\xe2\x80\x94away from here\xe2\x80\x94it was\xe2\x80\x94I do not know\xe2\x80\x94but it appears\r\nthat this recollection is connected with a lovely sky and some\r\nreligious _f\xc3\xaate_; mademoiselle was holding flowers in her hand, the\r\ninteresting boy was chasing a beautiful peacock in a garden, and you,\r\nmadame, were under the trellis of some arbor. Pray come to my aid,\r\nmadame; do not these circumstances appeal to your memory?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame de Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cand yet it appears to me,\r\nsir, that if I had met you anywhere, the recollection of you must have\r\nbeen imprinted on my memory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps the count saw us in Italy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine timidly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, in Italy; it was in Italy most probably,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou have travelled then in Italy, mademoiselle?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; madame and I were there two years ago. The doctors, anxious for\r\nmy lungs, had prescribed the air of Naples. We went by Bologna,\r\nPerugia, and Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes\xe2\x80\x94true, mademoiselle,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Monte Cristo as if this simple\r\nexplanation was sufficient to revive the recollection he sought. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\nwas at Perugia on Corpus Christi Day, in the garden of the H\xc3\xb4tel des\r\nPostes, when chance brought us together; you, Madame de Villefort, and\r\nher son; I now remember having had the honor of meeting you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI perfectly well remember Perugia, sir, and the H\xc3\xb4tel des Postes, and\r\nthe festival of which you speak,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cbut in\r\nvain do I tax my memory, of whose treachery I am ashamed, for I really\r\ndo not recall to mind that I ever had the pleasure of seeing you\r\nbefore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is strange, but neither do I recollect meeting with you,\xe2\x80\x9d observed\r\nValentine, raising her beautiful eyes to the count.\r\n\r\n30065m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I remember it perfectly,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed the darling Edward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will assist your memory, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the count; \xe2\x80\x9cthe day had\r\nbeen burning hot; you were waiting for horses, which were delayed in\r\nconsequence of the festival. Mademoiselle was walking in the shade of\r\nthe garden, and your son disappeared in pursuit of the peacock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I caught it, mamma, don\xe2\x80\x99t you remember?\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Edward, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\npulled three such beautiful feathers out of his tail.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, madame, remained under the arbor; do you not remember, that while\r\nyou were seated on a stone bench, and while, as I told you,\r\nMademoiselle de Villefort and your young son were absent, you conversed\r\nfor a considerable time with somebody?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, in truth, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the young lady, turning very red, \xe2\x80\x9cI do\r\nremember conversing with a person wrapped in a long woollen mantle; he\r\nwas a medical man, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely so, madame; this man was myself; for a fortnight I had been\r\nat that hotel, during which period I had cured my valet de chambre of a\r\nfever, and my landlord of the jaundice, so that I really acquired a\r\nreputation as a skilful physician. We discoursed a long time, madame,\r\non different subjects; of Perugino, of Raphael, of manners, customs, of\r\nthe famous _aqua Tofana_, of which they had told you, I think you said,\r\nthat certain individuals in Perugia had preserved the secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, true,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame de Villefort, somewhat uneasily, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nremember now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not recollect now all the various subjects of which we\r\ndiscoursed, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the count with perfect calmness; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I\r\nperfectly remember that, falling into the error which others had\r\nentertained respecting me, you consulted me as to the health of\r\nMademoiselle de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, really, sir, you were in fact a medical man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de\r\nVillefort, \xe2\x80\x9csince you had cured the sick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoli\xc3\xa8re or Beaumarchais would reply to you, madame, that it was\r\nprecisely because I was not, that I had cured my patients; for myself,\r\nI am content to say to you that I have studied chemistry and the\r\nnatural sciences somewhat deeply, but still only as an amateur, you\r\nunderstand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment the clock struck six.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is six o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, evidently agitated.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine, will you not go and see if your grandpapa will have his\r\ndinner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine rose, and saluting the count, left the apartment without\r\nspeaking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, when Valentine had left the room, \xe2\x80\x9cwas it\r\non my account that you sent Mademoiselle de Villefort away?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy no means,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young lady quickly; \xe2\x80\x9cbut this is the hour\r\nwhen we usually give M. Noirtier the unwelcome meal that sustains his\r\npitiful existence. You are aware, sir, of the deplorable condition of\r\nmy husband\xe2\x80\x99s father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, madame, M. de Villefort spoke of it to me\xe2\x80\x94a paralysis, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, yes; the poor old gentleman is entirely helpless; the mind alone\r\nis still active in this human machine, and that is faint and\r\nflickering, like the light of a lamp about to expire. But excuse me,\r\nsir, for talking of our domestic misfortunes; I interrupted you at the\r\nmoment when you were telling me that you were a skilful chemist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, madame, I did not say as much as that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count with a\r\nsmile; \xe2\x80\x9cquite the contrary. I have studied chemistry because, having\r\ndetermined to live in eastern climates I have been desirous of\r\nfollowing the example of King Mithridates.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Mithridates, rex Ponticus_,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young scamp, as he tore some\r\nbeautiful portraits out of a splendid album, \xe2\x80\x9cthe individual who took\r\ncream in his cup of poison every morning at breakfast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdward, you naughty boy,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Madame de Villefort, snatching the\r\nmutilated book from the urchin\xe2\x80\x99s grasp, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are positively past\r\nbearing; you really disturb the conversation; go, leave us, and join\r\nyour sister Valentine in dear grandpapa Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe album,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edward sulkily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x94the album!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want the album.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow dare you tear out the drawings?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it amuses me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo\xe2\x80\x94go at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t go unless you give me the album,\xe2\x80\x9d said the boy, seating\r\nhimself doggedly in an armchair, according to his habit of never giving\r\nway.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake it, then, and pray disturb us no longer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de\r\nVillefort, giving the album to Edward, who then went towards the door,\r\nled by his mother. The count followed her with his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us see if she shuts the door after him,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered.\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort closed the door carefully after the child, the\r\ncount appearing not to notice her; then casting a scrutinizing glance\r\naround the chamber, the young wife returned to her chair, in which she\r\nseated herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me to observe, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, with that kind tone he\r\ncould assume so well, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are really very severe with that dear clever\r\nchild.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sometimes severity is quite necessary,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame de\r\nVillefort, with all a mother\xe2\x80\x99s real firmness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was his Cornelius Nepos that Master Edward was repeating when he\r\nreferred to King Mithridates,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the count, \xe2\x80\x9cand you\r\ninterrupted him in a quotation which proves that his tutor has by no\r\nmeans neglected him, for your son is really advanced for his years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is, count,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the mother, agreeably flattered, \xe2\x80\x9che has\r\ngreat aptitude, and learns all that is set before him. He has but one\r\nfault, he is somewhat wilful; but really, on referring for the moment\r\nto what he said, do you truly believe that Mithridates used these\r\nprecautions, and that these precautions were efficacious?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so, madame, because I myself have made use of them, that I\r\nmight not be poisoned at Naples, at Palermo, and at Smyrna\xe2\x80\x94that is to\r\nsay, on three several occasions when, but for these precautions, I must\r\nhave lost my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd your precautions were successful?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCompletely so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I remember now your mentioning to me at Perugia something of this\r\nsort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count with an air of surprise, remarkably well\r\ncounterfeited; \xe2\x80\x9cI really did not remember.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI inquired of you if poisons acted equally, and with the same effect,\r\non men of the North as on men of the South; and you answered me that\r\nthe cold and sluggish habits of the North did not present the same\r\naptitude as the rich and energetic temperaments of the natives of the\r\nSouth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that is the case,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cI have seen Russians\r\ndevour, without being visibly inconvenienced, vegetable substances\r\nwhich would infallibly have killed a Neapolitan or an Arab.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you really believe the result would be still more sure with us\r\nthan in the East, and in the midst of our fogs and rains a man would\r\nhabituate himself more easily than in a warm latitude to this\r\nprogressive absorption of poison?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; it being at the same time perfectly understood that he\r\nshould have been duly fortified against the poison to which he had not\r\nbeen accustomed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I understand that; and how would you habituate yourself, for\r\ninstance, or rather, how did you habituate yourself to it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, very easily. Suppose you knew beforehand the poison that would be\r\nmade use of against you; suppose the poison was, for instance,\r\nbrucine\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrucine is extracted from the false angostura8 is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired\r\nMadame de Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I perceive I have not\r\nmuch to teach you. Allow me to compliment you on your knowledge; such\r\nlearning is very rare among ladies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I am aware of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I have a\r\npassion for the occult sciences, which speak to the imagination like\r\npoetry, and are reducible to figures, like an algebraic equation; but\r\ngo on, I beg of you; what you say interests me to the greatest degree.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30069m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9csuppose, then, that this poison was\r\nbrucine, and you were to take a milligramme the first day, two\r\nmilligrammes the second day, and so on. Well, at the end of ten days\r\nyou would have taken a centigramme, at the end of twenty days,\r\nincreasing another milligramme, you would have taken three hundred\r\ncentigrammes; that is to say, a dose which you would support without\r\ninconvenience, and which would be very dangerous for any other person\r\nwho had not taken the same precautions as yourself. Well, then, at the\r\nend of a month, when drinking water from the same carafe, you would\r\nkill the person who drank with you, without your perceiving, otherwise\r\nthan from slight inconvenience, that there was any poisonous substance\r\nmingled with this water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know any other counter-poisons?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have often read, and read again, the history of Mithridates,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMadame de Villefort in a tone of reflection, \xe2\x80\x9cand had always considered\r\nit a fable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, madame, contrary to most history, it is true; but what you tell\r\nme, madame, what you inquire of me, is not the result of a chance\r\nquery, for two years ago you asked me the same questions, and said\r\nthen, that for a very long time this history of Mithridates had\r\noccupied your mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, sir. The two favorite studies of my youth were botany and\r\nmineralogy, and subsequently, when I learned that the use of simples\r\nfrequently explained the whole history of a people, and the entire life\r\nof individuals in the East, as flowers betoken and symbolize a love\r\naffair, I have regretted that I was not a man, that I might have been a\r\nFlamel, a Fontana, or a Cabanis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the more, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cas the Orientals do not\r\nconfine themselves, as did Mithridates, to make a cuirass of his\r\npoisons, but they also made them a dagger. Science becomes, in their\r\nhands, not only a defensive weapon, but still more frequently an\r\noffensive one; the one serves against all their physical sufferings,\r\nthe other against all their enemies. With opium, belladonna, brucea,\r\nsnake-wood, and the cherry-laurel, they put to sleep all who stand in\r\ntheir way. There is not one of those women, Egyptian, Turkish, or\r\nGreek, whom here you call \xe2\x80\x98good women,\xe2\x80\x99 who do not know how, by means\r\nof chemistry, to stupefy a doctor, and in psychology to amaze a\r\nconfessor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, whose eyes sparkled with strange\r\nfire at this conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, indeed, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthe secret dramas\r\nof the East begin with a love philtre and end with a death potion\xe2\x80\x94begin\r\nwith paradise and end with\xe2\x80\x94hell. There are as many elixirs of every\r\nkind as there are caprices and peculiarities in the physical and moral\r\nnature of humanity; and I will say further\xe2\x80\x94the art of these chemists is\r\ncapable with the utmost precision to accommodate and proportion the\r\nremedy and the bane to yearnings for love or desires for vengeance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked the young woman, \xe2\x80\x9cthese Eastern societies, in the\r\nmidst of which you have passed a portion of your existence, are as\r\nfantastic as the tales that come from their strange land. A man can\r\neasily be put out of the way there, then; it is, indeed, the Bagdad and\r\nBassora of the _Thousand and One Nights_. The sultans and viziers who\r\nrule over society there, and who constitute what in France we call the\r\ngovernment, are really Haroun-al-Raschids and Giaffars, who not only\r\npardon a poisoner, but even make him a prime minister, if his crime has\r\nbeen an ingenious one, and who, under such circumstances, have the\r\nwhole story written in letters of gold, to divert their hours of\r\nidleness and _ennui_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy no means, madame; the fanciful exists no longer in the East. There,\r\ndisguised under other names, and concealed under other costumes, are\r\npolice agents, magistrates, attorneys-general, and bailiffs. They hang,\r\nbehead, and impale their criminals in the most agreeable possible\r\nmanner; but some of these, like clever rogues, have contrived to escape\r\nhuman justice, and succeed in their fraudulent enterprises by cunning\r\nstratagems. Amongst us a simpleton, possessed by the demon of hate or\r\ncupidity, who has an enemy to destroy, or some near relation to dispose\r\nof, goes straight to the grocer\xe2\x80\x99s or druggist\xe2\x80\x99s, gives a false name,\r\nwhich leads more easily to his detection than his real one, and under\r\nthe pretext that the rats prevent him from sleeping, purchases five or\r\nsix grammes of arsenic\xe2\x80\x94if he is really a cunning fellow, he goes to\r\nfive or six different druggists or grocers, and thereby becomes only\r\nfive or six times more easily traced;\xe2\x80\x94then, when he has acquired his\r\nspecific, he administers duly to his enemy, or near kinsman, a dose of\r\narsenic which would make a mammoth or mastodon burst, and which,\r\nwithout rhyme or reason, makes his victim utter groans which alarm the\r\nentire neighborhood. Then arrive a crowd of policemen and constables.\r\nThey fetch a doctor, who opens the dead body, and collects from the\r\nentrails and stomach a quantity of arsenic in a spoon. Next day a\r\nhundred newspapers relate the fact, with the names of the victim and\r\nthe murderer. The same evening the grocer or grocers, druggist or\r\ndruggists, come and say, \xe2\x80\x98It was I who sold the arsenic to the\r\ngentleman;\xe2\x80\x99 and rather than not recognize the guilty purchaser, they\r\nwill recognize twenty. Then the foolish criminal is taken, imprisoned,\r\ninterrogated, confronted, confounded, condemned, and cut off by hemp or\r\nsteel; or if she be a woman of any consideration, they lock her up for\r\nlife. This is the way in which you Northerns understand chemistry,\r\nmadame. Desrues was, however, I must confess, more skilful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady, laughing; \xe2\x80\x9cwe do what we\r\ncan. All the world has not the secret of the Medicis or the Borgias.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, shrugging his shoulders, \xe2\x80\x9cshall I tell you\r\nthe cause of all these stupidities? It is because, at your theatres, by\r\nwhat at least I could judge by reading the pieces they play, they see\r\npersons swallow the contents of a phial, or suck the button of a ring,\r\nand fall dead instantly. Five minutes afterwards the curtain falls, and\r\nthe spectators depart. They are ignorant of the consequences of the\r\nmurder; they see neither the police commissary with his badge of\r\noffice, nor the corporal with his four men; and so the poor fools\r\nbelieve that the whole thing is as easy as lying. But go a little way\r\nfrom France\xe2\x80\x94go either to Aleppo or Cairo, or only to Naples or Rome,\r\nand you will see people passing by you in the streets\xe2\x80\x94people erect,\r\nsmiling, and fresh-colored, of whom Asmodeus, if you were holding on by\r\nthe skirt of his mantle, would say, \xe2\x80\x98That man was poisoned three weeks\r\nago; he will be a dead man in a month.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthey have again discovered the\r\nsecret of the famous _aqua Tofana_ that they said was lost at Perugia.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, but madame, does mankind ever lose anything? The arts change about\r\nand make a tour of the world; things take a different name, and the\r\nvulgar do not follow them\xe2\x80\x94that is all; but there is always the same\r\nresult. Poisons act particularly on some organ or another\xe2\x80\x94one on the\r\nstomach, another on the brain, another on the intestines. Well, the\r\npoison brings on a cough, the cough an inflammation of the lungs, or\r\nsome other complaint catalogued in the book of science, which, however,\r\nby no means precludes it from being decidedly mortal; and if it were\r\nnot, would be sure to become so, thanks to the remedies applied by\r\nfoolish doctors, who are generally bad chemists, and which will act in\r\nfavor of or against the malady, as you please; and then there is a\r\nhuman being killed according to all the rules of art and skill, and of\r\nwhom justice learns nothing, as was said by a terrible chemist of my\r\nacquaintance, the worthy Abb\xc3\xa9 Adelmonte of Taormina, in Sicily, who has\r\nstudied these national phenomena very profoundly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is quite frightful, but deeply interesting,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young lady,\r\nmotionless with attention. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought, I must confess, that these\r\ntales, were inventions of the Middle Ages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, no doubt, but improved upon by ours. What is the use of time,\r\nrewards of merit, medals, crosses, Monthyon prizes, if they do not lead\r\nsociety towards more complete perfection? Yet man will never be perfect\r\nuntil he learns to create and destroy; he does know how to destroy, and\r\nthat is half the battle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo,\xe2\x80\x9d added Madame de Villefort, constantly returning to her object,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe poisons of the Borgias, the Medicis, the Ren\xc3\xa9es, the Ruggieris,\r\nand later, probably, that of Baron de Trenck, whose story has been so\r\nmisused by modern drama and romance\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere objects of art, madame, and nothing more,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count. \xe2\x80\x9cDo\r\nyou suppose that the real _savant_ addresses himself stupidly to the\r\nmere individual? By no means. Science loves eccentricities, leaps and\r\nbounds, trials of strength, fancies, if I may be allowed so to term\r\nthem. Thus, for instance, the excellent Abb\xc3\xa9 Adelmonte, of whom I spoke\r\njust now, made in this way some marvellous experiments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I will mention one to you. He had a remarkably fine garden, full\r\nof vegetables, flowers, and fruit. From amongst these vegetables he\r\nselected the most simple\xe2\x80\x94a cabbage, for instance. For three days he\r\nwatered this cabbage with a distillation of arsenic; on the third, the\r\ncabbage began to droop and turn yellow. At that moment he cut it. In\r\nthe eyes of everybody it seemed fit for table, and preserved its\r\nwholesome appearance. It was only poisoned to the Abb\xc3\xa9 Adelmonte. He\r\nthen took the cabbage to the room where he had rabbits\xe2\x80\x94for the Abb\xc3\xa9\r\nAdelmonte had a collection of rabbits, cats, and guinea-pigs, fully as\r\nfine as his collection of vegetables, flowers, and fruit. Well, the\r\nAbb\xc3\xa9 Adelmonte took a rabbit, and made it eat a leaf of the cabbage.\r\nThe rabbit died. What magistrate would find, or even venture to\r\ninsinuate, anything against this? What procureur has ever ventured to\r\ndraw up an accusation against M. Magendie or M. Flourens, in\r\nconsequence of the rabbits, cats, and guinea-pigs they have killed?\xe2\x80\x94not\r\none. So, then, the rabbit dies, and justice takes no notice. This\r\nrabbit dead, the Abb\xc3\xa9 Adelmonte has its entrails taken out by his cook\r\nand thrown on the dunghill; on this dunghill is a hen, who, pecking\r\nthese intestines, is in her turn taken ill, and dies next day. At the\r\nmoment when she is struggling in the convulsions of death, a vulture is\r\nflying by (there are a good many vultures in Adelmonte\xe2\x80\x99s country); this\r\nbird darts on the dead fowl, and carries it away to a rock, where it\r\ndines off its prey. Three days afterwards, this poor vulture, which has\r\nbeen very much indisposed since that dinner, suddenly feels very giddy\r\nwhile flying aloft in the clouds, and falls heavily into a fish-pond.\r\nThe pike, eels, and carp eat greedily always, as everybody knows\xe2\x80\x94well,\r\nthey feast on the vulture. Now suppose that next day, one of these\r\neels, or pike, or carp, poisoned at the fourth remove, is served up at\r\nyour table. Well, then, your guest will be poisoned at the fifth\r\nremove, and die, at the end of eight or ten days, of pains in the\r\nintestines, sickness, or abscess of the pylorus. The doctors open the\r\nbody and say with an air of profound learning, \xe2\x80\x98The subject has died of\r\na tumor on the liver, or of typhoid fever!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9call these circumstances which you\r\nlink thus to one another may be broken by the least accident; the\r\nvulture may not see the fowl, or may fall a hundred yards from the\r\nfish-pond.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that is where the art comes in. To be a great chemist in the East,\r\none must direct chance; and this is to be achieved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort was in deep thought, yet listened attentively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, suddenly, \xe2\x80\x9carsenic is indelible, indestructible;\r\nin whatsoever way it is absorbed, it will be found again in the body of\r\nthe victim from the moment when it has been taken in sufficient\r\nquantity to cause death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely so,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cprecisely so; and this is what I\r\nsaid to my worthy Adelmonte. He reflected, smiled, and replied to me by\r\na Sicilian proverb, which I believe is also a French proverb, \xe2\x80\x98My son,\r\nthe world was not made in a day\xe2\x80\x94but in seven. Return on Sunday.\xe2\x80\x99 On the\r\nSunday following I did return to him. Instead of having watered his\r\ncabbage with arsenic, he had watered it this time with a solution of\r\nsalts, having their basis in strychnine, _strychnos colubrina_, as the\r\nlearned term it. Now, the cabbage had not the slightest appearance of\r\ndisease in the world, and the rabbit had not the smallest distrust;\r\nyet, five minutes afterwards, the rabbit was dead. The fowl pecked at\r\nthe rabbit, and the next day was a dead hen. This time we were the\r\nvultures; so we opened the bird, and this time all special symptoms had\r\ndisappeared, there were only general symptoms. There was no peculiar\r\nindication in any organ\xe2\x80\x94an excitement of the nervous system\xe2\x80\x94that was\r\nit; a case of cerebral congestion\xe2\x80\x94nothing more. The fowl had not been\r\npoisoned\xe2\x80\x94she had died of apoplexy. Apoplexy is a rare disease among\r\nfowls, I believe, but very common among men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort appeared more and more thoughtful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very fortunate,\xe2\x80\x9d she observed, \xe2\x80\x9cthat such substances could only\r\nbe prepared by chemists; otherwise, all the world would be poisoning\r\neach other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy chemists and persons who have a taste for chemistry,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte\r\nCristo carelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, endeavoring by a struggle, and\r\nwith effort, to get away from her thoughts, \xe2\x80\x9chowever skilfully it is\r\nprepared, crime is always crime, and if it avoid human scrutiny, it\r\ndoes not escape the eye of God. The Orientals are stronger than we are\r\nin cases of conscience, and, very prudently, have no hell\xe2\x80\x94that is the\r\npoint.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30075m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, madame, this is a scruple which naturally must occur to a pure\r\nmind like yours, but which would easily yield before sound reasoning.\r\nThe bad side of human thought will always be defined by the paradox of\r\nJean Jacques Rousseau,\xe2\x80\x94you remember,\xe2\x80\x94the mandarin who is killed five\r\nhundred leagues off by raising the tip of the finger. Man\xe2\x80\x99s whole life\r\npasses in doing these things, and his intellect is exhausted by\r\nreflecting on them. You will find very few persons who will go and\r\nbrutally thrust a knife in the heart of a fellow-creature, or will\r\nadminister to him, in order to remove him from the surface of the globe\r\non which we move with life and animation, that quantity of arsenic of\r\nwhich we just now talked. Such a thing is really out of rule\xe2\x80\x94eccentric\r\nor stupid. To attain such a point, the blood must be heated to\r\nthirty-six degrees, the pulse be, at least, at ninety, and the feelings\r\nexcited beyond the ordinary limit. But suppose one pass, as is\r\npermissible in philology, from the word itself to its softened synonym,\r\nthen, instead of committing an ignoble assassination you make an\r\n\xe2\x80\x98elimination;\xe2\x80\x99 you merely and simply remove from your path the\r\nindividual who is in your way, and that without shock or violence,\r\nwithout the display of the sufferings which, in the case of becoming a\r\npunishment, make a martyr of the victim, and a butcher, in every sense\r\nof the word, of him who inflicts them. Then there will be no blood, no\r\ngroans, no convulsions, and above all, no consciousness of that horrid\r\nand compromising moment of accomplishing the act,\xe2\x80\x94then one escapes the\r\nclutch of the human law, which says, \xe2\x80\x98Do not disturb society!\xe2\x80\x99 This is\r\nthe mode in which they manage these things, and succeed in Eastern\r\nclimes, where there are grave and phlegmatic persons who care very\r\nlittle for the questions of time in conjunctures of importance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet conscience remains,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Madame de Villefort in an agitated\r\nvoice, and with a stifled sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9chappily, yes, conscience does remain; and\r\nif it did not, how wretched we should be! After every action requiring\r\nexertion, it is conscience that saves us, for it supplies us with a\r\nthousand good excuses, of which we alone are judges; and these reasons,\r\nhowsoever excellent in producing sleep, would avail us but very little\r\nbefore a tribunal, when we were tried for our lives. Thus Richard III.,\r\nfor instance, was marvellously served by his conscience after the\r\nputting away of the two children of Edward IV.; in fact, he could say,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98These two children of a cruel and persecuting king, who have inherited\r\nthe vices of their father, which I alone could perceive in their\r\njuvenile propensities\xe2\x80\x94these two children are impediments in my way of\r\npromoting the happiness of the English people, whose unhappiness they\r\n(the children) would infallibly have caused.\xe2\x80\x99 Thus was Lady Macbeth\r\nserved by her conscience, when she sought to give her son, and not her\r\nhusband (whatever Shakespeare may say), a throne. Ah, maternal love is\r\na great virtue, a powerful motive\xe2\x80\x94so powerful that it excuses a\r\nmultitude of things, even if, after Duncan\xe2\x80\x99s death, Lady Macbeth had\r\nbeen at all pricked by her conscience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort listened with avidity to these appalling maxims and\r\nhorrible paradoxes, delivered by the count with that ironical\r\nsimplicity which was peculiar to him.\r\n\r\nAfter a moment\xe2\x80\x99s silence, the lady inquired:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, my dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you are a very terrible\r\nreasoner, and that you look at the world through a somewhat distempered\r\nmedium? Have you really measured the world by scrutinies, or through\r\nalembics and crucibles? For you must indeed be a great chemist, and the\r\nelixir you administered to my son, which recalled him to life almost\r\ninstantaneously\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30077m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do not place any reliance on that, madame; _one_ drop of that\r\nelixir sufficed to recall life to a dying child, but three drops would\r\nhave impelled the blood into his lungs in such a way as to have\r\nproduced most violent palpitations; six would have suspended his\r\nrespiration, and caused syncope more serious than that in which he was;\r\nten would have destroyed him. You know, madame, how suddenly I snatched\r\nhim from those phials which he so imprudently touched?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it then so terrible a poison?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no! In the first place, let us agree that the word poison does not\r\nexist, because in medicine use is made of the most violent poisons,\r\nwhich become, according as they are employed, most salutary remedies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, then, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA skilful preparation of my friend\xe2\x80\x99s the worthy Abb\xc3\xa9 Adelmonte, who\r\ntaught me the use of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cit must be an admirable\r\nanti-spasmodic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfect, madame, as you have seen,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count; \xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\nfrequently make use of it\xe2\x80\x94with all possible prudence though, be it\r\nobserved,\xe2\x80\x9d he added with a smile of intelligence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost assuredly,\xe2\x80\x9d responded Madame de Villefort in the same tone. \xe2\x80\x9cAs\r\nfor me, so nervous, and so subject to fainting fits, I should require a\r\nDoctor Adelmonte to invent for me some means of breathing freely and\r\ntranquillizing my mind, in the fear I have of dying some fine day of\r\nsuffocation. In the meanwhile, as the thing is difficult to find in\r\nFrance, and your abb\xc3\xa9 is not probably disposed to make a journey to\r\nParis on my account, I must continue to use Monsieur Planche\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nanti-spasmodics; and mint and Hoffman\xe2\x80\x99s drops are among my favorite\r\nremedies. Here are some lozenges which I have made up on purpose; they\r\nare compounded doubly strong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo opened the tortoise-shell box, which the lady presented to\r\nhim, and inhaled the odor of the lozenges with the air of an amateur\r\nwho thoroughly appreciated their composition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are indeed exquisite,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cbut as they are necessarily\r\nsubmitted to the process of deglutition\xe2\x80\x94a function which it is\r\nfrequently impossible for a fainting person to accomplish\xe2\x80\x94I prefer my\r\nown specific.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUndoubtedly, and so should I prefer it, after the effects I have seen\r\nproduced; but of course it is a secret, and I am not so indiscreet as\r\nto ask it of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, rising as he spoke\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI am gallant enough to\r\noffer it you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30079m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow kind you are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly remember one thing\xe2\x80\x94a small dose is a remedy, a large one is\r\npoison. One drop will restore life, as you have seen; five or six will\r\ninevitably kill, and in a way the more terrible inasmuch as, poured\r\ninto a glass of wine, it would not in the slightest degree affect its\r\nflavor. But I say no more, madame; it is really as if I were\r\nprescribing for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe clock struck half-past six, and a lady was announced, a friend of\r\nMadame de Villefort, who came to dine with her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I had had the honor of seeing you for the third or fourth time,\r\ncount, instead of only for the second,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cif I\r\nhad had the honor of being your friend, instead of only having the\r\nhappiness of being under an obligation to you, I should insist on\r\ndetaining you to dinner, and not allow myself to be daunted by a first\r\nrefusal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA thousand thanks, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cbut I have an\r\nengagement which I cannot break. I have promised to escort to the\r\nAcad\xc3\xa9mie a Greek princess of my acquaintance who has never seen your\r\ngrand opera, and who relies on me to conduct her thither.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, then, sir, and do not forget the prescription.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, in truth, madame, to do that I must forget the hour\xe2\x80\x99s conversation\r\nI have had with you, which is indeed impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo bowed, and left the house. Madame de Villefort remained\r\nimmersed in thought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a very strange man,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cand in my opinion is himself the\r\nAdelmonte he talks about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs to Monte Cristo the result had surpassed his utmost expectations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as he went away; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is a fruitful soil, and I feel\r\ncertain that the seed sown will not be cast on barren ground.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNext morning, faithful to his promise, he sent the prescription\r\nrequested.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 53. Robert le Diable\r\n\r\nThe pretext of an opera engagement was so much the more feasible, as\r\nthere chanced to be on that very night a more than ordinary attraction\r\nat the Acad\xc3\xa9mie Royale. Levasseur, who had been suffering under severe\r\nillness, made his reappearance in the character of _Bertram_, and, as\r\nusual, the announcement of the most admired production of the favorite\r\ncomposer of the day had attracted a brilliant and fashionable audience.\r\nMorcerf, like most other young men of rank and fortune, had his\r\norchestra stall, with the certainty of always finding a seat in at\r\nleast a dozen of the principal boxes occupied by persons of his\r\nacquaintance; he had, moreover, his right of entry into the omnibus\r\nbox. Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud rented a stall beside his own, while Beauchamp, as\r\na journalist, had unlimited range all over the theatre. It happened\r\nthat on this particular night the minister\xe2\x80\x99s box was placed at the\r\ndisposal of Lucien Debray, who offered it to the Comte de Morcerf, who\r\nagain, upon his rejection of it by Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, sent it to Danglars, with\r\nan intimation that he should probably do himself the honor of joining\r\nthe baroness and her daughter during the evening, in the event of their\r\naccepting the box in question. The ladies received the offer with too\r\nmuch pleasure to dream of a refusal. To no class of persons is the\r\npresentation of a gratuitous opera-box more acceptable than to the\r\nwealthy millionaire, who still hugs economy while boasting of carrying\r\na king\xe2\x80\x99s ransom in his waistcoat pocket.\r\n\r\nDanglars had, however, protested against showing himself in a\r\nministerial box, declaring that his political principles, and his\r\nparliamentary position as member of the opposition party would not\r\npermit him so to commit himself; the baroness had, therefore,\r\ndespatched a note to Lucien Debray, bidding him call for them, it being\r\nwholly impossible for her to go alone with Eug\xc3\xa9nie to the opera.\r\n\r\nThere is no gainsaying the fact that a very unfavorable construction\r\nwould have been put upon the circumstance if the two women had gone\r\nwithout escort, while the addition of a third, in the person of her\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s admitted lover, enabled Mademoiselle Danglars to defy malice\r\nand ill-nature. One must take the world as one finds it.\r\n\r\n30083m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe curtain rose, as usual, to an almost empty house, it being one of\r\nthe absurdities of Parisian fashion never to appear at the opera until\r\nafter the beginning of the performance, so that the first act is\r\ngenerally played without the slightest attention being paid to it, that\r\npart of the audience already assembled being too much occupied in\r\nobserving the fresh arrivals, while nothing is heard but the noise of\r\nopening and shutting doors, and the buzz of conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, as the door of a box on the first circle opened,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat must be the Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who is the Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a question! Now, do you know, baron, I have a great mind to pick\r\na quarrel with you for asking it; as if all the world did not know who\r\nthe Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, to be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9cthe lovely Venetian, is it\r\nnot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHerself.\xe2\x80\x9d At this moment the countess perceived Albert, and returned\r\nhis salutation with a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know her, it seems?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFranz introduced me to her at Rome,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, will you do as much for me in Paris as Franz did for you\r\nin Rome?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith pleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a cry of \xe2\x80\x9cShut up!\xe2\x80\x9d from the audience. This manifestation on\r\nthe part of the spectators of their wish to be allowed to hear the\r\nmusic, produced not the slightest effect on the two young men, who\r\ncontinued their conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe countess was present at the races in the Champ-de-Mars,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless me, I quite forgot the races. Did you bet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, merely a paltry fifty louis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who was the winner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNautilus. I staked on him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut there were three races, were there not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; there was the prize given by the Jockey Club\xe2\x80\x94a gold cup, you\r\nknow\xe2\x80\x94and a very singular circumstance occurred about that race.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, shut up!\xe2\x80\x9d again interposed some of the audience.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it was won by a horse and rider utterly unknown on the course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that possible?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue as day. The fact was, nobody had observed a horse entered by the\r\nname of Vampa, or that of a jockey styled Job, when, at the last\r\nmoment, a splendid roan, mounted by a jockey about as big as your fist,\r\npresented themselves at the starting-post. They were obliged to stuff\r\nat least twenty pounds weight of shot in the small rider\xe2\x80\x99s pockets, to\r\nmake him weight; but with all that he outstripped Ariel and Barbare,\r\nagainst whom he ran, by at least three whole lengths.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd was it not found out at last to whom the horse and jockey\r\nbelonged?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say that the horse was entered under the name of Vampa?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly; that was the title.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI am better informed than you are, and know\r\nwho the owner of that horse was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShut up, there!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the pit in chorus. And this time the tone and\r\nmanner in which the command was given, betokened such growing hostility\r\nthat the two young men perceived, for the first time, that the mandate\r\nwas addressed to them. Leisurely turning round, they calmly scrutinized\r\nthe various countenances around them, as though demanding some one\r\nperson who would take upon himself the responsibility of what they\r\ndeemed excessive impertinence; but as no one responded to the\r\nchallenge, the friends turned again to the front of the theatre, and\r\naffected to busy themselves with the stage. At this moment the door of\r\nthe minister\xe2\x80\x99s box opened, and Madame Danglars, accompanied by her\r\ndaughter, entered, escorted by Lucien Debray, who assiduously conducted\r\nthem to their seats.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9chere come some friends of yours,\r\nviscount! What are you looking at there? don\xe2\x80\x99t you see they are trying\r\nto catch your eye?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert turned round, just in time to receive a gracious wave of the fan\r\nfrom the baroness; as for Mademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie, she scarcely vouchsafed\r\nto waste the glances of her large black eyes even upon the business of\r\nthe stage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you what, my dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot\r\nimagine what objection you can possibly have to Mademoiselle\r\nDanglars\xe2\x80\x94that is, setting aside her want of ancestry and somewhat\r\ninferior rank, which by the way I don\xe2\x80\x99t think you care very much about.\r\nNow, barring all that, I mean to say she is a deuced fine girl!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHandsome, certainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cbut not to my taste, which I\r\nconfess, inclines to something softer, gentler, and more feminine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, well,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, who because he had seen his\r\nthirtieth summer fancied himself duly warranted in assuming a sort of\r\npaternal air with his more youthful friend, \xe2\x80\x9cyou young people are never\r\nsatisfied; why, what would you have more? your parents have chosen you\r\na bride built on the model of Diana, the huntress, and yet you are not\r\ncontent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, for that very resemblance affrights me; I should have liked\r\nsomething more in the manner of the Venus of Milo or Capua; but this\r\nchase-loving Diana, continually surrounded by her nymphs, gives me a\r\nsort of alarm lest she should some day bring on me the fate of Act\xc3\xa6on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, indeed, it required but one glance at Mademoiselle Danglars to\r\ncomprehend the justness of Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s remark. She was beautiful, but her\r\nbeauty was of too marked and decided a character to please a fastidious\r\ntaste; her hair was raven black, but its natural waves seemed somewhat\r\nrebellious; her eyes, of the same color as her hair, were surmounted by\r\nwell-arched brows, whose great defect, however, consisted in an almost\r\nhabitual frown, while her whole physiognomy wore that expression of\r\nfirmness and decision so little in accordance with the gentler\r\nattributes of her sex\xe2\x80\x94her nose was precisely what a sculptor would have\r\nchosen for a chiselled Juno. Her mouth, which might have been found\r\nfault with as too large, displayed teeth of pearly whiteness, rendered\r\nstill more conspicuous by the brilliant carmine of her lips,\r\ncontrasting vividly with her naturally pale complexion. But that which\r\ncompleted the almost masculine look Morcerf found so little to his\r\ntaste, was a dark mole, of much larger dimensions than these freaks of\r\nnature generally are, placed just at the corner of her mouth; and the\r\neffect tended to increase the expression of self-dependence that\r\ncharacterized her countenance.\r\n\r\nThe rest of Mademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie\xe2\x80\x99s person was in perfect keeping with\r\nthe head just described; she, indeed, reminded one of Diana, as\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud observed, but her bearing was more haughty and resolute.\r\n\r\nAs regarded her attainments, the only fault to be found with them was\r\nthe same that a fastidious connoisseur might have found with her\r\nbeauty, that they were somewhat too erudite and masculine for so young\r\na person. She was a perfect linguist, a first-rate artist, wrote\r\npoetry, and composed music; to the study of the latter she professed to\r\nbe entirely devoted, following it with an indefatigable perseverance,\r\nassisted by a schoolfellow,\xe2\x80\x94a young woman without fortune whose talent\r\npromised to develop into remarkable powers as a singer. It was rumored\r\nthat she was an object of almost paternal interest to one of the\r\nprincipal composers of the day, who excited her to spare no pains in\r\nthe cultivation of her voice, which might hereafter prove a source of\r\nwealth and independence. But this counsel effectually decided\r\nMademoiselle Danglars never to commit herself by being seen in public\r\nwith one destined for a theatrical life; and acting upon this\r\nprinciple, the banker\xe2\x80\x99s daughter, though perfectly willing to allow\r\nMademoiselle Louise d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly (that was the name of the young virtuosa)\r\nto practice with her through the day, took especial care not to be seen\r\nin her company. Still, though not actually received at the H\xc3\xb4tel\r\nDanglars in the light of an acknowledged friend, Louise was treated\r\nwith far more kindness and consideration than is usually bestowed on a\r\ngoverness.\r\n\r\nThe curtain fell almost immediately after the entrance of Madame\r\nDanglars into her box, the band quitted the orchestra for the\r\naccustomed half-hour\xe2\x80\x99s interval allowed between the acts, and the\r\naudience were left at liberty to promenade the salon or lobbies, or to\r\npay and receive visits in their respective boxes.\r\n\r\nMorcerf and Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud were amongst the first to avail themselves\r\nof this permission. For an instant the idea struck Madame Danglars that\r\nthis eagerness on the part of the young viscount arose from his\r\nimpatience to join her party, and she whispered her expectations to her\r\ndaughter, that Albert was hurrying to pay his respects to them.\r\nMademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie, however, merely returned a dissenting movement of\r\nthe head, while, with a cold smile, she directed the attention of her\r\nmother to an opposite box on the first circle, in which sat the\r\nCountess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, and where Morcerf had just made his appearance.\r\n\r\n30087m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo we meet again, my travelling friend, do we?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the countess,\r\nextending her hand to him with all the warmth and cordiality of an old\r\nacquaintance; \xe2\x80\x9cit was really very good of you to recognize me so\r\nquickly, and still more so to bestow your first visit on me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe assured,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat if I had been aware of your arrival\r\nin Paris, and had known your address, I should have paid my respects to\r\nyou before this. Allow me to introduce my friend, Baron de\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, one of the few true gentlemen now to be found in\r\nFrance, and from whom I have just learned that you were a spectator of\r\nthe races in the Champ-de-Mars, yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud bowed to the countess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you were at the races, baron?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the countess eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, madame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Madame G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 with considerable animation, \xe2\x80\x9cyou can\r\nprobably tell me who won the Jockey Club stakes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry to say I cannot,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the baron; \xe2\x80\x9cand I was just asking\r\nthe same question of Albert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you very anxious to know, countess?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo know what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe name of the owner of the winning horse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcessively; only imagine\xe2\x80\x94but do tell me, viscount, whether you really\r\nare acquainted with it or no?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, madame, but you were about to relate some story,\r\nwere you not? You said, \xe2\x80\x98only imagine,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94and then paused. Pray\r\ncontinue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, listen. You must know I felt so interested in the splendid\r\nroan horse, with his elegant little rider, so tastefully dressed in a\r\npink satin jacket and cap, that I could not help praying for their\r\nsuccess with as much earnestness as though the half of my fortune were\r\nat stake; and when I saw them outstrip all the others, and come to the\r\nwinning-post in such gallant style, I actually clapped my hands with\r\njoy. Imagine my surprise, when, upon returning home, the first object I\r\nmet on the staircase was the identical jockey in the pink jacket! I\r\nconcluded that, by some singular chance, the owner of the winning horse\r\nmust live in the same hotel as myself; but, as I entered my apartments,\r\nI beheld the very gold cup awarded as a prize to the unknown horse and\r\nrider. Inside the cup was a small piece of paper, on which were written\r\nthese words\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98From Lord Ruthven to Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely; I was sure of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure of what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat the owner of the horse was Lord Ruthven himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat Lord Ruthven do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, our Lord Ruthven\xe2\x80\x94the Vampire of the Salle Argentina!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the countess; \xe2\x80\x9cis he here in Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure,\xe2\x80\x94why not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you visit him?\xe2\x80\x94meet him at your own house and elsewhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI assure you he is my most intimate friend, and M. de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud\r\nhas also the honor of his acquaintance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why are you so sure of his being the winner of the Jockey Club\r\nprize?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas not the winning horse entered by the name of Vampa?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat of that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, do you not recollect the name of the celebrated bandit by whom I\r\nwas made prisoner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd from whose hands the count extricated me in so wonderful a\r\nmanner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure, I remember it all now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe called himself Vampa. You see, it\xe2\x80\x99s evident where the count got the\r\nname.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what could have been his motive for sending the cup to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first place, because I had spoken much of you to him, as you\r\nmay believe; and in the second, because he delighted to see a\r\ncountrywoman take so lively an interest in his success.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI trust and hope you never repeated to the count all the foolish\r\nremarks we used to make about him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should not like to affirm upon oath that I have not. Besides, his\r\npresenting you the cup under the name of Lord Ruthven\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, but that is dreadful! Why, the man must owe me a fearful grudge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes his action appear like that of an enemy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; certainly not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so he is in Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what effect does he produce?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9che was talked about for a week; then the\r\ncoronation of the queen of England took place, followed by the theft of\r\nMademoiselle Mars\xe2\x80\x99s diamonds; and so people talked of something else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy good fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cthe count is your friend and\r\nyou treat him accordingly. Do not believe what Albert is telling you,\r\ncountess; so far from the sensation excited in the Parisian circles by\r\nthe appearance of the Count of Monte Cristo having abated, I take upon\r\nmyself to declare that it is as strong as ever. His first astounding\r\nact upon coming amongst us was to present a pair of horses, worth\r\n32,000 francs, to Madame Danglars; his second, the almost miraculous\r\npreservation of Madame de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s life; now it seems that he has\r\ncarried off the prize awarded by the Jockey Club.
