I therefore maintain,\r\nin spite of Morcerf, that not only is the count the object of interest\r\nat this present moment, but also that he will continue to be so for a\r\nmonth longer if he pleases to exhibit an eccentricity of conduct which,\r\nafter all, may be his ordinary mode of existence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you are right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cmeanwhile, who is in the\r\nRussian ambassador\xe2\x80\x99s box?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich box do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe one between the pillars on the first tier\xe2\x80\x94it seems to have been\r\nfitted up entirely afresh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you observe anyone during the first act?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that box.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the countess, \xe2\x80\x9cit was certainly empty during the first\r\nact;\xe2\x80\x9d then, resuming the subject of their previous conversation, she\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd so you really believe it was your mysterious Count of Monte\r\nCristo that gained the prize?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who afterwards sent the cup to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUndoubtedly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I don\xe2\x80\x99t know him,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess; \xe2\x80\x9cI have a great mind to\r\nreturn it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo no such thing, I beg of you; he would only send you another, formed\r\nof a magnificent sapphire, or hollowed out of a gigantic ruby. It is\r\nhis way, and you must take him as you find him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment the bell rang to announce the drawing up of the curtain\r\nfor the second act. Albert rose to return to his place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I see you again?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the end of the next act, with your permission, I will come and\r\ninquire whether there is anything I can do for you in Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray take notice,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, \xe2\x80\x9cthat my present residence is 22\r\nRue de Rivoli, and that I am at home to my friends every Saturday\r\nevening. So now, you are both forewarned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young men bowed, and quitted the box. Upon reaching their stalls,\r\nthey found the whole of the audience in the parterre standing up and\r\ndirecting their gaze towards the box formerly possessed by the Russian\r\nambassador. A man of from thirty-five to forty years of age, dressed in\r\ndeep black, had just entered, accompanied by a young woman dressed\r\nafter the Eastern style. The lady was surpassingly beautiful, while the\r\nrich magnificence of her attire drew all eyes upon her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHullo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cit is Monte Cristo and his Greek!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe strangers were, indeed, no other than the count and Hayd\xc3\xa9e. In a\r\nfew moments the young girl had attracted the attention of the whole\r\nhouse, and even the occupants of the boxes leaned forward to scrutinize\r\nher magnificent diamonds.\r\n\r\nThe second act passed away during one continued buzz of voices\xe2\x80\x94one deep\r\nwhisper\xe2\x80\x94intimating that some great and universally interesting event\r\nhad occurred; all eyes, all thoughts, were occupied with the young and\r\nbeautiful woman, whose gorgeous apparel and splendid jewels made a most\r\nextraordinary spectacle.\r\n\r\nUpon this occasion an unmistakable sign from Madame Danglars intimated\r\nher desire to see Albert in her box directly the curtain fell on the\r\nsecond act, and neither the politeness nor good taste of Morcerf would\r\npermit his neglecting an invitation so unequivocally given. At the\r\nclose of the act he therefore went to the baroness.\r\n\r\nHaving bowed to the two ladies, he extended his hand to Debray. By the\r\nbaroness he was most graciously welcomed, while Eug\xc3\xa9nie received him\r\nwith her accustomed coldness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have come in the nick of time.\r\nThere is madame overwhelming me with questions respecting the count;\r\nshe insists upon it that I can tell her his birth, education, and\r\nparentage, where he came from, and whither he is going. Being no\r\ndisciple of Cagliostro, I was wholly unable to do this; so, by way of\r\ngetting out of the scrape, I said, \xe2\x80\x98Ask Morcerf; he has got the whole\r\nhistory of his beloved Monte Cristo at his fingers\xe2\x80\x99 ends;\xe2\x80\x99 whereupon\r\nthe baroness signified her desire to see you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it not almost incredible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthat a person\r\nhaving at least half a million of secret-service money at his command,\r\nshould possess so little information?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me assure you, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucien, \xe2\x80\x9cthat had I really the sum\r\nyou mention at my disposal, I would employ it more profitably than in\r\ntroubling myself to obtain particulars respecting the Count of Monte\r\nCristo, whose only merit in my eyes consists in his being twice as rich\r\nas a nabob. However, I have turned the business over to Morcerf, so\r\npray settle it with him as may be most agreeable to you; for my own\r\npart, I care nothing about the count or his mysterious doings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30093m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very sure no nabob would have sent me a pair of horses worth\r\n32,000 francs, wearing on their heads four diamonds valued at 5,000\r\nfrancs each.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe seems to have a mania for diamonds,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\nverily believe that, like Potemkin, he keeps his pockets filled, for\r\nthe sake of strewing them along the road, as Tom Thumb did his flint\r\nstones.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps he has discovered some mine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars. \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose\r\nyou know he has an order for unlimited credit on the baron\xe2\x80\x99s banking\r\nestablishment?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was not aware of it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I can readily believe\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, further, that he stated to M. Danglars his intention of only\r\nstaying a year in Paris, during which time he proposed to spend six\r\nmillions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must be the Shah of Persia, travelling _incog_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you noticed the remarkable beauty of the young woman, M. Lucien?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ninquired Eug\xc3\xa9nie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI really never met with one woman so ready to do justice to the charms\r\nof another as yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d responded Lucien, raising his lorgnette to his\r\neye. \xe2\x80\x9cA most lovely creature, upon my soul!\xe2\x80\x9d was his verdict.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is this young person, M. de Morcerf?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Eug\xc3\xa9nie; \xe2\x80\x9cdoes\r\nanybody know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, replying to this direct appeal, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\r\ngive you very exact information on that subject, as well as on most\r\npoints relative to the mysterious person of whom we are now\r\nconversing\xe2\x80\x94the young woman is a Greek.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I should suppose by her dress; if you know no more than that,\r\neveryone here is as well-informed as yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am extremely sorry you find me so ignorant a _cicerone_,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nMorcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I am reluctantly obliged to confess, I have nothing\r\nfurther to communicate\xe2\x80\x94yes, stay, I do know one thing more, namely,\r\nthat she is a musician, for one day when I chanced to be breakfasting\r\nwith the count, I heard the sound of a guzla\xe2\x80\x94it is impossible that it\r\ncould have been touched by any other finger than her own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen your count entertains visitors, does he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Madame Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed he does, and in a most lavish manner, I can assure you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must try and persuade M. Danglars to invite him to a ball or dinner,\r\nor something of the sort, that he may be compelled to ask us in\r\nreturn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, laughing; \xe2\x80\x9cdo you really mean you would go to his\r\nhouse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not? my husband could accompany me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut do you know this mysterious count is a bachelor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have ample proof to the contrary, if you look opposite,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nbaroness, as she laughingly pointed to the beautiful Greek.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Debray; \xe2\x80\x9cthat girl is not his wife: he told us\r\nhimself she was his slave. Do you not recollect, Morcerf, his telling\r\nus so at your breakfast?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the baroness, \xe2\x80\x9cif slave she be, she has all the air\r\nand manner of a princess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf the \xe2\x80\x98Arabian Nights\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you like; but tell me, my dear Lucien, what it is that constitutes\r\na princess. Why, diamonds\xe2\x80\x94and she is covered with them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo me she seems overloaded,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Eug\xc3\xa9nie; \xe2\x80\x9cshe would look far\r\nbetter if she wore fewer, and we should then be able to see her finely\r\nformed throat and wrists.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee how the artist peeps out!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Madame Danglars. \xe2\x80\x9cMy poor\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie, you must conceal your passion for the fine arts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI admire all that is beautiful,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the young lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think of the count?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Debray; \xe2\x80\x9che is not much\r\namiss, according to my ideas of good looks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Eug\xc3\xa9nie, as though it had not occurred to her to\r\nobserve him sooner; \xe2\x80\x9cthe count?\xe2\x80\x94oh, he is so dreadfully pale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI quite agree with you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cand the secret of that very\r\npallor is what we want to find out. The Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 insists upon it\r\nthat he is a vampire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 has returned to Paris, has she?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the\r\nbaroness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that she, mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Eug\xc3\xa9nie; \xe2\x80\x9calmost opposite to us, with that\r\nprofusion of beautiful light hair?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is she. Shall I tell you what you\r\nought to do, Morcerf?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCommand me, madame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, you should go and bring your Count of Monte Cristo to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Eug\xc3\xa9nie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for? Why, to converse with him, of course. Have you really no\r\ndesire to meet him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone whatever,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Eug\xc3\xa9nie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrange child,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the baroness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will very probably come of his own accord,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf. \xe2\x80\x9cThere;\r\ndo you see, madame, he recognizes you, and bows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe baroness returned the salute in the most smiling and graceful\r\nmanner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cI may as well be magnanimous, and tear myself\r\naway to forward your wishes. Adieu; I will go and try if there are any\r\nmeans of speaking to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo straight to his box; that will be the simplest plan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I have never been presented.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPresented to whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the beautiful Greek.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say she is only a slave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile you assert that she is a queen, or at least a princess. No; I\r\nhope that when he sees me leave you, he will come out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is possible\xe2\x80\x94go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, as he made his parting bow.\r\n\r\nJust as he was passing the count\xe2\x80\x99s box, the door opened, and Monte\r\nCristo came forth. After giving some directions to Ali, who stood in\r\nthe lobby, the count took Albert\xe2\x80\x99s arm. Carefully closing the box door,\r\nAli placed himself before it, while a crowd of spectators assembled\r\nround the Nubian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cParis is a strange city, and the\r\nParisians a very singular people. See that cluster of persons collected\r\naround poor Ali, who is as much astonished as themselves; really one\r\nmight suppose he was the only Nubian they had ever beheld. Now I can\r\npromise you, that a Frenchman might show himself in public, either in\r\nTunis, Constantinople, Bagdad, or Cairo, without being treated in that\r\nway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat shows that the Eastern nations have too much good sense to waste\r\ntheir time and attention on objects undeserving of either. However, as\r\nfar as Ali is concerned, I can assure you, the interest he excites is\r\nmerely from the circumstance of his being your attendant\xe2\x80\x94you, who are\r\nat this moment the most celebrated and fashionable person in Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally? and what has procured me so flattering a distinction?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? why, yourself, to be sure! You give away horses worth a thousand\r\nlouis; you save the lives of ladies of high rank and beauty; under the\r\nname of Major Black you run thoroughbreds ridden by tiny urchins not\r\nlarger than marmots; then, when you have carried off the golden trophy\r\nof victory, instead of setting any value on it, you give it to the\r\nfirst handsome woman you think of!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who has filled your head with all this nonsense?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, in the first place, I heard it from Madame Danglars, who, by the\r\nby, is dying to see you in her box, or to have you seen there by\r\nothers; secondly, I learned it from Beauchamp\xe2\x80\x99s journal; and thirdly,\r\nfrom my own imagination. Why, if you sought concealment, did you call\r\nyour horse Vampa?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was an oversight, certainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count; \xe2\x80\x9cbut tell me,\r\ndoes the Count of Morcerf never visit the Opera? I have been looking\r\nfor him, but without success.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will be here tonight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what part of the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the baroness\xe2\x80\x99s box, I believe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat charming young woman with her is her daughter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI congratulate you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorcerf smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will discuss that subject at length some future time,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what do you think of the music?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat music?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, the music you have been listening to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is well enough as the production of a human composer, sung by\r\nfeatherless bipeds, to quote the late Diogenes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom which it would seem, my dear count, that you can at pleasure\r\nenjoy the seraphic strains that proceed from the seven choirs of\r\nparadise?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30097m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, in some degree; when I wish to listen to sounds more\r\nexquisitely attuned to melody than mortal ear ever yet listened to, I\r\ngo to sleep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen sleep here, my dear count. The conditions are favorable; what\r\nelse was opera invented for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, thank you. Your orchestra is too noisy. To sleep after the manner\r\nI speak of, absolute calm and silence are necessary, and then a certain\r\npreparation\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know\xe2\x80\x94the famous hashish!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely. So, my dear viscount, whenever you wish to be regaled with\r\nmusic come and sup with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have already enjoyed that treat when breakfasting with you,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMorcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean at Rome?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, then, I suppose you heard Hayd\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x99s guzla; the poor exile\r\nfrequently beguiles a weary hour in playing over to me the airs of her\r\nnative land.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorcerf did not pursue the subject, and Monte Cristo himself fell into\r\na silent reverie.\r\n\r\nThe bell rang at this moment for the rising of the curtain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will excuse my leaving you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, turning in the\r\ndirection of his box.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? Are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray, say everything that is kind to Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 on the part of her\r\nfriend the vampire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what message shall I convey to the baroness!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat, with her permission, I shall do myself the honor of paying my\r\nrespects in the course of the evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe third act had begun; and during its progress the Count of Morcerf,\r\naccording to his promise, made his appearance in the box of Madame\r\nDanglars. The Count of Morcerf was not a person to excite either\r\ninterest or curiosity in a place of public amusement; his presence,\r\ntherefore, was wholly unnoticed, save by the occupants of the box in\r\nwhich he had just seated himself.\r\n\r\nThe quick eye of Monte Cristo however, marked his coming; and a slight\r\nthough meaning smile passed over his lips. Hayd\xc3\xa9e, whose soul seemed\r\ncentred in the business of the stage, like all unsophisticated natures,\r\ndelighted in whatever addressed itself to the eye or ear.\r\n\r\n30099m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe third act passed off as usual. Mesdemoiselles Noblet, Julia, and\r\nLeroux executed the customary pirouettes; Robert duly challenged the\r\nPrince of Granada; and the royal father of the princess Isabella,\r\ntaking his daughter by the hand, swept round the stage with majestic\r\nstrides, the better to display the rich folds of his velvet robe and\r\nmantle. After which the curtain again fell, and the spectators poured\r\nforth from the theatre into the lobbies and salon.\r\n\r\nThe count left his box, and a moment later was saluting the Baronne\r\nDanglars, who could not restrain a cry of mingled pleasure and\r\nsurprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are welcome, count!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, as he entered. \xe2\x80\x9cI have been\r\nmost anxious to see you, that I might repeat orally the thanks writing\r\ncan so ill express.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely so trifling a circumstance cannot deserve a place in your\r\nremembrance. Believe me, madame, I had entirely forgotten it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it is not so easy to forget, monsieur, that the very next day\r\nafter your princely gift you saved the life of my dear friend, Madame\r\nde Villefort, which was endangered by the very animals your generosity\r\nrestored to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30101m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis time, at least, I do not deserve your thanks. It was Ali, my\r\nNubian slave, who rendered this service to Madame de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it Ali,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Count of Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cwho rescued my son from the\r\nhands of bandits?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, count,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo taking the hand held out to him by\r\nthe general; \xe2\x80\x9cin this instance I may fairly and freely accept your\r\nthanks; but you have already tendered them, and fully discharged your\r\ndebt\xe2\x80\x94if indeed there existed one\xe2\x80\x94and I feel almost mortified to find\r\nyou still reverting to the subject. May I beg of you, baroness, to\r\nhonor me with an introduction to your daughter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you are no stranger\xe2\x80\x94at least not by name,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame\r\nDanglars, \xe2\x80\x9cand the last two or three days we have really talked of\r\nnothing but you. Eug\xc3\xa9nie,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the baroness, turning towards her\r\ndaughter, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is the Count of Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count bowed, while Mademoiselle Danglars bent her head slightly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a charming young person with you tonight, count,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie. \xe2\x80\x9cIs she your daughter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, mademoiselle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, astonished at the coolness and\r\nfreedom of the question. \xe2\x80\x9cShe is a poor unfortunate Greek left under my\r\ncare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is her name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHayd\xc3\xa9e,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Greek?\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the Count of Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed, count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cand tell me, did you ever\r\nsee at the court of Ali Tepelini, whom you so gloriously and valiantly\r\nserved, a more exquisite beauty or richer costume?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I hear rightly, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cthat you served at\r\nYanina?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was inspector-general of the pasha\xe2\x80\x99s troops,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nit is no secret that I owe my fortune, such as it is, to the liberality\r\nof the illustrious Albanese chief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut look!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Madame Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo placing his arms around the count, and\r\nleaning with him over the front of the box, just as Hayd\xc3\xa9e, whose eyes\r\nwere occupied in examining the theatre in search of her guardian,\r\nperceived his pale features close to Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s face. It was as if the\r\nyoung girl beheld the head of Medusa. She bent forwards as though to\r\nassure herself of the reality of what she saw, then, uttering a faint\r\ncry, threw herself back in her seat. The sound was heard by the people\r\nabout Ali, who instantly opened the box-door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, count,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Eug\xc3\xa9nie, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat has happened to your ward? she\r\nseems to have been taken suddenly ill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery probably,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the count. \xe2\x80\x9cBut do not be alarmed on her\r\naccount. Hayd\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x99s nervous system is delicately organized, and she is\r\npeculiarly susceptible to the odors even of flowers\xe2\x80\x94nay, there are some\r\nwhich cause her to faint if brought into her presence. However,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued Monte Cristo, drawing a small phial from his pocket, \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\nan infallible remedy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he bowed to the baroness and her daughter, exchanged a\r\nparting shake of the hand with Debray and the count, and left Madame\r\nDanglars\xe2\x80\x99 box. Upon his return to Hayd\xc3\xa9e he found her still very pale.\r\nAs soon as she saw him she seized his hand; her own hands were moist\r\nand icy cold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho was it you were talking with over there?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith the Count of Morcerf,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cHe tells me he\r\nserved your illustrious father, and that he owes his fortune to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWretch!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Hayd\xc3\xa9e, her eyes flashing with rage; \xe2\x80\x9che sold my\r\nfather to the Turks, and the fortune he boasts of was the price of his\r\ntreachery! Did not you know that, my dear lord?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething of this I heard in Epirus,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut the\r\nparticulars are still unknown to me. You shall relate them to me, my\r\nchild. They are, no doubt, both curious and interesting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes; but let us go. I feel as though it would kill me to remain\r\nlong near that dreadful man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, Hayd\xc3\xa9e arose, and wrapping herself in her burnouse of white\r\ncashmere embroidered with pearls and coral, she hastily quitted the box\r\nat the moment when the curtain was rising upon the fourth act.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you observe,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 to Albert, who had returned to\r\nher side, \xe2\x80\x9cthat man does nothing like other people; he listens most\r\ndevoutly to the third act of _Robert le Diable_, and when the fourth\r\nbegins, takes his departure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 54. A Flurry in Stocks\r\n\r\nSome days after this meeting, Albert de Morcerf visited the Count of\r\nMonte Cristo at his house in the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es, which had already\r\nassumed that palace-like appearance which the count\xe2\x80\x99s princely fortune\r\nenabled him to give even to his most temporary residences. He came to\r\nrenew the thanks of Madame Danglars which had been already conveyed to\r\nthe count through the medium of a letter, signed \xe2\x80\x9cBaronne Danglars,\r\n_n\xc3\xa9e_ Hermine de Servieux.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert was accompanied by Lucien Debray, who, joining in his friend\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconversation, added some passing compliments, the source of which the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s talent for finesse easily enabled him to guess. He was\r\nconvinced that Lucien\xe2\x80\x99s visit was due to a double feeling of curiosity,\r\nthe larger half of which sentiment emanated from the Rue de la Chauss\xc3\xa9e\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99Antin. In short, Madame Danglars, not being able personally to\r\nexamine in detail the domestic economy and household arrangements of a\r\nman who gave away horses worth 30,000 francs and who went to the opera\r\nwith a Greek slave wearing diamonds to the amount of a million of\r\nmoney, had deputed those eyes, by which she was accustomed to see, to\r\ngive her a faithful account of the mode of life of this\r\nincomprehensible person. But the count did not appear to suspect that\r\nthere could be the slightest connection between Lucien\xe2\x80\x99s visit and the\r\ncuriosity of the baroness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are in constant communication with the Baron Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d the count\r\ninquired of Albert de Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, count, you know what I told you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll remains the same, then, in that quarter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is more than ever a settled thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucien,\xe2\x80\x94and, considering\r\nthat this remark was all that he was at that time called upon to make,\r\nhe adjusted the glass to his eye, and biting the top of his gold headed\r\ncane, began to make the tour of the apartment, examining the arms and\r\nthe pictures.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cI did not expect that the affair would be so\r\npromptly concluded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, things take their course without our assistance. While we are\r\nforgetting them, they are falling into their appointed order; and when,\r\nagain, our attention is directed to them, we are surprised at the\r\nprogress they have made towards the proposed end. My father and M.\r\nDanglars served together in Spain, my father in the army and M.\r\nDanglars in the commissariat department. It was there that my father,\r\nruined by the revolution, and M. Danglars, who never had possessed any\r\npatrimony, both laid the foundations of their different fortunes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cI think M. Danglars mentioned that in a visit\r\nwhich I paid him; and,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, casting a side-glance at Lucien,\r\nwho was turning over the leaves of an album, \xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie is\r\npretty\xe2\x80\x94I think I remember that to be her name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery pretty, or rather, very beautiful,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cbut of that\r\nstyle of beauty which I do not appreciate; I am an ungrateful fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou speak as if you were already her husband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Albert, in his turn looking around to see what Lucien\r\nwas doing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, lowering his voice, \xe2\x80\x9cyou do not appear to\r\nme to be very enthusiastic on the subject of this marriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle Danglars is too rich for me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cand that\r\nfrightens me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s a fine reason to give. Are you\r\nnot rich yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father\xe2\x80\x99s income is about 50,000 francs per annum; and he will give\r\nme, perhaps, ten or twelve thousand when I marry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat, perhaps, might not be considered a large sum, in Paris\r\nespecially,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cbut everything does not depend on wealth,\r\nand it is a fine thing to have a good name, and to occupy a high\r\nstation in society. Your name is celebrated, your position magnificent;\r\nand then the Comte de Morcerf is a soldier, and it is pleasing to see\r\nthe integrity of a Bayard united to the poverty of a Duguesclin;\r\ndisinterestedness is the brightest ray in which a noble sword can\r\nshine. As for me, I consider the union with Mademoiselle Danglars a\r\nmost suitable one; she will enrich you, and you will ennoble her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert shook his head, and looked thoughtful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is still something else,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI confess,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I have some difficulty in\r\ncomprehending your objection to a young lady who is both rich and\r\nbeautiful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cthis repugnance, if repugnance it may be called,\r\nis not all on my side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhence can it arise, then? for you told me your father desired the\r\nmarriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is my mother who dissents; she has a clear and penetrating\r\njudgment, and does not smile on the proposed union. I cannot account\r\nfor it, but she seems to entertain some prejudice against the\r\nDanglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30107m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, in a somewhat forced tone, \xe2\x80\x9cthat may be easily\r\nexplained; the Comtesse de Morcerf, who is aristocracy and refinement\r\nitself, does not relish the idea of being allied by your marriage with\r\none of ignoble birth; that is natural enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know if that is her reason,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cbut one thing I do\r\nknow, that if this marriage be consummated, it will render her quite\r\nmiserable. There was to have been a meeting six weeks ago in order to\r\ntalk over and settle the affair; but I had such a sudden attack of\r\nindisposition\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReal?\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the count, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, real enough, from anxiety doubtless,\xe2\x80\x94at any rate they postponed\r\nthe matter for two months. There is no hurry, you know. I am not yet\r\ntwenty-one, and Eug\xc3\xa9nie is only seventeen; but the two months expire\r\nnext week. It must be done. My dear count, you cannot imagine how my\r\nmind is harassed. How happy you are in being exempt from all this!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and why should not you be free, too? What prevents you from\r\nbeing so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it will be too great a disappointment to my father if I do not\r\nmarry Mademoiselle Danglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarry her then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, with a significant shrug of the\r\nshoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cbut that will plunge my mother into positive\r\ngrief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen do not marry her,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I shall see. I will try and think over what is the best thing to\r\nbe done; you will give me your advice, will you not, and if possible\r\nextricate me from my unpleasant position? I think, rather than give\r\npain to my dear mother, I would run the risk of offending the count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo turned away; he seemed moved by this last remark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Debray, who had thrown himself into an easy-chair at\r\nthe farthest extremity of the salon, and who held a pencil in his right\r\nhand and an account book in his left, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat are you doing there? Are\r\nyou making a sketch after Poussin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d was the tranquil response; \xe2\x80\x9cI am too fond of art to attempt\r\nanything of that sort. I am doing a little sum in arithmetic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn arithmetic?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I am calculating\xe2\x80\x94by the way, Morcerf, that indirectly concerns\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x94I am calculating what the house of Danglars must have gained by the\r\nlast rise in Haiti bonds; from 206 they have risen to 409 in three\r\ndays, and the prudent banker had purchased at 206; therefore he must\r\nhave made 300,000 livres.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not his biggest scoop,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cdid he not make a\r\nmillion in Spaniards this last year?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucien, \xe2\x80\x9chere is the Count of Monte Cristo, who\r\nwill say to you, as the Italians do,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Denaro e santit\xc3\xa0,\r\n\r\n      Met\xc3\xa0 della met\xc3\xa0.\xe2\x80\x999\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen they tell me such things, I only shrug my shoulders and say\r\nnothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you were speaking of Haitians?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Haitians,\xe2\x80\x94that is quite another thing! Haitians are the _\xc3\xa9cart\xc3\xa9_\r\nof French stock-jobbing. We may like bouillotte, delight in whist, be\r\nenraptured with boston, and yet grow tired of them all; but we always\r\ncome back to _\xc3\xa9cart\xc3\xa9_\xe2\x80\x94it is not only a game, it is a _hors-d\xe2\x80\x99\xc5\x93uvre_! M.\r\nDanglars sold yesterday at 405, and pockets 300,000 francs. Had he but\r\nwaited till today, the price would have fallen to 205, and instead of\r\ngaining 300,000 francs, he would have lost 20 or 25,000.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what has caused the sudden fall from 409 to 206?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte\r\nCristo. \xe2\x80\x9cI am profoundly ignorant of all these stock-jobbing\r\nintrigues.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cone piece of news follows another,\r\nand there is often great dissimilarity between them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cI see that M. Danglars is accustomed to play at\r\ngaining or losing 300,000 francs in a day; he must be enormously rich.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not he who plays!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Lucien; \xe2\x80\x9cit is Madame Danglars; she\r\nis indeed daring.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you who are a reasonable being, Lucien, and who knows how little\r\ndependence is to be placed on the news, since you are at the\r\nfountain-head, surely you ought to prevent it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, with a\r\nsmile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I, if her husband fails in controlling her?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Lucien;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou know the character of the baroness\xe2\x80\x94no one has any influence with\r\nher, and she does precisely what she pleases.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, if I were in your place\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would reform her; it would be rendering a service to her future\r\nson-in-law.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow would you set about it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that would be easy enough\xe2\x80\x94I would give her a lesson.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA lesson?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Your position as secretary to the minister renders your authority\r\ngreat on the subject of political news; you never open your mouth but\r\nthe stockbrokers immediately stenograph your words. Cause her to lose a\r\nhundred thousand francs, and that would teach her prudence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not understand,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Lucien.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very clear, notwithstanding,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man, with an\r\nartlessness wholly free from affectation; \xe2\x80\x9ctell her some fine morning\r\nan unheard-of piece of intelligence\xe2\x80\x94some telegraphic despatch, of which\r\nyou alone are in possession; for instance, that Henri IV. was seen\r\nyesterday at Gabrielle\xe2\x80\x99s. That would boom the market; she will buy\r\nheavily, and she will certainly lose when Beauchamp announces the\r\nfollowing day, in his gazette, \xe2\x80\x98The report circulated by some usually\r\nwell-informed persons that the king was seen yesterday at Gabrielle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhouse, is totally without foundation. We can positively assert that his\r\nmajesty did not quit the Pont-Neuf.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLucien half smiled. Monte Cristo, although apparently indifferent, had\r\nnot lost one word of this conversation, and his penetrating eye had\r\neven read a hidden secret in the embarrassed manner of the secretary.\r\nThis embarrassment had completely escaped Albert, but it caused Lucien\r\nto shorten his visit; he was evidently ill at ease. The count, in\r\ntaking leave of him, said something in a low voice, to which he\r\nanswered, \xe2\x80\x9cWillingly, count; I accept.\xe2\x80\x9d The count returned to young\r\nMorcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you not think, on reflection,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to him, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you have done\r\nwrong in thus speaking of your mother-in-law in the presence of M.\r\nDebray?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cI beg of you not to apply that title so\r\nprematurely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, speaking without any exaggeration, is your mother really so very\r\nmuch averse to this marriage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much so that the baroness very rarely comes to the house, and my\r\nmother, has not, I think, visited Madame Danglars twice in her whole\r\nlife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cI am emboldened to speak openly to you. M.\r\nDanglars is my banker; M. de Villefort has overwhelmed me with\r\npoliteness in return for a service which a casual piece of good fortune\r\nenabled me to render him. I predict from all this an avalanche of\r\ndinners and routs. Now, in order not to presume on this, and also to be\r\nbeforehand with them, I have, if agreeable to you, thought of inviting\r\nM. and Madame Danglars, and M. and Madame de Villefort, to my\r\ncountry-house at Auteuil. If I were to invite you and the Count and\r\nCountess of Morcerf to this dinner, I should give it the appearance of\r\nbeing a matrimonial meeting, or at least Madame de Morcerf would look\r\nupon the affair in that light, especially if Baron Danglars did me the\r\nhonor to bring his daughter. In that case your mother would hold me in\r\naversion, and I do not at all wish that; on the contrary, I desire to\r\nstand high in her esteem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cI thank you sincerely for having used\r\nso much candor towards me, and I gratefully accept the exclusion which\r\nyou propose. You say you desire my mother\xe2\x80\x99s good opinion; I assure you\r\nit is already yours to a very unusual extent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30111m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, with interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I am sure of it; we talked of you an hour after you left us the\r\nother day. But to return to what we were saying. If my mother could\r\nknow of this attention on your part\xe2\x80\x94and I will venture to tell her\xe2\x80\x94I am\r\nsure that she will be most grateful to you; it is true that my father\r\nwill be equally angry.\xe2\x80\x9d The count laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I think your father will not be the\r\nonly angry one; M. and Madame Danglars will think me a very\r\nill-mannered person. They know that I am intimate with you\xe2\x80\x94that you\r\nare, in fact; one of the oldest of my Parisian acquaintances\xe2\x80\x94and they\r\nwill not find you at my house; they will certainly ask me why I did not\r\ninvite you. Be sure to provide yourself with some previous engagement\r\nwhich shall have a semblance of probability, and communicate the fact\r\nto me by a line in writing. You know that with bankers nothing but a\r\nwritten document will be valid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do better than that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cmy mother is wishing to go\r\nto the sea-side\xe2\x80\x94what day is fixed for your dinner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaturday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is Tuesday\xe2\x80\x94well, tomorrow evening we leave, and the day after we\r\nshall be at Tr\xc3\xa9port. Really, count, you have a delightful way of\r\nsetting people at their ease.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, you give me more credit than I deserve; I only wish to do what\r\nwill be agreeable to you, that is all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen shall you send your invitations?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis very day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will immediately call on M. Danglars, and tell him that my\r\nmother and myself must leave Paris tomorrow. I have not seen you,\r\nconsequently I know nothing of your dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow foolish you are! Have you forgotten that M. Debray has just seen\r\nyou at my house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, true.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFix it this way. I have seen you, and invited you without any\r\nceremony, when you instantly answered that it would be impossible for\r\nyou to accept, as you were going to Tr\xc3\xa9port.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, that is settled; but you will come and call on my mother\r\nbefore tomorrow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBefore tomorrow?\xe2\x80\x94that will be a difficult matter to arrange, besides,\r\nI shall just be in the way of all the preparations for departure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you can do better. You were only a charming man before, but, if\r\nyou accede to my proposal, you will be adorable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat must I do to attain such sublimity?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are today free as air\xe2\x80\x94come and dine with me; we shall be a small\r\nparty\xe2\x80\x94only yourself, my mother, and I. You have scarcely seen my\r\nmother; you shall have an opportunity of observing her more closely.\r\nShe is a remarkable woman, and I only regret that there does not exist\r\nanother like her, about twenty years younger; in that case, I assure\r\nyou, there would very soon be a Countess and Viscountess of Morcerf. As\r\nto my father, you will not see him; he is officially engaged, and dines\r\nwith the chief referendary. We will talk over our travels; and you, who\r\nhave seen the whole world, will relate your adventures\xe2\x80\x94you shall tell\r\nus the history of the beautiful Greek who was with you the other night\r\nat the Opera, and whom you call your slave, and yet treat like a\r\nprincess. We will talk Italian and Spanish. Come, accept my invitation,\r\nand my mother will thank you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA thousand thanks,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cyour invitation is most gracious,\r\nand I regret exceedingly that it is not in my power to accept it. I am\r\nnot so much at liberty as you suppose; on the contrary, I have a most\r\nimportant engagement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, take care, you were teaching me just now how, in case of an\r\ninvitation to dinner, one might creditably make an excuse. I require\r\nthe proof of a pre-engagement. I am not a banker, like M. Danglars, but\r\nI am quite as incredulous as he is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going to give you a proof,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, and he rang the\r\nbell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumph,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is the second time you have refused to\r\ndine with my mother; it is evident that you wish to avoid her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo started. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, you do not mean that,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cbesides,\r\nhere comes the confirmation of my assertion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBaptistin entered, and remained standing at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had no previous knowledge of your visit, had I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, you are such an extraordinary person, that I would not answer\r\nfor it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt all events, I could not guess that you would invite me to dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProbably not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, listen, Baptistin, what did I tell you this morning when I\r\ncalled you into my laboratory?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo close the door against visitors as soon as the clock struck five,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied the valet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, I wish to do away with that mysterious reputation that you\r\nhave given me, my dear viscount; it is tiresome to be always acting\r\nManfred. I wish my life to be free and open. Go on, Baptistin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen to admit no one except Major Bartolomeo Cavalcanti and his son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou hear\xe2\x80\x94Major Bartolomeo Cavalcanti\xe2\x80\x94a man who ranks amongst the most\r\nancient nobility of Italy, whose name Dante has celebrated in the tenth\r\ncanto of _The Inferno_, you remember it, do you not? Then there is his\r\nson, Andrea, a charming young man, about your own age, viscount,\r\nbearing the same title as yourself, and who is making his entry into\r\nthe Parisian world, aided by his father\xe2\x80\x99s millions. The major will\r\nbring his son with him this evening, the _contino_, as we say in Italy;\r\nhe confides him to my care. If he proves himself worthy of it, I will\r\ndo what I can to advance his interests. You will assist me in the work,\r\nwill you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost undoubtedly. This Major Cavalcanti is an old friend of yours,\r\nthen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy no means. He is a perfect nobleman, very polite, modest, and\r\nagreeable, such as may be found constantly in Italy, descendants of\r\nvery ancient families. I have met him several times at Florence,\r\nBologna and Lucca, and he has now communicated to me the fact of his\r\narrival in Paris. The acquaintances one makes in travelling have a sort\r\nof claim on one; they everywhere expect to receive the same attention\r\nwhich you once paid them by chance, as though the civilities of a\r\npassing hour were likely to awaken any lasting interest in favor of the\r\nman in whose society you may happen to be thrown in the course of your\r\njourney. This good Major Cavalcanti is come to take a second view of\r\nParis, which he only saw in passing through in the time of the Empire,\r\nwhen he was on his way to Moscow. I shall give him a good dinner, he\r\nwill confide his son to my care, I will promise to watch over him, I\r\nshall let him follow in whatever path his folly may lead him, and then\r\nI shall have done my part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; I see you are a model Mentor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert \xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye, we\r\nshall return on Sunday. By the way, I have received news of Franz.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you? Is he still amusing himself in Italy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe so; however, he regrets your absence extremely. He says you\r\nwere the sun of Rome, and that without you all appears dark and cloudy;\r\nI do not know if he does not even go so far as to say that it rains.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis opinion of me is altered for the better, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he still persists in looking upon you as the most incomprehensible\r\nand mysterious of beings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a charming young man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cand I felt a lively\r\ninterest in him the very first evening of my introduction, when I met\r\nhim in search of a supper, and prevailed upon him to accept a portion\r\nof mine.
