But really, my dear count, we are talking as much of women as they\r\ndo of us; it is unpardonable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, that is a good idea!\xe2\x80\x94two hours have I been boring you to death\r\nwith my company, and then you, with the greatest politeness, ask me if\r\nI am going. Indeed, count, you are the most polished man in the world.\r\nAnd your servants, too, how very well behaved they are; there is quite\r\na style about them. Monsieur Baptistin especially; I could never get\r\nsuch a man as that. My servants seem to imitate those you sometimes see\r\nin a play, who, because they have only a word or two to say, aquit\r\nthemselves in the most awkward manner possible. Therefore, if you part\r\nwith M. Baptistin, give me the refusal of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy all means.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not all; give my compliments to your illustrious Luccanese,\r\nCavalcante of the Cavalcanti; and if by any chance he should be wishing\r\nto establish his son, find him a wife very rich, very noble on her\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s side at least, and a baroness in right of her father, I will\r\nhelp you in the search.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ha; you will do as much as that, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, really, nothing is certain in this world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, count, what a service you might render me! I should like you a\r\nhundred times better if, by your intervention, I could manage to remain\r\na bachelor, even were it only for ten years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing is impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d gravely replied Monte Cristo; and taking leave\r\nof Albert, he returned into the house, and struck the gong three times.\r\nBertuccio appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Bertuccio, you understand that I intend entertaining company\r\non Saturday at Auteuil.\xe2\x80\x9d Bertuccio slightly started. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall require\r\nyour services to see that all be properly arranged. It is a beautiful\r\nhouse, or at all events may be made so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere must be a good deal done before it can deserve that title, your\r\nexcellency, for the tapestried hangings are very old.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet them all be taken away and changed, then, with the exception of\r\nthe sleeping-chamber which is hung with red damask; you will leave that\r\nexactly as it is.\xe2\x80\x9d Bertuccio bowed. \xe2\x80\x9cYou will not touch the garden\r\neither; as to the yard, you may do what you please with it; I should\r\nprefer that being altered beyond all recognition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do everything in my power to carry out your wishes, your\r\nexcellency. I should be glad, however, to receive your excellency\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncommands concerning the dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, my dear M. Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9csince you have been in\r\nParis, you have become quite nervous, and apparently out of your\r\nelement; you no longer seem to understand me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut surely your excellency will be so good as to inform me whom you\r\nare expecting to receive?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not yet know myself, neither is it necessary that you should do\r\nso. \xe2\x80\x98Lucullus dines with Lucullus,\xe2\x80\x99 that is quite sufficient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio bowed, and left the room.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 55. Major Cavalcanti\r\n\r\nBoth the count and Baptistin had told the truth when they announced to\r\nMorcerf the proposed visit of the major, which had served Monte Cristo\r\nas a pretext for declining Albert\xe2\x80\x99s invitation. Seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock had just\r\nstruck, and M. Bertuccio, according to the command which had been given\r\nhim, had two hours before left for Auteuil, when a cab stopped at the\r\ndoor, and after depositing its occupant at the gate, immediately\r\nhurried away, as if ashamed of its employment. The visitor was about\r\nfifty-two years of age, dressed in one of the green surtouts,\r\nornamented with black frogs, which have so long maintained their\r\npopularity all over Europe. He wore trousers of blue cloth, boots\r\ntolerably clean, but not of the brightest polish, and a little too\r\nthick in the soles, buckskin gloves, a hat somewhat resembling in shape\r\nthose usually worn by the gendarmes, and a black cravat striped with\r\nwhite, which, if the proprietor had not worn it of his own free will,\r\nmight have passed for a halter, so much did it resemble one. Such was\r\nthe picturesque costume of the person who rang at the gate, and\r\ndemanded if it was not at No. 30 in the Avenue des Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es that\r\nthe Count of Monte Cristo lived, and who, being answered by the porter\r\nin the affirmative, entered, closed the gate after him, and began to\r\nascend the steps.\r\n\r\nThe small and angular head of this man, his white hair and thick gray\r\nmoustaches, caused him to be easily recognized by Baptistin, who had\r\nreceived an exact description of the expected visitor, and who was\r\nawaiting him in the hall. Therefore, scarcely had the stranger time to\r\npronounce his name before the count was apprised of his arrival. He was\r\nushered into a simple and elegant drawing-room, and the count rose to\r\nmeet him with a smiling air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear sir, you are most welcome; I was expecting you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Italian, \xe2\x80\x9cwas your excellency then aware of my\r\nvisit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I had been told that I should see you today at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have received full information concerning my arrival?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, so much the better, I feared this little precaution might have\r\nbeen forgotten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30119m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat precaution?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat of informing you beforehand of my coming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, it has not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you are sure you are not mistaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt really was I whom your excellency expected at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock this\r\nevening?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will prove it to you beyond a doubt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, never mind that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Italian; \xe2\x80\x9cit is not worth the\r\ntrouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. His visitor appeared slightly uneasy.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me see,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9care you not the Marquis Bartolomeo\r\nCavalcanti?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBartolomeo Cavalcanti,\xe2\x80\x9d joyfully replied the Italian; \xe2\x80\x9cyes, I am\r\nreally he.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEx-major in the Austrian service?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas I a major?\xe2\x80\x9d timidly asked the old soldier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cyou were a major; that is the title the\r\nFrench give to the post which you filled in Italy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not demand more, you understand\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour visit here today is not of your own suggestion, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMonte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, certainly not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were sent by some other person?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the excellent Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the delighted major.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have a letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, there it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive it to me, then.\xe2\x80\x9d And Monte Cristo took the letter, which he\r\nopened and read. The major looked at the count with his large staring\r\neyes, and then took a survey of the apartment, but his gaze almost\r\nimmediately reverted to the proprietor of the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, I see. \xe2\x80\x98Major Cavalcanti, a worthy patrician of Lucca, a\r\ndescendant of the Cavalcanti of Florence,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d continued Monte Cristo,\r\nreading aloud, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98possessing an income of half a million.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo raised his eyes from the paper, and bowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf a million,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cmagnificent!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf a million, is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the major.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, in so many words; and it must be so, for the abb\xc3\xa9 knows correctly\r\nthe amount of all the largest fortunes in Europe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it half a million, then; but on my word of honor, I had no idea\r\nthat it was so much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you are robbed by your steward. You must make some reformation\r\nin that quarter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have opened my eyes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Italian gravely; \xe2\x80\x9cI will show the\r\ngentlemen the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo resumed the perusal of the letter:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98And who only needs one thing more to make him happy.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed but one!\xe2\x80\x9d said the major with a sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Which is to recover a lost and adored son.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA lost and adored son!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Stolen away in his infancy, either by an enemy of his noble family or\r\nby the gypsies.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the age of five years!\xe2\x80\x9d said the major with a deep sigh, and\r\nraising his eye to heaven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnhappy father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. The count continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I have given him renewed life and hope, in the assurance that you\r\nhave the power of restoring the son whom he has vainly sought for\r\nfifteen years.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe major looked at the count with an indescribable expression of\r\nanxiety.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have the power of so doing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. The major recovered\r\nhis self-possession.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe letter was true to the end?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you doubt it, my dear Monsieur Bartolomeo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed; certainly not; a good man, a man holding religious office,\r\nas does the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni, could not condescend to deceive or play off a\r\njoke; but your excellency has not read all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cthere is a postscript.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the major, \xe2\x80\x9cyes\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x94is\xe2\x80\x94a\xe2\x80\x94postscript.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98In order to save Major Cavalcanti the trouble of drawing on his\r\nbanker, I send him a draft for 2,000 francs to defray his travelling\r\nexpenses, and credit on you for the further sum of 48,000 francs, which\r\nyou still owe me.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe major awaited the conclusion of the postscript, apparently with\r\ngreat anxiety.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe said \xe2\x80\x98very good,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the major, \xe2\x80\x9cthen\xe2\x80\x94sir\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d replied he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen what?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the postscript\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell; what of the postscript?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the postscript is as favorably received by you as the rest of the\r\nletter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni and myself have a small account open\r\nbetween us. I do not remember if it is exactly 48,000 francs, which I\r\nam still owing him, but I dare say we shall not dispute the difference.\r\nYou attached great importance, then, to this postscript, my dear\r\nMonsieur Cavalcanti?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must explain to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, \xe2\x80\x9cthat, fully confiding in the\r\nsignature of the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni, I had not provided myself with any other\r\nfunds; so that if this resource had failed me, I should have found\r\nmyself very unpleasantly situated in Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible that a man of your standing should be embarrassed\r\nanywhere?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, really I know no one,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut then you yourself are known to others?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I am known, so that\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProceed, my dear Monsieur Cavalcanti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that you will remit to me these 48,000 francs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, at your first request.\xe2\x80\x9d The major\xe2\x80\x99s eyes dilated with\r\npleasing astonishment. \xe2\x80\x9cBut sit down,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9creally I do\r\nnot know what I have been thinking of\xe2\x80\x94I have positively kept you\r\nstanding for the last quarter of an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t mention it.\xe2\x80\x9d The major drew an armchair towards him, and\r\nproceeded to seat himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat will you take\xe2\x80\x94a glass of sherry, port, or\r\nAlicante?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlicante, if you please; it is my favorite wine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have some that is very good. You will take a biscuit with it, will\r\nyou not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I will take a biscuit, as you are so obliging.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo rang; Baptistin appeared. The count advanced to meet him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said he in a low voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe young man is here,\xe2\x80\x9d said the valet de chambre in the same tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInto what room did you take him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInto the blue drawing-room, according to your excellency\xe2\x80\x99s orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s right; now bring the Alicante and some biscuits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBaptistin left the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, \xe2\x80\x9cI am quite ashamed of the trouble I am\r\ngiving you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray don\xe2\x80\x99t mention such a thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count. Baptistin re-entered\r\nwith glasses, wine, and biscuits. The count filled one glass, but in\r\nthe other he only poured a few drops of the ruby-colored liquid. The\r\nbottle was covered with spiders\xe2\x80\x99 webs, and all the other signs which\r\nindicate the age of wine more truly than do wrinkles on a man\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\nThe major made a wise choice; he took the full glass and a biscuit. The\r\ncount told Baptistin to leave the plate within reach of his guest, who\r\nbegan by sipping the Alicante with an expression of great satisfaction,\r\nand then delicately steeped his biscuit in the wine.\r\n\r\n30123m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, sir, you lived at Lucca, did you? You were rich, noble, held in\r\ngreat esteem\xe2\x80\x94had all that could render a man happy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, hastily swallowing his biscuit, \xe2\x80\x9cpositively\r\nall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet there was one thing wanting in order to complete your\r\nhappiness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly one thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Italian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that one thing, your lost child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, taking a second biscuit, \xe2\x80\x9cthat consummation of my\r\nhappiness was indeed wanting.\xe2\x80\x9d The worthy major raised his eyes to\r\nheaven and sighed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me hear, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cwho this deeply regretted son\r\nwas; for I always understood you were a bachelor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was the general opinion, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, \xe2\x80\x9cand you confirmed the report. A youthful\r\nindiscretion, I suppose, which you were anxious to conceal from the\r\nworld at large?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe major recovered himself, and resumed his usual calm manner, at the\r\nsame time casting his eyes down, either to give himself time to compose\r\nhis countenance, or to assist his imagination, all the while giving an\r\nunder-look at the count, the protracted smile on whose lips still\r\nannounced the same polite curiosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, \xe2\x80\x9cI did wish this fault to be hidden from every\r\neye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot on your own account, surely,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cfor a man is\r\nabove that sort of thing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, certainly not on my own account,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major with a smile\r\nand a shake of the head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut for the sake of the mother?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, for the mother\xe2\x80\x99s sake\xe2\x80\x94his poor mother!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the major, taking a\r\nthird biscuit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake some more wine, my dear Cavalcanti,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, pouring out\r\nfor him a second glass of Alicante; \xe2\x80\x9cyour emotion has quite overcome\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis poor mother,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the major, trying to get the lachrymal\r\ngland in operation, so as to moisten the corner of his eye with a false\r\ntear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe belonged to one of the first families in Italy, I think, did she\r\nnot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe was of a noble family of Fiesole, count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd her name was\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you desire to know her name\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cit would be quite superfluous for you to tell\r\nme, for I already know it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count knows everything,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Italian, bowing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOliva Corsinari, was it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOliva Corsinari!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA marchioness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA marchioness!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you married her at last, notwithstanding the opposition of her\r\nfamily?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that was the way it ended.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have doubtless brought all your papers with you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte\r\nCristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat papers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe certificate of your marriage with Oliva Corsinari, and the\r\nregister of your child\xe2\x80\x99s birth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe register of my child\xe2\x80\x99s birth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe register of the birth of Andrea Cavalcanti\xe2\x80\x94of your son; is not his\r\nname Andrea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? You believe so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare not positively assert it, as he has been lost for so long a\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cyou have all the documents with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency, I regret to say that, not knowing it was necessary to\r\ncome provided with these papers, I neglected to bring them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is unfortunate,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere they, then, so necessary?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey were indispensable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe major passed his hand across his brow. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, _perbacco_,\r\nindispensable, were they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly they were; supposing there were to be doubts raised as to\r\nthe validity of your marriage or the legitimacy of your child?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, \xe2\x80\x9cthere might be doubts raised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case your son would be very unpleasantly situated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be fatal to his interests.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt might cause him to fail in some desirable matrimonial alliance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_O peccato!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must know that in France they are very particular on these points;\r\nit is not sufficient, as in Italy, to go to the priest and say, \xe2\x80\x98We\r\nlove each other, and want you to marry us.\xe2\x80\x99 Marriage is a civil affair\r\nin France, and in order to marry in an orthodox manner you must have\r\npapers which undeniably establish your identity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the misfortune! You see I have not these necessary papers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFortunately, I have them, though,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, who, seeing the object of his journey\r\nfrustrated by the absence of the papers, feared also that his\r\nforgetfulness might give rise to some difficulty concerning the 48,000\r\nfrancs\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cah, indeed, that is a fortunate circumstance; yes, that really\r\nis lucky, for it never occurred to me to bring them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not at all wonder at it\xe2\x80\x94one cannot think of everything; but,\r\nhappily, the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni thought for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is an excellent person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is extremely prudent and thoughtful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is an admirable man,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major; \xe2\x80\x9cand he sent them to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere they are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe major clasped his hands in token of admiration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou married Oliva Corsinari in the church of San Paolo del\r\nMonte-Cattini; here is the priest\xe2\x80\x99s certificate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes indeed, there it is truly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Italian, looking on with\r\nastonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd here is Andrea Cavalcanti\xe2\x80\x99s baptismal register, given by the cur\xc3\xa9\r\nof Saravezza.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll quite correct.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake these documents, then; they do not concern me. You will give them\r\nto your son, who will, of course, take great care of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think so, indeed! If he were to lose them\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and if he were to lose them?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the major, \xe2\x80\x9cit would be necessary to write to\r\nthe cur\xc3\xa9 for duplicates, and it would be some time before they could be\r\nobtained.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be a difficult matter to arrange,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlmost an impossibility,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the major.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very glad to see that you understand the value of these papers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI regard them as invaluable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cas to the mother of the young man\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to the mother of the young man\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the Italian, with\r\nanxiety.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs regards the Marchesa Corsinari\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, \xe2\x80\x9cdifficulties seem to thicken upon us; will\r\nshe be wanted in any way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbesides, has she not\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, \xe2\x80\x9cshe has\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30127m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPaid the last debt of nature?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the Italian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cshe has been dead these ten years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I am still mourning her loss,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the major, drawing from\r\nhis pocket a checked handkerchief, and alternately wiping first the\r\nleft and then the right eye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cwe are all mortal. Now, you\r\nunderstand, my dear Monsieur Cavalcanti, that it is useless for you to\r\ntell people in France that you have been separated from your son for\r\nfifteen years. Stories of gypsies, who steal children, are not at all\r\nin vogue in this part of the world, and would not be believed. You sent\r\nhim for his education to a college in one of the provinces, and now you\r\nwish him to complete his education in the Parisian world. That is the\r\nreason which has induced you to leave Via Reggio, where you have lived\r\nsince the death of your wife. That will be sufficient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf they should hear of the separation\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes; what could I say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat an unfaithful tutor, bought over by the enemies of your family\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the Corsinari?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely. Had stolen away this child, in order that your name might\r\nbecome extinct.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is reasonable, since he is an only son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now that all is arranged, do not let these newly awakened\r\nremembrances be forgotten. You have, doubtless, already guessed that I\r\nwas preparing a surprise for you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn agreeable one?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Italian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, I see the eye of a father is no more to be deceived than his\r\nheart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHum!\xe2\x80\x9d said the major.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomeone has told you the secret; or, perhaps, you guessed that he was\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat who was here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour child\xe2\x80\x94your son\xe2\x80\x94your Andrea!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did guess it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the major with the greatest possible\r\ncoolness. \xe2\x80\x9cThen he is here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cwhen the valet de chambre came in just\r\nnow, he told me of his arrival.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, very well, very well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, clutching the buttons of\r\nhis coat at each exclamation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI understand your emotion; you must\r\nhave time to recover yourself. I will, in the meantime, go and prepare\r\nthe young man for this much-desired interview, for I presume that he is\r\nnot less impatient for it than yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should quite imagine that to be the case,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cavalcanti.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, in a quarter of an hour he shall be with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will bring him, then? You carry your goodness so far as even to\r\npresent him to me yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I do not wish to come between a father and son. Your interview\r\nwill be private. But do not be uneasy; even if the powerful voice of\r\nnature should be silent, you cannot well mistake him; he will enter by\r\nthis door. He is a fine young man, of fair complexion\xe2\x80\x94a little too\r\nfair, perhaps\xe2\x80\x94pleasing in manners; but you will see and judge for\r\nyourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the way,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know I have only the 2,000 francs\r\nwhich the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni sent me; this sum I have expended upon travelling\r\nexpenses, and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you want money; that is a matter of course, my dear M. Cavalcanti.\r\nWell, here are 8,000 francs on account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe major\xe2\x80\x99s eyes sparkled brilliantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is 40,000 francs which I now owe you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes your excellency wish for a receipt?\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, at the same\r\ntime slipping the money into the inner pocket of his coat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor what?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought you might want it to show the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, when you receive the remaining 40,000, you shall give me a\r\nreceipt in full. Between honest men such excessive precaution is, I\r\nthink, quite unnecessary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, so it is, between perfectly upright people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne word more,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will permit me to make one remark?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; pray do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I should advise you to leave off wearing that style of dress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, regarding himself with an air of complete\r\nsatisfaction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. It may be worn at Via Reggio; but that costume, however elegant\r\nin itself, has long been out of fashion in Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s unfortunate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if you really are attached to your old mode of dress; you can\r\neasily resume it when you leave Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what shall I wear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you find in your trunks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn my trunks? I have but one portmanteau.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say you have nothing else with you. What is the use of boring\r\none\xe2\x80\x99s self with so many things? Besides an old soldier always likes to\r\nmarch with as little baggage as possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is just the case\xe2\x80\x94precisely so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you are a man of foresight and prudence, therefore you sent your\r\nluggage on before you. It has arrived at the H\xc3\xb4tel des Princes, Rue de\r\nRichelieu. It is there you are to take up your quarters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, in these trunks\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI presume you have given orders to your valet de chambre to put in all\r\nyou are likely to need,\xe2\x80\x94your plain clothes and your uniform. On grand\r\noccasions you must wear your uniform; that will look very well. Do not\r\nforget your crosses. They still laugh at them in France, and yet always\r\nwear them, for all that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, very well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, who was in ecstasy at the\r\nattention paid him by the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you have fortified yourself against all\r\npainful excitement, prepare yourself, my dear M. Cavalcanti, to meet\r\nyour lost Andrea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSaying which Monte Cristo bowed, and disappeared behind the tapestry,\r\nleaving the major fascinated beyond expression with the delightful\r\nreception which he had received at the hands of the count.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 56. Andrea Cavalcanti\r\n\r\nThe Count of Monte Cristo entered the adjoining room, which Baptistin\r\nhad designated as the drawing-room, and found there a young man, of\r\ngraceful demeanor and elegant appearance, who had arrived in a cab\r\nabout half an hour previously. Baptistin had not found any difficulty\r\nin recognizing the person who presented himself at the door for\r\nadmittance. He was certainly the tall young man with light hair, red\r\nbeard, black eyes, and brilliant complexion, whom his master had so\r\nparticularly described to him. When the count entered the room the\r\nyoung man was carelessly stretched on a sofa, tapping his boot with the\r\ngold-headed cane which he held in his hand. On perceiving the count he\r\nrose quickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Count of Monte Cristo, I believe?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, and I think I have the honor of addressing Count Andrea\r\nCavalcanti?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount Andrea Cavalcanti,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the young man, accompanying his\r\nwords with a bow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are charged with a letter of introduction addressed to me, are you\r\nnot?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not mention that, because the signature seemed to me so\r\nstrange.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe letter signed \xe2\x80\x98Sinbad the Sailor,\xe2\x80\x99 is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so. Now, as I have never known any Sinbad, with the exception\r\nof the one celebrated in the _Thousand and One Nights_\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it is one of his descendants, and a great friend of mine; he is\r\na very rich Englishman, eccentric almost to insanity, and his real name\r\nis Lord Wilmore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed? Then that explains everything that is extraordinary,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAndrea. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is, then, the same Englishman whom I met\xe2\x80\x94at\xe2\x80\x94ah\xe2\x80\x94yes, indeed.\r\nWell, monsieur, I am at your service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf what you say be true,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps you\r\nwill be kind enough to give me some account of yourself and your\r\nfamily?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, I will do so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, with a quickness which\r\ngave proof of his ready invention. \xe2\x80\x9cI am (as you have said) the Count\r\nAndrea Cavalcanti, son of Major Bartolomeo Cavalcanti, a descendant of\r\nthe Cavalcanti whose names are inscribed in the golden book at\r\nFlorence. Our family, although still rich (for my father\xe2\x80\x99s income\r\namounts to half a million), has experienced many misfortunes, and I\r\nmyself was, at the age of five years, taken away by the treachery of my\r\ntutor, so that for fifteen years I have not seen the author of my\r\nexistence. Since I have arrived at years of discretion and become my\r\nown master, I have been constantly seeking him, but all in vain. At\r\nlength I received this letter from your friend, which states that my\r\nfather is in Paris, and authorizes me to address myself to you for\r\ninformation respecting him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, all you have related to me is exceedingly interesting,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMonte Cristo, observing the young man with a gloomy satisfaction; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nyou have done well to conform in everything to the wishes of my friend\r\nSinbad; for your father is indeed here, and is seeking you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count from the moment of first entering the drawing-room, had not\r\nonce lost sight of the expression of the young man\xe2\x80\x99s countenance; he\r\nhad admired the assurance of his look and the firmness of his voice;\r\nbut at these words, so natural in themselves, \xe2\x80\x9cYour father is indeed\r\nhere, and is seeking you,\xe2\x80\x9d young Andrea started, and exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cMy\r\nfather? Is my father here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost undoubtedly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cyour father, Major\r\nBartolomeo Cavalcanti.\xe2\x80\x9d The expression of terror which, for the moment,\r\nhad overspread the features of the young man, had now disappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes, that is the name, certainly. Major Bartolomeo Cavalcanti. And\r\nyou really mean to say; monsieur, that my dear father is here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir; and I can even add that I have only just left his company.\r\nThe history which he related to me of his lost son touched me to the\r\nquick; indeed, his griefs, hopes, and fears on that subject might\r\nfurnish material for a most touching and pathetic poem. At length, he\r\none day received a letter, stating that the abductors of his son now\r\noffered to restore him, or at least to give notice where he might be\r\nfound, on condition of receiving a large sum of money, by way of\r\nransom. Your father did not hesitate an instant, and the sum was sent\r\nto the frontier of Piedmont, with a passport signed for Italy. You were\r\nin the south of France, I think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Andrea, with an embarrassed air, \xe2\x80\x9cI was in the south of\r\nFrance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA carriage was to await you at Nice?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely so; and it conveyed me from Nice to Genoa, from Genoa to\r\nTurin, from Turin to Chamb\xc3\xa9ry, from Chamb\xc3\xa9ry to Pont-de-Beauvoisin, and\r\nfrom Pont-de-Beauvoisin to Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30133m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed? Then your father ought to have met with you on the road, for\r\nit is exactly the same route which he himself took, and that is how we\r\nhave been able to trace your journey to this place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9cif my father had met me, I doubt if he would have\r\nrecognized me; I must be somewhat altered since he last saw me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the voice of nature,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cI had not looked upon it in that\r\nlight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cthere is only one source of uneasiness\r\nleft in your father\xe2\x80\x99s mind, which is this\xe2\x80\x94he is anxious to know how you\r\nhave been employed during your long absence from him, how you have been\r\ntreated by your persecutors, and if they have conducted themselves\r\ntowards you with all the deference due to your rank. Finally, he is\r\nanxious to see if you have been fortunate enough to escape the bad\r\nmoral influence to which you have been exposed, and which is infinitely\r\nmore to be dreaded than any physical suffering; he wishes to discover\r\nif the fine abilities with which nature had endowed you have been\r\nweakened by want of culture; and, in short, whether you consider\r\nyourself capable of resuming and retaining in the world the high\r\nposition to which your rank entitles you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the young man, quite astounded, \xe2\x80\x9cI hope no false\r\nreport\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs for myself, I first heard you spoken of by my friend Wilmore, the\r\nphilanthropist. I believe he found you in some unpleasant position, but\r\ndo not know of what nature, for I did not ask, not being inquisitive.\r\nYour misfortunes engaged his sympathies, so you see you must have been\r\ninteresting. He told me that he was anxious to restore you to the\r\nposition which you had lost, and that he would seek your father until\r\nhe found him. He did seek, and has found him, apparently, since he is\r\nhere now; and, finally, my friend apprised me of your coming, and gave\r\nme a few other instructions relative to your future fortune. I am quite\r\naware that my friend Wilmore is peculiar, but he is sincere, and as\r\nrich as a gold mine, consequently, he may indulge his eccentricities\r\nwithout any fear of their ruining him, and I have promised to adhere to\r\nhis instructions. Now, sir, pray do not be offended at the question I\r\nam about to put to you, as it comes in the way of my duty as your\r\npatron. I would wish to know if the misfortunes which have happened to\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x94misfortunes entirely beyond your control, and which in no degree\r\ndiminish my regard for you\xe2\x80\x94I would wish to know if they have not, in\r\nsome measure, contributed to render you a stranger to the world in\r\nwhich your fortune and your name entitle you to make a conspicuous\r\nfigure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the young man, with a reassurance of manner, \xe2\x80\x9cmake your\r\nmind easy on this score. Those who took me from my father, and who\r\nalways intended, sooner or later, to sell me again to my original\r\nproprietor, as they have now done, calculated that, in order to make\r\nthe most of their bargain, it would be politic to leave me in\r\npossession of all my personal and hereditary worth, and even to\r\nincrease the value, if possible. I have, therefore, received a very\r\ngood education, and have been treated by these kidnappers very much as\r\nthe slaves were treated in Asia Minor, whose masters made them\r\ngrammarians, doctors, and philosophers, in order that they might fetch\r\na higher price in the Roman market.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo smiled with satisfaction; it appeared as if he had not\r\nexpected so much from M. Andrea Cavalcanti.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cif there did appear some defect in\r\neducation, or offence against the established forms of etiquette, I\r\nsuppose it would be excused, in consideration of the misfortunes which\r\naccompanied my birth, and followed me through my youth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo in an indifferent tone, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will do as you\r\nplease, count, for you are the master of your own actions, and are the\r\nperson most concerned in the matter, but if I were you, I would not\r\ndivulge a word of these adventures. Your history is quite a romance,\r\nand the world, which delights in romances in yellow covers, strangely\r\nmistrusts those which are bound in living parchment, even though they\r\nbe gilded like yourself. This is the kind of difficulty which I wished\r\nto represent to you, my dear count. You would hardly have recited your\r\ntouching history before it would go forth to the world, and be deemed\r\nunlikely and unnatural. You would be no longer a lost child found, but\r\nyou would be looked upon as an upstart, who had sprung up like a\r\nmushroom in the night. You might excite a little curiosity, but it is\r\nnot everyone who likes to be made the centre of observation and the\r\nsubject of unpleasant remark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI agree with you, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, turning pale, and, in\r\nspite of himself, trembling beneath the scrutinizing look of his\r\ncompanion, \xe2\x80\x9csuch consequences would be extremely unpleasant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless, you must not exaggerate the evil,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfor by endeavoring to avoid one fault you will fall into another. You\r\nmust resolve upon one simple and single line of conduct, and for a man\r\nof your intelligence, this plan is as easy as it is necessary; you must\r\nform honorable friendships, and by that means counteract the prejudice\r\nwhich may attach to the obscurity of your former life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea visibly changed countenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would offer myself as your surety and friendly adviser,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte\r\nCristo, \xe2\x80\x9cdid I not possess a moral distrust of my best friends, and a\r\nsort of inclination to lead others to doubt them too; therefore, in\r\ndeparting from this rule, I should (as the actors say) be playing a\r\npart quite out of my line, and should, therefore, run the risk of being\r\nhissed, which would be an act of folly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHowever, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9cin consideration of Lord\r\nWilmore, by whom I was recommended to you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, certainly,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut Lord Wilmore did not\r\nomit to inform me, my dear M. Andrea, that the season of your youth was\r\nrather a stormy one. Ah,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, watching Andrea\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncountenance, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not demand any confession from you; it is precisely\r\nto avoid that necessity that your father was sent for from Lucca. You\r\nshall soon see him. He is a little stiff and pompous in his manner, and\r\nhe is disfigured by his uniform; but when it becomes known that he has\r\nbeen for eighteen years in the Austrian service, all that will be\r\npardoned. We are not generally very severe with the Austrians. In\r\nshort, you will find your father a very presentable person, I assure\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, sir, you have given me confidence; it is so long since we were\r\nseparated, that I have not the least remembrance of him, and, besides,\r\nyou know that in the eyes of the world a large fortune covers all\r\ndefects.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a millionaire\xe2\x80\x94his income is 500,000 francs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, with anxiety, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall be sure to be placed\r\nin an agreeable position.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of the most agreeable possible, my dear sir; he will allow you an\r\nincome of 50,000 livres per annum during the whole time of your stay in\r\nParis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen in that case I shall always choose to remain there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou cannot control circumstances, my dear sir; \xe2\x80\x98man proposes, and God\r\ndisposes.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Andrea sighed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cso long as I do remain in Paris, and nothing forces me\r\nto quit it, do you mean to tell me that I may rely on receiving the sum\r\nyou just now mentioned to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I receive it from my father?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Andrea, with some\r\nuneasiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you will receive it from your father personally, but Lord Wilmore\r\nwill be the security for the money. He has, at the request of your\r\nfather, opened an account of 5,000 francs a month at M. Danglars\xe2\x80\x99,\r\nwhich is one of the safest banks in Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd does my father mean to remain long in Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Andrea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly a few days,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cHis service does not allow\r\nhim to absent himself more than two or three weeks together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear father!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Andrea, evidently charmed with the idea\r\nof his speedy departure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTherefore,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo feigning to mistake his\r\nmeaning\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ctherefore I will not, for another instant, retard the pleasure\r\nof your meeting. Are you prepared to embrace your worthy father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you do not doubt it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30137m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, then, into the drawing-room, my young friend, where you will find\r\nyour father awaiting you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea made a low bow to the count, and entered the adjoining room.\r\nMonte Cristo watched him till he disappeared, and then touched a spring\r\nin a panel made to look like a picture, which, in sliding partly from\r\nthe frame, discovered to view a small opening, so cleverly contrived\r\nthat it revealed all that was passing in the drawing-room now occupied\r\nby Cavalcanti and Andrea. The young man closed the door behind him, and\r\nadvanced towards the major, who had risen when he heard steps\r\napproaching him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear father!\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea in a loud voice, in order that the\r\ncount might hear him in the next room, \xe2\x80\x9cis it really you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you do, my dear son?\xe2\x80\x9d said the major gravely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter so many years of painful separation,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, in the same\r\ntone of voice, and glancing towards the door, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a happiness it is\r\nto meet again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed it is, after so long a separation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you not embrace me, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea.\r\n\r\n30139m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you wish it, my son,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major; and the two men embraced each\r\nother after the fashion of actors on the stage; that is to say, each\r\nrested his head on the other\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen we are once more reunited?\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnce more,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the major.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever more to be separated?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, as to that\xe2\x80\x94I think, my dear son, you must be by this time so\r\naccustomed to France as to look upon it almost as a second country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I should be exceedingly\r\ngrieved to leave it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs for me, you must know I cannot possibly live out of Lucca;\r\ntherefore I shall return to Italy as soon as I can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut before you leave France, my dear father, I hope you will put me in\r\npossession of the documents which will be necessary to prove my\r\ndescent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; I am come expressly on that account; it has cost me much\r\ntrouble to find you, but I had resolved on giving them into your hands,\r\nand if I had to recommence my search, it would occupy all the few\r\nremaining years of my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are these papers, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere they are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea seized the certificate of his father\xe2\x80\x99s marriage and his own\r\nbaptismal register, and after having opened them with all the eagerness\r\nwhich might be expected under the circumstances, he read them with a\r\nfacility which proved that he was accustomed to similar documents, and\r\nwith an expression which plainly denoted an unusual interest in the\r\ncontents. When he had perused the documents, an indefinable expression\r\nof pleasure lighted up his countenance, and looking at the major with a\r\nmost peculiar smile, he said, in very excellent Tuscan:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen there is no longer any such thing, in Italy as being condemned to\r\nthe galleys?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe major drew himself up to his full height.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x94what do you mean by that question?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean that if there were, it would be impossible to draw up with\r\nimpunity two such deeds as these. In France, my dear sir, half such a\r\npiece of effrontery as that would cause you to be quickly despatched to\r\nToulon for five years, for change of air.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you be good enough to explain your meaning?\xe2\x80\x9d said the major,\r\nendeavoring as much as possible to assume an air of the greatest\r\nmajesty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear M. Cavalcanti,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, taking the major by the arm in a\r\nconfidential manner, \xe2\x80\x9chow much are you paid for being my father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe major was about to speak, when Andrea continued, in a low voice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, I am going to set you an example of confidence, they give me\r\n50,000 francs a year to be your son; consequently, you can understand\r\nthat it is not at all likely I shall ever deny my parent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe major looked anxiously around him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMake yourself easy, we are quite alone,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea; \xe2\x80\x9cbesides, we are\r\nconversing in Italian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the major, \xe2\x80\x9cthey paid me 50,000 francs down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Cavalcanti,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you believe in fairy tales?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI used not to do so, but I really feel now almost obliged to have\r\nfaith in them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have, then, been induced to alter your opinion; you have had some\r\nproofs of their truth?\xe2\x80\x9d The major drew from his pocket a handful of\r\ngold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost palpable proofs,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cas you may perceive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think, then, that I may rely on the count\xe2\x80\x99s promises?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are sure he will keep his word with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the letter, but at the same time, remember, we must continue to\r\nplay our respective parts. I, as a tender father\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I as a dutiful son, as they choose that I shall be descended from\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom do you mean by they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi_, I can hardly tell, but I was alluding to those who wrote the\r\nletter; you received one, did you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom a certain Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you any knowledge of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I have never seen him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did he say in the letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will promise not to betray me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRest assured of that; you well know that our interests are the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen read for yourself;\xe2\x80\x9d and the major gave a letter into the young\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s hand. Andrea read in a low voice:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98You are poor; a miserable old age awaits you. Would you like to\r\nbecome rich, or at least independent? Set out immediately for Paris,\r\nand demand of the Count of Monte Cristo, Avenue des Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es, No.\r\n30, the son whom you had by the Marchesa Corsinari, and who was taken\r\nfrom you at five years of age. This son is named Andrea Cavalcanti. In\r\norder that you may not doubt the kind intention of the writer of this\r\nletter, you will find enclosed an order for 2,400 francs, payable in\r\nFlorence, at Signor Gozzi\xe2\x80\x99s; also a letter of introduction to the Count\r\nof Monte Cristo, on whom I give you a draft of 48,000 francs. Do you\r\nwish for a name? should you like to be rich, and your own master?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Parbleu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man; \xe2\x80\x9cwas it possible there could be two\r\nanswers to such a question?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Take the post-chaise which you will find waiting at the Porte de\r\nG\xc3\xaanes, as you enter Nice; pass through Turin, Chamb\xc3\xa9ry, and\r\nPont-de-Beauvoisin. Go to the Count of Monte Cristo, Avenue des\r\nChamps-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es, on the 26th of May, at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening,\r\nand demand of him your father. You are the son of the Marchese\r\nCavalcanti and the Marchesa Oliva Corsinari. The marquis will give you\r\nsome papers which will certify this fact, and authorize you to appear\r\nunder that name in the Parisian world. As to your rank, an annual\r\nincome of 50,000 livres will enable you to support it admirably. I\r\nenclose a draft for 5,000 livres, payable on M. Ferrea, banker at Nice,\r\nand also a letter of introduction to the Count of Monte Cristo, whom I\r\nhave directed to supply all your wants.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Sinbad the Sailor.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumph,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major; \xe2\x80\x9cvery good. We must play the game to the end, and\r\nconsent to be blindfolded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you shall see; I promise you I will sustain my part to\r\nadmiration.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never once doubted your doing so.\xe2\x80\x9d Monte Cristo chose this moment\r\nfor re-entering the drawing-room. On hearing the sound of his\r\nfootsteps, the two men threw themselves in each other\xe2\x80\x99s arms, and while\r\nthey were in the midst of this embrace, the count entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, marquis,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cyou appear to be in no way\r\ndisappointed in the son whom your good fortune has restored to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, your excellency, I am overwhelmed with delight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what are your feelings?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, turning to the young\r\nman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs for me, my heart is overflowing with happiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHappy father, happy son!\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is only one thing which grieves me,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the major, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nthat is the necessity for my leaving Paris so soon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear M.
