Well, then,\r\nhe deputes me to give you this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I to consider this as part of my income on account?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it is for the first expenses of your settling in Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, how good my dear father is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9che does not wish you to know that it\r\ncomes from him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fully appreciate his delicacy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, cramming the notes\r\nhastily into his pocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, gentlemen, I wish you good-morning,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when shall we have the honor of seeing you again, your\r\nexcellency?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Cavalcanti.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen may we hope for that pleasure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn Saturday, if you will\xe2\x80\x94Yes.\xe2\x80\x94Let me see\xe2\x80\x94Saturday\xe2\x80\x94I am to dine at my\r\ncountry house, at Auteuil, on that day, Rue de la Fontaine, No. 28.\r\nSeveral persons are invited, and among others, M. Danglars, your\r\nbanker. I will introduce you to him, for it will be necessary he should\r\nknow you, as he is to pay your money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFull dress?\xe2\x80\x9d said the major, half aloud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, certainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cuniform, cross, knee-breeches.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how shall I be dressed?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Andrea.\r\n\r\n30145m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, very simply; black trousers, patent leather boots, white\r\nwaistcoat, either a black or blue coat, and a long cravat. Go to Blin\r\nor V\xc3\xa9ronique for your clothes. Baptistin will tell you where, if you do\r\nnot know their address. The less pretension there is in your attire,\r\nthe better will be the effect, as you are a rich man. If you mean to\r\nbuy any horses, get them of Devedeux, and if you purchase a phaeton, go\r\nto Baptiste for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt what hour shall we come?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout half-past six.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will be with you at that time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the major. The two Cavalcanti\r\nbowed to the count, and left the house. Monte Cristo went to the\r\nwindow, and saw them crossing the street, arm in arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere go two miscreants;\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cit is a pity they are not really\r\nrelated!\xe2\x80\x9d Then, after an instant of gloomy reflection, \xe2\x80\x9cCome, I will go\r\nto see the Morrels,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cI think that disgust is even more\r\nsickening than hatred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30147m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 57. In the Lucern Patch\r\n\r\nOur readers must now allow us to transport them again to the enclosure\r\nsurrounding M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s house, and, behind the gate, half\r\nscreened from view by the large chestnut-trees, which on all sides\r\nspread their luxuriant branches, we shall find some people of our\r\nacquaintance. This time Maximilian was the first to arrive. He was\r\nintently watching for a shadow to appear among the trees, and awaiting\r\nwith anxiety the sound of a light step on the gravel walk.\r\n\r\nAt length, the long-desired sound was heard, and instead of one figure,\r\nas he had expected, he perceived that two were approaching him. The\r\ndelay had been occasioned by a visit from Madame Danglars and Eug\xc3\xa9nie,\r\nwhich had been prolonged beyond the time at which Valentine was\r\nexpected. That she might not appear to fail in her promise to\r\nMaximilian, she proposed to Mademoiselle Danglars that they should take\r\na walk in the garden, being anxious to show that the delay, which was\r\ndoubtless a cause of vexation to him, was not occasioned by any neglect\r\non her part. The young man, with the intuitive perception of a lover,\r\nquickly understood the circumstances in which she was involuntarily\r\nplaced, and he was comforted. Besides, although she avoided coming\r\nwithin speaking distance, Valentine arranged so that Maximilian could\r\nsee her pass and repass, and each time she went by, she managed,\r\nunperceived by her companion, to cast an expressive look at the young\r\nman, which seemed to say, \xe2\x80\x9cHave patience! You see it is not my fault.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Maximilian was patient, and employed himself in mentally\r\ncontrasting the two girls,\xe2\x80\x94one fair, with soft languishing eyes, a\r\nfigure gracefully bending like a weeping willow; the other a brunette,\r\nwith a fierce and haughty expression, and as straight as a poplar. It\r\nis unnecessary to state that, in the eyes of the young man, Valentine\r\ndid not suffer by the contrast. In about half an hour the girls went\r\naway, and Maximilian understood that Mademoiselle Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 visit had\r\nat last come to an end. In a few minutes Valentine re-entered the\r\ngarden alone. For fear that anyone should be observing her return, she\r\nwalked slowly; and instead of immediately directing her steps towards\r\nthe gate, she seated herself on a bench, and, carefully casting her\r\neyes around, to convince herself that she was not watched, she\r\npresently arose, and proceeded quickly to join Maximilian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-evening, Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said a well-known voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-evening, Maximilian; I know I have kept you waiting, but you saw\r\nthe cause of my delay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I recognized Mademoiselle Danglars. I was not aware that you were\r\nso intimate with her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho told you we were intimate, Maximilian?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one, but you appeared to be so. From the manner in which you walked\r\nand talked together, one would have thought you were two school-girls\r\ntelling your secrets to each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe were having a confidential conversation,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cshe\r\nwas owning to me her repugnance to the marriage with M. de Morcerf; and\r\nI, on the other hand, was confessing to her how wretched it made me to\r\nthink of marrying M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Valentine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will account to you for the unreserved manner which you observed\r\nbetween me and Eug\xc3\xa9nie, as in speaking of the man whom I could not\r\nlove, my thoughts involuntarily reverted to him on whom my affections\r\nwere fixed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, how good you are to say so, Valentine! You possess a quality which\r\ncan never belong to Mademoiselle Danglars. It is that indefinable charm\r\nwhich is to a woman what perfume is to the flower and flavor to the\r\nfruit, for the beauty of either is not the only quality we seek.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is your love which makes you look upon everything in that light.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Valentine, I assure you such is not the case. I was observing you\r\nboth when you were walking in the garden, and, on my honor, without at\r\nall wishing to depreciate the beauty of Mademoiselle Danglars, I cannot\r\nunderstand how any man can really love her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is, Maximilian, that I was there, and my presence had the\r\neffect of rendering you unjust in your comparison.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but tell me\xe2\x80\x94it is a question of simple curiosity, and which was\r\nsuggested by certain ideas passing in my mind relative to Mademoiselle\r\nDanglars\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare say it is something disparaging which you are going to say. It\r\nonly proves how little indulgence we may expect from your sex,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ninterrupted Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou cannot, at least, deny that you are very harsh judges of each\r\nother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we are so, it is because we generally judge under the influence of\r\nexcitement. But return to your question.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30151m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes Mademoiselle Danglars object to this marriage with M. de Morcerf\r\non account of loving another?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told you I was not on terms of strict intimacy with Eug\xc3\xa9nie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but girls tell each other secrets without being particularly\r\nintimate; own, now, that you did question her on the subject. Ah, I see\r\nyou are smiling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are already aware of the conversation that passed, the wooden\r\npartition which interposed between us and you has proved but a slight\r\nsecurity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, what did she say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe told me that she loved no one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cthat she disliked\r\nthe idea of being married; that she would infinitely prefer leading an\r\nindependent and unfettered life; and that she almost wished her father\r\nmight lose his fortune, that she might become an artist, like her\r\nfriend, Mademoiselle Louise d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you see\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what does that prove?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Maximilian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen why did you smile?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you know very well that you are reflecting on yourself,\r\nValentine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you want me to go away?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, no, no. But do not let us lose time; you are the subject on which\r\nI wish to speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, we must be quick, for we have scarcely ten minutes more to pass\r\ntogether.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, in consternation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you are right; I am but a poor friend to you. What a life I cause\r\nyou to lead, poor Maximilian, you who are formed for happiness! I\r\nbitterly reproach myself, I assure you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what does it signify, Valentine, so long as I am satisfied, and\r\nfeel that even this long and painful suspense is amply repaid by five\r\nminutes of your society, or two words from your lips? And I have also a\r\ndeep conviction that heaven would not have created two hearts,\r\nharmonizing as ours do, and almost miraculously brought us together, to\r\nseparate us at last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose are kind and cheering words. You must hope for us both,\r\nMaximilian; that will make me at least partly happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why must you leave me so soon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know particulars. I can only tell you that Madame de\r\nVillefort sent to request my presence, as she had a communication to\r\nmake on which a part of my fortune depended. Let them take my fortune,\r\nI am already too rich; and, perhaps, when they have taken it, they will\r\nleave me in peace and quietness. You would love me as much if I were\r\npoor, would you not, Maximilian?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I shall always love you. What should I care for either riches or\r\npoverty, if my Valentine was near me, and I felt certain that no one\r\ncould deprive me of her? But do you not fear that this communication\r\nmay relate to your marriage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think that is the case.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHowever it may be, Valentine, you must not be alarmed. I assure you\r\nthat, as long as I live, I shall never love anyone else!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think to reassure me when you say that, Maximilian?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, you are right. I am a brute. But I was going to tell you\r\nthat I met M. de Morcerf the other day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Franz is his friend, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur de Morcerf has received a letter from Franz, announcing his\r\nimmediate return.\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine turned pale, and leaned her hand against\r\nthe gate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh heavens, if it were that! But no, the communication would not come\r\nthrough Madame de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause\xe2\x80\x94I scarcely know why\xe2\x80\x94but it has appeared as if Madame de\r\nVillefort secretly objected to the marriage, although she did not\r\nchoose openly to oppose it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it so? Then I feel as if I could adore Madame de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not be in such a hurry to do that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, with a sad\r\nsmile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf she objects to your marrying M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, she would be all the more\r\nlikely to listen to any other proposition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Maximilian, it is not suitors to which Madame de Villefort\r\nobjects, it is marriage itself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarriage? If she dislikes that so much, why did she ever marry\r\nherself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not understand me, Maximilian. About a year ago, I talked of\r\nretiring to a convent. Madame de Villefort, in spite of all the remarks\r\nwhich she considered it her duty to make, secretly approved of the\r\nproposition, my father consented to it at her instigation, and it was\r\nonly on account of my poor grandfather that I finally abandoned the\r\nproject. You can form no idea of the expression of that old man\xe2\x80\x99s eye\r\nwhen he looks at me, the only person in the world whom he loves, and, I\r\nhad almost said, by whom he is beloved in return. When he learned my\r\nresolution, I shall never forget the reproachful look which he cast on\r\nme, and the tears of utter despair which chased each other down his\r\nlifeless cheeks. Ah, Maximilian, I experienced, at that moment, such\r\nremorse for my intention, that, throwing myself at his feet, I\r\nexclaimed,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Forgive me, pray forgive me, my dear grandfather; they may\r\ndo what they will with me, I will never leave you.\xe2\x80\x99 When I had ceased\r\nspeaking, he thankfully raised his eyes to heaven, but without uttering\r\na word. Ah, Maximilian, I may have much to suffer, but I feel as if my\r\ngrandfather\xe2\x80\x99s look at that moment would more than compensate for all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Valentine, you are a perfect angel, and I am sure I do not know\r\nwhat I\xe2\x80\x94sabring right and left among the Bedouins\xe2\x80\x94can have done to merit\r\nyour being revealed to me, unless, indeed, Heaven took into\r\nconsideration the fact that the victims of my sword were infidels. But\r\ntell me what interest Madame de Villefort can have in your remaining\r\nunmarried?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I not tell you just now that I was rich, Maximilian\xe2\x80\x94too rich? I\r\npossess nearly 50,000 livres in right of my mother; my grandfather and\r\nmy grandmother, the Marquis and Marquise de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, will leave me\r\nas much, and M. Noirtier evidently intends making me his heir. My\r\nbrother Edward, who inherits nothing from his mother, will, therefore,\r\nbe poor in comparison with me. Now, if I had taken the veil, all this\r\nfortune would have descended to my father, and, in reversion, to his\r\nson.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, how strange it seems that such a young and beautiful woman should\r\nbe so avaricious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not for herself that she is so, but for her son, and what you\r\nregard as a vice becomes almost a virtue when looked at in the light of\r\nmaternal love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut could you not compromise matters, and give up a portion of your\r\nfortune to her son?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow could I make such a proposition, especially to a woman who always\r\nprofesses to be so entirely disinterested?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine, I have always regarded our love in the light of something\r\nsacred; consequently, I have covered it with the veil of respect, and\r\nhid it in the innermost recesses of my soul. No human being, not even\r\nmy sister, is aware of its existence. Valentine, will you permit me to\r\nmake a confidant of a friend and reveal to him the love I bear you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine started. \xe2\x80\x9cA friend, Maximilian; and who is this friend? I\r\ntremble to give my permission.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, Valentine. Have you never experienced for anyone that sudden\r\nand irresistible sympathy which made you feel as if the object of it\r\nhad been your old and familiar friend, though, in reality, it was the\r\nfirst time you had ever met? Nay, further, have you never endeavored to\r\nrecall the time, place, and circumstances of your former intercourse,\r\nand failing in this attempt, have almost believed that your spirits\r\nmust have held converse with each other in some state of being anterior\r\nto the present, and that you are only now occupied in a reminiscence of\r\nthe past?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that is precisely the feeling which I experienced when I first\r\nsaw that extraordinary man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExtraordinary, did you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have known him for some time, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cScarcely longer than eight or ten days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you call a man your friend whom you have only known for eight\r\nor ten days? Ah, Maximilian, I had hoped you set a higher value on the\r\ntitle of friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour logic is most powerful, Valentine, but say what you will, I can\r\nnever renounce the sentiment which has instinctively taken possession\r\nof my mind. I feel as if it were ordained that this man should be\r\nassociated with all the good which the future may have in store for me,\r\nand sometimes it really seems as if his eye was able to see what was to\r\ncome, and his hand endowed with the power of directing events according\r\nto his own will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must be a prophet, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cI have often been almost tempted to\r\nattribute to him the gift of prophecy; at all events, he has a\r\nwonderful power of foretelling any future good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine in a mournful tone, \xe2\x80\x9cdo let me see this man,\r\nMaximilian; he may tell me whether I shall ever be loved sufficiently\r\nto make amends for all I have suffered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy poor girl, you know him already.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; it was he who saved the life of your step-mother and her son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Count of Monte Cristo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9che is too much the friend of Madame de\r\nVillefort ever to be mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe friend of Madame de Villefort! It cannot be; surely, Valentine,\r\nyou are mistaken?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed, I am not; for I assure you, his power over our household\r\nis almost unlimited. Courted by my step-mother, who regards him as the\r\nepitome of human wisdom; admired by my father, who says he has never\r\nbefore heard such sublime ideas so eloquently expressed; idolized by\r\nEdward, who, notwithstanding his fear of the count\xe2\x80\x99s large black eyes,\r\nruns to meet him the moment he arrives, and opens his hand, in which he\r\nis sure to find some delightful present,\xe2\x80\x94M. de Monte Cristo appears to\r\nexert a mysterious and almost uncontrollable influence over all the\r\nmembers of our family.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf such be the case, my dear Valentine, you must yourself have felt,\r\nor at all events will soon feel, the effects of his presence. He meets\r\nAlbert de Morcerf in Italy\xe2\x80\x94it is to rescue him from the hands of the\r\nbanditti; he introduces himself to Madame Danglars\xe2\x80\x94it is that he may\r\ngive her a royal present; your step-mother and her son pass before his\r\ndoor\xe2\x80\x94it is that his Nubian may save them from destruction. This man\r\nevidently possesses the power of influencing events, both as regards\r\nmen and things. I never saw more simple tastes united to greater\r\nmagnificence. His smile is so sweet when he addresses me, that I forget\r\nit ever can be bitter to others. Ah, Valentine, tell me, if he ever\r\nlooked on you with one of those sweet smiles? if so, depend on it, you\r\nwill be happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe?\xe2\x80\x9d said the young girl, \xe2\x80\x9che never even glances at me; on the\r\ncontrary, if I accidentally cross his path, he appears rather to avoid\r\nme. Ah, he is not generous, neither does he possess that supernatural\r\npenetration which you attribute to him, for if he did, he would have\r\nperceived that I was unhappy; and if he had been generous, seeing me\r\nsad and solitary, he would have used his influence to my advantage, and\r\nsince, as you say, he resembles the sun, he would have warmed my heart\r\nwith one of his life-giving rays. You say he loves you, Maximilian; how\r\ndo you know that he does? All would pay deference to an officer like\r\nyou, with a fierce moustache and a long sabre, but they think they may\r\ncrush a poor weeping girl with impunity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Valentine, I assure you you are mistaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it were otherwise\xe2\x80\x94if he treated me diplomatically\xe2\x80\x94that is to say,\r\nlike a man who wishes, by some means or other, to obtain a footing in\r\nthe house, so that he may ultimately gain the power of dictating to its\r\noccupants\xe2\x80\x94he would, if it had been but once, have honored me with the\r\nsmile which you extol so loudly; but no, he saw that I was unhappy, he\r\nunderstood that I could be of no use to him, and therefore paid no\r\nattention to me whatever. Who knows but that, in order to please Madame\r\nde Villefort and my father, he may not persecute me by every means in\r\nhis power? It is not just that he should despise me so, without any\r\nreason. Ah, forgive me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, perceiving the effect which\r\nher words were producing on Maximilian: \xe2\x80\x9cI have done wrong, for I have\r\ngiven utterance to thoughts concerning that man which I did not even\r\nknow existed in my heart. I do not deny the influence of which you\r\nspeak, or that I have not myself experienced it, but with me it has\r\nbeen productive of evil rather than good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel with a sigh, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will not discuss the\r\nmatter further. I will not make a confidant of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cI see that I have given you pain. I can only\r\nsay how sincerely I ask pardon for having grieved you. But, indeed, I\r\nam not prejudiced beyond the power of conviction. Tell me what this\r\nCount of Monte Cristo has done for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30157m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI own that your question embarrasses me, Valentine, for I cannot say\r\nthat the count has rendered me any ostensible service. Still, as I have\r\nalready told you, I have an instinctive affection for him, the source\r\nof which I cannot explain to you. Has the sun done anything for me? No;\r\nhe warms me with his rays, and it is by his light that I see\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x94nothing more. Has such and such a perfume done anything for me? No;\r\nits odor charms one of my senses\xe2\x80\x94that is all I can say when I am asked\r\nwhy I praise it. My friendship for him is as strange and unaccountable\r\nas his for me. A secret voice seems to whisper to me that there must be\r\nsomething more than chance in this unexpected reciprocity of\r\nfriendship. In his most simple actions, as well as in his most secret\r\nthoughts, I find a relation to my own. You will perhaps smile at me\r\nwhen I tell you that, ever since I have known this man, I have\r\ninvoluntarily entertained the idea that all the good fortune which has\r\nbefallen me originated from him. However, I have managed to live thirty\r\nyears without this protection, you will say; but I will endeavor a\r\nlittle to illustrate my meaning. He invited me to dine with him on\r\nSaturday, which was a very natural thing for him to do. Well, what have\r\nI learned since? That your mother and M. de Villefort are both coming\r\nto this dinner. I shall meet them there, and who knows what future\r\nadvantages may result from the interview? This may appear to you to be\r\nno unusual combination of circumstances; nevertheless, I perceive some\r\nhidden plot in the arrangement\xe2\x80\x94something, in fact, more than is\r\napparent on a casual view of the subject. I believe that this singular\r\nman, who appears to fathom the motives of everyone, has purposely\r\narranged for me to meet M. and Madame de Villefort, and sometimes, I\r\nconfess, I have gone so far as to try to read in his eyes whether he\r\nwas in possession of the secret of our love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy good friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cI should take you for a visionary,\r\nand should tremble for your reason, if I were always to hear you talk\r\nin a strain similar to this. Is it possible that you can see anything\r\nmore than the merest chance in this meeting? Pray reflect a little. My\r\nfather, who never goes out, has several times been on the point of\r\nrefusing this invitation; Madame de Villefort, on the contrary, is\r\nburning with the desire of seeing this extraordinary nabob in his own\r\nhouse, therefore, she has with great difficulty prevailed on my father\r\nto accompany her. No, no; it is as I have said, Maximilian,\xe2\x80\x94there is no\r\none in the world of whom I can ask help but yourself and my\r\ngrandfather, who is little better than a corpse\xe2\x80\x94no support to cling to\r\nbut my mother in heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see that you are right, logically speaking,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian; \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nthe gentle voice which usually has such power over me fails to convince\r\nme today.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feel the same as regards yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cand I own that,\r\nif you have no stronger proof to give me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have another,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Maximilian; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I fear you will deem it even\r\nmore absurd than the first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the worse,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, nevertheless, conclusive to my mind. My ten years of service\r\nhave also confirmed my ideas on the subject of sudden inspirations, for\r\nI have several times owed my life to a mysterious impulse which\r\ndirected me to move at once either to the right or to the left, in\r\norder to escape the ball which killed the comrade fighting by my side,\r\nwhile it left me unharmed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Maximilian, why not attribute your escape to my constant prayers\r\nfor your safety? When you are away, I no longer pray for myself, but\r\nfor you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30159m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, since you have known me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cbut that cannot\r\napply to the time previous to our acquaintance, Valentine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very provoking, and will not give me credit for anything; but\r\nlet me hear this second proof, which you yourself own to be absurd.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, look through this opening, and you will see the beautiful new\r\nhorse which I rode here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! what a beautiful creature!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cwhy did you not\r\nbring him close to the gate, so that I could talk to him and pat him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is, as you see, a very valuable animal,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know\r\nthat my means are limited, and that I am what would be designated a man\r\nof moderate pretensions. Well, I went to a horse dealer\xe2\x80\x99s, where I saw\r\nthis magnificent horse, which I have named M\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa9ah. I asked the price;\r\nthey told me it was 4,500 francs. I was, therefore, obliged to give it\r\nup, as you may imagine, but I own I went away with rather a heavy\r\nheart, for the horse had looked at me affectionately, had rubbed his\r\nhead against me and, when I mounted him, had pranced in the most\r\ndelightful way imaginable, so that I was altogether fascinated with\r\nhim. The same evening some friends of mine visited me,\xe2\x80\x94M. de\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, M. Debray, and five or six other choice spirits, whom\r\nyou do not know, even by name. They proposed a game of _bouillotte_. I\r\nnever play, for I am not rich enough to afford to lose, or sufficiently\r\npoor to desire to gain. But I was at my own house, you understand, so\r\nthere was nothing to be done but to send for the cards, which I did.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust as they were sitting down to table, M. de Monte Cristo arrived.\r\nHe took his seat amongst them; they played, and I won. I am almost\r\nashamed to say that my gains amounted to 5,000 francs. We separated at\r\nmidnight. I could not defer my pleasure, so I took a cabriolet and\r\ndrove to the horse dealer\xe2\x80\x99s. Feverish and excited, I rang at the door.\r\nThe person who opened it must have taken me for a madman, for I rushed\r\nat once to the stable. M\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa9ah was standing at the rack, eating his hay.\r\nI immediately put on the saddle and bridle, to which operation he lent\r\nhimself with the best grace possible; then, putting the 4,500 francs\r\ninto the hands of the astonished dealer, I proceeded to fulfil my\r\nintention of passing the night in riding in the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es. As I\r\nrode by the count\xe2\x80\x99s house I perceived a light in one of the windows,\r\nand fancied I saw the shadow of his figure moving behind the curtain.\r\nNow, Valentine, I firmly believe that he knew of my wish to possess\r\nthis horse, and that he lost expressly to give me the means of\r\nprocuring him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Maximilian, you are really too fanciful; you will not love\r\neven me long. A man who accustoms himself to live in such a world of\r\npoetry and imagination must find far too little excitement in a common,\r\nevery-day sort of attachment such as ours. But they are calling me. Do\r\nyou hear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cgive me but one finger through this\r\nopening in the grating, one finger, the littlest finger of all, that I\r\nmay have the happiness of kissing it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian, we said we would be to each other as two voices, two\r\nshadows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs you will, Valentine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall you be happy if I do what you wish?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine mounted on a bench, and passed not only her finger but her\r\nwhole hand through the opening. Maximilian uttered a cry of delight,\r\nand, springing forwards, seized the hand extended towards him, and\r\nimprinted on it a fervent and impassioned kiss. The little hand was\r\nthen immediately withdrawn, and the young man saw Valentine hurrying\r\ntowards the house, as though she were almost terrified at her own\r\nsensations.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 58. M. Noirtier de Villefort\r\n\r\nWe will now relate what was passing in the house of the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney\r\nafter the departure of Madame Danglars and her daughter, and during the\r\ntime of the conversation between Maximilian and Valentine, which we\r\nhave just detailed.\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort entered his father\xe2\x80\x99s room, followed by Madame de\r\nVillefort. Both of the visitors, after saluting the old man and\r\nspeaking to Barrois, a faithful servant, who had been twenty-five years\r\nin his service, took their places on either side of the paralytic.\r\n\r\nM. Noirtier was sitting in an armchair, which moved upon casters, in\r\nwhich he was wheeled into the room in the morning, and in the same way\r\ndrawn out again at night. He was placed before a large glass, which\r\nreflected the whole apartment, and so, without any attempt to move,\r\nwhich would have been impossible, he could see all who entered the room\r\nand everything which was going on around him. M. Noirtier, although\r\nalmost as immovable as a corpse, looked at the new-comers with a quick\r\nand intelligent expression, perceiving at once, by their ceremonious\r\ncourtesy, that they were come on business of an unexpected and official\r\ncharacter.\r\n\r\nSight and hearing were the only senses remaining, and they, like two\r\nsolitary sparks, remained to animate the miserable body which seemed\r\nfit for nothing but the grave; it was only, however, by means of one of\r\nthese senses that he could reveal the thoughts and feelings that still\r\noccupied his mind, and the look by which he gave expression to his\r\ninner life was like the distant gleam of a candle which a traveller\r\nsees by night across some desert place, and knows that a living being\r\ndwells beyond the silence and obscurity.\r\n\r\nNoirtier\xe2\x80\x99s hair was long and white, and flowed over his shoulders;\r\nwhile in his eyes, shaded by thick black lashes, was concentrated, as\r\nit often happens with an organ which is used to the exclusion of the\r\nothers, all the activity, address, force, and intelligence which were\r\nformerly diffused over his whole body; and so although the movement of\r\nthe arm, the sound of the voice, and the agility of the body, were\r\nwanting, the speaking eye sufficed for all. He commanded with it; it\r\nwas the medium through which his thanks were conveyed. In short, his\r\nwhole appearance produced on the mind the impression of a corpse with\r\nliving eyes, and nothing could be more startling than to observe the\r\nexpression of anger or joy suddenly lighting up these organs, while the\r\nrest of the rigid and marble-like features were utterly deprived of the\r\npower of participation. Three persons only could understand this\r\nlanguage of the poor paralytic; these were Villefort, Valentine, and\r\nthe old servant of whom we have already spoken. But as Villefort saw\r\nhis father but seldom, and then only when absolutely obliged, and as he\r\nnever took any pains to please or gratify him when he was there, all\r\nthe old man\xe2\x80\x99s happiness was centred in his granddaughter. Valentine, by\r\nmeans of her love, her patience, and her devotion, had learned to read\r\nin Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s look all the varied feelings which were passing in his\r\nmind. To this dumb language, which was so unintelligible to others, she\r\nanswered by throwing her whole soul into the expression of her\r\ncountenance, and in this manner were the conversations sustained\r\nbetween the blooming girl and the helpless invalid, whose body could\r\nscarcely be called a living one, but who, nevertheless, possessed a\r\nfund of knowledge and penetration, united with a will as powerful as\r\never although clogged by a body rendered utterly incapable of obeying\r\nits impulses.\r\n\r\nValentine had solved the problem, and was able easily to understand his\r\nthoughts, and to convey her own in return, and, through her untiring\r\nand devoted assiduity, it was seldom that, in the ordinary transactions\r\nof every-day life, she failed to anticipate the wishes of the living,\r\nthinking mind, or the wants of the almost inanimate body.\r\n\r\nAs to the servant, he had, as we have said, been with his master for\r\nfive-and-twenty years, therefore he knew all his habits, and it was\r\nseldom that Noirtier found it necessary to ask for anything, so prompt\r\nwas he in administering to all the necessities of the invalid.\r\n\r\nVillefort did not need the help of either Valentine or the domestic in\r\norder to carry on with his father the strange conversation which he was\r\nabout to begin. As we have said, he perfectly understood the old man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nvocabulary, and if he did not use it more often, it was only\r\nindifference and _ennui_ which prevented him from so doing. He\r\ntherefore allowed Valentine to go into the garden, sent away Barrois,\r\nand after having seated himself at his father\xe2\x80\x99s right hand, while\r\nMadame de Villefort placed herself on the left, he addressed him thus:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI trust you will not be displeased, sir, that Valentine has not come\r\nwith us, or that I dismissed Barrois, for our conference will be one\r\nwhich could not with propriety be carried on in the presence of either.\r\nMadame de Villefort and I have a communication to make to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier\xe2\x80\x99s face remained perfectly passive during this long preamble,\r\nwhile, on the contrary, Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s eye was endeavoring to penetrate\r\ninto the inmost recesses of the old man\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis communication,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the procureur, in that cold and\r\ndecisive tone which seemed at once to preclude all discussion, \xe2\x80\x9cwill,\r\nwe are sure, meet with your approbation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe eye of the invalid still retained that vacancy of expression which\r\nprevented his son from obtaining any knowledge of the feelings which\r\nwere passing in his mind; he listened, nothing more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are thinking of marrying Valentine.\xe2\x80\x9d Had\r\nthe old man\xe2\x80\x99s face been moulded in wax it could not have shown less\r\nemotion at this news than was now to be traced there. \xe2\x80\x9cThe marriage\r\nwill take place in less than three months,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\nNoirtier\xe2\x80\x99s eye still retained its inanimate expression.\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort now took her part in the conversation and added:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe thought this news would possess an interest for you, sir, who have\r\nalways entertained a great affection for Valentine; it therefore only\r\nnow remains for us to tell you the name of the young man for whom she\r\nis destined. It is one of the most desirable connections which could\r\npossibly be formed; he possesses fortune, a high rank in society, and\r\nevery personal qualification likely to render Valentine supremely\r\nhappy,\xe2\x80\x94his name, moreover, cannot be wholly unknown to you. It is M.\r\nFranz de Quesnel, Baron d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile his wife was speaking, Villefort had narrowly watched the old\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s countenance. When Madame de Villefort pronounced the name of\r\nFranz, the pupil of M. Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s eye began to dilate, and his eyelids\r\ntrembled with the same movement that may be perceived on the lips of an\r\nindividual about to speak, and he darted a lightning glance at Madame\r\nde Villefort and his son. The procureur, who knew the political hatred\r\nwhich had formerly existed between M. Noirtier and the elder d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay,\r\nwell understood the agitation and anger which the announcement had\r\nproduced; but, feigning not to perceive either, he immediately resumed\r\nthe narrative begun by his wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are aware that Valentine is about to enter her\r\nnineteenth year, which renders it important that she should lose no\r\ntime in forming a suitable alliance. Nevertheless, you have not been\r\nforgotten in our plans, and we have fully ascertained beforehand that\r\nValentine\xe2\x80\x99s future husband will consent, not to live in this house, for\r\nthat might not be pleasant for the young people, but that you should\r\nlive with them; so that you and Valentine, who are so attached to each\r\nother, would not be separated, and you would be able to pursue exactly\r\nthe same course of life which you have hitherto done, and thus, instead\r\nof losing, you will be a gainer by the change, as it will secure to you\r\ntwo children instead of one, to watch over and comfort you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30165m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNoirtier\xe2\x80\x99s look was furious; it was very evident that something\r\ndesperate was passing in the old man\xe2\x80\x99s mind, for a cry of anger and\r\ngrief rose in his throat, and not being able to find vent in utterance,\r\nappeared almost to choke him, for his face and lips turned quite purple\r\nwith the struggle. Villefort quietly opened a window, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is\r\nvery warm, and the heat affects M. Noirtier.\xe2\x80\x9d He then returned to his\r\nplace, but did not sit down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis marriage,\xe2\x80\x9d added Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cis quite agreeable to the\r\nwishes of M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay and his family; besides, he had no relations\r\nnearer than an uncle and aunt, his mother having died at his birth, and\r\nhis father having been assassinated in 1815, that is to say, when he\r\nwas but two years old; it naturally followed that the child was\r\npermitted to choose his own pursuits, and he has, therefore, seldom\r\nacknowledged any other authority but that of his own will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat assassination was a mysterious affair,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cand the\r\nperpetrators have hitherto escaped detection, although suspicion has\r\nfallen on the head of more than one person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier made such an effort that his lips expanded into a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthose to whom the guilt really belongs, by\r\nwhom the crime was committed, on whose heads the justice of man may\r\nprobably descend here, and the certain judgment of God hereafter, would\r\nrejoice in the opportunity thus afforded of bestowing such a\r\npeace-offering as Valentine on the son of him whose life they so\r\nruthlessly destroyed.\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier had succeeded in mastering his emotion\r\nmore than could have been deemed possible with such an enfeebled and\r\nshattered frame.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I understand,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply contained in his look; and this look\r\nexpressed a feeling of strong indignation, mixed with profound\r\ncontempt. Villefort fully understood his father\xe2\x80\x99s meaning, and answered\r\nby a slight shrug of his shoulders. He then motioned to his wife to\r\ntake leave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cI must bid you farewell. Would\r\nyou like me to send Edward to you for a short time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt had been agreed that the old man should express his approbation by\r\nclosing his eyes, his refusal by winking them several times, and if he\r\nhad some desire or feeling to express, he raised them to heaven. If he\r\nwanted Valentine, he closed his right eye only, and if Barrois, the\r\nleft. At Madame de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s proposition he instantly winked his\r\neyes.\r\n\r\nProvoked by a complete refusal, she bit her lip and said, \xe2\x80\x9cThen shall I\r\nsend Valentine to you?\xe2\x80\x9d The old man closed his eyes eagerly, thereby\r\nintimating that such was his wish.\r\n\r\nM. and Madame de Villefort bowed and left the room, giving orders that\r\nValentine should be summoned to her grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s presence, and feeling\r\nsure that she would have much to do to restore calmness to the\r\nperturbed spirit of the invalid. Valentine, with a color still\r\nheightened by emotion, entered the room just after her parents had\r\nquitted it. One look was sufficient to tell her that her grandfather\r\nwas suffering, and that there was much on his mind which he was wishing\r\nto communicate to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear grandpapa,\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat has happened? They have vexed you,\r\nand you are angry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe paralytic closed his eyes in token of assent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho has displeased you? Is it my father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame de Villefort?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe?\xe2\x80\x9d The former sign was repeated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you displeased with me?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Valentine in astonishment. M.\r\nNoirtier again closed his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what have I done, dear grandpapa, that you should be angry with\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Valentine.\r\n\r\nThere was no answer, and she continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not seen you all day. Has anyone been speaking to you against\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man\xe2\x80\x99s look, with eagerness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me think a moment. I do assure you, grandpapa\xe2\x80\x94Ah\xe2\x80\x94M. and Madame de\r\nVillefort have just left this room, have they not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it was they who told you something which made you angry? What was\r\nit then? May I go and ask them, that I may have the opportunity of\r\nmaking my peace with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you frighten me. What can they have said?\xe2\x80\x9d and she again tried to\r\nthink what it could be.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, I know,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, lowering her voice and going close to the old\r\nman. \xe2\x80\x9cThey have been speaking of my marriage,\xe2\x80\x94have they not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the angry look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand; you are displeased at the silence I have preserved on\r\nthe subject. The reason of it was, that they had insisted on my keeping\r\nthe matter a secret, and begged me not to tell you anything of it. They\r\ndid not even acquaint me with their intentions, and I only discovered\r\nthem by chance, that is why I have been so reserved with you, dear\r\ngrandpapa. Pray forgive me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut there was no look calculated to reassure her; all it seemed to say\r\nwas, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not only your reserve which afflicts me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the young girl. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you think I shall\r\nabandon you, dear grandpapa, and that I shall forget you when I am\r\nmarried?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey told you, then, that M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay consented to our all living\r\ntogether?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen why are you still vexed and grieved?\xe2\x80\x9d The old man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes beamed\r\nwith an expression of gentle affection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I understand,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cit is because you love me.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nold man assented.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are afraid I shall be unhappy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not like M. Franz?\xe2\x80\x9d The eyes repeated several times, \xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\r\nno.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you are vexed with the engagement?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, listen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, throwing herself on her knees, and\r\nputting her arm round her grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s neck, \xe2\x80\x9cI am vexed, too, for I\r\ndo not love M. Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn expression of intense joy illumined the old man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I wished to retire into a convent, you remember how angry you\r\nwere with me?\xe2\x80\x9d A tear trembled in the eye of the invalid. \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cthe reason of my proposing it was that I might\r\nescape this hateful marriage, which drives me to despair.\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbreathing came thick and short.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the idea of this marriage really grieves you too? Ah, if you\r\ncould but help me\xe2\x80\x94if we could both together defeat their plan! But you\r\nare unable to oppose them,\xe2\x80\x94you, whose mind is so quick, and whose will\r\nis so firm are nevertheless, as weak and unequal to the contest as I am\r\nmyself. Alas, you, who would have been such a powerful protector to me\r\nin the days of your health and strength, can now only sympathize in my\r\njoys and sorrows, without being able to take any active part in them.\r\nHowever, this is much, and calls for gratitude and Heaven has not taken\r\naway all my blessings when it leaves me your sympathy and kindness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words there appeared in Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s eye an expression of such\r\ndeep meaning that the young girl thought she could read these words\r\nthere: \xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken; I can still do much for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think you can help me, dear grandpapa?\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier raised his eyes, it was the sign agreed on between him\r\nand Valentine when he wanted anything.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it you want, dear grandpapa?\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, and she\r\nendeavored to recall to mind all the things which he would be likely to\r\nneed; and as the ideas presented themselves to her mind, she repeated\r\nthem aloud, then,\xe2\x80\x94finding that all her efforts elicited nothing but a\r\nconstant _\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d_\xe2\x80\x94she said, \xe2\x80\x9cCome, since this plan does not answer, I\r\nwill have recourse to another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe then recited all the letters of the alphabet from A down to N. When\r\nshe arrived at that letter the paralytic made her understand that she\r\nhad spoken the initial letter of the thing he wanted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cthe thing you desire begins with the letter N;\r\nit is with N that we have to do, then. Well, let me see, what can you\r\nwant that begins with N? Na\xe2\x80\x94Ne\xe2\x80\x94Ni\xe2\x80\x94No\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man\xe2\x80\x99s eye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, it is No, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine fetched a dictionary, which she placed on a desk before\r\nNoirtier; she opened it, and, seeing that the old man\xe2\x80\x99s eye was\r\nthoroughly fixed on its pages, she ran her finger quickly up and down\r\nthe columns. During the six years which had passed since Noirtier first\r\nfell into this sad state, Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s powers of invention had been too\r\noften put to the test not to render her expert in devising expedients\r\nfor gaining a knowledge of his wishes, and the constant practice had so\r\nperfected her in the art that she guessed the old man\xe2\x80\x99s meaning as\r\nquickly as if he himself had been able to seek for what he wanted. At\r\nthe word _Notary_, Noirtier made a sign to her to stop.\r\n\r\n30169m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNotary,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you want a notary, dear grandpapa?\xe2\x80\x9d The old man\r\nagain signified that it was a notary he desired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would wish a notary to be sent for then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall my father be informed of your wish?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you wish the notary to be sent for immediately?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen they shall go for him directly, dear grandpapa. Is that all you\r\nwant?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine rang the bell, and ordered the servant to tell\r\nMonsieur or Madame de Villefort that they were requested to come to M.\r\nNoirtier\xe2\x80\x99s room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you satisfied now?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure you are; it is not very difficult to discover that.\xe2\x80\x9d And the\r\nyoung girl smiled on her grandfather, as if he had been a child. M. de\r\nVillefort entered, followed by Barrois.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want me for, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded he of the paralytic.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cmy grandfather wishes for a notary.\xe2\x80\x9d At this\r\nstrange and unexpected demand M. de Villefort and his father exchanged\r\nlooks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d motioned the latter, with a firmness which seemed to declare\r\nthat with the help of Valentine and his old servant, who both knew what\r\nhis wishes were, he was quite prepared to maintain the contest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you wish for a notary?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier made no answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want with a notary?\xe2\x80\x9d again repeated Villefort. The\r\ninvalid\xe2\x80\x99s eye remained fixed, by which expression he intended to\r\nintimate that his resolution was unalterable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it to do us some ill turn? Do you think it is worth while?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nVillefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill,\xe2\x80\x9d said Barrois, with the freedom and fidelity of an old servant,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cif M. Noirtier asks for a notary, I suppose he really wishes for a\r\nnotary; therefore I shall go at once and fetch one.\xe2\x80\x9d Barrois\r\nacknowledged no master but Noirtier, and never allowed his desires in\r\nany way to be contradicted.\r\n\r\n30171m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I do want a notary,\xe2\x80\x9d motioned the old man, shutting his eyes with\r\na look of defiance, which seemed to say, \xe2\x80\x9cand I should like to see the\r\nperson who dares to refuse my request.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall have a notary, as you absolutely wish for one, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nVillefort; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I shall explain to him your state of health, and make\r\nexcuses for you, for the scene cannot fail of being a most ridiculous\r\none.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Barrois; \xe2\x80\x9cI shall go and fetch a notary,\r\nnevertheless.\xe2\x80\x9d And the old servant departed triumphantly on his\r\nmission.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 59. The Will\r\n\r\nAs soon as Barrois had left the room, Noirtier looked at Valentine with\r\na malicious expression that said many things. The young girl perfectly\r\nunderstood the look, and so did Villefort, for his countenance became\r\nclouded, and he knitted his eyebrows angrily. He took a seat, and\r\nquietly awaited the arrival of the notary. Noirtier saw him seat\r\nhimself with an appearance of perfect indifference, at the same time\r\ngiving a side look at Valentine, which made her understand that she\r\nalso was to remain in the room. Three-quarters of an hour after,\r\nBarrois returned, bringing the notary with him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, after the first salutations were over, \xe2\x80\x9cyou were\r\nsent for by M. Noirtier, whom you see here. All his limbs have become\r\ncompletely paralysed, he has lost his voice also, and we ourselves find\r\nmuch trouble in endeavoring to catch some fragments of his meaning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier cast an appealing look on Valentine, which look was at once so\r\nearnest and imperative, that she answered immediately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cI perfectly understand my grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s meaning at\r\nall times.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is quite true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Barrois; \xe2\x80\x9cand that is what I told the\r\ngentleman as we walked along.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPermit me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the notary, turning first to Villefort and then to\r\nValentine\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cpermit me to state that the case in question is just one of\r\nthose in which a public officer like myself cannot proceed to act\r\nwithout thereby incurring a dangerous responsibility. The first thing\r\nnecessary to render an act valid is, that the notary should be\r\nthoroughly convinced that he has faithfully interpreted the will and\r\nwishes of the person dictating the act. Now I cannot be sure of the\r\napprobation or disapprobation of a client who cannot speak, and as the\r\nobject of his desire or his repugnance cannot be clearly proved to me,\r\non account of his want of speech, my services here would be quite\r\nuseless, and cannot be legally exercised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe notary then prepared to retire. An imperceptible smile of triumph\r\nwas expressed on the lips of the procureur. Noirtier looked at\r\nValentine with an expression so full of grief, that she arrested the\r\ndeparture of the notary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cthe language which I speak with my grandfather may be\r\neasily learnt, and I can teach you in a few minutes, to understand it\r\nalmost as well as I can myself. Will you tell me what you require, in\r\norder to set your conscience quite at ease on the subject?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn order to render an act valid, I must be certain of the approbation\r\nor disapprobation of my client. Illness of body would not affect the\r\nvalidity of the deed, but sanity of mind is absolutely requisite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir, by the help of two signs, with which I will acquaint you\r\npresently, you may ascertain with perfect certainty that my grandfather\r\nis still in the full possession of all his mental faculties. M.\r\nNoirtier, being deprived of voice and motion, is accustomed to convey\r\nhis meaning by closing his eyes when he wishes to signify \xe2\x80\x98yes,\xe2\x80\x99 and to\r\nwink when he means \xe2\x80\x98no.\xe2\x80\x99 You now know quite enough to enable you to\r\nconverse with M. Noirtier;\xe2\x80\x94try.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier gave Valentine such a look of tenderness and gratitude that it\r\nwas comprehended even by the notary himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have heard and understood what your granddaughter has been saying,\r\nsir, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the notary. As to the time, it will not require very\r\nmuch more than the generality of wills. There are certain forms\r\nnecessary to be gone through, and which are always the same. I am the only person possessing the right to dispose of my\r\ndaughter\xe2\x80\x99s hand. It is my wish that she should marry M. Franz\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay\xe2\x80\x94and she shall marry him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine sank weeping into a chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the notary, \xe2\x80\x9chow do you intend disposing of your fortune in\r\ncase Mademoiselle de Villefort still determines on marrying M. Franz?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThe old man gave no answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will, of course, dispose of it in some way or other?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn favor of some member of your family?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you intend devoting it to charitable purposes, then?\xe2\x80\x9d pursued the\r\nnotary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said the notary, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are aware that the law does not allow a\r\nson to be entirely deprived of his patrimony?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou only intend, then, to dispose of that part of your fortune which\r\nthe law allows you to subtract from the inheritance of your son?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nNoirtier made no answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you still wish to dispose of all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut they will contest the will after your death?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father knows me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9che is quite sure that his\r\nwishes will be held sacred by me; besides, he understands that in my\r\nposition I cannot plead against the poor.\xe2\x80\x9d The eye of Noirtier beamed\r\nwith triumph.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you decide on, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the notary of Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, sir; it is a resolution which my father has taken and I know\r\nhe never alters his mind. I am quite resigned. These 900,000 francs\r\nwill go out of the family in order to enrich some hospital; but it is\r\nridiculous thus to yield to the caprices of an old man, and I shall,\r\ntherefore, act according to my conscience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaving said this, Villefort quitted the room with his wife, leaving his\r\nfather at liberty to do as he pleased. The same day the will was made,\r\nthe witnesses were brought, it was approved by the old man, sealed in\r\nthe presence of all and given in charge to M. Deschamps, the family\r\nnotary.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 60. The Telegraph\r\n\r\nM. and Madame de Villefort found on their return that the Count of\r\nMonte Cristo, who had come to visit them in their absence, had been\r\nushered into the drawing-room, and was still awaiting them there.\r\nMadame de Villefort, who had not yet sufficiently recovered from her\r\nlate emotion to allow of her entertaining visitors so immediately,\r\nretired to her bedroom, while the procureur, who could better depend\r\nupon himself, proceeded at once to the salon.\r\n\r\nAlthough M. de Villefort flattered himself that, to all outward view,\r\nhe had completely masked the feelings which were passing in his mind,\r\nhe did not know that the cloud was still lowering on his brow, so much\r\nso that the count, whose smile was radiant, immediately noticed his\r\nsombre and thoughtful air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, after the first compliments were over,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhat is the matter with you, M. de Villefort? Have I arrived at the\r\nmoment when you were drawing up an indictment for a capital crime?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort tried to smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, count,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cI am the only victim in this case. It is I\r\nwho lose my cause, and it is ill-luck, obstinacy, and folly which have\r\ncaused it to be decided against me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo what do you refer?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo with well-feigned interest.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you really met with some great misfortune?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort with a bitter smile; \xe2\x80\x9cit is only a\r\nloss of money which I have sustained\xe2\x80\x94nothing worth mentioning, I assure\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthe loss of a sum of money becomes almost\r\nimmaterial with a fortune such as you possess, and to one of your\r\nphilosophic spirit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not so much the loss of the money that vexes me,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nVillefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthough, after all, 900,000 francs are worth regretting; but\r\nI am the more annoyed with this fate, chance, or whatever you please to\r\ncall the power which has destroyed my hopes and my fortune, and may\r\nblast the prospects of my child also, as it is all occasioned by an old\r\nman relapsed into second childhood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30183m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you say?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9c900,000 francs? It is indeed a sum\r\nwhich might be regretted even by a philosopher. And who is the cause of\r\nall this annoyance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father, as I told you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Noirtier? But I thought you told me he had become entirely\r\nparalyzed, and that all his faculties were completely destroyed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, his bodily faculties, for he can neither move nor speak,\r\nnevertheless he thinks, acts, and wills in the manner I have described.\r\nI left him about five minutes ago, and he is now occupied in dictating\r\nhis will to two notaries.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut to do this he must have spoken?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has done better than that\xe2\x80\x94he has made himself understood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was such a thing possible?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the help of his eyes, which are still full of life, and, as you\r\nperceive, possess the power of inflicting mortal injury.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, who had just entered the room,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cperhaps you exaggerate the evil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-morning, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, bowing.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort acknowledged the salutation with one of her most\r\ngracious smiles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this that M. de Villefort has been telling me?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Monte\r\nCristo \xe2\x80\x9cand what incomprehensible misfortune\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIncomprehensible is the word!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the procureur, shrugging\r\nhis shoulders. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is an old man\xe2\x80\x99s caprice!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is there no means of making him revoke his decision?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cand it is still entirely in the power\r\nof my husband to cause the will, which is now in prejudice of\r\nValentine, to be altered in her favor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count, who perceived that M. and Madame de Villefort were beginning\r\nto speak in parables, appeared to pay no attention to the conversation,\r\nand feigned to be busily engaged in watching Edward, who was\r\nmischievously pouring some ink into the bird\xe2\x80\x99s water-glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, in answer to his wife, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know I have\r\nnever been accustomed to play the patriarch in my family, nor have I\r\never considered that the fate of a universe was to be decided by my\r\nnod. Nevertheless, it is necessary that my will should be respected in\r\nmy family, and that the folly of an old man and the caprice of a child\r\nshould not be allowed to overturn a project which I have entertained\r\nfor so many years. The Baron d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay was my friend, as you know, and\r\nan alliance with his son is the most suitable thing that could possibly\r\nbe arranged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Valentine is in league\r\nwith him? She has always been opposed to this marriage, and I should\r\nnot be at all surprised if what we have just seen and heard is nothing\r\nbut the execution of a plan concerted between them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cbelieve me, a fortune of 900,000 francs is\r\nnot so easily renounced.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe could, nevertheless, make up her mind to renounce the world, sir,\r\nsince it is only about a year ago that she herself proposed entering a\r\nconvent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cI say that this marriage _shall_ be\r\nconsummated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNotwithstanding your father\xe2\x80\x99s wishes to the contrary?\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de\r\nVillefort, selecting a new point of attack. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is a serious thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo, who pretended not to be listening, heard however, every\r\nword that was said.\r\n\r\n30185m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort \xe2\x80\x9cI can truly say that I have always\r\nentertained a high respect for my father, because, to the natural\r\nfeeling of relationship was added the consciousness of his moral\r\nsuperiority. The name of father is sacred in two senses; he should be\r\nreverenced as the author of our being and as a master whom we ought to\r\nobey. But, under the present circumstances, I am justified in doubting\r\nthe wisdom of an old man who, because he hated the father, vents his\r\nanger on the son. It would be ridiculous in me to regulate my conduct\r\nby such caprices. I shall still continue to preserve the same respect\r\ntoward M. Noirtier; I will suffer, without complaint, the pecuniary\r\ndeprivation to which he has subjected me; but I shall remain firm in my\r\ndetermination, and the world shall see which party has reason on his\r\nside. Consequently I shall marry my daughter to the Baron Franz\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, because I consider it would be a proper and eligible match\r\nfor her to make, and, in short, because I choose to bestow my\r\ndaughter\xe2\x80\x99s hand on whomever I please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, the approbation of whose eye Villefort had\r\nfrequently solicited during this speech. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat? Do you say that M.\r\nNoirtier disinherits Mademoiselle de Villefort because she is going to\r\nmarry M. le Baron Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, that is the reason,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, shrugging his\r\nshoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe apparent reason, at least,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe _real_ reason, madame, I can assure you; I know my father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I want to know in what way M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay can have displeased your\r\nfather more than any other person?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe I know M. Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cis he not the\r\nson of General de Quesnel, who was created Baron d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay by Charles\r\nX.?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but he is a charming young man, according to my ideas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is, which makes me believe that it is only an excuse of M. Noirtier\r\nto prevent his granddaughter marrying; old men are always so selfish in\r\ntheir affection,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cdo you not know any cause for this hatred?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, _ma foi!_ who is to know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps it is some political difference?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father and the Baron d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay lived in the stormy times of which I\r\nonly saw the ending,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas not your father a Bonapartist?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI think I\r\nremember that you told me something of that kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father has been a Jacobin more than anything else,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort,\r\ncarried by his emotion beyond the bounds of prudence; \xe2\x80\x9cand the\r\nsenator\xe2\x80\x99s robe, which Napoleon cast on his shoulders, only served to\r\ndisguise the old man without in any degree changing him. When my father\r\nconspired, it was not for the emperor, it was against the Bourbons; for\r\nM. Noirtier possessed this peculiarity, he never projected any Utopian\r\nschemes which could never be realized, but strove for possibilities,\r\nand he applied to the realization of these possibilities the terrible\r\ntheories of The Mountain,\xe2\x80\x94theories that never shrank from any means\r\nthat were deemed necessary to bring about the desired result.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cit is just as I thought; it was politics\r\nwhich brought Noirtier and M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay into personal contact. Although\r\nGeneral d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay served under Napoleon, did he not still retain\r\nroyalist sentiments? And was he not the person who was assassinated one\r\nevening on leaving a Bonapartist meeting to which he had been invited\r\non the supposition that he favored the cause of the emperor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort looked at the count almost with terror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I mistaken, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir, the facts were precisely what you have stated,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame\r\nde Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cand it was to prevent the renewal of old feuds that M.\r\nde Villefort formed the idea of uniting in the bonds of affection the\r\ntwo children of these inveterate enemies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was a sublime and charitable thought,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cand the\r\nwhole world should applaud it. It would be noble to see Mademoiselle\r\nNoirtier de Villefort assuming the title of Madame Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort shuddered and looked at Monte Cristo as if he wished to read\r\nin his countenance the real feelings which had dictated the words he\r\nhad just uttered. But the count completely baffled the procureur, and\r\nprevented him from discovering anything beneath the never-varying smile\r\nhe was so constantly in the habit of assuming.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlthough,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cit will be a serious thing for Valentine\r\nto lose her grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s fortune, I do not think that M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay will\r\nbe frightened at this pecuniary loss. He will, perhaps, hold me in\r\ngreater esteem than the money itself, seeing that I sacrifice\r\neverything in order to keep my word with him. Besides, he knows that\r\nValentine is rich in right of her mother, and that she will, in all\r\nprobability, inherit the fortune of M. and Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, her\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s parents, who both love her tenderly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who are fully as well worth loving and tending as M. Noirtier,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Madame de Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cbesides, they are to come to Paris in about\r\na month, and Valentine, after the affront she has received, need not\r\nconsider it necessary to continue to bury herself alive by being shut\r\nup with M. Noirtier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count listened with satisfaction to this tale of wounded self-love\r\nand defeated ambition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it seems to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cand I must begin by asking\r\nyour pardon for what I am about to say, that if M. Noirtier disinherits\r\nMademoiselle de Villefort because she is going to marry a man whose\r\nfather he detested, he cannot have the same cause of complaint against\r\nthis dear Edward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, with an intonation of voice which it\r\nis impossible to describe; \xe2\x80\x9cis it not unjust\xe2\x80\x94shamefully unjust? Poor\r\nEdward is as much M. Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s grandchild as Valentine, and yet, if\r\nshe had not been going to marry M. Franz, M. Noirtier would have left\r\nher all his money; and supposing Valentine to be disinherited by her\r\ngrandfather, she will still be three times richer than he.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count listened and said no more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will not entertain you any longer with our\r\nfamily misfortunes. It is true that my patrimony will go to endow\r\ncharitable institutions, and my father will have deprived me of my\r\nlawful inheritance without any reason for doing so, but I shall have\r\nthe satisfaction of knowing that I have acted like a man of sense and\r\nfeeling. M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, to whom I had promised the interest of this sum,\r\nshall receive it, even if I endure the most cruel privations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHowever,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, returning to the one idea which\r\nincessantly occupied her mind, \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps it would be better to explain\r\nthis unlucky affair to M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, in order to give him the\r\nopportunity of himself renouncing his claim to the hand of Mademoiselle\r\nde Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that would be a great pity,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA great pity,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUndoubtedly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, moderating the tones of his voice, \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nmarriage once concerted and then broken off, throws a sort of discredit\r\non a young lady; then again, the old reports, which I was so anxious to\r\nput an end to, will instantly gain ground. No, it will all go well; M.\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, if he is an honorable man, will consider himself more than\r\never pledged to Mademoiselle de Villefort, unless he were actuated by a\r\ndecided feeling of avarice, but that is impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI agree with M. de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, fixing his eyes on\r\nMadame de Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cand if I were sufficiently intimate with him to\r\nallow of giving my advice, I would persuade him, since I have been told\r\nM. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay is coming back, to settle this affair at once beyond all\r\npossibility of revocation. I will answer for the success of a project\r\nwhich will reflect so much honor on M. de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe procureur arose, delighted with the proposition, but his wife\r\nslightly changed color.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that is all that I wanted, and I will be guided by a counsellor\r\nsuch as you are,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, extending his hand to Monte Cristo.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTherefore let everyone here look upon what has passed today as if it\r\nhad not happened, and as though we had never thought of such a thing as\r\na change in our original plans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cthe world, unjust as it is, will be pleased\r\nwith your resolution; your friends will be proud of you, and M.\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, even if he took Mademoiselle de Villefort without any dowry,\r\nwhich he will not do, would be delighted with the idea of entering a\r\nfamily which could make such sacrifices in order to keep a promise and\r\nfulfil a duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the conclusion of these words, the count rose to depart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you going to leave us, count?\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry to say I must do so, madame, I only came to remind you of\r\nyour promise for Saturday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you fear that we should forget it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very good, madame, but M. de Villefort has so many important\r\nand urgent occupations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy husband has given me his word, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort;
