\xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nhave just seen him resolve to keep it when he has everything to lose,\r\nand surely there is more reason for his doing so where he has\r\neverything to gain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cis it at your house in the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es that\r\nyou receive your visitors?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich is precisely the reason which renders\r\nyour kindness more meritorious,\xe2\x80\x94it is in the country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the country?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is it, then? Near Paris, is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery near, only half a league from the Barriers,\xe2\x80\x94it is at Auteuil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Auteuil?\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9ctrue, Madame de Villefort told me you\r\nlived at Auteuil, since it was to your house that she was taken. And in\r\nwhat part of Auteuil do you reside?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRue de la Fontaine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRue de la Fontaine!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Villefort in an agitated tone; \xe2\x80\x9cat what\r\nnumber?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. 28.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cwas it you who bought M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhouse!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid it belong to M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame de Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cand, would you believe it,\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBelieve what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think this house pretty, do you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think it charming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my husband would never live in it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d returned Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is a prejudice on your part, M.\r\nde Villefort, for which I am quite at a loss to account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not like Auteuil, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the procureur, making an evident\r\neffort to appear calm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I hope you will not carry your antipathy so far as to deprive me\r\nof the pleasure of your company, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, count,\xe2\x80\x94I hope\xe2\x80\x94I assure you I shall do my best,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered\r\nVillefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI allow of no excuse. On Saturday, at six\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock. I shall be expecting you, and if you fail to come, I shall\r\nthink\xe2\x80\x94for how do I know to the contrary?\xe2\x80\x94that this house, which has\r\nremained uninhabited for twenty years, must have some gloomy tradition\r\nor dreadful legend connected with it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will come, count,\xe2\x80\x94I will be sure to come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cnow you must permit me to take my\r\nleave of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said before that you were obliged to leave us, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMadame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cand you were about to tell us why when your\r\nattention was called to some other subject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo: \xe2\x80\x9cI scarcely know if I dare tell you\r\nwhere I am going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense; say on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, it is to see a thing on which I have sometimes mused for\r\nhours together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA telegraph. So now I have told my secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA telegraph?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Madame de Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a telegraph. I had often seen one placed at the end of a road on\r\na hillock, and in the light of the sun its black arms, bending in every\r\ndirection, always reminded me of the claws of an immense beetle, and I\r\nassure you it was never without emotion that I gazed on it, for I could\r\nnot help thinking how wonderful it was that these various signs should\r\nbe made to cleave the air with such precision as to convey to the\r\ndistance of three hundred leagues the ideas and wishes of a man sitting\r\nat a table at one end of the line to another man similarly placed at\r\nthe opposite extremity, and all this effected by a simple act of\r\nvolition on the part of the sender of the message. I began to think of\r\ngenii, sylphs, gnomes, in short, of all the ministers of the occult\r\nsciences, until I laughed aloud at the freaks of my own imagination.\r\nNow, it never occurred to me to wish for a nearer inspection of these\r\nlarge insects, with their long black claws, for I always feared to find\r\nunder their stone wings some little human genius fagged to death with\r\ncabals, factions, and government intrigues. But one fine day I learned\r\nthat the mover of this telegraph was only a poor wretch, hired for\r\ntwelve hundred francs a year, and employed all day, not in studying the\r\nheavens like an astronomer, or in gazing on the water like an angler,\r\nor even in enjoying the privilege of observing the country around him,\r\nbut all his monotonous life was passed in watching his white-bellied,\r\nblack-clawed fellow insect, four or five leagues distant from him. At\r\nlength I felt a desire to study this living chrysalis more closely, and\r\nto endeavor to understand the secret part played by these insect-actors\r\nwhen they occupy themselves simply with pulling different pieces of\r\nstring.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30191m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd are you going there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat telegraph do you intend visiting? that of the home department, or\r\nof the observatory?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no; I should find there people who would force me to understand\r\nthings of which I would prefer to remain ignorant, and who would try to\r\nexplain to me, in spite of myself, a mystery which even they do not\r\nunderstand. _Ma foi!_ I should wish to keep my illusions concerning\r\ninsects unimpaired; it is quite enough to have those dissipated which I\r\nhad formed of my fellow-creatures. I shall, therefore, not visit either\r\nof these telegraphs, but one in the open country where I shall find a\r\ngood-natured simpleton, who knows no more than the machine he is\r\nemployed to work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a singular man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat line would you advise me to study?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe one that is most in use just at this time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Spanish one, you mean, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; should you like a letter to the minister that they might explain\r\nto you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9csince, as I told you before, I do not wish to\r\ncomprehend it. The moment I understand it there will no longer exist a\r\ntelegraph for me; it will be nothing more than a sign from M. Duch\xc3\xa2tel,\r\nor from M. Montalivet, transmitted to the prefect of Bayonne, mystified\r\nby two Greek words, _t\xc3\xaale_, _graphein_. It is the insect with black\r\nclaws, and the awful word which I wish to retain in my imagination in\r\nall its purity and all its importance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo then; for in the course of two hours it will be dark, and you will\r\nnot be able to see anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi!_ you frighten me. Which is the nearest way? Bayonne?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; the road to Bayonne.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd afterwards the road to Ch\xc3\xa2tillon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the tower of Montlh\xc3\xa9ry, you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you. Good-bye. On Saturday I will tell you my impressions\r\nconcerning the telegraph.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the door the count was met by the two notaries, who had just\r\ncompleted the act which was to disinherit Valentine, and who were\r\nleaving under the conviction of having done a thing which could not\r\nfail of redounding considerably to their credit.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 61. How a Gardener May Get Rid of the Dormice that Eat His\r\n Peaches\r\n\r\nNot on the same night as he had stated, but the next morning, the Count\r\nof Monte Cristo went out by the Barri\xc3\xa8re d\xe2\x80\x99Enfer, taking the road to\r\nOrl\xc3\xa9ans. Leaving the village of Linas, without stopping at the\r\ntelegraph, which flourished its great bony arms as he passed, the count\r\nreached the tower of Montlh\xc3\xa9ry, situated, as everyone knows, upon the\r\nhighest point of the plain of that name. At the foot of the hill the\r\ncount dismounted and began to ascend by a little winding path, about\r\neighteen inches wide; when he reached the summit he found himself\r\nstopped by a hedge, upon which green fruit had succeeded to red and\r\nwhite flowers.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo looked for the entrance to the enclosure, and was not long\r\nin finding a little wooden gate, working on willow hinges, and fastened\r\nwith a nail and string. The count soon mastered the mechanism, the gate\r\nopened, and he then found himself in a little garden, about twenty feet\r\nlong by twelve wide, bounded on one side by part of the hedge, which\r\ncontained the ingenious contrivance we have called a gate, and on the\r\nother by the old tower, covered with ivy and studded with wall-flowers.\r\n\r\nNo one would have thought in looking at this old, weather-beaten,\r\nfloral-decked tower (which might be likened to an elderly dame dressed\r\nup to receive her grandchildren at a birthday feast) that it would have\r\nbeen capable of telling strange things, if,\xe2\x80\x94in addition to the menacing\r\nears which the proverb says all walls are provided with,\xe2\x80\x94it had also a\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\nThe garden was crossed by a path of red gravel, edged by a border of\r\nthick box, of many years\xe2\x80\x99 growth, and of a tone and color that would\r\nhave delighted the heart of Delacroix, our modern Rubens. This path was\r\nformed in the shape of the figure of 8, thus, in its windings, making a\r\nwalk of sixty feet in a garden of only twenty.\r\n\r\nNever had Flora, the fresh and smiling goddess of gardeners, been\r\nhonored with a purer or more scrupulous worship than that which was\r\npaid to her in this little enclosure. In fact, of the twenty rose-trees\r\nwhich formed the _parterre_, not one bore the mark of the slug, nor\r\nwere there evidences anywhere of the clustering aphis which is so\r\ndestructive to plants growing in a damp soil. And yet it was not\r\nbecause the damp had been excluded from the garden; the earth, black as\r\nsoot, the thick foliage of the trees betrayed its presence; besides,\r\nhad natural humidity been wanting, it could have been immediately\r\nsupplied by artificial means, thanks to a tank of water, sunk in one of\r\nthe corners of the garden, and upon which were stationed a frog and a\r\ntoad, who, from antipathy, no doubt, always remained on the two\r\nopposite sides of the basin. There was not a blade of grass to be seen\r\nin the paths, or a weed in the flower-beds; no fine lady ever trained\r\nand watered her geraniums, her cacti, and her rhododendrons, in her\r\nporcelain _jardini\xc3\xa8re_ with more pains than this hitherto unseen\r\ngardener bestowed upon his little enclosure.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo stopped after having closed the gate and fastened the\r\nstring to the nail, and cast a look around.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe man at the telegraph,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cmust either engage a gardener or\r\ndevote himself passionately to agriculture.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuddenly he struck against something crouching behind a wheelbarrow\r\nfilled with leaves; the something rose, uttering an exclamation of\r\nastonishment, and Monte Cristo found himself facing a man about fifty\r\nyears old, who was plucking strawberries, which he was placing upon\r\ngrape leaves. He had twelve leaves and about as many strawberries,\r\nwhich, on rising suddenly, he let fall from his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are gathering your crop, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, smiling.\r\n\r\n30193m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the man, raising his hand to his cap; \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nnot up there, I know, but I have only just come down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not let me interfere with you in anything, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ncount; \xe2\x80\x9cgather your strawberries, if, indeed, there are any left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have ten left,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, \xe2\x80\x9cfor here are eleven, and I had\r\ntwenty-one, five more than last year. But I am not surprised; the\r\nspring has been warm this year, and strawberries require heat, sir.\r\nThis is the reason that, instead of the sixteen I had last year, I have\r\nthis year, you see, eleven, already plucked\xe2\x80\x94twelve, thirteen, fourteen,\r\nfifteen, sixteen, seventeen, eighteen. Ah, I miss three, they were here\r\nlast night, sir\xe2\x80\x94I am sure they were here\xe2\x80\x94I counted them. It must be the\r\nson of M\xc3\xa8re Simon who has stolen them; I saw him strolling about here\r\nthis morning. Ah, the young rascal\xe2\x80\x94stealing in a garden\xe2\x80\x94he does not\r\nknow where that may lead him to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, it is wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cbut you should take into\r\nconsideration the youth and greediness of the delinquent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gardener, \xe2\x80\x9cbut that does not make it the less\r\nunpleasant. But, sir, once more I beg pardon; perhaps you are an\r\nofficer that I am detaining here.\xe2\x80\x9d And he glanced timidly at the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s blue coat.\r\n\r\n30197m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCalm yourself, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, with the smile which he\r\nmade at will either terrible or benevolent, and which now expressed\r\nonly the kindliest feeling; \xe2\x80\x9cI am not an inspector, but a traveller,\r\nbrought here by a curiosity he half repents of, since he causes you to\r\nlose your time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my time is not valuable,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the man with a melancholy smile.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill it belongs to government, and I ought not to waste it; but,\r\nhaving received the signal that I might rest for an hour\xe2\x80\x9d (here he\r\nglanced at the sun-dial, for there was everything in the enclosure of\r\nMontlh\xc3\xa9ry, even a sun-dial), \xe2\x80\x9cand having ten minutes before me, and my\r\nstrawberries being ripe, when a day longer\xe2\x80\x94by-the-by, sir, do you think\r\ndormice eat them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, I should think not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cdormice are bad\r\nneighbors for us who do not eat them preserved, as the Romans did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? Did the Romans eat them?\xe2\x80\x9d said the gardener\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cate dormice?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have read so in Petronius,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally? They can\xe2\x80\x99t be nice, though they do say \xe2\x80\x98as fat as a dormouse.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nIt is not a wonder they are fat, sleeping all day, and only waking to\r\neat all night. Listen. Last year I had four apricots\xe2\x80\x94they stole one, I\r\nhad one nectarine, only one\xe2\x80\x94well, sir, they ate half of it on the wall;\r\na splendid nectarine\xe2\x80\x94I never ate a better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ate it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say, the half that was left\xe2\x80\x94you understand; it was\r\nexquisite, sir. Ah, those gentlemen never choose the worst morsels;\r\nlike M\xc3\xa8re Simon\xe2\x80\x99s son, who has not chosen the worst strawberries. But\r\nthis year,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the horticulturist, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take care it shall not\r\nhappen, even if I should be forced to sit by the whole night to watch\r\nwhen the strawberries are ripe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo had seen enough. Every man has a devouring passion in his\r\nheart, as every fruit has its worm; that of the telegraph man was\r\nhorticulture. He began gathering the grape-leaves which screened the\r\nsun from the grapes, and won the heart of the gardener.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you come here, sir, to see the telegraph?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, if it isn\xe2\x80\x99t contrary to the rules.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gardener; \xe2\x80\x9cnot in the least, since there is no\r\ndanger that anyone can possibly understand what we are saying.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been told,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you do not always yourselves\r\nunderstand the signals you repeat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true, sir, and that is what I like best,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man,\r\nsmiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you like that best?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause then I have no responsibility. I am a machine then, and\r\nnothing else, and so long as I work, nothing more is required of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I can have met\r\nwith a man that has no ambition? That would spoil my plans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gardener, glancing at the sun-dial, \xe2\x80\x9cthe ten minutes\r\nare almost up; I must return to my post. Will you go up with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI follow you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo entered the tower, which was divided into three stories.\r\nThe tower contained implements, such as spades, rakes, watering-pots,\r\nhung against the wall; this was all the furniture. The second was the\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s conventional abode, or rather sleeping-place; it contained a few\r\npoor articles of household furniture\xe2\x80\x94a bed, a table, two chairs, a\r\nstone pitcher\xe2\x80\x94and some dry herbs, hung up to the ceiling, which the\r\ncount recognized as sweet peas, and of which the good man was\r\npreserving the seeds; he had labelled them with as much care as if he\r\nhad been master botanist in the Jardin des Plantes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes it require much study to learn the art of telegraphing?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nMonte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe study does not take long; it was acting as a supernumerary that\r\nwas so tedious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is the pay?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA thousand francs, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but then we are lodged, as you perceive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo looked at the room. They passed to the third story; it was\r\nthe telegraph room. Monte Cristo looked in turn at the two iron handles\r\nby which the machine was worked. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is very interesting,\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut it must be very tedious for a lifetime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. At first my neck was cramped with looking at it, but at the end\r\nof a year I became used to it; and then we have our hours of\r\nrecreation, and our holidays.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHolidays?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen we have a fog.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, to be sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose are indeed holidays to me; I go into the garden, I plant, I\r\nprune, I trim, I kill the insects all day long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long have you been here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTen years, and five as a supernumerary make fifteen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFifty-five years old.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long must you have served to claim the pension?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sir, twenty-five years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how much is the pension?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hundred crowns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor humanity!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you say, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was saying it was very interesting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll you were showing me. And you really understand none of these\r\nsignals?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd have you never tried to understand them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever. Why should I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut still there are some signals only addressed to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you understand them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are always the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they mean\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98_Nothing new; You have an hour;_\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98_Tomorrow_.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is simple enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cbut look, is not your\r\ncorrespondent putting itself in motion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes; thank you, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is it saying\xe2\x80\x94anything you understand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; it asks if I am ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you reply?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the same sign, which, at the same time, tells my right-hand\r\ncorrespondent that I am ready, while it gives notice to my left-hand\r\ncorrespondent to prepare in his turn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very ingenious,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will see,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man proudly; \xe2\x80\x9cin five minutes he will speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have, then, five minutes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo to himself; \xe2\x80\x9cit is more\r\ntime than I require. My dear sir, will you allow me to ask you a\r\nquestion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are fond of gardening?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPassionately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you would be pleased to have, instead of this terrace of twenty\r\nfeet, an enclosure of two acres?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, I should make a terrestrial paradise of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou live badly on your thousand francs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBadly enough; but yet I do live.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but you have a wretchedly small garden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, the garden is not large.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, then, such as it is, it is filled with dormice, who eat\r\neverything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, they are my scourges.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me, should you have the misfortune to turn your head while your\r\nright-hand correspondent was telegraphing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should not see him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen what would happen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could not repeat the signals.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot having repeated them, through negligence, I should be fined.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hundred francs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe tenth of your income\xe2\x80\x94that would be fine work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said the man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas it ever happened to you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnce, sir, when I was grafting a rose-tree.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, suppose you were to alter a signal, and substitute another?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that is another case; I should be turned off, and lose my\r\npension.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree hundred francs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hundred crowns, yes, sir; so you see that I am not likely to do any\r\nof these things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot even for fifteen years\xe2\x80\x99 wages? Come, it is worth thinking about?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor fifteen thousand francs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, you alarm me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, you are tempting me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust so; fifteen thousand francs, do you understand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, let me see my right-hand correspondent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, do not look at him, but at this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? Do you not know these bits of paper?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBank-notes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly; there are fifteen of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd whose are they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYours, if you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMine?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the man, half-suffocated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; yours\xe2\x80\x94your own property.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, my right-hand correspondent is signalling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him signal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, you have distracted me; I shall be fined.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will cost you a hundred francs; you see it is your interest to\r\ntake my bank-notes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, my right-hand correspondent redoubles his signals; he is\r\nimpatient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind\xe2\x80\x94take these;\xe2\x80\x9d and the count placed the packet in the man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhands. \xe2\x80\x9cNow this is not all,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cyou cannot live upon your\r\nfifteen thousand francs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall still have my place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you will lose it, for you are going to alter your correspondent\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmessage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sir, what are you proposing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA jest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, unless you force me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I can effectually force you;\xe2\x80\x9d and Monte Cristo drew another\r\npacket from his pocket. \xe2\x80\x9cHere are ten thousand more francs,\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwith the fifteen thousand already in your pocket, they will make\r\ntwenty-five thousand. With five thousand you can buy a pretty little\r\nhouse with two acres of land; the remaining twenty thousand will bring\r\nyou in a thousand francs a year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA garden with two acres of land!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd a thousand francs a year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, heavens!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, take them,\xe2\x80\x9d and Monte Cristo forced the bank-notes into his\r\nhand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing very difficult.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo repeat these signs.\xe2\x80\x9d Monte Cristo took a paper from his pocket,\r\nupon which were drawn three signs, with numbers to indicate the order\r\nin which they were to be worked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, you see it will not take long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo this, and you will have nectarines and all the rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe shot told; red with fever, while the large drops fell from his\r\nbrow, the man executed, one after the other, the three signs given by\r\nthe count, in spite of the frightful contortions of the right-hand\r\ncorrespondent, who, not understanding the change, began to think the\r\ngardener had gone mad. As to the left-hand one, he conscientiously\r\nrepeated the same signals, which were finally transmitted to the\r\nMinister of the Interior.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow you are rich,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the man, \xe2\x80\x9cbut at what a price!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cI do not wish to cause you any\r\nremorse; believe me, then, when I swear to you that you have wronged no\r\nman, but on the contrary have benefited mankind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man looked at the bank-notes, felt them, counted them, turned pale,\r\nthen red, then rushed into his room to drink a glass of water, but he\r\nhad no time to reach the water-jug, and fainted in the midst of his\r\ndried herbs. Five minutes after the new telegram reached the minister,\r\nDebray had the horses put to his carriage, and drove to Danglars\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhouse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas your husband any Spanish bonds?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked of the baroness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so, indeed! He has six millions\xe2\x80\x99 worth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must sell them at whatever price.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause Don Carlos has fled from Bourges, and has returned to Spain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30203m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know?\xe2\x80\x9d Debray shrugged his shoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe idea of asking how I hear the news,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThe baroness did not wait for a repetition; she ran to her husband, who\r\nimmediately hastened to his agent, and ordered him to sell at any\r\nprice. When it was seen that Danglars sold, the Spanish funds fell\r\ndirectly. Danglars lost five hundred thousand francs; but he rid\r\nhimself of all his Spanish shares. The same evening the following was\r\nread in _Le Messager_:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c[By telegraph.] The king, Don Carlos, has escaped the vigilance of his\r\nguardians at Bourges, and has returned to Spain by the Catalonian\r\nfrontier. Barcelona has risen in his favor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll that evening nothing was spoken of but the foresight of Danglars,\r\nwho had sold his shares, and of the luck of the stock-jobber, who only\r\nlost five hundred thousand francs by such a blow. Those who had kept\r\ntheir shares, or bought those of Danglars, looked upon themselves as\r\nruined, and passed a very bad night. Next morning _Le Moniteur_\r\ncontained the following:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was without any foundation that _Le Messager_ yesterday announced\r\nthe flight of Don Carlos and the revolt of Barcelona. The king (Don\r\nCarlos) has not left Bourges, and the peninsula is in the enjoyment of\r\nprofound peace. A telegraphic signal, improperly interpreted, owing to\r\nthe fog, was the cause of this error.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe funds rose one per cent higher than before they had fallen. This,\r\nreckoning his loss, and what he had missed gaining, made the difference\r\nof a million to Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo to Morrel, who was at his house when the news\r\narrived of the strange reverse of fortune of which Danglars had been\r\nthe victim, \xe2\x80\x9cI have just made a discovery for twenty-five thousand\r\nfrancs, for which I would have paid a hundred thousand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you discovered?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have just discovered how a gardener may get rid of the dormice that\r\neat his peaches.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 62. Ghosts\r\n\r\nAt first sight, the exterior of the house at Auteuil gave no\r\nindications of splendor, nothing one would expect from the destined\r\nresidence of the magnificent Count of Monte Cristo; but this simplicity\r\nwas according to the will of its master, who positively ordered nothing\r\nto be altered outside. The splendor was within. Indeed, almost before\r\nthe door opened, the scene changed.\r\n\r\nM. Bertuccio had outdone himself in the taste displayed in furnishing,\r\nand in the rapidity with which it was executed. It is told that the Duc\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99Antin removed in a single night a whole avenue of trees that annoyed\r\nLouis XIV.; in three days M. Bertuccio planted an entirely bare court\r\nwith poplars, large spreading sycamores to shade the different parts of\r\nthe house, and in the foreground, instead of the usual paving-stones,\r\nhalf hidden by the grass, there extended a lawn but that morning laid\r\ndown, and upon which the water was yet glistening. For the rest, the\r\norders had been issued by the count; he himself had given a plan to\r\nBertuccio, marking the spot where each tree was to be planted, and the\r\nshape and extent of the lawn which was to take the place of the\r\npaving-stones.\r\n\r\nThus the house had become unrecognizable, and Bertuccio himself\r\ndeclared that he scarcely knew it, encircled as it was by a framework\r\nof trees. The overseer would not have objected, while he was about it,\r\nto have made some improvements in the garden, but the count had\r\npositively forbidden it to be touched. Bertuccio made amends, however,\r\nby loading the antechambers, staircases, and mantle-pieces with\r\nflowers.\r\n\r\nWhat, above all, manifested the shrewdness of the steward, and the\r\nprofound science of the master, the one in carrying out the ideas of\r\nthe other, was that this house which appeared only the night before so\r\nsad and gloomy, impregnated with that sickly smell one can almost fancy\r\nto be the smell of time, had in a single day acquired the aspect of\r\nlife, was scented with its master\xe2\x80\x99s favorite perfumes, and had the very\r\nlight regulated according to his wish. When the count arrived, he had\r\nunder his touch his books and arms, his eyes rested upon his favorite\r\npictures; his dogs, whose caresses he loved, welcomed him in the\r\nantechamber; the birds, whose songs delighted him, cheered him with\r\ntheir music; and the house, awakened from its long sleep, like the\r\nsleeping beauty in the wood, lived, sang, and bloomed like the houses\r\nwe have long cherished, and in which, when we are forced to leave them,\r\nwe leave a part of our souls.\r\n\r\nThe servants passed gayly along the fine courtyard; some, belonging to\r\nthe kitchens, gliding down the stairs, restored but the previous day,\r\nas if they had always inhabited the house; others filling the\r\ncoach-houses, where the equipages, encased and numbered, appeared to\r\nhave been installed for the last fifty years; and in the stables the\r\nhorses replied with neighs to the grooms, who spoke to them with much\r\nmore respect than many servants pay their masters.\r\n\r\nThe library was divided into two parts on either side of the wall, and\r\ncontained upwards of two thousand volumes; one division was entirely\r\ndevoted to novels, and even the volume which had been published but the\r\nday before was to be seen in its place in all the dignity of its red\r\nand gold binding.\r\n\r\nOn the other side of the house, to match with the library, was the\r\nconservatory, ornamented with rare flowers, that bloomed in china jars;\r\nand in the midst of the greenhouse, marvellous alike to sight and\r\nsmell, was a billiard-table which looked as if it had been abandoned\r\nduring the past hour by players who had left the balls on the cloth.\r\n\r\nOne chamber alone had been respected by the magnificent Bertuccio.\r\nBefore this room, to which you could ascend by the grand, and go out by\r\nthe back staircase, the servants passed with curiosity, and Bertuccio\r\nwith terror.\r\n\r\nAt five o\xe2\x80\x99clock precisely, the count arrived before the house at\r\nAuteuil, followed by Ali. Bertuccio was awaiting this arrival with\r\nimpatience, mingled with uneasiness; he hoped for some compliments,\r\nwhile, at the same time, he feared to have frowns. Monte Cristo\r\ndescended into the courtyard, walked all over the house, without giving\r\nany sign of approbation or pleasure, until he entered his bedroom,\r\nsituated on the opposite side to the closed room; then he approached a\r\nlittle piece of furniture, made of rosewood, which he had noticed at a\r\nprevious visit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat can only be to hold gloves,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill your excellency deign to open it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the delighted Bertuccio,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand you will find gloves in it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nElsewhere the count found everything he required\xe2\x80\x94smelling-bottles,\r\ncigars, knick-knacks.\r\n\r\n30207m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; and M. Bertuccio left enraptured, so great, so\r\npowerful, and real was the influence exercised by this man over all who\r\nsurrounded him.\r\n\r\nAt precisely six o\xe2\x80\x99clock the clatter of horses\xe2\x80\x99 hoofs was heard at the\r\nentrance door; it was our captain of Spahis, who had arrived on M\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa9ah.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure I am the first,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cI did it on purpose to have\r\nyou a minute to myself, before everyone came. Julie and Emmanuel have a\r\nthousand things to tell you. Ah, really this is magnificent! But tell\r\nme, count, will your people take care of my horse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not alarm yourself, my dear Maximilian\xe2\x80\x94they understand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean, because he wants petting. If you had seen at what a pace he\r\ncame\xe2\x80\x94like the wind!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think so,\xe2\x80\x94a horse that cost 5,000 francs!\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo,\r\nin the tone which a father would use towards a son.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you regret them?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel, with his open laugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? Certainly not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count. \xe2\x80\x9cNo; I should only regret if the\r\nhorse had not proved good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is so good, that I have distanced M. de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, one of the\r\nbest riders in France, and M. Debray, who both mount the minister\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nArabians; and close on their heels are the horses of Madame Danglars,\r\nwho always go at six leagues an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen they follow you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee, they are here.\xe2\x80\x9d And at the same minute a carriage with smoking\r\nhorses, accompanied by two mounted gentlemen, arrived at the gate,\r\nwhich opened before them. The carriage drove round, and stopped at the\r\nsteps, followed by the horsemen.\r\n\r\nThe instant Debray had touched the ground, he was at the carriage-door.\r\nHe offered his hand to the baroness, who, descending, took it with a\r\npeculiarity of manner imperceptible to everyone but Monte Cristo. But\r\nnothing escaped the count\xe2\x80\x99s notice, and he observed a little note,\r\npassed with the facility that indicates frequent practice, from the\r\nhand of Madame Danglars to that of the minister\xe2\x80\x99s secretary.\r\n\r\nAfter his wife the banker descended, as pale as though he had issued\r\nfrom his tomb instead of his carriage.\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars threw a rapid and inquiring glance which could only be\r\ninterpreted by Monte Cristo, around the courtyard, over the peristyle,\r\nand across the front of the house, then, repressing a slight emotion,\r\nwhich must have been seen on her countenance if she had not kept her\r\ncolor, she ascended the steps, saying to Morrel:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, if you were a friend of mine, I should ask you if you would sell\r\nyour horse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel smiled with an expression very like a grimace, and then turned\r\nround to Monte Cristo, as if to ask him to extricate him from his\r\nembarrassment. The count understood him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy did you not make that request of me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the baroness, \xe2\x80\x9cone can wish for nothing, one\r\nis so sure to obtain it. If it were so with M. Morrel\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnfortunately,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, \xe2\x80\x9cI am witness that M. Morrel cannot\r\ngive up his horse, his honor being engaged in keeping it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe laid a wager he would tame M\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa9ah in the space of six months. You\r\nunderstand now that if he were to get rid of the animal before the time\r\nnamed, he would not only lose his bet, but people would say he was\r\nafraid; and a brave captain of Spahis cannot risk this, even to gratify\r\na pretty woman, which is, in my opinion, one of the most sacred\r\nobligations in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see my position, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, bestowing a grateful smile\r\non Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, in his coarse tone, ill-concealed by a\r\nforced smile, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you have already got horses enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars seldom allowed remarks of this kind to pass unnoticed,\r\nbut, to the surprise of the young people, she pretended not to hear it,\r\nand said nothing. Monte Cristo smiled at her unusual humility, and\r\nshowed her two immense porcelain jars, over which wound marine plants,\r\nof a size and delicacy that nature alone could produce. The baroness\r\nwas astonished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cyou could plant one of the chestnut-trees in the\r\nTuileries inside! How can such enormous jars have been manufactured?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must not ask of us, the\r\nmanufacturers of fine porcelain, such a question. It is the work of\r\nanother age, constructed by the genii of earth and water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x94at what period can that have been?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know; I have only heard that an emperor of China had an oven\r\nbuilt expressly, and that in this oven twelve jars like this were\r\nsuccessively baked. Two broke, from the heat of the fire; the other ten\r\nwere sunk three hundred fathoms deep into the sea. The sea, knowing\r\nwhat was required of her, threw over them her weeds, encircled them\r\nwith coral, and encrusted them with shells; the whole was cemented by\r\ntwo hundred years beneath these almost impervious depths, for a\r\nrevolution carried away the emperor who wished to make the trial, and\r\nonly left the documents proving the manufacture of the jars and their\r\ndescent into the sea. At the end of two hundred years the documents\r\nwere found, and they thought of bringing up the jars. Divers descended\r\nin machines, made expressly on the discovery, into the bay where they\r\nwere thrown; but of ten three only remained, the rest having been\r\nbroken by the waves. I am fond of these jars, upon which, perhaps,\r\nmisshapen, frightful monsters have fixed their cold, dull eyes, and in\r\nwhich myriads of small fish have slept, seeking a refuge from the\r\npursuit of their enemies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, Danglars, who had cared little for curiosities, was\r\nmechanically tearing off the blossoms of a splendid orange-tree, one\r\nafter another. When he had finished with the orange-tree, he began at\r\nthe cactus; but this, not being so easily plucked as the orange-tree,\r\npricked him dreadfully. He shuddered, and rubbed his eyes as though\r\nawaking from a dream.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo to him, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not recommend my pictures to\r\nyou, who possess such splendid paintings; but, nevertheless, here are\r\ntwo by Hobbema, a Paul Potter, a Mieris, two by Gerard Douw, a Raphael,\r\na Van Dyck, a Zurbaran, and two or three by Murillo, worth looking at.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray; \xe2\x80\x9cI recognize this Hobbema.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; it was proposed for the Museum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich, I believe, does not contain one?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; and yet they refused to buy it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou pretend not to know,\xe2\x80\x94because government was not rich enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, pardon me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9cI have heard of these things\r\nevery day during the last eight years, and I cannot understand them\r\nyet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will, by and by,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMajor Bartolomeo Cavalcanti and Count Andrea Cavalcanti,\xe2\x80\x9d announced\r\nBaptistin.\r\n\r\nA black satin stock, fresh from the maker\xe2\x80\x99s hands, gray moustaches, a\r\nbold eye, a major\xe2\x80\x99s uniform, ornamented with three medals and five\r\ncrosses\xe2\x80\x94in fact, the thorough bearing of an old soldier\xe2\x80\x94such was the\r\nappearance of Major Bartolomeo Cavalcanti, that tender father with whom\r\nwe are already acquainted. Close to him, dressed in entirely new\r\nclothes, advanced smilingly Count Andrea Cavalcanti, the dutiful son,\r\nwhom we also know. The three young people were talking together. On the\r\nentrance of the new-comers, their eyes glanced from father to son, and\r\nthen, naturally enough, rested on the latter, whom they began\r\ncriticising.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCavalcanti!\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fine name,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cthese Italians are well named and badly\r\ndressed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are fastidious, Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Debray; \xe2\x80\x9cthose clothes\r\nare well cut and quite new.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is just what I find fault with. That gentleman appears to be well\r\ndressed for the first time in his life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are those gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Danglars of Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou heard\xe2\x80\x94Cavalcanti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat tells me their name, and nothing else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! true. You do not know the Italian nobility; the Cavalcanti are all\r\ndescended from princes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave they any fortune?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn enormous one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do they do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTry to spend it all. They have some business with you, I think, from\r\nwhat they told me the day before yesterday. I, indeed, invited them\r\nhere today on your account. I will introduce you to them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut they appear to speak French with a very pure accent,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nDanglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe son has been educated in a college in the south; I believe near\r\nMarseilles. You will find him quite enthusiastic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon what subject?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Madame Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe French ladies, madame. He has made up his mind to take a wife from\r\nParis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fine idea that of his,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, shrugging his shoulders.\r\nMadame Danglars looked at her husband with an expression which, at any\r\nother time, would have indicated a storm, but for the second time she\r\ncontrolled herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe baron appears thoughtful today,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo to her; \xe2\x80\x9care\r\nthey going to put him in the ministry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot yet, I think. More likely he has been speculating on the Bourse,\r\nand has lost money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. and Madame de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Baptistin.\r\n\r\nThey entered. M. de Villefort, notwithstanding his self-control, was\r\nvisibly affected, and when Monte Cristo touched his hand, he felt it\r\ntremble.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, women alone know how to dissimulate,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo to\r\nhimself, glancing at Madame Danglars, who was smiling on the procureur,\r\nand embracing his wife.\r\n\r\nAfter a short time, the count saw Bertuccio, who, until then, had been\r\noccupied on the other side of the house, glide into an adjoining room.\r\nHe went to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want, M. Bertuccio?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency has not stated the number of guests.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, true.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow many covers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount for yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs everyone here, your excellency?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio glanced through the door, which was ajar. The count watched\r\nhim. \xe2\x80\x9cGood heavens!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat woman\xe2\x80\x94that woman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe one with a white dress and so many diamonds\xe2\x80\x94the fair one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know her name; but it is she, sir, it is she!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe woman of the garden!\xe2\x80\x94she that was _enceinte_\xe2\x80\x94she who was walking\r\nwhile she waited for\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio stood at the open door, with his eyes starting and his hair\r\non end.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWaiting for whom?\xe2\x80\x9d Bertuccio, without answering, pointed to Villefort\r\nwith something of the gesture Macbeth uses to point out Banquo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, oh!\xe2\x80\x9d he at length muttered, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? Who?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHim!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHim!\xe2\x80\x94M. de Villefort, the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney? Certainly I see him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I did not kill him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, I think you are going mad, good Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he is not dead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30213m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; you see plainly he is not dead. Instead of striking between the\r\nsixth and seventh left ribs, as your countrymen do, you must have\r\nstruck higher or lower, and life is very tenacious in these lawyers, or\r\nrather there is no truth in anything you have told me\xe2\x80\x94it was a fright\r\nof the imagination, a dream of your fancy. You went to sleep full of\r\nthoughts of vengeance; they weighed heavily upon your stomach; you had\r\nthe nightmare\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s all. Come, calm yourself, and reckon them up\xe2\x80\x94M.\r\nand Madame de Villefort, two; M. and Madame Danglars, four; M. de\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, M. Debray, M. Morrel, seven; Major Bartolomeo\r\nCavalcanti, eight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEight!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Bertuccio.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop! You are in a shocking hurry to be off\xe2\x80\x94you forget one of my\r\nguests. Lean a little to the left. Stay! look at M. Andrea Cavalcanti,\r\nthe young man in a black coat, looking at Murillo\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98Madonna\xe2\x80\x99; now he\r\nis turning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis time Bertuccio would have uttered an exclamation, had not a look\r\nfrom Monte Cristo silenced him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBenedetto?\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered; \xe2\x80\x9cfatality!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf-past six o\xe2\x80\x99clock has just struck, M. Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count\r\nseverely; \xe2\x80\x9cI ordered dinner at that hour, and I do not like to wait;\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand he returned to his guests, while Bertuccio, leaning against the\r\nwall, succeeded in reaching the dining-room. Five minutes afterwards\r\nthe doors of the drawing-room were thrown open, and Bertuccio appearing\r\nsaid, with a violent effort, \xe2\x80\x9cThe dinner waits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Count of Monte Cristo offered his arm to Madame de Villefort. \xe2\x80\x9cM.\r\nde Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you conduct the Baroness Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort complied, and they passed on to the dining-room.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 63. The Dinner\r\n\r\nIt was evident that one sentiment affected all the guests on entering\r\nthe dining-room. Each one asked what strange influence had brought them\r\nto this house, and yet astonished, even uneasy though they were, they\r\nstill felt that they would not like to be absent. The recent events,\r\nthe solitary and eccentric position of the count, his enormous, nay,\r\nalmost incredible fortune, should have made men cautious, and have\r\naltogether prevented ladies visiting a house where there was no one of\r\ntheir own sex to receive them; and yet curiosity had been enough to\r\nlead them to overleap the bounds of prudence and decorum.\r\n\r\nAnd all present, even including Cavalcanti and his son, notwithstanding\r\nthe stiffness of the one and the carelessness of the other, were\r\nthoughtful, on finding themselves assembled at the house of this\r\nincomprehensible man. Madame Danglars had started when Villefort, on\r\nthe count\xe2\x80\x99s invitation, offered his arm; and Villefort felt that his\r\nglance was uneasy beneath his gold spectacles, when he felt the arm of\r\nthe baroness press upon his own. None of this had escaped the count,\r\nand even by this mere contact of individuals the scene had already\r\nacquired considerable interest for an observer.\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort had on the right hand Madame Danglars, on his left\r\nMorrel. The count was seated between Madame de Villefort and Danglars;\r\nthe other seats were filled by Debray, who was placed between the two\r\nCavalcanti, and by Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, seated between Madame de Villefort\r\nand Morrel.\r\n\r\nThe repast was magnificent; Monte Cristo had endeavored completely to\r\noverturn the Parisian ideas, and to feed the curiosity as much as the\r\nappetite of his guests. It was an Oriental feast that he offered to\r\nthem, but of such a kind as the Arabian fairies might be supposed to\r\nprepare. Every delicious fruit that the four quarters of the globe\r\ncould provide was heaped in vases from China and jars from Japan. Rare\r\nbirds, retaining their most brilliant plumage, enormous fish, spread\r\nupon massive silver dishes, together with every wine produced in the\r\nArchipelago, Asia Minor, or the Cape, sparkling in bottles, whose\r\ngrotesque shape seemed to give an additional flavor to the draught,\xe2\x80\x94all\r\nthese, like one of the displays with which Apicius of old gratified his\r\nguests, passed in review before the eyes of the astonished Parisians,\r\nwho understood that it was possible to expend a thousand louis upon a\r\ndinner for ten persons, but only on the condition of eating pearls,\r\nlike Cleopatra, or drinking refined gold, like Lorenzo de\xe2\x80\x99 Medici.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo noticed the general astonishment, and began laughing and\r\njoking about it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will admit that, when arrived at a certain\r\ndegree of fortune, the superfluities of life are all that can be\r\ndesired; and the ladies will allow that, after having risen to a\r\ncertain eminence of position, the ideal alone can be more exalted. Now,\r\nto follow out this reasoning, what is the marvellous?\xe2\x80\x94that which we do\r\nnot understand. What is it that we really desire?\xe2\x80\x94that which we cannot\r\nobtain. Now, to see things which I cannot understand, to procure\r\nimpossibilities, these are the study of my life. I gratify my wishes by\r\ntwo means\xe2\x80\x94my will and my money. I take as much interest in the pursuit\r\nof some whim as you do, M. Danglars, in promoting a new railway line;\r\nyou, M. de Villefort, in condemning a culprit to death; you, M. Debray,\r\nin pacifying a kingdom; you, M. de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, in pleasing a woman;\r\nand you, Morrel, in breaking a horse that no one can ride. For example,\r\nyou see these two fish; one brought from fifty leagues beyond St.\r\nPetersburg, the other five leagues from Naples. Is it not amusing to\r\nsee them both on the same table?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are the two fish?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, who has lived in Russia, will tell you the name of\r\none, and Major Cavalcanti, who is an Italian, will tell you the name of\r\nthe other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis one is, I think, a sterlet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that one, if I mistake not, a lamprey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust so. Now, M. Danglars, ask these gentlemen where they are caught.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSterlets,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9care only found in the Volga.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cavalcanti, \xe2\x80\x9cI know that Lake Fusaro alone supplies\r\nlampreys of that size.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly; one comes from the Volga, and the other from Lake Fusaro.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible!\xe2\x80\x9d cried all the guests simultaneously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, this is just what amuses me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cI am like\r\nNero\xe2\x80\x94_cupitor impossibilium_; and that is what is amusing you at this\r\nmoment. This fish, which seems so exquisite to you, is very likely no\r\nbetter than perch or salmon; but it seemed impossible to procure it,\r\nand here it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how could you have these fish brought to France?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing more easy. Each fish was brought over in a cask\xe2\x80\x94one filled\r\nwith river herbs and weeds, the other with rushes and lake plants; they\r\nwere placed in a wagon built on purpose, and thus the sterlet lived\r\ntwelve days, the lamprey eight, and both were alive when my cook seized\r\nthem, killing one with milk and the other with wine. You do not believe\r\nme, M. Danglars!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot help doubting,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Danglars with his stupid smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBaptistin,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9chave the other fish brought in\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nsterlet and the lamprey which came in the other casks, and which are\r\nyet alive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars opened his bewildered eyes; the company clapped their hands.\r\nFour servants carried in two casks covered with aquatic plants, and in\r\neach of which was breathing a fish similar to those on the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why have two of each sort?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerely because one might have died,\xe2\x80\x9d carelessly answered Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are certainly an extraordinary man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nphilosophers may well say it is a fine thing to be rich.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to have ideas,\xe2\x80\x9d added Madame Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do not give me credit for this, madame; it was done by the Romans,\r\nwho much esteemed them, and Pliny relates that they sent slaves from\r\nOstia to Rome, who carried on their heads fish which he calls the\r\n_mulus_, and which, from the description, must probably be the\r\ngoldfish. It was also considered a luxury to have them alive, it being\r\nan amusing sight to see them die, for, when dying, they change color\r\nthree or four times, and like the rainbow when it disappears, pass\r\nthrough all the prismatic shades, after which they were sent to the\r\nkitchen. Their agony formed part of their merit\xe2\x80\x94if they were not seen\r\nalive, they were despised when dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cbut then Ostia is only a few leagues from Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut what would be the use of living\r\neighteen hundred years after Lucullus, if we can do no better than he\r\ncould?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two Cavalcanti opened their enormous eyes, but had the good sense\r\nnot to say anything.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll this is very extraordinary,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9cstill, what I\r\nadmire the most, I confess, is the marvellous promptitude with which\r\nyour orders are executed. Is it not true that you only bought this\r\nhouse five or six days ago?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I am sure it is quite transformed since last week. If I remember\r\nrightly, it had another entrance, and the courtyard was paved and\r\nempty; while today we have a splendid lawn, bordered by trees which\r\nappear to be a hundred years old.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not? I am fond of grass and shade,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthe door was towards the road before,\r\nand on the day of my miraculous escape you brought me into the house\r\nfrom the road, I remember.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I preferred having an entrance\r\nwhich would allow me to see the Bois de Boulogne over my gate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn four days,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cit is extraordinary!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cit seems quite miraculous to make a new\r\nhouse out of an old one; for it was very old, and dull too. I recollect\r\ncoming for my mother to look at it when M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran advertised it\r\nfor sale two or three years ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran?\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cthen this house\r\nbelonged to M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran before you bought it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible that you do not know of whom you purchased it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite so; my steward transacts all this business for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is certainly ten years since the house had been occupied,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cand it was quite melancholy to look at it, with the\r\nblinds closed, the doors locked, and the weeds in the court. Really, if\r\nthe house had not belonged to the father-in-law of the procureur, one\r\nmight have thought it some accursed place where a horrible crime had\r\nbeen committed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort, who had hitherto not tasted the three or four glasses of\r\nrare wine which were placed before him, here took one, and drank it\r\noff. Monte Cristo allowed a short time to elapse, and then said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is singular, baron, but the same idea came across me the first time\r\nI came here; it looked so gloomy I should never have bought it if my\r\nsteward had not taken the matter into his own hands. Perhaps the fellow\r\nhad been bribed by the notary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is probable,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered out Villefort, trying to smile; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I can\r\nassure you that I had nothing to do with any such proceeding. This\r\nhouse is part of Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s marriage-portion, and M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\r\nwished to sell it; for if it had remained another year or two\r\nuninhabited it would have fallen to ruin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s turn to become pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere was, above all, one room,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cvery plain\r\nin appearance, hung with red damask, which, I know not why, appeared to\r\nme quite dramatic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cwhy dramatic?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan we account for instinct?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cAre there not some\r\nplaces where we seem to breathe sadness?\xe2\x80\x94why, we cannot tell. It is a\r\nchain of recollections\xe2\x80\x94an idea which carries you back to other times,\r\nto other places\xe2\x80\x94which, very likely, have no connection with the present\r\ntime and place. And there is something in this room which reminds me\r\nforcibly of the chamber of the Marquise de Ganges10 or Desdemona. Stay,\r\nsince we have finished dinner, I will show it to you, and then we will\r\ntake coffee in the garden. After dinner, the play.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo looked inquiringly at his guests. Madame de Villefort\r\nrose, Monte Cristo did the same, and the rest followed their example.\r\nVillefort and Madame Danglars remained for a moment, as if rooted to\r\ntheir seats; they questioned each other with vague and stupid glances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you hear?\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must go,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, offering his arm.\r\n\r\nThe others, attracted by curiosity, were already scattered in different\r\nparts of the house; for they thought the visit would not be limited to\r\nthe one room, and that, at the same time, they would obtain a view of\r\nthe rest of the building, of which Monte Cristo had created a palace.\r\nEach one went out by the open doors. Monte Cristo waited for the two\r\nwho remained; then, when they had passed, he brought up the rear, and\r\non his face was a smile, which, if they could have understood it, would\r\nhave alarmed them much more than a visit to the room they were about to\r\nenter. They began by walking through the apartments, many of which were\r\nfitted up in the Eastern style, with cushions and divans instead of\r\nbeds, and pipes instead of furniture. The drawing-rooms were decorated\r\nwith the rarest pictures by the old masters, the boudoirs hung with\r\ndraperies from China, of fanciful colors, fantastic design, and\r\nwonderful texture. At length they arrived at the famous room. There was\r\nnothing particular about it, excepting that, although daylight had\r\ndisappeared, it was not lighted, and everything in it was\r\nold-fashioned, while the rest of the rooms had been redecorated. These\r\ntwo causes were enough to give it a gloomy aspect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh.\xe2\x80\x9d cried Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cit is really frightful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars tried to utter a few words, but was not heard. Many\r\nobservations were made, the import of which was a unanimous opinion\r\nthat there was something sinister about the room.\r\n\r\n30221m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it not so?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cLook at that large clumsy bed,\r\nhung with such gloomy, blood-colored drapery! And those two crayon\r\nportraits, that have faded from the dampness; do they not seem to say,\r\nwith their pale lips and staring eyes, \xe2\x80\x98We have seen\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort became livid; Madame Danglars fell into a long seat placed\r\nnear the chimney.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9care you courageous enough to\r\nsit down upon the very seat perhaps upon which the crime was\r\ncommitted?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars rose suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is not all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is there more?\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, who had not failed to notice the\r\nagitation of Madame Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, what else is there?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cfor, at present, I cannot say\r\nthat I have seen anything extraordinary. What do you say, M.\r\nCavalcanti?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have at Pisa, Ugolino\xe2\x80\x99s tower; at Ferrara, Tasso\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nprison; at Rimini, the room of Francesca and Paolo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but you have not this little staircase,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo,\r\nopening a door concealed by the drapery. \xe2\x80\x9cLook at it, and tell me what\r\nyou think of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a wicked-looking, crooked staircase,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud with a\r\nsmile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know whether the wine of Chios produces melancholy, but\r\ncertainly everything appears to me black in this house,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray.\r\n\r\nEver since Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s dowry had been mentioned, Morrel had been silent\r\nand sad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you imagine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9csome Othello or Abb\xc3\xa9 de Ganges,\r\none stormy, dark night, descending these stairs step by step, carrying\r\na load, which he wishes to hide from the sight of man, if not from\r\nGod?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars half fainted on the arm of Villefort, who was obliged\r\nto support himself against the wall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is the matter with you? how pale you\r\nlook!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very evident what is the matter with her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de\r\nVillefort; \xe2\x80\x9cM. de Monte Cristo is relating horrible stories to us,\r\ndoubtless intending to frighten us to death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9creally, count, you frighten the ladies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Debray, in a whisper, of Madame Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied with a violent effort. \xe2\x80\x9cI want air, that is\r\nall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you come into the garden?\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, advancing towards the\r\nback staircase.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, \xe2\x80\x9cI would rather remain here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you really frightened, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you suppose scenes in a\r\nmanner which gives them the appearance of reality.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30223m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cit is all a matter of\r\nimagination. Why should we not imagine this the apartment of an honest\r\nmother? And this bed with red hangings, a bed visited by the goddess\r\nLucina? And that mysterious staircase, the passage through which, not\r\nto disturb their sleep, the doctor and nurse pass, or even the father\r\ncarrying the sleeping child?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere Madame Danglars, instead of being calmed by the soft picture,\r\nuttered a groan and fainted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame Danglars is ill,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cit would be better to take\r\nher to her carriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, _mon Dieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cand I have forgotten my\r\nsmelling-bottle!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have mine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort; and she passed over to Monte\r\nCristo a bottle full of the same kind of red liquid whose good\r\nproperties the count had tested on Edward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, taking it from her hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cat your advice I have made the trial.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd have you succeeded?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars was carried into the adjoining room; Monte Cristo\r\ndropped a very small portion of the red liquid upon her lips; she\r\nreturned to consciousness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d she cried, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a frightful dream!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort pressed her hand to let her know it was not a dream. They\r\nlooked for M. Danglars, but, as he was not especially interested in\r\npoetical ideas, he had gone into the garden, and was talking with Major\r\nCavalcanti on the projected railway from Leghorn to Florence. Monte\r\nCristo seemed in despair. He took the arm of Madame Danglars, and\r\nconducted her into the garden, where they found Danglars taking coffee\r\nbetween the Cavalcanti.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cdid I alarm you much?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you know, things impress us\r\ndifferently, according to the mood of our minds.\xe2\x80\x9d Villefort forced a\r\nlaugh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then, you know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9can idea, a supposition, is sufficient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cyou may believe me if you like, but it is\r\nmy opinion that a crime has been committed in this house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthe king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney is here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9csince that is the case, I will take\r\nadvantage of his presence to make my declaration.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour declaration?\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, before witnesses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, this is very interesting,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray; \xe2\x80\x9cif there really has been\r\na crime, we will investigate it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere has been a crime,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cCome this way, gentlemen;\r\ncome, M. Villefort, for a declaration to be available, should be made\r\nbefore the competent authorities.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then took Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and, at the same time, holding that of\r\nMadame Danglars under his own, he dragged the procureur to the\r\nplantain-tree, where the shade was thickest. All the other guests\r\nfollowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9chere, in this very spot\xe2\x80\x9d (and he stamped\r\nupon the ground), \xe2\x80\x9cI had the earth dug up and fresh mould put in, to\r\nrefresh these old trees; well, my man, digging, found a box, or rather,\r\nthe iron-work of a box, in the midst of which was the skeleton of a\r\nnewly born infant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30225m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo felt the arm of Madame Danglars stiffen, while that of\r\nVillefort trembled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA newly born infant,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Debray; \xe2\x80\x9cthis affair becomes serious!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cI was not wrong just now then, when I\r\nsaid that houses had souls and faces like men, and that their exteriors\r\ncarried the impress of their characters. This house was gloomy because\r\nit was remorseful: it was remorseful because it concealed a crime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho said it was a crime?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Villefort, with a last effort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow? is it not a crime to bury a living child in a garden?\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nMonte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd pray what do you call such an action?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who said it was buried alive?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy bury it there if it were dead? This garden has never been a\r\ncemetery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is done to infanticides in this country?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Major Cavalcanti\r\ninnocently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, their heads are soon cut off,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cavalcanti.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so; am I not right, M. de Villefort?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, count,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, in a voice now scarcely human.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo, seeing that the two persons for whom he had prepared this\r\nscene could scarcely endure it, and not wishing to carry it too far,\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x94some coffee, we seem to have forgotten it,\xe2\x80\x9d and he\r\nconducted the guests back to the table on the lawn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI am ashamed to own it, but all\r\nyour frightful stories have so upset me, that I must beg you to let me\r\nsit down;\xe2\x80\x9d and she fell into a chair.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo bowed, and went to Madame de Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think Madame Danglars again requires your bottle,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. But\r\nbefore Madame de Villefort could reach her friend, the procureur had\r\nfound time to whisper to Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI must speak to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn my office, or in the court, if you like,\xe2\x80\x94that is the surest place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will be there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment Madame de Villefort approached.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, my dear friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars, trying to smile; \xe2\x80\x9cit is\r\nover now, and I am much better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 64. The Beggar\r\n\r\nThe evening passed on; Madame de Villefort expressed a desire to return\r\nto Paris, which Madame Danglars had not dared to do, notwithstanding\r\nthe uneasiness she experienced. On his wife\xe2\x80\x99s request, M. de Villefort\r\nwas the first to give the signal of departure. He offered a seat in his\r\nlandau to Madame Danglars, that she might be under the care of his\r\nwife. As for M. Danglars, absorbed in an interesting conversation with\r\nM. Cavalcanti, he paid no attention to anything that was passing. While\r\nMonte Cristo had begged the smelling-bottle of Madame de Villefort, he\r\nhad noticed the approach of Villefort to Madame Danglars, and he soon\r\nguessed all that had passed between them, though the words had been\r\nuttered in so low a voice as hardly to be heard by Madame Danglars.\r\nWithout opposing their arrangements, he allowed Morrel, Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud,\r\nand Debray to leave on horseback, and the ladies in M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncarriage. Danglars, more and more delighted with Major Cavalcanti, had\r\noffered him a seat in his carriage. Andrea Cavalcanti found his tilbury\r\nwaiting at the door; the groom, in every respect a caricature of the\r\nEnglish fashion, was standing on tiptoe to hold a large iron-gray\r\nhorse.\r\n\r\nAndrea had spoken very little during dinner; he was an intelligent lad,\r\nand he feared to utter some absurdity before so many grand people,\r\namongst whom, with dilating eyes, he saw the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney. Then he\r\nhad been seized upon by Danglars, who, with a rapid glance at the\r\nstiff-necked old major and his modest son, and taking into\r\nconsideration the hospitality of the count, made up his mind that he\r\nwas in the society of some nabob come to Paris to finish the worldly\r\neducation of his heir.
