He contemplated with unspeakable delight the\r\nlarge diamond which shone on the major\xe2\x80\x99s little finger; for the major,\r\nlike a prudent man, in case of any accident happening to his\r\nbank-notes, had immediately converted them into an available asset.\r\nThen, after dinner, on the pretext of business, he questioned the\r\nfather and son upon their mode of living; and the father and son,\r\npreviously informed that it was through Danglars the one was to receive\r\nhis 48,000 francs and the other 50,000 livres annually, were so full of\r\naffability that they would have shaken hands even with the banker\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nservants, so much did their gratitude need an object to expend itself\r\nupon.\r\n\r\nOne thing above all the rest heightened the respect, nay almost the\r\nveneration, of Danglars for Cavalcanti. The latter, faithful to the\r\nprinciple of Horace, _nil admirari_, had contented himself with showing\r\nhis knowledge by declaring in what lake the best lampreys were caught.\r\nThen he had eaten some without saying a word more; Danglars, therefore,\r\nconcluded that such luxuries were common at the table of the\r\nillustrious descendant of the Cavalcanti, who most likely in Lucca fed\r\nupon trout brought from Switzerland, and lobsters sent from England, by\r\nthe same means used by the count to bring the lampreys from Lake\r\nFusaro, and the sterlet from the Volga. Thus it was with much\r\npoliteness of manner that he heard Cavalcanti pronounce these words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow, sir, I shall have the honor of waiting upon you on\r\nbusiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cshall be most happy to receive you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUpon which he offered to take Cavalcanti in his carriage to the H\xc3\xb4tel\r\ndes Princes, if it would not be depriving him of the company of his\r\nson. To this Cavalcanti replied by saying that for some time past his\r\nson had lived independently of him, that he had his own horses and\r\ncarriages, and that not having come together, it would not be difficult\r\nfor them to leave separately. The major seated himself, therefore, by\r\nthe side of Danglars, who was more and more charmed with the ideas of\r\norder and economy which ruled this man, and yet who, being able to\r\nallow his son 60,000 francs a year, might be supposed to possess a\r\nfortune of 500,000 or 600,000 livres.\r\n\r\nAs for Andrea, he began, by way of showing off, to scold his groom,\r\nwho, instead of bringing the tilbury to the steps of the house, had\r\ntaken it to the outer door, thus giving him the trouble of walking\r\nthirty steps to reach it. The groom heard him with humility, took the\r\nbit of the impatient animal with his left hand, and with the right held\r\nout the reins to Andrea, who, taking them from him, rested his polished\r\nboot lightly on the step.\r\n\r\nAt that moment a hand touched his shoulder. The young man turned round,\r\nthinking that Danglars or Monte Cristo had forgotten something they\r\nwished to tell him, and had returned just as they were starting. But\r\ninstead of either of these, he saw nothing but a strange face,\r\nsunburnt, and encircled by a beard, with eyes brilliant as carbuncles,\r\nand a smile upon the mouth which displayed a perfect set of white\r\nteeth, pointed and sharp as the wolf\xe2\x80\x99s or jackal\xe2\x80\x99s. A red handkerchief\r\nencircled his gray head; torn and filthy garments covered his large\r\nbony limbs, which seemed as though, like those of a skeleton, they\r\nwould rattle as he walked; and the hand with which he leaned upon the\r\nyoung man\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, and which was the first thing Andrea saw, seemed\r\nof gigantic size.\r\n\r\n30229m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDid the young man recognize that face by the light of the lantern in\r\nhis tilbury, or was he merely struck with the horrible appearance of\r\nhis interrogator? We cannot say; but only relate the fact that he\r\nshuddered and stepped back suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want of me?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, my friend, if I disturb you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man with the red\r\nhandkerchief, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I want to speak to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have no right to beg at night,\xe2\x80\x9d said the groom, endeavoring to rid\r\nhis master of the troublesome intruder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not begging, my fine fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the unknown to the servant,\r\nwith so ironical an expression of the eye, and so frightful a smile,\r\nthat he withdrew; \xe2\x80\x9cI only wish to say two or three words to your\r\nmaster, who gave me a commission to execute about a fortnight ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, with sufficient nerve for his servant not to\r\nperceive his agitation, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you want? Speak quickly, friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe man said, in a low voice: \xe2\x80\x9cI wish\xe2\x80\x94I wish you to spare me the walk\r\nback to Paris. I am very tired, and as I have not eaten so good a\r\ndinner as you, I can scarcely stand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young man shuddered at this strange familiarity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ctell me what you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, I want you to take me up in your fine carriage, and carry\r\nme back.\xe2\x80\x9d Andrea turned pale, but said nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, thrusting his hands into his pockets, and looking\r\nimpudently at the youth; \xe2\x80\x9cI have taken the whim into my head; do you\r\nunderstand, Master Benedetto?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this name, no doubt, the young man reflected a little, for he went\r\ntowards his groom, saying:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis man is right; I did indeed charge him with a commission, the\r\nresult of which he must tell me; walk to the barrier, there take a cab,\r\nthat you may not be too late.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe surprised groom retired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me at least reach a shady spot,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, as for that, I\xe2\x80\x99ll take you to a splendid place,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man with\r\nthe handkerchief; and taking the horse\xe2\x80\x99s bit he led the tilbury where\r\nit was certainly impossible for anyone to witness the honor that Andrea\r\nconferred upon him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t think I want the glory of riding in your fine carriage,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nhe; \xe2\x80\x9coh, no, it\xe2\x80\x99s only because I am tired, and also because I have a\r\nlittle business to talk over with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, step in,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man. It was a pity this scene had not\r\noccurred in daylight, for it was curious to see this rascal throwing\r\nhimself heavily down on the cushion beside the young and elegant driver\r\nof the tilbury. Andrea drove past the last house in the village without\r\nsaying a word to his companion, who smiled complacently, as though\r\nwell-pleased to find himself travelling in so comfortable a vehicle.\r\nOnce out of Auteuil, Andrea looked around, in order to assure himself\r\nthat he could neither be seen nor heard, and then, stopping the horse\r\nand crossing his arms before the man, he asked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, tell me why you come to disturb my tranquillity?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me ask you why you deceived me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow have I deceived you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98How,\xe2\x80\x99 do you ask? When we parted at the Pont du Var, you told me you\r\nwere going to travel through Piedmont and Tuscany; but instead of that,\r\nyou come to Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow does that annoy you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt does not; on the contrary, I think it will answer my purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are speculating upon me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat fine words he uses!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI warn you, Master Caderousse, that you are mistaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well, don\xe2\x80\x99t be angry, my boy; you know well enough what it is to\r\nbe unfortunate; and misfortunes make us jealous. I thought you were\r\nearning a living in Tuscany or Piedmont by acting as _facchino_ or\r\n_cicerone_, and I pitied you sincerely, as I would a child of my own.\r\nYou know I always did call you my child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, what then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPatience\xe2\x80\x94patience!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am patient, but go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll at once I see you pass through the barrier with a groom, a\r\ntilbury, and fine new clothes. You must have discovered a mine, or else\r\nbecome a stockbroker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that, as you confess, you are jealous?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I am pleased\xe2\x80\x94so pleased that I wished to congratulate you; but as\r\nI am not quite properly dressed, I chose my opportunity, that I might\r\nnot compromise you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and a fine opportunity you have chosen!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Andrea; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nspeak to me before my servant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I help that, my boy? I speak to you when I can catch you. You\r\nhave a quick horse, a light tilbury, you are naturally as slippery as\r\nan eel; if I had missed you tonight, I might not have had another\r\nchance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, I do not conceal myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are lucky; I wish I could say as much, for I do conceal myself;\r\nand then I was afraid you would not recognize me, but you did,\xe2\x80\x9d added\r\nCaderousse with his unpleasant smile. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was very polite of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not speak affectionately to me, Benedetto, my old friend, that\r\nis not right\xe2\x80\x94take care, or I may become troublesome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis menace smothered the young man\xe2\x80\x99s passion. He urged the horse again\r\ninto a trot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should not speak so to an old friend like me, Caderousse, as you\r\nsaid just now; you are a native of Marseilles, I am\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know then now what you are?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but I was brought up in Corsica; you are old and obstinate, I am\r\nyoung and wilful. Between people like us threats are out of place,\r\neverything should be amicably arranged. Is it my fault if fortune,\r\nwhich has frowned on you, has been kind to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFortune has been kind to you, then? Your tilbury, your groom, your\r\nclothes, are not then hired? Good, so much the better,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCaderousse, his eyes sparkling with avarice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you knew that well enough before speaking to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea,\r\nbecoming more and more excited. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I had been wearing a handkerchief\r\nlike yours on my head, rags on my back, and worn-out shoes on my feet,\r\nyou would not have known me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wrong me, my boy; now I have found you, nothing prevents my being\r\nas well-dressed as anyone, knowing, as I do, the goodness of your\r\nheart. If you have two coats you will give me one of them. I used to\r\ndivide my soup and beans with you when you were hungry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat an appetite you used to have! Is it as good now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Andrea, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did you come to be dining with that prince whose house you have\r\njust left?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is not a prince; simply a count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA count, and a rich one too, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but you had better not have anything to say to him, for he is not\r\na very good-tempered gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, be easy! I have no design upon your count, and you shall have him\r\nall to yourself. But,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, again smiling with the\r\ndisagreeable expression he had before assumed, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must pay for it\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nunderstand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think that with a hundred francs a month\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could live\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon a hundred francs!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome\xe2\x80\x94you understand me; but that with\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith a hundred and fifty francs I should be quite happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere are two hundred,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea; and he placed ten gold louis in\r\nthe hand of Caderousse.\r\n\r\n30233m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cApply to the steward on the first day of every month, and you will\r\nreceive the same sum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now, again you degrade me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy making me apply to the servants, when I want to transact business\r\nwith you alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, be it so, then. Take it from me then, and so long at least as I\r\nreceive my income, you shall be paid yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come; I always said you were a fine fellow, and it is a blessing\r\nwhen good fortune happens to such as you. But tell me all about it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you wish to know?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Cavalcanti.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? do you again defy me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; the fact is, I have found my father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? a real father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, so long as he pays me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll honor and believe him\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s right. What is his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMajor Cavalcanti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he pleased with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo far I have appeared to answer his purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who found this father for you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Count of Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe man whose house you have just left?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you would try and find me a situation with him as grandfather,\r\nsince he holds the money-chest!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will mention you to him. Meanwhile, what are you going to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very kind of you to trouble yourself about me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSince you interest yourself in my affairs, I think it is now my turn\r\nto ask you some questions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, true. Well; I shall rent a room in some respectable house, wear a\r\ndecent coat, shave every day, and go and read the papers in a caf\xc3\xa9.\r\nThen, in the evening, I shall go to the theatre; I shall look like some\r\nretired baker. That is what I want.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, if you will only put this scheme into execution, and be steady,\r\nnothing could be better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think so, M. Bossuet? And you\xe2\x80\x94what will you become? A peer of\r\nFrance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9cwho knows?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMajor Cavalcanti is already one, perhaps; but then, hereditary rank is\r\nabolished.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo politics, Caderousse. And now that you have all you want, and that\r\nwe understand each other, jump down from the tilbury and disappear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all, my good friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow? Not at all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, just think for a moment; with this red handkerchief on my head,\r\nwith scarcely any shoes, no papers, and ten gold napoleons in my\r\npocket, without reckoning what was there before\xe2\x80\x94making in all about two\r\nhundred francs,\xe2\x80\x94why, I should certainly be arrested at the barriers.\r\nThen, to justify myself, I should say that you gave me the money; this\r\nwould cause inquiries, it would be found that I left Toulon without\r\ngiving due notice, and I should then be escorted back to the shores of\r\nthe Mediterranean. Then I should become simply No. 106, and good-bye to\r\nmy dream of resembling the retired baker! No, no, my boy; I prefer\r\nremaining honorably in the capital.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea scowled. Certainly, as he had himself owned, the reputed son of\r\nMajor Cavalcanti was a wilful fellow. He drew up for a minute, threw a\r\nrapid glance around him, and then his hand fell instantly into his\r\npocket, where it began playing with a pistol. But, meanwhile,\r\nCaderousse, who had never taken his eyes off his companion, passed his\r\nhand behind his back, and opened a long Spanish knife, which he always\r\ncarried with him, to be ready in case of need. The two friends, as we\r\nsee, were worthy of and understood one another. Andrea\xe2\x80\x99s hand left his\r\npocket inoffensively, and was carried up to the red moustache, which it\r\nplayed with for some time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Caderousse,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9chow happy you will be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do my best,\xe2\x80\x9d said the innkeeper of the Pont du Gard, shutting\r\nup his knife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, we will go into Paris. But how will you pass through the\r\nbarrier without exciting suspicion? It seems to me that you are in more\r\ndanger riding than on foot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall see.\xe2\x80\x9d He then took the greatcoat\r\nwith the large collar, which the groom had left behind in the tilbury,\r\nand put it on his back; then he took off Cavalcanti\xe2\x80\x99s hat, which he\r\nplaced upon his own head, and finally he assumed the careless attitude\r\nof a servant whose master drives himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, tell me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9cam I to remain bareheaded?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPooh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cit is so windy that your hat can easily\r\nappear to have blown off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come; enough of this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cavalcanti.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you waiting for?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope I am not the\r\ncause.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea. They passed the barrier without accident. At the\r\nfirst cross street Andrea stopped his horse, and Caderousse leaped out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cmy servant\xe2\x80\x99s coat and my hat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cyou would not like me to risk taking cold?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what am I to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou? Oh, you are young while I am beginning to get old. _Au revoir_,\r\nBenedetto;\xe2\x80\x9d and running into a court, he disappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, sighing, \xe2\x80\x9cone cannot be completely happy in this\r\nworld!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 65. A Conjugal Scene\r\n\r\nAt the Place Louis XV. the three young people separated\xe2\x80\x94that is to say,\r\nMorrel went to the Boulevards, Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud to the Pont de la\r\nR\xc3\xa9volution, and Debray to the Quai. Most probably Morrel and\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud returned to their \xe2\x80\x9cdomestic hearths,\xe2\x80\x9d as they say in the\r\ngallery of the Chamber in well-turned speeches, and in the theatre of\r\nthe Rue Richelieu in well-written pieces; but it was not the case with\r\nDebray. When he reached the wicket of the Louvre, he turned to the\r\nleft, galloped across the Carrousel, passed through the Rue Saint-Roch,\r\nand, issuing from the Rue de la Michodi\xc3\xa8re, he arrived at M. Danglars\xe2\x80\x99\r\ndoor just at the same time that Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s landau, after having\r\ndeposited him and his wife at the Faubourg Saint-Honor\xc3\xa9, stopped to\r\nleave the baroness at her own house.\r\n\r\nDebray, with the air of a man familiar with the house, entered first\r\ninto the court, threw his bridle into the hands of a footman, and\r\nreturned to the door to receive Madame Danglars, to whom he offered his\r\narm, to conduct her to her apartments. The gate once closed, and Debray\r\nand the baroness alone in the court, he asked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was the matter with you, Hermine? and why were you so affected at\r\nthat story, or rather fable, which the count related?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I have been in such shocking spirits all the evening, my\r\nfriend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the baroness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Hermine,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Debray; \xe2\x80\x9cyou cannot make me believe that; on the\r\ncontrary, you were in excellent spirits when you arrived at the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s. M. Danglars was disagreeable, certainly, but I know how much\r\nyou care for his ill-humor. Someone has vexed you; I will allow no one\r\nto annoy you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are deceived, Lucien, I assure you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nwhat I have told you is really the case, added to the ill-humor you\r\nremarked, but which I did not think it worth while to allude to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was evident that Madame Danglars was suffering from that nervous\r\nirritability which women frequently cannot account for even to\r\nthemselves; or that, as Debray had guessed, she had experienced some\r\nsecret agitation that she would not acknowledge to anyone. Being a man\r\nwho knew that the former of these symptoms was one of the inherent\r\npenalties of womanhood, he did not then press his inquiries, but waited\r\nfor a more appropriate opportunity when he should again interrogate\r\nher, or receive an avowal _proprio motu_.\r\n\r\nAt the door of her apartment the baroness met Mademoiselle Corn\xc3\xa9lie,\r\nher confidential maid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is my daughter doing?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Madame Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe practiced all the evening, and then went to bed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nMademoiselle Corn\xc3\xa9lie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet I think I hear her piano.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Mademoiselle Louise d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly, who is playing while Mademoiselle\r\nDanglars is in bed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9ccome and undress me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey entered the bedroom. Debray stretched himself upon a large couch,\r\nand Madame Danglars passed into her dressing-room with Mademoiselle\r\nCorn\xc3\xa9lie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear M. Lucien,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars through the door, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are\r\nalways complaining that Eug\xc3\xa9nie will not address a word to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucien, playing with a little dog, who, recognizing him\r\nas a friend of the house, expected to be caressed, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not the only\r\none who makes similar complaints, I think I heard Morcerf say that he\r\ncould not extract a word from his betrothed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cyet I think this will all pass off, and\r\nthat you will one day see her enter your study.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy study?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt least that of the minister.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo ask for an engagement at the Opera. Really, I never saw such an\r\ninfatuation for music; it is quite ridiculous for a young lady of\r\nfashion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDebray smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9clet her come, with your consent and\r\nthat of the baron, and we will try and give her an engagement, though\r\nwe are very poor to pay such talent as hers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, Corn\xc3\xa9lie,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not require you any\r\nlonger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCorn\xc3\xa9lie obeyed, and the next minute Madame Danglars left her room in a\r\ncharming loose dress, and came and sat down close to Debray. Then she\r\nbegan thoughtfully to caress the little spaniel. Lucien looked at her\r\nfor a moment in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Hermine,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, after a short time, \xe2\x80\x9canswer\r\ncandidly,\xe2\x80\x94something vexes you\xe2\x80\x94is it not so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30239m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the baroness.\r\n\r\nAnd yet, as she could scarcely breathe, she rose and went towards a\r\nlooking-glass. \xe2\x80\x9cI am frightful tonight,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. Debray rose,\r\nsmiling, and was about to contradict the baroness upon this latter\r\npoint, when the door opened suddenly. M. Danglars appeared; Debray\r\nreseated himself. At the noise of the door Madame Danglars turned\r\nround, and looked upon her husband with an astonishment she took no\r\ntrouble to conceal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-evening, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the banker; \xe2\x80\x9cgood-evening, M. Debray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nProbably the baroness thought this unexpected visit signified a desire\r\nto make up for the sharp words he had uttered during the day. Assuming\r\na dignified air, she turned round to Debray, without answering her\r\nhusband.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead me something, M. Debray,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. Debray, who was slightly\r\ndisturbed at this visit, recovered himself when he saw the calmness of\r\nthe baroness, and took up a book marked by a mother-of-pearl knife\r\ninlaid with gold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the banker, \xe2\x80\x9cbut you will tire yourself, baroness, by\r\nsuch late hours, and M. Debray lives some distance from here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDebray was petrified, not only to hear Danglars speak so calmly and\r\npolitely, but because it was apparent that beneath outward politeness\r\nthere really lurked a determined spirit of opposition to anything his\r\nwife might wish to do. The baroness was also surprised, and showed her\r\nastonishment by a look which would doubtless have had some effect upon\r\nher husband if he had not been intently occupied with the paper, where\r\nhe was looking to see the closing stock quotations. The result was,\r\nthat the proud look entirely failed of its purpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Lucien,\xe2\x80\x9d said the baroness, \xe2\x80\x9cI assure you I have no desire to\r\nsleep, and that I have a thousand things to tell you this evening,\r\nwhich you must listen to, even though you slept while hearing me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am at your service, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Lucien coldly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear M. Debray,\xe2\x80\x9d said the banker, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not kill yourself tonight\r\nlistening to the follies of Madame Danglars, for you can hear them as\r\nwell tomorrow; but I claim tonight and will devote it, if you will\r\nallow me, to talk over some serious matters with my wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis time the blow was so well aimed, and hit so directly, that Lucien\r\nand the baroness were staggered, and they interrogated each other with\r\ntheir eyes, as if to seek help against this aggression, but the\r\nirresistible will of the master of the house prevailed, and the husband\r\nwas victorious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not think I wish to turn you out, my dear Debray,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nDanglars; \xe2\x80\x9coh, no, not at all. An unexpected occurrence forces me to\r\nask my wife to have a little conversation with me; it is so rarely I\r\nmake such a request, I am sure you cannot grudge it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDebray muttered something, bowed and went out, knocking himself against\r\nthe edge of the door, like Nathan in _Athalie_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is extraordinary,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, when the door was closed behind him,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chow easily these husbands, whom we ridicule, gain an advantage over\r\nus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30241m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nLucien having left, Danglars took his place on the sofa, closed the\r\nopen book, and placing himself in a dreadfully dictatorial attitude, he\r\nbegan playing with the dog; but the animal, not liking him as well as\r\nDebray, and attempting to bite him, Danglars seized him by the skin of\r\nhis neck and threw him upon a couch on the other side of the room. The\r\nanimal uttered a cry during the transit, but, arrived at its\r\ndestination, it crouched behind the cushions, and stupefied at such\r\nunusual treatment remained silent and motionless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the baroness, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you are improving?\r\nGenerally you are only rude, but tonight you are brutal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is because I am in a worse humor than usual,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars.\r\nHermine looked at the banker with supreme disdain. These glances\r\nfrequently exasperated the pride of Danglars, but this evening he took\r\nno notice of them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what have I to do with your ill-humor?\xe2\x80\x9d said the baroness,\r\nirritated at the impassibility of her husband; \xe2\x80\x9cdo these things concern\r\nme? Keep your ill-humor at home in your money boxes, or, since you have\r\nclerks whom you pay, vent it upon them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cyour advice is wrong, so I shall not\r\nfollow it. My money boxes are my Pactolus, as, I think, M. Demoustier\r\nsays, and I will not retard its course, or disturb its calm. My clerks\r\nare honest men, who earn my fortune, whom I pay much below their\r\ndeserts, if I may value them according to what they bring in; therefore\r\nI shall not get into a passion with them; those with whom I will be in\r\na passion are those who eat my dinners, mount my horses, and exhaust my\r\nfortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd pray who are the persons who exhaust your fortune? Explain\r\nyourself more clearly, I beg, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, make yourself easy!\xe2\x80\x94I am not speaking riddles, and you will soon\r\nknow what I mean. The people who exhaust my fortune are those who draw\r\nout 700,000 francs in the course of an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not understand you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the baroness, trying to disguise\r\nthe agitation of her voice and the flush of her face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou understand me perfectly, on the contrary,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars: \xe2\x80\x9cbut, if\r\nyou will persist, I will tell you that I have just lost 700,000 francs\r\nupon the Spanish loan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd pray,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the baroness, \xe2\x80\x9cam I responsible for this loss?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it my fault you have lost 700,000 francs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly it is not mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnce for all, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the baroness sharply, \xe2\x80\x9cI tell you I will\r\nnot hear cash named; it is a style of language I never heard in the\r\nhouse of my parents or in that of my first husband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I can well believe that, for neither of them was worth a penny.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe better reason for my not being conversant with the slang of the\r\nbank, which is here dinning in my ears from morning to night; that\r\nnoise of jingling crowns, which are constantly being counted and\r\nre-counted, is odious to me. I only know one thing I dislike more,\r\nwhich is the sound of your voice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, this surprises me, for I thought you\r\ntook the liveliest interest in all my affairs!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30243m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? What could put such an idea into your head?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh?\xe2\x80\x94what next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost assuredly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like to know upon what occasion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, _mon Dieu!_ that is very easily done. Last February you were the\r\nfirst who told me of the Haitian funds. You had dreamed that a ship had\r\nentered the harbor at Le Havre, that this ship brought news that a\r\npayment we had looked upon as lost was going to be made. I know how\r\nclear-sighted your dreams are; I therefore purchased immediately as\r\nmany shares as I could of the Haitian debt, and I gained 400,000 francs\r\nby it, of which 100,000 have been honestly paid to you. You spent it as\r\nyou pleased; that was your business. In March there was a question\r\nabout a grant to a railway. Three companies presented themselves, each\r\noffering equal securities. You told me that your instinct,\xe2\x80\x94and although\r\nyou pretend to know nothing about speculations, I think on the\r\ncontrary, that your comprehension is very clear upon certain\r\naffairs,\xe2\x80\x94well, you told me that your instinct led you to believe the\r\ngrant would be given to the company called the Southern. I bought two\r\nthirds of the shares of that company; as you had foreseen, the shares\r\ntrebled in value, and I picked up a million, from which 250,000 francs\r\nwere paid to you for pin-money. How have you spent this 250,000\r\nfrancs?\xe2\x80\x94it is no business of mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen are you coming to the point?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the baroness, shivering with\r\nanger and impatience.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPatience, madame, I am coming to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s fortunate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn April you went to dine at the minister\xe2\x80\x99s. You heard a private\r\nconversation respecting Spanish affairs\xe2\x80\x94on the expulsion of Don Carlos.\r\nI bought some Spanish shares. The expulsion took place and I pocketed\r\n600,000 francs the day Charles V. repassed the Bidassoa. Of these\r\n600,000 francs you took 50,000 crowns. They were yours, you disposed of\r\nthem according to your fancy, and I asked no questions; but it is not\r\nthe less true that you have this year received 500,000 livres.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir, and what then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes, it was just after this that you spoiled everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, your manner of speaking\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt expresses my meaning, and that is all I want. Well, three days\r\nafter that you talked politics with M. Debray, and you fancied from his\r\nwords that Don Carlos had returned to Spain. Well, I sold my shares,\r\nthe news got out, and I no longer sold\xe2\x80\x94I gave them away, next day I\r\nfind the news was false, and by this false report I have lost 700,000\r\nfrancs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, since I gave you a fourth of my gains, I think you owe me a\r\nfourth of my losses; the fourth of 700,000 francs is 175,000 francs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you say is absurd, and I cannot see why M. Debray\xe2\x80\x99s name is mixed\r\nup in this affair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause if you do not possess the 175,000 francs I reclaim, you must\r\nhave lent them to your friends, and M. Debray is one of your friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30245m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor shame!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the baroness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, let us have no gestures, no screams, no modern drama, or you will\r\noblige me to tell you that I see Debray leave here, pocketing the whole\r\nof the 500,000 livres you have handed over to him this year, while he\r\nsmiles to himself, saying that he has found what the most skilful\r\nplayers have never discovered\xe2\x80\x94that is, a roulette where he wins without\r\nplaying, and is no loser when he loses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe baroness became enraged.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWretch!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you dare to tell me you did not know what\r\nyou now reproach me with?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not say that I did know it, and I do not say that I did not know\r\nit. I merely tell you to look into my conduct during the last four\r\nyears that we have ceased to be husband and wife, and see whether it\r\nhas not always been consistent. Some time after our rupture, you wished\r\nto study music, under the celebrated baritone who made such a\r\nsuccessful appearance at the Th\xc3\xa9\xc3\xa2tre Italien; at the same time I felt\r\ninclined to learn dancing of the _danseuse_ who acquired such a\r\nreputation in London. This cost me, on your account and mine, 100,000\r\nfrancs. I said nothing, for we must have peace in the house; and\r\n100,000 francs for a lady and gentleman to be properly instructed in\r\nmusic and dancing are not too much. Well, you soon become tired of\r\nsinging, and you take a fancy to study diplomacy with the minister\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsecretary. You understand, it signifies nothing to me so long as you\r\npay for your lessons out of your own cash box. But today I find you are\r\ndrawing on mine, and that your apprenticeship may cost me 700,000\r\nfrancs per month. Stop there, madame, for this cannot last. Either the\r\ndiplomatist must give his lessons gratis, and I will tolerate him, or\r\nhe must never set his foot again in my house;\xe2\x80\x94do you understand,\r\nmadame?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, this is too much,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Hermine, choking, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are worse than\r\ndespicable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI find you did not even pause there\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInsults!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right; let us leave these facts alone, and reason coolly. I\r\nhave never interfered in your affairs excepting for your good; treat me\r\nin the same way. You say you have nothing to do with my cash box. Be it\r\nso. Do as you like with your own, but do not fill or empty mine.\r\nBesides, how do I know that this was not a political trick, that the\r\nminister enraged at seeing me in the opposition, and jealous of the\r\npopular sympathy I excite, has not concerted with M. Debray to ruin\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA probable thing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not? Who ever heard of such an occurrence as this?\xe2\x80\x94a false\r\ntelegraphic despatch\xe2\x80\x94it is almost impossible for wrong signals to be\r\nmade as they were in the last two telegrams. It was done on purpose for\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94I am sure of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the baroness humbly, \xe2\x80\x9care you not aware that the man\r\nemployed there was dismissed, that they talked of going to law with\r\nhim, that orders were issued to arrest him and that this order would\r\nhave been put into execution if he had not escaped by flight, which\r\nproves that he was either mad or guilty? It was a mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, which made fools laugh, which caused the minister to have a\r\nsleepless night, which has caused the minister\xe2\x80\x99s secretaries to blacken\r\nseveral sheets of paper, but which has cost me 700,000 francs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hermine suddenly, \xe2\x80\x9cif all this is, as you say, caused\r\nby M. Debray, why, instead of going direct to him, do you come and tell\r\nme of it? Why, to accuse the man, do you address the woman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo I know M. Debray?\xe2\x80\x94do I wish to know him?\xe2\x80\x94do I wish to know that he\r\ngives advice?\xe2\x80\x94do I wish to follow it?\xe2\x80\x94do I speculate? No; you do all\r\nthis, not I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill it seems to me, that as you profit by it\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars shrugged his shoulders. \xe2\x80\x9cFoolish creature,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWomen fancy they have talent because they have managed two or three\r\nintrigues without being the talk of Paris! But know that if you had\r\neven hidden your irregularities from your husband, who has but the\r\ncommencement of the art\xe2\x80\x94for generally husbands _will_ not see\xe2\x80\x94you would\r\nthen have been but a faint imitation of most of your friends among the\r\nwomen of the world. But it has not been so with me,\xe2\x80\x94I see, and always\r\nhave seen, during the last sixteen years. You may, perhaps, have hidden\r\na thought; but not a step, not an action, not a fault, has escaped me,\r\nwhile you flattered yourself upon your address, and firmly believed you\r\nhad deceived me. What has been the result?\xe2\x80\x94that, thanks to my pretended\r\nignorance, there is none of your friends, from M. de Villefort to M.\r\nDebray, who has not trembled before me. There is not one who has not\r\ntreated me as the master of the house,\xe2\x80\x94the only title I desire with\r\nrespect to you; there is not one, in fact, who would have dared to\r\nspeak of me as I have spoken of them this day. I will allow you to make\r\nme hateful, but I will prevent your rendering me ridiculous, and, above\r\nall, I forbid you to ruin me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe baroness had been tolerably composed until the name of Villefort\r\nhad been pronounced; but then she became pale, and, rising, as if\r\ntouched by a spring, she stretched out her hands as though conjuring an\r\napparition; she then took two or three steps towards her husband, as\r\nthough to tear the secret from him, of which he was ignorant, or which\r\nhe withheld from some odious calculation,\xe2\x80\x94odious, as all his\r\ncalculations were.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Villefort!\xe2\x80\x94What do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean that M. de Nargonne, your first husband, being neither a\r\nphilosopher nor a banker, or perhaps being both, and seeing there was\r\nnothing to be got out of a king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney, died of grief or anger at\r\nfinding, after an absence of nine months, that you had been _enceinte_\r\nsix. I am brutal,\xe2\x80\x94I not only allow it, but boast of it; it is one of\r\nthe reasons of my success in commercial business. Why did he kill\r\nhimself instead of you? Because he had no cash to save. My life belongs\r\nto my cash. M. Debray has made me lose 700,000 francs; let him bear his\r\nshare of the loss, and we will go on as before; if not, let him become\r\nbankrupt for the 250,000 livres, and do as all bankrupts do\xe2\x80\x94disappear.\r\nHe is a charming fellow, I allow, when his news is correct; but when it\r\nis not, there are fifty others in the world who would do better than\r\nhe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars was rooted to the spot; she made a violent effort to\r\nreply to this last attack, but she fell upon a chair thinking of\r\nVillefort, of the dinner scene, of the strange series of misfortunes\r\nwhich had taken place in her house during the last few days, and\r\nchanged the usual calm of her establishment to a scene of scandalous\r\ndebate.\r\n\r\nDanglars did not even look at her, though she did her best to faint. He\r\nshut the bedroom door after him, without adding another word, and\r\nreturned to his apartments; and when Madame Danglars recovered from her\r\nhalf-fainting condition, she could almost believe that she had had a\r\ndisagreeable dream.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 66. Matrimonial Projects\r\n\r\nThe day following this scene, at the hour Debray usually chose to pay a\r\nvisit to Madame Danglars on his way to his office, his _coup\xc3\xa9_ did not\r\nappear. At this time, that is, about half-past twelve, Madame Danglars\r\nordered her carriage, and went out. Danglars, hidden behind a curtain,\r\nwatched the departure he had been waiting for. He gave orders that he\r\nshould be informed as soon as Madame Danglars appeared; but at two\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock she had not returned. He then called for his horses, drove to\r\nthe Chamber, and inscribed his name to speak against the budget. From\r\ntwelve to two o\xe2\x80\x99clock Danglars had remained in his study, unsealing his\r\ndispatches, and becoming more and more sad every minute, heaping figure\r\nupon figure, and receiving, among other visits, one from Major\r\nCavalcanti, who, as stiff and exact as ever, presented himself\r\nprecisely at the hour named the night before, to terminate his business\r\nwith the banker.\r\n\r\nOn leaving the Chamber, Danglars, who had shown violent marks of\r\nagitation during the sitting, and been more bitter than ever against\r\nthe ministry, re-entered his carriage, and told the coachman to drive\r\nto the Avenue des Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es, No. 30.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo was at home; only he was engaged with someone and begged\r\nDanglars to wait for a moment in the drawing-room. While the banker was\r\nwaiting in the anteroom, the door opened, and a man dressed as an abb\xc3\xa9\r\nand doubtless more familiar with the house than he was, came in and\r\ninstead of waiting, merely bowed, passed on to the farther apartments,\r\nand disappeared.\r\n\r\nA minute after the door by which the priest had entered reopened, and\r\nMonte Cristo appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cmy dear baron, but one of my friends, the Abb\xc3\xa9\r\nBusoni, whom you perhaps saw pass by, has just arrived in Paris; not\r\nhaving seen him for a long time, I could not make up my mind to leave\r\nhim sooner, so I hope this will be sufficient reason for my having made\r\nyou wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cit is my fault; I have chosen my visit at a\r\nwrong time, and will retire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all; on the contrary, be seated; but what is the matter with\r\nyou? You look careworn; really, you alarm me. Melancholy in a\r\ncapitalist, like the appearance of a comet, presages some misfortune to\r\nthe world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been in ill-luck for several days,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cand I have\r\nheard nothing but bad news.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you had another fall at the\r\nBourse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I am safe for a few days at least. I am only annoyed about a\r\nbankrupt of Trieste.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally? Does it happen to be Jacopo Manfredi?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so. Imagine a man who has transacted business with me for I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t know how long, to the amount of 800,000 or 900,000 francs during\r\nthe year. Never a mistake or delay\xe2\x80\x94a fellow who paid like a prince.\r\nWell, I was a million in advance with him, and now my fine Jacopo\r\nManfredi suspends payment!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is an unheard-of fatality. I draw upon him for 600,000 francs, my\r\nbills are returned unpaid, and, more than that, I hold bills of\r\nexchange signed by him to the value of 400,000 francs, payable at his\r\ncorrespondent\xe2\x80\x99s in Paris at the end of this month. Today is the 30th. I\r\npresent them; but my correspondent has disappeared. This, with my\r\nSpanish affairs, made a pretty end to the month.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you really lost by that affair in Spain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; only 700,000 francs out of my cash box\xe2\x80\x94nothing more!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, how could you make such a mistake\xe2\x80\x94such an old stager?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is all my wife\xe2\x80\x99s fault. She dreamed Don Carlos had returned to\r\nSpain; she believes in dreams. It is magnetism, she says, and when she\r\ndreams a thing it is sure to happen, she assures me. On this conviction\r\nI allow her to speculate, she having her bank and her stockbroker; she\r\nspeculated and lost. It is true she speculates with her own money, not\r\nmine; nevertheless, you can understand that when 700,000 francs leave\r\nthe wife\xe2\x80\x99s pocket, the husband always finds it out. But do you mean to\r\nsay you have not heard of this? Why, the thing has made a tremendous\r\nnoise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I heard it spoken of, but I did not know the details, and then no\r\none can be more ignorant than I am of the affairs in the Bourse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30251m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you do not speculate?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x94How could I speculate when I already have so much trouble in\r\nregulating my income? I should be obliged, besides my steward, to keep\r\na clerk and a boy. But touching these Spanish affairs, I think that the\r\nbaroness did not dream the whole of the Don Carlos matter. The papers\r\nsaid something about it, did they not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you believe the papers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x94not the least in the world; only I fancied that the honest\r\n_Messager_ was an exception to the rule, and that it only announced\r\ntelegraphic despatches.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s what puzzles me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cthe news of the\r\nreturn of Don Carlos was brought by telegraph.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have lost nearly 1,700,000 francs\r\nthis month.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot nearly, indeed; that is exactly my loss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Diable!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo compassionately, \xe2\x80\x9cit is a hard blow for a\r\nthird-rate fortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThird-rate,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, rather humble, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you mean by that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI make three assortments in\r\nfortune\xe2\x80\x94first-rate, second-rate, and third-rate fortunes. I call those\r\nfirst-rate which are composed of treasures one possesses under one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand, such as mines, lands, and funded property, in such states as\r\nFrance, Austria, and England, provided these treasures and property\r\nform a total of about a hundred millions; I call those second-rate\r\nfortunes, that are gained by manufacturing enterprises, joint-stock\r\ncompanies, viceroyalties, and principalities, not drawing more than\r\n1,500,000 francs, the whole forming a capital of about fifty millions;\r\nfinally, I call those third-rate fortunes, which are composed of a\r\nfluctuating capital, dependent upon the will of others, or upon chances\r\nwhich a bankruptcy involves or a false telegram shakes, such as banks,\r\nspeculations of the day\xe2\x80\x94in fact, all operations under the influence of\r\ngreater or less mischances, the whole bringing in a real or fictitious\r\ncapital of about fifteen millions. I think this is about your position,\r\nis it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConfound it, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe result, then, of six more such months as this would be to reduce\r\nthe third-rate house to despair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, becoming very pale, how you are running on!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us imagine seven such months,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Monte Cristo, in the same\r\ntone. \xe2\x80\x9cTell me, have you ever thought that seven times 1,700,000 francs\r\nmake nearly twelve millions? No, you have not;\xe2\x80\x94well, you are right, for\r\nif you indulged in such reflections, you would never risk your\r\nprincipal, which is to the speculator what the skin is to civilized\r\nman. We have our clothes, some more splendid than others,\xe2\x80\x94this is our\r\ncredit; but when a man dies he has only his skin; in the same way, on\r\nretiring from business, you have nothing but your real principal of\r\nabout five or six millions, at the most; for third-rate fortunes are\r\nnever more than a fourth of what they appear to be, like the locomotive\r\non a railway, the size of which is magnified by the smoke and steam\r\nsurrounding it. Well, out of the five or six millions which form your\r\nreal capital, you have just lost nearly two millions, which must, of\r\ncourse, in the same degree diminish your credit and fictitious fortune;\r\nto follow out my simile, your skin has been opened by bleeding, and\r\nthis if repeated three or four times will cause death\xe2\x80\x94so pay attention\r\nto it, my dear Monsieur Danglars. Do you want money? Do you wish me to\r\nlend you some?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30253m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a bad calculator you are!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Danglars, calling to his\r\nassistance all his philosophy and dissimulation. \xe2\x80\x9cI have made money at\r\nthe same time by speculations which have succeeded. I have made up the\r\nloss of blood by nutrition. I lost a battle in Spain, I have been\r\ndefeated in Trieste, but my naval army in India will have taken some\r\ngalleons, and my Mexican pioneers will have discovered some mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good, very good! But the wound remains and will reopen at the\r\nfirst loss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, for I am only embarked in certainties,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars, with the\r\nair of a mountebank sounding his own praises; \xe2\x80\x9cto involve me, three\r\ngovernments must crumble to dust.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, such things have been.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat there should be a famine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRecollect the seven fat and the seven lean kine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr, that the sea should become dry, as in the days of Pharaoh, and\r\neven then my vessels would become caravans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better. I congratulate you, my dear M. Danglars,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMonte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI see I was deceived, and that you belong to the class\r\nof second-rate fortunes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I may aspire to that honor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars with a smile, which\r\nreminded Monte Cristo of the sickly moons which bad artists are so fond\r\nof daubing into their pictures of ruins. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, while we are speaking of\r\nbusiness,\xe2\x80\x9d Danglars added, pleased to find an opportunity of changing\r\nthe subject, \xe2\x80\x9ctell me what I am to do for M. Cavalcanti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive him money, if he is recommended to you, and the recommendation\r\nseems good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcellent; he presented himself this morning with a bond of 40,000\r\nfrancs, payable at sight, on you, signed by Busoni, and returned by you\r\nto me, with your endorsement\xe2\x80\x94of course, I immediately counted him over\r\nthe forty bank-notes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo nodded his head in token of assent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that is not all,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9che has opened an account\r\nwith my house for his son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I ask how much he allows the young man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive thousand francs per month.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSixty thousand francs per year. I thought I was right in believing\r\nthat Cavalcanti to be a stingy fellow. How can a young man live upon\r\n5,000 francs a month?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you understand that if the young man should want a few thousands\r\nmore\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not advance it; the father will never repay it. You do not know\r\nthese ultramontane millionaires; they are regular misers. And by whom\r\nwere they recommended to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, by the house of Fenzi, one of the best in Florence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not mean to say you will lose, but, nevertheless, mind you hold\r\nto the terms of the agreement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you not trust the Cavalcanti?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? oh, I would advance ten millions on his signature. I was only\r\nspeaking in reference to the second-rate fortunes we were mentioning\r\njust now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd with all this, how unassuming he is! I should never have taken him\r\nfor anything more than a mere major.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you would have flattered him, for certainly, as you say, he has no\r\nmanner. The first time I saw him he appeared to me like an old\r\nlieutenant who had grown mouldy under his epaulets. But all the\r\nItalians are the same; they are like old Jews when they are not\r\nglittering in Oriental splendor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe young man is better,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; a little nervous, perhaps, but, upon the whole, he appeared\r\ntolerable. I was uneasy about him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you met him at my house, just after his introduction into the\r\nworld, as they told me. He has been travelling with a very severe\r\ntutor, and had never been to Paris before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, I believe noblemen marry amongst themselves, do they not?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nDanglars carelessly; \xe2\x80\x9cthey like to unite their fortunes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is usual, certainly; but Cavalcanti is an original who does nothing\r\nlike other people. I cannot help thinking that he has brought his son\r\nto France to choose a wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have heard his fortune mentioned?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing else was talked of; only some said he was worth millions, and\r\nothers that he did not possess a farthing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is your opinion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ought not to influence you, because it is only my own personal\r\nimpression.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and it is that\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy opinion is, that all these old _podest\xc3\xa0s_, these ancient\r\n_condottieri_,\xe2\x80\x94for the Cavalcanti have commanded armies and governed\r\nprovinces,\xe2\x80\x94my opinion, I say, is, that they have buried their millions\r\nin corners, the secret of which they have transmitted only to their\r\neldest sons, who have done the same from generation to generation; and\r\nthe proof of this is seen in their yellow and dry appearance, like the\r\nflorins of the republic, which, from being constantly gazed upon, have\r\nbecome reflected in them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cand this is further supported by the fact\r\nof their not possessing an inch of land.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery little, at least; I know of none which Cavalcanti possesses,\r\nexcepting his palace in Lucca.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, he has a palace?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, laughing; \xe2\x80\x9ccome, that is\r\nsomething.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; and more than that, he lets it to the Minister of Finance while\r\nhe lives in a simple house. Oh, as I told you before, I think the old\r\nfellow is very close.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, you do not flatter him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI scarcely know him; I think I have seen him three times in my life;\r\nall I know relating to him is through Busoni and himself. He was\r\ntelling me this morning that, tired of letting his property lie dormant\r\nin Italy, which is a dead nation, he wished to find a method, either in\r\nFrance or England, of multiplying his millions, but remember, that\r\nthough I place great confidence in Busoni, I am not responsible for\r\nthis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind; accept my thanks for the client you have sent me. It is a\r\nfine name to inscribe on my ledgers, and my cashier was quite proud of\r\nit when I explained to him who the Cavalcanti were. By the way, this is\r\nmerely a simple question, when this sort of people marry their sons, do\r\nthey give them any fortune?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that depends upon circumstances. I know an Italian prince, rich as\r\na gold mine, one of the noblest families in Tuscany, who, when his sons\r\nmarried according to his wish, gave them millions; and when they\r\nmarried against his consent, merely allowed them thirty crowns a month.\r\nShould Andrea marry according to his father\xe2\x80\x99s views, he will, perhaps,\r\ngive him one, two, or three millions. For example, supposing it were\r\nthe daughter of a banker, he might take an interest in the house of the\r\nfather-in-law of his son; then again, if he disliked his choice, the\r\nmajor takes the key, double-locks his coffer, and Master Andrea would\r\nbe obliged to live like the sons of a Parisian family, by shuffling\r\ncards or rattling the dice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that boy will find out some Bavarian or Peruvian princess; he will\r\nwant a crown, an El Dorado, and Potos\xc3\xad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; these grand lords on the other side of the Alps frequently marry\r\ninto plain families; like Jupiter, they like to cross the race. But do\r\nyou wish to marry Andrea, my dear M. Danglars, that you are asking so\r\nmany questions?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cit would not be a bad speculation, I fancy,\r\nand you know I am a speculator.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are not thinking of Mademoiselle Danglars, I hope; you would not\r\nlike poor Andrea to have his throat cut by Albert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Danglars, shrugging his shoulders; \xe2\x80\x9cah, well; he\r\nwould care very little about it, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he is betrothed to your daughter, I believe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, M. de Morcerf and I have talked about this marriage, but Madame\r\nde Morcerf and Albert\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not mean to say that it would not be a good match?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, I imagine that Mademoiselle Danglars is as good as M. de\r\nMorcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 fortune will be great, no doubt, especially if\r\nthe telegraph should not make any more mistakes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I do not mean her fortune only; but tell me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you not invite M. and Madame de Morcerf to your dinner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did so, but he excused himself on account of Madame de Morcerf being\r\nobliged to go to Dieppe for the benefit of sea air.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cit would do her a great deal of\r\ngood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause it is the air she always breathed in her youth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo took no notice of this ill-natured remark.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut still, if Albert be not so rich as Mademoiselle Danglars,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe count, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must allow that he has a fine name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo he has; but I like mine as well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; your name is popular, and does honor to the title they have\r\nadorned it with; but you are too intelligent not to know that according\r\nto a prejudice, too firmly rooted to be exterminated, a nobility which\r\ndates back five centuries is worth more than one that can only reckon\r\ntwenty years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd for this very reason,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars with a smile, which he tried\r\nto make sardonic, \xe2\x80\x9cI prefer M. Andrea Cavalcanti to M. Albert de\r\nMorcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill, I should not think the Morcerfs would yield to the Cavalcanti?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Morcerfs!\xe2\x80\x94Stay, my dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are a man of\r\nthe world, are you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you understand heraldry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, look at my coat-of-arms, it is worth more than Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, though I am not a baron by birth, my real name is, at least,\r\nDanglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile his name is not Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x94not Morcerf?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot the least in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been made a baron, so that I actually am one; he made himself a\r\ncount, so that he is not one at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen my dear count; M. de Morcerf has been my friend, or rather my\r\nacquaintance, during the last thirty years. You know I have made the\r\nmost of my arms, though I never forgot my origin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA proof of great humility or great pride,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, when I was a clerk, Morcerf was a mere fisherman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then he was called\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFernand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly Fernand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFernand Mondego.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are sure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_ I have bought enough fish of him to know his name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, why did you think of giving your daughter to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause Fernand and Danglars, being both parvenus, both having become\r\nnoble, both rich, are about equal in worth, excepting that there have\r\nbeen certain things mentioned of him that were never said of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes; what you tell me recalls to mind something about the name of\r\nFernand Mondego. I have heard that name in Greece.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn conjunction with the affairs of Ali Pasha?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the mystery,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars. \xe2\x80\x9cI acknowledge I would have given\r\nanything to find it out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be very easy if you much wished it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProbably you have some correspondent in Greece?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should think so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Yanina?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverywhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, write to your correspondent in Yanina, and ask him what part was\r\nplayed by a Frenchman named Fernand Mondego in the catastrophe of Ali\r\nTepelini.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Danglars, rising quickly, \xe2\x80\x9cI will write\r\ntoday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30259m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if you should hear of anything very scandalous\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will communicate it to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will oblige me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars rushed out of the room, and made but one leap into his\r\n_coup\xc3\xa9_.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 67. The Office of the King\xe2\x80\x99s Attorney\r\n\r\nLet us leave the banker driving his horses at their fullest speed, and\r\nfollow Madame Danglars in her morning excursion. We have said that at\r\nhalf-past twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock Madame Danglars had ordered her horses, and\r\nhad left home in the carriage. She directed her course towards the\r\nFaubourg Saint Germain, went down the Rue Mazarine, and stopped at the\r\nPassage du Pont-Neuf. She descended, and went through the passage. She\r\nwas very plainly dressed, as would be the case with a woman of taste\r\nwalking in the morning. At the Rue Gu\xc3\xa9n\xc3\xa9gaud she called a cab, and\r\ndirected the driver to go to the Rue de Harlay. As soon as she was\r\nseated in the vehicle, she drew from her pocket a very thick black\r\nveil, which she tied on to her straw bonnet. She then replaced the\r\nbonnet, and saw with pleasure, in a little pocket-mirror, that her\r\nwhite complexion and brilliant eyes were alone visible. The cab crossed\r\nthe Pont-Neuf and entered the Rue de Harlay by the Place Dauphine; the\r\ndriver was paid as the door opened, and stepping lightly up the stairs\r\nMadame Danglars soon reached the Salle des Pas-Perdus.\r\n\r\nThere was a great deal going on that morning, and many business-like\r\npersons at the Palais; business-like persons pay very little attention\r\nto women, and Madame Danglars crossed the hall without exciting any\r\nmore attention than any other woman calling upon her lawyer.\r\n\r\nThere was a great press of people in M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s antechamber, but\r\nMadame Danglars had no occasion even to pronounce her name. The instant\r\nshe appeared the door-keeper rose, came to her, and asked her whether\r\nshe was not the person with whom the procureur had made an appointment;\r\nand on her affirmative answer being given, he conducted her by a\r\nprivate passage to M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s office.\r\n\r\nThe magistrate was seated in an armchair, writing, with his back\r\ntowards the door; he did not move as he heard it open, and the\r\ndoor-keeper pronounce the words, \xe2\x80\x9cWalk in, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d and then reclose\r\nit; but no sooner had the man\xe2\x80\x99s footsteps ceased, than he started up,\r\ndrew the bolts, closed the curtains, and examined every corner of the\r\nroom. Then, when he had assured himself that he could neither be seen\r\nnor heard, and was consequently relieved of doubts, he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, madame,\xe2\x80\x94thanks for your punctuality;\xe2\x80\x9d and he offered a chair\r\nto Madame Danglars, which she accepted, for her heart beat so violently\r\nthat she felt nearly suffocated.\r\n\r\n30261m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a long time, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the procureur, describing a\r\nhalf-circle with his chair, so as to place himself exactly opposite to\r\nMadame Danglars,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit is a long time since I had the pleasure of\r\nspeaking alone with you, and I regret that we have only now met to\r\nenter upon a painful conversation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless, sir, you see I have answered your first appeal, although\r\ncertainly the conversation must be much more painful for me than for\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d Villefort smiled bitterly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true, then,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, rather uttering his thoughts aloud than\r\naddressing his companion,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit is true, then, that all our actions leave\r\ntheir traces\xe2\x80\x94some sad, others bright\xe2\x80\x94on our paths; it is true that\r\nevery step in our lives is like the course of an insect on the\r\nsands;\xe2\x80\x94it leaves its track! Alas, to many the path is traced by tears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cyou can feel for my emotion, can you not?\r\nSpare me, then, I beseech you. When I look at this room,\xe2\x80\x94whence so many\r\nguilty creatures have departed, trembling and ashamed, when I look at\r\nthat chair before which I now sit trembling and ashamed,\xe2\x80\x94oh, it\r\nrequires all my reason to convince me that I am not a very guilty woman\r\nand you a menacing judge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort dropped his head and sighed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI feel that my place is not in the judge\xe2\x80\x99s seat, but\r\non the prisoner\xe2\x80\x99s bench.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30263m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou?\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think, sir, you exaggerate your situation,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars,\r\nwhose beautiful eyes sparkled for a moment. \xe2\x80\x9cThe paths of which you\r\nwere just speaking have been traced by all young men of ardent\r\nimaginations. Besides the pleasure, there is always remorse from the\r\nindulgence of our passions, and, after all, what have you men to fear\r\nfrom all this? the world excuses, and notoriety ennobles you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know that I am no hypocrite, or, at\r\nleast, that I never deceive without a reason. If my brow be severe, it\r\nis because many misfortunes have clouded it; if my heart be petrified,\r\nit is that it might sustain the blows it has received. I was not so in\r\nmy youth, I was not so on the night of the betrothal, when we were all\r\nseated around a table in the Rue du Cours at Marseilles. But since then\r\neverything has changed in and about me; I am accustomed to brave\r\ndifficulties, and, in the conflict to crush those who, by their own\r\nfree will, or by chance, voluntarily or involuntarily, interfere with\r\nme in my career. It is generally the case that what we most ardently\r\ndesire is as ardently withheld from us by those who wish to obtain it,\r\nor from whom we attempt to snatch it. Thus, the greater number of a\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s errors come before him disguised under the specious form of\r\nnecessity; then, after error has been committed in a moment of\r\nexcitement, of delirium, or of fear, we see that we might have avoided\r\nand escaped it. The means we might have used, which we in our blindness\r\ncould not see, then seem simple and easy, and we say, \xe2\x80\x98Why did I not do\r\nthis, instead of that?\xe2\x80\x99 Women, on the contrary, are rarely tormented\r\nwith remorse; for the decision does not come from you,\xe2\x80\x94your misfortunes\r\nare generally imposed upon you, and your faults the results of others\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncrimes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn any case, sir, you will allow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthat,\r\neven if the fault were alone mine, I last night received a severe\r\npunishment for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, pressing her hand, \xe2\x80\x9cit was too severe for\r\nyour strength, for you were twice overwhelmed, and yet\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I must tell you. Collect all your courage, for you have not yet\r\nheard all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Madame Danglars, alarmed, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is there more to hear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou only look back to the past, and it is, indeed, bad enough. Well,\r\npicture to yourself a future more gloomy still\xe2\x80\x94certainly frightful,\r\nperhaps sanguinary!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe baroness knew how calm Villefort naturally was, and his present\r\nexcitement frightened her so much that she opened her mouth to scream,\r\nbut the sound died in her throat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow has this terrible past been recalled?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9chow is it\r\nthat it has escaped from the depths of the tomb and the recesses of our\r\nhearts, where it was buried, to visit us now, like a phantom, whitening\r\nour cheeks and flushing our brows with shame?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hermine, \xe2\x80\x9cdoubtless it is chance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChance?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, madame, there is no such thing as\r\nchance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes; has not a fatal chance revealed all this? Was it not by\r\nchance the Count of Monte Cristo bought that house? Was it not by\r\nchance he caused the earth to be dug up? Is it not by chance that the\r\nunfortunate child was disinterred under the trees?\xe2\x80\x94that poor innocent\r\noffspring of mine, which I never even kissed, but for whom I wept many,\r\nmany tears. Ah, my heart clung to the count when he mentioned the dear\r\nspoil found beneath the flowers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, no, madame,\xe2\x80\x94this is the terrible news I have to tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nVillefort in a hollow voice\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cno, nothing was found beneath the flowers;\r\nthere was no child disinterred\xe2\x80\x94no. You must not weep, no, you must not\r\ngroan, you must tremble!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Madame Danglars, shuddering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean that M. de Monte Cristo, digging underneath these trees, found\r\nneither skeleton nor chest, because neither of them was there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNeither of them there?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Madame Danglars, her staring,\r\nwide-open eyes expressing her alarm. \xe2\x80\x9cNeither of them there!\xe2\x80\x9d she again\r\nsaid, as though striving to impress herself with the meaning of the\r\nwords which escaped her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, burying his face in his hands, \xe2\x80\x9cno, a hundred\r\ntimes no!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you did not bury the poor child there, sir? Why did you deceive\r\nme? Where did you place it? tell me\xe2\x80\x94where?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere! But listen to me\xe2\x80\x94listen\xe2\x80\x94and you will pity me who has for twenty\r\nyears alone borne the heavy burden of grief I am about to reveal,\r\nwithout casting the least portion upon you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you frighten me! But speak; I will listen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou recollect that sad night, when you were half-expiring on that bed\r\nin the red damask room, while I, scarcely less agitated than you,\r\nawaited your delivery. The child was born, was given to me\xe2\x80\x94motionless,\r\nbreathless, voiceless; we thought it dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars moved rapidly, as though she would spring from her\r\nchair, but Villefort stopped, and clasped his hands as if to implore\r\nher attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe thought it dead,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated; \xe2\x80\x9cI placed it in the chest, which was\r\nto take the place of a coffin; I descended to the garden, I dug a hole,\r\nand then flung it down in haste. Scarcely had I covered it with earth,\r\nwhen the arm of the Corsican was stretched towards me; I saw a shadow\r\nrise, and, at the same time, a flash of light. I felt pain; I wished to\r\ncry out, but an icy shiver ran through my veins and stifled my voice; I\r\nfell lifeless, and fancied myself killed. Never shall I forget your\r\nsublime courage, when, having returned to consciousness, I dragged\r\nmyself to the foot of the stairs, and you, almost dying yourself, came\r\nto meet me.
