We were obliged to keep silent upon the dreadful\r\ncatastrophe. You had the fortitude to regain the house, assisted by\r\nyour nurse. A duel was the pretext for my wound. Though we scarcely\r\nexpected it, our secret remained in our own keeping alone. I was taken\r\nto Versailles; for three months I struggled with death; at last, as I\r\nseemed to cling to life, I was ordered to the South. Four men carried\r\nme from Paris to Ch\xc3\xa2lons, walking six leagues a day; Madame de\r\nVillefort followed the litter in her carriage. At Ch\xc3\xa2lons I was put\r\nupon the Sa\xc3\xb4ne, thence I passed on to the Rh\xc3\xb4ne, whence I descended,\r\nmerely with the current, to Arles; at Arles I was again placed on my\r\nlitter, and continued my journey to Marseilles. My recovery lasted six\r\nmonths. I never heard you mentioned, and I did not dare inquire for\r\nyou. When I returned to Paris, I learned that you, the widow of M. de\r\nNargonne, had married M. Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was the subject of my thoughts from the time consciousness\r\nreturned to me? Always the same\xe2\x80\x94always the child\xe2\x80\x99s corpse, coming every\r\nnight in my dreams, rising from the earth, and hovering over the grave\r\nwith menacing look and gesture. I inquired immediately on my return to\r\nParis; the house had not been inhabited since we left it, but it had\r\njust been let for nine years. I found the tenant. I pretended that I\r\ndisliked the idea that a house belonging to my wife\xe2\x80\x99s father and mother\r\nshould pass into the hands of strangers. I offered to pay them for\r\ncancelling the lease; they demanded 6,000 francs. I would have given\r\n10,000\xe2\x80\x94I would have given 20,000. I had the money with me; I made the\r\ntenant sign the deed of resilition, and when I had obtained what I so\r\nmuch wanted, I galloped to Auteuil. No one had entered the house since\r\nI had left it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the afternoon; I ascended into the red room,\r\nand waited for night. There all the thoughts which had disturbed me\r\nduring my year of constant agony came back with double force. The\r\nCorsican, who had declared the vendetta against me, who had followed me\r\nfrom N\xc3\xaemes to Paris, who had hid himself in the garden, who had struck\r\nme, had seen me dig the grave, had seen me inter the child,\xe2\x80\x94he might\r\nbecome acquainted with your person,\xe2\x80\x94nay, he might even then have known\r\nit. Would he not one day make you pay for keeping this terrible secret?\r\nWould it not be a sweet revenge for him when he found that I had not\r\ndied from the blow of his dagger? It was therefore necessary, before\r\neverything else, and at all risks, that I should cause all traces of\r\nthe past to disappear\xe2\x80\x94that I should destroy every material vestige; too\r\nmuch reality would always remain in my recollection. It was for this I\r\nhad annulled the lease\xe2\x80\x94it was for this I had come\xe2\x80\x94it was for this I was\r\nwaiting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNight arrived; I allowed it to become quite dark. I was without a\r\nlight in that room; when the wind shook all the doors, behind which I\r\ncontinually expected to see some spy concealed, I trembled. I seemed\r\neverywhere to hear your moans behind me in the bed, and I dared not\r\nturn around. My heart beat so violently that I feared my wound would\r\nopen. At length, one by one, all the noises in the neighborhood ceased.\r\nI understood that I had nothing to fear, that I should neither be seen\r\nnor heard, so I decided upon descending to the garden.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, Hermine; I consider myself as brave as most men, but when I\r\ndrew from my breast the little key of the staircase, which I had found\r\nin my coat\xe2\x80\x94that little key we both used to cherish so much, which you\r\nwished to have fastened to a golden ring\xe2\x80\x94when I opened the door, and\r\nsaw the pale moon shedding a long stream of white light on the spiral\r\nstaircase like a spectre, I leaned against the wall, and nearly\r\nshrieked. I seemed to be going mad. At last I mastered my agitation. I\r\ndescended the staircase step by step; the only thing I could not\r\nconquer was a strange trembling in my knees. I grasped the railings; if\r\nI had relaxed my hold for a moment, I should have fallen. I reached the\r\nlower door. Outside this door a spade was placed against the wall; I\r\ntook it, and advanced towards the thicket. I had provided myself with a\r\ndark lantern. In the middle of the lawn I stopped to light it, then I\r\ncontinued my path.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was the end of November, all the verdure of the garden had\r\ndisappeared, the trees were nothing more than skeletons with their long\r\nbony arms, and the dead leaves sounded on the gravel under my feet. My\r\nterror overcame me to such a degree as I approached the thicket, that I\r\ntook a pistol from my pocket and armed myself. I fancied continually\r\nthat I saw the figure of the Corsican between the branches. I examined\r\nthe thicket with my dark lantern; it was empty. I looked carefully\r\naround; I was indeed alone,\xe2\x80\x94no noise disturbed the silence but the owl,\r\nwhose piercing cry seemed to be calling up the phantoms of the night. I\r\ntied my lantern to a forked branch I had noticed a year before at the\r\nprecise spot where I stopped to dig the hole.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe grass had grown very thickly there during the summer, and when\r\nautumn arrived no one had been there to mow it. Still one place where\r\nthe grass was thin attracted my attention; it evidently was there I had\r\nturned up the ground. I went to work. The hour, then, for which I had\r\nbeen waiting during the last year had at length arrived. How I worked,\r\nhow I hoped, how I struck every piece of turf, thinking to find some\r\nresistance to my spade! But no, I found nothing, though I had made a\r\nhole twice as large as the first. I thought I had been deceived\xe2\x80\x94had\r\nmistaken the spot. I turned around, I looked at the trees, I tried to\r\nrecall the details which had struck me at the time. A cold, sharp wind\r\nwhistled through the leafless branches, and yet the drops fell from my\r\nforehead. I recollected that I was stabbed just as I was trampling the\r\nground to fill up the hole; while doing so I had leaned against a\r\nlaburnum; behind me was an artificial rockery, intended to serve as a\r\nresting-place for persons walking in the garden; in falling, my hand,\r\nrelaxing its hold of the laburnum, felt the coldness of the stone. On\r\nmy right I saw the tree, behind me the rock. I stood in the same\r\nattitude, and threw myself down. I rose, and again began digging and\r\nenlarging the hole; still I found nothing, nothing\xe2\x80\x94the chest was no\r\nlonger there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30269m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe chest no longer there?\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Madame Danglars, choking with\r\nfear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink not I contented myself with this one effort,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nVillefort. \xe2\x80\x9cNo; I searched the whole thicket. I thought the assassin,\r\nhaving discovered the chest, and supposing it to be a treasure, had\r\nintended carrying it off, but, perceiving his error, had dug another\r\nhole, and deposited it there; but I could find nothing. Then the idea\r\nstruck me that he had not taken these precautions, and had simply\r\nthrown it in a corner. In the last case I must wait for daylight to\r\nrenew my search. I remained in the room and waited.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30271m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen daylight dawned I went down again. My first visit was to the\r\nthicket. I hoped to find some traces which had escaped me in the\r\ndarkness. I had turned up the earth over a surface of more than twenty\r\nfeet square, and a depth of two feet. A laborer would not have done in\r\na day what occupied me an hour. But I could find nothing\xe2\x80\x94absolutely\r\nnothing. Then I renewed the search. Supposing it had been thrown aside,\r\nit would probably be on the path which led to the little gate; but this\r\nexamination was as useless as the first, and with a bursting heart I\r\nreturned to the thicket, which now contained no hope for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cit was enough to drive you mad!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hoped for a moment that it might,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cbut that\r\nhappiness was denied me. However, recovering my strength and my ideas,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Why,\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98should that man have carried away the corpse?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you said,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9che would require it as a\r\nproof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, no, madame, that could not be. Dead bodies are not kept a year;\r\nthey are shown to a magistrate, and the evidence is taken. Now, nothing\r\nof the kind has happened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Hermine, trembling violently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething more terrible, more fatal, more alarming for us\xe2\x80\x94the child\r\nwas, perhaps, alive, and the assassin may have saved it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars uttered a piercing cry, and, seizing Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s hands,\r\nexclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cMy child was alive?\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cyou buried my child alive?\r\nYou were not certain my child was dead, and you buried it? Ah\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars had risen, and stood before the procureur, whose hands\r\nshe wrung in her feeble grasp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know not; I merely suppose so, as I might suppose anything else,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied Villefort with a look so fixed, it indicated that his powerful\r\nmind was on the verge of despair and madness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my child, my poor child!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the baroness, falling on her\r\nchair, and stifling her sobs in her handkerchief. Villefort, becoming\r\nsomewhat reassured, perceived that to avert the maternal storm\r\ngathering over his head, he must inspire Madame Danglars with the\r\nterror he felt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou understand, then, that if it were so,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, rising in his\r\nturn, and approaching the baroness, to speak to her in a lower tone,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwe are lost. This child lives, and someone knows it lives\xe2\x80\x94someone is\r\nin possession of our secret; and since Monte Cristo speaks before us of\r\na child disinterred, when that child could not be found, it is he who\r\nis in possession of our secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust God, avenging God!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Madame Danglars.\r\n\r\nVillefort\xe2\x80\x99s only answer was a stifled groan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the child\xe2\x80\x94the child, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the agitated mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow I have searched for him,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, wringing his hands;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chow I have called him in my long sleepless nights; how I have longed\r\nfor royal wealth to purchase a million of secrets from a million of\r\nmen, and to find mine among them! At last, one day, when for the\r\nhundredth time I took up my spade, I asked myself again and again what\r\nthe Corsican could have done with the child. A child encumbers a\r\nfugitive; perhaps, on perceiving it was still alive, he had thrown it\r\ninto the river.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Madame Danglars: \xe2\x80\x9ca man may murder another out of\r\nrevenge, but he would not deliberately drown a child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9che had put it in the foundling\r\nhospital.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the baroness; \xe2\x80\x9cmy child is there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ran to the hospital, and learned that the same night\xe2\x80\x94the night of\r\nthe 20th of September\xe2\x80\x94a child had been brought there, wrapped in part\r\nof a fine linen napkin, purposely torn in half. This portion of the\r\nnapkin was marked with half a baron\xe2\x80\x99s crown, and the letter H.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly, truly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9call my linen is marked thus;\r\nMonsieur de Nargonne was a baron, and my name is Hermine. Thank God, my\r\nchild was not then dead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it was not dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you can tell me so without fearing to make me die of joy? Where is\r\nthe child?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort shrugged his shoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo I know?\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cand do you believe that if I knew I would relate\r\nto you all its trials and all its adventures as would a dramatist or a\r\nnovel writer? Alas, no, I know not. A woman, about six months after,\r\ncame to claim it with the other half of the napkin. This woman gave all\r\nthe requisite particulars, and it was intrusted to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you should have inquired for the woman; you should have traced\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what do you think I did? I feigned a criminal process, and\r\nemployed all the most acute bloodhounds and skilful agents in search of\r\nher. They traced her to Ch\xc3\xa2lons, and there they lost her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey lost her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, forever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars had listened to this recital with a sigh, a tear, or a\r\nshriek for every detail. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd this is all?\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cand you stopped\r\nthere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cI never ceased to search and to inquire.\r\nHowever, the last two or three years I had allowed myself some respite.\r\nBut now I will begin with more perseverance and fury than ever, since\r\nfear urges me, not my conscience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Count of Monte Cristo can know\r\nnothing, or he would not seek our society as he does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the wickedness of man is very great,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9csince it\r\nsurpasses the goodness of God. Did you observe that man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes while he\r\nwas speaking to us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut have you ever watched him carefully?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless he is capricious, but that is all; one thing alone struck\r\nme,\xe2\x80\x94of all the exquisite things he placed before us, he touched\r\nnothing. I might have suspected he was poisoning us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you see you would have been deceived.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, doubtless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut believe me, that man has other projects. For that reason I wished\r\nto see you, to speak to you, to warn you against everyone, but\r\nespecially against him. Tell me,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Villefort, fixing his eyes more\r\nsteadfastly on her than he had ever done before, \xe2\x80\x9cdid you ever reveal\r\nto anyone our connection?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever, to anyone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou understand me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, affectionately; \xe2\x80\x9cwhen I say\r\nanyone,\xe2\x80\x94pardon my urgency,\xe2\x80\x94to anyone living I mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, I understand very well,\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated the baroness; \xe2\x80\x9cnever, I\r\nswear to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you ever in the habit of writing in the evening what had\r\ntranspired in the morning? Do you keep a journal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my life has been passed in frivolity; I wish to forget it myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you talk in your sleep?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30275m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI sleep soundly, like a child; do you not remember?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe color mounted to the baroness\xe2\x80\x99s face, and Villefort turned awfully\r\npale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in so low a tone that he could hardly be heard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said the baroness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I understand what I now have to do,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort. \xe2\x80\x9cIn less\r\nthan one week from this time I will ascertain who this M. de Monte\r\nCristo is, whence he comes, where he goes, and why he speaks in our\r\npresence of children that have been disinterred in a garden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort pronounced these words with an accent which would have made\r\nthe count shudder had he heard him. Then he pressed the hand the\r\nbaroness reluctantly gave him, and led her respectfully back to the\r\ndoor. Madame Danglars returned in another cab to the passage, on the\r\nother side of which she found her carriage, and her coachman sleeping\r\npeacefully on his box while waiting for her.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 68. A Summer Ball\r\n\r\nThe same day during the interview between Madame Danglars and the\r\nprocureur, a travelling-carriage entered the Rue du Helder, passed\r\nthrough the gateway of No. 27, and stopped in the yard. In a moment the\r\ndoor was opened, and Madame de Morcerf alighted, leaning on her son\xe2\x80\x99s\r\narm. Albert soon left her, ordered his horses, and having arranged his\r\ntoilet, drove to the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es, to the house of Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\nThe count received him with his habitual smile. It was a strange thing\r\nthat no one ever appeared to advance a step in that man\xe2\x80\x99s favor. Those\r\nwho would, as it were, force a passage to his heart, found an\r\nimpassable barrier. Morcerf, who ran towards him with open arms, was\r\nchilled as he drew near, in spite of the friendly smile, and simply\r\nheld out his hand. Monte Cristo shook it coldly, according to his\r\ninvariable practice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere I am, dear count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWelcome home again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI arrived an hour since.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom Dieppe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, from Tr\xc3\xa9port.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I have come at once to see you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is extremely kind of you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo with a tone of\r\nperfect indifference.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is the news?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should not ask a stranger, a foreigner, for news.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it, but in asking for news, I mean, have you done anything for\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad you commissioned me?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, feigning uneasiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not assume so much indifference. It is\r\nsaid, sympathy travels rapidly, and when at Tr\xc3\xa9port, I felt the\r\nelectric shock; you have either been working for me or thinking of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI have indeed thought of you, but the\r\nmagnetic wire I was guiding acted, indeed, without my knowledge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30277m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed! Pray tell me how it happened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWillingly. M. Danglars dined with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it; to avoid meeting him, my mother and I left town.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he met here M. Andrea Cavalcanti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Italian prince?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so fast; M. Andrea only calls himself count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCalls himself, do you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, calls himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he not a count?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can I know of him? He calls himself so. I, of course, give him\r\nthe same title, and everyone else does likewise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a strange man you are! What next? You say M. Danglars dined\r\nhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, with Count Cavalcanti, the marquis his father, Madame Danglars,\r\nM. and Madame de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x94charming people,\xe2\x80\x94M. Debray, Maximilian\r\nMorrel, and M. de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid they speak of me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the worse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so? I thought you wished them to forget you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf they did not speak of me, I am sure they thought about me, and I am\r\nin despair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow will that affect you, since Mademoiselle Danglars was not among\r\nthe number here who thought of you? Truly, she might have thought of\r\nyou at home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no fear of that; or, if she did, it was only in the same way in\r\nwhich I think of her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTouching sympathy! So you hate each other?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cif Mademoiselle Danglars were disposed to take\r\npity on my supposed martyrdom on her account, and would dispense with\r\nall matrimonial formalities between our two families, I am ready to\r\nagree to the arrangement. In a word, Mademoiselle Danglars would make a\r\ncharming mistress\xe2\x80\x94but a wife\xe2\x80\x94_diable!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cis your opinion of your intended\r\nspouse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; it is rather unkind, I acknowledge, but it is true. But as this\r\ndream cannot be realized, since Mademoiselle Danglars must become my\r\nlawful wife, live perpetually with me, sing to me, compose verses and\r\nmusic within ten paces of me, and that for my whole life, it frightens\r\nme. One may forsake a mistress, but a wife,\xe2\x80\x94good heavens! There she\r\nmust always be; and to marry Mademoiselle Danglars would be awful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are difficult to please, viscount.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, for I often wish for what is impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo find such a wife as my father found.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo turned pale, and looked at Albert, while playing with some\r\nmagnificent pistols.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour father was fortunate, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know my opinion of my mother, count; look at her,\xe2\x80\x94still beautiful,\r\nwitty, more charming than ever. For any other son to have stayed with\r\nhis mother for four days at Tr\xc3\xa9port, it would have been a condescension\r\nor a martyrdom, while I return, more contented, more peaceful\xe2\x80\x94shall I\r\nsay more poetic!\xe2\x80\x94than if I had taken Queen Mab or Titania as my\r\ncompanion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30279m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is an overwhelming demonstration, and you would make everyone vow\r\nto live a single life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch are my reasons for not liking to marry Mademoiselle Danglars.\r\nHave you ever noticed how much a thing is heightened in value when we\r\nobtain possession of it? The diamond which glittered in the window at\r\nMarl\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x99s or Fossin\xe2\x80\x99s shines with more splendor when it is our own; but\r\nif we are compelled to acknowledge the superiority of another, and\r\nstill must retain the one that is inferior, do you not know what we\r\nhave to endure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWorldling,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThus I shall rejoice when Mademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie perceives I am but a\r\npitiful atom, with scarcely as many hundred thousand francs as she has\r\nmillions.\xe2\x80\x9d Monte Cristo smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cOne plan occurred to me,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nAlbert; \xe2\x80\x9cFranz likes all that is eccentric; I tried to make him fall in\r\nlove with Mademoiselle Danglars; but in spite of four letters, written\r\nin the most alluring style, he invariably answered: \xe2\x80\x98My eccentricity\r\nmay be great, but it will not make me break my promise.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is what I call devoted friendship, to recommend to another one\r\nwhom you would not marry yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d Albert smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cApropos,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, \xe2\x80\x9cFranz is coming soon, but it will not\r\ninterest you; you dislike him, I think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cmy dear viscount, how have you discovered that\r\nI did not like M. Franz! I like everyone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you include me in the expression everyone\xe2\x80\x94many thanks!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us not mistake,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI love everyone as God\r\ncommands us to love our neighbor, as Christians; but I thoroughly hate\r\nbut a few. Let us return to M. Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay. Did you say he was\r\ncoming?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; summoned by M. de Villefort, who is apparently as anxious to get\r\nMademoiselle Valentine married as M. Danglars is to see Mademoiselle\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie settled. It must be a very irksome office to be the father of a\r\ngrown-up daughter; it seems to make one feverish, and to raise one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npulse to ninety beats a minute until the deed is done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, unlike you, bears his misfortune patiently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill more, he talks seriously about the matter, puts on a white tie,\r\nand speaks of his family. He entertains a very high opinion of M. and\r\nMadame de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich they deserve, do they not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe they do. M. de Villefort has always passed for a severe but\r\na just man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is, then, one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cwhom you do not condemn like\r\npoor Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I am not compelled to marry his daughter perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nAlbert, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, my dear sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are revoltingly\r\nfoppish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI foppish? how do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; pray take a cigar, and cease to defend yourself, and to struggle\r\nto escape marrying Mademoiselle Danglars. Let things take their course;\r\nperhaps you may not have to retract.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, staring.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless, my dear viscount, you will not be taken by force; and\r\nseriously, do you wish to break off your engagement?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would give a hundred thousand francs to be able to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen make yourself quite easy. M. Danglars would give double that sum\r\nto attain the same end.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I, indeed, so happy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, who still could not prevent an\r\nalmost imperceptible cloud passing across his brow. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, my dear\r\ncount, has M. Danglars any reason?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! there is your proud and selfish nature. You would expose the\r\nself-love of another with a hatchet, but you shrink if your own is\r\nattacked with a needle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut yet, M. Danglars appeared\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDelighted with you, was he not? Well, he is a man of bad taste, and is\r\nstill more enchanted with another. I know not whom; look and judge for\r\nyourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, I understand. But my mother\xe2\x80\x94no, not my mother; I mistake\xe2\x80\x94my\r\nfather intends giving a ball.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA ball at this season?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSummer balls are fashionable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf they were not, the countess has only to wish it, and they would\r\nbecome so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right; You know they are select affairs; those who remain in\r\nParis in July must be true Parisians. Will you take charge of our\r\ninvitation to Messieurs Cavalcanti?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen will it take place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn Saturday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Cavalcanti\xe2\x80\x99s father will be gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the son will be here; will you invite young M. Cavalcanti?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know him, viscount.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not know him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I never saw him until a few days since, and am not responsible for\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you receive him at your house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is another thing: he was recommended to me by a good abb\xc3\xa9, who\r\nmay be deceived. Give him a direct invitation, but do not ask me to\r\npresent him. If he were afterwards to marry Mademoiselle Danglars, you\r\nwould accuse me of intrigue, and would be challenging me,\xe2\x80\x94besides, I\r\nmay not be there myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt your ball.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should you not be there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you have not yet invited me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I come expressly for that purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very kind, but I may be prevented.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I tell you one thing, you will be so amiable as to set aside all\r\nimpediments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me what it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mother begs you to come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Comtesse de Morcerf?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, starting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI assure you Madame de Morcerf speaks freely\r\nto me, and if you have not felt those sympathetic fibres of which I\r\nspoke just now thrill within you, you must be entirely devoid of them,\r\nfor during the last four days we have spoken of no one else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have talked of me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is the penalty of being a living puzzle!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I am also a puzzle to your mother? I should have thought her too\r\nreasonable to be led by imagination.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA problem, my dear count, for everyone\xe2\x80\x94for my mother as well as\r\nothers; much studied, but not solved, you still remain an enigma, do\r\nnot fear. My mother is only astonished that you remain so long\r\nunsolved. I believe, while the Countess G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 takes you for Lord Ruthven,\r\nmy mother imagines you to be Cagliostro or the Count Saint-Germain. The\r\nfirst opportunity you have, confirm her in her opinion; it will be easy\r\nfor you, as you have the philosophy of the one and the wit of the\r\nother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you for the warning,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cI shall endeavor to be\r\nprepared for all suppositions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will, then, come on Saturday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, since Madame de Morcerf invites me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill M. Danglars be there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has already been invited by my father. We shall try to persuade the\r\ngreat d\xe2\x80\x99Aguesseau,11 M. de Villefort, to come, but have not much hope\r\nof seeing him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Never despair of anything,\xe2\x80\x99 says the proverb.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you dance, count?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you; it would not be astonishing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is very well before one is over forty. No, I do not dance, but I\r\nlike to see others do so. Does Madame de Morcerf dance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever; you can talk to her, she so delights in your conversation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30283m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, truly; and I assure you. You are the only man of whom I have\r\nheard her speak with interest.\xe2\x80\x9d Albert rose and took his hat; the count\r\nconducted him to the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have one thing to reproach myself with,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, stopping Albert on\r\nthe steps. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have spoken to you indiscreetly about Danglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, speak to me always in the same strain about him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am glad to be reassured on that point. Apropos, when do you aspect\r\nM. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive or six days hence at the latest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when is he to be married?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImmediately on the arrival of M. and Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBring him to see me. Although you say I do not like him, I assure you\r\nI shall be happy to see him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will obey your orders, my lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUntil Saturday, when I may expect you, may I not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I promised you.\xe2\x80\x9d The Count watched Albert, waving his hand to\r\nhim. When he had mounted his phaeton, Monte Cristo turned, and seeing\r\nBertuccio, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat news?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe went to the Palais,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the steward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she stay long there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn hour and a half.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she return home?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDirectly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear Bertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cI now advise you to go in\r\nquest of the little estate I spoke to you of in Normandy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio bowed, and as his wishes were in perfect harmony with the\r\norder he had received, he started the same evening.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 69. The Inquiry\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort kept the promise he had made to Madame Danglars, to\r\nendeavor to find out how the Count of Monte Cristo had discovered the\r\nhistory of the house at Auteuil. He wrote the same day for the required\r\ninformation to M. de Boville, who, from having been an inspector of\r\nprisons, was promoted to a high office in the police; and the latter\r\nbegged for two days time to ascertain exactly who would be most likely\r\nto give him full particulars. At the end of the second day M. de\r\nVillefort received the following note:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe person called the Count of Monte Cristo is an intimate\r\nacquaintance of Lord Wilmore, a rich foreigner, who is sometimes seen\r\nin Paris and who is there at this moment; he is also known to the Abb\xc3\xa9\r\nBusoni, a Sicilian priest, of high repute in the East, where he has\r\ndone much good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort replied by ordering the strictest inquiries to be made\r\nrespecting these two persons; his orders were executed, and the\r\nfollowing evening he received these details:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe abb\xc3\xa9, who was in Paris only for a month, inhabited a small\r\ntwo-storied house behind Saint-Sulpice; there were two rooms on each\r\nfloor and he was the only tenant. The two lower rooms consisted of a\r\ndining-room, with a table, chairs, and side-board of walnut, and a\r\nwainscoted parlor, without ornaments, carpet, or timepiece. It was\r\nevident that the abb\xc3\xa9 limited himself to objects of strict necessity.\r\nHe preferred to use the sitting-room upstairs, which was more library\r\nthan parlor, and was furnished with theological books and parchments,\r\nin which he delighted to bury himself for months at a time, according\r\nto his valet de chambre. His valet looked at the visitors through a\r\nsort of wicket; and if their faces were unknown to him or displeased\r\nhim, he replied that the abb\xc3\xa9 was not in Paris, an answer which\r\nsatisfied most persons, because the abb\xc3\xa9 was known to be a great\r\ntraveller. Besides, whether at home or not, whether in Paris or Cairo,\r\nthe abb\xc3\xa9 always left something to give away, which the valet\r\ndistributed through this wicket in his master\xe2\x80\x99s name. The other room\r\nnear the library was a bedroom. A bed without curtains, four armchairs,\r\nand a couch, covered with yellow Utrecht velvet, composed, with a\r\n_prie-Dieu_, all its furniture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord Wilmore resided in Rue Fontaine-Saint-Georges. He was one of\r\nthose English tourists who consume a large fortune in travelling. He\r\nhired the apartment in which he lived furnished, passed only a few\r\nhours in the day there, and rarely slept there. One of his\r\npeculiarities was never to speak a word of French, which he however\r\nwrote with great facility.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe day after this important information had been given to the king\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattorney, a man alighted from a carriage at the corner of the Rue\r\nF\xc3\xa9rou, and rapping at an olive-green door, asked if the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni\r\nwere within.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he went out early this morning,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the valet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI might not always be content with that answer,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the visitor,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfor I come from one to whom everyone must be at home. But have the\r\nkindness to give the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told you he was not at home,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the valet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen on his return give him that card and this sealed paper. Will he\r\nbe at home at eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock this evening?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless, unless he is at work, which is the same as if he were out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will come again at that time,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the visitor, who then\r\nretired.\r\n\r\nAt the appointed hour the same man returned in the same carriage,\r\nwhich, instead of stopping this time at the end of the Rue F\xc3\xa9rou, drove\r\nup to the green door. He knocked, and it opened immediately to admit\r\nhim. From the signs of respect the valet paid him, he saw that his note\r\nhad produced a good effect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the abb\xc3\xa9 at home?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; he is at work in his library, but he expects you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nthe valet. The stranger ascended a rough staircase, and before a table,\r\nillumined by a lamp whose light was concentrated by a large shade while\r\nthe rest of the apartment was in partial darkness, he perceived the\r\nabb\xc3\xa9 in a monk\xe2\x80\x99s dress, with a cowl on his head such as was used by\r\nlearned men of the Middle Ages.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave I the honor of addressing the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the visitor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the abb\xc3\xa9; \xe2\x80\x9cand you are the person whom M. de\r\nBoville, formerly an inspector of prisons, sends to me from the prefect\r\nof police?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of the agents appointed to secure the safety of Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir\xe2\x80\x9d replied the stranger with a slight hesitation, and blushing.\r\n\r\nThe abb\xc3\xa9 replaced the large spectacles, which covered not only his eyes\r\nbut his temples, and sitting down motioned to his visitor to do the\r\nsame. \xe2\x80\x9cI am at your service, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, with a marked Italian\r\naccent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe mission with which I am charged, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the visitor,\r\nspeaking with hesitation, \xe2\x80\x9cis a confidential one on the part of him who\r\nfulfils it, and him by whom he is employed.\xe2\x80\x9d The abb\xc3\xa9 bowed. \xe2\x80\x9cYour\r\nprobity,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the stranger, \xe2\x80\x9cis so well known to the prefect that\r\nhe wishes as a magistrate to ascertain from you some particulars\r\nconnected with the public safety, to ascertain which I am deputed to\r\nsee you. It is hoped that no ties of friendship or humane consideration\r\nwill induce you to conceal the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProvided, sir, the particulars you wish for do not interfere with my\r\nscruples or my conscience. I am a priest, sir, and the secrets of\r\nconfession, for instance, must remain between me and God, and not\r\nbetween me and human justice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not alarm yourself, monsieur, we will duly respect your\r\nconscience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment the abb\xc3\xa9 pressed down his side of the shade and so\r\nraised it on the other, throwing a bright light on the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s face,\r\nwhile his own remained obscured.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, abb\xc3\xa9,\xe2\x80\x9d said the envoy of the prefect of the police, \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nthe light tries my eyes very much.\xe2\x80\x9d The abb\xc3\xa9 lowered the shade.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, sir, I am listening\xe2\x80\x94go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will come at once to the point. Do you know the Count of Monte\r\nCristo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean Monsieur Zaccone, I presume?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cZaccone?\xe2\x80\x94is not his name Monte Cristo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonte Cristo is the name of an estate, or, rather, of a rock, and not\r\na family name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, be it so\xe2\x80\x94let us not dispute about words; and since M. de Monte\r\nCristo and M. Zaccone are the same\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbsolutely the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us speak of M. Zaccone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgreed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI asked you if you knew him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExtremely well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe son of a rich shipbuilder in Malta.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know that is the report; but, as you are aware, the police does not\r\ncontent itself with vague reports.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHowever,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the abb\xc3\xa9, with an affable smile, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen that report\r\nis in accordance with the truth, everybody must believe it, the police\r\nas well as all the rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you sure of what you assert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean by that question?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnderstand, sir, I do not in the least suspect your veracity; I ask if\r\nyou are certain of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knew his father, M. Zaccone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when a child I often played with the son in the timber-yards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut whence does he derive the title of count?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are aware that may be bought.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn Italy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverywhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd his immense riches, whence does he procure them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey may not be so very great.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much do you suppose he possesses?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom one hundred and fifty to two hundred thousand livres per annum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is reasonable,\xe2\x80\x9d said the visitor; \xe2\x80\x9cI have heard he had three or\r\nfour millions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo hundred thousand per annum would make four millions of capital.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I was told he had four millions per annum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not probable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know this Island of Monte Cristo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, everyone who has come from Palermo, Naples, or Rome to\r\nFrance by sea must know it, since he has passed close to it and must\r\nhave seen it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am told it is a delightful place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a rock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why has the count bought a rock?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the sake of being a count. In Italy one must have territorial\r\npossessions to be a count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have, doubtless, heard the adventures of M. Zaccone\xe2\x80\x99s youth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe father\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, the son\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know nothing certain; at that period of his life, I lost sight of my\r\nyoung comrade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas he in the wars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think he entered the service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what branch?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the navy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you not his confessor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir; I believe he is a Lutheran.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Lutheran?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, I believe such is the case, I do not affirm it; besides,\r\nliberty of conscience is established in France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless, and we are not now inquiring into his creed, but his\r\nactions; in the name of the prefect of police, I ask you what you know\r\nof him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe passes for a very charitable man. Our holy father, the pope, has\r\nmade him a knight of Jesus Christ for the services he rendered to the\r\nChristians in the East; he has five or six rings as testimonials from\r\nEastern monarchs of his services.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes he wear them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but he is proud of them; he is better pleased with rewards given\r\nto the benefactors of man than to his destroyers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a Quaker then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly, he is a Quaker, with the exception of the peculiar dress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he any friends?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, everyone who knows him is his friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut has he any enemies?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne only.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord Wilmore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is in Paris just now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan he give me any particulars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImportant ones; he was in India with Zaccone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know his abode?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s somewhere in the Chauss\xc3\xa9e d\xe2\x80\x99Antin; but I know neither the street\r\nnor the number.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30289m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you at variance with the Englishman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love Zaccone, and he hates him; we are consequently not friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think the Count of Monte Cristo had ever been in France before\r\nhe made this visit to Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo that question I can answer positively; no, sir, he had not, because\r\nhe applied to me six months ago for the particulars he required, and as\r\nI did not know when I might again come to Paris, I recommended M.\r\nCavalcanti to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAndrea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Bartolomeo, his father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, sir, I have but one question more to ask, and I charge you, in\r\nthe name of honor, of humanity, and of religion, to answer me\r\ncandidly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know with what design M. de Monte Cristo purchased a house at\r\nAuteuil?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, for he told me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo make a lunatic asylum of it, similar to that founded by the Count\r\nof Pisani at Palermo. Do you know about that institution?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heard of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a magnificent charity.\xe2\x80\x9d Having said this, the abb\xc3\xa9 bowed to\r\nimply he wished to pursue his studies.\r\n\r\nThe visitor either understood the abb\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x99s meaning, or had no more\r\nquestions to ask; he arose, and the abb\xc3\xa9 accompanied him to the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a great almsgiver,\xe2\x80\x9d said the visitor, \xe2\x80\x9cand although you are\r\nsaid to be rich, I will venture to offer you something for your poor\r\npeople; will you accept my offering?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you, sir; I am only jealous in one thing, and that is that the\r\nrelief I give should be entirely from my own resources.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHowever\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy resolution, sir, is unchangeable, but you have only to search for\r\nyourself and you will find, alas, but too many objects upon whom to\r\nexercise your benevolence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe abb\xc3\xa9 once more bowed as he opened the door, the stranger bowed and\r\ntook his leave, and the carriage conveyed him straight to the house of\r\nM. de Villefort. An hour afterwards the carriage was again ordered, and\r\nthis time it went to the Rue Fontaine-Saint-Georges, and stopped at No.\r\n5, where Lord Wilmore lived. The stranger had written to Lord Wilmore,\r\nrequesting an interview, which the latter had fixed for ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock. As\r\nthe envoy of the prefect of police arrived ten minutes before ten, he\r\nwas told that Lord Wilmore, who was precision and punctuality\r\npersonified, was not yet come in, but that he would be sure to return\r\nas the clock struck.\r\n\r\nThe visitor was introduced into the drawing-room, which was like all\r\nother furnished drawing-rooms. A mantle-piece, with two modern S\xc3\xa8vres\r\nvases, a timepiece representing Cupid with his bent bow, a mirror with\r\nan engraving on each side\xe2\x80\x94one representing Homer carrying his guide,\r\nthe other, Belisarius begging\xe2\x80\x94a grayish paper; red and black\r\ntapestry\xe2\x80\x94such was the appearance of Lord Wilmore\xe2\x80\x99s drawing-room.\r\n\r\nIt was illuminated by lamps with ground-glass shades which gave only a\r\nfeeble light, as if out of consideration for the envoy\xe2\x80\x99s weak sight.\r\nAfter ten minutes\xe2\x80\x99 expectation the clock struck ten; at the fifth\r\nstroke the door opened and Lord Wilmore appeared. He was rather above\r\nthe middle height, with thin reddish whiskers, light complexion and\r\nlight hair, turning rather gray. He was dressed with all the English\r\npeculiarity, namely, in a blue coat, with gilt buttons and high collar,\r\nin the fashion of 1811, a white kerseymere waistcoat, and nankeen\r\npantaloons, three inches too short, but which were prevented by straps\r\nfrom slipping up to the knee. His first remark on entering was:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, sir, I do not speak French?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know you do not like to converse in our language,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\nenvoy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you may use it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Lord Wilmore; \xe2\x80\x9cI understand it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the visitor, changing his idiom, \xe2\x80\x9cknow enough of\r\nEnglish to keep up the conversation. Do not put yourself to the\r\nslightest inconvenience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAw?\xe2\x80\x9d said Lord Wilmore, with that tone which is only known to natives\r\nof Great Britain.\r\n\r\nThe envoy presented his letter of introduction, which the latter read\r\nwith English coolness, and having finished:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cperfectly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30293m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThen began the questions, which were similar to those which had been\r\naddressed to the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni. But as Lord Wilmore, in the character of\r\nthe count\xe2\x80\x99s enemy, was less restrained in his answers, they were more\r\nnumerous; he described the youth of Monte Cristo, who he said, at ten\r\nyears of age, entered the service of one of the petty sovereigns of\r\nIndia who make war on the English. It was there Wilmore had first met\r\nhim and fought against him; and in that war Zaccone had been taken\r\nprisoner, sent to England, and consigned to the hulks, whence he had\r\nescaped by swimming. Then began his travels, his duels, his caprices;\r\nthen the insurrection in Greece broke out, and he had served in the\r\nGrecian ranks. While in that service he had discovered a silver mine in\r\nthe mountains of Thessaly, but he had been careful to conceal it from\r\neveryone. After the battle of Navarino, when the Greek government was\r\nconsolidated, he asked of King Otho a mining grant for that district,\r\nwhich was given him. Hence that immense fortune, which, in Lord\r\nWilmore\xe2\x80\x99s opinion, possibly amounted to one or two millions per\r\nannum,\xe2\x80\x94a precarious fortune, which might be momentarily lost by the\r\nfailure of the mine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the visitor, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know why he came to France?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is speculating in railways,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lord Wilmore, \xe2\x80\x9cand as he is an\r\nexpert chemist and physicist, he has invented a new system of\r\ntelegraphy, which he is seeking to bring to perfection.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much does he spend yearly?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the prefect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot more than five or six hundred thousand francs,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lord Wilmore;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9che is a miser.\xe2\x80\x9d Hatred evidently inspired the Englishman, who, knowing\r\nno other reproach to bring on the count, accused him of avarice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know his house at Auteuil?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you know respecting it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you wish to know why he bought it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count is a speculator, who will certainly ruin himself in\r\nexperiments. He supposes there is in the neighborhood of the house he\r\nhas bought a mineral spring equal to those at Bagn\xc3\xa8res, Luchon, and\r\nCauterets. He is going to turn his house into a _Badhaus_, as the\r\nGermans term it. He has already dug up all the garden two or three\r\ntimes to find the famous spring, and, being unsuccessful, he will soon\r\npurchase all the contiguous houses. Now, as I dislike him, and hope his\r\nrailway, his electric telegraph, or his search for baths, will ruin\r\nhim, I am watching for his discomfiture, which must soon take place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was the cause of your quarrel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen he was in England he seduced the wife of one of my friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you not seek revenge?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have already fought three duels with him,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman, \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nfirst with the pistol, the second with the sword, and the third with\r\nthe sabre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what was the result of those duels?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe first time, he broke my arm; the second, he wounded me in the\r\nbreast; and the third time, made this large wound.\xe2\x80\x9d The Englishman\r\nturned down his shirt-collar, and showed a scar, whose redness proved\r\nit to be a recent one. \xe2\x80\x9cSo that, you see, there is a deadly feud\r\nbetween us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said the envoy, \xe2\x80\x9cyou do not go about it in the right way to kill\r\nhim, if I understand you correctly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAw?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman, \xe2\x80\x9cI practice shooting every day, and every\r\nother day Grisier comes to my house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was all the visitor wished to ascertain, or, rather, all the\r\nEnglishman appeared to know. The agent arose, and having bowed to Lord\r\nWilmore, who returned his salutation with the stiff politeness of the\r\nEnglish, he retired. Lord Wilmore, having heard the door close after\r\nhim, returned to his bedroom, where with one hand he pulled off his\r\nlight hair, his red whiskers, his false jaw, and his wound, to resume\r\nthe black hair, dark complexion, and pearly teeth of the Count of Monte\r\nCristo.\r\n\r\nIt was M. de Villefort, and not the prefect, who returned to the house\r\nof M. de Villefort. The procureur felt more at ease, although he had\r\nlearned nothing really satisfactory, and, for the first time since the\r\ndinner-party at Auteuil, he slept soundly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 70. The Ball\r\n\r\nIt was in the warmest days of July, when in due course of time the\r\nSaturday arrived upon which the ball was to take place at M. de\r\nMorcerf\xe2\x80\x99s. It was ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock at night; the branches of the great trees\r\nin the garden of the count\xe2\x80\x99s house stood out boldly against the azure\r\ncanopy of heaven, which was studded with golden stars, but where the\r\nlast fleeting clouds of a vanishing storm yet lingered.\r\n\r\nFrom the apartments on the ground floor might be heard the sound of\r\nmusic, with the whirl of the waltz and galop, while brilliant streams\r\nof light shone through the openings of the Venetian blinds. At this\r\nmoment the garden was only occupied by about ten servants, who had just\r\nreceived orders from their mistress to prepare the supper, the serenity\r\nof the weather continuing to increase. Until now, it had been undecided\r\nwhether the supper should take place in the dining-room, or under a\r\nlong tent erected on the lawn, but the beautiful blue sky, studded with\r\nstars, had settled the question in favor of the lawn.\r\n\r\nThe gardens were illuminated with colored lanterns, according to the\r\nItalian custom, and, as is usual in countries where the luxuries of the\r\ntable\xe2\x80\x94the rarest of all luxuries in their complete form\xe2\x80\x94are well\r\nunderstood, the supper-table was loaded with wax-lights and flowers.\r\n\r\n30297m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAt the time the Countess of Morcerf returned to the rooms, after giving\r\nher orders, many guests were arriving, more attracted by the charming\r\nhospitality of the countess than by the distinguished position of the\r\ncount; for, owing to the good taste of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, one was sure of\r\nfinding some devices at her entertainment worthy of describing, or even\r\ncopying in case of need.\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars, in whom the events we have related had caused deep\r\nanxiety, had hesitated about going to Madame de Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s, when during\r\nthe morning her carriage happened to meet that of Villefort. The latter\r\nmade a sign, and when the carriages had drawn close together, said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are going to Madame de Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s, are you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI am too ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, significantly; \xe2\x80\x9cit is important\r\nthat you should be seen there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the baroness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case I will go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the two carriages passed on towards their different destinations.\r\nMadame Danglars therefore came, not only beautiful in person, but\r\nradiant with splendor; she entered by one door at the time when\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s appeared at the door. The countess took Albert to meet Madame\r\nDanglars. He approached, paid her some well merited compliments on her\r\ntoilet, and offered his arm to conduct her to a seat. Albert looked\r\naround him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are looking for my daughter?\xe2\x80\x9d said the baroness, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI confess it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert. \xe2\x80\x9cCould you have been so cruel as not to\r\nbring her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCalm yourself. She has met Mademoiselle de Villefort, and has taken\r\nher arm; see, they are following us, both in white dresses, one with a\r\nbouquet of camellias, the other with one of myosotis. But tell me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what do you wish to know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill not the Count of Monte Cristo be here tonight?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeventeen!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only mean that the count seems the rage,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the viscount,\r\nsmiling, \xe2\x80\x9cand that you are the seventeenth person that has asked me the\r\nsame question. The count is in fashion; I congratulate him upon it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd have you replied to everyone as you have to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, to be sure, I have not answered you; be satisfied, we shall have\r\nthis \xe2\x80\x98lion\xe2\x80\x99; we are among the privileged ones.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you at the Opera yesterday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed? And did the eccentric person commit any new originality?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan he be seen without doing so? Elssler was dancing in _Le Diable\r\nboiteux_; the Greek princess was in ecstasies. After the cachucha he\r\nplaced a magnificent ring on the stem of a bouquet, and threw it to the\r\ncharming danseuse, who, in the third act, to do honor to the gift,\r\nreappeared with it on her finger. And the Greek princess,\xe2\x80\x94will she be\r\nhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you will be deprived of that pleasure; her position in the count\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nestablishment is not sufficiently understood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait; leave me here, and go and speak to Madame de Villefort, who is\r\ntrying to attract your attention.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert bowed to Madame Danglars, and advanced towards Madame de\r\nVillefort, whose lips opened as he approached.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wager anything,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, interrupting her, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I know what\r\nyou were about to say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I guess rightly, will you confess it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn your honor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were going to ask me if the Count of Monte Cristo had arrived, or\r\nwas expected.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all. It is not of him that I am now thinking. I was going to\r\nask you if you had received any news of Monsieur Franz.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x94yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did he tell you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat he was leaving at the same time as his letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now then, the count?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count will come, of that you may be satisfied.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know that he has another name besides Monte Cristo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I did not know it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonte Cristo is the name of an island, and he has a family name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never heard it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, I am better informed than you; his name is Zaccone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a Maltese.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is also possible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe son of a shipowner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, you should relate all this aloud, you would have the greatest\r\nsuccess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe served in India, discovered a mine in Thessaly, and comes to Paris\r\nto establish a mineral water-cure at Auteuil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99m sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is indeed news! Am I allowed to\r\nrepeat it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but cautiously, tell one thing at a time, and do not say I told\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause it is a secret just discovered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe police.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the news originated\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the prefect\xe2\x80\x99s last night. Paris, you can understand, is astonished\r\nat the sight of such unusual splendor, and the police have made\r\ninquiries.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well! Nothing more is wanting than to arrest the count as a\r\nvagabond, on the pretext of his being too rich.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, that doubtless would have happened if his credentials had not\r\nbeen so favorable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor count! And is he aware of the danger he has been in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it will be but charitable to inform him. When he arrives, I will\r\nnot fail to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJust then, a handsome young man, with bright eyes, black hair, and\r\nglossy moustache, respectfully bowed to Madame de Villefort. Albert\r\nextended his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9callow me to present to you M. Maximilian\r\nMorrel, captain of Spahis, one of our best, and, above all, of our\r\nbravest officers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have already had the pleasure of meeting this gentleman at Auteuil,\r\nat the house of the Count of Monte Cristo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame de\r\nVillefort, turning away with marked coldness of manner.\r\n\r\nThis answer, and especially the tone in which it was uttered, chilled\r\nthe heart of poor Morrel. But a recompense was in store for him;\r\nturning around, he saw near the door a beautiful fair face, whose large\r\nblue eyes were, without any marked expression, fixed upon him, while\r\nthe bouquet of myosotis was gently raised to her lips.\r\n\r\nThe salutation was so well understood that Morrel, with the same\r\nexpression in his eyes, placed his handkerchief to his mouth; and these\r\ntwo living statues, whose hearts beat so violently under their marble\r\naspect, separated from each other by the whole length of the room,\r\nforgot themselves for a moment, or rather forgot the world in their\r\nmutual contemplation. They might have remained much longer lost in one\r\nanother, without anyone noticing their abstraction. The Count of Monte\r\nCristo had just entered.\r\n\r\nWe have already said that there was something in the count which\r\nattracted universal attention wherever he appeared. It was not the\r\ncoat, unexceptional in its cut, though simple and unornamented; it was\r\nnot the plain white waistcoat; it was not the trousers, that displayed\r\nthe foot so perfectly formed\xe2\x80\x94it was none of these things that attracted\r\nthe attention,\xe2\x80\x94it was his pale complexion, his waving black hair, his\r\ncalm and serene expression, his dark and melancholy eye, his mouth,\r\nchiselled with such marvellous delicacy, which so easily expressed such\r\nhigh disdain,\xe2\x80\x94these were what fixed the attention of all upon him.\r\n\r\nMany men might have been handsomer, but certainly there could be none\r\nwhose appearance was more _significant_, if the expression may be used.\r\nEverything about the count seemed to have its meaning, for the constant\r\nhabit of thought which he had acquired had given an ease and vigor to\r\nthe expression of his face, and even to the most trifling gesture,\r\nscarcely to be understood. Yet the Parisian world is so strange, that\r\neven all this might not have won attention had there not been connected\r\nwith it a mysterious story gilded by an immense fortune.\r\n\r\n30301m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMeanwhile he advanced through the assemblage of guests under a battery\r\nof curious glances towards Madame de Morcerf, who, standing before a\r\nmantle-piece ornamented with flowers, had seen his entrance in a\r\nlooking-glass placed opposite the door, and was prepared to receive\r\nhim. She turned towards him with a serene smile just at the moment he\r\nwas bowing to her. No doubt she fancied the count would speak to her,\r\nwhile on his side the count thought she was about to address him; but\r\nboth remained silent, and after a mere bow, Monte Cristo directed his\r\nsteps to Albert, who received him cordially.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you seen my mother?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have just had the pleasure,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I have not seen\r\nyour father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee, he is down there, talking politics with that little group of\r\ngreat geniuses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cand so those gentlemen down there are men\r\nof great talent. I should not have guessed it. And for what kind of\r\ntalent are they celebrated? You know there are different sorts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat tall, harsh-looking man is very learned, he discovered, in the\r\nneighborhood of Rome, a kind of lizard with a vertebra more than\r\nlizards usually have, and he immediately laid his discovery before the\r\nInstitute. The thing was discussed for a long time, but finally decided\r\nin his favor. I can assure you the vertebra made a great noise in the\r\nlearned world, and the gentleman, who was only a knight of the Legion\r\nof Honor, was made an officer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthis cross seems to me to be wisely\r\nawarded. I suppose, had he found another additional vertebra, they\r\nwould have made him a commander.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery likely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who can that person be who has taken it into his head to wrap\r\nhimself up in a blue coat embroidered with green?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that coat is not his own idea; it is the Republic\xe2\x80\x99s, which deputed\r\nDavid12 to devise a uniform for the Academicians.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cso this gentleman is an Academician?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithin the last week he has been made one of the learned assembly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is his especial talent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis talent? I believe he thrusts pins through the heads of rabbits, he\r\nmakes fowls eat madder, and punches the spinal marrow out of dogs with\r\nwhalebone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he is made a member of the Academy of Sciences for this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; of the French Academy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what has the French Academy to do with all this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was going to tell you. It seems\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat his experiments have very considerably advanced the cause of\r\nscience, doubtless?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; that his style of writing is very good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis must be very flattering to the feelings of the rabbits into whose\r\nheads he has thrust pins, to the fowls whose bones he has dyed red, and\r\nto the dogs whose spinal marrow he has punched out?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert laughed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the other one?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat one?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the third.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe one in the dark blue coat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a colleague of the count, and one of the most active opponents\r\nto the idea of providing the Chamber of Peers with a uniform. He was\r\nvery successful upon that question. He stood badly with the Liberal\r\npapers, but his noble opposition to the wishes of the court is now\r\ngetting him into favor with the journalists. They talk of making him an\r\nambassador.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30303m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what are his claims to the peerage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has composed two or three comic operas, written four or five\r\narticles in the _Si\xc3\xa8cle_, and voted five or six years on the\r\nministerial side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo, viscount,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are a delightful\r\n_cicerone_. And now you will do me a favor, will you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not introduce me to any of these gentlemen; and should they wish\r\nit, you will warn me.\xe2\x80\x9d Just then the count felt his arm pressed. He\r\nturned round; it was Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! is it you, baron?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you call me baron?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cyou know that I care\r\nnothing for my title. I am not like you, viscount; you like your title,\r\ndo you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cseeing that without my title I should be\r\nnothing; while you, sacrificing the baron, would still remain the\r\nmillionaire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich seems to me the finest title under the royalty of July,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nDanglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnfortunately,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cone\xe2\x80\x99s title to a millionaire does\r\nnot last for life, like that of baron, peer of France, or academician;\r\nfor example, the millionaires Franck & Poulmann, of Frankfurt, who have\r\njust become bankrupts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, becoming pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I received the news this evening by a courier. I had about a\r\nmillion in their hands, but, warned in time, I withdrew it a month\r\nago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, _mon Dieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthey have drawn on me for\r\n200,000 francs!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you can throw out the draft; their signature is worth five per\r\ncent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but it is too late,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI have honored their bills.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9chere are 200,000 francs gone after\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush, do not mention these things,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; then, approaching\r\nMonte Cristo, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cespecially before young M. Cavalcanti;\xe2\x80\x9d after\r\nwhich he smiled, and turned towards the young man in question.\r\n\r\nAlbert had left the count to speak to his mother, Danglars to converse\r\nwith young Cavalcanti; Monte Cristo was for an instant alone. Meanwhile\r\nthe heat became excessive. The footmen were hastening through the rooms\r\nwith waiters loaded with ices. Monte Cristo wiped the perspiration from\r\nhis forehead, but drew back when the waiter was presented to him; he\r\ntook no refreshment. Madame de Morcerf did not lose sight of Monte\r\nCristo; she saw that he took nothing, and even noticed his gesture of\r\nrefusal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert,\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, \xe2\x80\x9cdid you notice that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat the count has never been willing to partake of food under the\r\nroof of M. de Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but then he breakfasted with me\xe2\x80\x94indeed, he made his first\r\nappearance in the world on that occasion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut your house is not M. de Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s; \xe2\x80\x9cand since\r\nhe has been here I have watched him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, he has taken nothing yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count is very temperate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s smiled sadly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cApproach him,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cand when the next waiter passes, insist upon\r\nhis taking something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why, mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust to please me, Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s. Albert kissed his mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand, and drew near the count. Another salver passed, loaded like the\r\npreceding ones; she saw Albert attempt to persuade the count, but he\r\nobstinately refused. Albert rejoined his mother; she was very pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cyou see he refuses?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but why need this annoy you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, Albert, women are singular creatures. I should like to have\r\nseen the count take something in my house, if only an ice. Perhaps he\r\ncannot reconcile himself to the French style of living, and might\r\nprefer something else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no; I have seen him eat of everything in Italy; no doubt he does\r\nnot feel inclined this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd besides,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, \xe2\x80\x9caccustomed as he is to burning\r\nclimates, possibly he does not feel the heat as we do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think that, for he has complained of feeling almost\r\nsuffocated, and asked why the Venetian blinds were not opened as well\r\nas the windows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn a word,\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cit was a way of assuring me that his\r\nabstinence was intended.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she left the room.\r\n\r\nA minute afterwards the blinds were thrown open, and through the\r\njessamine and clematis that overhung the window one could see the\r\ngarden ornamented with lanterns, and the supper laid under the tent.\r\nDancers, players, talkers, all uttered an exclamation of joy\xe2\x80\x94everyone\r\ninhaled with delight the breeze that floated in. At the same time\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s reappeared, paler than before, but with that imperturbable\r\nexpression of countenance which she sometimes wore. She went straight\r\nto the group of which her husband formed the centre.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not detain those gentlemen here, count,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cthey would\r\nprefer, I should think, to breathe in the garden rather than suffocate\r\nhere, since they are not playing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said a gallant old general, who, in 1809, had sung _Partant pour\r\nla Syrie_,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwe will not go alone to the garden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cI will lead the way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTurning towards Monte Cristo, she added, \xe2\x80\x9ccount, will you oblige me\r\nwith your arm?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count almost staggered at these simple words; then he fixed his\r\neyes on Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s. It was only a momentary glance, but it seemed to the\r\ncountess to have lasted for a century, so much was expressed in that\r\none look.
