He offered his arm to the countess; she took it, or rather\r\njust touched it with her little hand, and they together descended the\r\nsteps, lined with rhododendrons and camellias. Behind them, by another\r\noutlet, a group of about twenty persons rushed into the garden with\r\nloud exclamations of delight.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 71. Bread and Salt\r\n\r\nMadame de Morcerf entered an archway of trees with her companion. It\r\nled through a grove of lindens to a conservatory.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was too warm in the room, was it not, count?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, madame; and it was an excellent idea of yours to open the doors\r\nand the blinds.\xe2\x80\x9d As he ceased speaking, the count felt the hand of\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s tremble. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwith that light dress, and\r\nwithout anything to cover you but that gauze scarf, perhaps you feel\r\ncold?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know where I am leading you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, without\r\nreplying to the question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you see I make no resistance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are going to the greenhouse that you see at the other end of the\r\ngrove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count looked at Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s as if to interrogate her, but she\r\ncontinued to walk on in silence, and he refrained from speaking. They\r\nreached the building, ornamented with magnificent fruits, which ripen\r\nat the beginning of July in the artificial temperature which takes the\r\nplace of the sun, so frequently absent in our climate. The countess\r\nleft the arm of Monte Cristo, and gathered a bunch of Muscatel grapes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee, count,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with a smile so sad in its expression that one\r\ncould almost detect the tears on her eyelids\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9csee, our French grapes\r\nare not to be compared, I know, with yours of Sicily and Cyprus, but\r\nyou will make allowance for our northern sun.\xe2\x80\x9d The count bowed, but\r\nstepped back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you refuse?\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, in a tremulous voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray excuse me, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I never eat\r\nMuscatel grapes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s let them fall, and sighed. A magnificent peach was hanging\r\nagainst an adjoining wall, ripened by the same artificial heat.\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s drew near, and plucked the fruit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake this peach, then,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. The count again refused. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat,\r\nagain?\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, in so plaintive an accent that it seemed to\r\nstifle a sob; \xe2\x80\x9creally, you pain me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA long silence followed; the peach, like the grapes, fell to the\r\nground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d added Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s with a supplicating glance, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is a\r\nbeautiful Arabian custom, which makes eternal friends of those who have\r\ntogether eaten bread and salt under the same roof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count; \xe2\x80\x9cbut we are in France, and not\r\nin Arabia, and in France eternal friendships are as rare as the custom\r\nof dividing bread and salt with one another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said the countess, breathlessly, with her eyes fixed on Monte\r\nCristo, whose arm she convulsively pressed with both hands, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are\r\nfriends, are we not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count became pale as death, the blood rushed to his heart, and then\r\nagain rising, dyed his cheeks with crimson; his eyes swam like those of\r\na man suddenly dazzled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, we are friends,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied; \xe2\x80\x9cwhy should we not be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe answer was so little like the one Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s desired, that she turned\r\naway to give vent to a sigh, which sounded more like a groan. \xe2\x80\x9cThank\r\nyou,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. And they walked on again. They went the whole length of\r\nthe garden without uttering a word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d suddenly exclaimed the countess, after their walk had continued\r\nten minutes in silence, \xe2\x80\x9cis it true that you have seen so much,\r\ntravelled so far, and suffered so deeply?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have suffered deeply, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut now you are happy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, \xe2\x80\x9csince no one hears me complain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd your present happiness, has it softened your heart?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy present happiness equals my past misery,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you not married?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, married?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Monte Cristo, shuddering; \xe2\x80\x9cwho could have told\r\nyou so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one told me you were, but you have frequently been seen at the\r\nOpera with a young and lovely woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is a slave whom I bought at Constantinople, madame, the daughter\r\nof a prince. I have adopted her as my daughter, having no one else to\r\nlove in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou live alone, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have no sister\xe2\x80\x94no son\xe2\x80\x94no father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you exist thus without anyone to attach you to life?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not my fault, madame. At Malta, I loved a young girl, was on the\r\npoint of marrying her, when war came and carried me away. I thought she\r\nloved me well enough to wait for me, and even to remain faithful to my\r\nmemory. When I returned she was married. This is the history of most\r\nmen who have passed twenty years of age. Perhaps my heart was weaker\r\nthan the hearts of most men, and I suffered more than they would have\r\ndone in my place; that is all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe countess stopped for a moment, as if gasping for breath. \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cand you have still preserved this love in your heart\xe2\x80\x94one can\r\nonly love once\xe2\x80\x94and did you ever see her again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30309m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never returned to the country where she lived.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Malta?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; Malta.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is, then, now at Malta?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd have you forgiven her for all she has made you suffer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer,\xe2\x80\x94yes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut only her; do you then still hate those who separated you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hate them? Not at all; why should I?\xe2\x80\x9d The countess placed herself\r\nbefore Monte Cristo, still holding in her hand a portion of the\r\nperfumed grapes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake some,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame, I never eat Muscatel grapes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, as if the\r\nsubject had not been mentioned before. The countess dashed the grapes\r\ninto the nearest thicket, with a gesture of despair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInflexible man!\xe2\x80\x9d she murmured. Monte Cristo remained as unmoved as if\r\nthe reproach had not been addressed to him.\r\n\r\nAlbert at this moment ran in. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9csuch a\r\nmisfortune has happened!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? What has happened?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the countess, as though awakening from\r\na sleep to the realities of life; \xe2\x80\x9cdid you say a misfortune? Indeed, I\r\nshould expect misfortunes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Villefort is here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe comes to fetch his wife and daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran is just arrived in Paris, bringing the\r\nnews of M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s death, which took place on the first stage\r\nafter he left Marseilles. Madame de Villefort, who was in very good\r\nspirits, would neither believe nor think of the misfortune, but\r\nMademoiselle Valentine, at the first words, guessed the whole truth,\r\nnotwithstanding all the precautions of her father; the blow struck her\r\nlike a thunderbolt, and she fell senseless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how was M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran related to Mademoiselle de Villefort?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was her grandfather on the mother\xe2\x80\x99s side. He was coming here to\r\nhasten her marriage with Franz.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo Franz must wait. Why was not M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran also grandfather to\r\nMademoiselle Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert, Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Morcerf, in a tone of mild reproof,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhat are you saying? Ah, count, he esteems you so highly, tell him\r\nthat he has spoken amiss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she took two or three steps forward. Monte Cristo watched her with\r\nan air so thoughtful, and so full of affectionate admiration, that she\r\nturned back and grasped his hand; at the same time she seized that of\r\nher son, and joined them together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are friends; are we not?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, madame, I do not presume to call myself your friend, but at all\r\ntimes I am your most respectful servant.\xe2\x80\x9d The countess left with an\r\nindescribable pang in her heart, and before she had taken ten steps the\r\ncount saw her raise her handkerchief to her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not my mother and you agree?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Albert, astonished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count, \xe2\x80\x9cdid you not hear her declare\r\nthat we were friends?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey re-entered the drawing-room, which Valentine and Madame de\r\nVillefort had just quitted. It is perhaps needless to add that Morrel\r\ndeparted almost at the same time.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 72. Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\r\n\r\nA gloomy scene had indeed just passed at the house of M. de Villefort.\r\nAfter the ladies had departed for the ball, whither all the entreaties\r\nof Madame de Villefort had failed in persuading him to accompany them,\r\nthe procureur had shut himself up in his study, according to his\r\ncustom, with a heap of papers calculated to alarm anyone else, but\r\nwhich generally scarcely satisfied his inordinate desires.\r\n\r\nBut this time the papers were a mere matter of form. Villefort had\r\nsecluded himself, not to study, but to reflect; and with the door\r\nlocked and orders given that he should not be disturbed excepting for\r\nimportant business, he sat down in his armchair and began to ponder\r\nover the events, the remembrance of which had during the last eight\r\ndays filled his mind with so many gloomy thoughts and bitter\r\nrecollections.\r\n\r\nThen, instead of plunging into the mass of documents piled before him,\r\nhe opened the drawer of his desk, touched a spring, and drew out a\r\nparcel of cherished memoranda, amongst which he had carefully arranged,\r\nin characters only known to himself, the names of all those who, either\r\nin his political career, in money matters, at the bar, or in his\r\nmysterious love affairs, had become his enemies.\r\n\r\nTheir number was formidable, now that he had begun to fear, and yet\r\nthese names, powerful though they were, had often caused him to smile\r\nwith the same kind of satisfaction experienced by a traveller who from\r\nthe summit of a mountain beholds at his feet the craggy eminences, the\r\nalmost impassable paths, and the fearful chasms, through which he has\r\nso perilously climbed. When he had run over all these names in his\r\nmemory, again read and studied them, commenting meanwhile upon his\r\nlists, he shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured, \xe2\x80\x9cnone of my enemies would have waited so patiently\r\nand laboriously for so long a space of time, that they might now come\r\nand crush me with this secret. Sometimes, as Hamlet says:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Foul deeds will rise,\r\n\r\nThough all the earth o\xe2\x80\x99erwhelm them, to men\xe2\x80\x99s eyes;\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\nbut, like a phosphoric light, they rise but to mislead. The story has\r\nbeen told by the Corsican to some priest, who in his turn has repeated\r\nit. M. de Monte Cristo may have heard it, and to enlighten himself\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why should he wish to enlighten himself upon the subject?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nVillefort, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s reflection, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat interest can this M. de\r\nMonte Cristo or M. Zaccone,\xe2\x80\x94son of a shipowner of Malta, discoverer of\r\na mine in Thessaly, now visiting Paris for the first time,\xe2\x80\x94what\r\ninterest, I say, can he take in discovering a gloomy, mysterious, and\r\nuseless fact like this? However, among all the incoherent details given\r\nto me by the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni and by Lord Wilmore, by that friend and that\r\nenemy, one thing appears certain and clear in my opinion\xe2\x80\x94that in no\r\nperiod, in no case, in no circumstance, could there have been any\r\ncontact between him and me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Villefort uttered words which even he himself did not believe. He\r\ndreaded not so much the revelation, for he could reply to or deny its\r\ntruth;\xe2\x80\x94he cared little for that _mene, mene, tekel upharsin_, which\r\nappeared suddenly in letters of blood upon the wall;\xe2\x80\x94but what he was\r\nreally anxious for was to discover whose hand had traced them. While he\r\nwas endeavoring to calm his fears,\xe2\x80\x94and instead of dwelling upon the\r\npolitical future that had so often been the subject of his ambitious\r\ndreams, was imagining a future limited to the enjoyments of home, in\r\nfear of awakening the enemy that had so long slept,\xe2\x80\x94the noise of a\r\ncarriage sounded in the yard, then he heard the steps of an aged person\r\nascending the stairs, followed by tears and lamentations, such as\r\nservants always give vent to when they wish to appear interested in\r\ntheir master\xe2\x80\x99s grief.\r\n\r\nHe drew back the bolt of his door, and almost directly an old lady\r\nentered, unannounced, carrying her shawl on her arm, and her bonnet in\r\nher hand. The white hair was thrown back from her yellow forehead, and\r\nher eyes, already sunken by the furrows of age, now almost disappeared\r\nbeneath the eyelids swollen with grief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9coh, sir, what a misfortune! I shall die of it;\r\noh, yes, I shall certainly die of it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd then, falling upon the chair nearest the door, she burst into a\r\nparoxysm of sobs. The servants, standing in the doorway, not daring to\r\napproach nearer, were looking at Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s old servant, who had heard\r\nthe noise from his master\xe2\x80\x99s room, and run there also, remaining behind\r\nthe others. Villefort rose, and ran towards his mother-in-law, for it\r\nwas she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what can have happened?\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat has thus disturbed\r\nyou? Is M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran is dead,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the old marchioness, without\r\npreface and without expression; she appeared to be stupefied. Villefort\r\ndrew back, and clasping his hands together, exclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead!\xe2\x80\x94so suddenly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA week ago,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, \xe2\x80\x9cwe went out together in\r\nthe carriage after dinner. M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran had been unwell for some\r\ndays; still, the idea of seeing our dear Valentine again inspired him\r\nwith courage, and notwithstanding his illness he would leave. At six\r\nleagues from Marseilles, after having eaten some of the lozenges he is\r\naccustomed to take, he fell into such a deep sleep, that it appeared to\r\nme unnatural; still I hesitated to wake him, although I fancied that\r\nhis face was flushed, and that the veins of his temples throbbed more\r\nviolently than usual. However, as it became dark, and I could no longer\r\nsee, I fell asleep; I was soon aroused by a piercing shriek, as from a\r\nperson suffering in his dreams, and he suddenly threw his head back\r\nviolently. I called the valet, I stopped the postilion, I spoke to M.\r\nde Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, I applied my smelling-salts; but all was over, and I\r\narrived at Aix by the side of a corpse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort stood with his mouth half open, quite stupefied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course you sent for a doctor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImmediately; but, as I have told you, it was too late.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but then he could tell of what complaint the poor marquis had\r\ndied.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, sir, he told me; it appears to have been an apoplectic\r\nstroke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did you do then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran had always expressed a desire, in case his death\r\nhappened during his absence from Paris, that his body might be brought\r\nto the family vault. I had him put into a leaden coffin, and I am\r\npreceding him by a few days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! my poor mother!\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cto have such duties to perform\r\nat your age after such a blow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod has supported me through all; and then, my dear marquis, he would\r\ncertainly have done everything for me that I performed for him. It is\r\ntrue that since I left him, I seem to have lost my senses. I cannot\r\ncry; at my age they say that we have no more tears,\xe2\x80\x94still I think that\r\nwhen one is in trouble one should have the power of weeping. Where is\r\nValentine, sir? It is on her account I am here; I wish to see\r\nValentine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30315m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVillefort thought it would be terrible to reply that Valentine was at a\r\nball; so he only said that she had gone out with her step-mother, and\r\nthat she should be fetched. \xe2\x80\x9cThis instant, sir\xe2\x80\x94this instant, I beseech\r\nyou!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old lady. Villefort placed the arm of Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran within his own, and conducted her to his apartment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRest yourself, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nThe marchioness raised her head at this word, and beholding the man who\r\nso forcibly reminded her of her deeply-regretted child, who still lived\r\nfor her in Valentine, she felt touched at the name of mother, and\r\nbursting into tears, she fell on her knees before an armchair, where\r\nshe buried her venerable head. Villefort left her to the care of the\r\nwomen, while old Barrois ran, half-scared, to his master; for nothing\r\nfrightens old people so much as when death relaxes its vigilance over\r\nthem for a moment in order to strike some other old person. Then, while\r\nMadame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran remained on her knees, praying fervently,\r\nVillefort sent for a cab, and went himself to fetch his wife and\r\ndaughter from Madame de Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s. He was so pale when he appeared at\r\nthe door of the ball-room, that Valentine ran to him, saying:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, father, some misfortune has happened!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour grandmamma has just arrived, Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd grandpapa?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the young girl, trembling with apprehension.\r\nM. de Villefort only replied by offering his arm to his daughter. It\r\nwas just in time, for Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s head swam, and she staggered; Madame\r\nde Villefort instantly hastened to her assistance, and aided her\r\nhusband in dragging her to the carriage, saying:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a singular event! Who could have thought it? Ah, yes, it is\r\nindeed strange!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the wretched family departed, leaving a cloud of sadness hanging\r\nover the rest of the evening. At the foot of the stairs, Valentine\r\nfound Barrois awaiting her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Noirtier wishes to see you tonight, he said, in an undertone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him I will come when I leave my dear grandmamma,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied,\r\nfeeling, with true delicacy, that the person to whom she could be of\r\nthe most service just then was Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran.\r\n\r\nValentine found her grandmother in bed; silent caresses, heartwrung\r\nsobs, broken sighs, burning tears, were all that passed in this sad\r\ninterview, while Madame de Villefort, leaning on her husband\xe2\x80\x99s arm,\r\nmaintained all outward forms of respect, at least towards the poor\r\nwidow. She soon whispered to her husband:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think it would be better for me to retire, with your permission, for\r\nthe sight of me appears still to afflict your mother-in-law.\xe2\x80\x9d Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran heard her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said softly to Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9clet her leave; but do you\r\nstay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort left, and Valentine remained alone beside the bed,\r\nfor the procureur, overcome with astonishment at the unexpected death,\r\nhad followed his wife. Meanwhile, Barrois had returned for the first\r\ntime to old Noirtier, who having heard the noise in the house, had, as\r\nwe have said, sent his old servant to inquire the cause; on his return,\r\nhis quick intelligent eye interrogated the messenger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Barrois, \xe2\x80\x9ca great misfortune has happened.\r\nMadame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran has arrived, and her husband is dead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran and Noirtier had never been on strict terms of\r\nfriendship; still, the death of one old man always considerably affects\r\nanother. Noirtier let his head fall upon his chest, apparently\r\noverwhelmed and thoughtful; then he closed one eye, in token of\r\ninquiry.\r\n\r\nBarrois asked, \xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle Valentine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier nodded his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is at the ball, as you know, since she came to say good-bye to you\r\nin full dress.\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier again closed his left eye.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you wish to see her?\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier again made an affirmative sign.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, they have gone to fetch her, no doubt, from Madame de Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s;\r\nI will await her return, and beg her to come up here. Is that what you\r\nwish for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the invalid.\r\n\r\nBarrois, therefore, as we have seen, watched for Valentine, and\r\ninformed her of her grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s wish. Consequently, Valentine came up\r\nto Noirtier, on leaving Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, who in the midst of her\r\ngrief had at last yielded to fatigue and fallen into a feverish sleep.\r\nWithin reach of her hand they placed a small table upon which stood a\r\nbottle of orangeade, her usual beverage, and a glass. Then, as we have\r\nsaid, the young girl left the bedside to see M. Noirtier.\r\n\r\nValentine kissed the old man, who looked at her with such tenderness\r\nthat her eyes again filled with tears, whose sources he thought must be\r\nexhausted. The old gentleman continued to dwell upon her with the same\r\nexpression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cyou mean that I have yet a kind\r\ngrandfather left, do you not.\xe2\x80\x9d The old man intimated that such was his\r\nmeaning. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes, happily I have,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Valentine. \xe2\x80\x9cWithout that,\r\nwhat would become of me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was one o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning. Barrois, who wished to go to bed\r\nhimself, observed that after such sad events everyone stood in need of\r\nrest. Noirtier would not say that the only rest he needed was to see\r\nhis child, but wished her good-night, for grief and fatigue had made\r\nher appear quite ill.\r\n\r\nThe next morning she found her grandmother in bed; the fever had not\r\nabated, on the contrary her eyes glistened and she appeared to be\r\nsuffering from violent nervous irritability.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear grandmamma, are you worse?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Valentine, perceiving\r\nall these signs of agitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my child, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I was impatiently\r\nwaiting for your arrival, that I might send for your father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Valentine, uneasily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I wish to speak to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine durst not oppose her grandmother\xe2\x80\x99s wish, the cause of which\r\nshe did not know, and an instant afterwards Villefort entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, without using any circumlocution,\r\nand as if fearing she had no time to lose, \xe2\x80\x9cyou wrote to me concerning\r\nthe marriage of this child?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not only projected but\r\narranged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour intended son-in-law is named M. Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, madame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he not the son of General d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay who was on our side, and who was\r\nassassinated some days before the usurper returned from the Island of\r\nElba?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes he not dislike the idea of marrying the granddaughter of a\r\nJacobin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur civil dissensions are now happily extinguished, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nVillefort; \xe2\x80\x9cM. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay was quite a child when his father died, he\r\nknows very little of M. Noirtier, and will meet him, if not with\r\npleasure, at least with indifference.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it a suitable match?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn every respect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the young man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs regarded with universal esteem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou approve of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is one of the most well-bred young men I know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDuring the whole of this conversation Valentine had remained silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, after a few minutes\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreflection, \xe2\x80\x9cI must hasten the marriage, for I have but a short time to\r\nlive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cYou, dear mamma?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed M. de Villefort and\r\nValentine at the same time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know what I am saying,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the marchioness; \xe2\x80\x9cI must hurry\r\nyou, so that, as she has no mother, she may at least have a grandmother\r\nto bless her marriage. I am all that is left to her belonging to my\r\npoor Ren\xc3\xa9e, whom you have so soon forgotten, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cyou forget that I was obliged to give a\r\nmother to my child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA stepmother is never a mother, sir. But this is not to the\r\npurpose,\xe2\x80\x94our business concerns Valentine, let us leave the dead in\r\npeace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll this was said with such exceeding rapidity, that there was\r\nsomething in the conversation that seemed like the beginning of\r\ndelirium.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt shall be as you wish, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cmore especially\r\nsince your wishes coincide with mine, and as soon as M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay\r\narrives in Paris\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30319m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear grandmother,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cconsider decorum\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nrecent death. You would not have me marry under such sad auspices?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy child,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the old lady sharply, \xe2\x80\x9clet us hear none of the\r\nconventional objections that deter weak minds from preparing for the\r\nfuture. I also was married at the death-bed of my mother, and certainly\r\nI have not been less happy on that account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill that idea of death, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill?\xe2\x80\x94Always! I tell you I am going to die\xe2\x80\x94do you understand? Well,\r\nbefore dying, I wish to see my son-in-law. I wish to tell him to make\r\nmy child happy; I wish to read in his eyes whether he intends to obey\r\nme;\xe2\x80\x94in fact, I will know him\xe2\x80\x94I will!\xe2\x80\x9d continued the old lady, with a\r\nfearful expression, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I may rise from the depths of my grave to\r\nfind him, if he should not fulfil his duty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must lay aside these exalted ideas,\r\nwhich almost assume the appearance of madness. The dead, once buried in\r\ntheir graves, rise no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I tell you, sir, that you are mistaken. This night I have had a\r\nfearful sleep. It seemed as though my soul were already hovering over\r\nmy body, my eyes, which I tried to open, closed against my will, and\r\nwhat will appear impossible above all to you, sir, I saw, with my eyes\r\nshut, in the spot where you are now standing, issuing from that corner\r\nwhere there is a door leading into Madame Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s dressing-room\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nsaw, I tell you, silently enter, a white figure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine screamed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was the fever that disturbed you, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\n30321m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubt, if you please, but I am sure of what I say. I saw a white\r\nfigure, and as if to prevent my discrediting the testimony of only one\r\nof my senses, I heard my glass removed\xe2\x80\x94the same which is there now on\r\nthe table.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear mother, it was a dream.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo little was it a dream, that I stretched my hand towards the bell;\r\nbut when I did so, the shade disappeared; my maid then entered with a\r\nlight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut she saw no one?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPhantoms are visible to those only who ought to see them. It was the\r\nsoul of my husband!\xe2\x80\x94Well, if my husband\xe2\x80\x99s soul can come to me, why\r\nshould not my soul reappear to guard my granddaughter? the tie is even\r\nmore direct, it seems to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, deeply affected, in spite of himself, \xe2\x80\x9cdo\r\nnot yield to those gloomy thoughts; you will long live with us, happy,\r\nloved, and honored, and we will make you forget\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever, never, never,\xe2\x80\x9d said the marchioness. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen does M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay\r\nreturn?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe expect him every moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well. As soon as he arrives inform me. We must be expeditious.\r\nAnd then I also wish to see a notary, that I may be assured that all\r\nour property returns to Valentine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, grandmamma,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Valentine, pressing her lips on the burning\r\nbrow, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you wish to kill me? Oh, how feverish you are; we must not\r\nsend for a notary, but for a doctor!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA doctor?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, shrugging her shoulders, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not ill; I am\r\nthirsty\xe2\x80\x94that is all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30323m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you drinking, dear grandmamma?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same as usual, my dear, my glass is there on the table\xe2\x80\x94give it to\r\nme, Valentine.\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine poured the orangeade into a glass and gave it\r\nto her grandmother with a certain degree of dread, for it was the same\r\nglass she fancied that had been touched by the spectre.\r\n\r\nThe marchioness drained the glass at a single draught, and then turned\r\non her pillow, repeating,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe notary, the notary!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort left the room, and Valentine seated herself at the\r\nbedside of her grandmother. The poor child appeared herself to require\r\nthe doctor she had recommended to her aged relative. A bright spot\r\nburned in either cheek, her respiration was short and difficult, and\r\nher pulse beat with feverish excitement. She was thinking of the\r\ndespair of Maximilian, when he should be informed that Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran, instead of being an ally, was unconsciously acting as his\r\nenemy.\r\n\r\nMore than once she thought of revealing all to her grandmother, and she\r\nwould not have hesitated a moment, if Maximilian Morrel had been named\r\nAlbert de Morcerf or Raoul de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; but Morrel was of\r\nplebeian extraction, and Valentine knew how the haughty Marquise de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran despised all who were not noble. Her secret had each time\r\nbeen repressed when she was about to reveal it, by the sad conviction\r\nthat it would be useless to do so; for, were it once discovered by her\r\nfather and mother, all would be lost.\r\n\r\nTwo hours passed thus; Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran was in a feverish sleep,\r\nand the notary had arrived. Though his coming was announced in a very\r\nlow tone, Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran arose from her pillow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe notary!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9clet him come in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe notary, who was at the door, immediately entered. \xe2\x80\x9cGo, Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, \xe2\x80\x9cand leave me with this gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, grandmamma\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave me\xe2\x80\x94go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young girl kissed her grandmother, and left with her handkerchief\r\nto her eyes; at the door she found the valet de chambre, who told her\r\nthat the doctor was waiting in the dining-room. Valentine instantly ran\r\ndown. The doctor was a friend of the family, and at the same time one\r\nof the cleverest men of the day, and very fond of Valentine, whose\r\nbirth he had witnessed. He had himself a daughter about her age, but\r\nwhose life was one continued source of anxiety and fear to him from her\r\nmother having been consumptive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have been waiting for you with such\r\nimpatience, dear M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny. But, first of all, how are Madeleine and\r\nAntoinette?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadeleine was the daughter of M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, and Antoinette his niece.\r\nM. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny smiled sadly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAntoinette is very well,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand Madeleine tolerably so. But\r\nyou sent for me, my dear child. It is not your father or Madame de\r\nVillefort who is ill. As for you, although we doctors cannot divest our\r\npatients of nerves, I fancy you have no further need of me than to\r\nrecommend you not to allow your imagination to take too wide a field.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine colored. M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny carried the science of divination\r\nalmost to a miraculous extent, for he was one of the physicians who\r\nalways work upon the body through the mind.\r\n\r\n30325m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied, \xe2\x80\x9cit is for my poor grandmother. You know the\r\ncalamity that has happened to us, do you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d said M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, restraining her tears, \xe2\x80\x9cmy grandfather is\r\ndead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuddenly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom an apoplectic stroke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn apoplectic stroke?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the doctor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and my poor grandmother fancies that her husband, whom she never\r\nleft, has called her, and that she must go and join him. Oh, M.\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, I beseech you, do something for her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn her room with the notary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd M. Noirtier?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust as he was, his mind perfectly clear, but the same incapability of\r\nmoving or speaking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the same love for you\xe2\x80\x94eh, my dear child?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9che was very fond of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho does not love you?\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine smiled sadly. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are your\r\ngrandmother\xe2\x80\x99s symptoms?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn extreme nervous excitement and a strangely agitated sleep; she\r\nfancied this morning in her sleep that her soul was hovering above her\r\nbody, which she at the same time watched. It must have been delirium;\r\nshe fancies, too, that she saw a phantom enter her chamber and even\r\nheard the noise it made on touching her glass.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is singular,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor; \xe2\x80\x9cI was not aware that Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran was subject to such hallucinations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the first time I ever saw her in this condition,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nValentine; \xe2\x80\x9cand this morning she frightened me so that I thought her\r\nmad; and my father, who you know is a strong-minded man, himself\r\nappeared deeply impressed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will go and see,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat you tell me seems very\r\nstrange.\xe2\x80\x9d The notary here descended, and Valentine was informed that\r\nher grandmother was alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo upstairs,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to the doctor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I dare not\xe2\x80\x94she forbade my sending for you; and, as you say, I am\r\nmyself agitated, feverish and out of sorts. I will go and take a turn\r\nin the garden to recover myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe doctor pressed Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and while he visited her\r\ngrandmother, she descended the steps. We need not say which portion of\r\nthe garden was her favorite walk. After remaining for a short time in\r\nthe parterre surrounding the house, and gathering a rose to place in\r\nher waist or hair, she turned into the dark avenue which led to the\r\nbench; then from the bench she went to the gate. As usual, Valentine\r\nstrolled for a short time among her flowers, but without gathering\r\nthem. The mourning in her heart forbade her assuming this simple\r\nornament, though she had not yet had time to put on the outward\r\nsemblance of woe.\r\n\r\n30327m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nShe then turned towards the avenue. As she advanced she fancied she\r\nheard a voice speaking her name. She stopped astonished, then the voice\r\nreached her ear more distinctly, and she recognized it to be that of\r\nMaximilian.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 73. The Promise\r\n\r\nIt was indeed Maximilian Morrel, who had passed a wretched existence\r\nsince the previous day. With the instinct peculiar to lovers he had\r\nanticipated after the return of Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran and the death of\r\nthe marquis, that something would occur at M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s in\r\nconnection with his attachment for Valentine. His presentiments were\r\nrealized, as we shall see, and his uneasy forebodings had goaded him\r\npale and trembling to the gate under the chestnut-trees.\r\n\r\nValentine was ignorant of the cause of this sorrow and anxiety, and as\r\nit was not his accustomed hour for visiting her, she had gone to the\r\nspot simply by accident or perhaps through sympathy. Morrel called her,\r\nand she ran to the gate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou here at this hour?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my poor girl,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cI come to bring and to hear bad\r\ntidings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is, indeed, a house of mourning,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cspeak,\r\nMaximilian, although the cup of sorrow seems already full.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, endeavoring to conceal his own emotion,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clisten, I entreat you; what I am about to say is very serious. When\r\nare you to be married?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cfrom you I have nothing to\r\nconceal. This morning the subject was introduced, and my dear\r\ngrandmother, on whom I depended as my only support, not only declared\r\nherself favorable to it, but is so anxious for it, that they only await\r\nthe arrival of M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, and the following day the contract will be\r\nsigned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA deep sigh escaped the young man, who gazed long and mournfully at her\r\nhe loved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, \xe2\x80\x9cit is dreadful thus to hear my condemnation from\r\nyour own lips. The sentence is passed, and, in a few hours, will be\r\nexecuted; it must be so, and I will not endeavor to prevent it. But,\r\nsince you say nothing remains but for M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay to arrive that the\r\ncontract may be signed, and the following day you will be his, tomorrow\r\nyou will be engaged to M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, for he came this morning to Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nValentine uttered a cry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was at the house of Monte Cristo an hour since,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cwe\r\nwere speaking, he of the sorrow your family had experienced, and I of\r\nyour grief, when a carriage rolled into the courtyard. Never, till\r\nthen, had I placed any confidence in presentiments, but now I cannot\r\nhelp believing them, Valentine. At the sound of that carriage I\r\nshuddered; soon I heard steps on the staircase, which terrified me as\r\nmuch as the footsteps of the commander did Don Juan. The door at last\r\nopened; Albert de Morcerf entered first, and I began to hope my fears\r\nwere vain, when, after him, another young man advanced, and the count\r\nexclaimed: \xe2\x80\x98Ah, here is the Baron Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay!\xe2\x80\x99 I summoned all my\r\nstrength and courage to my support. Perhaps I turned pale and trembled,\r\nbut certainly I smiled; and five minutes after I left, without having\r\nheard one word that had passed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Maximilian!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine, the time has arrived when you must answer me. And remember\r\nmy life depends on your answer. What do you intend doing?\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine\r\nheld down her head; she was overwhelmed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cit is not the first time you have contemplated\r\nour present position, which is a serious and urgent one; I do not think\r\nit is a moment to give way to useless sorrow; leave that for those who\r\nlike to suffer at their leisure and indulge their grief in secret.\r\nThere are such in the world, and God will doubtless reward them in\r\nheaven for their resignation on earth, but those who mean to contend\r\nmust not lose one precious moment, but must return immediately the blow\r\nwhich fortune strikes. Do you intend to struggle against our\r\nill-fortune? Tell me, Valentine for it is that I came to know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine trembled, and looked at him with amazement. The idea of\r\nresisting her father, her grandmother, and all the family, had never\r\noccurred to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you say, Maximilian?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Valentine. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean by a\r\nstruggle? Oh, it would be a sacrilege. What? I resist my father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\norder, and my dying grandmother\xe2\x80\x99s wish? Impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel started.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are too noble not to understand me, and you understand me so well\r\nthat you already yield, dear Maximilian. No, no; I shall need all my\r\nstrength to struggle with myself and support my grief in secret, as you\r\nsay. But to grieve my father\xe2\x80\x94to disturb my grandmother\xe2\x80\x99s last\r\nmoments\xe2\x80\x94never!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, calmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what a tone you speak!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI speak as one who admires you, mademoiselle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cmademoiselle! Oh, selfish man! he\r\nsees me in despair, and pretends he cannot understand me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mistake\xe2\x80\x94I understand you perfectly. You will not oppose M.\r\nVillefort, you will not displease the marchioness, and tomorrow you\r\nwill sign the contract which will bind you to your husband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, _mon Dieu!_ tell me, how can I do otherwise?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not appeal to me, mademoiselle; I shall be a bad judge in such a\r\ncase; my selfishness will blind me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel, whose low voice\r\nand clenched hands announced his growing desperation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have proposed, Maximilian, had you found me willing to\r\naccede?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not for me to say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are wrong; you must advise me what to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you seriously ask my advice, Valentine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, dear Maximilian, for if it is good, I will follow it; you\r\nknow my devotion to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel pushing aside a loose plank, \xe2\x80\x9cgive me your\r\nhand in token of forgiveness of my anger; my senses are confused, and\r\nduring the last hour the most extravagant thoughts have passed through\r\nmy brain. Oh, if you refuse my advice\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you advise?\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, raising her eyes to heaven and\r\nsighing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am free,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cand rich enough to support you. I\r\nswear to make you my lawful wife before my lips even shall have\r\napproached your forehead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou make me tremble!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFollow me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cI will take you to my sister, who is worthy\r\nalso to be yours. We will embark for Algiers, for England, for America,\r\nor, if you prefer it, retire to the country and only return to Paris\r\nwhen our friends have reconciled your family.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine shook her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feared it, Maximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cit is the counsel of a madman,\r\nand I should be more mad than you, did I not stop you at once with the\r\nword \xe2\x80\x98Impossible, Morrel, impossible!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will then submit to what fate decrees for you without even\r\nattempting to contend with it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel sorrowfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x94if I die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cI can only say again that you\r\nare right. Truly, it is I who am mad, and you prove to me that passion\r\nblinds the most well-meaning. I appreciate your calm reasoning. It is\r\nthen understood that tomorrow you will be irrevocably promised to M.\r\nFranz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, not only by that theatrical formality invented to\r\nheighten the effect of a comedy called the signature of the contract,\r\nbut your own will?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgain you drive me to despair, Maximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cagain you\r\nplunge the dagger into the wound! What would you do, tell me, if your\r\nsister listened to such a proposition?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel with a bitter smile, \xe2\x80\x9cI am selfish\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nhave already said so\xe2\x80\x94and as a selfish man I think not of what others\r\nwould do in my situation, but of what I intend doing myself. I think\r\nonly that I have known you not a whole year. From the day I first saw\r\nyou, all my hopes of happiness have been in securing your affection.\r\nOne day you acknowledged that you loved me, and since that day my hope\r\nof future happiness has rested on obtaining you, for to gain you would\r\nbe life to me. Now, I think no more; I say only that fortune has turned\r\nagainst me\xe2\x80\x94I had thought to gain heaven, and now I have lost it. It is\r\nan every-day occurrence for a gambler to lose not only what he\r\npossesses but also what he has not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel pronounced these words with perfect calmness; Valentine looked\r\nat him a moment with her large, scrutinizing eyes, endeavoring not to\r\nlet Morrel discover the grief which struggled in her heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, in a word, what are you going to do?\xe2\x80\x9d asked she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going to have the honor of taking my leave of you, mademoiselle,\r\nsolemnly assuring you that I wish your life may be so calm, so happy,\r\nand so fully occupied, that there may be no place for me even in your\r\nmemory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, Valentine, adieu!\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, bowing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the young girl, extending her hand through\r\nthe opening, and seizing Maximilian by his coat, for she understood\r\nfrom her own agitated feelings that her lover\xe2\x80\x99s calmness could not be\r\nreal; \xe2\x80\x9cwhere are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going, that I may not bring fresh trouble into your family: and\r\nto set an example which every honest and devoted man, situated as I am,\r\nmay follow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBefore you leave me, tell me what you are going to do, Maximilian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThe young man smiled sorrowfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, speak!\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cI entreat you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas your resolution changed, Valentine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt cannot change, unhappy man; you know it must not!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the young\r\ngirl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen adieu, Valentine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine shook the gate with a strength of which she could not have\r\nbeen supposed to be possessed, as Morrel was going away, and passing\r\nboth her hands through the opening, she clasped and wrung them. \xe2\x80\x9cI must\r\nknow what you mean to do!\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, fear not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, stopping at a short distance, \xe2\x80\x9cI do\r\nnot intend to render another man responsible for the rigorous fate\r\nreserved for me. Another might threaten to seek M. Franz, to provoke\r\nhim, and to fight with him; all that would be folly. What has M. Franz\r\nto do with it? He saw me this morning for the first time, and has\r\nalready forgotten he has seen me. He did not even know I existed when\r\nit was arranged by your two families that you should be united. I have\r\nno enmity against M. Franz, and promise you the punishment shall not\r\nfall on him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn whom, then!\xe2\x80\x94on me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn you? Valentine! Oh, Heaven forbid! Woman is sacred; the woman one\r\nloves is holy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn yourself, then, unhappy man; on yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am the only guilty person, am I not?\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian!\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian, come back, I entreat you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe drew near with his sweet smile, and but for his paleness one might\r\nhave thought him in his usual happy mood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, my dear, my adored Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said he in his melodious and\r\ngrave tone; \xe2\x80\x9cthose who, like us, have never had a thought for which we\r\nneed blush before the world, such may read each other\xe2\x80\x99s hearts. I never\r\nwas romantic, and am no melancholy hero. I imitate neither Manfred nor\r\nAnthony; but without words, protestations, or vows, my life has\r\nentwined itself with yours; you leave me, and you are right in doing\r\nso,\xe2\x80\x94I repeat it, you are right; but in losing you, I lose my life. The\r\nmoment you leave me, Valentine, I am alone in the world. My sister is\r\nhappily married; her husband is only my brother-in-law, that is, a man\r\nwhom the ties of social life alone attach to me; no one then longer\r\nneeds my useless life. This is what I shall do; I will wait until the\r\nvery moment you are married, for I will not lose the shadow of one of\r\nthose unexpected chances which are sometimes reserved for us, since M.\r\nFranz may, after all, die before that time, a thunderbolt may fall even\r\non the altar as you approach it,\xe2\x80\x94nothing appears impossible to one\r\ncondemned to die, and miracles appear quite reasonable when his escape\r\nfrom death is concerned. I will, then, wait until the last moment, and\r\nwhen my misery is certain, irremediable, hopeless, I will write a\r\nconfidential letter to my brother-in-law, another to the prefect of\r\npolice, to acquaint them with my intention, and at the corner of some\r\nwood, on the brink of some abyss, on the bank of some river, I will put\r\nan end to my existence, as certainly as I am the son of the most honest\r\nman who ever lived in France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30333m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nValentine trembled convulsively; she loosened her hold of the gate, her\r\narms fell by her side, and two large tears rolled down her cheeks. The\r\nyoung man stood before her, sorrowful and resolute.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, for pity\xe2\x80\x99s sake,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will live, will you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, on my honor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian; \xe2\x80\x9cbut that will not affect you. You\r\nhave done your duty, and your conscience will be at rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine fell on her knees, and pressed her almost bursting heart.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian, my friend, my brother on earth, my\r\ntrue husband in heaven, I entreat you, do as I do, live in suffering;\r\nperhaps we may one day be united.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, raising both her hands to heaven with a\r\nsublime expression, \xe2\x80\x9cI have done my utmost to remain a submissive\r\ndaughter; I have begged, entreated, implored; he has regarded neither\r\nmy prayers, my entreaties, nor my tears. It is done,\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, wiping\r\naway her tears, and resuming her firmness, \xe2\x80\x9cI am resolved not to die of\r\nremorse, but rather of shame. Live, Maximilian, and I will be yours.\r\nSay when shall it be? Speak, command, I will obey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel, who had already gone some few steps away, again returned, and\r\npale with joy extended both hands towards Valentine through the\r\nopening.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cdear Valentine, you must not speak thus\xe2\x80\x94rather\r\nlet me die. Why should I obtain you by violence, if our love is mutual?\r\nIs it from mere humanity you bid me live? I would then rather die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cwho on this earth cares for me, if he\r\ndoes not? Who has consoled me in my sorrow but he? On whom do my hopes\r\nrest? On whom does my bleeding heart repose? On him, on him, always on\r\nhim! Yes, you are right, Maximilian, I will follow you. I will leave\r\nthe paternal home, I will give up all. Oh, ungrateful girl that I am,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncried Valentine, sobbing, \xe2\x80\x9cI will give up all, even my dear old\r\ngrandfather, whom I had nearly forgotten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall not leave him. M. Noirtier has\r\nevinced, you say, a kind feeling towards me. Well, before you leave,\r\ntell him all; his consent would be your justification in God\xe2\x80\x99s sight.\r\nAs soon as we are married, he shall come and live with us, instead of\r\none child, he shall have two. You have told me how you talk to him and\r\nhow he answers you; I shall very soon learn that language by signs,\r\nValentine, and I promise you solemnly, that instead of despair, it is\r\nhappiness that awaits us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, see, Maximilian, see the power you have over me, you almost make\r\nme believe you; and yet, what you tell me is madness, for my father\r\nwill curse me\xe2\x80\x94he is inflexible\xe2\x80\x94he will never pardon me. Now listen to\r\nme, Maximilian; if by artifice, by entreaty, by accident\xe2\x80\x94in short, if\r\nby any means I can delay this marriage, will you wait?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I promise you, as faithfully as you have promised me that this\r\nhorrible marriage shall not take place, and that if you are dragged\r\nbefore a magistrate or a priest, you will refuse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promise you by all that is most sacred to me in the world, namely,\r\nby my mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will wait, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we will wait,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Valentine, who revived at these words;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthere are so many things which may save unhappy beings such as we\r\nare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI rely on you, Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9call you do will be well done;\r\nonly if they disregard your prayers, if your father and Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran insist that M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay should be called tomorrow to sign\r\nthe contract\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have my promise, Maximilian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInstead of signing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go to you, and we will fly; but from this moment until then,\r\nlet us not tempt Providence, let us not see each other. It is a\r\nmiracle, it is a providence that we have not been discovered. If we\r\nwere surprised, if it were known that we met thus, we should have no\r\nfurther resource.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, Valentine; but how shall I ascertain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the notary, M. Deschamps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd for myself\xe2\x80\x94I will write to you, depend on me. I dread this\r\nmarriage, Maximilian, as much as you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, my adored Valentine, thank you; that is enough. When once I\r\nknow the hour, I will hasten to this spot, you can easily get over this\r\nfence with my assistance, a carriage will await us at the gate, in\r\nwhich you will accompany me to my sister\xe2\x80\x99s; there living, retired or\r\nmingling in society, as you wish, we shall be enabled to use our power\r\nto resist oppression, and not suffer ourselves to be put to death like\r\nsheep, which only defend themselves by sighs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cI will now acknowledge you are right,\r\nMaximilian; and now are you satisfied with your betrothal?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nyoung girl sorrowfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy adored Valentine, words cannot express one half of my\r\nsatisfaction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine had approached, or rather, had placed her lips so near the\r\nfence, that they nearly touched those of Morrel, which were pressed\r\nagainst the other side of the cold and inexorable barrier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, then, till we meet again,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, tearing herself\r\naway. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall hear from you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, thanks, dear love, adieu!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sound of a kiss was heard, and Valentine fled through the avenue.\r\nMorrel listened to catch the last sound of her dress brushing the\r\nbranches, and of her footstep on the gravel, then raised his eyes with\r\nan ineffable smile of thankfulness to heaven for being permitted to be\r\nthus loved, and then also disappeared.\r\n\r\nThe young man returned home and waited all the evening and all the next\r\nday without getting any message. It was only on the following day, at\r\nabout ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, as he was starting to call on M.\r\nDeschamps, the notary, that he received from the postman a small\r\nbillet, which he knew to be from Valentine, although he had not before\r\nseen her writing. It was to this effect:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTears, entreaties, prayers, have availed me nothing. Yesterday, for\r\ntwo hours, I was at the church of Saint-Philippe-du-Roule, and for two\r\nhours I prayed most fervently. Heaven is as inflexible as man, and the\r\nsignature of the contract is fixed for this evening at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock. I\r\nhave but one promise and but one heart to give; that promise is pledged\r\nto you, that heart is also yours. This evening, then, at a quarter to\r\nnine at the gate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour betrothed,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cP.S.\xe2\x80\x94My poor grandmother gets worse and worse; yesterday her fever\r\namounted to delirium; today her delirium is almost madness. You will be\r\nvery kind to me, will you not, Morrel, to make me forget my sorrow in\r\nleaving her thus? I think it is kept a secret from grandpapa Noirtier,\r\nthat the contract is to be signed this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel went also to the notary, who confirmed the news that the\r\ncontract was to be signed that evening. Then he went to call on Monte\r\nCristo and heard still more. Franz had been to announce the ceremony,\r\nand Madame de Villefort had also written to beg the count to excuse her\r\nnot inviting him; the death of M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran and the dangerous\r\nillness of his widow would cast a gloom over the meeting which she\r\nwould regret should be shared by the count whom she wished every\r\nhappiness.\r\n\r\nThe day before Franz had been presented to Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, who\r\nhad left her bed to receive him, but had been obliged to return to it\r\nimmediately after.\r\n\r\nIt is easy to suppose that Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s agitation would not escape the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s penetrating eye. Monte Cristo was more affectionate than\r\never,\xe2\x80\x94indeed, his manner was so kind that several times Morrel was on\r\nthe point of telling him all. But he recalled the promise he had made\r\nto Valentine, and kept his secret.\r\n\r\nThe young man read Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s letter twenty times in the course of the\r\nday. It was her first, and on what an occasion! Each time he read it he\r\nrenewed his vow to make her happy. How great is the power of a woman\r\nwho has made so courageous a resolution! What devotion does she deserve\r\nfrom him for whom she has sacrificed everything! How ought she really\r\nto be supremely loved! She becomes at once a queen and a wife, and it\r\nis impossible to thank and love her sufficiently.\r\n\r\nMorrel longed intensely for the moment when he should hear Valentine\r\nsay, \xe2\x80\x9cHere I am, Maximilian; come and help me.\xe2\x80\x9d He had arranged\r\neverything for her escape; two ladders were hidden in the clover-field;\r\na cabriolet was ordered for Maximilian alone, without a servant,\r\nwithout lights; at the turning of the first street they would light the\r\nlamps, as it would be foolish to attract the notice of the police by\r\ntoo many precautions. Occasionally he shuddered; he thought of the\r\nmoment when, from the top of that wall, he should protect the descent\r\nof his dear Valentine, pressing in his arms for the first time her of\r\nwhom he had yet only kissed the delicate hand.\r\n\r\nWhen the afternoon arrived and he felt that the hour was drawing near,\r\nhe wished for solitude, his agitation was extreme; a simple question\r\nfrom a friend would have irritated him. He shut himself in his room,\r\nand tried to read, but his eye glanced over the page without\r\nunderstanding a word, and he threw away the book, and for the second\r\ntime sat down to sketch his plan, the ladders and the fence.\r\n\r\nAt length the hour drew near. Never did a man deeply in love allow the\r\nclocks to go on peacefully. Morrel tormented his so effectually that\r\nthey struck eight at half-past six. He then said, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is time to start;\r\nthe signature was indeed fixed to take place at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock, but\r\nperhaps Valentine will not wait for that.\xe2\x80\x9d Consequently, Morrel, having\r\nleft the Rue Meslay at half-past eight by his timepiece, entered the\r\nclover-field while the clock of Saint-Philippe-du-Roule was striking\r\neight. The horse and cabriolet were concealed behind a small ruin,\r\nwhere Morrel had often waited.\r\n\r\nThe night gradually drew on, and the foliage in the garden assumed a\r\ndeeper hue. Then Morrel came out from his hiding-place with a beating\r\nheart, and looked through the small opening in the gate; there was yet\r\nno one to be seen.\r\n\r\nThe clock struck half-past eight, and still another half-hour was\r\npassed in waiting, while Morrel walked to and fro, and gazed more and\r\nmore frequently through the opening. The garden became darker still,\r\nbut in the darkness he looked in vain for the white dress, and in the\r\nsilence he vainly listened for the sound of footsteps. The house, which\r\nwas discernible through the trees, remained in darkness, and gave no\r\nindication that so important an event as the signature of a\r\nmarriage-contract was going on. Morrel looked at his watch, which\r\nwanted a quarter to ten; but soon the same clock he had already heard\r\nstrike two or three times rectified the error by striking half-past\r\nnine.\r\n\r\nThis was already half an hour past the time Valentine had fixed. It was\r\na terrible moment for the young man. The slightest rustling of the\r\nfoliage, the least whistling of the wind, attracted his attention, and\r\ndrew the perspiration to his brow; then he tremblingly fixed his\r\nladder, and, not to lose a moment, placed his foot on the first step.\r\nAmidst all these alternations of hope and fear, the clock struck ten.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the signing of a contract\r\nshould occupy so long a time without unexpected interruptions. I have\r\nweighed all the chances, calculated the time required for all the\r\nforms; something must have happened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd then he walked rapidly to and fro, and pressed his burning forehead\r\nagainst the fence. Had Valentine fainted? or had she been discovered\r\nand stopped in her flight? These were the only obstacles which appeared\r\npossible to the young man.\r\n\r\nThe idea that her strength had failed her in attempting to escape, and\r\nthat she had fainted in one of the paths, was the one that most\r\nimpressed itself upon his mind. \xe2\x80\x9cIn that case,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI should lose\r\nher, and by my own fault.\xe2\x80\x9d He dwelt on this idea for a moment, then it\r\nappeared reality. He even thought he could perceive something on the\r\nground at a distance; he ventured to call, and it seemed to him that\r\nthe wind wafted back an almost inarticulate sigh.\r\n\r\nAt last the half-hour struck. It was impossible to wait longer, his\r\ntemples throbbed violently, his eyes were growing dim; he passed one\r\nleg over the wall, and in a moment leaped down on the other side. He\r\nwas on Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s premises\xe2\x80\x94had arrived there by scaling the wall. What\r\nmight be the consequences? However, he had not ventured thus far to\r\ndraw back. He followed a short distance close under the wall, then\r\ncrossed a path, hid entered a clump of trees. In a moment he had passed\r\nthrough them, and could see the house distinctly.\r\n\r\n30341m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThen Morrel saw that he had been right in believing that the house was\r\nnot illuminated. Instead of lights at every window, as is customary on\r\ndays of ceremony, he saw only a gray mass, which was veiled also by a\r\ncloud, which at that moment obscured the moon\xe2\x80\x99s feeble light. A light\r\nmoved rapidly from time to time past three windows of the second floor.\r\nThese three windows were in Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s room. Another\r\nremained motionless behind some red curtains which were in Madame de\r\nVillefort\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom. Morrel guessed all this. So many times, in order\r\nto follow Valentine in thought at every hour in the day, had he made\r\nher describe the whole house, that without having seen it he knew it\r\nall.\r\n\r\nThis darkness and silence alarmed Morrel still more than Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nabsence had done. Almost mad with grief, and determined to venture\r\neverything in order to see Valentine once more, and be certain of the\r\nmisfortune he feared, Morrel gained the edge of the clump of trees, and\r\nwas going to pass as quickly as possible through the flower-garden,\r\nwhen the sound of a voice, still at some distance, but which was borne\r\nupon the wind, reached him. At this sound, as he was already partially\r\nexposed to view, he stepped back and concealed himself completely,\r\nremaining perfectly motionless.\r\n\r\nHe had formed his resolution. If it was Valentine alone, he would speak\r\nas she passed; if she was accompanied, and he could not speak, still he\r\nshould see her, and know that she was safe; if they were strangers, he\r\nwould listen to their conversation, and might understand something of\r\nthis hitherto incomprehensible mystery.\r\n\r\nThe moon had just then escaped from behind the cloud which had\r\nconcealed it, and Morrel saw Villefort come out upon the steps,\r\nfollowed by a gentleman in black. They descended, and advanced towards\r\nthe clump of trees, and Morrel soon recognized the other gentleman as\r\nDoctor d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny.\r\n\r\n30339m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe young man, seeing them approach, drew back mechanically, until he\r\nfound himself stopped by a sycamore-tree in the centre of the clump;\r\nthere he was compelled to remain. Soon the two gentlemen stopped also.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear doctor,\xe2\x80\x9d said the procureur, \xe2\x80\x9cHeaven declares itself\r\nagainst my house! What a dreadful death\xe2\x80\x94what a blow! Seek not to\r\nconsole me; alas, nothing can alleviate so great a sorrow\xe2\x80\x94the wound is\r\ntoo deep and too fresh! Dead, dead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cold sweat sprang to the young man\xe2\x80\x99s brow, and his teeth chattered.\r\nWho could be dead in that house, which Villefort himself had called\r\naccursed?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear M. de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the doctor, with a tone which\r\nredoubled the terror of the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cI have not led you here to\r\nconsole you; on the contrary\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the procureur, alarmed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean that behind the misfortune which has just happened to you,\r\nthere is another, perhaps, still greater.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan it be possible?\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Villefort, clasping his hands. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are\r\nyou going to tell me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre we quite alone, my friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, quite; but why all these precautions?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I have a terrible secret to communicate to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ndoctor. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us sit down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort fell, rather than seated himself. The doctor stood before\r\nhim, with one hand placed on his shoulder. Morrel, horrified, supported\r\nhis head with one hand, and with the other pressed his heart, lest its\r\nbeatings should be heard. \xe2\x80\x9cDead, dead!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated he within himself; and\r\nhe felt as if he were also dying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, doctor\xe2\x80\x94I am listening,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cstrike\xe2\x80\x94I am prepared\r\nfor everything!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran was, doubtless, advancing in years, but she\r\nenjoyed excellent health.\xe2\x80\x9d Morrel began again to breathe freely, which\r\nhe had not done during the last ten minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrief has consumed her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyes, grief, doctor! After\r\nliving forty years with the marquis\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not grief, my dear Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor; \xe2\x80\x9cgrief may kill,\r\nalthough it rarely does, and never in a day, never in an hour, never in\r\nten minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d Villefort answered nothing, he simply raised his head,\r\nwhich had been cast down before, and looked at the doctor with\r\namazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you present during the last struggle?\xe2\x80\x9d asked M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the procureur; \xe2\x80\x9cyou begged me not to leave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you notice the symptoms of the disease to which Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran has fallen a victim?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did. Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran had three successive attacks, at\r\nintervals of some minutes, each one more serious than the former. When\r\nyou arrived, Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran had already been panting for breath\r\nsome minutes; she then had a fit, which I took to be simply a nervous\r\nattack, and it was only when I saw her raise herself in the bed, and\r\nher limbs and neck appear stiffened, that I became really alarmed. Then\r\nI understood from your countenance there was more to fear than I had\r\nthought. This crisis past, I endeavored to catch your eye, but could\r\nnot. You held her hand\xe2\x80\x94you were feeling her pulse\xe2\x80\x94and the second fit\r\ncame on before you had turned towards me. This was more terrible than\r\nthe first; the same nervous movements were repeated, and the mouth\r\ncontracted and turned purple.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd at the third she expired.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the end of the first attack I discovered symptoms of tetanus; you\r\nconfirmed my opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, before others,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the doctor; \xe2\x80\x9cbut now we are alone\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you going to say? Oh, spare me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat the symptoms of tetanus and poisoning by vegetable substances are\r\nthe same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort started from his seat, then in a moment fell down\r\nagain, silent and motionless. Morrel knew not if he were dreaming or\r\nawake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor; \xe2\x80\x9cI know the full importance of the statement\r\nI have just made, and the disposition of the man to whom I have made\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you speak to me as a magistrate or as a friend?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs a friend, and only as a friend, at this moment. The similarity in\r\nthe symptoms of tetanus and poisoning by vegetable substances is so\r\ngreat, that were I obliged to affirm by oath what I have now stated, I\r\nshould hesitate; I therefore repeat to you, I speak not to a\r\nmagistrate, but to a friend. And to that friend I say, \xe2\x80\x98During the\r\nthree-quarters of an hour that the struggle continued, I watched the\r\nconvulsions and the death of Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, and am thoroughly\r\nconvinced that not only did her death proceed from poison, but I could\r\nalso specify the poison.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan it be possible?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe symptoms are marked, do you see?\xe2\x80\x94sleep broken by nervous spasms,\r\nexcitation of the brain, torpor of the nerve centres. Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran succumbed to a powerful dose of brucine or of strychnine,\r\nwhich by some mistake, perhaps, has been given to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort seized the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI must be dreaming! It is frightful\r\nto hear such things from such a man as you! Tell me, I entreat you, my\r\ndear doctor, that you may be deceived.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless I may, but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n30345m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I do not think so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave pity on me doctor! So many dreadful things have happened to me\r\nlately that I am on the verge of madness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas anyone besides me seen Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas anything been sent for from a chemist\xe2\x80\x99s that I have not examined?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran any enemies?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot to my knowledge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould her death affect anyone\xe2\x80\x99s interest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt could not indeed, my daughter is her only heiress\xe2\x80\x94Valentine alone.\r\nOh, if such a thought could present itself, I would stab myself to\r\npunish my heart for having for one instant harbored it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, my dear friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, \xe2\x80\x9cI would not accuse\r\nanyone; I speak only of an accident, you understand,\xe2\x80\x94of a mistake,\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nwhether accident or mistake, the fact is there; it is on my conscience\r\nand compels me to speak aloud to you.
