Noirtier poison Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing is more simple. You know poisons become remedies in certain\r\ndiseases, of which paralysis is one. For instance, having tried every\r\nother remedy to restore movement and speech to M. Noirtier, I resolved\r\nto try one last means, and for three months I have been giving him\r\nbrucine; so that in the last dose I ordered for him there were six\r\ngrains. This quantity, which is perfectly safe to administer to the\r\nparalyzed frame of M. Noirtier, which has become gradually accustomed\r\nto it, would be sufficient to kill another person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear doctor, there is no communication between M. In short, doctor although I know you to be the\r\nmost conscientious man in the world, and although I place the utmost\r\nreliance in you, I want, notwithstanding my conviction, to believe this\r\naxiom, _errare humanum est_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there one of my brethren in whom you have equal confidence with\r\nmyself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you ask me that?\xe2\x80\x94what do you wish?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSend for him; I will tell him what I have seen, and we will consult\r\ntogether, and examine the body.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will find traces of poison?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I did not say of poison, but we can prove what was the state of\r\nthe body; we shall discover the cause of her sudden death, and we shall\r\nsay, \xe2\x80\x98Dear Villefort, if this thing has been caused by negligence,\r\nwatch over your servants; if from hatred, watch your enemies.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you propose to me, d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny?\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort in despair; \xe2\x80\x9cso\r\nsoon as another is admitted into our secret, an inquest will become\r\nnecessary; and an inquest in my house\xe2\x80\x94impossible! Still,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the\r\nprocureur, looking at the doctor with uneasiness, \xe2\x80\x9cif you wish it\xe2\x80\x94if\r\nyou demand it, why then it shall be done. But, doctor, you see me\r\nalready so grieved\xe2\x80\x94how can I introduce into my house so much scandal,\r\nafter so much sorrow? My wife and my daughter would die of it! And I,\r\ndoctor\xe2\x80\x94you know a man does not arrive at the post I occupy\xe2\x80\x94one has not\r\nbeen king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney twenty-five years without having amassed a\r\ntolerable number of enemies; mine are numerous. Let this affair be\r\ntalked of, it will be a triumph for them, which will make them rejoice,\r\nand cover me with shame. Pardon me, doctor, these worldly ideas; were\r\nyou a priest I should not dare tell you that, but you are a man, and\r\nyou know mankind. Doctor, pray recall your words; you have said\r\nnothing, have you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear M. de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the doctor, \xe2\x80\x9cmy first duty is to\r\nhumanity. I would have saved Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, if science could\r\nhave done it; but she is dead and my duty regards the living. Let us\r\nbury this terrible secret in the deepest recesses of our hearts; I am\r\nwilling, if anyone should suspect this, that my silence on the subject\r\nshould be imputed to my ignorance. Meanwhile, sir, watch always\xe2\x80\x94watch\r\ncarefully, for perhaps the evil may not stop here. And when you have\r\nfound the culprit, if you find him, I will say to you, \xe2\x80\x98You are a\r\nmagistrate, do as you will!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you, doctor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort with indescribable joy; \xe2\x80\x9cI never\r\nhad a better friend than you.\xe2\x80\x9d And, as if he feared Doctor d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny\r\nwould recall his promise, he hurried him towards the house.\r\n\r\nWhen they were gone, Morrel ventured out from under the trees, and the\r\nmoon shone upon his face, which was so pale it might have been taken\r\nfor that of a ghost.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am manifestly protected in a most wonderful, but most terrible\r\nmanner,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cbut Valentine, poor girl, how will she bear so much\r\nsorrow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he thought thus, he looked alternately at the window with red\r\ncurtains and the three windows with white curtains. The light had\r\nalmost disappeared from the former; doubtless Madame de Villefort had\r\njust put out her lamp, and the nightlamp alone reflected its dull light\r\non the window. At the extremity of the building, on the contrary, he\r\nsaw one of the three windows open. A wax-light placed on the\r\nmantle-piece threw some of its pale rays without, and a shadow was seen\r\nfor one moment on the balcony. Morrel shuddered; he thought he heard a\r\nsob.\r\n\r\nIt cannot be wondered at that his mind, generally so courageous, but\r\nnow disturbed by the two strongest human passions, love and fear, was\r\nweakened even to the indulgence of superstitious thoughts. Although it\r\nwas impossible that Valentine should see him, hidden as he was, he\r\nthought he heard the shadow at the window call him; his disturbed mind\r\ntold him so. This double error became an irresistible reality, and by\r\none of the incomprehensible transports of youth, he bounded from his\r\nhiding-place, and with two strides, at the risk of being seen, at the\r\nrisk of alarming Valentine, at the risk of being discovered by some\r\nexclamation which might escape the young girl, he crossed the\r\nflower-garden, which by the light of the moon resembled a large white\r\nlake, and having passed the rows of orange-trees which extended in\r\nfront of the house, he reached the step, ran quickly up and pushed the\r\ndoor, which opened without offering any resistance.\r\n\r\nValentine had not seen him. Her eyes, raised towards heaven, were\r\nwatching a silvery cloud gliding over the azure, its form that of a\r\nshadow mounting towards heaven. Her poetic and excited mind pictured it\r\nas the soul of her grandmother.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, Morrel had traversed the anteroom and found the staircase,\r\nwhich, being carpeted, prevented his approach being heard, and he had\r\nregained that degree of confidence that the presence of M. de Villefort\r\neven would not have alarmed him. He was quite prepared for any such\r\nencounter. He would at once approach Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s father and acknowledge\r\nall, begging Villefort to pardon and sanction the love which united two\r\nfond and loving hearts. Morrel was mad.\r\n\r\nHappily he did not meet anyone. Now, especially, did he find the\r\ndescription Valentine had given of the interior of the house useful to\r\nhim; he arrived safely at the top of the staircase, and while he was\r\nfeeling his way, a sob indicated the direction he was to take. He\r\nturned back, a door partly open enabled him to see his road, and to\r\nhear the voice of one in sorrow. He pushed the door open and entered.\r\nAt the other end of the room, under a white sheet which covered it, lay\r\nthe corpse, still more alarming to Morrel since the account he had so\r\nunexpectedly overheard. By its side, on her knees, and with her head\r\nburied in the cushion of an easy-chair, was Valentine, trembling and\r\nsobbing, her hands extended above her head, clasped and stiff. She had\r\nturned from the window, which remained open, and was praying in accents\r\nthat would have affected the most unfeeling; her words were rapid,\r\nincoherent, unintelligible, for the burning weight of grief almost\r\nstopped her utterance.\r\n\r\nThe moon shining through the open blinds made the lamp appear to burn\r\npaler, and cast a sepulchral hue over the whole scene. Morrel could not\r\nresist this; he was not exemplary for piety, he was not easily\r\nimpressed, but Valentine suffering, weeping, wringing her hands before\r\nhim, was more than he could bear in silence. He sighed, and whispered a\r\nname, and the head bathed in tears and pressed on the velvet cushion of\r\nthe chair\xe2\x80\x94a head like that of a Magdalen by Correggio\xe2\x80\x94was raised and\r\nturned towards him. Valentine perceived him without betraying the least\r\nsurprise. A heart overwhelmed with one great grief is insensible to\r\nminor emotions. Morrel held out his hand to her. Valentine, as her only\r\napology for not having met him, pointed to the corpse under the sheet,\r\nand began to sob again.\r\n\r\nNeither dared for some time to speak in that room. They hesitated to\r\nbreak the silence which death seemed to impose; at length Valentine\r\nventured.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9chow came you here? Alas, I would say you are\r\nwelcome, had not death opened the way for you into this house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel with a trembling voice, \xe2\x80\x9cI had waited since\r\nhalf-past eight, and did not see you come; I became uneasy, leaped the\r\nwall, found my way through the garden, when voices conversing about the\r\nfatal event\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat voices?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Valentine. Morrel shuddered as he thought of the\r\nconversation of the doctor and M. de Villefort, and he thought he could\r\nsee through the sheet the extended hands, the stiff neck, and the\r\npurple lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour servants,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwho were repeating the whole of the\r\nsorrowful story; from them I learned it all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it was risking the failure of our plan to come up here, love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cI will go away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cyou might meet someone; stay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if anyone should come here\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young girl shook her head. \xe2\x80\x9cNo one will come,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cdo not\r\nfear, there is our safeguard,\xe2\x80\x9d pointing to the bed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what has become of M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel.\r\n\r\n30349m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Franz arrived to sign the contract just as my dear grandmother was\r\ndying.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel with a feeling of selfish joy; for he thought this\r\ndeath would cause the wedding to be postponed indefinitely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what redoubles my sorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the young girl, as if this\r\nfeeling was to receive its immediate punishment, \xe2\x80\x9cis that the poor old\r\nlady, on her death-bed, requested that the marriage might take place as\r\nsoon as possible; she also, thinking to protect me, was acting against\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHark!\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel. They both listened; steps were distinctly heard in\r\nthe corridor and on the stairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is my father, who has just left his study.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo accompany the doctor to the door,\xe2\x80\x9d added Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know it is the doctor?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Valentine, astonished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI imagined it must be,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel.\r\n\r\nValentine looked at the young man; they heard the street door close,\r\nthen M. de Villefort locked the garden door, and returned upstairs. He\r\nstopped a moment in the anteroom, as if hesitating whether to turn to\r\nhis own apartment or into Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s; Morrel concealed\r\nhimself behind a door; Valentine remained motionless, grief seeming to\r\ndeprive her of all fear. M. de Villefort passed on to his own room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cyou can neither go out by the front door nor by\r\nthe garden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel looked at her with astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is but one way left you that is safe,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cit is through\r\nmy grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s room.\xe2\x80\x9d She rose. \xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d she added.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Maximilian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo my grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI in M. Are you sure you are more reasonable?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cand I have but one scruple,\xe2\x80\x94that of leaving my\r\ndear grandmother\xe2\x80\x99s remains, which I had undertaken to watch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cdeath is in itself sacred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cbesides, it will not be for long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe then crossed the corridor, and led the way down a narrow staircase\r\nto M. There was\r\nsomething grave and solemn in the approach of the young girl which\r\nstruck the old man, and immediately his bright eye began to\r\ninterrogate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear grandfather.\xe2\x80\x9d said she hurriedly, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know poor grandmamma died\r\nan hour since, and now I have no friend in the world but you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis expressive eyes evinced the greatest tenderness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo you alone, then, may I confide my sorrows and my hopes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe paralytic motioned \xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine took Maximilian\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook attentively, then, at this gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old man fixed his scrutinizing gaze with slight astonishment on\r\nMorrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is M. Noirtier?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man\xe2\x80\x99s eye. Then he looked anxiously at\r\nValentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you fear he will not understand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, we have so often spoken of you, that he knows exactly how I talk\r\nto you.\xe2\x80\x9d Then turning to Maximilian, with an adorable smile; although\r\nshaded by sorrow,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHe knows everything I know,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\nValentine arose, placed a chair for Morrel, requested Barrois not to\r\nadmit anyone, and having tenderly embraced her grandfather, and\r\nsorrowfully taken leave of Morrel, she went away. To prove to Noirtier\r\nthat he was in Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s confidence and knew all their secrets,\r\nMorrel took the dictionary, a pen, and some paper, and placed them all\r\non a table where there was a light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut first,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9callow me, sir, to tell you who I am, how\r\nmuch I love Mademoiselle Valentine, and what are my designs respecting\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier made a sign that he would listen.\r\n\r\nIt was an imposing sight to witness this old man, apparently a mere\r\nuseless burden, becoming the sole protector, support, and adviser of\r\nthe lovers who were both young, beautiful, and strong. His remarkably\r\nnoble and austere expression struck Morrel, who began his story with\r\ntrembling. He related the manner in which he had become acquainted with\r\nValentine, and how he had loved her, and that Valentine, in her\r\nsolitude and her misfortune, had accepted the offer of his devotion. He\r\ntold him his birth, his position, his fortune, and more than once, when\r\nhe consulted the look of the paralytic, that look answered, \xe2\x80\x9cThat is\r\ngood, proceed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, when he had finished the first part of his\r\nrecital, \xe2\x80\x9cnow I have told you of my love and my hopes, may I inform you\r\nof my intentions?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d signified the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis was our resolution; a cabriolet was in waiting at the gate, in\r\nwhich I intended to carry off Valentine to my sister\xe2\x80\x99s house, to marry\r\nher, and to wait respectfully M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s pardon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noirtier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must not do so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not sanction our project?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is another way,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel. The old man\xe2\x80\x99s interrogative eye\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cWhich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cI will seek M. Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay\xe2\x80\x94I am\r\nhappy to be able to mention this in Mademoiselle de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nabsence\xe2\x80\x94and will conduct myself toward him so as to compel him to\r\nchallenge me.\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s look continued to interrogate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wish to know what I will do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will find him, as I told you.
