I am here\r\nalmost miraculously, and can scarcely hope for so good an opportunity\r\nto occur again. Believe me, there are only the two plans I have\r\nproposed to you; forgive my vanity, and tell me which you prefer. Do\r\nyou authorize Mademoiselle Valentine to intrust herself to my honor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you prefer I should seek M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhence then will come the help we need\xe2\x80\x94from chance?\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou thoroughly understand me, sir? Pardon my eagerness, for my life\r\ndepends on your answer. Will our help come from you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are sure of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d There was so much firmness in the look which gave this answer,\r\nno one could, at any rate, doubt his will, if they did his power.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, thank you a thousand times! But how, unless a miracle should\r\nrestore your speech, your gesture, your movement, how can you, chained\r\nto that armchair, dumb and motionless, oppose this marriage?\xe2\x80\x9d A smile\r\nlit up the old man\xe2\x80\x99s face, a strange smile of the eyes in a paralyzed\r\nface.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I must wait?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the contract?\xe2\x80\x9d The same smile returned. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you assure me it\r\nshall not be signed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noirtier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe contract shall not be signed!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morrel. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, pardon me, sir;\r\nI can scarcely realize so great a happiness. Will they not sign it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said the paralytic. Notwithstanding that assurance, Morrel still\r\nhesitated. This promise of an impotent old man was so strange that,\r\ninstead of being the result of the power of his will, it might emanate\r\nfrom enfeebled organs. Is it not natural that the madman, ignorant of\r\nhis folly, should attempt things beyond his power? The weak man talks\r\nof burdens he can raise, the timid of giants he can confront, the poor\r\nof treasures he spends, the most humble peasant, in the height of his\r\npride, calls himself Jupiter. Whether Noirtier understood the young\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s indecision, or whether he had not full confidence in his\r\ndocility, he looked uneasily at him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you wish, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cthat I should renew my promise\r\nof remaining tranquil?\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s eye remained fixed and firm, as if\r\nto imply that a promise did not suffice; then it passed from his face\r\nto his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I swear to you, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Maximilian.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the paralytic with the same solemnity. Morrel understood\r\nthat the old man attached great importance to an oath. He extended his\r\nhand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI swear to you, on my honor,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cto await your decision\r\nrespecting the course I am to pursue with M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you wish me to retire?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout seeing Mademoiselle Valentine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel made a sign that he was ready to obey. \xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cfirst\r\nallow me to embrace you as your daughter did just now.\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nexpression could not be understood. The young man pressed his lips on\r\nthe same spot, on the old man\xe2\x80\x99s forehead, where Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s had been.\r\nThen he bowed a second time and retired.\r\n\r\nHe found outside the door the old servant, to whom Valentine had given\r\ndirections. Morrel was conducted along a dark passage, which led to a\r\nlittle door opening on the garden, soon found the spot where he had\r\nentered, with the assistance of the shrubs gained the top of the wall,\r\nand by his ladder was in an instant in the clover-field where his\r\ncabriolet was still waiting for him. He got in it, and thoroughly\r\nwearied by so many emotions, arrived about midnight in the Rue Meslay,\r\nthrew himself on his bed and slept soundly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVOLUME FOUR\r\n\r\n40010m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n40012m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n40020m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 74. The Villefort Family Vault\r\n\r\nTwo days after, a considerable crowd was assembled, towards ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\nin the morning, around the door of M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s house, and a long\r\nfile of mourning-coaches and private carriages extended along the\r\nFaubourg Saint-Honor\xc3\xa9 and the Rue de la P\xc3\xa9pini\xc3\xa8re. Among them was one\r\nof a very singular form, which appeared to have come from a distance.\r\nIt was a kind of covered wagon, painted black, and was one of the first\r\nto arrive. Inquiry was made, and it was ascertained that, by a strange\r\ncoincidence, this carriage contained the corpse of the Marquis de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran, and that those who had come thinking to attend one funeral\r\nwould follow two. Their number was great. The Marquis de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran,\r\none of the most zealous and faithful dignitaries of Louis XVIII. and\r\nKing Charles X., had preserved a great number of friends, and these,\r\nadded to the personages whom the usages of society gave Villefort a\r\nclaim on, formed a considerable body.\r\n\r\nDue information was given to the authorities, and permission obtained\r\nthat the two funerals should take place at the same time. A second\r\nhearse, decked with the same funereal pomp, was brought to M. de\r\nVillefort\xe2\x80\x99s door, and the coffin removed into it from the post-wagon.\r\nThe two bodies were to be interred in the cemetery of P\xc3\xa8re-Lachaise,\r\nwhere M. de Villefort had long since had a tomb prepared for the\r\nreception of his family. The remains of poor Ren\xc3\xa9e were already\r\ndeposited there, and now, after ten years of separation, her father and\r\nmother were to be reunited with her.\r\n\r\nThe Parisians, always curious, always affected by funereal display,\r\nlooked on with religious silence while the splendid procession\r\naccompanied to their last abode two of the number of the old\r\naristocracy\xe2\x80\x94the greatest protectors of commerce and sincere devotees to\r\ntheir principles.\r\n\r\nIn one of the mourning-coaches Beauchamp, Debray, and Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud\r\nwere talking of the very sudden death of the marchioness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran only last year at Marseilles, when I was\r\ncoming back from Algiers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9cshe looked like a\r\nwoman destined to live to be a hundred years old, from her apparent\r\nsound health and great activity of mind and body. How old was she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFranz assured me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat she was sixty-six years old.\r\nBut she has not died of old age, but of grief; it appears that since\r\nthe death of the marquis, which affected her very deeply, she has not\r\ncompletely recovered her reason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut of what disease, then, did she die?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is said to have been a congestion of the brain, or apoplexy, which\r\nis the same thing, is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNearly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is difficult to believe that it was apoplexy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, whom I once saw, was short, of slender form,\r\nand of a much more nervous than sanguine temperament; grief could\r\nhardly produce apoplexy in such a constitution as that of Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cwhatever disease or doctor may have killed\r\nher, M. de Villefort, or rather, Mademoiselle Valentine,\xe2\x80\x94or, still\r\nrather, our friend Franz, inherits a magnificent fortune, amounting, I\r\nbelieve, to 80,000 livres per annum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this fortune will be doubled at the death of the old Jacobin,\r\nNoirtier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is a tenacious old grandfather,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp. \xe2\x80\x9c_Tenacem\r\npropositi virum_. I think he must have made an agreement with death to\r\noutlive all his heirs, and he appears likely to succeed. He resembles\r\nthe old Conventionalist of \xe2\x80\x9993, who said to Napoleon, in 1814, \xe2\x80\x98You\r\nbend because your empire is a young stem, weakened by rapid growth.\r\nTake the Republic for a tutor; let us return with renewed strength to\r\nthe battle-field, and I promise you 500,000 soldiers, another Marengo,\r\nand a second Austerlitz. Ideas do not become extinct, sire; they\r\nslumber sometimes, but only revive the stronger before they sleep\r\nentirely.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIdeas and men appeared the same to him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert. \xe2\x80\x9cOne thing only\r\npuzzles me, namely, how Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay will like a grandfather who\r\ncannot be separated from his wife. But where is Franz?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first carriage, with M. de Villefort, who considers him already\r\nas one of the family.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40024m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSuch was the conversation in almost all the carriages; these two sudden\r\ndeaths, so quickly following each other, astonished everyone, but no\r\none suspected the terrible secret which M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny had communicated,\r\nin his nocturnal walk to M. de Villefort. They arrived in about an hour\r\nat the cemetery; the weather was mild, but dull, and in harmony with\r\nthe funeral ceremony. Among the groups which flocked towards the family\r\nvault, Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud recognized Morrel, who had come alone in a\r\ncabriolet, and walked silently along the path bordered with yew-trees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou here?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, passing his arms through the young\r\ncaptain\xe2\x80\x99s; \xe2\x80\x9care you a friend of Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s? How is it that I have\r\nnever met you at his house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am no acquaintance of M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I\r\nwas of Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran.\xe2\x80\x9d Albert came up to them at this moment\r\nwith Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe time and place are but ill-suited for an introduction.\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAlbert; \xe2\x80\x9cbut we are not superstitious. M. Morrel, allow me to present\r\nto you M. Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, a delightful travelling companion, with whom\r\nI made the tour of Italy. My dear Franz, M. Maximilian Morrel, an\r\nexcellent friend I have acquired in your absence, and whose name you\r\nwill hear me mention every time I make any allusion to affection, wit,\r\nor amiability.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel hesitated for a moment; he feared it would be hypocritical to\r\naccost in a friendly manner the man whom he was tacitly opposing, but\r\nhis oath and the gravity of the circumstances recurred to his memory;\r\nhe struggled to conceal his emotion and bowed to Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle de Villefort is in deep sorrow, is she not?\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray\r\nto Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExtremely,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he; \xe2\x80\x9cshe looked so pale this morning, I scarcely\r\nknew her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese apparently simple words pierced Morrel to the heart. This man had\r\nseen Valentine, and spoken to her! The young and high-spirited officer\r\nrequired all his strength of mind to resist breaking his oath. He took\r\nthe arm of Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, and turned towards the vault, where the\r\nattendants had already placed the two coffins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a magnificent habitation,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, looking towards the\r\nmausoleum; \xe2\x80\x9ca summer and winter palace. You will, in turn, enter it, my\r\ndear d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, for you will soon be numbered as one of the family. I,\r\nas a philosopher, should like a little country-house, a cottage down\r\nthere under the trees, without so many free-stones over my poor body.\r\nIn dying, I will say to those around me what Voltaire wrote to Piron:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_Eo rus_, and all will be over.\xe2\x80\x99 But come, Franz, take courage, your\r\nwife is an heiress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, Beauchamp, you are unbearable. Politics has made you laugh at\r\neverything, and political men have made you disbelieve everything. But\r\nwhen you have the honor of associating with ordinary men, and the\r\npleasure of leaving politics for a moment, try to find your\r\naffectionate heart, which you leave with your stick when you go to the\r\nChamber.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut tell me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is life? Is it not a halt in\r\nDeath\xe2\x80\x99s anteroom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40026m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am prejudiced against Beauchamp,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, drawing Franz away,\r\nand leaving the former to finish his philosophical dissertation with\r\nDebray.\r\n\r\nThe Villefort vault formed a square of white stones, about twenty feet\r\nhigh; an interior partition separated the two families, and each\r\napartment had its entrance door. Here were not, as in other tombs,\r\nignoble drawers, one above another, where thrift bestows its dead and\r\nlabels them like specimens in a museum; all that was visible within the\r\nbronze gates was a gloomy-looking room, separated by a wall from the\r\nvault itself. The two doors before mentioned were in the middle of this\r\nwall, and enclosed the Villefort and Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran coffins. There grief\r\nmight freely expend itself without being disturbed by the trifling\r\nloungers who came from a picnic party to visit P\xc3\xa8re-Lachaise, or by\r\nlovers who make it their rendezvous.\r\n\r\nThe two coffins were placed on trestles previously prepared for their\r\nreception in the right-hand crypt belonging to the Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran family.\r\nVillefort, Franz, and a few near relatives alone entered the sanctuary.\r\n\r\nAs the religious ceremonies had all been performed at the door, and\r\nthere was no address given, the party all separated; Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud,\r\nAlbert, and Morrel, went one way, and Debray and Beauchamp the other.\r\nFranz remained with M. de Villefort; at the gate of the cemetery Morrel\r\nmade an excuse to wait; he saw Franz and M. de Villefort get into the\r\nsame mourning-coach, and thought this meeting forboded evil. He then\r\nreturned to Paris, and although in the same carriage with\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud and Albert, he did not hear one word of their\r\nconversation.\r\n\r\nAs Franz was about to take leave of M. de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen shall I see\r\nyou again?\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt what time you please, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs soon as possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am at your command, sir; shall we return together?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf not unpleasant to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, I shall feel much pleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus, the future father and son-in-law stepped into the same carriage,\r\nand Morrel, seeing them pass, became uneasy. Villefort and Franz\r\nreturned to the Faubourg Saint-Honor\xc3\xa9. The procureur, without going to\r\nsee either his wife or his daughter, went at once to his study, and,\r\noffering the young man a chair:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9callow me to remind you at this moment,\xe2\x80\x94which\r\nis perhaps not so ill-chosen as at first sight may appear, for\r\nobedience to the wishes of the departed is the first offering which\r\nshould be made at their tomb,\xe2\x80\x94allow me then to remind you of the wish\r\nexpressed by Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran on her death-bed, that Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwedding might not be deferred. You know the affairs of the deceased are\r\nin perfect order, and her will bequeaths to Valentine the entire\r\nproperty of the Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran family; the notary showed me the documents\r\nyesterday, which will enable us to draw up the contract immediately.\r\nYou may call on the notary, M. Deschamps, Place Beauveau, Faubourg\r\nSaint-Honor\xc3\xa9, and you have my authority to inspect those deeds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not, perhaps, the moment for\r\nMademoiselle Valentine, who is in deep distress, to think of a husband;\r\nindeed, I fear\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40028m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine will have no greater pleasure than that of fulfilling her\r\ngrandmother\xe2\x80\x99s last injunctions; there will be no obstacle from that\r\nquarter, I assure you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cas I shall raise none, you may make\r\narrangements when you please; I have pledged my word, and shall feel\r\npleasure and happiness in adhering to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cnothing further is required. The contract was\r\nto have been signed three days since; we shall find it all ready, and\r\ncan sign it today.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the mourning?\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, hesitating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be uneasy on that score,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cno ceremony will\r\nbe neglected in my house. Mademoiselle de Villefort may retire during\r\nthe prescribed three months to her estate of Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran; I say hers,\r\nfor she inherits it today. There, after a few days, if you like, the\r\ncivil marriage shall be celebrated without pomp or ceremony. Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran wished her daughter should be married there. When that is\r\nover, you, sir, can return to Paris, while your wife passes the time of\r\nher mourning with her mother-in-law.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs you please, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9chave the kindness to wait half an\r\nhour; Valentine shall come down into the drawing-room. I will send for\r\nM. Deschamps; we will read and sign the contract before we separate,\r\nand this evening Madame de Villefort shall accompany Valentine to her\r\nestate, where we will rejoin them in a week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cI have one request to make.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish Albert de Morcerf and Raoul de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud to be present at\r\nthis signature; you know they are my witnesses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf an hour will suffice to apprise them; will you go for them\r\nyourself, or shall you send?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI prefer going, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall expect you, then, in half an hour, baron, and Valentine will\r\nbe ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz bowed and left the room. Scarcely had the door closed, when M. de\r\nVillefort sent to tell Valentine to be ready in the drawing-room in\r\nhalf an hour, as he expected the notary and M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay and his\r\nwitnesses. The news caused a great sensation throughout the house;\r\nMadame de Villefort would not believe it, and Valentine was\r\nthunderstruck. She looked around for help, and would have gone down to\r\nher grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s room, but on the stairs she met M. de Villefort, who\r\ntook her arm and led her into the drawing-room. In the anteroom,\r\nValentine met Barrois, and looked despairingly at the old servant. A\r\nmoment later, Madame de Villefort entered the drawing-room with her\r\nlittle Edward. It was evident that she had shared the grief of the\r\nfamily, for she was pale and looked fatigued. She sat down, took Edward\r\non her knees, and from time to time pressed this child, on whom her\r\naffections appeared centred, almost convulsively to her bosom.\r\n\r\nTwo carriages were soon heard to enter the courtyard. One was the\r\nnotary\xe2\x80\x99s; the other, that of Franz and his friends. In a moment the\r\nwhole party was assembled. Valentine was so pale one might trace the\r\nblue veins from her temples, round her eyes and down her cheeks. Franz\r\nwas deeply affected. Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud and Albert looked at each other\r\nwith amazement; the ceremony which was just concluded had not appeared\r\nmore sorrowful than did that which was about to begin. Madame de\r\nVillefort had placed herself in the shadow behind a velvet curtain, and\r\nas she constantly bent over her child, it was difficult to read the\r\nexpression of her face. M. de Villefort was, as usual, unmoved.\r\n\r\nThe notary, after having, according to the customary method, arranged\r\nthe papers on the table, taken his place in an armchair, and raised his\r\nspectacles, turned towards Franz:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you M. Franz de Quesnel, baron d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, although he\r\nknew it perfectly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Franz. The notary bowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have, then, to inform you, sir, at the request of M. de Villefort,\r\nthat your projected marriage with Mademoiselle de Villefort has changed\r\nthe feeling of M. Noirtier towards his grandchild, and that he\r\ndisinherits her entirely of the fortune he would have left her. Let me\r\nhasten to add,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the testator, having only the right\r\nto alienate a part of his fortune, and having alienated it all, the\r\nwill will not bear scrutiny, and is declared null and void.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I warn M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, that during my\r\nlife-time my father\xe2\x80\x99s will shall never be questioned, my position\r\nforbidding any doubt to be entertained.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40032m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cI regret much that such a question has been raised\r\nin the presence of Mademoiselle Valentine; I have never inquired the\r\namount of her fortune, which, however limited it may be, exceeds mine.\r\nMy family has sought consideration in this alliance with M. de\r\nVillefort; all I seek is happiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine imperceptibly thanked him, while two silent tears rolled down\r\nher cheeks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, addressing himself to his future\r\nson-in-law, \xe2\x80\x9cexcepting the loss of a portion of your hopes, this\r\nunexpected will need not personally wound you; M. Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s weakness\r\nof mind sufficiently explains it. It is not because Mademoiselle\r\nValentine is going to marry you that he is angry, but because she will\r\nmarry, a union with any other would have caused him the same sorrow.\r\nOld age is selfish, sir, and Mademoiselle de Villefort has been a\r\nfaithful companion to M. Noirtier, which she cannot be when she becomes\r\nthe Baroness d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay. My father\xe2\x80\x99s melancholy state prevents our\r\nspeaking to him on any subjects, which the weakness of his mind would\r\nincapacitate him from understanding, and I am perfectly convinced that\r\nat the present time, although, he knows that his granddaughter is going\r\nto be married, M. Noirtier has even forgotten the name of his intended\r\ngrandson.\xe2\x80\x9d M. de Villefort had scarcely said this, when the door\r\nopened, and Barrois appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in a tone strangely firm for a servant speaking\r\nto his masters under such solemn circumstances,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cgentlemen, M. Noirtier\r\nde Villefort wishes to speak immediately to M. Franz de Quesnel, baron\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay.\xe2\x80\x9d He, as well as the notary, that there might be no mistake in\r\nthe person, gave all his titles to the bridegroom elect.\r\n\r\nVillefort started, Madame de Villefort let her son slip from her knees,\r\nValentine rose, pale and dumb as a statue. Albert and Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud\r\nexchanged a second look, more full of amazement than the first. The\r\nnotary looked at Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d said the procureur. \xe2\x80\x9cM. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay cannot leave the\r\ndrawing-room at present.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is at this moment,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Barrois with the same firmness, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nM. Noirtier, my master, wishes to speak on important subjects to M.\r\nFranz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrandpapa Noirtier can speak now, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edward, with his\r\nhabitual quickness. However, his remark did not make Madame de\r\nVillefort even smile, so much was every mind engaged, and so solemn was\r\nthe situation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell M. Nortier,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthat what he demands is\r\nimpossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, M. Nortier gives notice to these gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Barrois,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat he will give orders to be carried to the drawing-room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAstonishment was at its height. Something like a smile was perceptible\r\non Madame de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s countenance. Valentine instinctively raised\r\nher eyes, as if to thank heaven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray go, Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said; M. de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cand see what this new\r\nfancy of your grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s is.\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine rose quickly, and was\r\nhastening joyfully towards the door, when M. de Villefort altered his\r\nintention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cI will go with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, \xe2\x80\x9csince M. Noirtier sent for me, I am\r\nready to attend to his wish; besides, I shall be happy to pay my\r\nrespects to him, not having yet had the honor of doing so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort with marked uneasiness, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not disturb\r\nyourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40032m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz in a resolute tone. \xe2\x80\x9cI would not lose\r\nthis opportunity of proving to M. Noirtier how wrong it would be of him\r\nto encourage feelings of dislike to me, which I am determined to\r\nconquer, whatever they may be, by my devotion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd without listening to Villefort he arose, and followed Valentine,\r\nwho was running downstairs with the joy of a shipwrecked mariner who\r\nfinds a rock to cling to. M. de Villefort followed them. Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud\r\nand Morcerf exchanged a third look of still increasing wonder.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 75. A Signed Statement\r\n\r\nNoirtier was prepared to receive them, dressed in black, and installed\r\nin his armchair. When the three persons he expected had entered, he\r\nlooked at the door, which his valet immediately closed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Villefort to Valentine, who could not conceal her\r\njoy; \xe2\x80\x9cif M. Noirtier wishes to communicate anything which would delay\r\nyour marriage, I forbid you to understand him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine blushed, but did not answer. Villefort, approached Noirtier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is M. Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cyou requested to see him. We\r\nhave all wished for this interview, and I trust it will convince you\r\nhow ill-formed are your objections to Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s marriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier answered only by a look which made Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s blood run cold.\r\nHe motioned to Valentine to approach. In a moment, thanks to her habit\r\nof conversing with her grandfather, she understood that he asked for a\r\nkey. Then his eye was fixed on the drawer of a small chest between the\r\nwindows. She opened the drawer, and found a key; and, understanding\r\nthat was what he wanted, again watched his eyes, which turned toward an\r\nold secretaire which had been neglected for many years and was supposed\r\nto contain nothing but useless documents.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I open the secretaire?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the drawers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose at the side?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe middle one?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine opened it and drew out a bundle of papers. \xe2\x80\x9cIs that what you\r\nwish for?\xe2\x80\x9d asked she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe took successively all the other papers out till the drawer was\r\nempty. \xe2\x80\x9cBut there are no more,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s eye was fixed on\r\nthe dictionary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I understand, grandfather,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young girl.\r\n\r\n40036m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nShe pointed to each letter of the alphabet. At the letter S the old man\r\nstopped her. She opened, and found the word \xe2\x80\x9csecret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! is there a secret spring?\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noirtier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who knows it?\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier looked at the door where the servant had\r\ngone out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBarrois?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I call him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine went to the door, and called Barrois. Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s impatience\r\nduring this scene made the perspiration roll from his forehead, and\r\nFranz was stupefied. The old servant came.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBarrois,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cmy grandfather has told me to open that\r\ndrawer in the secretaire, but there is a secret spring in it, which you\r\nknow\xe2\x80\x94will you open it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBarrois looked at the old man. \xe2\x80\x9cObey,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s intelligent eye.\r\nBarrois touched a spring, the false bottom came out, and they saw a\r\nbundle of papers tied with a black string.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that what you wish for?\xe2\x80\x9d said Barrois.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I give these papers to M. de Villefort?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Mademoiselle Valentine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo M. Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz, astonished, advanced a step. \xe2\x80\x9cTo me, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz took them from Barrois and casting a glance at the cover, read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98To be given, after my death, to General Durand, who shall bequeath\r\nthe packet to his son, with an injunction to preserve it as containing\r\nan important document.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you wish me to do with this paper?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo preserve it, sealed up as it is, doubtless,\xe2\x80\x9d said the procureur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Noirtier eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you wish him to read it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou understand, baron, my grandfather wishes you to read this paper,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen let us sit down,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort impatiently, \xe2\x80\x9cfor it will take\r\nsome time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man. Villefort took a chair, but Valentine\r\nremained standing by her father\xe2\x80\x99s side, and Franz before him, holding\r\nthe mysterious paper in his hand. \xe2\x80\x9cRead,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man. Franz\r\nuntied it, and in the midst of the most profound silence read:\r\n\r\n40038m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98_Extract of the report of a meeting of the Bonapartist Club in the\r\nRue Saint-Jacques, held February 5th, 1815_.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz stopped. \xe2\x80\x9cFebruary 5th, 1815!\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cit is the day my father\r\nwas murdered.\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine and Villefort were dumb; the eye of the old\r\nman alone seemed to say clearly, \xe2\x80\x9cGo on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it was on leaving this club,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cmy father disappeared.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier\xe2\x80\x99s eye continued to say, \xe2\x80\x9cRead.\xe2\x80\x9d He resumed:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The undersigned Louis-Jacques Beaurepaire, lieutenant-colonel of\r\nartillery, \xc3\x89tienne Duchampy, general of brigade, and Claude Lecharpal,\r\nkeeper of woods and forests, declare, that on the 4th of February, a\r\nletter arrived from the Island of Elba, recommending to the kindness\r\nand the confidence of the Bonapartist Club, General Flavien de Quesnel,\r\nwho having served the emperor from 1804 to 1814 was supposed to be\r\ndevoted to the interests of the Napoleon dynasty, notwithstanding the\r\ntitle of baron which Louis XVIII. had just granted to him with his\r\nestate of \xc3\x89pinay.\r\n\r\n400340m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98A note was in consequence addressed to General de Quesnel, begging\r\nhim to be present at the meeting next day, the 5th. The note indicated\r\nneither the street nor the number of the house where the meeting was to\r\nbe held; it bore no signature, but it announced to the general that\r\nsomeone would call for him if he would be ready at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock. The\r\nmeetings were always held from that time till midnight. At nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\nthe president of the club presented himself; the general was ready, the\r\npresident informed him that one of the conditions of his introduction\r\nwas that he should be eternally ignorant of the place of meeting, and\r\nthat he would allow his eyes to be bandaged, swearing that he would not\r\nendeavor to take off the bandage. General de Quesnel accepted the\r\ncondition, and promised on his honor not to seek to discover the road\r\nthey took. The general\xe2\x80\x99s carriage was ready, but the president told him\r\nit was impossible for him to use it, since it was useless to blindfold\r\nthe master if the coachman knew through what streets he went. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nmust be done then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the general.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI have my carriage here,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe president.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cHave you, then, so much confidence in your servant that you can\r\nintrust him with a secret you will not allow me to know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cOur coachman is a member of the club,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president; \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall\r\nbe driven by a State-Councillor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cThen we run another risk,\xe2\x80\x9d said the general, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cthat of\r\nbeing upset.\xe2\x80\x9d We insert this joke to prove that the general was not in\r\nthe least compelled to attend the meeting, but that he came willingly.\r\nWhen they were seated in the carriage the president reminded the\r\ngeneral of his promise to allow his eyes to be bandaged, to which he\r\nmade no opposition. On the road the president thought he saw the\r\ngeneral make an attempt to remove the handkerchief, and reminded him of\r\nhis oath. \xe2\x80\x9cSure enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said the general. The carriage stopped at an\r\nalley leading out of the Rue Saint-Jacques. The general alighted,\r\nleaning on the arm of the president, of whose dignity he was not aware,\r\nconsidering him simply as a member of the club; they went through the\r\nalley, mounted a flight of stairs, and entered the assembly-room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The deliberations had already begun. The members, apprised of the\r\nsort of presentation which was to be made that evening, were all in\r\nattendance. When in the middle of the room the general was invited to\r\nremove his bandage, he did so immediately, and was surprised to see so\r\nmany well-known faces in a society of whose existence he had till then\r\nbeen ignorant. They questioned him as to his sentiments, but he\r\ncontented himself with answering, that the letters from the Island of\r\nElba ought to have informed them\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz interrupted himself by saying, \xe2\x80\x9cMy father was a royalist; they\r\nneed not have asked his sentiments, which were well known.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd hence,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9carose my affection for your father, my\r\ndear M. Franz. Opinions held in common are a ready bond of union.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead again,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man.\r\n\r\nFranz continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The president then sought to make him speak more explicitly, but M.\r\nde Quesnel replied that he wished first to know what they wanted with\r\nhim. He was then informed of the contents of the letter from the Island\r\nof Elba, in which he was recommended to the club as a man who would be\r\nlikely to advance the interests of their party. One paragraph spoke of\r\nthe return of Bonaparte and promised another letter and further\r\ndetails, on the arrival of the _Pharaon_ belonging to the shipbuilder\r\nMorrel, of Marseilles, whose captain was entirely devoted to the\r\nemperor. During all this time, the general, on whom they thought to\r\nhave relied as on a brother, manifested evidently signs of discontent\r\nand repugnance. When the reading was finished, he remained silent, with\r\nknitted brows.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the president, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you say to this letter,\r\ngeneral?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cI say that it is too soon after declaring myself for Louis XVIII. to\r\nbreak my vow in behalf of the ex-emperor.\xe2\x80\x9d This answer was too clear to\r\npermit of any mistake as to his sentiments. \xe2\x80\x9cGeneral,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\npresident, \xe2\x80\x9cwe acknowledge no King Louis XVIII., or an ex-emperor, but\r\nhis majesty the emperor and king, driven from France, which is his\r\nkingdom, by violence and treason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the general; \xe2\x80\x9cyou may not acknowledge\r\nLouis XVIII., but I do, as he has made me a baron and a field-marshal,\r\nand I shall never forget that for these two titles I am indebted to his\r\nhappy return to France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president, rising with gravity, \xe2\x80\x9cbe careful what you\r\nsay; your words clearly show us that they are deceived concerning you\r\nin the Island of Elba, and have deceived us! The communication has been\r\nmade to you in consequence of the confidence placed in you, and which\r\ndoes you honor. Now we discover our error; a title and promotion attach\r\nyou to the government we wish to overturn. We will not constrain you to\r\nhelp us; we enroll no one against his conscience, but we will compel\r\nyou to act generously, even if you are not disposed to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cYou would call acting generously, knowing your conspiracy and not\r\ninforming against you, that is what I should call becoming your\r\naccomplice. You see I am more candid than you.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my father!\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, interrupting himself. \xe2\x80\x9cI understand now\r\nwhy they murdered him.\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine could not help casting one glance\r\ntowards the young man, whose filial enthusiasm it was delightful to\r\nbehold. Villefort walked to and fro behind them. Noirtier watched the\r\nexpression of each one, and preserved his dignified and commanding\r\nattitude. Franz returned to the manuscript, and continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have been invited to join this\r\nassembly\xe2\x80\x94you were not forced here; it was proposed to you to come\r\nblindfolded\xe2\x80\x94you accepted. When you complied with this twofold request\r\nyou well knew we did not wish to secure the throne of Louis XVIII., or\r\nwe should not take so much care to avoid the vigilance of the police.\r\nIt would be conceding too much to allow you to put on a mask to aid you\r\nin the discovery of our secret, and then to remove it that you may ruin\r\nthose who have confided in you. No, no, you must first say if you\r\ndeclare yourself for the king of a day who now reigns, or for his\r\nmajesty the emperor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cI am a royalist,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the general; \xe2\x80\x9cI have taken the oath of\r\nallegiance to Louis XVIII., and I will adhere to it.\xe2\x80\x9d These words were\r\nfollowed by a general murmur, and it was evident that several of the\r\nmembers were discussing the propriety of making the general repent of\r\nhis rashness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The president again arose, and having imposed silence, said,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\r\nyou are too serious and too sensible a man not to understand the\r\nconsequences of our present situation, and your candor has already\r\ndictated to us the conditions which remain for us to offer you.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\ngeneral, putting his hand on his sword, exclaimed,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIf you talk of\r\nhonor, do not begin by disavowing its laws, and impose nothing by\r\nviolence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the president, with a calmness still more\r\nterrible than the general\xe2\x80\x99s anger, \xe2\x80\x9cI advise you not to touch your\r\nsword.\xe2\x80\x9d The general looked around him with slight uneasiness; however\r\nhe did not yield, but calling up all his fortitude, said,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI will not\r\nswear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cThen you must die,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the president calmly. M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay became\r\nvery pale; he looked round him a second time, several members of the\r\nclub were whispering, and getting their arms from under their cloaks.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeneral,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not alarm yourself; you are among\r\nmen of honor who will use every means to convince you before resorting\r\nto the last extremity, but as you have said, you are among\r\nconspirators, you are in possession of our secret, and you must restore\r\nit to us.\xe2\x80\x9d A significant silence followed these words, and as the\r\ngeneral did not reply,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cClose the doors,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president to the\r\ndoor-keeper.\r\n\r\n40042m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The same deadly silence succeeded these words. Then the general\r\nadvanced, and making a violent effort to control his feelings,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\na son,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cand I ought to think of him, finding myself among\r\nassassins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cGeneral,\xe2\x80\x9d said the chief of the assembly, \xe2\x80\x9cone man may insult\r\nfifty\xe2\x80\x94it is the privilege of weakness. But he does wrong to use his\r\nprivilege. Follow my advice, swear, and do not insult.\xe2\x80\x9d The general,\r\nagain daunted by the superiority of the chief, hesitated a moment; then\r\nadvancing to the president\xe2\x80\x99s desk,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the form, said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cIt is this:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I swear by my honor not to reveal to anyone what I have\r\nseen and heard on the 5th of February, 1815, between nine and ten\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening; and I plead guilty of death should I ever\r\nviolate this oath.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d The general appeared to be affected by a nervous\r\ntremor, which prevented his answering for some moments; then,\r\novercoming his manifest repugnance, he pronounced the required oath,\r\nbut in so low a tone as to be scarcely audible to the majority of the\r\nmembers, who insisted on his repeating it clearly and distinctly, which\r\nhe did.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cNow am I at liberty to retire?\xe2\x80\x9d said the general. The president\r\nrose, appointed three members to accompany him, and got into the\r\ncarriage with the general after bandaging his eyes. One of those three\r\nmembers was the coachman who had driven them there. The other members\r\nsilently dispersed. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere do you wish to be taken?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the\r\npresident.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAnywhere out of your presence,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeware, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the president, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are no longer in the\r\nassembly, and have only to do with individuals; do not insult them\r\nunless you wish to be held responsible.\xe2\x80\x9d But instead of listening, M.\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay went on,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYou are still as brave in your carriage as in your\r\nassembly because you are still four against one.\xe2\x80\x9d The president stopped\r\nthe coach. They were at that part of the Quai des Ormes where the steps\r\nlead down to the river. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you stop here?\xe2\x80\x9d asked d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have insulted a man, and\r\nthat man will not go one step farther without demanding honorable\r\nreparation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cAnother method of assassination?\xe2\x80\x9d said the general, shrugging his\r\nshoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x9cMake no noise, sir, unless you wish me to consider you as one of the\r\nmen of whom you spoke just now as cowards, who take their weakness for\r\na shield. You are alone, one alone shall answer you; you have a sword\r\nby your side, I have one in my cane; you have no witness, one of these\r\ngentlemen will serve you. Now, if you please, remove your bandage.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\ngeneral tore the handkerchief from his eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cAt last,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nshall know with whom I have to do.\xe2\x80\x9d They opened the door and the four\r\nmen alighted.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz again interrupted himself, and wiped the cold drops from his\r\nbrow; there was something awful in hearing the son read aloud in\r\ntrembling pallor these details of his father\xe2\x80\x99s death, which had\r\nhitherto been a mystery. Valentine clasped her hands as if in prayer.\r\nNoirtier looked at Villefort with an almost sublime expression of\r\ncontempt and pride.\r\n\r\nFranz continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98It was, as we said, the fifth of February. For three days the mercury\r\nhad been five or six degrees below freezing and the steps were covered\r\nwith ice. The general was stout and tall, the president offered him the\r\nside of the railing to assist him in getting down. The two witnesses\r\nfollowed. It was a dark night. The ground from the steps to the river\r\nwas covered with snow and hoarfrost, the water of the river looked\r\nblack and deep. One of the seconds went for a lantern in a coal-barge\r\nnear, and by its light they examined the weapons. The president\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsword, which was simply, as he had said, one he carried in his cane,\r\nwas five inches shorter than the general\xe2\x80\x99s, and had no guard. The\r\ngeneral proposed to cast lots for the swords, but the president said it\r\nwas he who had given the provocation, and when he had given it he had\r\nsupposed each would use his own arms. The witnesses endeavored to\r\ninsist, but the president bade them be silent. The lantern was placed\r\non the ground, the two adversaries took their stations, and the duel\r\nbegan. The light made the two swords appear like flashes of lightning;\r\nas for the men, they were scarcely perceptible, the darkness was so\r\ngreat.\r\n\r\n40044m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98General d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay passed for one of the best swordsmen in the army,\r\nbut he was pressed so closely in the onset that he missed his aim and\r\nfell. The witnesses thought he was dead, but his adversary, who knew he\r\nhad not struck him, offered him the assistance of his hand to rise. The\r\ncircumstance irritated instead of calming the general, and he rushed on\r\nhis adversary. But his opponent did not allow his guard to be broken.\r\nHe received him on his sword and three times the general drew back on\r\nfinding himself too closely engaged, and then returned to the charge.\r\nAt the third he fell again. They thought he slipped, as at first, and\r\nthe witnesses, seeing he did not move, approached and endeavored to\r\nraise him, but the one who passed his arm around the body found it was\r\nmoistened with blood. The general, who had almost fainted, revived.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthey have sent some fencing-master to fight with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThe president, without answering, approached the witness who held the\r\nlantern, and raising his sleeve, showed him two wounds he had received\r\nin his arm; then opening his coat, and unbuttoning his waistcoat,\r\ndisplayed his side, pierced with a third wound. Still he had not even\r\nuttered a sigh. General d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay died five minutes after.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFranz read these last words in a voice so choked that they were hardly\r\naudible, and then stopped, passing his hand over his eyes as if to\r\ndispel a cloud; but after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s silence, he continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The president went up the steps, after pushing his sword into his\r\ncane; a track of blood on the snow marked his course. He had scarcely\r\narrived at the top when he heard a heavy splash in the water\xe2\x80\x94it was the\r\ngeneral\xe2\x80\x99s body, which the witnesses had just thrown into the river\r\nafter ascertaining that he was dead. The general fell, then, in a loyal\r\nduel, and not in ambush as it might have been reported. In proof of\r\nthis we have signed this paper to establish the truth of the facts,\r\nlest the moment should arrive when either of the actors in this\r\nterrible scene should be accused of premeditated murder or of\r\ninfringement of the laws of honor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Signed, Beaurepaire, Duchampy, and Lecharpal.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Franz had finished reading this account, so dreadful for a son;\r\nwhen Valentine, pale with emotion, had wiped away a tear; when\r\nVillefort, trembling, and crouched in a corner, had endeavored to\r\nlessen the storm by supplicating glances at the implacable old man,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay to Noirtier, \xe2\x80\x9csince you are well acquainted with\r\nall these details, which are attested by honorable signatures,\xe2\x80\x94since\r\nyou appear to take some interest in me, although you have only\r\nmanifested it hitherto by causing me sorrow, refuse me not one final\r\nsatisfaction\xe2\x80\x94tell me the name of the president of the club, that I may\r\nat least know who killed my father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort mechanically felt for the handle of the door; Valentine, who\r\nunderstood sooner than anyone her grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s answer, and who had\r\noften seen two scars upon his right arm, drew back a few steps.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz, turning towards Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cunite your\r\nefforts with mine to find out the name of the man who made me an orphan\r\nat two years of age.\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine remained dumb and motionless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not prolong this dreadful scene. The\r\nnames have been purposely concealed; my father himself does not know\r\nwho this president was, and if he knows, he cannot tell you; proper\r\nnames are not in the dictionary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, misery,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Franz: \xe2\x80\x9cthe only hope which sustained me and\r\nenabled me to read to the end was that of knowing, at least, the name\r\nof him who killed my father! Sir, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, turning to Noirtier,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdo what you can\xe2\x80\x94make me understand in some way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Noirtier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mademoiselle, mademoiselle!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Franz, \xe2\x80\x9cyour grandfather says\r\nhe can indicate the person. Help me,\xe2\x80\x94lend me your assistance!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier looked at the dictionary. Franz took it with a nervous\r\ntrembling, and repeated the letters of the alphabet successively, until\r\nhe came to M. At that letter the old man signified \xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Franz. The young man\xe2\x80\x99s finger, glided over the words, but\r\nat each one Noirtier answered by a negative sign. Valentine hid her\r\nhead between her hands. At length, Franz arrived at the word MYSELF.\r\n\r\n40046m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Franz, whose hair stood on end; \xe2\x80\x9cyou, M. Noirtier\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nkilled my father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Noirtier, fixing a majestic look on the young man. Franz\r\nfell powerless on a chair; Villefort opened the door and escaped, for\r\nthe idea had entered his mind to stifle the little remaining life in\r\nthe heart of this terrible old man.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 76. Progress of Cavalcanti the Younger\r\n\r\nMeanwhile M. Cavalcanti the elder had returned to his service, not in\r\nthe army of his majesty the Emperor of Austria, but at the gaming-table\r\nof the baths of Lucca, of which he was one of the most assiduous\r\ncourtiers. He had spent every farthing that had been allowed for his\r\njourney as a reward for the majestic and solemn manner in which he had\r\nmaintained his assumed character of father.\r\n\r\nM. Andrea at his departure inherited all the papers which proved that\r\nhe had indeed the honor of being the son of the Marquis Bartolomeo and\r\nthe Marchioness Oliva Corsinari. He was now fairly launched in that\r\nParisian society which gives such ready access to foreigners, and\r\ntreats them, not as they really are, but as they wish to be considered.\r\nBesides, what is required of a young man in Paris? To speak its\r\nlanguage tolerably, to make a good appearance, to be a good gamester,\r\nand to pay in cash. They are certainly less particular with a foreigner\r\nthan with a Frenchman. Andrea had, then, in a fortnight, attained a\r\nvery fair position. He was called count, he was said to possess 50,000\r\nlivres per annum; and his father\xe2\x80\x99s immense riches, buried in the\r\nquarries of Saravezza, were a constant theme. A learned man, before\r\nwhom the last circumstance was mentioned as a fact, declared he had\r\nseen the quarries in question, which gave great weight to assertions\r\nhitherto somewhat doubtful, but which now assumed the garb of reality.\r\n\r\nSuch was the state of society in Paris at the period we bring before\r\nour readers, when Monte Cristo went one evening to pay M. Danglars a\r\nvisit. M. Danglars was out, but the count was asked to go and see the\r\nbaroness, and he accepted the invitation. It was never without a\r\nnervous shudder, since the dinner at Auteuil, and the events which\r\nfollowed it, that Madame Danglars heard Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s name announced.\r\nIf he did not come, the painful sensation became most intense; if, on\r\nthe contrary, he appeared, his noble countenance, his brilliant eyes,\r\nhis amiability, his polite attention even towards Madame Danglars, soon\r\ndispelled every impression of fear. It appeared impossible to the\r\nbaroness that a man of such delightfully pleasing manners should\r\nentertain evil designs against her; besides, the most corrupt minds\r\nonly suspect evil when it would answer some interested end\xe2\x80\x94useless\r\ninjury is repugnant to every mind.\r\n\r\n40048m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen Monte Cristo entered the boudoir, to which we have already once\r\nintroduced our readers, and where the baroness was examining some\r\ndrawings, which her daughter passed to her after having looked at them\r\nwith M. Cavalcanti, his presence soon produced its usual effect, and it\r\nwas with smiles that the baroness received the count, although she had\r\nbeen a little disconcerted at the announcement of his name. The latter\r\ntook in the whole scene at a glance.\r\n\r\nThe baroness was partially reclining on a sofa, Eug\xc3\xa9nie sat near her,\r\nand Cavalcanti was standing. Cavalcanti, dressed in black, like one of\r\nGoethe\xe2\x80\x99s heroes, with varnished shoes and white silk open-worked\r\nstockings, passed a white and tolerably nice-looking hand through his\r\nlight hair, and so displayed a sparkling diamond, that in spite of\r\nMonte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s advice the vain young man had been unable to resist\r\nputting on his little finger. This movement was accompanied by killing\r\nglances at Mademoiselle Danglars, and by sighs launched in the same\r\ndirection.\r\n\r\nMademoiselle Danglars was still the same\xe2\x80\x94cold, beautiful, and\r\nsatirical. Not one of these glances, nor one sigh, was lost on her;\r\nthey might have been said to fall on the shield of Minerva, which some\r\nphilosophers assert protected sometimes the breast of Sappho. Eug\xc3\xa9nie\r\nbowed coldly to the count, and availed herself of the first moment when\r\nthe conversation became earnest to escape to her study, whence very\r\nsoon two cheerful and noisy voices being heard in connection with\r\noccasional notes of the piano assured Monte Cristo that Mademoiselle\r\nDanglars preferred to his society and to that of M. Cavalcanti the\r\ncompany of Mademoiselle Louise d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly, her singing teacher.\r\n\r\nIt was then, especially while conversing with Madame Danglars, and\r\napparently absorbed by the charm of the conversation, that the count\r\nnoticed M. Andrea Cavalcanti\xe2\x80\x99s solicitude, his manner of listening to\r\nthe music at the door he dared not pass, and of manifesting his\r\nadmiration.\r\n\r\nThe banker soon returned. His first look was certainly directed towards\r\nMonte Cristo, but the second was for Andrea. As for his wife, he bowed\r\nto her, as some husbands do to their wives, but in a way that bachelors\r\nwill never comprehend, until a very extensive code is published on\r\nconjugal life.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave not the ladies invited you to join them at the piano?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nDanglars to Andrea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, no, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Andrea with a sigh, still more remarkable than\r\nthe former ones. Danglars immediately advanced towards the door and\r\nopened it.\r\n\r\n40050m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe two young ladies were seen seated on the same chair, at the piano,\r\naccompanying themselves, each with one hand, a fancy to which they had\r\naccustomed themselves, and performed admirably. Mademoiselle d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly,\r\nwhom they then perceived through the open doorway, formed with Eug\xc3\xa9nie\r\none of the _tableaux vivants_ of which the Germans are so fond. She was\r\nsomewhat beautiful, and exquisitely formed\xe2\x80\x94a little fairy-like figure,\r\nwith large curls falling on her neck, which was rather too long, as\r\nPerugino sometimes makes his Virgins, and her eyes dull from fatigue.\r\nShe was said to have a weak chest, and like Antonia in the _Cremona\r\nViolin_, she would die one day while singing.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo cast one rapid and curious glance round this sanctum; it\r\nwas the first time he had ever seen Mademoiselle d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly, of whom he\r\nhad heard much.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the banker to his daughter, \xe2\x80\x9care we then all to be\r\nexcluded?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then led the young man into the study, and either by chance or\r\nman\xc5\x93uvre the door was partially closed after Andrea, so that from the\r\nplace where they sat neither the Count nor the baroness could see\r\nanything; but as the banker had accompanied Andrea, Madame Danglars\r\nappeared to take no notice of it.\r\n\r\nThe count soon heard Andrea\xe2\x80\x99s voice, singing a Corsican song,\r\naccompanied by the piano. While the count smiled at hearing this song,\r\nwhich made him lose sight of Andrea in the recollection of Benedetto,\r\nMadame Danglars was boasting to Monte Cristo of her husband\xe2\x80\x99s strength\r\nof mind, who that very morning had lost three or four hundred thousand\r\nfrancs by a failure at Milan. The praise was well deserved, for had not\r\nthe count heard it from the baroness, or by one of those means by which\r\nhe knew everything, the baron\xe2\x80\x99s countenance would not have led him to\r\nsuspect it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHem,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9che begins to conceal his losses; a month\r\nsince he boasted of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen aloud,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cOh, madame, M. Danglars is so skilful, he will soon regain\r\nat the Bourse what he loses elsewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see that you participate in a prevalent error,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame\r\nDanglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat M. Danglars speculates, whereas he never does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly, madame, I recollect M. Debray told me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94apropos, what has become\r\nof him? I have seen nothing of him the last three or four days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you began a sentence, sir, and did\r\nnot finish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Debray had told you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes; he told me it was you who sacrificed to the demon of\r\nspeculation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was once very fond of it, but I do not indulge now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you are wrong, madame. Fortune is precarious; and if I were a\r\nwoman and fate had made me a banker\xe2\x80\x99s wife, whatever might be my\r\nconfidence in my husband\xe2\x80\x99s good fortune, still in speculation you know\r\nthere is great risk. Well, I would secure for myself a fortune\r\nindependent of him, even if I acquired it by placing my interests in\r\nhands unknown to him.\xe2\x80\x9d Madame Danglars blushed, in spite of all her\r\nefforts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, as though he had not observed her confusion,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heard of a lucky hit that was made yesterday on the Neapolitan\r\nbonds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have none\xe2\x80\x94nor have I ever possessed any; but really we have talked\r\nlong enough of money, count, we are like two stockbrokers; have you\r\nheard how fate is persecuting the poor Villeforts?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has happened?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, simulating total ignorance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know the Marquis of Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran died a few days after he had set\r\nout on his journey to Paris, and the marchioness a few days after her\r\narrival?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI have heard that; but, as Claudius said to\r\nHamlet, \xe2\x80\x98it is a law of nature; their fathers died before them, and\r\nthey mourned their loss; they will die before their children, who will,\r\nin their turn, grieve for them.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that is not all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot all!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; they were going to marry their daughter\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo M. Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay. Is it broken off?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYesterday morning, it appears, Franz declined the honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed? They both went into the house; the drawing-room was lighted\r\nup\xe2\x80\x94they went in there. \xe2\x80\x9cYou will make tea for us, Baptistin,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ncount. Baptistin left the room without waiting to answer, and in two\r\nseconds reappeared, bringing on a tray, all that his master had\r\nordered, ready prepared, and appearing to have sprung from the ground,\r\nlike the repasts which we read of in fairy tales.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, my dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat I admire in you is, not so\r\nmuch your riches, for perhaps there are people even wealthier than\r\nyourself, nor is it only your wit, for Beaumarchais might have\r\npossessed as much,\xe2\x80\x94but it is your manner of being served, without any\r\nquestions, in a moment, in a second; it is as if they guessed what you\r\nwanted by your manner of ringing, and made a point of keeping\r\neverything you can possibly desire in constant readiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you say is perhaps true; they know my habits. For instance, you\r\nshall see; how do you wish to occupy yourself during tea-time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi_, I should like to smoke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo took the gong and struck it once. In about the space of a\r\nsecond a private door opened, and Ali appeared, bringing two chibouques\r\nfilled with excellent latakia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is quite wonderful,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh no, it is as simple as possible,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cAli knows\r\nI generally smoke while I am taking my tea or coffee; he has heard that\r\nI ordered tea, and he also knows that I brought you home with me; when\r\nI summoned him he naturally guessed the reason of my doing so, and as\r\nhe comes from a country where hospitality is especially manifested\r\nthrough the medium of smoking, he naturally concludes that we shall\r\nsmoke in company, and therefore brings two chibouques instead of\r\none\xe2\x80\x94and now the mystery is solved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly you give a most commonplace air to your explanation, but it\r\nis not the less true that you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94Ah, but what do I hear?\xe2\x80\x9d and Morcerf\r\ninclined his head towards the door, through which sounds seemed to\r\nissue resembling those of a guitar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi_, my dear viscount, you are fated to hear music this evening;\r\nyou have only escaped from Mademoiselle Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 piano, to be attacked\r\nby Hayd\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x99s guzla.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHayd\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x94what an adorable name! The\r\nslave of the Count of Monte Cristo! Why, it is a rank of itself in\r\nFrance, and from the way in which you lavish money, it is a place that\r\nmust be worth a hundred thousand francs a year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hundred thousand francs! The poor girl originally possessed much\r\nmore than that; she was born to treasures in comparison with which\r\nthose recorded in the _Thousand and One Nights_ would seem but\r\npoverty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe must be a princess then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right; and she is one of the greatest in her country too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought so. But how did it happen that such a great princess became\r\na slave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow was it that Dionysius the Tyrant became a schoolmaster? The\r\nfortune of war, my dear viscount,\xe2\x80\x94the caprice of fortune; that is the\r\nway in which these things are to be accounted for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is her name a secret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs regards the generality of mankind it is; but not for you, my dear\r\nviscount, who are one of my most intimate friends, and on whose silence\r\nI feel I may rely, if I consider it necessary to enjoin it\xe2\x80\x94may I not do\r\nso?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; on my word of honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know the history of the Pasha of Yanina, do you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf Ali Tepelini?13 Oh, yes; it was in his service that my father made\r\nhis fortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, I had forgotten that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40062m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what is Hayd\xc3\xa9e to Ali Tepelini?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerely his daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? the daughter of Ali Pasha?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf Ali Pasha and the beautiful Vasiliki.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd your slave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi_, yes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how did she become so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, simply from the circumstance of my having bought her one day, as\r\nI was passing through the market at Constantinople.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWonderful! Really, my dear count, you seem to throw a sort of magic\r\ninfluence over all in which you are concerned; when I listen to you,\r\nexistence no longer seems reality, but a waking dream. Now, I am\r\nperhaps going to make an imprudent and thoughtless request, but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, since you go out with Hayd\xc3\xa9e, and sometimes even take her to the\r\nOpera\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I may venture to ask you this favor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may venture to ask me anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, my dear count, present me to your princess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do so; but on two conditions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI accept them at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe first is, that you will never tell anyone that I have granted the\r\ninterview.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, extending his hand; \xe2\x80\x9cI swear I will not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe second is, that you will not tell her that your father ever served\r\nhers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give you my oath that I will not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough, viscount; you will remember those two vows, will you not? But\r\nI know you to be a man of honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count again struck the gong. Ali reappeared. \xe2\x80\x9cTell Hayd\xc3\xa9e,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nhe, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I will take coffee with her, and give her to understand that\r\nI desire permission to present one of my friends to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAli bowed and left the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, understand me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cno direct questions, my dear\r\nMorcerf; if you wish to know anything, tell me, and I will ask her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgreed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAli reappeared for the third time, and drew back the tapestried hanging\r\nwhich concealed the door, to signify to his master and Albert that they\r\nwere at liberty to pass on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\nAlbert passed his hand through his hair, and curled his moustache,\r\nthen, having satisfied himself as to his personal appearance, followed\r\nthe count into the room, the latter having previously resumed his hat\r\nand gloves. Ali was stationed as a kind of advanced guard, and the door\r\nwas kept by the three French attendants, commanded by Myrtho.\r\n\r\nHayd\xc3\xa9e was awaiting her visitors in the first room of her apartments,\r\nwhich was the drawing-room. Her large eyes were dilated with surprise\r\nand expectation, for it was the first time that any man, except Monte\r\nCristo, had been accorded an entrance into her presence. She was\r\nsitting on a sofa placed in an angle of the room, with her legs crossed\r\nunder her in the Eastern fashion, and seemed to have made for herself,\r\nas it were, a kind of nest in the rich Indian silks which enveloped\r\nher. Near her was the instrument on which she had just been playing; it\r\nwas elegantly fashioned, and worthy of its mistress. On perceiving\r\nMonte Cristo, she arose and welcomed him with a smile peculiar to\r\nherself, expressive at once of the most implicit obedience and also of\r\nthe deepest love. Monte Cristo advanced towards her and extended his\r\nhand, which she as usual raised to her lips.\r\n\r\n40064m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAlbert had proceeded no farther than the door, where he remained rooted\r\nto the spot, being completely fascinated by the sight of such\r\nsurpassing beauty, beheld as it was for the first time, and of which an\r\ninhabitant of more northern climes could form no adequate idea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom do you bring?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the young girl in Romaic, of Monte Cristo;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cis it a friend, a brother, a simple acquaintance, or an enemy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo in the same language.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount Albert; it is the same man whom I rescued from the hands of the\r\nbanditti at Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what language would you like me to converse with him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo turned to Albert. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know modern Greek,\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas! no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cnor even ancient Greek, my dear count; never\r\nhad Homer or Plato a more unworthy scholar than myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hayd\xc3\xa9e, proving by her remark that she had quite\r\nunderstood Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s question and Albert\xe2\x80\x99s answer, \xe2\x80\x9cthen I will\r\nspeak either in French or Italian, if my lord so wills it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo reflected one instant. \xe2\x80\x9cYou will speak in Italian,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nhe.\r\n\r\nThen, turning towards Albert,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a pity you do not understand\r\neither ancient or modern Greek, both of which Hayd\xc3\xa9e speaks so\r\nfluently; the poor child will be obliged to talk to you in Italian,\r\nwhich will give you but a very false idea of her powers of\r\nconversation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count made a sign to Hayd\xc3\xa9e to address his visitor. \xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d she said\r\nto Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are most welcome as the friend of my lord and master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThis was said in excellent Tuscan, and with that soft Roman accent\r\nwhich makes the language of Dante as sonorous as that of Homer. Then,\r\nturning to Ali, she directed him to bring coffee and pipes, and when he\r\nhad left the room to execute the orders of his young mistress she\r\nbeckoned Albert to approach nearer to her. Monte Cristo and Morcerf\r\ndrew their seats towards a small table, on which were arranged music,\r\ndrawings, and vases of flowers. Ali then entered bringing coffee and\r\nchibouques; as to M. Baptistin, this portion of the building was\r\ninterdicted to him. Albert refused the pipe which the Nubian offered\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, take it\xe2\x80\x94take it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cHayd\xc3\xa9e is almost as civilized\r\nas a Parisian; the smell of a Havana is disagreeable to her, but the\r\ntobacco of the East is a most delicious perfume, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAli left the room. The cups of coffee were all prepared, with the\r\naddition of sugar, which had been brought for Albert. Monte Cristo and\r\nHayd\xc3\xa9e took the beverage in the original Arabian manner, that is to\r\nsay, without sugar. Hayd\xc3\xa9e took the porcelain cup in her little slender\r\nfingers and conveyed it to her mouth with all the innocent artlessness\r\nof a child when eating or drinking something which it likes. At this\r\nmoment two women entered, bringing salvers filled with ices and\r\nsherbet, which they placed on two small tables appropriated to that\r\npurpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear host, and you, signora,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, in Italian, \xe2\x80\x9cexcuse my\r\napparent stupidity. I am quite bewildered, and it is natural that it\r\nshould be so. Here I am in the heart of Paris; but a moment ago I heard\r\nthe rumbling of the omnibuses and the tinkling of the bells of the\r\nlemonade-sellers, and now I feel as if I were suddenly transported to\r\nthe East; not such as I have seen it, but such as my dreams have\r\npainted it. Oh, signora, if I could but speak Greek, your conversation,\r\nadded to the fairy-scene which surrounds me, would furnish an evening\r\nof such delight as it would be impossible for me ever to forget.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI speak sufficient Italian to enable me to converse with you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Hayd\xc3\xa9e quietly; \xe2\x80\x9cand if you like what is Eastern, I will do my\r\nbest to secure the gratification of your tastes while you are here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn what subject shall I converse with her?\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, in a low tone\r\nto Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust what you please; you may speak of her country and of her youthful\r\nreminiscences, or if you like it better you can talk of Rome, Naples,\r\nor Florence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cit is of no use to be in the company of a Greek if\r\none converses just in the same style as with a Parisian; let me speak\r\nto her of the East.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo so then, for of all themes which you could choose that will be the\r\nmost agreeable to her taste.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert turned towards Hayd\xc3\xa9e. \xe2\x80\x9cAt what age did you leave Greece,\r\nsignora?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI left it when I was but five years old,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Hayd\xc3\xa9e.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd have you any recollection of your country?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I shut my eyes and think, I seem to see it all again. The mind\r\ncan see as well as the body.
