The body forgets sometimes; but the mind\r\nalways remembers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how far back into the past do your recollections extend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could scarcely walk when my mother, who was called Vasiliki, which\r\nmeans royal,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young girl, tossing her head proudly, \xe2\x80\x9ctook me\r\nby the hand, and after putting in our purse all the money we possessed,\r\nwe went out, both covered with veils, to solicit alms for the\r\nprisoners, saying, \xe2\x80\x98He who giveth to the poor lendeth to the Lord.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nThen when our purse was full we returned to the palace, and without\r\nsaying a word to my father, we sent it to the convent, where it was\r\ndivided amongst the prisoners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how old were you at that time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was three years old,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hayd\xc3\xa9e.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you remember everything that went on about you from the time when\r\nyou were three years old?\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, in a low tone to Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cdo allow the\r\nsignora to tell me something of her history. You prohibited my\r\nmentioning my father\xe2\x80\x99s name to her, but perhaps she will allude to him\r\nof her own accord in the course of the recital, and you have no idea\r\nhow delighted I should be to hear our name pronounced by such beautiful\r\nlips.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo turned to Hayd\xc3\xa9e, and with an expression of countenance\r\nwhich commanded her to pay the most implicit attention to his words, he\r\nsaid in Greek, \xe2\x80\x9c\xce\xa0\xce\xb1\xcf\x84\xcf\x81\xe1\xbd\xb8\xcf\x82 \xce\xbc\xe1\xbd\xb2\xce\xbd \xe1\xbc\x84\xcf\x84\xce\xb7\xce\xbd \xce\xbc\xe1\xbd\xb5\xce\xb6\xce\xb5 \xcf\x84\xe1\xbd\xb8 \xe1\xbd\x84\xce\xbd\xce\xbf\xce\xbc\xce\xb1 \xcf\x80\xcf\x81\xce\xbf\xce\xb4\xe1\xbd\xb9\xcf\x84\xce\xbf\xcf\x85 \xce\xba\xce\xb1\xe1\xbd\xb6 \xcf\x80\xcf\x81\xce\xbf\xce\xb4\xce\xbf\xcf\x83\xe1\xbd\xb7\xce\xb1\xce\xbd\r\n\xce\xb5\xe1\xbc\xb0\xcf\x80\xe1\xbd\xb2 \xe1\xbc\xa1\xce\xbc\xe1\xbf\x96\xce\xbd,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94that is, \xe2\x80\x9cTell us the fate of your father; but neither the\r\nname of the traitor nor the treason.\xe2\x80\x9d Hayd\xc3\xa9e sighed deeply, and a shade\r\nof sadness clouded her beautiful brow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you saying to her?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf in an undertone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI again reminded her that you were a friend, and that she need not\r\nconceal anything from you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cthis pious pilgrimage in behalf of the prisoners\r\nwas your first remembrance; what is the next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, then I remember as if it were but yesterday sitting under the\r\nshade of some sycamore-trees, on the borders of a lake, in the waters\r\nof which the trembling foliage was reflected as in a mirror. Under the\r\noldest and thickest of these trees, reclining on cushions, sat my\r\nfather; my mother was at his feet, and I, childlike, amused myself by\r\nplaying with his long white beard which descended to his girdle, or\r\nwith the diamond-hilt of the scimitar attached to his girdle. Then from\r\ntime to time there came to him an Albanian who said something to which\r\nI paid no attention, but which he always answered in the same tone of\r\nvoice, either \xe2\x80\x98Kill,\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98Pardon.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very strange,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cto hear such words proceed from the\r\nmouth of anyone but an actress on the stage, and one needs constantly\r\nto be saying to one\xe2\x80\x99s self, \xe2\x80\x98This is no fiction, it is all reality,\xe2\x80\x99 in\r\norder to believe it. And how does France appear in your eyes,\r\naccustomed as they have been to gaze on such enchanted scenes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think it is a fine country,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hayd\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I see France as it\r\nreally is, because I look on it with the eyes of a woman; whereas my\r\nown country, which I can only judge of from the impression produced on\r\nmy childish mind, always seems enveloped in a vague atmosphere, which\r\nis luminous or otherwise, according as my remembrances of it are sad or\r\njoyous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo young,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, forgetting at the moment the Count\xe2\x80\x99s command\r\nthat he should ask no questions of the slave herself, \xe2\x80\x9cis it possible\r\nthat you can have known what suffering is except by name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHayd\xc3\xa9e turned her eyes towards Monte Cristo, who, making at the same\r\ntime some imperceptible sign, murmured:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xce\x95\xe1\xbc\xb0\xcf\x80\xe1\xbd\xb3\xe2\x80\x94speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing is ever so firmly impressed on the mind as the memory of our\r\nearly childhood, and with the exception of the two scenes I have just\r\ndescribed to you, all my earliest reminiscences are fraught with\r\ndeepest sadness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40068m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, speak, signora,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI am listening with the most\r\nintense delight and interest to all you say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHayd\xc3\xa9e answered his remark with a melancholy smile. \xe2\x80\x9cYou wish me, then,\r\nto relate the history of my past sorrows?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg you to do so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I was but four years old when one night I was suddenly awakened\r\nby my mother. We were in the palace of Yanina; she snatched me from the\r\ncushions on which I was sleeping, and on opening my eyes I saw hers\r\nfilled with tears. She took me away without speaking. When I saw her\r\nweeping I began to cry too. \xe2\x80\x98Hush, child!\xe2\x80\x99 said she. At other times in\r\nspite of maternal endearments or threats, I had with a child\xe2\x80\x99s caprice\r\nbeen accustomed to indulge my feelings of sorrow or anger by crying as\r\nmuch as I felt inclined; but on this occasion there was an intonation\r\nof such extreme terror in my mother\xe2\x80\x99s voice when she enjoined me to\r\nsilence, that I ceased crying as soon as her command was given. She\r\nbore me rapidly away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw then that we were descending a large staircase; around us were\r\nall my mother\xe2\x80\x99s servants carrying trunks, bags, ornaments, jewels,\r\npurses of gold, with which they were hurrying away in the greatest\r\ndistraction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBehind the women came a guard of twenty men armed with long guns and\r\npistols, and dressed in the costume which the Greeks have assumed since\r\nthey have again become a nation. You may imagine there was something\r\nstartling and ominous,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hayd\xc3\xa9e, shaking her head and turning pale\r\nat the mere remembrance of the scene, \xe2\x80\x9cin this long file of slaves and\r\nwomen only half-aroused from sleep, or at least so they appeared to me,\r\nwho was myself scarcely awake. Here and there on the walls of the\r\nstaircase, were reflected gigantic shadows, which trembled in the\r\nflickering light of the pine-torches till they seemed to reach to the\r\nvaulted roof above.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Quick!\xe2\x80\x99 said a voice at the end of the gallery. This voice made\r\neveryone bow before it, resembling in its effect the wind passing over\r\na field of wheat, by its superior strength forcing every ear to yield\r\nobeisance. As for me, it made me tremble. This voice was that of my\r\nfather. He came last, clothed in his splendid robes and holding in his\r\nhand the carbine which your emperor presented him. He was leaning on\r\nthe shoulder of his favorite Selim, and he drove us all before him, as\r\na shepherd would his straggling flock. My father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hayd\xc3\xa9e, raising\r\nher head, \xe2\x80\x9cwas that illustrious man known in Europe under the name of\r\nAli Tepelini, pasha of Yanina, and before whom Turkey trembled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert, without knowing why, started on hearing these words pronounced\r\nwith such a haughty and dignified accent; it appeared to him as if\r\nthere was something supernaturally gloomy and terrible in the\r\nexpression which gleamed from the brilliant eyes of Hayd\xc3\xa9e at this\r\nmoment; she appeared like a Pythoness evoking a spectre, as she\r\nrecalled to his mind the remembrance of the fearful death of this man,\r\nto the news of which all Europe had listened with horror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hayd\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x9cwe halted on our march, and found ourselves on\r\nthe borders of a lake. My mother pressed me to her throbbing heart, and\r\nat the distance of a few paces I saw my father, who was glancing\r\nanxiously around. Four marble steps led down to the water\xe2\x80\x99s edge, and\r\nbelow them was a boat floating on the tide.\r\n\r\n40070m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom where we stood I could see in the middle of the lake a large\r\nblank mass; it was the kiosk to which we were going. This kiosk\r\nappeared to me to be at a considerable distance, perhaps on account of\r\nthe darkness of the night, which prevented any object from being more\r\nthan partially discerned. We stepped into the boat. I remember well\r\nthat the oars made no noise whatever in striking the water, and when I\r\nleaned over to ascertain the cause I saw that they were muffled with\r\nthe sashes of our Palikares.14 Besides the rowers, the boat contained\r\nonly the women, my father, mother, Selim, and myself. The Palikares had\r\nremained on the shore of the lake, ready to cover our retreat; they\r\nwere kneeling on the lowest of the marble steps, and in that manner\r\nintended making a rampart of the three others, in case of pursuit. Our\r\nbark flew before the wind. \xe2\x80\x98Why does the boat go so fast?\xe2\x80\x99 asked I of\r\nmy mother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Silence, child! Hush, we are flying!\xe2\x80\x99 I did not understand. Why\r\nshould my father fly?\xe2\x80\x94he, the all-powerful\xe2\x80\x94he, before whom others were\r\naccustomed to fly\xe2\x80\x94he, who had taken for his device,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98They hate me; then they fear me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was, indeed, a flight which my father was trying to effect. I have\r\nbeen told since that the garrison of the castle of Yanina, fatigued\r\nwith long service\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere Hayd\xc3\xa9e cast a significant glance at Monte Cristo, whose eyes had\r\nbeen riveted on her countenance during the whole course of her\r\nnarrative. The young girl then continued, speaking slowly, like a\r\nperson who is either inventing or suppressing some feature of the\r\nhistory which he is relating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were saying, signora,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, who was paying the most\r\nimplicit attention to the recital, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the garrison of Yanina,\r\nfatigued with long service\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad treated with the Seraskier15 Kourchid, who had been sent by the\r\nsultan to gain possession of the person of my father; it was then that\r\nAli Tepelini\xe2\x80\x94after having sent to the sultan a French officer in whom\r\nhe reposed great confidence\xe2\x80\x94resolved to retire to the asylum which he\r\nhad long before prepared for himself, and which he called\r\n_kataphygion_, or the refuge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this officer,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you remember his name, signora?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo exchanged a rapid glance with the young girl, which was\r\nquite unperceived by Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not remember it just at this moment; but if it\r\nshould occur to me presently, I will tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert was on the point of pronouncing his father\xe2\x80\x99s name, when Monte\r\nCristo gently held up his finger in token of reproach; the young man\r\nrecollected his promise, and was silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was towards this kiosk that we were rowing. A ground floor,\r\nornamented with arabesques, bathing its terraces in the water, and\r\nanother floor, looking on the lake, was all which was visible to the\r\neye. But beneath the ground floor, stretching out into the island, was\r\na large subterranean cavern, to which my mother, myself, and the women\r\nwere conducted. In this place were together 60,000 pouches and 200\r\nbarrels; the pouches contained 25,000,000 of money in gold, and the\r\nbarrels were filled with 30,000 pounds of gunpowder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNear the barrels stood Selim, my father\xe2\x80\x99s favorite, whom I mentioned\r\nto you just now. He stood watch day and night with a lance provided\r\nwith a lighted slowmatch in his hand, and he had orders to blow up\r\neverything\xe2\x80\x94kiosk, guards, women, gold, and Ali Tepelini himself\xe2\x80\x94at the\r\nfirst signal given by my father. I remember well that the slaves,\r\nconvinced of the precarious tenure on which they held their lives,\r\npassed whole days and nights in praying, crying, and groaning. As for\r\nme, I can never forget the pale complexion and black eyes of the young\r\nsoldier, and whenever the angel of death summons me to another world, I\r\nam quite sure I shall recognize Selim. I cannot tell you how long we\r\nremained in this state; at that period I did not even know what time\r\nmeant. Sometimes, but very rarely, my father summoned me and my mother\r\nto the terrace of the palace; these were hours of recreation for me, as\r\nI never saw anything in the dismal cavern but the gloomy countenances\r\nof the slaves and Selim\xe2\x80\x99s fiery lance. My father was endeavoring to\r\npierce with his eager looks the remotest verge of the horizon,\r\nexamining attentively every black speck which appeared on the lake,\r\nwhile my mother, reclining by his side, rested her head on his\r\nshoulder, and I played at his feet, admiring everything I saw with that\r\nunsophisticated innocence of childhood which throws a charm round\r\nobjects insignificant in themselves, but which in its eyes are invested\r\nwith the greatest importance. The heights of Pindus towered above us;\r\nthe castle of Yanina rose white and angular from the blue waters of the\r\nlake, and the immense masses of black vegetation which, viewed in the\r\ndistance, gave the idea of lichens clinging to the rocks, were in\r\nreality gigantic fir-trees and myrtles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne morning my father sent for us; my mother had been crying all the\r\nnight, and was very wretched; we found the pasha calm, but paler than\r\nusual. \xe2\x80\x98Take courage, Vasiliki,\xe2\x80\x99 said he; \xe2\x80\x98today arrives the firman of\r\nthe master, and my fate will be decided. If my pardon be complete, we\r\nshall return triumphant to Yanina; if the news be inauspicious, we must\r\nfly this night.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98But supposing our enemy should not allow us to do\r\nso?\xe2\x80\x99 said my mother. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, make yourself easy on that head,\xe2\x80\x99 said Ali,\r\nsmiling; \xe2\x80\x98Selim and his flaming lance will settle that matter. They\r\nwould be glad to see me dead, but they would not like themselves to die\r\nwith me.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mother only answered by sighs to consolations which she knew did\r\nnot come from my father\xe2\x80\x99s heart. She prepared the iced water which he\r\nwas in the habit of constantly drinking,\xe2\x80\x94for since his sojourn at the\r\nkiosk he had been parched by the most violent fever,\xe2\x80\x94after which she\r\nanointed his white beard with perfumed oil, and lighted his chibouque,\r\nwhich he sometimes smoked for hours together, quietly watching the\r\nwreaths of vapor that ascended in spiral clouds and gradually melted\r\naway in the surrounding atmosphere. Presently he made such a sudden\r\nmovement that I was paralyzed with fear. Then, without taking his eyes\r\nfrom the object which had first attracted his attention, he asked for\r\nhis telescope. My mother gave it him, and as she did so, looked whiter\r\nthan the marble against which she leaned. I saw my father\xe2\x80\x99s hand\r\ntremble. \xe2\x80\x98A boat!\xe2\x80\x94two!\xe2\x80\x94three!\xe2\x80\x99 murmured my, father;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98four!\xe2\x80\x99 He then\r\narose, seizing his arms and priming his pistols. \xe2\x80\x98Vasiliki,\xe2\x80\x99 said he to\r\nmy mother, trembling perceptibly, \xe2\x80\x98the instant approaches which will\r\ndecide everything. In the space of half an hour we shall know the\r\nemperor\xe2\x80\x99s answer. Go into the cavern with Hayd\xc3\xa9e.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I will not quit\r\nyou,\xe2\x80\x99 said Vasiliki; \xe2\x80\x98if you die, my lord, I will die with you.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Go to\r\nSelim!\xe2\x80\x99 cried my father. \xe2\x80\x98Adieu, my lord,\xe2\x80\x99 murmured my mother,\r\ndetermining quietly to await the approach of death. \xe2\x80\x98Take away\r\nVasiliki!\xe2\x80\x99 said my father to his Palikares.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs for me, I had been forgotten in the general confusion; I ran toward\r\nAli Tepelini; he saw me hold out my arms to him, and he stooped down\r\nand pressed my forehead with his lips. Oh, how distinctly I remember\r\nthat kiss!\xe2\x80\x94it was the last he ever gave me, and I feel as if it were\r\nstill warm on my forehead. On descending, we saw through the\r\nlattice-work several boats which were gradually becoming more distinct\r\nto our view. At first they appeared like black specks, and now they\r\nlooked like birds skimming the surface of the waves. During this time,\r\nin the kiosk at my father\xe2\x80\x99s feet, were seated twenty Palikares,\r\nconcealed from view by an angle of the wall and watching with eager\r\neyes the arrival of the boats. They were armed with their long guns\r\ninlaid with mother-of-pearl and silver, and cartridges in great numbers\r\nwere lying scattered on the floor. My father looked at his watch, and\r\npaced up and down with a countenance expressive of the greatest\r\nanguish. This was the scene which presented itself to my view as I\r\nquitted my father after that last kiss.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mother and I traversed the gloomy passage leading to the cavern.\r\nSelim was still at his post, and smiled sadly on us as we entered. We\r\nfetched our cushions from the other end of the cavern, and sat down by\r\nSelim. In great dangers the devoted ones cling to each other; and,\r\nyoung as I was, I quite understood that some imminent danger was\r\nhanging over our heads.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert had often heard\xe2\x80\x94not from his father, for he never spoke on the\r\nsubject, but from strangers\xe2\x80\x94the description of the last moments of the\r\nvizier of Yanina; he had read different accounts of his death, but the\r\nstory seemed to acquire fresh meaning from the voice and expression of\r\nthe young girl, and her sympathetic accent and the melancholy\r\nexpression of her countenance at once charmed and horrified him.\r\n\r\nAs to Hayd\xc3\xa9e, these terrible reminiscences seemed to have overpowered\r\nher for a moment, for she ceased speaking, her head leaning on her hand\r\nlike a beautiful flower bowing beneath the violence of the storm; and\r\nher eyes gazing on vacancy indicated that she was mentally\r\ncontemplating the green summit of the Pindus and the blue waters of the\r\nlake of Yanina, which, like a magic mirror, seemed to reflect the\r\nsombre picture which she sketched. Monte Cristo looked at her with an\r\nindescribable expression of interest and pity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, my child,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count in the Romaic language.\r\n\r\n40074m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHayd\xc3\xa9e looked up abruptly, as if the sonorous tones of Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nvoice had awakened her from a dream; and she resumed her narrative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was about four o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the afternoon, and although the day was\r\nbrilliant out-of-doors, we were enveloped in the gloomy darkness of the\r\ncavern. One single, solitary light was burning there, and it appeared\r\nlike a star set in a heaven of blackness; it was Selim\xe2\x80\x99s flaming lance.\r\nMy mother was a Christian, and she prayed. Selim repeated from time to\r\ntime the sacred words: \xe2\x80\x98God is great!\xe2\x80\x99 However, my mother had still\r\nsome hope. As she was coming down, she thought she recognized the\r\nFrench officer who had been sent to Constantinople, and in whom my\r\nfather placed so much confidence; for he knew that all the soldiers of\r\nthe French emperor were naturally noble and generous. She advanced some\r\nsteps towards the staircase, and listened. \xe2\x80\x98They are approaching,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nshe; \xe2\x80\x98perhaps they bring us peace and liberty!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98What do you fear, Vasiliki?\xe2\x80\x99 said Selim, in a voice at once so gentle\r\nand yet so proud. \xe2\x80\x98If they do not bring us peace, we will give them\r\nwar; if they do not bring life, we will give them death.\xe2\x80\x99 And he\r\nrenewed the flame of his lance with a gesture which made one think of\r\nDionysus of old Crete.16 But I, being only a little child, was\r\nterrified by this undaunted courage, which appeared to me both\r\nferocious and senseless, and I recoiled with horror from the idea of\r\nthe frightful death amidst fire and flames which probably awaited us.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mother experienced the same sensations, for I felt her tremble.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mamma, mamma,\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98are we really to be killed?\xe2\x80\x99 And at the sound\r\nof my voice the slaves redoubled their cries and prayers and\r\nlamentations. \xe2\x80\x98My child,\xe2\x80\x99 said Vasiliki, \xe2\x80\x98may God preserve you from\r\never wishing for that death which today you so much dread!\xe2\x80\x99 Then,\r\nwhispering to Selim, she asked what were her master\xe2\x80\x99s orders. \xe2\x80\x98If he\r\nsend me his poniard, it will signify that the emperor\xe2\x80\x99s intentions are\r\nnot favorable, and I am to set fire to the powder; if, on the contrary,\r\nhe send me his ring, it will be a sign that the emperor pardons him,\r\nand I am to extinguish the match and leave the magazine untouched.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98My\r\nfriend,\xe2\x80\x99 said my mother, \xe2\x80\x98when your master\xe2\x80\x99s orders arrive, if it is\r\nthe poniard which he sends, instead of despatching us by that horrible\r\ndeath which we both so much dread, you will mercifully kill us with\r\nthis same poniard, will you not?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Yes, Vasiliki,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Selim\r\ntranquilly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuddenly we heard loud cries; and, listening, discerned that they were\r\ncries of joy. The name of the French officer who had been sent to\r\nConstantinople resounded on all sides amongst our Palikares; it was\r\nevident that he brought the answer of the emperor, and that it was\r\nfavorable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you not remember the Frenchman\xe2\x80\x99s name?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, quite\r\nready to aid the memory of the narrator. Monte Cristo made a sign to\r\nhim to be silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not recollect it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hayd\xc3\xa9e.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe noise increased; steps were heard approaching nearer and nearer;\r\nthey were descending the steps leading to the cavern. Selim made ready\r\nhis lance. Soon a figure appeared in the gray twilight at the entrance\r\nof the cave, formed by the reflection of the few rays of daylight which\r\nhad found their way into this gloomy retreat. \xe2\x80\x98Who are you?\xe2\x80\x99 cried\r\nSelim. \xe2\x80\x98But whoever you may be, I charge you not to advance another\r\nstep.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Long live the emperor!\xe2\x80\x99 said the figure. \xe2\x80\x98He grants a full\r\npardon to the Vizier Ali, and not only gives him his life, but restores\r\nto him his fortune and his possessions.\xe2\x80\x99 My mother uttered a cry of\r\njoy, and clasped me to her bosom. \xe2\x80\x98Stop,\xe2\x80\x99 said Selim, seeing that she\r\nwas about to go out; \xe2\x80\x98you see I have not yet received the\r\nring,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98True,\xe2\x80\x99 said my mother. And she fell on her knees, at the same\r\ntime holding me up towards heaven, as if she desired, while praying to\r\nGod in my behalf, to raise me actually to his presence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd for the second time Hayd\xc3\xa9e stopped, overcome by such violent\r\nemotion that the perspiration stood upon her pale brow, and her stifled\r\nvoice seemed hardly able to find utterance, so parched and dry were her\r\nthroat and lips.\r\n\r\n40076m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo poured a little iced water into a glass, and presented it\r\nto her, saying with a mildness in which was also a shade of\r\ncommand,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cCourage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHayd\xc3\xa9e dried her eyes, and continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy this time our eyes, habituated to the darkness, had recognized the\r\nmessenger of the pasha,\xe2\x80\x94it was a friend. Selim had also recognized him,\r\nbut the brave young man only acknowledged one duty, which was to obey.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98In whose name do you come?\xe2\x80\x99 said he to him. \xe2\x80\x98I come in the name of our\r\nmaster, Ali Tepelini.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98If you come from Ali himself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Selim, \xe2\x80\x98you\r\nknow what you were charged to remit to me?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 said the messenger,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98and I bring you his ring.\xe2\x80\x99 At these words he raised his hand above his\r\nhead, to show the token; but it was too far off, and there was not\r\nlight enough to enable Selim, where he was standing, to distinguish and\r\nrecognize the object presented to his view. \xe2\x80\x98I do not see what you have\r\nin your hand,\xe2\x80\x99 said Selim. \xe2\x80\x98Approach then,\xe2\x80\x99 said the messenger, \xe2\x80\x98or I\r\nwill come nearer to you, if you prefer it.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I will agree to neither\r\none nor the other,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the young soldier; \xe2\x80\x98place the object which\r\nI desire to see in the ray of light which shines there, and retire\r\nwhile I examine it.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Be it so,\xe2\x80\x99 said the envoy; and he retired, after\r\nhaving first deposited the token agreed on in the place pointed out to\r\nhim by Selim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, how our hearts palpitated; for it did, indeed, seem to be a ring\r\nwhich was placed there. But was it my father\xe2\x80\x99s ring? that was the\r\nquestion. Selim, still holding in his hand the lighted match, walked\r\ntowards the opening in the cavern, and, aided by the faint light which\r\nstreamed in through the mouth of the cave, picked up the token.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98It is well,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, kissing it; \xe2\x80\x98it is my master\xe2\x80\x99s ring!\xe2\x80\x99 And\r\nthrowing the match on the ground, he trampled on it and extinguished\r\nit. The messenger uttered a cry of joy and clapped his hands. At this\r\nsignal four soldiers of the Seraskier Kourchid suddenly appeared, and\r\nSelim fell, pierced by five blows. Each man had stabbed him separately,\r\nand, intoxicated by their crime, though still pale with fear, they\r\nsought all over the cavern to discover if there was any fear of fire,\r\nafter which they amused themselves by rolling on the bags of gold. At\r\nthis moment my mother seized me in her arms, and hurrying noiselessly\r\nalong numerous turnings and windings known only to ourselves, she\r\narrived at a private staircase of the kiosk, where was a scene of\r\nfrightful tumult and confusion. The lower rooms were entirely filled\r\nwith Kourchid\xe2\x80\x99s troops; that is to say, with our enemies. Just as my\r\nmother was on the point of pushing open a small door, we heard the\r\nvoice of the pasha sounding in a loud and threatening tone. My mother\r\napplied her eye to the crack between the boards; I luckily found a\r\nsmall opening which afforded me a view of the apartment and what was\r\npassing within. \xe2\x80\x98What do you want?\xe2\x80\x99 said my father to some people who\r\nwere holding a paper inscribed with characters of gold. \xe2\x80\x98What we want,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreplied one, \xe2\x80\x98is to communicate to you the will of his highness. Do you\r\nsee this firman?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I do,\xe2\x80\x99 said my father. \xe2\x80\x98Well, read it; he demands\r\nyour head.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n40078m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father answered with a loud laugh, which was more frightful than\r\neven threats would have been, and he had not ceased when two reports of\r\na pistol were heard; he had fired them himself, and had killed two men.\r\nThe Palikares, who were prostrated at my father\xe2\x80\x99s feet, now sprang up\r\nand fired, and the room was filled with fire and smoke. At the same\r\ninstant the firing began on the other side, and the balls penetrated\r\nthe boards all round us. Oh, how noble did the grand vizier my father\r\nlook at that moment, in the midst of the flying bullets, his scimitar\r\nin his hand, and his face blackened with the powder of his enemies! and\r\nhow he terrified them, even then, and made them fly before him! \xe2\x80\x98Selim,\r\nSelim!\xe2\x80\x99 cried he, \xe2\x80\x98guardian of the fire, do your duty!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Selim is\r\ndead,\xe2\x80\x99 replied a voice which seemed to come from the depths of the\r\nearth, \xe2\x80\x98and you are lost, Ali!\xe2\x80\x99 At the same moment an explosion was\r\nheard, and the flooring of the room in which my father was sitting was\r\nsuddenly torn up and shivered to atoms\xe2\x80\x94the troops were firing from\r\nunderneath. Three or four Palikares fell with their bodies literally\r\nploughed with wounds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father howled aloud, plunged his fingers into the holes which the\r\nballs had made, and tore up one of the planks entire. But immediately\r\nthrough this opening twenty more shots were fired, and the flame,\r\nrushing up like fire from the crater of a volcano, soon reached the\r\ntapestry, which it quickly devoured. In the midst of all this frightful\r\ntumult and these terrific cries, two reports, fearfully distinct,\r\nfollowed by two shrieks more heartrending than all, froze me with\r\nterror. These two shots had mortally wounded my father, and it was he\r\nwho had given utterance to these frightful cries. However, he remained\r\nstanding, clinging to a window. My mother tried to force the door, that\r\nshe might go and die with him, but it was fastened on the inside. All\r\naround him were lying the Palikares, writhing in convulsive agonies,\r\nwhile two or three who were only slightly wounded were trying to escape\r\nby springing from the windows. At this crisis the whole flooring\r\nsuddenly gave way, my father fell on one knee, and at the same moment\r\ntwenty hands were thrust forth, armed with sabres, pistols, and\r\nponiards\xe2\x80\x94twenty blows were instantaneously directed against one man,\r\nand my father disappeared in a whirlwind of fire and smoke kindled by\r\nthese demons, and which seemed like hell itself opening beneath his\r\nfeet. I felt myself fall to the ground, my mother had fainted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHayd\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x99s arms fell by her side, and she uttered a deep groan, at the\r\nsame time looking towards the count as if to ask if he were satisfied\r\nwith her obedience to his commands.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo arose and approached her, took her hand, and said to her\r\nin Romaic:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCalm yourself, my dear child, and take courage in remembering that\r\nthere is a God who will punish traitors.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a frightful story, count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, terrified at the\r\npaleness of Hayd\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x99s countenance, \xe2\x80\x9cand I reproach myself now for having\r\nbeen so cruel and thoughtless in my request.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. Then, patting the young girl on\r\nthe head, he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cHayd\xc3\xa9e is very courageous, and she sometimes\r\neven finds consolation in the recital of her misfortunes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hayd\xc3\xa9e eagerly, \xe2\x80\x9cmy miseries recall to me the\r\nremembrance of your goodness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert looked at her with curiosity, for she had not yet related what\r\nhe most desired to know,\xe2\x80\x94how she had become the slave of the count.\r\nHayd\xc3\xa9e saw at a glance the same expression pervading the countenances\r\nof her two auditors; she continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen my mother recovered her senses we were before the seraskier.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Kill,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, \xe2\x80\x98but spare the honor of the widow of Ali.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98It is not\r\nto me to whom you must address yourself,\xe2\x80\x99 said Kourchid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98To whom, then?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98To your new master.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Who and where is he?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98He is here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Kourchid pointed out one who had more than any contributed to the\r\ndeath of my father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hayd\xc3\xa9e, in a tone of chastened anger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cyou became the property of this man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40080m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Hayd\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x9che did not dare to keep us, so we were sold to\r\nsome slave-merchants who were going to Constantinople. We traversed\r\nGreece, and arrived half dead at the imperial gates. They were\r\nsurrounded by a crowd of people, who opened a way for us to pass, when\r\nsuddenly my mother, having looked closely at an object which was\r\nattracting their attention, uttered a piercing cry and fell to the\r\nground, pointing as she did so to a head which was placed over the\r\ngates, and beneath which were inscribed these words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_This is the head of Ali Tepelini, Pasha of Yanina._\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cried bitterly, and tried to raise my mother from the earth, but she\r\nwas dead! I was taken to the slave-market, and was purchased by a rich\r\nArmenian. He caused me to be instructed, gave me masters, and when I\r\nwas thirteen years of age he sold me to the Sultan Mahmoud.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf whom I bought her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cas I told you, Albert, with\r\nthe emerald which formed a match to the one I had made into a box for\r\nthe purpose of holding my hashish pills.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you are good, you are great, my lord!\xe2\x80\x9d said Hayd\xc3\xa9e, kissing the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s hand, \xe2\x80\x9cand I am very fortunate in belonging to such a master!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert remained quite bewildered with all that he had seen and heard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, finish your cup of coffee,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cthe history is\r\nended.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 78. We hear From Yanina\r\n\r\nIf Valentine could have seen the trembling step and agitated\r\ncountenance of Franz when he quitted the chamber of M. Noirtier, even\r\nshe would have been constrained to pity him. Villefort had only just\r\ngiven utterance to a few incoherent sentences, and then retired to his\r\nstudy, where he received about two hours afterwards the following\r\nletter:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter all the disclosures which were made this morning, M. Noirtier de\r\nVillefort must see the utter impossibility of any alliance being formed\r\nbetween his family and that of M. Franz d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay. M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay must say\r\nthat he is shocked and astonished that M. de Villefort, who appeared to\r\nbe aware of all the circumstances detailed this morning, should not\r\nhave anticipated him in this announcement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nNo one who had seen the magistrate at this moment, so thoroughly\r\nunnerved by the recent inauspicious combination of circumstances, would\r\nhave supposed for an instant that he had anticipated the annoyance;\r\nalthough it certainly never had occurred to him that his father would\r\ncarry candor, or rather rudeness, so far as to relate such a history.\r\nAnd in justice to Villefort, it must be understood that M. Noirtier,\r\nwho never cared for the opinion of his son on any subject, had always\r\nomitted to explain the affair to Villefort, so that he had all his life\r\nentertained the belief that General de Quesnel, or the Baron d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay,\r\nas he was alternately styled, according as the speaker wished to\r\nidentify him by his own family name, or by the title which had been\r\nconferred on him, fell the victim of assassination, and not that he was\r\nkilled fairly in a duel. This harsh letter, coming as it did from a man\r\ngenerally so polite and respectful, struck a mortal blow at the pride\r\nof Villefort.\r\n\r\nHardly had he read the letter, when his wife entered. The sudden\r\ndeparture of Franz, after being summoned by M. Noirtier, had so much\r\nastonished everyone, that the position of Madame de Villefort, left\r\nalone with the notary and the witnesses, became every moment more\r\nembarrassing. Determined to bear it no longer, she arose and left the\r\nroom; saying she would go and make some inquiries into the cause of his\r\nsudden disappearance.\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s communications on the subject were very limited and\r\nconcise; he told her, in fact, that an explanation had taken place\r\nbetween M. Noirtier, M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, and himself, and that the marriage of\r\nValentine and Franz would consequently be broken off. This was an\r\nawkward and unpleasant thing to have to report to those who were\r\nwaiting. She therefore contented herself with saying that M. Noirtier\r\nhaving at the commencement of the discussion been attacked by a sort of\r\napoplectic fit, the affair would necessarily be deferred for some days\r\nlonger. This news, false as it was following so singularly in the train\r\nof the two similar misfortunes which had so recently occurred,\r\nevidently astonished the auditors, and they retired without a word.\r\n\r\nDuring this time Valentine, at once terrified and happy, after having\r\nembraced and thanked the feeble old man for thus breaking with a single\r\nblow the chain which she had been accustomed to consider as\r\nirrefragable, asked leave to retire to her own room, in order to\r\nrecover her composure. Noirtier looked the permission which she\r\nsolicited. But instead of going to her own room, Valentine, having once\r\ngained her liberty, entered the gallery, and, opening a small door at\r\nthe end of it, found herself at once in the garden.\r\n\r\nIn the midst of all the strange events which had crowded one on the\r\nother, an indefinable sentiment of dread had taken possession of\r\nValentine\xe2\x80\x99s mind. She expected every moment that she should see Morrel\r\nappear, pale and trembling, to forbid the signing of the contract, like\r\nthe Laird of Ravenswood in _The Bride of Lammermoor_.\r\n\r\nIt was high time for her to make her appearance at the gate, for\r\nMaximilian had long awaited her coming. He had half guessed what was\r\ngoing on when he saw Franz quit the cemetery with M. de Villefort. He\r\nfollowed M. d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\x89pinay, saw him enter, afterwards go out, and then\r\nre-enter with Albert and Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. He had no longer any doubts as\r\nto the nature of the conference; he therefore quickly went to the gate\r\nin the clover-patch, prepared to hear the result of the proceedings,\r\nand very certain that Valentine would hasten to him the first moment\r\nshe should be set at liberty. He was not mistaken; peering through the\r\ncrevices of the wooden partition, he soon discovered the young girl,\r\nwho cast aside all her usual precautions and walked at once to the\r\nbarrier. The first glance which Maximilian directed towards her\r\nentirely reassured him, and the first words she spoke made his heart\r\nbound with delight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are saved!\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaved?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Morrel, not being able to conceive such intense\r\nhappiness; \xe2\x80\x9cby whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my grandfather. Oh, Morrel, pray love him for all his goodness to\r\nus!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel swore to love him with all his soul; and at that moment he could\r\nsafely promise to do so, for he felt as though it were not enough to\r\nlove him merely as a friend or even as a father, he worshiped him as a\r\ngod.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut tell me, Valentine, how has it all been effected? What strange\r\nmeans has he used to compass this blessed end?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine was on the point of relating all that had passed, but she\r\nsuddenly remembered that in doing so she must reveal a terrible secret\r\nwhich concerned others as well as her grandfather, and she said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt some future time I will tell you all about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut when will that be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I am your wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe conversation had now turned upon a topic so pleasing to Morrel,\r\nthat he was ready to accede to anything that Valentine thought fit to\r\npropose, and he likewise felt that a piece of intelligence such as he\r\njust heard ought to be more than sufficient to content him for one day.\r\nHowever, he would not leave without the promise of seeing Valentine\r\nagain the next night. Valentine promised all that Morrel required of\r\nher, and certainly it was less difficult now for her to believe that\r\nshe should marry Maximilian than it was an hour ago to assure herself\r\nthat she should not marry Franz.\r\n\r\nDuring the time occupied by the interview we have just detailed, Madame\r\nde Villefort had gone to visit M. Noirtier. The old man looked at her\r\nwith that stern and forbidding expression with which he was accustomed\r\nto receive her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cit is superfluous for me to tell you that Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmarriage is broken off, since it was here that the affair was\r\nconcluded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier\xe2\x80\x99s countenance remained immovable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut one thing I can tell you, of which I do not think you are aware;\r\nthat is, that I have always been opposed to this marriage, and that the\r\ncontract was entered into entirely without my consent or approbation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier regarded his daughter-in-law with the look of a man desiring\r\nan explanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow that this marriage, which I know you so much disliked, is done\r\naway with, I come to you on an errand which neither M. de Villefort nor\r\nValentine could consistently undertake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier\xe2\x80\x99s eyes demanded the nature of her mission.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI come to entreat you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cas the\r\nonly one who has the right of doing so, inasmuch as I am the only one\r\nwho will receive no personal benefit from the transaction,\xe2\x80\x94I come to\r\nentreat you to restore, not your love, for that she has always\r\npossessed, but to restore your fortune to your granddaughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a doubtful expression in Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s eyes; he was evidently\r\ntrying to discover the motive of this proceeding, and he could not\r\nsucceed in doing so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I hope, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthat your intentions\r\naccord with my request?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier made a sign that they did.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cI will leave you\r\noverwhelmed with gratitude and happiness at your prompt acquiescence to\r\nmy wishes.\xe2\x80\x9d She then bowed to M. Noirtier and retired.\r\n\r\nThe next day M. Noirtier sent for the notary; the first will was torn\r\nup and a second made, in which he left the whole of his fortune to\r\nValentine, on condition that she should never be separated from him. It\r\nwas then generally reported that Mademoiselle de Villefort, the heiress\r\nof the marquis and marchioness of Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, had regained the good\r\ngraces of her grandfather, and that she would ultimately be in\r\npossession of an income of 300,000 livres.\r\n\r\nWhile all the proceedings relative to the dissolution of the\r\nmarriage-contract were being carried on at the house of M. de\r\nVillefort, Monte Cristo had paid his visit to the Count of Morcerf,\r\nwho, in order to lose no time in responding to M. Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 wishes, and\r\nat the same time to pay all due deference to his position in society,\r\ndonned his uniform of lieutenant-general, which he ornamented with all\r\nhis crosses, and thus attired, ordered his finest horses and drove to\r\nthe Rue de la Chauss\xc3\xa9e d\xe2\x80\x99Antin.\r\n\r\nDanglars was balancing his monthly accounts, and it was perhaps not the\r\nmost favorable moment for finding him in his best humor. At the first\r\nsight of his old friend, Danglars assumed his majestic air, and settled\r\nhimself in his easy-chair.\r\n\r\nMorcerf, usually so stiff and formal, accosted the banker in an affable\r\nand smiling manner, and, feeling sure that the overture he was about to\r\nmake would be well received, he did not consider it necessary to adopt\r\nany man\xc5\x93uvres in order to gain his end, but went at once straight to\r\nthe point.\r\n\r\n40086m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, baron,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9chere I am at last; some time has elapsed since\r\nour plans were formed, and they are not yet executed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorcerf paused at these words, quietly waiting till the cloud should\r\nhave dispersed which had gathered on the brow of Danglars, and which he\r\nattributed to his silence; but, on the contrary, to his great surprise,\r\nit grew darker and darker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo what do you allude, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; as if he were trying\r\nin vain to guess at the possible meaning of the general\xe2\x80\x99s words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cI see you are a stickler for forms, my dear sir,\r\nand you would remind me that the ceremonial rites should not be\r\nomitted. _Ma foi_, I beg your pardon, but as I have but one son, and it\r\nis the first time I have ever thought of marrying him, I am still\r\nserving my apprenticeship, you know; come, I will reform.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Morcerf with a forced smile arose, and, making a low bow to M.\r\nDanglars, said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBaron, I have the honor of asking of you the hand of Mademoiselle\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie Danglars for my son, the Vicomte Albert de Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Danglars, instead of receiving this address in the favorable manner\r\nwhich Morcerf had expected, knit his brow, and without inviting the\r\ncount, who was still standing, to take a seat, he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, it will be necessary to reflect before I give you an\r\nanswer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo reflect?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, more and more astonished; \xe2\x80\x9chave you not had\r\nenough time for reflection during the eight years which have elapsed\r\nsince this marriage was first discussed between us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d said the banker, \xe2\x80\x9cthings are constantly occurring in the world\r\nto induce us to lay aside our most established opinions, or at all\r\nevents to cause us to remodel them according to the change of\r\ncircumstances, which may have placed affairs in a totally different\r\nlight to that in which we at first viewed them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not understand you, baron,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I mean to say is this, sir,\xe2\x80\x94that during the last fortnight\r\nunforeseen circumstances have occurred\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cbut is it a play we are acting?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA play?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, for it is like one; pray let us come more to the point, and\r\nendeavor thoroughly to understand each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is quite my desire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have seen M. de Monte Cristo have you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see him very often,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, drawing himself up; \xe2\x80\x9che is a\r\nparticular friend of mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, in one of your late conversations with him, you said that I\r\nappeared to be forgetful and irresolute concerning this marriage, did\r\nyou not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did say so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, here I am, proving at once that I am really neither the one nor\r\nthe other, by entreating you to keep your promise on that score.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars did not answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you so soon changed your mind,\xe2\x80\x9d added Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cor have you only\r\nprovoked my request that you may have the pleasure of seeing me\r\nhumbled?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars, seeing that if he continued the conversation in the same tone\r\nin which he had begun it, the whole thing might turn out to his own\r\ndisadvantage, turned to Morcerf, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount, you must doubtless be surprised at my reserve, and I assure you\r\nit costs me much to act in such a manner towards you; but, believe me\r\nwhen I say that imperative necessity has imposed the painful task upon\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese are all so many empty words, my dear sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf: \xe2\x80\x9cthey\r\nmight satisfy a new acquaintance, but the Comte de Morcerf does not\r\nrank in that list; and when a man like him comes to another, recalls to\r\nhim his plighted word, and this man fails to redeem the pledge, he has\r\nat least a right to exact from him a good reason for so doing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars was a coward, but did not wish to appear so; he was piqued at\r\nthe tone which Morcerf had just assumed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not without a good reason for my conduct,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the banker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean to say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean to say that I have a good reason, but that it is difficult to\r\nexplain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must be aware, at all events, that it is impossible for me to\r\nunderstand motives before they are explained to me; but one thing at\r\nleast is clear, which is, that you decline allying yourself with my\r\nfamily.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cI merely suspend my decision, that is all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you really flatter yourself that I shall yield to all your\r\ncaprices, and quietly and humbly await the time of again being received\r\ninto your good graces?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, count, if you will not wait, we must look upon these projects as\r\nif they had never been entertained.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count bit his lips till the blood almost started, to prevent the\r\nebullition of anger which his proud and irritable temper scarcely\r\nallowed him to restrain; understanding, however, that in the present\r\nstate of things the laugh would decidedly be against him, he turned\r\nfrom the door, towards which he had been directing his steps, and again\r\nconfronted the banker. A cloud settled on his brow, evincing decided\r\nanxiety and uneasiness, instead of the expression of offended pride\r\nwhich had lately reigned there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Danglars,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have been acquainted for many\r\nyears, and consequently we ought to make some allowance for each\r\nother\xe2\x80\x99s failings. You owe me an explanation, and really it is but fair\r\nthat I should know what circumstance has occurred to deprive my son of\r\nyour favor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is from no personal ill-feeling towards the viscount, that is all I\r\ncan say, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars, who resumed his insolent manner as\r\nsoon as he perceived that Morcerf was a little softened and calmed\r\ndown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd towards whom do you bear this personal ill-feeling, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMorcerf, turning pale with anger. The expression of the count\xe2\x80\x99s face\r\nhad not remained unperceived by the banker; he fixed on him a look of\r\ngreater assurance than before, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may, perhaps, be better satisfied that I should not go farther\r\ninto particulars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA tremor of suppressed rage shook the whole frame of the count, and\r\nmaking a violent effort over himself, he said: \xe2\x80\x9cI have a right to\r\ninsist on your giving me an explanation. Is it Madame de Morcerf who\r\nhas displeased you? Is it my fortune which you find insufficient? Is it\r\nbecause my opinions differ from yours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing of the kind, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars: \xe2\x80\x9cif such had been the\r\ncase, I only should have been to blame, inasmuch as I was aware of all\r\nthese things when I made the engagement. No, do not seek any longer to\r\ndiscover the reason. I really am quite ashamed to have been the cause\r\nof your undergoing such severe self-examination; let us drop the\r\nsubject, and adopt the middle course of delay, which implies neither a\r\nrupture nor an engagement. _Ma foi_, there is no hurry. My daughter is\r\nonly seventeen years old, and your son twenty-one. While we wait, time\r\nwill be progressing, events will succeed each other; things which in\r\nthe evening look dark and obscure, appear but too clearly in the light\r\nof morning, and sometimes the utterance of one word, or the lapse of a\r\nsingle day, will reveal the most cruel calumnies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCalumnies, did you say, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morcerf, turning livid with rage.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes anyone dare to slander me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, I told you that I considered it best to avoid all\r\nexplanation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, sir, I am patiently to submit to your refusal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, although I assure you the refusal is as painful for me to\r\ngive as it is for you to receive, for I had reckoned on the honor of\r\nyour alliance, and the breaking off of a marriage contract always\r\ninjures the lady more than the gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will speak no more on the subject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd clutching his gloves in anger, he left the apartment. Danglars\r\nobserved that during the whole conversation Morcerf had never once\r\ndared to ask if it was on his own account that Danglars recalled his\r\nword.\r\n\r\nThat evening he had a long conference with several friends; and M.\r\nCavalcanti, who had remained in the drawing-room with the ladies, was\r\nthe last to leave the banker\xe2\x80\x99s house.\r\n\r\nThe next morning, as soon as he awoke, Danglars asked for the\r\nnewspapers; they were brought to him; he laid aside three or four, and\r\nat last fixed on _l\xe2\x80\x99Impartial_, the paper of which Beauchamp was the\r\nchief editor. He hastily tore off the cover, opened the journal with\r\nnervous precipitation, passed contemptuously over the Paris jottings,\r\nand arriving at the miscellaneous intelligence, stopped with a\r\nmalicious smile, at a paragraph headed\r\n\r\n_We hear from Yanina._\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Danglars, after having read the paragraph; \xe2\x80\x9chere\r\nis a little article on Colonel Fernand, which, if I am not mistaken,\r\nwould render the explanation which the Comte de Morcerf required of me\r\nperfectly unnecessary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the same moment, that is, at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, Albert de\r\nMorcerf, dressed in a black coat buttoned up to his chin, might have\r\nbeen seen walking with a quick and agitated step in the direction of\r\nMonte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s house in the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es. When he presented himself\r\nat the gate the porter informed him that the Count had gone out about\r\nhalf an hour previously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he take Baptistin with him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCall him, then; I wish to speak to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe concierge went to seek the valet de chambre, and returned with him\r\nin an instant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy good friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI beg pardon for my intrusion, but I\r\nwas anxious to know from your own mouth if your master was really out\r\nor not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is really out, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Baptistin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOut, even to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know how happy my master always is to receive the vicomte,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nBaptistin; \xe2\x80\x9cand I should therefore never think of including him in any\r\ngeneral order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right; and now I wish to see him on an affair of great\r\nimportance. Do you think it will be long before he comes in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I think not, for he ordered his breakfast at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will go and take a turn in the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es, and at ten\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock I will return here; meanwhile, if the count should come in,\r\nwill you beg him not to go out again without seeing me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may depend on my doing so, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Baptistin.\r\n\r\nAlbert left the cab in which he had come at the count\xe2\x80\x99s door, intending\r\nto take a turn on foot. As he was passing the All\xc3\xa9e des Veuves, he\r\nthought he saw the count\xe2\x80\x99s horses standing at Gosset\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nshooting-gallery; he approached, and soon recognized the coachman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the count shooting in the gallery?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the coachman. While he was speaking, Albert had\r\nheard the report of two or three pistol-shots. He entered, and on his\r\nway met the waiter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lad; \xe2\x80\x9cbut will you have the kindness to\r\nwait a moment?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for, Philip?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Albert, who, being a constant visitor there,\r\ndid not understand this opposition to his entrance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause the person who is now in the gallery prefers being alone, and\r\nnever practices in the presence of anyone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot even before you, Philip? Then who loads his pistol?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis servant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Nubian?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA negro.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is he, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know this gentleman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and I am come to look for him; he is a friend of mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that is quite another thing, then. I will go immediately and\r\ninform him of your arrival.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Philip, urged by his own curiosity, entered the gallery; a second\r\nafterwards, Monte Cristo appeared on the threshold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ask your pardon, my dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cfor following you\r\nhere, and I must first tell you that it was not the fault of your\r\nservants that I did so; I alone am to blame for the indiscretion. I\r\nwent to your house, and they told me you were out, but that they\r\nexpected you home at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock to breakfast. I was walking about in\r\norder to pass away the time till ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock, when I caught sight of\r\nyour carriage and horses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you have just said induces me to hope that you intend\r\nbreakfasting with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40092m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, thank you, I am thinking of other things besides breakfast just\r\nnow; perhaps we may take that meal at a later hour and in worse\r\ncompany.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat on earth are you talking of?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am to fight today.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the sake of fighting!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I understand that, but what is the quarrel? People fight for all\r\nsorts of reasons, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fight in the cause of honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that is something serious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo serious, that I come to beg you to render me a service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be my second.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is a serious matter, and we will not discuss it here; let us\r\nspeak of nothing till we get home. Ali, bring me some water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count turned up his sleeves, and passed into the little vestibule\r\nwhere the gentlemen were accustomed to wash their hands after shooting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in, my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said Philip in a low tone, \xe2\x80\x9cand I will show you\r\nsomething droll.\xe2\x80\x9d Morcerf entered, and in place of the usual target, he\r\nsaw some playing-cards fixed against the wall. At a distance Albert\r\nthought it was a complete suit, for he counted from the ace to the ten.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ha,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI see you were preparing for a game of cards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cI was making a suit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose are really aces and twos which you see, but my shots have turned\r\nthem into threes, fives, sevens, eights, nines, and tens.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert approached. In fact, the bullets had actually pierced the cards\r\nin the exact places which the painted signs would otherwise have\r\noccupied, the lines and distances being as regularly kept as if they\r\nhad been ruled with pencil. In going up to the target Morcerf picked up\r\ntwo or three swallows that had been rash enough to come within the\r\nrange of the count\xe2\x80\x99s pistol.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Diable!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have, my dear viscount?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, wiping his\r\nhands on the towel which Ali had brought him; \xe2\x80\x9cI must occupy my leisure\r\nmoments in some way or other. But come, I am waiting for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBoth men entered Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s carriage, which in the course of a few\r\nminutes deposited them safely at No. 30. Monte Cristo took Albert into\r\nhis study, and pointing to a seat, placed another for himself. \xe2\x80\x9cNow let\r\nus talk the matter over quietly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see I am perfectly composed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith whom are you going to fight?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith Beauchamp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of your friends!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course; it is always with friends that one fights.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you have some cause of quarrel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40094m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has he done to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere appeared in his journal last night\xe2\x80\x94but wait, and read for\r\nyourself.\xe2\x80\x9d And Albert handed over the paper to the count, who read as\r\nfollows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA correspondent at Yanina informs us of a fact of which until now we\r\nhad remained in ignorance. The castle which formed the protection of\r\nthe town was given up to the Turks by a French officer named Fernand,\r\nin whom the grand vizier, Ali Tepelini, had reposed the greatest\r\nconfidence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you see in that to annoy you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do I see in it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; what does it signify to you if the castle of Yanina was given up\r\nby a French officer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt signifies to my father, the Count of Morcerf, whose Christian name\r\nis Fernand!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid your father serve under Ali Pasha?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; that is to say, he fought for the independence of the Greeks, and\r\nhence arises the calumny.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my dear viscount, do talk reason!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not desire to do otherwise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, just tell me who the devil should know in France that the officer\r\nFernand and the Count of Morcerf are one and the same person? and who\r\ncares now about Yanina, which was taken as long ago as the year 1822 or\r\n1823?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat just shows the meanness of this slander. They have allowed all\r\nthis time to elapse, and then all of a sudden rake up events which have\r\nbeen forgotten to furnish materials for scandal, in order to tarnish\r\nthe lustre of our high position. I inherit my father\xe2\x80\x99s name, and I do\r\nnot choose that the shadow of disgrace should darken it. I am going to\r\nBeauchamp, in whose journal this paragraph appears, and I shall insist\r\non his retracting the assertion before two witnesses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeauchamp will never retract.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen we must fight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo you will not, for he will tell you, what is very true, that perhaps\r\nthere were fifty officers in the Greek army bearing the same name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will fight, nevertheless. I will efface that blot on my father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncharacter. My father, who was such a brave soldier, whose career was so\r\nbrilliant\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, well, he will add, \xe2\x80\x98We are warranted in believing that this\r\nFernand is not the illustrious Count of Morcerf, who also bears the\r\nsame Christian name.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am determined not to be content with anything short of an entire\r\nretractation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you intend to make him do it in the presence of two witnesses, do\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do wrong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich means, I suppose, that you refuse the service which I asked of\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know my theory regarding duels; I told you my opinion on that\r\nsubject, if you remember, when we were at Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless, my dear count, I found you this morning engaged in an\r\noccupation but little consistent with the notions you profess to\r\nentertain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, my dear fellow, you understand one must never be eccentric.\r\nIf one\xe2\x80\x99s lot is cast among fools, it is necessary to study folly. I\r\nshall perhaps find myself one day called out by some harebrained scamp,\r\nwho has no more real cause of quarrel with me than you have with\r\nBeauchamp; he may take me to task for some foolish trifle or other, he\r\nwill bring his witnesses, or will insult me in some public place, and I\r\nam expected to kill him for all that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou admit that you would fight, then? Well, if so, why do you object\r\nto my doing so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not say that you ought not to fight, I only say that a duel is a\r\nserious thing, and ought not to be undertaken without due reflection.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he reflect before he insulted my father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he spoke hastily, and owns that he did so, you ought to be\r\nsatisfied.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear count, you are far too indulgent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are far too exacting. Supposing, for instance, and do not be\r\nangry at what I am going to say\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSupposing the assertion to be really true?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA son ought not to submit to such a stain on his father\xe2\x80\x99s honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi!_ we live in times when there is much to which we must\r\nsubmit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is precisely the fault of the age.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you undertake to reform it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, as far as I am personally concerned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you are indeed exacting, my dear fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I own it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you quite impervious to good advice?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot when it comes from a friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you account me that title?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, before going to Beauchamp with your witnesses, seek\r\nfurther information on the subject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom Hayd\xc3\xa9e.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what can be the use of mixing a woman up in the affair?\xe2\x80\x94what can\r\nshe do in it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe can declare to you, for example, that your father had no hand\r\nwhatever in the defeat and death of the vizier; or if by chance he had,\r\nindeed, the misfortune to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have told you, my dear count, that I would not for one moment admit\r\nof such a proposition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou reject this means of information, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do\xe2\x80\x94most decidedly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen let me offer one more word of advice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo so, then, but let it be the last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not wish to hear it, perhaps?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, I request it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not take any witnesses with you when you go to Beauchamp\xe2\x80\x94visit him\r\nalone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would be contrary to all custom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour case is not an ordinary one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is your reason for advising me to go alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause then the affair will rest between you and Beauchamp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do so. If Beauchamp be disposed to retract, you ought at least\r\nto give him the opportunity of doing it of his own free will,\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nsatisfaction to you will be the same. If, on the contrary, he refuses\r\nto do so, it will then be quite time enough to admit two strangers into\r\nyour secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey will not be strangers, they will be friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, but the friends of today are the enemies of tomorrow; Beauchamp,\r\nfor instance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you recommend\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI recommend you to be prudent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you advise me to go alone to Beauchamp?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do, and I will tell you why. When you wish to obtain some concession\r\nfrom a man\xe2\x80\x99s self-love, you must avoid even the appearance of wishing\r\nto wound it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe you are right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am glad of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I will go alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo; but you would do better still by not going at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo so, then; it will be a wiser plan than the first which you\r\nproposed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if, in spite of all my precautions, I am at last obliged to fight,\r\nwill you not be my second?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear viscount,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must have seen\r\nbefore today that at all times and in all places I have been at your\r\ndisposal, but the service which you have just demanded of me is one\r\nwhich it is out of my power to render you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you may know at some future period, and in the mean time I\r\nrequest you to excuse my declining to put you in possession of my\r\nreasons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will have Franz and Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; they will be the very men\r\nfor it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo so, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if I do fight, you will surely not object to giving me a lesson or\r\ntwo in shooting and fencing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat, too, is impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a singular being you are!\xe2\x80\x94you will not interfere in anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right\xe2\x80\x94that is the principle on which I wish to act.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will say no more about it, then. Good-bye, count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorcerf took his hat, and left the room. He found his carriage at the\r\ndoor, and doing his utmost to restrain his anger he went at once to\r\nfind Beauchamp, who was in his office. It was a gloomy, dusty-looking\r\napartment, such as journalists\xe2\x80\x99 offices have always been from time\r\nimmemorial. The servant announced M. Albert de Morcerf. Beauchamp\r\nrepeated the name to himself, as though he could scarcely believe that\r\nhe had heard aright, and then gave orders for him to be admitted.\r\nAlbert entered.\r\n\r\nBeauchamp uttered an exclamation of surprise on seeing his friend leap\r\nover and trample under foot all the newspapers which were strewed about\r\nthe room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis way, this way, my dear Albert!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, holding out his hand to\r\nthe young man. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you out of your senses, or do you come peaceably to\r\ntake breakfast with me? Try and find a seat\xe2\x80\x94there is one by that\r\ngeranium, which is the only thing in the room to remind me that there\r\nare other leaves in the world besides leaves of paper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeauchamp,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cit is of your journal that I come to speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed? What do you wish to say about it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI desire that a statement contained in it should be rectified.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo what do you refer? But pray sit down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, with a cold and formal bow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you now have the kindness to explain the nature of the statement\r\nwhich has displeased you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn announcement has been made which implicates the honor of a member\r\nof my family.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, much surprised; \xe2\x80\x9csurely you must be\r\nmistaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe story sent you from Yanina.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYanina?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; really you appear to be totally ignorant of the cause which\r\nbrings me here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch is really the case, I assure you, upon my honor! Baptiste, give\r\nme yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s paper,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, I have brought mine with me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert.\r\n\r\nBeauchamp took the paper, and read the article to which Albert pointed\r\nin an undertone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see it is a serious annoyance,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, when Beauchamp had\r\nfinished the perusal of the paragraph.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the officer referred to a relation of yours, then?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the\r\njournalist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, blushing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what do you wish me to do for you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp mildly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Beauchamp, I wish you to contradict this statement.\xe2\x80\x9d Beauchamp\r\nlooked at Albert with a benevolent expression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthis matter will want a good deal of talking over; a\r\nretractation is always a serious thing, you know. Sit down, and I will\r\nread it again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert resumed his seat, and Beauchamp read, with more attention than\r\nat first, the lines denounced by his friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert in a determined tone, \xe2\x80\x9cyou see that your paper has\r\ninsulted a member of my family, and I insist on a retractation being\r\nmade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou insist?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I insist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPermit me to remind you that you are not in the Chamber, my dear\r\nviscount.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor do I wish to be there,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man, rising. \xe2\x80\x9cI repeat\r\nthat I am determined to have the announcement of yesterday\r\ncontradicted. You have known me long enough,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Albert, biting\r\nhis lips convulsively, for he saw that Beauchamp\xe2\x80\x99s anger was beginning\r\nto rise,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyou have been my friend, and therefore sufficiently intimate\r\nwith me to be aware that I am likely to maintain my resolution on this\r\npoint.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I have been your friend, Morcerf, your present manner of speaking\r\nwould almost lead me to forget that I ever bore that title. But wait a\r\nmoment, do not let us get angry, or at least not yet. You are irritated\r\nand vexed\xe2\x80\x94tell me how this Fernand is related to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is merely my father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cM. Fernand Mondego, Count of\r\nMorcerf, an old soldier who has fought in twenty battles and whose\r\nhonorable scars they would denounce as badges of disgrace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it your father?\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is quite another thing. Then\r\nI can well understand your indignation, my dear Albert.
