I will look at\r\nit again;\xe2\x80\x9d and he read the paragraph for the third time, laying a\r\nstress on each word as he proceeded. \xe2\x80\x9cBut the paper nowhere identifies\r\nthis Fernand with your father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40100m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but the connection will be seen by others, and therefore I will\r\nhave the article contradicted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the words _I will_, Beauchamp steadily raised his eyes to Albert\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncountenance, and then as gradually lowering them, he remained\r\nthoughtful for a few moments.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will retract this assertion, will you not, Beauchamp?\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert\r\nwith increased though stifled anger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImmediately?\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I am convinced that the statement is false.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe thing is worth looking into, and I will take pains to investigate\r\nthe matter thoroughly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what is there to investigate, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, enraged beyond\r\nmeasure at Beauchamp\xe2\x80\x99s last remark. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you do not believe that it is\r\nmy father, say so immediately; and if, on the contrary, you believe it\r\nto be him, state your reasons for doing so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBeauchamp looked at Albert with the smile which was so peculiar to him,\r\nand which in its numerous modifications served to express every varied\r\nemotion of his mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, \xe2\x80\x9cif you came to me with the idea of demanding\r\nsatisfaction, you should have gone at once to the point, and not have\r\nentertained me with the idle conversation to which I have been\r\npatiently listening for the last half hour. Am I to put this\r\nconstruction on your visit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, if you will not consent to retract that infamous calumny.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a moment\xe2\x80\x94no threats, if you please, M. Fernand Mondego, Vicomte\r\nde Morcerf; I never allow them from my enemies, and therefore shall not\r\nput up with them from my friends. You insist on my contradicting the\r\narticle relating to General Fernand, an article with which, I assure\r\nyou on my word of honor, I had nothing whatever to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I insist on it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, whose mind was beginning to get\r\nbewildered with the excitement of his feelings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if I refuse to retract, you wish to fight, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp\r\nin a calm tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, raising his voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9chere is my answer, my dear sir. The article\r\nwas not inserted by me\xe2\x80\x94I was not even aware of it; but you have, by the\r\nstep you have taken, called my attention to the paragraph in question,\r\nand it will remain until it shall be either contradicted or confirmed\r\nby someone who has a right to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, rising, \xe2\x80\x9cI will do myself the honor of sending my\r\nseconds to you, and you will be kind enough to arrange with them the\r\nplace of meeting and the weapons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, my dear sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this evening, if you please, or tomorrow at the latest, we will\r\nmeet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, I will be on the ground at the proper time; but in my opinion\r\n(and I have a right to dictate the preliminaries, as it is I who have\r\nreceived the provocation)\xe2\x80\x94in my opinion the time ought not to be yet. I\r\nknow you to be well skilled in the management of the sword, while I am\r\nonly moderately so; I know, too, that you are a good marksman\xe2\x80\x94there we\r\nare about equal. I know that a duel between us two would be a serious\r\naffair, because you are brave, and I am brave also. I do not therefore\r\nwish either to kill you, or to be killed myself without a cause. Now, I\r\nam going to put a question to you, and one very much to the purpose\r\ntoo. Do you insist on this retractation so far as to kill me if I do\r\nnot make it, although I have repeated more than once, and affirmed on\r\nmy honor, that I was ignorant of the thing with which you charge me,\r\nand although I still declare that it is impossible for anyone but you\r\nto recognize the Count of Morcerf under the name of Fernand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI maintain my original resolution.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, my dear sir; then I consent to cut throats with you. But I\r\nrequire three weeks\xe2\x80\x99 preparation; at the end of that time I shall come\r\nand say to you, \xe2\x80\x98The assertion is false, and I retract it,\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98The\r\nassertion is true,\xe2\x80\x99 when I shall immediately draw the sword from its\r\nsheath, or the pistols from the case, whichever you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree weeks!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cthey will pass as slowly as three\r\ncenturies when I am all the time suffering dishonor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad you continued to remain on amicable terms with me, I should have\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x98Patience, my friend;\xe2\x80\x99 but you have constituted yourself my\r\nenemy, therefore I say, \xe2\x80\x98What does that signify to me, sir?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, let it be three weeks then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x9cbut remember, at the\r\nexpiration of that time no delay or subterfuge will justify you in\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Albert de Morcerf,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, rising in his turn, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot\r\nthrow you out of window for three weeks\xe2\x80\x94that is to say, for twenty-four\r\ndays to come\xe2\x80\x94nor have you any right to split my skull open till that\r\ntime has elapsed. Today is the 29th of August; the 21st of September\r\nwill, therefore, be the conclusion of the term agreed on, and till that\r\ntime arrives\xe2\x80\x94and it is the advice of a gentleman which I am about to\r\ngive you\xe2\x80\x94till then we will refrain from growling and barking like two\r\ndogs chained within sight of each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen he had concluded his speech, Beauchamp bowed coldly to Albert,\r\nturned his back upon him, and went to the press-room. Albert vented his\r\nanger on a pile of newspapers, which he sent flying all over the office\r\nby switching them violently with his stick; after which ebullition he\r\ndeparted\xe2\x80\x94not, however, without walking several times to the door of the\r\npress-room, as if he had half a mind to enter.\r\n\r\n40104m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile Albert was lashing the front of his carriage in the same manner\r\nthat he had the newspapers which were the innocent agents of his\r\ndiscomfiture, as he was crossing the barrier he perceived Morrel, who\r\nwas walking with a quick step and a bright eye. He was passing the\r\nChinese Baths, and appeared to have come from the direction of the\r\nPorte Saint-Martin, and to be going towards the Madeleine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cthere goes a happy man!\xe2\x80\x9d And it so happened Albert\r\nwas not mistaken in his opinion.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 79. The Lemonade\r\n\r\nMorrel was, in fact, very happy. M. Noirtier had just sent for him, and\r\nhe was in such haste to know the reason of his doing so that he had not\r\nstopped to take a cab, placing infinitely more dependence on his own\r\ntwo legs than on the four legs of a cab-horse. He had therefore set off\r\nat a furious rate from the Rue Meslay, and was hastening with rapid\r\nstrides in the direction of the Faubourg Saint-Honor\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\nMorrel advanced with a firm, manly tread, and poor Barrois followed him\r\nas he best might. Morrel was only thirty-one, Barrois was sixty years\r\nof age; Morrel was deeply in love, and Barrois was dying with heat and\r\nexertion. These two men, thus opposed in age and interests, resembled\r\ntwo parts of a triangle, presenting the extremes of separation, yet\r\nnevertheless possessing their point of union. This point of union was\r\nNoirtier, and it was he who had just sent for Morrel, with the request\r\nthat the latter would lose no time in coming to him\xe2\x80\x94a command which\r\nMorrel obeyed to the letter, to the great discomfiture of Barrois. On\r\narriving at the house, Morrel was not even out of breath, for love\r\nlends wings to our desires; but Barrois, who had long forgotten what it\r\nwas to love, was sorely fatigued by the expedition he had been\r\nconstrained to use.\r\n\r\nThe old servant introduced Morrel by a private entrance, closed the\r\ndoor of the study, and soon the rustling of a dress announced the\r\narrival of Valentine. She looked marvellously beautiful in her deep\r\nmourning dress, and Morrel experienced such intense delight in gazing\r\nupon her that he felt as if he could almost have dispensed with the\r\nconversation of her grandfather.\r\n\r\nBut the easy-chair of the old man was heard rolling along the floor,\r\nand he soon made his appearance in the room. Noirtier acknowledged by a\r\nlook of extreme kindness and benevolence the thanks which Morrel\r\nlavished on him for his timely intervention on behalf of Valentine and\r\nhimself\xe2\x80\x94an intervention which had saved them from despair. Morrel then\r\ncast on the invalid an interrogative look as to the new favor which he\r\ndesigned to bestow on him. Valentine was sitting at a little distance\r\nfrom them, timidly awaiting the moment when she should be obliged to\r\nspeak. Noirtier fixed his eyes on her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I to say what you told me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Valentine. Noirtier made a sign\r\nthat she was to do so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine to the young man, who was regarding\r\nher with the most intense interest, \xe2\x80\x9cmy grandfather, M. Noirtier, had a\r\nthousand things to say, which he told me three days ago; and now, he\r\nhas sent for you, that I may repeat them to you. I will repeat them,\r\nthen; and since he has chosen me as his interpreter, I will be faithful\r\nto the trust, and will not alter a word of his intentions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I am listening with the greatest impatience,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young\r\nman; \xe2\x80\x9cspeak, I beg of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine cast down her eyes; this was a good omen for Morrel, for he\r\nknew that nothing but happiness could have the power of thus overcoming\r\nValentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy grandfather intends leaving this house,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cand Barrois is\r\nlooking out for suitable apartments for him in another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you, Mademoiselle de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x94you, who are necessary to M.\r\nNoirtier\xe2\x80\x99s happiness\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cI shall not leave my grandfather,\xe2\x80\x94that is\r\nan understood thing between us. My apartment will be close to his. Now,\r\nM. de Villefort must either give his consent to this plan or his\r\nrefusal; in the first case, I shall leave directly, and in the second,\r\nI shall wait till I am of age, which will be in about ten months. Then\r\nI shall be free, I shall have an independent fortune, and\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd with my grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s consent I shall fulfil the promise which I\r\nhave made you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine pronounced these last few words in such a low tone, that\r\nnothing but Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s intense interest in what she was saying could have\r\nenabled him to hear them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave I not explained your wishes, grandpapa?\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine,\r\naddressing Noirtier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d looked the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnce under my grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s roof, M. Morrel can visit me in the\r\npresence of my good and worthy protector, if we still feel that the\r\nunion we contemplated will be likely to insure our future comfort and\r\nhappiness; in that case I shall expect M. Morrel to come and claim me\r\nat my own hands. But, alas, I have heard it said that hearts inflamed\r\nby obstacles to their desire grew cold in time of security; I trust we\r\nshall never find it so in our experience!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morrel, almost tempted to throw himself on his knees before\r\nNoirtier and Valentine, and to adore them as two superior beings, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\r\nhave I ever done in my life to merit such unbounded happiness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUntil that time,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the young girl in a calm and\r\nself-possessed tone of voice, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will conform to circumstances, and be\r\nguided by the wishes of our friends, so long as those wishes do not\r\ntend finally to separate us; in a word, and I repeat it, because it\r\nexpresses all I wish to convey,\xe2\x80\x94we will wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I swear to make all the sacrifices which this word imposes, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cnot only with resignation, but with cheerfulness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTherefore,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Valentine, looking playfully at Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cno\r\nmore inconsiderate actions\xe2\x80\x94no more rash projects; for you surely would\r\nnot wish to compromise one who from this day regards herself as\r\ndestined, honorably and happily, to bear your name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel looked obedience to her commands. Noirtier regarded the lovers\r\nwith a look of ineffable tenderness, while Barrois, who had remained in\r\nthe room in the character of a man privileged to know everything that\r\npassed, smiled on the youthful couple as he wiped the perspiration from\r\nhis bald forehead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow hot you look, my good Barrois,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, I have been running very fast, mademoiselle, but I must do M.\r\nMorrel the justice to say that he ran still faster.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier directed their attention to a waiter, on which was placed a\r\ndecanter containing lemonade and a glass. The decanter was nearly full,\r\nwith the exception of a little, which had been already drunk by M.\r\nNoirtier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Barrois,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young girl, \xe2\x80\x9ctake some of this lemonade; I\r\nsee you are coveting a good draught of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is, mademoiselle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Barrois, \xe2\x80\x9cI am dying with thirst, and\r\nsince you are so kind as to offer it me, I cannot say I should at all\r\nobject to drinking your health in a glass of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake some, then, and come back immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBarrois took away the waiter, and hardly was he outside the door, which\r\nin his haste he forgot to shut, than they saw him throw back his head\r\nand empty to the very dregs the glass which Valentine had filled.\r\nValentine and Morrel were exchanging their adieux in the presence of\r\nNoirtier when a ring was heard at the door-bell. It was the signal of a\r\nvisit. Valentine looked at her watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is past noon,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cand today is Saturday; I dare say it is\r\nthe doctor, grandpapa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier looked his conviction that she was right in her supposition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will come in here, and M. Morrel had better go,\xe2\x80\x94do you not think\r\nso, grandpapa?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d signed the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBarrois,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cBarrois!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am coming, mademoiselle,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBarrois will open the door for you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, addressing\r\nMorrel. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd now remember one thing, Monsieur Officer, that my\r\ngrandfather commands you not to take any rash or ill-advised step which\r\nwould be likely to compromise our happiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40108m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promised him to wait,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cand I will wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment Barrois entered. \xe2\x80\x9cWho rang?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoctor d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny,\xe2\x80\x9d said Barrois, staggering as if he would fall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter, Barrois?\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine. The old man did not\r\nanswer, but looked at his master with wild staring eyes, while with his\r\ncramped hand he grasped a piece of furniture to enable him to stand\r\nupright.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is going to fall!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morrel.\r\n\r\nThe rigors which had attacked Barrois gradually increased, the features\r\nof the face became quite altered, and the convulsive movement of the\r\nmuscles appeared to indicate the approach of a most serious nervous\r\ndisorder. Noirtier, seeing Barrois in this pitiable condition, showed\r\nby his looks all the various emotions of sorrow and sympathy which can\r\nanimate the heart of man. Barrois made some steps towards his master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9ctell me what is the matter with me. I am\r\nsuffering\xe2\x80\x94I cannot see. A thousand fiery darts are piercing my brain.\r\nAh, don\xe2\x80\x99t touch me, pray don\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy this time his haggard eyes had the appearance of being ready to\r\nstart from their sockets; his head fell back, and the lower extremities\r\nof the body began to stiffen. Valentine uttered a cry of horror; Morrel\r\ntook her in his arms, as if to defend her from some unknown danger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny,\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, in a stifled voice. \xe2\x80\x9cHelp,\r\nhelp!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBarrois turned round and with a great effort stumbled a few steps, then\r\nfell at the feet of Noirtier, and resting his hand on the knee of the\r\ninvalid, exclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy master, my good master!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment M. de Villefort, attracted by the noise, appeared on the\r\nthreshold. Morrel relaxed his hold of Valentine, and retreating to a\r\ndistant corner of the room remained half hidden behind a curtain. Pale\r\nas if he had been gazing on a serpent, he fixed his terrified eye on\r\nthe agonized sufferer.\r\n\r\nNoirtier, burning with impatience and terror, was in despair at his\r\nutter inability to help his old domestic, whom he regarded more in the\r\nlight of a friend than a servant. One might by the fearful swelling of\r\nthe veins of his forehead and the contraction of the muscles round the\r\neye, trace the terrible conflict which was going on between the living\r\nenergetic mind and the inanimate and helpless body.\r\n\r\nBarrois, his features convulsed, his eyes suffused with blood, and his\r\nhead thrown back, was lying at full length, beating the floor with his\r\nhands, while his legs had become so stiff, that they looked as if they\r\nwould break rather than bend. A slight appearance of foam was visible\r\naround the mouth, and he breathed painfully, and with extreme\r\ndifficulty.\r\n\r\nVillefort seemed stupefied with astonishment, and remained gazing\r\nintently on the scene before him without uttering a word. He had not\r\nseen Morrel. After a moment of dumb contemplation, during which his\r\nface became pale and his hair seemed to stand on end, he sprang towards\r\nthe door, crying out:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoctor, doctor! come instantly, pray come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Valentine, calling her step-mother, and running\r\nupstairs to meet her; \xe2\x80\x9ccome quick, quick!\xe2\x80\x94and bring your bottle of\r\nsmelling-salts with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame de Villefort in a harsh and\r\nconstrained tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! come! come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where is the doctor?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cwhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort now deliberately descended the staircase. In one\r\nhand she held her handkerchief, with which she appeared to be wiping\r\nher face, and in the other a bottle of English smelling-salts. Her\r\nfirst look on entering the room was at Noirtier, whose face,\r\nindependent of the emotion which such a scene could not fail of\r\nproducing, proclaimed him to be in possession of his usual health; her\r\nsecond glance was at the dying man. She turned pale, and her eye passed\r\nquickly from the servant and rested on the master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of heaven, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere is the doctor?\r\nHe was with you just now. You see this is a fit of apoplexy, and he\r\nmight be saved if he could but be bled!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he eaten anything lately?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Madame de Villefort, eluding her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x99s question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9che has not even breakfasted. The old man,\r\nwho had preserved all his usual coolness, made a sign to him to do so.\r\nThe young man pressed Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s hand to his lips, and then left the\r\nhouse by a back staircase.\r\n\r\nAt the same moment that he quitted the room, Villefort and the doctor\r\nentered by an opposite door. Barrois was now showing signs of returning\r\nconsciousness. The risis seemed past, a low moaning was heard, and he\r\nraised himself on one knee. D\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny and Villefort laid him on a\r\ncouch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you prescribe, doctor?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me some water and ether. The doctor\r\nleft him in this paroxysm, knowing that he could do nothing to\r\nalleviate it, and, going up to Noirtier, said abruptly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you find yourself?\xe2\x80\x94well?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you any weight on the chest; or does your stomach feel light and\r\ncomfortable\xe2\x80\x94eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you feel pretty much as you generally do after you have had the\r\ndose which I am accustomed to give you every Sunday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid Barrois make your lemonade?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it you who asked him to drink some of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it M. de Villefort?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was your granddaughter, then, was it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA groan from Barrois, accompanied by a yawn which seemed to crack the\r\nvery jawbones, attracted the attention of M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny; he left M.\r\nNoirtier, and returned to the sick man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBarrois,\xe2\x80\x9d said the doctor, \xe2\x80\x9ccan you speak?\xe2\x80\x9d Barrois muttered a few\r\nunintelligible words. \xe2\x80\x9cTry and make an effort to do so, my good man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny. I know it well; I have studied it in all its forms\r\nand in the effects which it produces. I recognized the presence of this\r\npoison in the case of poor Barrois as well as in that of Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran. There is a way of detecting its presence. It restores the\r\nblue color of litmus-paper reddened by an acid, and it turns syrup of\r\nviolets green. We have no litmus-paper, but, see, here they come with\r\nthe syrup of violets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe doctor was right; steps were heard in the passage. M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny\r\nopened the door, and took from the hands of the chambermaid a cup which\r\ncontained two or three spoonfuls of the syrup, he then carefully closed\r\nthe door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the procureur, whose heart beat so loudly that it\r\nmight almost be heard, \xe2\x80\x9chere is in this cup some syrup of violets, and\r\nthis decanter contains the remainder of the lemonade of which M.\r\nNoirtier and Barrois partook. If the lemonade be pure and inoffensive,\r\nthe syrup will retain its color; if, on the contrary, the lemonade be\r\ndrugged with poison, the syrup will become green. Look closely!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe doctor then slowly poured some drops of the lemonade from the\r\ndecanter into the cup, and in an instant a light cloudy sediment began\r\nto form at the bottom of the cup; this sediment first took a blue\r\nshade, then from the color of sapphire it passed to that of opal, and\r\nfrom opal to emerald. The\r\nresult of the experiment left no doubt whatever on the mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe unfortunate Barrois has been poisoned,\xe2\x80\x9d said d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\nwill maintain this assertion before God and man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort said nothing, but he clasped his hands, opened his haggard\r\neyes, and, overcome with his emotion, sank into a chair.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 80. The Accusation\r\n\r\nM. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny soon restored the magistrate to consciousness, who had\r\nlooked like a second corpse in that chamber of death.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, death is in my house!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, rather, crime!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the doctor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot tell you all I feel at this\r\nmoment,\xe2\x80\x94terror, grief, madness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, with an imposing calmness, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I think it is\r\nnow time to act. I think it is time to stop this torrent of mortality.\r\nI can no longer bear to be in possession of these secrets without the\r\nhope of seeing the victims and society generally revenged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort cast a gloomy look around him. \xe2\x80\x9cIn my house,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cin my house!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, magistrate,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, \xe2\x80\x9cshow yourself a man; as an\r\ninterpreter of the law, do honor to your profession by sacrificing your\r\nselfish interests to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou make me shudder, doctor. Do you talk of a sacrifice?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you then suspect anyone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suspect no one; death raps at your door\xe2\x80\x94it enters\xe2\x80\x94it goes, not\r\nblindfolded, but circumspectly, from room to room. Well, I follow its\r\ncourse, I track its passage; I adopt the wisdom of the ancients, and\r\nfeel my way, for my friendship for your family and my respect for you\r\nare as a twofold bandage over my eyes; well\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, speak, speak, doctor; I shall have courage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir, you have in your establishment, or in your family, perhaps,\r\none of the frightful monstrosities of which each century produces only\r\none. Locusta and Agrippina, living at the same time, were an exception,\r\nand proved the determination of Providence to effect the entire ruin of\r\nthe Roman empire, sullied by so many crimes. Brunhilda and Fredegund\r\nwere the results of the painful struggle of civilization in its\r\ninfancy, when man was learning to control mind, were it even by an\r\nemissary from the realms of darkness. All these women had been, or\r\nwere, beautiful. The same flower of innocence had flourished, or was\r\nstill flourishing, on their brow, that is seen on the brow of the\r\nculprit in your house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40120m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVillefort shrieked, clasped his hands, and looked at the doctor with a\r\nsupplicating air. But the latter went on without pity:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Seek whom the crime will profit,\xe2\x80\x99 says an axiom of jurisprudence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoctor,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9calas, doctor, how often has man\xe2\x80\x99s justice\r\nbeen deceived by those fatal words. I know not why, but I feel that\r\nthis crime\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou acknowledge, then, the existence of the crime?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I see too plainly that it does exist. I fear an attack myself, after all\r\nthese disasters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, man!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, \xe2\x80\x9cthe most selfish of all animals, the\r\nmost personal of all creatures, who believes the earth turns, the sun\r\nshines, and death strikes for him alone,\xe2\x80\x94an ant cursing God from the\r\ntop of a blade of grass! And have those who have lost their lives lost\r\nnothing?\xe2\x80\x94M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, M. Noirtier\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow? M. Noirtier?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; think you it was the poor servant\xe2\x80\x99s life was coveted? No, no;\r\nlike Shakespeare\xe2\x80\x99s Polonius, he died for another. It was Noirtier the\r\nlemonade was intended for\xe2\x80\x94it is Noirtier, logically speaking, who drank\r\nit. The other drank it only by accident, and, although Barrois is dead,\r\nit was Noirtier whose death was wished for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why did it not kill my father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told you one evening in the garden after Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndeath\xe2\x80\x94because his system is accustomed to that very poison, and the\r\ndose was trifling to him, which would be fatal to another; because no\r\none knows, not even the assassin, that, for the last twelve months, I\r\nhave given M. Noirtier,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny in the same pitiless tone,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cM.\r\nNoirtier had once made a will against you\xe2\x80\x94against your family\xe2\x80\x94in favor\r\nof the poor, in fact; M. Noirtier is spared, because nothing is\r\nexpected from him. But he has no sooner destroyed his first will and\r\nmade a second, than, for fear he should make a third, he is struck\r\ndown. The will was made the day before yesterday, I believe; you see\r\nthere has been no time lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mercy, M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo mercy, sir! The physician has a sacred mission on earth; and to\r\nfulfil it he begins at the source of life, and goes down to the\r\nmysterious darkness of the tomb. When crime has been committed, and\r\nGod, doubtless in anger, turns away his face, it is for the physician\r\nto bring the culprit to justice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40122m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave mercy on my child, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see it is yourself who have first named her\xe2\x80\x94you, her father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave pity on Valentine! Listen, it is impossible. I would as willingly\r\naccuse myself! Valentine, whose heart is pure as a diamond or a lily!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo pity, procureur; the crime is fragrant. Mademoiselle de Villefort prepared all the cooling\r\ndraughts which Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran took, and Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran is\r\ndead. Mademoiselle de Villefort took from the hands of Barrois, who was\r\nsent out, the lemonade which M. Noirtier had every morning, and he has\r\nescaped by a miracle. Mademoiselle de Villefort is the culprit\xe2\x80\x94she is\r\nthe poisoner! To you, as the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney, I denounce Mademoiselle\r\nde Villefort, do your duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoctor, I resist no longer\xe2\x80\x94I can no longer defend myself\xe2\x80\x94I believe\r\nyou; but, for pity\xe2\x80\x99s sake, spare my life, my honor!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the doctor, with increased vehemence, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\r\nare occasions when I dispense with all foolish human circumspection. If\r\nyour daughter had committed only one crime, and I saw her meditating\r\nanother, I would say \xe2\x80\x98Warn her, punish her, let her pass the remainder\r\nof her life in a convent, weeping and praying.\xe2\x80\x99 If she had committed\r\ntwo crimes, I would say, \xe2\x80\x98Here, M. de Villefort, is a poison that the\r\nprisoner is not acquainted with,\xe2\x80\x94one that has no known antidote, quick\r\nas thought, rapid as lightning, mortal as the thunderbolt; give her\r\nthat poison, recommending her soul to God, and save your honor and your\r\nlife, for it is yours she aims at; and I can picture her approaching\r\nyour pillow with her hypocritical smiles and her sweet exhortations.\r\nWoe to you, M. de Villefort, if you do not strike first!\xe2\x80\x99 This is what\r\nI would say had she only killed two persons but she has seen three\r\ndeaths,\xe2\x80\x94has contemplated three murdered persons,\xe2\x80\x94has knelt by three\r\ncorpses! To the scaffold with the poisoner\xe2\x80\x94to the scaffold! Do you talk\r\nof your honor? Do what I tell you, and immortality awaits you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort fell on his knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cI have not the strength of mind you have, or rather\r\nthat which you would not have, if instead of my daughter Valentine your\r\ndaughter Madeleine were concerned.\xe2\x80\x9d The doctor turned pale. \xe2\x80\x9cDoctor,\r\nevery son of woman is born to suffer and to die; I am content to suffer\r\nand to await death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeware,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, \xe2\x80\x9cit may come slowly; you will see it\r\napproach after having struck your father, your wife, perhaps your son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort, suffocating, pressed the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s arm.\r\n\r\n40124m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he; \xe2\x80\x9cpity me\xe2\x80\x94help me! No, my daughter is not guilty. If\r\nyou drag us both before a tribunal I will still say, \xe2\x80\x98No, my daughter\r\nis not guilty;\xe2\x80\x94there is no crime in my house. I will not acknowledge a\r\ncrime in my house; for when crime enters a dwelling, it is like\r\ndeath\xe2\x80\x94it does not come alone.\xe2\x80\x99 Listen. What does it signify to you if I\r\nam murdered? Are you my friend? Are you a man? Have you a heart? No,\r\nyou are a physician! Well, I tell you I will not drag my daughter\r\nbefore a tribunal, and give her up to the executioner! The bare idea\r\nwould kill me\xe2\x80\x94would drive me like a madman to dig my heart out with my\r\nfinger-nails! I will consent to share this dreadful\r\nsecret with you, but I will not allow shame and remorse to grow and\r\nincrease in my conscience, as crime and misery will in your house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you abandon me, doctor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, for I can follow you no farther, and I only stop at the foot of\r\nthe scaffold. Some further discovery will be made, which will bring\r\nthis dreadful tragedy to a close. Adieu.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI entreat you, doctor!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll the horrors that disturb my thoughts make your house odious and\r\nfatal. Adieu, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne word\xe2\x80\x94one single word more, doctor! You go, leaving me in all the\r\nhorror of my situation, after increasing it by what you have revealed\r\nto me. But what will be reported of the sudden death of the poor old\r\nservant?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny; \xe2\x80\x9cwe will return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe doctor went out first, followed by M. de Villefort. The terrified\r\nservants were on the stairs and in the passage where the doctor would\r\npass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny to Villefort, so loud that all might hear, \xe2\x80\x9cpoor\r\nBarrois has led too sedentary a life of late; accustomed formerly to\r\nride on horseback, or in the carriage, to the four corners of Europe,\r\nthe monotonous walk around that armchair has killed him\xe2\x80\x94his blood has\r\nthickened. He was stout, had a short, thick neck; he was attacked with\r\napoplexy, and I was called in too late. By the way,\xe2\x80\x9d added he in a low\r\ntone, \xe2\x80\x9ctake care to throw away that cup of syrup of violets in the\r\nashes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe doctor, without shaking hands with Villefort, without adding a word\r\nto what he had said, went out, amid the tears and lamentations of the\r\nwhole household. The same evening all Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s servants, who had\r\nassembled in the kitchen, and had a long consultation, came to tell\r\nMadame de Villefort that they wished to leave. No entreaty, no\r\nproposition of increased wages, could induce them to remain; to every\r\nargument they replied, \xe2\x80\x9cWe must go, for death is in this house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey all left, in spite of prayers and entreaties, testifying their\r\nregret at leaving so good a master and mistress, and especially\r\nMademoiselle Valentine, so good, so kind, and so gentle.\r\n\r\nVillefort looked at Valentine as they said this. She was in tears, and,\r\nstrange as it was, in spite of the emotions he felt at the sight of\r\nthese tears, he looked also at Madame de Villefort, and it appeared to\r\nhim as if a slight gloomy smile had passed over her thin lips, like a\r\nmeteor seen passing inauspiciously between two clouds in a stormy sky.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 81. The Room of the Retired Baker\r\n\r\nThe evening of the day on which the Count of Morcerf had left Danglars\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhouse with feelings of shame and anger at the rejection of the\r\nprojected alliance, M. Andrea Cavalcanti, with curled hair, moustaches\r\nin perfect order, and white gloves which fitted admirably, had entered\r\nthe courtyard of the banker\xe2\x80\x99s house in Rue de la Chauss\xc3\xa9e d\xe2\x80\x99Antin. He\r\nhad not been more than ten minutes in the drawing-room before he drew\r\nDanglars aside into the recess of a bow-window, and, after an ingenious\r\npreamble, related to him all his anxieties and cares since his noble\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s departure. He acknowledged the extreme kindness which had been\r\nshown him by the banker\xe2\x80\x99s family, in which he had been received as a\r\nson, and where, besides, his warmest affections had found an object on\r\nwhich to centre in Mademoiselle Danglars.\r\n\r\nDanglars listened with the most profound attention; he had expected\r\nthis declaration for the last two or three days, and when at last it\r\ncame his eyes glistened as much as they had lowered on listening to\r\nMorcerf. He would not, however, yield immediately to the young man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nrequest, but made a few conscientious objections.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you not rather young, M. Andrea, to think of marrying?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think not, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. Cavalcanti; \xe2\x80\x9cin Italy the nobility\r\ngenerally marry young. Life is so uncertain, that we ought to secure\r\nhappiness while it is within our reach.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cin case your proposals, which do me honor,\r\nare accepted by my wife and daughter, by whom shall the preliminary\r\narrangements be settled? So important a negotiation should, I think, be\r\nconducted by the respective fathers of the young people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, my father is a man of great foresight and prudence. Thinking that\r\nI might wish to settle in France, he left me at his departure, together\r\nwith the papers establishing my identity, a letter promising, if he\r\napproved of my choice, 150,000 livres per annum from the day I was\r\nmarried. So far as I can judge, I suppose this to be a quarter of my\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s revenue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9chave always intended giving my daughter 500,000\r\nfrancs as her dowry; she is, besides, my sole heiress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll would then be easily arranged if the baroness and her daughter are\r\nwilling. We should command an annuity of 175,000 livres. Supposing,\r\nalso, I should persuade the marquis to give me my capital, which is not\r\nlikely, but still is possible, we would place these two or three\r\nmillions in your hands, whose talent might make it realize ten per\r\ncent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never give more than four per cent, and generally only three and a\r\nhalf; but to my son-in-law I would give five, and we would share the\r\nprofits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good, father-in-law,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cavalcanti, yielding to his low-born\r\nnature, which would escape sometimes through the aristocratic gloss\r\nwith which he sought to conceal it. Correcting himself immediately, he\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, sir; hope alone makes me almost mad,\xe2\x80\x94what will not\r\nreality do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, who, on his part, did not perceive how soon the\r\nconversation, which was at first disinterested, was turning to a\r\nbusiness transaction, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is, doubtless, a part of your fortune your\r\nfather could not refuse you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat you inherit from your mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly, from my mother, Leonora Corsinari.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much may it amount to?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9cI assure you I have never given the\r\nsubject a thought, but I suppose it must have been at least two\r\nmillions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars felt as much overcome with joy as the miser who finds a lost\r\ntreasure, or as the shipwrecked mariner who feels himself on solid\r\nground instead of in the abyss which he expected would swallow him up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, bowing to the banker respectfully, \xe2\x80\x9cmay I\r\nhope?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may not only hope,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cbut consider it a settled\r\nthing, if no obstacle arises on your part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am, indeed, rejoiced,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars thoughtfully, \xe2\x80\x9chow is it that your patron, M. de\r\nMonte Cristo, did not make his proposal for you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea blushed imperceptibly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have just left the count, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9che is, doubtless, a\r\ndelightful man but inconceivably peculiar in his ideas. He esteems me\r\nhighly. He even told me he had not the slightest doubt that my father\r\nwould give me the capital instead of the interest of my property. He\r\nhas promised to use his influence to obtain it for me; but he also\r\ndeclared that he never had taken on himself the responsibility of\r\nmaking proposals for another, and he never would. I must, however, do\r\nhim the justice to add that he assured me if ever he had regretted the\r\nrepugnance he felt to such a step it was on this occasion, because he\r\nthought the projected union would be a happy and suitable one. Besides,\r\nif he will do nothing officially, he will answer any questions you\r\npropose to him. And now,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, with one of his most charming\r\nsmiles, \xe2\x80\x9chaving finished talking to the father-in-law, I must address\r\nmyself to the banker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what may you have to say to him?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, laughing in his\r\nturn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat the day after tomorrow I shall have to draw upon you for about\r\nfour thousand francs; but the count, expecting my bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s revenue\r\ncould not suffice for the coming month\xe2\x80\x99s outlay, has offered me a draft\r\nfor twenty thousand francs. It bears his signature, as you see, which\r\nis all-sufficient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBring me a million such as that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall be well\r\npleased,\xe2\x80\x9d putting the draft in his pocket. \xe2\x80\x9cFix your own hour for\r\ntomorrow, and my cashier shall call on you with a check for eighty\r\nthousand francs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock then, if you please; I should like it early, as I am\r\ngoing into the country tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock; you are still at the H\xc3\xb4tel des Princes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe following morning, with the banker\xe2\x80\x99s usual punctuality, the eighty\r\nthousand francs were placed in the young man\xe2\x80\x99s hands, as he was on the\r\npoint of starting, after having left two hundred francs for Caderousse.\r\nHe went out chiefly to avoid this dangerous enemy, and returned as late\r\nas possible in the evening.\r\n\r\nBut scarcely had he stepped out of his carriage when the porter met him\r\nwith a parcel in his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthat man has been here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat man?\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea carelessly, apparently forgetting him whom he\r\nbut too well recollected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHim to whom your excellency pays that little annuity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9cmy father\xe2\x80\x99s old servant. Well, you gave him the two\r\nhundred francs I had left for him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d Andrea had expressed a wish to be thus\r\naddressed. \xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the porter, \xe2\x80\x9che would not take them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea turned pale, but as it was dark his pallor was not perceptible.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? he would not take them?\xe2\x80\x9d said he with slight emotion.\r\n\r\n40130m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he wished to speak to your excellency; I told him you were gone\r\nout, and after some dispute he believed me and gave me this letter,\r\nwhich he had brought with him already sealed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive it me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, and he read by the light of his\r\ncarriage-lamp:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98You know where I live; I expect you tomorrow morning at nine\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea examined it carefully, to ascertain if the letter had been\r\nopened, or if any indiscreet eyes had seen its contents; but it was so\r\ncarefully folded, that no one could have read it, and the seal was\r\nperfect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor man, he is a worthy creature.\xe2\x80\x9d He left the\r\nporter to ponder on these words, not knowing which most to admire, the\r\nmaster or the servant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake out the horses quickly, and come up to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea to his\r\ngroom. In two seconds the young man had reached his room and burnt\r\nCaderousse\xe2\x80\x99s letter. The servant entered just as he had finished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are about my height, Pierre,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have that honor, your excellency.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had a new livery yesterday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have an engagement with a pretty little girl for this evening, and\r\ndo not wish to be known; lend me your livery till tomorrow. I may\r\nsleep, perhaps, at an inn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPierre obeyed. Five minutes after, Andrea left the hotel, completely\r\ndisguised, took a cabriolet, and ordered the driver to take him to the\r\nCheval Rouge, at Picpus. The next morning he left that inn as he had\r\nleft the H\xc3\xb4tel des Princes, without being noticed, walked down the\r\nFaubourg Saint-Antoine, along the boulevard to Rue M\xc3\xa9nilmontant, and\r\nstopping at the door of the third house on the left looked for someone\r\nof whom to make inquiry in the porter\xe2\x80\x99s absence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor whom are you looking, my fine fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the fruiteress on the\r\nopposite side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Pailletin, if you please, my good woman,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Andrea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA retired baker?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the fruiteress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe lives at the end of the yard, on the left, on the third story.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40132m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAndrea went as she directed him, and on the third floor he found a\r\nhare\xe2\x80\x99s paw, which, by the hasty ringing of the bell, it was evident he\r\npulled with considerable ill-temper. A moment after Caderousse\xe2\x80\x99s face\r\nappeared at the grating in the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! you are punctual,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as he drew back the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConfound you and your punctuality!\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, throwing himself into\r\na chair in a manner which implied that he would rather have flung it at\r\nthe head of his host.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, my little fellow, don\xe2\x80\x99t be angry. See, I have thought\r\nabout you\xe2\x80\x94look at the good breakfast we are going to have; nothing but\r\nwhat you are fond of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea, indeed, inhaled the scent of something cooking which was not\r\nunwelcome to him, hungry as he was; it was that mixture of fat and\r\ngarlic peculiar to Proven\xc3\xa7al kitchens of an inferior order, added to\r\nthat of dried fish, and above all, the pungent smell of musk and\r\ncloves. These odors escaped from two deep dishes which were covered and\r\nplaced on a stove, and from a copper pan placed in an old iron pot. In\r\nan adjoining room Andrea saw also a tolerably clean table prepared for\r\ntwo, two bottles of wine sealed, the one with green, the other with\r\nyellow, a supply of brandy in a decanter, and a measure of fruit in a\r\ncabbage-leaf, cleverly arranged on an earthenware plate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think of it, my little fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cAy, that\r\nsmells good! You know I used to be a good cook; do you recollect how\r\nyou used to lick your fingers? You were among the first who tasted any\r\nof my dishes, and I think you relished them tolerably.\xe2\x80\x9d While speaking,\r\nCaderousse went on peeling a fresh supply of onions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, ill-temperedly, \xe2\x80\x9cby my faith, if it was only to\r\nbreakfast with you, that you disturbed me, I wish the devil had taken\r\nyou!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse sententiously, \xe2\x80\x9cone can talk while eating.\r\nAnd then, you ungrateful being, you are not pleased to see an old\r\nfriend? I am weeping with joy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was truly crying, but it would have been difficult to say whether\r\njoy or the onions produced the greatest effect on the lachrymal glands\r\nof the old innkeeper of the Pont-du-Gard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, hypocrite,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea; \xe2\x80\x9cyou love me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I do, or may the devil take me. I know it is a weakness,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCaderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it overpowers me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet it has not prevented your sending for me to play me some\r\ntrick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, wiping his large knife on his apron, \xe2\x80\x9cif I did\r\nnot like you, do you think I should endure the wretched life you lead\r\nme? Think for a moment. You have your servant\xe2\x80\x99s clothes on\xe2\x80\x94you\r\ntherefore keep a servant; I have none, and am obliged to prepare my own\r\nmeals. You abuse my cookery because you dine at the table d\xe2\x80\x99h\xc3\xb4te of the\r\nH\xc3\xb4tel des Princes, or the Caf\xc3\xa9 de Paris. Well, I too could keep a\r\nservant; I too could have a tilbury; I too could dine where I like; but\r\nwhy do I not? Because I would not annoy my little Benedetto. Ah, yes; you\r\nlook at my room, my four straw chairs, my images, three francs each.\r\nBut what do you expect? You see I am\r\nobliged to economize, in case your prosperity should cease. Well, my\r\nfriend, fortune is inconstant, as the chaplain of the regiment said. I\r\nknow your prosperity is great, you rascal; you are to marry the\r\ndaughter of Danglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? of Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, to be sure; must I say Baron Danglars? I have a fancy, and mean to get a housekeeper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you shall have your five hundred francs,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it\r\nis very hard for me, my poor Caderousse\xe2\x80\x94you take advantage\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen you have access to countless stores.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne would have said Andrea anticipated his companion\xe2\x80\x99s words, so did\r\nhis eye flash like lightning, but it was but for a moment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cand my protector is very kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat dear protector,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cand how much does he give you\r\nmonthly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive thousand francs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs many thousands as you give me hundreds! Truly, it is only bastards\r\nwho are thus fortunate. Five thousand francs per month! What the devil\r\ncan you do with all that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is no trouble to spend that; and I am like you, I want\r\ncapital.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapital?\xe2\x80\x94yes\xe2\x80\x94I understand\xe2\x80\x94everyone would like capital.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and I shall get it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho will give it to you\xe2\x80\x94your prince?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my prince. But unfortunately I must wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40138m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must wait for what?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor his death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe death of your prince?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause he has made his will in my favor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor how much?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor five hundred thousand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly that? It\xe2\x80\x99s little enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut so it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it cannot be!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you my friend, Caderousse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, in life or death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will tell you a secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut remember\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! _pardieu!_ mute as a carp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I think\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea stopped and looked around.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think? Do not fear; _pardieu!_ we are alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I have discovered my father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour true father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot old Cavalcanti?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, for he has gone again; the true one, as you say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that father is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Caderousse, it is Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you understand, that explains all. He cannot acknowledge me\r\nopenly, it appears, but he does it through M. Cavalcanti, and gives him\r\nfifty thousand francs for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFifty thousand francs for being your father? I would have done it for\r\nhalf that, for twenty thousand, for fifteen thousand; why did you not\r\nthink of me, ungrateful man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid I know anything about it, when it was all done when I was down\r\nthere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, truly? And you say that by his will\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe leaves me five hundred thousand livres.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you sure of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe showed it me; but that is not all\xe2\x80\x94there is a codicil, as I said\r\njust now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProbably.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd in that codicil he acknowledges me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the good father, the brave father, the very honest father!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCaderousse, twirling a plate in the air between his two hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, say if I conceal anything from you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, and your confidence makes you honorable in my opinion; and your\r\nprincely father, is he rich, very rich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he is that; he does not himself know the amount of his fortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it possible?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is evident enough to me, who am always at his house. The other day\r\na banker\xe2\x80\x99s clerk brought him fifty thousand francs in a portfolio about\r\nthe size of your plate; yesterday his banker brought him a hundred\r\nthousand francs in gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse was filled with wonder; the young man\xe2\x80\x99s words sounded to him\r\nlike metal, and he thought he could hear the rushing of cascades of\r\nlouis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you go into that house?\xe2\x80\x9d cried he briskly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse was thoughtful for a moment. It was easy to perceive he was\r\nrevolving some unfortunate idea in his mind. Then suddenly,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow I should like to see all that,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he; \xe2\x80\x9chow beautiful it must\r\nbe!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, in fact, magnificent,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd does he not live in the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, No. 30.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cNo. 30.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a fine house standing alone, between a courtyard and a\r\ngarden,\xe2\x80\x94you must know it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly; but it is not the exterior I care for, it is the interior.\r\nWhat beautiful furniture there must be in it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you ever seen the Tuileries?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it surpasses that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt must be worth one\xe2\x80\x99s while to stoop, Andrea, when that good M. Is it large?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiddling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is it arranged?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFaith, I should require pen, ink, and paper to make a plan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are all here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, briskly. He fetched from an old\r\nsecretaire a sheet of white paper and pen and ink. \xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCaderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cdraw me all that on the paper, my boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea took the pen with an imperceptible smile and began.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe house, as I said, is between the court and the garden; in this\r\nway, do you see?\xe2\x80\x9d Andrea drew the garden, the court and the house.\r\n\r\n40142m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHigh walls?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot more than eight or ten feet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not prudent,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the court are orange-trees in pots, turf, and clumps of flowers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd no steel-traps?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe stables?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre on either side of the gate, which you see there.\xe2\x80\x9d And Andrea\r\ncontinued his plan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us see the ground floor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the ground floor, dining-room, two drawing-rooms, billiard-room,\r\nstaircase in the hall, and a little back staircase.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWindows?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMagnificent windows, so beautiful, so large, that I believe a man of\r\nyour size should pass through each frame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy the devil have they any stairs with such windows?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLuxury has everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut shutters?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but they are never used. Well,\r\nover that coach-house are the servants\xe2\x80\x99 rooms, with bells corresponding\r\nwith the different apartments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, _diable!_ bells did you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing! I was told\r\nthere were such at the last exhibition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has simply a mahogany secretaire, in which the key is always kept.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he is not robbed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; his servants are all devoted to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere ought to be some money in that secretaire?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere may be. The famous secretaire is in the dressing-room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there a window in the dressing-room?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo,\xe2\x80\x94one here and one there.\xe2\x80\x9d Andrea sketched two windows in the room,\r\nwhich formed an angle on the plan, and appeared as a small square added\r\nto the rectangle of the bedroom. Caderousse became thoughtful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes he often go to Auteuil?\xe2\x80\x9d added he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo or three times a week. But Andrea drew a cigar-case from his pocket, took\r\na Havana, quietly lit it, and began smoking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen do you want your twelve hundred francs?\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, if you have them.\xe2\x80\x9d Andrea took five-and-twenty louis from his\r\npocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYellow boys?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cno, I thank you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you despise them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, I esteem them, but will not have them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can change them, idiot; gold is worth five sous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly; and he who changes them will follow friend Caderousse, lay\r\nhands on him, and demand what farmers pay him their rent in gold. No\r\nnonsense, my good fellow; silver simply, round coins with the head of\r\nsome monarch or other on them. Anybody may possess a five-franc piece.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut do you suppose I carry five hundred francs about with me? I should\r\nwant a porter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, leave them with your porter; he is to be trusted. I will call\r\nfor them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, tomorrow; I shall not have time today.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, tomorrow I will leave them when I go to Auteuil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I depend on it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I shall secure my housekeeper on the strength of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow see here, will that be all? Eh? And will you not torment me any\r\nmore?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse had become so gloomy that Andrea feared he should be obliged\r\nto notice the change. He redoubled his gayety and carelessness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow sprightly you are,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cOne would say you were\r\nalready in possession of your property.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, unfortunately; but when I do obtain it\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall remember old friends, I can tell you that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, since you have such a good memory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?
