I, who am going to give you another piece of good\r\nadvice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo leave behind you the diamond you have on your finger. We shall both\r\nget into trouble. You will ruin both yourself and me by your folly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow? You put on a livery, you disguise yourself as a servant, and yet\r\nkeep a diamond on your finger worth four or five thousand francs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou guess well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know something of diamonds; I have had some.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do well to boast of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, who, without becoming angry,\r\nas Caderousse feared, at this new extortion, quietly resigned the ring.\r\nCaderousse looked so closely at it that Andrea well knew that he was\r\nexamining to see if all the edges were perfect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a false diamond,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are joking now,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Andrea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not be angry, we can try it.\xe2\x80\x9d Caderousse went to the window,\r\ntouched the glass with it, and found it would cut.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Confiteor!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, putting the diamond on his little\r\nfinger; \xe2\x80\x9cI was mistaken; but those thieves of jewellers imitate so well\r\nthat it is no longer worthwhile to rob a jeweller\xe2\x80\x99s shop\xe2\x80\x94it is another\r\nbranch of industry paralyzed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you finished?\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cdo you want anything more?\xe2\x80\x94will you\r\nhave my waistcoat or my hat? Make free, now you have begun.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; you are, after all, a good companion; I will not detain you, and\r\nwill try to cure myself of my ambition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut take care the same thing does not happen to you in selling the\r\ndiamond you feared with the gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall not sell it\xe2\x80\x94do not fear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at least till the day after tomorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d thought the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHappy rogue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are going to find your servants,\r\nyour horses, your carriage, and your betrothed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I hope you will make a handsome wedding-present the day you\r\nmarry Mademoiselle Danglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have already told you it is a fancy you have taken in your head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat fortune has she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I tell you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA million?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea shrugged his shoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet it be a million,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cyou can never have so much as\r\nI wish you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I wish it you with all my heart!\xe2\x80\x9d added Caderousse with his hoarse\r\nlaugh. \xe2\x80\x9cStop, let me show you the way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not worthwhile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause there is a little secret, a precaution I thought it desirable\r\nto take, one of Huret & Fichet\xe2\x80\x99s locks, revised and improved by Gaspard\r\nCaderousse; I will manufacture you a similar one when you are a\r\ncapitalist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea; \xe2\x80\x9cI will let you know a week beforehand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey parted. Caderousse remained on the landing until he had not only\r\nseen Andrea go down the three stories, but also cross the court. Then\r\nhe returned hastily, shut his door carefully, and began to study, like\r\na clever architect, the plan Andrea had left him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Benedetto,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI think he will not be sorry to inherit his\r\nfortune, and he who hastens the day when he can touch his five hundred\r\nthousand will not be his worst friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 82. The Burglary\r\n\r\nThe day following that on which the conversation we have related took\r\nplace, the Count of Monte Cristo set out for Auteuil, accompanied by\r\nAli and several attendants, and also taking with him some horses whose\r\nqualities he was desirous of ascertaining. He was induced to undertake\r\nthis journey, of which the day before he had not even thought and which\r\nhad not occurred to Andrea either, by the arrival of Bertuccio from\r\nNormandy with intelligence respecting the house and sloop. The house\r\nwas ready, and the sloop which had arrived a week before lay at anchor\r\nin a small creek with her crew of six men, who had observed all the\r\nrequisite formalities and were ready again to put to sea.\r\n\r\nThe count praised Bertuccio\xe2\x80\x99s zeal, and ordered him to prepare for a\r\nspeedy departure, as his stay in France would not be prolonged more\r\nthan a month.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI may require to go in one night from Paris to\r\nTr\xc3\xa9port; let eight fresh horses be in readiness on the road, which will\r\nenable me to go fifty leagues in ten hours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour highness had already expressed that wish,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bertuccio, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nthe horses are ready. I have bought them, and stationed them myself at\r\nthe most desirable posts, that is, in villages, where no one generally\r\nstops.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI remain here a day or two\xe2\x80\x94arrange\r\naccordingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs Bertuccio was leaving the room to give the requisite orders,\r\nBaptistin opened the door: he held a letter on a silver waiter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing here?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count, seeing him covered with\r\ndust; \xe2\x80\x9cI did not send for you, I think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBaptistin, without answering, approached the count, and presented the\r\nletter. \xe2\x80\x9cImportant and urgent,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\nThe count opened the letter, and read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98M. de Monte Cristo is apprised that this night a man will enter his\r\nhouse in the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es with the intention of carrying off some\r\npapers supposed to be in the secretaire in the dressing-room. The\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s well-known courage will render unnecessary the aid of the\r\npolice, whose interference might seriously affect him who sends this\r\nadvice. The count, by any opening from the bedroom, or by concealing\r\nhimself in the dressing-room, would be able to defend his property\r\nhimself. Many attendants or apparent precautions would prevent the\r\nvillain from the attempt, and M. de Monte Cristo would lose the\r\nopportunity of discovering an enemy whom chance has revealed to him who\r\nnow sends this warning to the count,\xe2\x80\x94a warning he might not be able to\r\nsend another time, if this first attempt should fail and another be\r\nmade.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe count\xe2\x80\x99s first idea was that this was an artifice\xe2\x80\x94a gross deception,\r\nto draw his attention from a minor danger in order to expose him to a\r\ngreater. He was on the point of sending the letter to the commissary of\r\npolice, notwithstanding the advice of his anonymous friend, or perhaps\r\nbecause of that advice, when suddenly the idea occurred to him that it\r\nmight be some personal enemy, whom he alone should recognize and over\r\nwhom, if such were the case, he alone would gain any advantage, as\r\nFiesco17 had done over the Moor who would have killed him. We know the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s vigorous and daring mind, denying anything to be impossible,\r\nwith that energy which marks the great man.\r\n\r\nFrom his past life, from his resolution to shrink from nothing, the\r\ncount had acquired an inconceivable relish for the contests in which he\r\nhad engaged, sometimes against nature, that is to say, against God, and\r\nsometimes against the world, that is, against the devil.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey do not want my papers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthey want to kill me;\r\nthey are no robbers, but assassins. I will not allow the prefect of\r\npolice to interfere with my private affairs. I am rich enough,\r\nforsooth, to distribute his authority on this occasion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count recalled Baptistin, who had left the room after delivering\r\nthe letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReturn to Paris,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cassemble the servants who remain there. I\r\nwant all my household at Auteuil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut will no one remain in the house, my lord?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Baptistin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the porter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy lord will remember that the lodge is at a distance from the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe house might be stripped without his hearing the least noise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy thieves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a fool, M. Baptistin. Thieves might strip the house\xe2\x80\x94it would\r\nannoy me less than to be disobeyed.\xe2\x80\x9d Baptistin bowed.\r\n\r\n40150m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou understand me?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count. \xe2\x80\x9cBring your comrades here, one and\r\nall; but let everything remain as usual, only close the shutters of the\r\nground floor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd those of the first floor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know they are never closed. Go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count signified his intention of dining alone, and that no one but\r\nAli should attend him. Having dined with his usual tranquillity and\r\nmoderation, the count, making a signal to Ali to follow him, went out\r\nby the side-gate and on reaching the Bois de Boulogne turned,\r\napparently without design towards Paris and at twilight; found himself\r\nopposite his house in the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es. All was dark; one solitary,\r\nfeeble light was burning in the porter\xe2\x80\x99s lodge, about forty paces\r\ndistant from the house, as Baptistin had said.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo leaned against a tree, and with that scrutinizing glance\r\nwhich was so rarely deceived, looked up and down the avenue, examined\r\nthe passers-by, and carefully looked down the neighboring streets, to\r\nsee that no one was concealed. Ten minutes passed thus, and he was\r\nconvinced that no one was watching him. He hastened to the side-door\r\nwith Ali, entered hurriedly, and by the servants\xe2\x80\x99 staircase, of which\r\nhe had the key, gained his bedroom without opening or disarranging a\r\nsingle curtain, without even the porter having the slightest suspicion\r\nthat the house, which he supposed empty, contained its chief occupant.\r\n\r\nArrived in his bedroom, the count motioned to Ali to stop; then he\r\npassed into the dressing-room, which he examined. Everything appeared\r\nas usual\xe2\x80\x94the precious secretaire in its place, and the key in the\r\nsecretaire. He double locked it, took the key, returned to the bedroom\r\ndoor, removed the double staple of the bolt, and went in. Meanwhile Ali\r\nhad procured the arms the count required\xe2\x80\x94namely, a short carbine and a\r\npair of double-barrelled pistols, with which as sure an aim might be\r\ntaken as with a single-barrelled one. Thus armed, the count held the\r\nlives of five men in his hands. It was about half-past nine.\r\n\r\nThe count and Ali ate in haste a crust of bread and drank a glass of\r\nSpanish wine; then Monte Cristo slipped aside one of the movable\r\npanels, which enabled him to see into the adjoining room. He had within\r\nhis reach his pistols and carbine, and Ali, standing near him, held one\r\nof the small Arabian hatchets, whose form has not varied since the\r\nCrusades. Through one of the windows of the bedroom, on a line with\r\nthat in the dressing-room, the count could see into the street.\r\n\r\nTwo hours passed thus. It was intensely dark; still Ali, thanks to his\r\nwild nature, and the count, thanks doubtless to his long confinement,\r\ncould distinguish in the darkness the slightest movement of the trees.\r\nThe little light in the lodge had long been extinct. It might be\r\nexpected that the attack, if indeed an attack was projected, would be\r\nmade from the staircase of the ground floor, and not from a window; in\r\nMonte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s opinion, the villains sought his life, not his money. It\r\nwould be his bedroom they would attack, and they must reach it by the\r\nback staircase, or by the window in the dressing-room.\r\n\r\nThe clock of the Invalides struck a quarter to twelve; the west wind\r\nbore on its moistened gusts the doleful vibration of the three strokes.\r\n\r\n40152m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAs the last stroke died away, the count thought he heard a slight noise\r\nin the dressing-room; this first sound, or rather this first grinding,\r\nwas followed by a second, then a third; at the fourth, the count knew\r\nwhat to expect. A firm and well-practised hand was engaged in cutting\r\nthe four sides of a pane of glass with a diamond. The count felt his\r\nheart beat more rapidly.\r\n\r\nInured as men may be to danger, forewarned as they may be of peril,\r\nthey understand, by the fluttering of the heart and the shuddering of\r\nthe frame, the enormous difference between a dream and a reality,\r\nbetween the project and the execution. However, Monte Cristo only made\r\na sign to apprise Ali, who, understanding that danger was approaching\r\nfrom the other side, drew nearer to his master. Monte Cristo was eager\r\nto ascertain the strength and number of his enemies.\r\n\r\nThe window whence the noise proceeded was opposite the opening by which\r\nthe count could see into the dressing-room. He fixed his eyes on that\r\nwindow\xe2\x80\x94he distinguished a shadow in the darkness; then one of the panes\r\nbecame quite opaque, as if a sheet of paper were stuck on the outside,\r\nthen the square cracked without falling. Through the opening an arm was\r\npassed to find the fastening, then a second; the window turned on its\r\nhinges, and a man entered. He was alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a daring rascal,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the count.\r\n\r\nAt that moment Ali touched him slightly on the shoulder. He turned; Ali\r\npointed to the window of the room in which they were, facing the\r\nstreet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthere are two of them; one does the work while the\r\nother stands guard.\xe2\x80\x9d He made a sign to Ali not to lose sight of the man\r\nin the street, and turned to the one in the dressing-room.\r\n\r\nThe glass-cutter had entered, and was feeling his way, his arms\r\nstretched out before him. At last he appeared to have made himself\r\nfamiliar with his surroundings. There were two doors; he bolted them\r\nboth.\r\n\r\nWhen he drew near to the bedroom door, Monte Cristo expected that he\r\nwas coming in, and raised one of his pistols; but he simply heard the\r\nsound of the bolts sliding in their copper rings. It was only a\r\nprecaution. The nocturnal visitor, ignorant of the fact that the count\r\nhad removed the staples, might now think himself at home, and pursue\r\nhis purpose with full security. Alone and free to act as he wished, the\r\nman then drew from his pocket something which the count could not\r\ndiscern, placed it on a stand, then went straight to the secretaire,\r\nfelt the lock, and contrary to his expectation found that the key was\r\nmissing. But the glass-cutter was a prudent man who had provided for\r\nall emergencies. The count soon heard the rattling of a bunch of\r\nskeleton keys, such as the locksmith brings when called to force a\r\nlock, and which thieves call nightingales, doubtless from the music of\r\ntheir nightly song when they grind against the bolt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ha,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Monte Cristo with a smile of disappointment, \xe2\x80\x9che is\r\nonly a thief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the man in the dark could not find the right key. He reached the\r\ninstrument he had placed on the stand, touched a spring, and\r\nimmediately a pale light, just bright enough to render objects\r\ndistinct, was reflected on his hands and countenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy heavens,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Monte Cristo, starting back, \xe2\x80\x9cit is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAli raised his hatchet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t stir,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cand put down your hatchet; we\r\nshall require no arms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40154m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThen he added some words in a low tone, for the exclamation which\r\nsurprise had drawn from the count, faint as it had been, had startled\r\nthe man who remained in the pose of the old knife-grinder.\r\n\r\nIt was an order the count had just given, for immediately Ali went\r\nnoiselessly, and returned, bearing a black dress and a three-cornered\r\nhat. Meanwhile Monte Cristo had rapidly taken off his greatcoat,\r\nwaistcoat, and shirt, and one might distinguish by the glimmering\r\nthrough the open panel that he wore a pliant tunic of steel mail, of\r\nwhich the last in France, where daggers are no longer dreaded, was worn\r\nby King Louis XVI., who feared the dagger at his breast, and whose head\r\nwas cleft with a hatchet. The tunic soon disappeared under a long\r\ncassock, as did his hair under a priest\xe2\x80\x99s wig; the three-cornered hat\r\nover this effectually transformed the count into an abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\nThe man, hearing nothing more, stood erect, and while Monte Cristo was\r\ncompleting his disguise had advanced straight to the secretaire, whose\r\nlock was beginning to crack under his nightingale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTry again,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the count, who depended on the secret spring,\r\nwhich was unknown to the picklock, clever as he might be\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ctry again,\r\nyou have a few minutes\xe2\x80\x99 work there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he advanced to the window. The man whom he had seen seated on a\r\nfence had got down, and was still pacing the street; but, strange as it\r\nappeared, he cared not for those who might pass from the avenue of the\r\nChamps-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es or by the Faubourg Saint-Honor\xc3\xa9; his attention was\r\nengrossed with what was passing at the count\xe2\x80\x99s, and his only aim\r\nappeared to be to discern every movement in the dressing-room.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo suddenly struck his finger on his forehead and a smile\r\npassed over his lips; then drawing near to Ali, he whispered:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemain here, concealed in the dark, and whatever noise you hear,\r\nwhatever passes, only come in or show yourself if I call you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAli bowed in token of strict obedience. Monte Cristo then drew a\r\nlighted taper from a closet, and when the thief was deeply engaged with\r\nhis lock, silently opened the door, taking care that the light should\r\nshine directly on his face. The door opened so quietly that the thief\r\nheard no sound; but, to his astonishment, the room was suddenly\r\nilluminated. He turned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, good-evening, my dear M. Caderousse,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat are\r\nyou doing here, at such an hour?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40156m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Caderousse; and, not knowing how this\r\nstrange apparition could have entered when he had bolted the doors, he\r\nlet fall his bunch of keys, and remained motionless and stupefied. The\r\ncount placed himself between Caderousse and the window, thus cutting\r\noff from the thief his only chance of retreat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Caderousse, fixing his haggard gaze on the\r\ncount.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, undoubtedly, the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni himself,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nI am very glad you recognize me, dear M. Caderousse; it proves you have\r\na good memory, for it must be about ten years since we last met.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis calmness of Busoni, combined with his irony and boldness,\r\nstaggered Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe abb\xc3\xa9, the abb\xc3\xa9!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he, clenching his fists, and his teeth\r\nchattering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you would rob the Count of Monte Cristo?\xe2\x80\x9d continued the false abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReverend sir,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Caderousse, seeking to regain the window,\r\nwhich the count pitilessly blocked\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9creverend sir, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know\xe2\x80\x94believe\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94I take my oath\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA pane of glass out,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the count, \xe2\x80\x9ca dark lantern, a bunch of\r\nfalse keys, a secretaire half forced\xe2\x80\x94it is tolerably evident\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse was choking; he looked around for some corner to hide in,\r\nsome way of escape.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the count, \xe2\x80\x9cI see you are still the same,\xe2\x80\x94an\r\nassassin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReverend sir, since you know everything, you know it was not I\xe2\x80\x94it was\r\nLa Carconte; that was proved at the trial, since I was only condemned\r\nto the galleys.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs your time, then, expired, since I find you in a fair way to return\r\nthere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, reverend sir; I have been liberated by someone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat someone has done society a great kindness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cI had promised\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are breaking your promise!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse very uneasily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA bad relapse, that will lead you, if I mistake not, to the Place de\r\nGr\xc3\xa8ve. And when the jeweller Johannes had\r\njust paid you 45,000 francs for the diamond I had given you, and you\r\nkilled him to get the diamond and the money both, was that also\r\npoverty?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon, reverend sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have saved my life once,\r\nsave me again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is but poor encouragement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you alone, reverend sir, or have you there soldiers ready to seize\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am alone,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, \xe2\x80\x9cand I will again have pity on you, and\r\nwill let you escape, at the risk of the fresh miseries my weakness may\r\nlead to, if you tell me the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, reverend sir,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Caderousse, clasping his hands, and drawing\r\nnearer to Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI may indeed say you are my deliverer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean to say you have been freed from confinement?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is true, reverend sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho was your liberator?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn Englishman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord Wilmore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know him; Do you know\r\nSaint-Mandrier?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the hour of rest, between noon and one o\xe2\x80\x99clock\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGalley-slaves having a nap after dinner! We may well pity the poor\r\nfellows!\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cone can\xe2\x80\x99t always work\xe2\x80\x94one is not a dog.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better for the dogs,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile the rest slept, then, we went away a short distance; we severed\r\nour fetters with a file the Englishman had given us, and swam away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is become of this Benedetto?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, in truth; we parted at Hy\xc3\xa8res.\xe2\x80\x9d And, to give more weight to his\r\nprotestation, Caderousse advanced another step towards the abb\xc3\xa9, who\r\nremained motionless in his place, as calm as ever, and pursuing his\r\ninterrogation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou lie,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni, with a tone of irresistible authority.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReverend sir!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou lie! This man is still your friend, and you, perhaps, make use of\r\nhim as your accomplice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40160m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, reverend sir!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSince you left Toulon what have you lived on? Answer me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn what I could get.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou lie,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the abb\xc3\xa9 a third time, with a still more imperative\r\ntone. Caderousse, terrified, looked at the count. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have lived on\r\nthe money he has given you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cBenedetto has become the son of a great\r\nlord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can he be the son of a great lord?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA natural son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is that great lord\xe2\x80\x99s name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Count of Monte Cristo, the very same in whose house we are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBenedetto the count\xe2\x80\x99s son?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, astonished in his\r\nturn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I should think so, since the count has found him a false\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x94since the count gives him four thousand francs a month, and\r\nleaves him 500,000 francs in his will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the factitious abb\xc3\xa9, who began to understand; \xe2\x80\x9cand what\r\nname does the young man bear meanwhile?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAndrea Cavalcanti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it, then, that young man whom my friend the Count of Monte Cristo\r\nhas received into his house, and who is going to marry Mademoiselle\r\nDanglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you suffer that, you wretch!\xe2\x80\x94you, who know his life and his\r\ncrime?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should I stand in a comrade\xe2\x80\x99s way?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right; it is not you who should apprise M. Danglars, it is I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not do so, reverend sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you would bring us to ruin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you think that to save such villains as you I will become an\r\nabettor of their plot, an accomplice in their crimes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReverend sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, drawing still nearer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will expose all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo M. Danglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Caderousse, drawing from his waistcoat an open\r\nknife, and striking the count in the breast, \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall disclose\r\nnothing, reverend sir!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo Caderousse\xe2\x80\x99s great astonishment, the knife, instead of piercing the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s breast, flew back blunted. At the same moment the count seized\r\nwith his left hand the assassin\xe2\x80\x99s wrist, and wrung it with such\r\nstrength that the knife fell from his stiffened fingers, and Caderousse\r\nuttered a cry of pain. But the count, disregarding his cry, continued\r\nto wring the bandit\xe2\x80\x99s wrist, until, his arm being dislocated, he fell\r\nfirst on his knees, then flat on the floor.\r\n\r\nThe count then placed his foot on his head, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cI know not what\r\nrestrains me from crushing thy skull, rascal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, mercy\xe2\x80\x94mercy!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Caderousse.\r\n\r\nThe count withdrew his foot.\r\n\r\n40162m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRise!\xe2\x80\x9d said he. Caderousse rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a wrist you have, reverend sir!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, stroking his\r\narm, all bruised by the fleshy pincers which had held it; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a\r\nwrist!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence! God gives me strength to overcome a wild beast like you; in\r\nthe name of that God I act,\xe2\x80\x94remember that, wretch,\xe2\x80\x94and to spare thee at\r\nthis moment is still serving him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, groaning with pain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake this pen and paper, and write what I dictate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know how to write, reverend sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou lie! Take this pen, and write!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse, awed by the superior power of the abb\xc3\xa9, sat down and wrote:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x94The man whom you are receiving at your house, and to whom you\r\nintend to marry your daughter, is a felon who escaped with me from\r\nconfinement at Toulon. He was No. 59, and I No. 58. He was called\r\nBenedetto, but he is ignorant of his real name, having never known his\r\nparents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSign it!\xe2\x80\x9d continued the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut would you ruin me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I sought your ruin, fool, I should drag you to the first\r\nguard-house; besides, when that note is delivered, in all probability\r\nyou will have no more to fear. Sign it, then!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse signed it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe address, \xe2\x80\x98To monsieur the Baron Danglars, banker, Rue de la\r\nChauss\xc3\xa9e d\xe2\x80\x99Antin.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse wrote the address. The abb\xc3\xa9 took the note.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthat suffices\xe2\x80\x94begone!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe way you came.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wish me to get out at that window?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou got in very well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you have some design against me, reverend sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIdiot! what design can I have?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, then, not let me out by the door?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would be the advantage of waking the porter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, reverend sir, tell me, do you wish me dead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish what God wills.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut swear that you will not strike me as I go down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCowardly fool!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you intend doing with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ask you what can I do? I have tried to make you a happy man, and you\r\nhave turned out a murderer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cmake one more attempt\xe2\x80\x94try me once\r\nmore!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count. \xe2\x80\x9cListen\xe2\x80\x94you know if I may be relied on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you arrive safely at home\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have I to fear, except from you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you reach your home safely, leave Paris, leave France, and wherever\r\nyou may be, so long as you conduct yourself well, I will send you a\r\nsmall annuity; for, if you return home safely, then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Caderousse, shuddering.\r\n\r\n40164m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I shall believe God has forgiven you, and I will forgive you\r\ntoo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs true as I am a Christian,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will make me\r\ndie of fright!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow begone,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, pointing to the window.\r\n\r\nCaderousse, scarcely yet relying on this promise, put his legs out of\r\nthe window and stood on the ladder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow go down,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, folding his arms. Understanding he had\r\nnothing more to fear from him, Caderousse began to go down. Then the\r\ncount brought the taper to the window, that it might be seen in the\r\nChamps-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es that a man was getting out of the window while another\r\nheld a light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing, reverend sir? Suppose a watchman should pass?\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nhe blew out the light. He then descended, but it was only when he felt\r\nhis foot touch the ground that he was satisfied of his safety.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo returned to his bedroom, and, glancing rapidly from the\r\ngarden to the street, he saw first Caderousse, who after walking to the\r\nend of the garden, fixed his ladder against the wall at a different\r\npart from where he came in. The count then looking over into the\r\nstreet, saw the man who appeared to be waiting run in the same\r\ndirection, and place himself against the angle of the wall where\r\nCaderousse would come over. Caderousse climbed the ladder slowly, and\r\nlooked over the coping to see if the street was quiet. No one could be\r\nseen or heard. The clock of the Invalides struck one. Then Caderousse\r\nsat astride the coping, and drawing up his ladder passed it over the\r\nwall; then he began to descend, or rather to slide down by the two\r\nstanchions, which he did with an ease which proved how accustomed he\r\nwas to the exercise. But, once started, he could not stop. In vain did\r\nhe see a man start from the shadow when he was halfway down\xe2\x80\x94in vain did\r\nhe see an arm raised as he touched the ground.\r\n\r\nBefore he could defend himself that arm struck him so violently in the\r\nback that he let go the ladder, crying, \xe2\x80\x9cHelp!\xe2\x80\x9d A second blow struck\r\nhim almost immediately in the side, and he fell, calling, \xe2\x80\x9cHelp,\r\nmurder!\xe2\x80\x9d Then, as he rolled on the ground, his adversary seized him by\r\nthe hair, and struck him a third blow in the chest.\r\n\r\nThis time Caderousse endeavored to call again, but he could only utter\r\na groan, and he shuddered as the blood flowed from his three wounds.\r\nThe assassin, finding that he no longer cried out, lifted his head up\r\nby the hair; his eyes were closed, and the mouth was distorted. The\r\nmurderer, supposing him dead, let fall his head and disappeared.\r\n\r\nThen Caderousse, feeling that he was leaving him, raised himself on his\r\nelbow, and with a dying voice cried with great effort:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMurder! I am dying! Help, reverend sir,\xe2\x80\x94help!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis mournful appeal pierced the darkness. The door of the\r\nback-staircase opened, then the side-gate of the garden, and Ali and\r\nhis master were on the spot with lights.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 83. The Hand of God\r\n\r\nCaderousse continued to call piteously, \xe2\x80\x9cHelp, reverend sir, help!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cI am murdered!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are here;\xe2\x80\x94take courage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, it\xe2\x80\x99s all over! You are come too late\xe2\x80\x94you are come to see me die.\r\nWhat blows, what blood!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe fainted. Ali and his master conveyed the wounded man into a room.\r\nMonte Cristo motioned to Ali to undress him, and he then examined his\r\ndreadful wounds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cthy vengeance is sometimes delayed, but only\r\nthat it may fall the more effectually.\xe2\x80\x9d Ali looked at his master for\r\nfurther instructions. \xe2\x80\x9cBring here immediately the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney, M.\r\nde Villefort, who lives in the Faubourg Saint-Honor\xc3\xa9. As you pass the\r\nlodge, wake the porter, and send him for a surgeon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAli obeyed, leaving the abb\xc3\xa9 alone with Caderousse, who had not yet\r\nrevived.\r\n\r\nWhen the wretched man again opened his eyes, the count looked at him\r\nwith a mournful expression of pity, and his lips moved as if in prayer.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA surgeon, reverend sir\xe2\x80\x94a surgeon!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have sent for one,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know he cannot save my life, but he may strengthen me to give my\r\nevidence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgainst whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgainst my murderer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you recognize him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; it was Benedetto.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe young Corsican?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHimself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour comrade?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. After giving me the plan of this house, doubtless hoping I should\r\nkill the count and he thus become his heir, or that the count would\r\nkill me and I should be out of his way, he waylaid me, and has murdered\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have also sent for the procureur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will not come in time; I feel my life fast ebbing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. He left the room, and returned in\r\nfive minutes with a phial. The dying man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes were all the time\r\nriveted on the door, through which he hoped succor would arrive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHasten, reverend sir, hasten! I shall faint again!\xe2\x80\x9d Monte Cristo\r\napproached, and dropped on his purple lips three or four drops of the\r\ncontents of the phial. Caderousse drew a deep breath. \xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat is life to me; more, more!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo drops more would kill you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the abb\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, send for someone to whom I can denounce the wretch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I write your deposition? You can sign it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; and his eyes glistened at the thought of\r\nthis posthumous revenge. Monte Cristo wrote:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI die, murdered by the Corsican Benedetto, my comrade in the galleys\r\nat Toulon, No. 59.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuick, quick!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cor I shall be unable to sign it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo gave the pen to Caderousse, who collected all his\r\nstrength, signed it, and fell back on his bed, saying:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will relate all the rest, reverend sir; you will say he calls\r\nhimself Andrea Cavalcanti. He lodges at the H\xc3\xb4tel des Princes. Oh, I am\r\ndying!\xe2\x80\x9d He again fainted. The abb\xc3\xa9 made him smell the contents of the\r\nphial, and he again opened his eyes. His desire for revenge had not\r\nforsaken him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you will tell all I have said, will you not, reverend sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and much more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat more will you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will say he had doubtless given you the plan of this house, in the\r\nhope the count would kill you. I will say, likewise, he had apprised\r\nthe count, by a note, of your intention, and, the count being absent, I\r\nread the note and sat up to await you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he will be guillotined, will be not?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse. \xe2\x80\x9cPromise me\r\nthat, and I will die with that hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will say,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the count, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he followed and watched you\r\nthe whole time, and when he saw you leave the house, ran to the angle\r\nof the wall to conceal himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you see all that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember my words: \xe2\x80\x98If you return home safely, I shall believe God has\r\nforgiven you, and I will forgive you also.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you did not warn me!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Caderousse, raising himself on his\r\nelbows. \xe2\x80\x9cYou knew I should be killed on leaving this house, and did not\r\nwarn me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40168m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; for I saw God\xe2\x80\x99s justice placed in the hands of Benedetto, and\r\nshould have thought it sacrilege to oppose the designs of Providence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod\xe2\x80\x99s justice! Speak not of it, reverend sir. If God were just, you\r\nknow how many would be punished who now escape.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPatience,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, in a tone which made the dying man shudder;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chave patience!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse looked at him with amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, \xe2\x80\x9cGod is merciful to all, as he has been to\r\nyou; he is first a father, then a judge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you then believe in God?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad I been so unhappy as not to believe in him until now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte\r\nCristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI must believe on seeing you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse raised his clenched hands towards heaven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9, extending his hand over the wounded man, as if\r\nto command him to believe; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is what the God in whom, on your\r\ndeath-bed, you refuse to believe, has done for you\xe2\x80\x94he gave you health,\r\nstrength, regular employment, even friends\xe2\x80\x94a life, in fact, which a man\r\nmight enjoy with a calm conscience. Instead of improving these gifts,\r\nrarely granted so abundantly, this has been your course\xe2\x80\x94you have given\r\nyourself up to sloth and drunkenness, and in a fit of intoxication have\r\nruined your best friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cI require a surgeon, not a priest; perhaps I\r\nam not mortally wounded\xe2\x80\x94I may not die; perhaps they can yet save my\r\nlife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour wounds are so far mortal that, without the three drops I gave\r\nyou, you would now be dead. Listen, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a strange priest you are; you drive\r\nthe dying to despair, instead of consoling them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the abb\xc3\xa9. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you had betrayed your friend, God\r\nbegan not to strike, but to warn you. Poverty overtook you. You had\r\nalready passed half your life in coveting that which you might have\r\nhonorably acquired; and already you contemplated crime under the excuse\r\nof want, when God worked a miracle in your behalf, sending you, by my\r\nhands, a fortune\xe2\x80\x94brilliant, indeed, for you, who had never possessed\r\nany. But this unexpected, unhoped-for, unheard-of fortune sufficed you\r\nno longer when you once possessed it; you wished to double it, and\r\nhow?\xe2\x80\x94by a murder! You succeeded, and then God snatched it from you, and\r\nbrought you to justice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was not I who wished to kill the Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cit was La\r\nCarconte.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cand God,\xe2\x80\x94I cannot say in justice, for his\r\njustice would have slain you,\xe2\x80\x94but God, in his mercy, spared your life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_ to transport me for life, how merciful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou thought it a mercy then, miserable wretch! The coward who feared\r\ndeath rejoiced at perpetual disgrace; for like all galley-slaves, you\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x98I may escape from prison, I cannot from the grave.\xe2\x80\x99 And you said\r\ntruly; the way was opened for you unexpectedly. An Englishman visited\r\nToulon, who had vowed to rescue two men from infamy, and his choice\r\nfell on you and your companion. You received a second fortune, money\r\nand tranquillity were restored to you, and you, who had been condemned\r\nto a felon\xe2\x80\x99s life, might live as other men. Then, wretched creature,\r\nthen you tempted God a third time. \xe2\x80\x98I have not enough,\xe2\x80\x99 you said, when\r\nyou had more than you before possessed, and you committed a third\r\ncrime, without reason, without excuse. God is wearied; he has punished\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse was fast sinking. \xe2\x80\x9cGive me drink,\xe2\x80\x9d said he: \xe2\x80\x9cI thirst\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nburn!\xe2\x80\x9d Monte Cristo gave him a glass of water. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet that villain,\r\nBenedetto, will escape!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one, I tell you, will escape; Benedetto will be punished.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, you, too, will be punished, for you did not do your duty as a\r\npriest\xe2\x80\x94you should have prevented Benedetto from killing me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, with a smile which petrified the dying man, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen\r\nyou had just broken your knife against the coat of mail which protected\r\nmy breast! Yet perhaps if I had found you humble and penitent, I might\r\nhave prevented Benedetto from killing you; but I found you proud and\r\nblood-thirsty, and I left you in the hands of God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not believe there is a God,\xe2\x80\x9d howled Caderousse; \xe2\x80\x9cyou do not\r\nbelieve it; you lie\xe2\x80\x94you lie!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abb\xc3\xa9; \xe2\x80\x9cyou will force the last drop of blood from\r\nyour veins. What! you do not believe in God when he is striking you\r\ndead? you will not believe in him, who requires but a prayer, a word, a\r\ntear, and he will forgive? God, who might have directed the assassin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndagger so as to end your career in a moment, has given you this quarter\r\nof an hour for repentance. Reflect, then, wretched man, and repent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, \xe2\x80\x9cno; I will not repent. There is no God; there\r\nis no Providence\xe2\x80\x94all comes by chance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a Providence; there is a God,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cof whom\r\nyou are a striking proof, as you lie in utter despair, denying him,\r\nwhile I stand before you, rich, happy, safe and entreating that God in\r\nwhom you endeavor not to believe, while in your heart you still believe\r\nin him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who are you, then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Caderousse, fixing his dying eyes on the\r\ncount.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook well at me!\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, putting the light near his face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the abb\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x94the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni.\xe2\x80\x9d Monte Cristo took off the wig which\r\ndisfigured him, and let fall his black hair, which added so much to the\r\nbeauty of his pallid features.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh?\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, thunderstruck, \xe2\x80\x9cbut for that black hair, I\r\nshould say you were the Englishman, Lord Wilmore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am neither the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni nor Lord Wilmore,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthink again,\xe2\x80\x94do you not recollect me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a magic effect in the count\xe2\x80\x99s words, which once more revived\r\nthe exhausted powers of the miserable man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cI think I have seen you and known you\r\nformerly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Caderousse, you have seen me; you knew me once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho, then, are you? and why, if you knew me, do you let me die?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause nothing can save you; your wounds are mortal. Had it been\r\npossible to save you, I should have considered it another proof of\r\nGod\xe2\x80\x99s mercy, and I would again have endeavored to restore you, I swear\r\nby my father\xe2\x80\x99s tomb.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy your father\xe2\x80\x99s tomb!\xe2\x80\x9d said Caderousse, supported by a supernatural\r\npower, and half-raising himself to see more distinctly the man who had\r\njust taken the oath which all men hold sacred; \xe2\x80\x9cwho, then, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count had watched the approach of death. He knew this was the last\r\nstruggle. He approached the dying man, and, leaning over him with a\r\ncalm and melancholy look, he whispered, \xe2\x80\x9cI am\xe2\x80\x94I am\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd his almost closed lips uttered a name so low that the count himself\r\nappeared afraid to hear it. Caderousse, who had raised himself on his\r\nknees, and stretched out his arm, tried to draw back, then clasping his\r\nhands, and raising them with a desperate effort, \xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid he, \xe2\x80\x9cpardon me for having denied thee; thou dost exist, thou art\r\nindeed man\xe2\x80\x99s father in heaven, and his judge on earth. My God, my Lord,\r\nI have long despised thee! Pardon me, my God; receive me, Oh, my Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaderousse sighed deeply, and fell back with a groan. The blood no\r\nlonger flowed from his wounds. He was dead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_One!_\xe2\x80\x9d said the count mysteriously, his eyes fixed on the corpse,\r\ndisfigured by so awful a death.\r\n\r\nTen minutes afterwards the surgeon and the procureur arrived, the one\r\naccompanied by the porter, the other by Ali, and were received by the\r\nAbb\xc3\xa9 Busoni, who was praying by the side of the corpse.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 84. Beauchamp\r\n\r\nThe daring attempt to rob the count was the topic of conversation\r\nthroughout Paris for the next fortnight. The dying man had signed a\r\ndeposition declaring Benedetto to be the assassin. The police had\r\norders to make the strictest search for the murderer. Caderousse\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nknife, dark lantern, bunch of keys, and clothing, excepting the\r\nwaistcoat, which could not be found, were deposited at the registry;\r\nthe corpse was conveyed to the morgue. The count told everyone that\r\nthis adventure had happened during his absence at Auteuil, and that he\r\nonly knew what was related by the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni, who that evening, by\r\nmere chance, had requested to pass the night in his house, to examine\r\nsome valuable books in his library.\r\n\r\nBertuccio alone turned pale whenever Benedetto\xe2\x80\x99s name was mentioned in\r\nhis presence, but there was no reason why anyone should notice his\r\ndoing so.\r\n\r\nVillefort, being called on to prove the crime, was preparing his brief\r\nwith the same ardor that he was accustomed to exercise when required to\r\nspeak in criminal cases.\r\n\r\nBut three weeks had already passed, and the most diligent search had\r\nbeen unsuccessful; the attempted robbery and the murder of the robber\r\nby his comrade were almost forgotten in anticipation of the approaching\r\nmarriage of Mademoiselle Danglars to the Count Andrea Cavalcanti. It\r\nwas expected that this wedding would shortly take place, as the young\r\nman was received at the banker\xe2\x80\x99s as the betrothed.\r\n\r\nLetters had been despatched to M. Cavalcanti, as the count\xe2\x80\x99s father,\r\nwho highly approved of the union, regretted his inability to leave\r\nParma at that time, and promised a wedding gift of a hundred and fifty\r\nthousand livres. It was agreed that the three millions should be\r\nintrusted to Danglars to invest; some persons had warned the young man\r\nof the circumstances of his future father-in-law, who had of late\r\nsustained repeated losses; but with sublime disinterestedness and\r\nconfidence the young man refused to listen, or to express a single\r\ndoubt to the baron.\r\n\r\nThe baron adored Count Andrea Cavalcanti; not so Mademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie\r\nDanglars. With an instinctive hatred of matrimony, she suffered\r\nAndrea\xe2\x80\x99s attentions in order to get rid of Morcerf; but when Andrea\r\nurged his suit, she betrayed an entire dislike to him. The baron might\r\npossibly have perceived it, but, attributing it to a caprice, feigned\r\nignorance.\r\n\r\nThe delay demanded by Beauchamp had nearly expired. Morcerf appreciated\r\nthe advice of Monte Cristo to let things die away of their own accord.\r\nNo one had taken up the remark about the general, and no one had\r\nrecognized in the officer who betrayed the castle of Yanina the noble\r\ncount in the House of Peers.\r\n\r\nAlbert, however, felt no less insulted; the few lines which had\r\nirritated him were certainly intended as an insult. Besides, the manner\r\nin which Beauchamp had closed the conference left a bitter recollection\r\nin his heart. He cherished the thought of the duel, hoping to conceal\r\nits true cause even from his seconds. Beauchamp had not been seen since\r\nthe day he visited Albert, and those of whom the latter inquired always\r\ntold him he was out on a journey which would detain him some days.\r\nWhere he was no one knew.\r\n\r\nOne morning Albert was awakened by his valet de chambre, who announced\r\nBeauchamp. Albert rubbed his eyes, ordered his servant to introduce him\r\ninto the small smoking-room on the ground floor, dressed himself\r\nquickly, and went down.\r\n\r\nHe found Beauchamp pacing the room; on perceiving him Beauchamp\r\nstopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour arrival here, without waiting my visit at your house today, looks\r\nwell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert. \xe2\x80\x9cTell me, may I shake hands with you, saying,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Beauchamp, acknowledge you have injured me, and retain my friendship,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nor must I simply propose to you a choice of arms?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, with a look of sorrow which stupefied the\r\nyoung man, \xe2\x80\x9clet us first sit down and talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRather, sir, before we sit down, I must demand your answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert,\xe2\x80\x9d said the journalist, \xe2\x80\x9cthese are questions which it is\r\ndifficult to answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will facilitate it by repeating the question, \xe2\x80\x98Will you, or will you\r\nnot, retract?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMorcerf, it is not enough to answer \xe2\x80\x98yes\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98no\xe2\x80\x99 to questions which\r\nconcern the honor, the social interest, and the life of such a man as\r\nLieutenant-g\xc3\xa9n\xc3\xa9ral the Count of Morcerf, peer of France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat must then be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40174m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I have done, Albert. I reasoned thus\xe2\x80\x94money, time, and fatigue are\r\nnothing compared with the reputation and interests of a whole family;\r\nprobabilities will not suffice, only facts will justify a deadly combat\r\nwith a friend. If I strike with the sword, or discharge the contents of\r\na pistol at man with whom, for three years, I have been on terms of\r\nintimacy, I must, at least, know why I do so; I must meet him with a\r\nheart at ease, and that quiet conscience which a man needs when his own\r\narm must save his life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, impatiently, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat does all this mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt means that I have just returned from Yanina.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom Yanina?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is my passport; examine the visa\xe2\x80\x94Geneva, Milan, Venice, Trieste,\r\nDelvino, Yanina. Will you believe the government of a republic, a\r\nkingdom, and an empire?\xe2\x80\x9d Albert cast his eyes on the passport, then\r\nraised them in astonishment to Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have been to Yanina?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert, had you been a stranger, a foreigner, a simple lord, like that\r\nEnglishman who came to demand satisfaction three or four months since,\r\nand whom I killed to get rid of, I should not have taken this trouble;\r\nbut I thought this mark of consideration due to you. I took a week to\r\ngo, another to return, four days of quarantine, and forty-eight hours\r\nto stay there; that makes three weeks. I returned last night, and here\r\nI am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat circumlocution! How long you are before you tell me what I most\r\nwish to know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, in truth, Albert\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou hesitate?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x94I fear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou fear to acknowledge that your correspondent has deceived you? Oh,\r\nno self-love, Beauchamp. Acknowledge it, Beauchamp; your courage cannot\r\nbe doubted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the journalist; \xe2\x80\x9con the contrary\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert turned frightfully pale; he endeavored to speak, but the words\r\ndied on his lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, in the most affectionate tone, \xe2\x80\x9cI should\r\ngladly make an apology; but, alas!\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe paragraph was correct, my friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? That French officer\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFernand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe traitor who surrendered the castle of the man in whose service he\r\nwas\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, my friend, that man was your father!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert advanced furiously towards Beauchamp, but the latter restrained\r\nhim more by a mild look than by his extended hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9chere is a proof of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40176m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAlbert opened the paper, it was an attestation of four notable\r\ninhabitants of Yanina, proving that Colonel Fernand Mondego, in the\r\nservice of Ali Tepelini, had surrendered the castle for two million\r\ncrowns. The signatures were perfectly legal. Albert tottered and fell\r\noverpowered in a chair. It could no longer be doubted; the family name\r\nwas fully given. After a moment\xe2\x80\x99s mournful silence, his heart\r\noverflowed, and he gave way to a flood of tears. Beauchamp, who had\r\nwatched with sincere pity the young man\xe2\x80\x99s paroxysm of grief, approached\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou understand me\xe2\x80\x94do you not? I wished to see\r\nall, and to judge of everything for myself, hoping the explanation\r\nwould be in your father\xe2\x80\x99s favor, and that I might do him justice. But,\r\non the contrary, the particulars which are given prove that Fernand\r\nMondego, raised by Ali Pasha to the rank of governor-general, is no\r\nother than Count Fernand of Morcerf; then, recollecting the honor you\r\nhad done me, in admitting me to your friendship, I hastened to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert, still extended on the chair, covered his face with both hands,\r\nas if to prevent the light from reaching him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hastened to you,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cto tell you, Albert, that in\r\nthis changing age, the faults of a father cannot revert upon his\r\nchildren. Few have passed through this revolutionary period, in the\r\nmidst of which we were born, without some stain of infamy or blood to\r\nsoil the uniform of the soldier, or the gown of the magistrate. Now I\r\nhave these proofs, Albert, and I am in your confidence, no human power\r\ncan force me to a duel which your own conscience would reproach you\r\nwith as criminal, but I come to offer you what you can no longer demand\r\nof me. Do you wish these proofs, these attestations, which I alone\r\npossess, to be destroyed? Do you wish this frightful secret to remain\r\nwith us? Confided to me, it shall never escape my lips; say, Albert, my\r\nfriend, do you wish it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert threw himself on Beauchamp\xe2\x80\x99s neck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, noble fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake these,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, presenting the papers to Albert.\r\n\r\nAlbert seized them with a convulsive hand, tore them in pieces, and\r\ntrembling lest the least vestige should escape and one day appear to\r\nconfront him, he approached the wax-light, always kept burning for\r\ncigars, and burned every fragment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear, excellent friend,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Albert, still burning the papers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet all be forgotten as a sorrowful dream,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9clet it\r\nvanish as the last sparks from the blackened paper, and disappear as\r\nthe smoke from those silent ashes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cand may there remain only the eternal\r\nfriendship which I promised to my deliverer, which shall be transmitted\r\nto our children\xe2\x80\x99s children, and shall always remind me that I owe my\r\nlife and the honor of my name to you,\xe2\x80\x94for had this been known, oh,\r\nBeauchamp, I should have destroyed myself; or,\xe2\x80\x94no, my poor mother! I\r\ncould not have killed her by the same blow,\xe2\x80\x94I should have fled from my\r\ncountry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp. But this sudden and factitious joy soon\r\nforsook the young man, and was succeeded by a still greater grief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat still oppresses you, my friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40178m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am broken-hearted,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert. \xe2\x80\x9cListen, Beauchamp! Oh, Beauchamp,\r\nBeauchamp, how shall I now approach mine? Shall I draw back my forehead\r\nfrom his embrace, or withhold my hand from his? I am the most wretched\r\nof men. Ah, my mother, my poor mother!\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, gazing through his\r\ntears at his mother\xe2\x80\x99s portrait; \xe2\x80\x9cif you know this, how much must you\r\nsuffer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, taking both his hands, \xe2\x80\x9ctake courage, my\r\nfriend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how came that first note to be inserted in your journal? Go,\r\nmy friend, reserve your strength for the moment when the crash shall\r\ncome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40179m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think, then, all is not over yet?\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, horror-stricken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think nothing, my friend; but all things are possible. By the way\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, seeing that Beauchamp hesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you going to marry Mademoiselle Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you ask me now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause the rupture or fulfilment of this engagement is connected with\r\nthe person of whom we were speaking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, whose brow reddened; \xe2\x80\x9cyou think M. When they arrived at the\r\nMadeleine:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSince we are out,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9clet us call on M. de Monte Cristo;\r\nhe is admirably adapted to revive one\xe2\x80\x99s spirits, because he never\r\ninterrogates, and in my opinion those who ask no questions are the best\r\ncomforters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGladly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert; \xe2\x80\x9clet us call\xe2\x80\x94I love him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 85. The Journey\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo uttered a joyful exclamation on seeing the young men\r\ntogether. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, ha!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI hope all is over, explained and\r\nsettled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9cthe absurd reports have died away, and should\r\nthey be renewed, I would be the first to oppose them; so let us speak\r\nno more of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert will tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count \xe2\x80\x9cthat I gave him the same\r\nadvice. Cavalcanti is going to marry Mademoiselle Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nBeauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly! do you come from the end of the world?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou, a journalist, the husband of renown? No, you do not know me; I have done all in my power to oppose\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, I understand,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9con our friend Albert\xe2\x80\x99s account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my account?\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man; \xe2\x80\x9coh, no, indeed, the count will do\r\nme the justice to assert that I have, on the contrary, always entreated\r\nhim to break off my engagement, and happily it is ended. The count\r\npretends I have not him to thank;\xe2\x80\x94so be it\xe2\x80\x94I will erect an altar _Deo\r\nignoto_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI have had little to do with it, for I am\r\nat variance both with the father-in-law and the young man; there is\r\nonly Mademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie, who appears but little charmed with the\r\nthoughts of matrimony, and who, seeing how little I was disposed to\r\npersuade her to renounce her dear liberty, retains any affection for\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you say this wedding is at hand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, in spite of all I could say. I do not know the young man; he\r\nis said to be of good family and rich, but I never trust to vague\r\nassertions. I have warned M. Danglars of it till I am tired, but he is\r\nfascinated with his Luccanese. I have even informed him of a\r\ncircumstance I consider very serious; the young man was either charmed\r\nby his nurse, stolen by gypsies, or lost by his tutor, I scarcely know\r\nwhich. But I do know his father lost sight of him for more than ten\r\nyears; what he did during these ten years, God only knows. Well, all\r\nthat was useless. They have commissioned me to write to the major to\r\ndemand papers, and here they are. I send them, but like Pilate\xe2\x80\x94washing\r\nmy hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what does Mademoiselle d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly say to you for robbing her of her\r\npupil?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, well, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know; but I understand that she is going to Italy.\r\nMadame Danglars asked me for letters of recommendation for the\r\n_impresari_; I gave her a few lines for the director of the Valle\r\nTheatre, who is under some obligation to me. Who is this\r\nCaderousse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome Proven\xc3\xa7al, it appears. M. de Villefort heard of him at\r\nMarseilles, and M. Danglars recollects having seen him. Consequently,\r\nthe procureur is very active in the affair, and the prefect of police\r\nvery much interested; and, thanks to that interest, for which I am very\r\ngrateful, they send me all the robbers of Paris and the neighborhood,\r\nunder pretence of their being Caderousse\xe2\x80\x99s murderers, so that in three\r\nmonths, if this continues, every robber and assassin in France will\r\nhave the plan of my house at his fingers\xe2\x80\x99 ends. I am resolved to desert\r\nthem and go to some remote corner of the earth, and shall be happy if\r\nyou will accompany me, viscount.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWillingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it is settled?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but where?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have told you, where the air is pure, where every sound soothes,\r\nwhere one is sure to be humbled, however proud may be his nature. I\r\nlove that humiliation, I, who am master of the universe, as was\r\nAugustus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where are you really going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo sea, viscount; you know I am a sailor. I was rocked when an infant\r\nin the arms of old Ocean, and on the bosom of the beautiful Amphitrite;\r\nI have sported with the green mantle of the one and the azure robe of\r\nthe other; I love the sea as a mistress, and pine if I do not often see\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go, count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo sea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou accept my proposal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, viscount, there will be in my courtyard this evening a good\r\ntravelling britzka, with four post-horses, in which one may rest as in\r\na bed. M. Beauchamp, it holds four very well, will you accompany us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, I have just returned from sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? you have been to sea?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I have just made a little excursion to the Borromean Islands18.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat of that? come with us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, dear Morcerf; you know I only refuse when the thing is impossible.\r\nBesides, it is important,\xe2\x80\x9d added he in a low tone, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I should\r\nremain in Paris just now to watch the paper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you are a good and an excellent friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cyes, you\r\nare right; watch, watch, Beauchamp, and try to discover the enemy who\r\nmade this disclosure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert and Beauchamp parted, the last pressure of their hands\r\nexpressing what their tongues could not before a stranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeauchamp is a worthy fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, when the journalist\r\nwas gone; \xe2\x80\x9cis he not, Albert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and a sincere friend; I love him devotedly. But now we are\r\nalone,\xe2\x80\x94although it is immaterial to me,\xe2\x80\x94where are we going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInto Normandy, if you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDelightful; shall we be quite retired? have no society, no neighbors?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur companions will be riding-horses, dogs to hunt with, and a\r\nfishing-boat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly what I wish for; I will apprise my mother of my intention, and\r\nreturn to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut shall you be allowed to go into Normandy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI may go where I please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I am aware you may go alone, since I once met you in Italy\xe2\x80\x94but to\r\naccompany the mysterious Monte Cristo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou forget, count, that I have often told you of the deep interest my\r\nmother takes in you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Woman is fickle.\xe2\x80\x99 said Francis I.; \xe2\x80\x98woman is like a wave of the sea,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsaid Shakespeare; both the great king and the great poet ought to have\r\nknown woman\xe2\x80\x99s nature well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWoman\xe2\x80\x99s, yes; my mother is not woman, but _a_ woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I am only a humble foreigner, you must pardon me if I do not\r\nunderstand all the subtle refinements of your language.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I mean to say is, that my mother is not quick to give her\r\nconfidence, but when she does she never changes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo with a sigh; \xe2\x80\x9cand do you think she\r\nis in the least interested in me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI repeat it, you must really be a very strange and superior man, for\r\nmy mother is so absorbed by the interest you have excited, that when I\r\nam with her she speaks of no one else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd does she try to make you dislike me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, she often says, \xe2\x80\x98Morcerf, I believe the count has a\r\nnoble nature; try to gain his esteem.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, sighing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat instead of opposing, she will\r\nencourage me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, then, until five o\xe2\x80\x99clock; be punctual, and we shall arrive at\r\ntwelve or one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Tr\xc3\xa9port?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; or in the neighborhood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut can we travel forty-eight leagues in eight hours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEasily,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are certainly a prodigy; you will soon not only surpass the\r\nrailway, which would not be very difficult in France, but even the\r\ntelegraph.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, viscount, since we cannot perform the journey in less than seven\r\nor eight hours, do not keep me waiting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not fear, I have little to prepare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo smiled as he nodded to Albert, then remained a moment\r\nabsorbed in deep meditation. But passing his hand across his forehead\r\nas if to dispel his reverie, he rang the bell twice and Bertuccio\r\nentered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBertuccio,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI intend going this evening to Normandy, instead\r\nof tomorrow or the next day. You will have sufficient time before five\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock; despatch a messenger to apprise the grooms at the first\r\nstation. M. de Morcerf will accompany me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBertuccio obeyed and despatched a courier to Pontoise to say the\r\ntravelling-carriage would arrive at six o\xe2\x80\x99clock. From Pontoise another\r\nexpress was sent to the next stage, and in six hours all the horses\r\nstationed on the road were ready.\r\n\r\nBefore his departure, the count went to Hayd\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x99s apartments, told her\r\nhis intention, and resigned everything to her care.\r\n\r\nAlbert was punctual. The journey soon became interesting from its\r\nrapidity, of which Morcerf had formed no previous idea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cwith your post-horses going at the rate of\r\ntwo leagues an hour, and that absurd law that one traveller shall not\r\npass another without permission, so that an invalid or ill-tempered\r\ntraveller may detain those who are well and active, it is impossible to\r\nmove; I escape this annoyance by travelling with my own postilion and\r\nhorses; do I not, Ali?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count put his head out of the window and whistled, and the horses\r\nappeared to fly. The carriage rolled with a thundering noise over the\r\npavement, and everyone turned to notice the dazzling meteor. Ali,\r\nsmiling, repeated the sound, grasped the reins with a firm hand, and\r\nspurred his horses, whose beautiful manes floated in the breeze. This\r\nchild of the desert was in his element, and with his black face and\r\nsparkling eyes appeared, in the cloud of dust he raised, like the\r\ngenius of the simoom and the god of the hurricane.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never knew till now the delight of speed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, and the\r\nlast cloud disappeared from his brow; \xe2\x80\x9cbut where the devil do you get\r\nsuch horses? Are they made to order?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9csix years since I bought a horse in\r\nHungary remarkable for its swiftness. The thirty-two that we shall use\r\ntonight are its progeny; they are all entirely black, with the\r\nexception of a star upon the forehead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is perfectly admirable; but what do you do, count, with all these\r\nhorses?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, I travel with them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you are not always travelling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I no longer require them, Bertuccio will sell them, and he\r\nexpects to realize thirty or forty thousand francs by the sale.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut no monarch in Europe will be wealthy enough to purchase them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he will sell them to some Eastern vizier, who will empty his\r\ncoffers to purchase them, and refill them by applying the bastinado to\r\nhis subjects.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount, may I suggest one idea to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is that, next to you, Bertuccio must be the richest gentleman in\r\nEurope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken, viscount; I believe he has not a franc in his\r\npossession.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he must be a wonder. My dear count, if you tell me many more\r\nmarvellous things, I warn you I shall not believe them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI countenance nothing that is marvellous, M. Albert. Tell me, why does\r\na steward rob his master?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, I suppose, it is his nature to do so, for the love of\r\nrobbing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken; it is because he has a wife and family, and\r\nambitious desires for himself and them. Also because he is not sure of\r\nalways retaining his situation, and wishes to provide for the future.\r\nNow, M. Bertuccio is alone in the world; he uses my property without\r\naccounting for the use he makes of it; he is sure never to leave my\r\nservice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I should never get a better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProbabilities are deceptive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I deal in certainties; he is the best servant over whom one has\r\nthe power of life and death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you possess that right over Bertuccio?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere are words which close a conversation with an iron door; such was\r\nthe count\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cyes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe whole journey was performed with equal rapidity; the thirty-two\r\nhorses, dispersed over seven stages, brought them to their destination\r\nin eight hours. At midnight they arrived at the gate of a beautiful\r\npark. The porter was in attendance; he had been apprised by the groom\r\nof the last stage of the count\xe2\x80\x99s approach. At half past two in the\r\nmorning Morcerf was conducted to his apartments, where a bath and\r\nsupper were prepared. The servant who had travelled at the back of the\r\ncarriage waited on him; Baptistin, who rode in front, attended the\r\ncount.\r\n\r\nAlbert bathed, took his supper, and went to bed. All night he was\r\nlulled by the melancholy noise of the surf.
