On rising, he went to his\r\nwindow, which opened on a terrace, having the sea in front, and at the\r\nback a pretty park bounded by a small forest.\r\n\r\nIn a creek lay a little sloop, with a narrow keel and high masts,\r\nbearing on its flag the Monte Cristo arms which were a mountain _or_,\r\non a sea _azure_, with a cross _gules_ in chief which might be an\r\nallusion to his name that recalled Calvary, the mount rendered by our\r\nLord\xe2\x80\x99s passion more precious than gold, and to the degrading cross\r\nwhich his blood had rendered holy; or it might be some personal\r\nremembrance of suffering and regeneration buried in the night of this\r\nmysterious personage\xe2\x80\x99s pas life.\r\n\r\nAround the schooner lay a number of small fishing-boats belonging to\r\nthe fishermen of the neighboring village, like humble subjects awaiting\r\norders from their queen. There, as in every spot where Monte Cristo\r\nstopped, if but for two days, luxury abounded and life went on with the\r\nutmost ease.\r\n\r\nAlbert found in his anteroom two guns, with all the accoutrements for\r\nhunting; a lofty room on the ground floor containing all the ingenious\r\ninstruments the English\xe2\x80\x94eminent in piscatory pursuits, since they are\r\npatient and sluggish\xe2\x80\x94have invented for fishing. The day passed in\r\npursuing those exercises in which Monte Cristo excelled. They killed a\r\ndozen pheasants in the park, as many trout in the stream, dined in a\r\nsummer-house overlooking the ocean, and took tea in the library.\r\n\r\nTowards the evening of the third day. Albert, completely exhausted with\r\nthe exercise which invigorated Monte Cristo, was sleeping in an\r\narmchair near the window, while the count was designing with his\r\narchitect the plan of a conservatory in his house, when the sound of a\r\nhorse at full speed on the high road made Albert look up. He was\r\ndisagreeably surprised to see his own valet de chambre, whom he had not\r\nbrought, that he might not inconvenience Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n40188m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFlorentin here!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, starting up; \xe2\x80\x9cis my mother ill?\xe2\x80\x9d And he\r\nhastened to the door. Monte Cristo watched and saw him approach the\r\nvalet, who drew a small sealed parcel from his pocket, containing a\r\nnewspaper and a letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom whom is this?\xe2\x80\x9d said he eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom M. Beauchamp,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Florentin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he send you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir; he sent for me to his house, gave me money for my journey,\r\nprocured a horse, and made me promise not to stop till I had reached\r\nyou, I have come in fifteen hours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert opened the letter with fear, uttered a shriek on reading the\r\nfirst line, and seized the paper. His sight was dimmed, his legs sank\r\nunder him, and he would have fallen had not Florentin supported him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor young man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo in a low voice; \xe2\x80\x9cit is then true\r\nthat the sin of the father shall fall on the children to the third and\r\nfourth generation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMeanwhile Albert had revived, and, continuing to read, he threw back\r\nhis head, saying:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFlorentin, is your horse fit to return immediately?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a poor, lame post-horse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what state was the house when you left?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll was quiet, but on returning from M. Beauchamp\xe2\x80\x99s, I found madame in\r\ntears; she had sent for me to know when you would return. I told her my\r\norders from M. Beauchamp; she first extended her arms to prevent me,\r\nbut after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s reflection, \xe2\x80\x98Yes, go, Florentin,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, \xe2\x80\x98and\r\nmay he come quickly.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI will return, and woe to the infamous\r\nwretch! But first of all I must get there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went back to the room where he had left Monte Cristo. Five minutes\r\nhad sufficed to make a complete transformation in his appearance. His\r\nvoice had become rough and hoarse; his face was furrowed with wrinkles;\r\nhis eyes burned under the blue-veined lids, and he tottered like a\r\ndrunken man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI thank you for your hospitality, which I would\r\ngladly have enjoyed longer; but I must return to Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has happened?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA great misfortune, more important to me than life. Don\xe2\x80\x99t question me,\r\nI beg of you, but lend me a horse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy stables are at your command, viscount; but you will kill yourself\r\nby riding on horseback. Take a post-chaise or a carriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it would delay me, and I need the fatigue you warn me of; it will\r\ndo me good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert reeled as if he had been shot, and fell on a chair near the\r\ndoor. Monte Cristo did not see this second manifestation of physical\r\nexhaustion; he was at the window, calling:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAli, a horse for M. de Morcerf\xe2\x80\x94quick! he is in a hurry!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40190m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThese words restored Albert; he darted from the room, followed by the\r\ncount.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, throwing himself on his horse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReturn as soon as you can, Florentin. Must I use any password to\r\nprocure a horse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly dismount; another will be immediately saddled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert hesitated a moment. \xe2\x80\x9cYou may think my departure strange and\r\nfoolish,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man; \xe2\x80\x9cyou do not know how a paragraph in a\r\nnewspaper may exasperate one. Read that,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen I am gone,\r\nthat you may not be witness of my anger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile the count picked up the paper he put spurs to his horse, which\r\nleaped in astonishment at such an unusual stimulus, and shot away with\r\nthe rapidity of an arrow. The count watched him with a feeling of\r\ncompassion, and when he had completely disappeared, read as follows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe French officer in the service of Ali Pasha of Yanina alluded to\r\nthree weeks since in _l\xe2\x80\x99Impartial_, who not only surrendered the castle\r\nof Yanina, but sold his benefactor to the Turks, styled himself truly\r\nat that time Fernand, as our esteemed contemporary states; but he has\r\nsince added to his Christian name a title of nobility and a family\r\nname. He now calls himself the Count of Morcerf, and ranks among the\r\npeers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus the terrible secret, which Beauchamp had so generously destroyed,\r\nappeared again like an armed phantom; and another paper, deriving its\r\ninformation from some malicious source, had published two days after\r\nAlbert\xe2\x80\x99s departure for Normandy the few lines which had rendered the\r\nunfortunate young man almost crazy.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 86. The Trial\r\n\r\nAt eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning Albert had arrived at Beauchamp\xe2\x80\x99s door.\r\nThe valet de chambre had received orders to usher him in at once.\r\nBeauchamp was in his bath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere I am,\xe2\x80\x9d Albert said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my poor friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cI expected you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI need not say I think you are too faithful and too kind to have\r\nspoken of that painful circumstance. Your having sent for me is another\r\nproof of your affection. So, without losing time, tell me, have you the\r\nslightest idea whence this terrible blow proceeds?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I have some clew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut first tell me all the particulars of this shameful plot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBeauchamp proceeded to relate to the young man, who was overwhelmed\r\nwith shame and grief, the following facts. Two days previously, the\r\narticle had appeared in another paper besides _ l\xe2\x80\x99Impartial_, and, what\r\nwas more serious, one that was well known as a government paper.\r\nBeauchamp was breakfasting when he read the paragraph. He sent\r\nimmediately for a cabriolet, and hastened to the publisher\xe2\x80\x99s office.\r\nAlthough professing diametrically opposite principles from those of the\r\neditor of the other paper, Beauchamp\xe2\x80\x94as it sometimes, we may say often,\r\nhappens\xe2\x80\x94was his intimate friend. The editor was reading, with apparent\r\ndelight, a leading article in the same paper on beet-sugar, probably a\r\ncomposition of his own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, _pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cwith the paper in your hand, my\r\nfriend, I need not tell you the cause of my visit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you interested in the sugar question?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the editor of the\r\nministerial paper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cI have not considered the question; a totally\r\ndifferent subject interests me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe article relative to Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed? Is it not a curious affair?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo curious, that I think you are running a great risk of a prosecution\r\nfor defamation of character.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all; we have received with the information all the requisite\r\nproofs, and we are quite sure M. de Morcerf will not raise his voice\r\nagainst us; besides, it is rendering a service to one\xe2\x80\x99s country to\r\ndenounce these wretched criminals who are unworthy of the honor\r\nbestowed on them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBeauchamp was thunderstruck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho, then, has so correctly informed you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he; \xe2\x80\x9cfor my paper,\r\nwhich gave the first information on the subject, has been obliged to\r\nstop for want of proof; and yet we are more interested than you in\r\nexposing M. de Morcerf, as he is a peer of France, and we are of the\r\nopposition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that is very simple; we have not sought to scandalize. This news\r\nwas brought to us. A man arrived yesterday from Yanina, bringing a\r\nformidable array of documents; and when we hesitated to publish the\r\naccusatory article, he told us it should be inserted in some other\r\npaper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBeauchamp understood that nothing remained but to submit, and left the\r\noffice to despatch a courier to Morcerf. But he had been unable to send\r\nto Albert the following particulars, as the events had transpired after\r\nthe messenger\xe2\x80\x99s departure; namely, that the same day a great agitation\r\nwas manifest in the House of Peers among the usually calm members of\r\nthat dignified assembly. Everyone had arrived almost before the usual\r\nhour, and was conversing on the melancholy event which was to attract\r\nthe attention of the public towards one of their most illustrious\r\ncolleagues. Some were perusing the article, others making comments and\r\nrecalling circumstances which substantiated the charges still more.\r\n\r\nThe Count of Morcerf was no favorite with his colleagues. Like all\r\nupstarts, he had had recourse to a great deal of haughtiness to\r\nmaintain his position. The true nobility laughed at him, the talented\r\nrepelled him, and the honorable instinctively despised him. He was, in\r\nfact, in the unhappy position of the victim marked for sacrifice; the\r\nfinger of God once pointed at him, everyone was prepared to raise the\r\nhue and cry.\r\n\r\nThe Count of Morcerf alone was ignorant of the news. He did not take in\r\nthe paper containing the defamatory article, and had passed the morning\r\nin writing letters and in trying a horse. He arrived at his usual hour,\r\nwith a proud look and insolent demeanor; he alighted, passed through\r\nthe corridors, and entered the house without observing the hesitation\r\nof the door-keepers or the coolness of his colleagues.\r\n\r\n40194m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBusiness had already been going on for half an hour when he entered.\r\nEveryone held the accusing paper, but, as usual, no one liked to take\r\nupon himself the responsibility of the attack. At length an honorable\r\npeer, Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s acknowledged enemy, ascended the tribune with that\r\nsolemnity which announced that the expected moment had arrived. There\r\nwas an impressive silence; Morcerf alone knew not why such profound\r\nattention was given to an orator who was not always listened to with so\r\nmuch complacency.\r\n\r\nThe count did not notice the introduction, in which the speaker\r\nannounced that his communication would be of that vital importance that\r\nit demanded the undivided attention of the House; but at the mention of\r\nYanina and Colonel Fernand, he turned so frightfully pale that every\r\nmember shuddered and fixed his eyes upon him. Moral wounds have this\r\npeculiarity,\xe2\x80\x94they may be hidden, but they never close; always painful,\r\nalways ready to bleed when touched, they remain fresh and open in the\r\nheart.\r\n\r\nThe article having been read during the painful hush that followed, a\r\nuniversal shudder pervaded the assembly, and immediately the closest\r\nattention was given to the orator as he resumed his remarks. He stated\r\nhis scruples and the difficulties of the case; it was the honor of M.\r\nde Morcerf, and that of the whole House, he proposed to defend, by\r\nprovoking a debate on personal questions, which are always such painful\r\nthemes of discussion. He concluded by calling for an investigation,\r\nwhich might dispose of the calumnious report before it had time to\r\nspread, and restore M. de Morcerf to the position he had long held in\r\npublic opinion.\r\n\r\nMorcerf was so completely overwhelmed by this great and unexpected\r\ncalamity that he could scarcely stammer a few words as he looked around\r\non the assembly. This timidity, which might proceed from the\r\nastonishment of innocence as well as the shame of guilt, conciliated\r\nsome in his favor; for men who are truly generous are always ready to\r\ncompassionate when the misfortune of their enemy surpasses the limits\r\nof their hatred.\r\n\r\nThe president put it to the vote, and it was decided that the\r\ninvestigation should take place. The count was asked what time he\r\nrequired to prepare his defence. Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s courage had revived when he\r\nfound himself alive after this horrible blow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy lords,\xe2\x80\x9d answered he, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not by time I could repel the attack\r\nmade on me by enemies unknown to me, and, doubtless, hidden in\r\nobscurity; it is immediately, and by a thunderbolt, that I must repel\r\nthe flash of lightning which, for a moment, startled me. Oh, that I\r\ncould, instead of taking up this defence, shed my last drop of blood to\r\nprove to my noble colleagues that I am their equal in worth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese words made a favorable impression on behalf of the accused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI demand, then, that the examination shall take place as soon as\r\npossible, and I will furnish the house with all necessary information.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat day do you fix?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the president.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cToday I am at your service,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count.\r\n\r\nThe president rang the bell. \xe2\x80\x9cDoes the House approve that the\r\nexamination should take place today?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40196m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d was the unanimous answer.\r\n\r\nA committee of twelve members was chosen to examine the proofs brought\r\nforward by Morcerf. The investigation would begin at eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock that\r\nevening in the committee-room, and if postponement were necessary, the\r\nproceedings would be resumed each evening at the same hour. Morcerf\r\nasked leave to retire; he had to collect the documents he had long been\r\npreparing against this storm, which his sagacity had foreseen.\r\n\r\nBeauchamp related to the young man all the facts we have just narrated;\r\nhis story, however, had over ours all the advantage of the animation of\r\nliving things over the coldness of dead things.\r\n\r\nAlbert listened, trembling now with hope, then with anger, and then\r\nagain with shame, for from Beauchamp\xe2\x80\x99s confidence he knew his father\r\nwas guilty, and he asked himself how, since he was guilty, he could\r\nprove his innocence. Beauchamp hesitated to continue his narrative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat next?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat next? My friend, you impose a painful task on me. Must you know\r\nall?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbsolutely; and rather from your lips than another\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuster up all your courage, then, for never have you required it\r\nmore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert passed his hand over his forehead, as if to try his strength, as\r\na man who is preparing to defend his life proves his shield and bends\r\nhis sword. He thought himself strong enough, for he mistook fever for\r\nenergy. \xe2\x80\x9cGo on,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe evening arrived; all Paris was in expectation. Many said your\r\nfather had only to show himself to crush the charge against him; many\r\nothers said he would not appear; while some asserted that they had seen\r\nhim start for Brussels; and others went to the police-office to inquire\r\nif he had taken out a passport. I used all my influence with one of the\r\ncommittee, a young peer of my acquaintance, to get admission to one of\r\nthe galleries. He called for me at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and, before anyone\r\nhad arrived, asked one of the door-keepers to place me in a box. I was\r\nconcealed by a column, and might witness the whole of the terrible\r\nscene which was about to take place. At eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock all were in their\r\nplaces, and M. de Morcerf entered at the last stroke. He held some\r\npapers in his hand; his countenance was calm, and his step firm, and he\r\nwas dressed with great care in his military uniform, which was buttoned\r\ncompletely up to the chin. His presence produced a good effect. The\r\ncommittee was made up of Liberals, several of whom came forward to\r\nshake hands with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert felt his heart bursting at these particulars, but gratitude\r\nmingled with his sorrow: he would gladly have embraced those who had\r\ngiven his father this proof of esteem at a moment when his honor was so\r\npowerfully attacked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt this moment one of the door-keepers brought in a letter for the\r\npresident. \xe2\x80\x98You are at liberty to speak, M. de Morcerf,\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\npresident, as he unsealed the letter; and the count began his defence,\r\nI assure you, Albert, in a most eloquent and skilful manner. He\r\nproduced documents proving that the Vizier of Yanina had up to the last\r\nmoment honored him with his entire confidence, since he had interested\r\nhim with a negotiation of life and death with the emperor. He produced\r\nthe ring, his mark of authority, with which Ali Pasha generally sealed\r\nhis letters, and which the latter had given him, that he might, on his\r\nreturn at any hour of the day or night, gain access to the presence,\r\neven in the harem. Unfortunately, the negotiation failed, and when he\r\nreturned to defend his benefactor, he was dead. \xe2\x80\x98But,\xe2\x80\x99 said the count,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98so great was Ali Pasha\xe2\x80\x99s confidence, that on his death-bed he resigned\r\nhis favorite mistress and her daughter to my care.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert started on hearing these words; the history of Hayd\xc3\xa9e recurred\r\nto him, and he remembered what she had said of that message and the\r\nring, and the manner in which she had been sold and made a slave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what effect did this discourse produce?\xe2\x80\x9d anxiously inquired\r\nAlbert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI acknowledge it affected me, and, indeed, all the committee also,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMeanwhile, the president carelessly opened the letter which had been\r\nbrought to him; but the first lines aroused his attention; he read them\r\nagain and again, and fixing his eyes on M. de Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x98Count,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nhe, \xe2\x80\x98you have said that the Vizier of Yanina confided his wife and\r\ndaughter to your care?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Morcerf; \xe2\x80\x98but in that, like\r\nall the rest, misfortune pursued me. On my return, Vasiliki and her\r\ndaughter Hayd\xc3\xa9e had disappeared.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Did you know them?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98My intimacy\r\nwith the pasha and his unlimited confidence had gained me an\r\nintroduction to them, and I had seen them above twenty times.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Have you any idea what became of them?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir; I heard they had\r\nfallen victims to their sorrow, and, perhaps, to their poverty. I was\r\nnot rich; my life was in constant danger; I could not seek them, to my\r\ngreat regret.\xe2\x80\x99 The president frowned imperceptibly. \xe2\x80\x98Gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nhe, \xe2\x80\x98you have heard the Comte de Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s defence. Can you, sir,\r\nproduce any witnesses to the truth of what you have asserted?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Alas,\r\nno, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the count; \xe2\x80\x98all those who surrounded the vizier,\r\nor who knew me at his court, are either dead or gone away, I know not\r\nwhere. I believe that I alone, of all my countrymen, survived that\r\ndreadful war. I have only the letters of Ali Tepelini, which I have\r\nplaced before you; the ring, a token of his good-will, which is here;\r\nand, lastly, the most convincing proof I can offer, after an anonymous\r\nattack, and that is the absence of any witness against my veracity and\r\nthe purity of my military life.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA murmur of approbation ran through the assembly; and at this moment,\r\nAlbert, had nothing more transpired, your father\xe2\x80\x99s cause had been\r\ngained. It only remained to put it to the vote, when the president\r\nresumed: \xe2\x80\x98Gentlemen and you, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x94you will not be displeased, I\r\npresume, to listen to one who calls himself a very important witness,\r\nand who has just presented himself. He is, doubtless, come to prove the\r\nperfect innocence of our colleague. Here is a letter I have just\r\nreceived on the subject; shall it be read, or shall it be passed over?\r\nand shall we take no notice of this incident?\xe2\x80\x99 M. de Morcerf turned\r\npale, and clenched his hands on the papers he held. The committee\r\ndecided to hear the letter; the count was thoughtful and silent. The\r\npresident read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Mr. President,\xe2\x80\x94I can furnish the committee of inquiry into the\r\nconduct of the Lieutenant-General the Count of Morcerf in Epirus and in\r\nMacedonia with important particulars.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe president paused, and the count turned pale. The president looked\r\nat his auditors. \xe2\x80\x98Proceed,\xe2\x80\x99 was heard on all sides. The president\r\nresumed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I was on the spot at the death of Ali Pasha. I was present during his\r\nlast moments. I know what is become of Vasiliki and Hayd\xc3\xa9e. I am at the\r\ncommand of the committee, and even claim the honor of being heard. I\r\nshall be in the lobby when this note is delivered to you.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98And who is this witness, or rather this enemy?\xe2\x80\x99 asked the count, in a\r\ntone in which there was a visible alteration. \xe2\x80\x98We shall know, sir,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nreplied the president. \xe2\x80\x98Is the committee willing to hear this\r\nwitness?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Yes, yes,\xe2\x80\x99 they all said at once. The door-keeper was\r\ncalled. \xe2\x80\x98Is there anyone in the lobby?\xe2\x80\x99 said the president.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Yes, sir.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Who is it?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98A woman, accompanied by a servant.\xe2\x80\x99 Everyone\r\nlooked at his neighbor. \xe2\x80\x98Bring her in,\xe2\x80\x99 said the president. Five\r\nminutes after the door-keeper again appeared; all eyes were fixed on\r\nthe door, and I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cshared the general expectation and\r\nanxiety. Behind the door-keeper walked a woman enveloped in a large\r\nveil, which completely concealed her. It was evident, from her figure\r\nand the perfumes she had about her, that she was young and fastidious\r\nin her tastes, but that was all. The president requested her to throw\r\naside her veil, and it was then seen that she was dressed in the\r\nGrecian costume, and was remarkably beautiful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cit was she.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHayd\xc3\xa9e.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho told you that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, I guess it. But go on, Beauchamp. You see I am calm and strong.\r\nAnd yet we must be drawing near the disclosure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Morcerf,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9clooked at this woman with\r\nsurprise and terror. Her lips were about to pass his sentence of life\r\nor death. To the committee the adventure was so extraordinary and\r\ncurious, that the interest they had felt for the count\xe2\x80\x99s safety became\r\nnow quite a secondary matter. The president himself advanced to place a\r\nseat for the young lady; but she declined availing herself of it. As\r\nfor the count, he had fallen on his chair; it was evident that his legs\r\nrefused to support him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Madame,\xe2\x80\x99 said the president, \xe2\x80\x98you have engaged to furnish the\r\ncommittee with some important particulars respecting the affair at\r\nYanina, and you have stated that you were an eyewitness of the\r\nevent.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I was, indeed,\xe2\x80\x99 said the stranger, with a tone of sweet\r\nmelancholy, and with the sonorous voice peculiar to the East.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98But allow me to say that you must have been very young then.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I was\r\nfour years old; but as those events deeply concerned me, not a single\r\ndetail has escaped my memory.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98In what manner could these events\r\nconcern you? and who are you, that they should have made so deep an\r\nimpression on you?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98On them depended my father\xe2\x80\x99s life,\xe2\x80\x99 replied she.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I am Hayd\xc3\xa9e, the daughter of Ali Tepelini, pasha of Yanina, and of\r\nVasiliki, his beloved wife.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n40202m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe blush of mingled pride and modesty which suddenly suffused the\r\ncheeks of the young woman, the brilliancy of her eye, and her highly\r\nimportant communication, produced an indescribable effect on the\r\nassembly. As for the count, he could not have been more overwhelmed if\r\na thunderbolt had fallen at his feet and opened an immense gulf before\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Madame,\xe2\x80\x99 replied the president, bowing with profound respect, \xe2\x80\x98allow\r\nme to ask one question; it shall be the last: Can you prove the\r\nauthenticity of what you have now stated?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I can, sir,\xe2\x80\x99 said Hayd\xc3\xa9e, drawing from under her veil a satin satchel\r\nhighly perfumed; \xe2\x80\x98for here is the register of my birth, signed by my\r\nfather and his principal officers, and that of my baptism, my father\r\nhaving consented to my being brought up in my mother\xe2\x80\x99s faith,\xe2\x80\x94this\r\nlatter has been sealed by the grand primate of Macedonia and Epirus;\r\nand lastly (and perhaps the most important), the record of the sale of\r\nmy person and that of my mother to the Armenian merchant El-Kobbir, by\r\nthe French officer, who, in his infamous bargain with the Porte, had\r\nreserved as his part of the booty the wife and daughter of his\r\nbenefactor, whom he sold for the sum of four hundred thousand francs.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nA greenish pallor spread over the count\xe2\x80\x99s cheeks, and his eyes became\r\nbloodshot at these terrible imputations, which were listened to by the\r\nassembly with ominous silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHayd\xc3\xa9e, still calm, but with a calmness more dreadful than the anger\r\nof another would have been, handed to the president the record of her\r\nsale, written in Arabic. It had been supposed some of the papers might\r\nbe in the Arabian, Romaic, or Turkish language, and the interpreter of\r\nthe House was in attendance. One of the noble peers, who was familiar\r\nwith the Arabic language, having studied it during the famous Egyptian\r\ncampaign, followed with his eye as the translator read aloud:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I, El-Kobbir, a slave-merchant, and purveyor of the harem of his\r\nhighness, acknowledge having received for transmission to the sublime\r\nemperor, from the French lord, the Count of Monte Cristo, an emerald\r\nvalued at eight hundred thousand francs; as the ransom of a young\r\nChristian slave of eleven years of age, named Hayd\xc3\xa9e, the acknowledged\r\ndaughter of the late lord Ali Tepelini, pasha of Yanina, and of\r\nVasiliki, his favorite; she having been sold to me seven years\r\npreviously, with her mother, who had died on arriving at\r\nConstantinople, by a French colonel in the service of the Vizier Ali\r\nTepelini, named Fernand Mondego. The above-mentioned purchase was made\r\non his highness\xe2\x80\x99s account, whose mandate I had, for the sum of four\r\nhundred thousand francs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Given at Constantinople, by authority of his highness, in the year\r\n1247 of the Hegira.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Signed, El-Kobbir.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98That this record should have all due authority, it shall bear the\r\nimperial seal, which the vendor is bound to have affixed to it.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNear the merchant\xe2\x80\x99s signature there was, indeed, the seal of the\r\nsublime emperor. A dreadful silence followed the reading of this\r\ndocument; the count could only stare, and his gaze, fixed as if\r\nunconsciously on Hayd\xc3\xa9e, seemed one of fire and blood. \xe2\x80\x98Madame,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nthe president, \xe2\x80\x98may reference be made to the Count of Monte Cristo, who\r\nis now, I believe, in Paris?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Hayd\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x98the Count of Monte Cristo, my foster-father,\r\nhas been in Normandy the last three days.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Who, then, has counselled you to take this step, one for which the\r\ncourt is deeply indebted to you, and which is perfectly natural,\r\nconsidering your birth and your misfortunes?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Sir,\xe2\x80\x99 replied Hayd\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x98I\r\nhave been led to take this step from a feeling of respect and grief.\r\nAlthough a Christian, may God forgive me, I have always sought to\r\nrevenge my illustrious father. Since I set my foot in France, and knew\r\nthe traitor lived in Paris, I have watched carefully. I live retired in\r\nthe house of my noble protector, but I do it from choice. I love\r\nretirement and silence, because I can live with my thoughts and\r\nrecollections of past days. But the Count of Monte Cristo surrounds me\r\nwith every paternal care, and I am ignorant of nothing which passes in\r\nthe world. I learn all in the silence of my apartments,\xe2\x80\x94for instance, I\r\nsee all the newspapers, every periodical, as well as every new piece of\r\nmusic; and by thus watching the course of the life of others, I learned\r\nwhat had transpired this morning in the House of Peers, and what was to\r\ntake place this evening; then I wrote.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n40204m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Then,\xe2\x80\x99 remarked the president, \xe2\x80\x98the Count of Monte Cristo knows\r\nnothing of your present proceedings?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98He is quite unaware of them, and\r\nI have but one fear, which is that he should disapprove of what I have\r\ndone. But it is a glorious day for me,\xe2\x80\x99 continued the young girl,\r\nraising her ardent gaze to heaven, \xe2\x80\x98that on which I find at last an\r\nopportunity of avenging my father!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count had not uttered one word the whole of this time. His\r\ncolleagues looked at him, and doubtless pitied his prospects, blighted\r\nunder the perfumed breath of a woman. His misery was depicted in\r\nsinister lines on his countenance. \xe2\x80\x98M. de Morcerf,\xe2\x80\x99 said the president,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98do you recognize this lady as the daughter of Ali Tepelini, pasha of\r\nYanina?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98No,\xe2\x80\x99 said Morcerf, attempting to rise, \xe2\x80\x98it is a base plot,\r\ncontrived by my enemies.\xe2\x80\x99 Hayd\xc3\xa9e, whose eyes had been fixed on the\r\ndoor, as if expecting someone, turned hastily, and, seeing the count\r\nstanding, shrieked, \xe2\x80\x98You do not know me?\xe2\x80\x99 said she. \xe2\x80\x98Well, I\r\nfortunately recognize you! You are Fernand Mondego, the French officer\r\nwho led the troops of my noble father! It is you who surrendered the\r\ncastle of Yanina! It is you who, sent by him to Constantinople, to\r\ntreat with the emperor for the life or death of your benefactor,\r\nbrought back a false mandate granting full pardon! It is you who, with\r\nthat mandate, obtained the pasha\xe2\x80\x99s ring, which gave you authority over\r\nSelim, the fire-keeper! It is you who stabbed Selim. It is you who sold\r\nus, my mother and me, to the merchant, El-Kobbir! Assassin, assassin,\r\nassassin, you have still on your brow your master\xe2\x80\x99s blood! Look,\r\ngentlemen, all!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese words had been pronounced with such enthusiasm and evident\r\ntruth, that every eye was fixed on the count\xe2\x80\x99s forehead, and he himself\r\npassed his hand across it, as if he felt Ali\xe2\x80\x99s blood still lingering\r\nthere. \xe2\x80\x98You positively recognize M. de Morcerf as the officer, Fernand\r\nMondego?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Indeed I do!\xe2\x80\x99 cried Hayd\xc3\xa9e. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, my mother, it was you who\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cYou were free, you had a beloved father, you were destined to be\r\nalmost a queen. Look well at that man; it is he who raised your\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s head on the point of a spear; it is he who sold us; it is he\r\nwho forsook us! Look well at his right hand, on which he has a large\r\nwound; if you forgot his features, you would know him by that hand,\r\ninto which fell, one by one, the gold pieces of the merchant\r\nEl-Kobbir!\xe2\x80\x9d I know him! Ah, let him say now if he does not recognize\r\nme!\xe2\x80\x99 Each word fell like a dagger on Morcerf, and deprived him of a\r\nportion of his energy; as she uttered the last, he hid his mutilated\r\nhand hastily in his bosom, and fell back on his seat, overwhelmed by\r\nwretchedness and despair. This scene completely changed the opinion of\r\nthe assembly respecting the accused count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Count of Morcerf,\xe2\x80\x99 said the president, \xe2\x80\x98do not allow yourself to be\r\ncast down; answer. The justice of the court is supreme and impartial as\r\nthat of God; it will not suffer you to be trampled on by your enemies\r\nwithout giving you an opportunity of defending yourself. Shall further\r\ninquiries be made? Shall two members of the House be sent to Yanina?\r\nSpeak!\xe2\x80\x99 Morcerf did not reply. Then all the members looked at each\r\nother with terror. They knew the count\xe2\x80\x99s energetic and violent temper;\r\nit must be, indeed, a dreadful blow which would deprive him of courage\r\nto defend himself. They expected that his stupefied silence would be\r\nfollowed by a fiery outburst. \xe2\x80\x98Well,\xe2\x80\x99 asked the president, \xe2\x80\x98what is\r\nyour decision?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n40206m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I have no reply to make,\xe2\x80\x99 said the count in a low tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Has the daughter of Ali Tepelini spoken the truth?\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\npresident. \xe2\x80\x98Is she, then, the terrible witness to whose charge you dare\r\nnot plead \xe2\x80\x9cNot guilty\xe2\x80\x9d? Have you really committed the crimes of which\r\nyou are accused?\xe2\x80\x99 The count looked around him with an expression which\r\nmight have softened tigers, but which could not disarm his judges. Then\r\nhe raised his eyes towards the ceiling, but withdrew then, immediately,\r\nas if he feared the roof would open and reveal to his distressed view\r\nthat second tribunal called heaven, and that other judge named God.\r\nThen, with a hasty movement, he tore open his coat, which seemed to\r\nstifle him, and flew from the room like a madman; his footstep was\r\nheard one moment in the corridor, then the rattling of his\r\ncarriage-wheels as he was driven rapidly away. \xe2\x80\x98Gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99 said the\r\npresident, when silence was restored, \xe2\x80\x98is the Count of Morcerf\r\nconvicted of felony, treason, and conduct unbecoming a member of this\r\nHouse?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Yes,\xe2\x80\x99 replied all the members of the committee of inquiry with\r\na unanimous voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHayd\xc3\xa9e had remained until the close of the meeting. She heard the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s sentence pronounced without betraying an expression of joy or\r\npity; then drawing her veil over her face she bowed majestically to the\r\ncouncillors, and left with that dignified step which Virgil attributes\r\nto his goddesses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 87. The Challenge\r\n\r\nThen,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cI took advantage of the silence and the\r\ndarkness to leave the house without being seen. The usher who had\r\nintroduced me was waiting for me at the door, and he conducted me\r\nthrough the corridors to a private entrance opening into the Rue de\r\nVaugirard. I left with mingled feelings of sorrow and delight. Excuse\r\nme, Albert,\xe2\x80\x94sorrow on your account, and delight with that noble girl,\r\nthus pursuing paternal vengeance. Yes, Albert, from whatever source the\r\nblow may have proceeded\xe2\x80\x94it may be from an enemy, but that enemy is only\r\nthe agent of Providence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert held his head between his hands; he raised his face, red with\r\nshame and bathed in tears, and seizing Beauchamp\xe2\x80\x99s arm:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cmy life is ended. I cannot calmly say with you,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Providence has struck the blow;\xe2\x80\x99 but I must discover who pursues me\r\nwith this hatred, and when I have found him I shall kill him, or he\r\nwill kill me. I rely on your friendship to assist me, Beauchamp, if\r\ncontempt has not banished it from your heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cContempt, my friend? How does this misfortune affect you? No, happily\r\nthat unjust prejudice is forgotten which made the son responsible for\r\nthe father\xe2\x80\x99s actions. Review your life, Albert; although it is only\r\njust beginning, did a lovely summer\xe2\x80\x99s day ever dawn with greater purity\r\nthan has marked the commencement of your career? No, Albert, take my\r\nadvice. You are young and rich\xe2\x80\x94leave Paris\xe2\x80\x94all is soon forgotten in\r\nthis great Babylon of excitement and changing tastes. You will return\r\nafter three or four years with a Russian princess for a bride, and no\r\none will think more of what occurred yesterday than if it had happened\r\nsixteen years ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, my dear Beauchamp, thank you for the excellent feeling\r\nwhich prompts your advice; but it cannot be. I have told you my wish,\r\nor rather my determination. You understand that, interested as I am in\r\nthis affair, I cannot see it in the same light as you do. What appears\r\nto you to emanate from a celestial source, seems to me to proceed from\r\none far less pure. Providence appears to me to have no share in this\r\naffair; and happily so, for instead of the invisible, impalpable agent\r\nof celestial rewards and punishments, I shall find one both palpable\r\nand visible, on whom I shall revenge myself, I assure you, for all I\r\nhave suffered during the last month. Now, I repeat, Beauchamp, I wish\r\nto return to human and material existence, and if you are still the\r\nfriend you profess to be, help me to discover the hand that struck the\r\nblow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9cif you must have me descend to earth, I\r\nsubmit; and if you will seek your enemy, I will assist you, and I will\r\nengage to find him, my honor being almost as deeply interested as\r\nyours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, you understand, Beauchamp, that we begin our search\r\nimmediately. Each moment\xe2\x80\x99s delay is an eternity for me. The calumniator\r\nis not yet punished, and he may hope that he will not be; but, on my\r\nhonor, if he thinks so, he deceives himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, listen, Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Beauchamp, I see you know something already; you will restore me\r\nto life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not say there is any truth in what I am going to tell you, but it\r\nis, at least, a ray of light in a dark night; by following it we may,\r\nperhaps, discover something more certain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me; satisfy my impatience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will tell you what I did not like to mention on my return from\r\nYanina.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI went, of course, to the chief banker of the town to make inquiries.\r\nAt the first word, before I had even mentioned your father\xe2\x80\x99s name\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Ah,\xe2\x80\x99 said he. \xe2\x80\x98I guess what brings you here.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98How, and why?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Because a fortnight since I was questioned on the same subject.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98By whom?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98By a banker of Paris, my correspondent.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Whose name is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Danglars.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cyes, it is indeed he who has so long pursued my\r\nfather with jealous hatred. He, the man who would be popular, cannot\r\nforgive the Count of Morcerf for being created a peer; and this\r\nmarriage broken off without a reason being assigned\xe2\x80\x94yes, it is all from\r\nthe same cause.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMake inquiries, Albert, but do not be angry without reason; make\r\ninquiries, and if it be true\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, if it be true,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the young man, \xe2\x80\x9che shall pay me all I\r\nhave suffered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeware, Morcerf, he is already an old man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will respect his age as he has respected the honor of my family; if\r\nmy father had offended him, why did he not attack him personally? Oh,\r\nno, he was afraid to encounter him face to face.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not condemn you, Albert; I only restrain you. Act prudently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do not fear; besides, you will accompany me. Beauchamp, solemn\r\ntransactions should be sanctioned by a witness. Before this day closes,\r\nif M. Danglars is guilty, he shall cease to live, or I shall die.\r\n_Pardieu_, Beauchamp, mine shall be a splendid funeral!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen such resolutions are made, Albert, they should be promptly\r\nexecuted. Do you wish to go to M. Danglars? Let us go immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey sent for a cabriolet. On entering the banker\xe2\x80\x99s mansion, they\r\nperceived the phaeton and servant of M. Andrea Cavalcanti.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! _parbleu!_ that\xe2\x80\x99s good,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, with a gloomy tone. \xe2\x80\x9cIf M.\r\nDanglars will not fight with me, I will kill his son-in-law; Cavalcanti\r\nwill certainly fight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe servant announced the young man; but the banker, recollecting what\r\nhad transpired the day before, did not wish him admitted. It was,\r\nhowever, too late; Albert had followed the footman, and, hearing the\r\norder given, forced the door open, and followed by Beauchamp found\r\nhimself in the banker\xe2\x80\x99s study.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the latter, \xe2\x80\x9cam I no longer at liberty to receive whom I\r\nchoose in my house? You appear to forget yourself sadly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, coldly; \xe2\x80\x9cthere are circumstances in which one\r\ncannot, except through cowardice,\xe2\x80\x94I offer you that refuge,\xe2\x80\x94refuse to\r\nadmit certain persons at least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your errand, then, with me, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, drawing near, and without apparently noticing\r\nCavalcanti, who stood with his back towards the fireplace\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI mean to\r\npropose a meeting in some retired corner where no one will interrupt us\r\nfor ten minutes; that will be sufficient\xe2\x80\x94where two men having met, one\r\nof them will remain on the ground.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars turned pale; Cavalcanti moved a step forward, and Albert\r\nturned towards him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, too,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9ccome, if you like, monsieur; you have a\r\nclaim, being almost one of the family, and I will give as many\r\nrendezvous of that kind as I can find persons willing to accept them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCavalcanti looked at Danglars with a stupefied air, and the latter,\r\nmaking an effort, arose and stepped between the two young men. Albert\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattack on Andrea had placed him on a different footing, and he hoped\r\nthis visit had another cause than that he had at first supposed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cif you are come to quarrel with this\r\ngentleman because I have preferred him to you, I shall resign the case\r\nto the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mistake, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf with a gloomy smile; \xe2\x80\x9cI am not\r\nreferring in the least to matrimony, and I only addressed myself to M.\r\nCavalcanti because he appeared disposed to interfere between us. In one\r\nrespect you are right, for I am ready to quarrel with everyone today;\r\nbut you have the first claim, M. Danglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40212m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars, pale with anger and fear, \xe2\x80\x9cI warn you, when I\r\nhave the misfortune to meet with a mad dog, I kill it; and far from\r\nthinking myself guilty of a crime, I believe I do society a kindness.\r\nNow, if you are mad and try to bite me, I will kill you without pity.\r\nIs it my fault that your father has dishonored himself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, miserable wretch!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morcerf, \xe2\x80\x9cit is your fault.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars retreated a few steps. \xe2\x80\x9cMy fault?\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cyou must be mad!\r\nWhat do I know of the Grecian affair? Have I travelled in that country?\r\nDid I advise your father to sell the castle of Yanina\xe2\x80\x94to betray\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence!\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, with a thundering voice. \xe2\x80\x9cNo; it is not you who\r\nhave directly made this exposure and brought this sorrow on us, but you\r\nhypocritically provoked it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; you! How came it known?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you read it in the paper in the account from Yanina?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho wrote to Yanina?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Yanina?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Who wrote for particulars concerning my father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI imagine anyone may write to Yanina.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut one person only wrote!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne only?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; and that was you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, doubtless, wrote. It appears to me that when about to marry your\r\ndaughter to a young man, it is right to make some inquiries respecting\r\nhis family; it is not only a right, but a duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wrote, sir, knowing what answer you would receive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, indeed? I assure you,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Danglars, with a confidence and\r\nsecurity proceeding less from fear than from the interest he really\r\nfelt for the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cI solemnly declare to you, that I should never\r\nhave thought of writing to Yanina, did I know anything of Ali Pasha\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmisfortunes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho, then, urged you to write? Tell me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_ it was the most simple thing in the world. I was speaking\r\nof your father\xe2\x80\x99s past history. I said the origin of his fortune\r\nremained obscure. The person to whom I addressed my scruples asked me\r\nwhere your father had acquired his property? I answered, \xe2\x80\x98In\r\nGreece.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Then,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98write to Yanina.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who thus advised you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo other than your friend, Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Count of Monte Cristo told you to write to Yanina?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; and I wrote, and will show you my correspondence, if you like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert and Beauchamp looked at each other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, who had not yet spoken, \xe2\x80\x9cyou appear to accuse\r\nthe count, who is absent from Paris at this moment, and cannot justify\r\nhimself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI accuse no one, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cI relate, and I will repeat\r\nbefore the count what I have said to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes the count know what answer you received?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I showed it to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he know my father\xe2\x80\x99s Christian name was Fernand, and his family\r\nname Mondego?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I had told him that long since, and I did only what any other\r\nwould have done in my circumstances, and perhaps less. When, the day\r\nafter the arrival of this answer, your father came by the advice of\r\nMonte Cristo to ask my daughter\xe2\x80\x99s hand for you, I decidedly refused\r\nhim, but without any explanation or exposure. In short, why should I\r\nhave any more to do with the affair? How did the honor or disgrace of\r\nM. de Morcerf affect me? It neither increased nor decreased my income.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert felt the blood mounting to his brow; there was no doubt upon the\r\nsubject. Danglars defended himself with the baseness, but at the same\r\ntime with the assurance, of a man who speaks the truth, at least in\r\npart, if not wholly\xe2\x80\x94not for conscience\xe2\x80\x99 sake, but through fear.\r\nBesides, what was Morcerf seeking? It was not whether Danglars or Monte\r\nCristo was more or less guilty; it was a man who would answer for the\r\noffence, whether trifling or serious; it was a man who would fight, and\r\nit was evident Danglars would not fight.\r\n\r\nIn addition to this, everything forgotten or unperceived before\r\npresented itself now to his recollection. Monte Cristo knew everything,\r\nas he had bought the daughter of Ali Pasha; and, knowing everything, he\r\nhad advised Danglars to write to Yanina. The answer known, he had\r\nyielded to Albert\xe2\x80\x99s wish to be introduced to Hayd\xc3\xa9e, and allowed the\r\nconversation to turn on the death of Ali, and had not opposed Hayd\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nrecital (but having, doubtless, warned the young girl, in the few\r\nRomaic words he spoke to her, not to implicate Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s father).\r\nBesides, had he not begged of Morcerf not to mention his father\xe2\x80\x99s name\r\nbefore Hayd\xc3\xa9e? Lastly, he had taken Albert to Normandy when he knew the\r\nfinal blow was near. There could be no doubt that all had been\r\ncalculated and previously arranged; Monte Cristo then was in league\r\nwith his father\xe2\x80\x99s enemies. Albert took Beauchamp aside, and\r\ncommunicated these ideas to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter; \xe2\x80\x9cM. Danglars has only been a\r\nsecondary agent in this sad affair, and it is of M. de Monte Cristo\r\nthat you must demand an explanation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert turned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cunderstand that I do not take a final\r\nleave of you; I must ascertain if your insinuations are just, and am\r\ngoing now to inquire of the Count of Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe bowed to the banker, and went out with Beauchamp, without appearing\r\nto notice Cavalcanti. Danglars accompanied him to the door, where he\r\nagain assured Albert that no motive of personal hatred had influenced\r\nhim against the Count of Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 88. The Insult\r\n\r\nAt the banker\xe2\x80\x99s door Beauchamp stopped Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cjust now I told you it was of M. de Monte Cristo\r\nyou must demand an explanation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; and we are going to his house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReflect, Morcerf, one moment before you go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn what shall I reflect?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the importance of the step you are taking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it more serious than going to M. Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; M. Danglars is a money-lover, and those who love money, you know,\r\nthink too much of what they risk to be easily induced to fight a duel.\r\nThe other is, on the contrary, to all appearance a true nobleman; but\r\ndo you not fear to find him a bully?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only fear one thing; namely, to find a man who will not fight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not be alarmed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9che will meet you. My only fear is\r\nthat he will be too strong for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morcerf, with a sweet smile, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is what I wish.\r\nThe happiest thing that could occur to me, would be to die in my\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s stead; that would save us all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour mother would die of grief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy poor mother!\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, passing his hand across his eyes, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nknow she would; but better so than die of shame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you quite decided, Albert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; let us go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut do you think we shall find the count at home?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe intended returning some hours after me, and doubtless he is now at\r\nhome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey ordered the driver to take them to No. 30 Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es.\r\nBeauchamp wished to go in alone, but Albert observed that as this was\r\nan unusual circumstance he might be allowed to deviate from the usual\r\netiquette of duels. The cause which the young man espoused was one so\r\nsacred that Beauchamp had only to comply with all his wishes; he\r\nyielded and contented himself with following Morcerf. Albert sprang\r\nfrom the porter\xe2\x80\x99s lodge to the steps. He was received by Baptistin. The\r\ncount had, indeed, just arrived, but he was in his bath, and had\r\nforbidden that anyone should be admitted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut after his bath?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morcerf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy master will go to dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd after dinner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will sleep an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is going to the Opera.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you sure of it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite, sir; my master has ordered his horses at eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\nprecisely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is all I wished to know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen, turning towards Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cIf you have anything to attend to,\r\nBeauchamp, do it directly; if you have any appointment for this\r\nevening, defer it till tomorrow. I depend on you to accompany me to the\r\nOpera; and if you can, bring Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBeauchamp availed himself of Albert\xe2\x80\x99s permission, and left him,\r\npromising to call for him at a quarter before eight. On his return\r\nhome, Albert expressed his wish to Franz Debray, and Morrel, to see\r\nthem at the Opera that evening. Then he went to see his mother, who\r\nsince the events of the day before had refused to see anyone, and had\r\nkept her room. He found her in bed, overwhelmed with grief at this\r\npublic humiliation.\r\n\r\nThe sight of Albert produced the effect which might naturally be\r\nexpected on Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s; she pressed her son\xe2\x80\x99s hand and sobbed aloud, but\r\nher tears relieved her. Albert stood one moment speechless by the side\r\nof his mother\xe2\x80\x99s bed. It was evident from his pale face and knit brows\r\nthat his resolution to revenge himself was growing weaker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know if M. de Morcerf has any\r\nenemy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s started; she noticed that the young man did not say \xe2\x80\x9cmy\r\nfather.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy son,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cpersons in the count\xe2\x80\x99s situation have many secret\r\nenemies. Those who are known are not the most dangerous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it, and appeal to your penetration. You are of so superior a\r\nmind, nothing escapes you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you say so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, for instance, you noticed on the evening of the ball we gave,\r\nthat M. de Monte Cristo would eat nothing in our house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s raised herself on her feverish arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Monte Cristo!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed; \xe2\x80\x9cand how is he connected with the\r\nquestion you asked me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40219m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, mother, M. de Monte Cristo is almost an Oriental, and it is\r\ncustomary with the Orientals to secure full liberty for revenge by not\r\neating or drinking in the houses of their enemies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you say M. de Monte Cristo is our enemy?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s,\r\nbecoming paler than the sheet which covered her. \xe2\x80\x9cWho told you so? Why,\r\nyou are mad, Albert! M. de Monte Cristo has only shown us kindness. M.\r\nde Monte Cristo saved your life; you yourself presented him to us. Oh,\r\nI entreat you, my son, if you had entertained such an idea, dispel it;\r\nand my counsel to you\xe2\x80\x94nay, my prayer\xe2\x80\x94is to retain his friendship.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have special reasons for telling\r\nme to conciliate that man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, blushing as rapidly as she had turned pale, and\r\nagain becoming paler than ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, doubtless; and is it not that he may never do us any harm?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s shuddered, and, fixing on her son a scrutinizing gaze, \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nspeak strangely,\xe2\x80\x9d said she to Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cand you appear to have some\r\nsingular prejudices. What has the count done? Three days since you were\r\nwith him in Normandy; only three days since we looked on him as our\r\nbest friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn ironical smile passed over Albert\xe2\x80\x99s lips. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s saw it and with\r\nthe double instinct of woman and mother guessed all; but as she was\r\nprudent and strong-minded she concealed both her sorrows and her fears.\r\nAlbert was silent; an instant after, the countess resumed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou came to inquire after my health; I will candidly acknowledge that\r\nI am not well. You should install yourself here, and cheer my solitude.\r\nI do not wish to be left alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know how gladly I would obey your\r\nwish, but an urgent and important affair obliges me to leave you for\r\nthe whole evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, sighing, \xe2\x80\x9cgo, Albert; I will not make you a\r\nslave to your filial piety.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert pretended he did not hear, bowed to his mother, and quitted her.\r\nScarcely had he shut her door, when Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s called a confidential\r\nservant, and ordered him to follow Albert wherever he should go that\r\nevening, and to come and tell her immediately what he observed. Then\r\nshe rang for her lady\xe2\x80\x99s maid, and, weak as she was, she dressed, in\r\norder to be ready for whatever might happen. The footman\xe2\x80\x99s mission was\r\nan easy one. Albert went to his room, and dressed with unusual care. At\r\nten minutes to eight Beauchamp arrived; he had seen Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, who\r\nhad promised to be in the orchestra before the curtain was raised. Both\r\ngot into Albert\xe2\x80\x99s _coup\xc3\xa9_; and, as the young man had no reason to\r\nconceal where he was going, he called aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cTo the Opera.\xe2\x80\x9d In his\r\nimpatience he arrived before the beginning of the performance.\r\n\r\n40221m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud was at his post; apprised by Beauchamp of the\r\ncircumstances, he required no explanation from Albert. The conduct of\r\nthe son in seeking to avenge his father was so natural that\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud did not seek to dissuade him, and was content with\r\nrenewing his assurances of devotion. Debray was not yet come, but\r\nAlbert knew that he seldom lost a scene at the Opera.\r\n\r\nAlbert wandered about the theatre until the curtain was drawn up. He\r\nhoped to meet with M. de Monte Cristo either in the lobby or on the\r\nstairs. The bell summoned him to his seat, and he entered the orchestra\r\nwith Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud and Beauchamp. But his eyes scarcely quitted the\r\nbox between the columns, which remained obstinately closed during the\r\nwhole of the first act. At last, as Albert was looking at his watch for\r\nabout the hundredth time, at the beginning of the second act the door\r\nopened, and Monte Cristo entered, dressed in black, and, leaning over\r\nthe front of the box, looked around the pit. Morrel followed him, and\r\nlooked also for his sister and brother in-law; he soon discovered them\r\nin another box, and kissed his hand to them.\r\n\r\nThe count, in his survey of the pit, encountered a pale face and\r\nthreatening eyes, which evidently sought to gain his attention. He\r\nrecognized Albert, but thought it better not to notice him, as he\r\nlooked so angry and discomposed. Without communicating his thoughts to\r\nhis companion, he sat down, drew out his opera-glass, and looked\r\nanother way. Although apparently not noticing Albert, he did not,\r\nhowever, lose sight of him, and when the curtain fell at the end of the\r\nsecond act, he saw him leave the orchestra with his two friends. Then\r\nhis head was seen passing at the back of the boxes, and the count knew\r\nthat the approaching storm was intended to fall on him. He was at the\r\nmoment conversing cheerfully with Morrel, but he was well prepared for\r\nwhat might happen.\r\n\r\nThe door opened, and Monte Cristo, turning round, saw Albert, pale and\r\ntrembling, followed by Beauchamp and Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, with that benevolent politeness which distinguished\r\nhis salutation from the common civilities of the world, \xe2\x80\x9cmy cavalier\r\nhas attained his object. Good-evening, M. de Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe countenance of this man, who possessed such extraordinary control\r\nover his feelings, expressed the most perfect cordiality. Morrel only\r\nthen recollected the letter he had received from the viscount, in\r\nwhich, without assigning any reason, he begged him to go to the Opera,\r\nbut he understood that something terrible was brooding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are not come here, sir, to exchange hypocritical expressions of\r\npoliteness, or false professions of friendship,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cbut to\r\ndemand an explanation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young man\xe2\x80\x99s trembling voice was scarcely audible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn explanation at the Opera?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, with that calm tone and\r\npenetrating eye which characterize the man who knows his cause is good.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLittle acquainted as I am with the habits of Parisians, I should not\r\nhave thought this the place for such a demand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill, if people will shut themselves up,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cand cannot be\r\nseen because they are bathing, dining, or asleep, we must avail\r\nourselves of the opportunity whenever they are to be seen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not difficult of access, sir; for yesterday, if my memory does\r\nnot deceive me, you were at my house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYesterday I was at your house, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man; \xe2\x80\x9cbecause then\r\nI knew not who you were.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn pronouncing these words Albert had raised his voice so as to be\r\nheard by those in the adjoining boxes and in the lobby. Thus the\r\nattention of many was attracted by this altercation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you come from, sir? \xe2\x80\x9c said Monte Cristo \xe2\x80\x9cYou do not appear\r\nto be in the possession of your senses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProvided I understand your perfidy, sir, and succeed in making you\r\nunderstand that I will be revenged, I shall be reasonable enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAlbert furiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not understand you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cand if I did,\r\nyour tone is too high. I am at home here, and I alone have a right to\r\nraise my voice above another\xe2\x80\x99s. Leave the box, sir!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo pointed towards the door with the most commanding dignity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, I shall know how to make you leave your home!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert,\r\nclasping in his convulsed grasp the glove, which Monte Cristo did not\r\nlose sight of.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo quietly, \xe2\x80\x9cI see you wish to quarrel\r\nwith me; but I would give you one piece of advice, which you will do\r\nwell to keep in mind. It is in poor taste to make a display of a\r\nchallenge. Display is not becoming to everyone, M. de Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this name a murmur of astonishment passed around the group of\r\nspectators of this scene. They had talked of no one but Morcerf the\r\nwhole day. Albert understood the allusion in a moment, and was about to\r\nthrow his glove at the count, when Morrel seized his hand, while\r\nBeauchamp and Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, fearing the scene would surpass the\r\nlimits of a challenge, held him back. But Monte Cristo, without rising,\r\nand leaning forward in his chair, merely stretched out his arm and,\r\ntaking the damp, crushed glove from the clenched hand of the young man:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he in a solemn tone, \xe2\x80\x9cI consider your glove thrown, and\r\nwill return it to you wrapped around a bullet. Now leave me or I will\r\nsummon my servants to throw you out at the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWild, almost unconscious, and with eyes inflamed, Albert stepped back,\r\nand Morrel closed the door. Monte Cristo took up his glass again as if\r\nnothing had happened; his face was like marble, and his heart was like\r\nbronze. Morrel whispered, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you done to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? Nothing\xe2\x80\x94at least personally,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut there must be some cause for this strange scene.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Count of Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s adventure exasperates the young man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you anything to do with it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was through Hayd\xc3\xa9e that the Chamber was informed of his father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntreason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel. \xe2\x80\x9cI had been told, but would not credit it, that\r\nthe Grecian slave I have seen with you here in this very box was the\r\ndaughter of Ali Pasha.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true, nevertheless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cI understand it all, and this scene was\r\npremeditated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Albert wrote to request me to come to the Opera, doubtless that I\r\nmight be a witness to the insult he meant to offer you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProbably,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo with his imperturbable tranquillity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what shall you do with him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith Albert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall I do with Albert? As certainly, Maximilian, as I now press\r\nyour hand, I shall kill him before ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock tomorrow morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nMorrel, in his turn, took Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s hand in both of his, and he\r\nshuddered to feel how cold and steady it was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, count,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9chis father loves him so much!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not speak to me of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, with the first\r\nmovement of anger he had betrayed; \xe2\x80\x9cI will make him suffer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel, amazed, let fall Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s hand. \xe2\x80\x9cCount, count!\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Maximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the count, \xe2\x80\x9clisten how adorably Duprez\r\nis singing that line,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98O Mathilde! idole de mon \xc3\xa2me!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was the first to discover Duprez at Naples, and the first to applaud\r\nhim. Bravo, bravo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel saw it was useless to say more, and refrained. The curtain,\r\nwhich had risen at the close of the scene with Albert, again fell, and\r\na rap was heard at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo with a voice that betrayed not the least\r\nemotion; and immediately Beauchamp appeared. \xe2\x80\x9cGood-evening, M.\r\nBeauchamp,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, as if this was the first time he had\r\nseen the journalist that evening; \xe2\x80\x9cbe seated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBeauchamp bowed, and, sitting down, \xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI just now\r\naccompanied M. de Morcerf, as you saw.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that means,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you had,\r\nprobably, just dined together. I am happy to see, M. Beauchamp, that\r\nyou are more sober than he was.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cAlbert was wrong, I acknowledge, to betray\r\nso much anger, and I come, on my own account, to apologize for him. And\r\nhaving done so, entirely on my own account, be it understood, I would\r\nadd that I believe you too gentlemanly to refuse giving him some\r\nexplanation concerning your connection with Yanina. Then I will add two\r\nwords about the young Greek girl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo motioned him to be silent. \xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, laughing,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthere are all my hopes about to be destroyed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless you wish to make me appear a very eccentric character. I am,\r\nin your opinion, a Lara, a Manfred, a Lord Ruthven; then, just as I am\r\narriving at the climax, you defeat your own end, and seek to make an\r\nordinary man of me. You bring me down to your own level, and demand\r\nexplanations! Indeed, M. Beauchamp, it is quite laughable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Beauchamp haughtily, \xe2\x80\x9cthere are occasions when probity\r\ncommands\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Beauchamp,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed this strange man, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Count of Monte Cristo\r\nbows to none but the Count of Monte Cristo himself. Say no more, I\r\nentreat you. I do what I please, M. Beauchamp, and it is always well\r\ndone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man, \xe2\x80\x9chonest men are not to be paid with such\r\ncoin. I require honorable guaranties.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am, sir, a living guaranty,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, motionless, but\r\nwith a threatening look; \xe2\x80\x9cwe have both blood in our veins which we wish\r\nto shed\xe2\x80\x94that is our mutual guaranty. Tell the viscount so, and that\r\ntomorrow, before ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock, I shall see what color his is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I have only to make arrangements for the duel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is quite immaterial to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cand it was very\r\nunnecessary to disturb me at the Opera for such a trifle. In France\r\npeople fight with the sword or pistol, in the colonies with the\r\ncarbine, in Arabia with the dagger. Tell your client that, although I\r\nam the insulted party, in order to carry out my eccentricity, I leave\r\nhim the choice of arms, and will accept without discussion, without\r\ndispute, anything, even combat by drawing lots, which is always stupid,\r\nbut with me different from other people, as I am sure to gain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSure to gain!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Beauchamp, looking with amazement at the\r\ncount.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, slightly shrugging his shoulders;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cotherwise I would not fight with M. de Morcerf. I shall kill him\xe2\x80\x94I\r\ncannot help it. Only by a single line this evening at my house let me\r\nknow the arms and the hour; I do not like to be kept waiting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPistols, then, at eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock, in the Bois de Vincennes,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nBeauchamp, quite disconcerted, not knowing if he was dealing with an\r\narrogant braggadocio or a supernatural being.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cNow all that is settled, do let\r\nme see the performance, and tell your friend Albert not to come any\r\nmore this evening; he will hurt himself with all his ill-chosen\r\nbarbarisms: let him go home and go to sleep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBeauchamp left the box, perfectly amazed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, turning towards Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cI may depend upon\r\nyou, may I not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cI am at your service, count; still\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is desirable I should know the real cause.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say, you would rather not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe young man himself is acting blindfolded, and knows not the true\r\ncause, which is known only to God and to me; but I give you my word,\r\nMorrel, that God, who does know it, will be on our side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cwho is your second witness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know no one in Paris, Morrel, on whom I could confer that honor\r\nbesides you and your brother Emmanuel. Do you think Emmanuel would\r\noblige me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will answer for him, count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell? that is all I require. Tomorrow morning, at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, you\r\nwill be with me, will you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush, the curtain is rising. Listen! I never lose a note of this opera\r\nif I can avoid it; the music of _William Tell_ is so sweet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 89. The Night\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo waited, according to his usual custom, until Duprez had\r\nsung his famous \xe2\x80\x9c_Suivez-moi!_\xe2\x80\x9d then he rose and went out. Morrel took\r\nleave of him at the door, renewing his promise to be with him the next\r\nmorning at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and to bring Emmanuel. Then he stepped into\r\nhis _coup\xc3\xa9_, calm and smiling, and was at home in five minutes. No one\r\nwho knew the count could mistake his expression when, on entering, he\r\nsaid:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAli, bring me my pistols with the ivory cross.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAli brought the box to his master, who examined the weapons with a\r\nsolicitude very natural to a man who is about to intrust his life to a\r\nlittle powder and shot. These were pistols of an especial pattern,\r\nwhich Monte Cristo had had made for target practice in his own room. A\r\ncap was sufficient to drive out the bullet, and from the adjoining room\r\nno one would have suspected that the count was, as sportsmen would say,\r\nkeeping his hand in.\r\n\r\nHe was just taking one up and looking for the point to aim at on a\r\nlittle iron plate which served him as a target, when his study door\r\nopened, and Baptistin entered. Before he had spoken a word, the count\r\nsaw in the next room a veiled woman, who had followed closely after\r\nBaptistin, and now, seeing the count with a pistol in his hand and\r\nswords on the table, rushed in.
