Baptistin looked at his master, who\r\nmade a sign to him, and he went out, closing the door after him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count to the veiled woman.\r\n\r\n40227m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe stranger cast one look around her, to be certain that they were\r\nquite alone; then bending as if she would have knelt, and joining her\r\nhands, she said with an accent of despair:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdmond, you will not kill my son!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count retreated a step, uttered a slight exclamation, and let fall\r\nthe pistol he held.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat name did you pronounce then, Madame de Morcerf?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYours!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, throwing back her veil,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyours, which I alone,\r\nperhaps, have not forgotten. Edmond, it is not Madame de Morcerf who is\r\ncome to you, it is Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s is dead, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI know no one now of\r\nthat name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s lives, sir, and she remembers, for she alone recognized you\r\nwhen she saw you, and even before she saw you, by your voice,\r\nEdmond,\xe2\x80\x94by the simple sound of your voice; and from that moment she has\r\nfollowed your steps, watched you, feared you, and she needs not to\r\ninquire what hand has dealt the blow which now strikes M. de Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFernand, do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, with bitter irony; \xe2\x80\x9csince\r\nwe are recalling names, let us remember them all.\xe2\x80\x9d Monte Cristo had\r\npronounced the name of Fernand with such an expression of hatred that\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s felt a thrill of horror run through every vein.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, Edmond, I am not mistaken, and have cause to say, \xe2\x80\x98Spare my\r\nson!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who told you, madame, that I have any hostile intentions against\r\nyour son?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one, in truth; but a mother has twofold sight. I guessed all; I\r\nfollowed him this evening to the Opera, and, concealed in a parquet\r\nbox, have seen all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you have seen all, madame, you know that the son of Fernand has\r\npublicly insulted me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo with awful calmness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, for pity\xe2\x80\x99s sake!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have seen that he would have thrown his glove in my face if\r\nMorrel, one of my friends, had not stopped him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen to me, my son has also guessed who you are,\xe2\x80\x94he attributes his\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s misfortunes to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame, you are mistaken, they are not misfortunes,\xe2\x80\x94it is a\r\npunishment. It is not I who strike M. de Morcerf; it is Providence\r\nwhich punishes him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why do you represent Providence?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you\r\nremember when it forgets? What are Yanina and its vizier to you,\r\nEdmond? What injury has Fernand Mondego done you in betraying Ali\r\nTepelini?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9call this is an affair between the\r\nFrench captain and the daughter of Vasiliki. It does not concern me,\r\nyou are right; and if I have sworn to revenge myself, it is not on the\r\nFrench captain, or the Count of Morcerf, but on the fisherman Fernand,\r\nthe husband of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s the Catalane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, sir!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the countess, \xe2\x80\x9chow terrible a vengeance for a fault\r\nwhich fatality made me commit!\xe2\x80\x94for I am the only culprit, Edmond, and\r\nif you owe revenge to anyone, it is to me, who had not fortitude to\r\nbear your absence and my solitude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy was I absent? And why were you\r\nalone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40231m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you had been arrested, Edmond, and were a prisoner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why was I arrested? Why was I a prisoner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not, madame; at least, I hope not. But I will tell you. I was\r\narrested and became a prisoner because, under the arbor of La R\xc3\xa9serve,\r\nthe day before I was to marry you, a man named Danglars wrote this\r\nletter, which the fisherman Fernand himself posted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo went to a secretaire, opened a drawer by a spring, from\r\nwhich he took a paper which had lost its original color, and the ink of\r\nwhich had become of a rusty hue\xe2\x80\x94this he placed in the hands of\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s. It was Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 letter to the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney, which the\r\nCount of Monte Cristo, disguised as a clerk from the house of Thomson &\r\nFrench, had taken from the file against Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s, on the day he\r\nhad paid the two hundred thousand francs to M. de Boville. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s\r\nread with terror the following lines:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney is informed by a friend to the throne and religion\r\nthat one Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s, second in command on board the _Pharaon_, this\r\nday arrived from Smyrna, after having touched at Naples and\r\nPorto-Ferrajo, is the bearer of a letter from Murat to the usurper, and\r\nof another letter from the usurper to the Bonapartist club in Paris.\r\nAmple corroboration of this statement may be obtained by arresting the\r\nabove-mentioned Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s, who either carries the letter for Paris\r\nabout with him, or has it at his father\xe2\x80\x99s abode. Should it not be found\r\nin possession of either father or son, then it will assuredly be\r\ndiscovered in the cabin belonging to the said Dant\xc3\xa8s on board the\r\n_Pharaon_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow dreadful!\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, passing her hand across her brow, moist\r\nwith perspiration; \xe2\x80\x9cand that letter\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI bought it for two hundred thousand francs, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte\r\nCristo; \xe2\x80\x9cbut that is a trifle, since it enables me to justify myself to\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the result of that letter\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou well know, madame, was my arrest; but you do not know how long\r\nthat arrest lasted. You do not know that I remained for fourteen years\r\nwithin a quarter of a league of you, in a dungeon in the Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If.\r\nYou do not know that every day of those fourteen years I renewed the\r\nvow of vengeance which I had made the first day; and yet I was not\r\naware that you had married Fernand, my calumniator, and that my father\r\nhad died of hunger!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan it be?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, shuddering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is what I heard on leaving my prison fourteen years after I had\r\nentered it; and that is why, on account of the living Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s and my\r\ndeceased father, I have sworn to revenge myself on Fernand, and\xe2\x80\x94I have\r\nrevenged myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are sure the unhappy Fernand did that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am satisfied, madame, that he did what I have told you; besides,\r\nthat is not much more odious than that a Frenchman by adoption should\r\npass over to the English; that a Spaniard by birth should have fought\r\nagainst the Spaniards; that a stipendiary of Ali should have betrayed\r\nand murdered Ali. Compared with such things, what is the letter you\r\nhave just read?\xe2\x80\x94a lover\xe2\x80\x99s deception, which the woman who has married\r\nthat man ought certainly to forgive; but not so the lover who was to\r\nhave married her. Well, the French did not avenge themselves on the\r\ntraitor, the Spaniards did not shoot the traitor, Ali in his tomb left\r\nthe traitor unpunished; but I, betrayed, sacrificed, buried, have risen\r\nfrom my tomb, by the grace of God, to punish that man. He sends me for\r\nthat purpose, and here I am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe poor woman\xe2\x80\x99s head and arms fell; her legs bent under her, and she\r\nfell on her knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive, Edmond, forgive for my sake, who love you still!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe dignity of the wife checked the fervor of the lover and the mother.\r\nHer forehead almost touched the carpet, when the count sprang forward\r\nand raised her. Then seated on a chair, she looked at the manly\r\ncountenance of Monte Cristo, on which grief and hatred still impressed\r\na threatening expression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot crush that accursed race?\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he; \xe2\x80\x9cabandon my purpose at the\r\nmoment of its accomplishment? Impossible, madame, impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdmond,\xe2\x80\x9d said the poor mother, who tried every means, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen I call you\r\nEdmond, why do you not call me Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s! Well yes, you are right;\r\nthat name has still its charms, and this is the first time for a long\r\nperiod that I have pronounced it so distinctly. Oh, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, I have\r\nuttered your name with the sigh of melancholy, with the groan of\r\nsorrow, with the last effort of despair; I have uttered it when frozen\r\nwith cold, crouched on the straw in my dungeon; I have uttered it,\r\nconsumed with heat, rolling on the stone floor of my prison. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s,\r\nI must revenge myself, for I suffered fourteen years,\xe2\x80\x94fourteen years I\r\nwept, I cursed; now I tell you, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, I must revenge myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count, fearing to yield to the entreaties of her he had so ardently\r\nloved, called his sufferings to the assistance of his hatred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRevenge yourself, then, Edmond,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the poor mother; \xe2\x80\x9cbut let your\r\nvengeance fall on the culprits,\xe2\x80\x94on him, on me, but not on my son!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is written in the good book,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the sins of\r\nthe fathers shall fall upon their children to the third and fourth\r\ngeneration. Since God himself dictated those words to his prophet, why\r\nshould I seek to make myself better than God?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdmond,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, with her arms extended towards the count,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csince I first knew you, I have adored your name, have respected your\r\nmemory. Edmond, my friend, do not compel me to tarnish that noble and\r\npure image reflected incessantly on the mirror of my heart. Edmond, if\r\nyou knew all the prayers I have addressed to God for you while I\r\nthought you were living and since I have thought you must be dead! Yes,\r\ndead, alas! I imagined your dead body buried at the foot of some gloomy\r\ntower, or cast to the bottom of a pit by hateful jailers, and I wept!\r\nWhat could I do for you, Edmond, besides pray and weep? Listen; for ten\r\nyears I dreamed each night the same dream. I had been told that you had\r\nendeavored to escape; that you had taken the place of another prisoner;\r\nthat you had slipped into the winding sheet of a dead body; that you\r\nhad been thrown alive from the top of the Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If, and that the\r\ncry you uttered as you dashed upon the rocks first revealed to your\r\njailers that they were your murderers. Well, Edmond, I swear to you, by\r\nthe head of that son for whom I entreat your pity,\xe2\x80\x94Edmond, for ten\r\nyears I saw every night every detail of that frightful tragedy, and for\r\nten years I heard every night the cry which awoke me, shuddering and\r\ncold. And I, too, Edmond\xe2\x80\x94oh! believe me\xe2\x80\x94guilty as I was\xe2\x80\x94oh, yes, I,\r\ntoo, have suffered much!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you known what it is to have your father starve to death in your\r\nabsence?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Monte Cristo, thrusting his hands into his hair; \xe2\x80\x9chave\r\nyou seen the woman you loved giving her hand to your rival, while you\r\nwere perishing at the bottom of a dungeon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I have seen him whom I loved on the\r\npoint of murdering my son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s uttered these words with such deep anguish, with an accent of\r\nsuch intense despair, that Monte Cristo could not restrain a sob. The\r\nlion was daunted; the avenger was conquered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you ask of me?\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyour son\xe2\x80\x99s life? Well, he shall\r\nlive!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s uttered a cry which made the tears start from Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s\r\neyes; but these tears disappeared almost instantaneously, for,\r\ndoubtless, God had sent some angel to collect them\xe2\x80\x94far more precious\r\nwere they in his eyes than the richest pearls of Guzerat and Ophir.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, seizing the count\xe2\x80\x99s hand and raising it to her lips;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9coh, thank you, thank you, Edmond! Now you are exactly what I dreamt\r\nyou were,\xe2\x80\x94the man I always loved. Oh, now I may say so!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cas that poor Edmond will\r\nnot have long to be loved by you. Death is about to return to the tomb,\r\nthe phantom to retire in darkness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you say, Edmond?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, since you command me, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, I must die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDie? and why so? Who talks of dying? Whence have you these ideas of\r\ndeath?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not suppose that, publicly outraged in the face of a whole\r\ntheatre, in the presence of your friends and those of your\r\nson\xe2\x80\x94challenged by a boy who will glory in my forgiveness as if it were\r\na victory\xe2\x80\x94you do not suppose that I can for one moment wish to live.\r\nWhat I most loved after you, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, was myself, my dignity, and that\r\nstrength which rendered me superior to other men; that strength was my\r\nlife. With one word you have crushed it, and I die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the duel will not take place, Edmond, since you forgive?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will take place,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, in a most solemn tone; \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\ninstead of your son\xe2\x80\x99s blood to stain the ground, mine will flow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s shrieked, and sprang towards Monte Cristo, but, suddenly\r\nstopping, \xe2\x80\x9cEdmond,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is a God above us, since you live\r\nand since I have seen you again; I trust to him from my heart. While\r\nwaiting his assistance I trust to your word; you have said that my son\r\nshould live, have you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, madame, he shall live,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, surprised that without\r\nmore emotion Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s had accepted the heroic sacrifice he made for\r\nher. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s extended her hand to the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdmond,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, and her eyes were wet with tears while looking at\r\nhim to whom she spoke, \xe2\x80\x9chow noble it is of you, how great the action\r\nyou have just performed, how sublime to have taken pity on a poor woman\r\nwho appealed to you with every chance against her, Alas, I am grown old\r\nwith grief more than with years, and cannot now remind my Edmond by a\r\nsmile, or by a look, of that Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s whom he once spent so many hours\r\nin contemplating. Ah, believe me, Edmond, as I told you, I too have\r\nsuffered much; I repeat, it is melancholy to pass one\xe2\x80\x99s life without\r\nhaving one joy to recall, without preserving a single hope; but that\r\nproves that all is not yet over. No, it is not finished; I feel it by\r\nwhat remains in my heart. Oh, I repeat it, Edmond; what you have just\r\ndone is beautiful\xe2\x80\x94it is grand; it is sublime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you say so now, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s?\xe2\x80\x94then what would you say if you knew the\r\nextent of the sacrifice I make to you? Suppose that the Supreme Being,\r\nafter having created the world and fertilized chaos, had paused in the\r\nwork to spare an angel the tears that might one day flow for mortal\r\nsins from her immortal eyes; suppose that when everything was in\r\nreadiness and the moment had come for God to look upon his work and see\r\nthat it was good\xe2\x80\x94suppose he had snuffed out the sun and tossed the\r\nworld back into eternal night\xe2\x80\x94then\xe2\x80\x94even then, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, you could not\r\nimagine what I lose in sacrificing my life at this moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMerc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s looked at the count in a way which expressed at the same time\r\nher astonishment, her admiration, and her gratitude. Monte Cristo\r\npressed his forehead on his burning hands, as if his brain could no\r\nlonger bear alone the weight of its thoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdmond,\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cI have but one word more to say to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count smiled bitterly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdmond,\xe2\x80\x9d continued she, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will see that if my face is pale, if my\r\neyes are dull, if my beauty is gone; if Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, in short, no longer\r\nresembles her former self in her features, you will see that her heart\r\nis still the same. Adieu, then, Edmond; I have nothing more to ask of\r\nheaven\xe2\x80\x94I have seen you again, and have found you as noble and as great\r\nas formerly you were. Adieu, Edmond, adieu, and thank you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the count did not answer. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s opened the door of the study and\r\nhad disappeared before he had recovered from the painful and profound\r\nreverie into which his thwarted vengeance had plunged him.\r\n\r\nThe clock of the Invalides struck one when the carriage which conveyed\r\nMadame de Morcerf rolled away on the pavement of the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es,\r\nand made Monte Cristo raise his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a fool I was,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cnot to tear my heart out on the day when\r\nI resolved to avenge myself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 90. The Meeting\r\n\r\nAfter Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s had left Monte Cristo, he fell into profound gloom.\r\nAround him and within him the flight of thought seemed to have stopped;\r\nhis energetic mind slumbered, as the body does after extreme fatigue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d said he to himself, while the lamp and the wax lights were\r\nnearly burnt out, and the servants were waiting impatiently in the\r\nanteroom; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat? this edifice which I have been so long preparing,\r\nwhich I have reared with so much care and toil, is to be crushed by a\r\nsingle touch, a word, a breath! Yes, this self, of whom I thought so\r\nmuch, of whom I was so proud, who had appeared so worthless in the\r\ndungeons of the Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If, and whom I had succeeded in making so\r\ngreat, will be but a lump of clay tomorrow. Alas, it is not the death\r\nof the body I regret; for is not the destruction of the vital\r\nprinciple, the repose to which everything is tending, to which every\r\nunhappy being aspires,\xe2\x80\x94is not this the repose of matter after which I\r\nso long sighed, and which I was seeking to attain by the painful\r\nprocess of starvation when Faria appeared in my dungeon? What is death\r\nfor me? One step farther into rest,\xe2\x80\x94two, perhaps, into silence. No, it\r\nis not existence, then, that I regret, but the ruin of projects so\r\nslowly carried out, so laboriously framed. Providence is now opposed to\r\nthem, when I most thought it would be propitious. It is not God\xe2\x80\x99s will\r\nthat they should be accomplished. This burden, almost as heavy as a\r\nworld, which I had raised, and I had thought to bear to the end, was\r\ntoo great for my strength, and I was compelled to lay it down in the\r\nmiddle of my career. Oh, shall I then, again become a fatalist, whom\r\nfourteen years of despair and ten of hope had rendered a believer in\r\nProvidence?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd all this\xe2\x80\x94all this, because my heart, which I thought dead, was\r\nonly sleeping; because it has awakened and has begun to beat again,\r\nbecause I have yielded to the pain of the emotion excited in my breast\r\nby a woman\xe2\x80\x99s voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the count, becoming each moment more absorbed in the\r\nanticipation of the dreadful sacrifice for the morrow, which Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s\r\nhad accepted, \xe2\x80\x9cyet, it is impossible that so noble-minded a woman\r\nshould thus through selfishness consent to my death when I am in the\r\nprime of life and strength; it is impossible that she can carry to such\r\na point maternal love, or rather delirium. There are virtues which\r\nbecome crimes by exaggeration. No, she must have conceived some\r\npathetic scene; she will come and throw herself between us; and what\r\nwould be sublime here will there appear ridiculous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe blush of pride mounted to the count\xe2\x80\x99s forehead as this thought\r\npassed through his mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRidiculous?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated he; \xe2\x80\x9cand the ridicule will fall on me. I\r\nridiculous? No, I would rather die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy thus exaggerating to his own mind the anticipated ill-fortune of the\r\nnext day, to which he had condemned himself by promising Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s to\r\nspare her son, the count at last exclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFolly, folly, folly!\xe2\x80\x94to carry generosity so far as to put myself up as\r\na mark for that young man to aim at. He will never believe that my\r\ndeath was suicide; and yet it is important for the honor of my\r\nmemory,\xe2\x80\x94and this surely is not vanity, but a justifiable pride,\xe2\x80\x94it is\r\nimportant the world should know that I have consented, by my free will,\r\nto stop my arm, already raised to strike, and that with the arm which\r\nhas been so powerful against others I have struck myself. It must be;\r\nit shall be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSeizing a pen, he drew a paper from a secret drawer in his desk, and\r\nwrote at the bottom of the document (which was no other than his will,\r\nmade since his arrival in Paris) a sort of codicil, clearly explaining\r\nthe nature of his death.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do this, Oh, my God,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with his eyes raised to heaven, \xe2\x80\x9cas\r\nmuch for thy honor as for mine. I have during ten years considered\r\nmyself the agent of thy vengeance, and other wretches, like Morcerf,\r\nDanglars, Villefort, even Morcerf himself, must not imagine that chance\r\nhas freed them from their enemy. Let them know, on the contrary, that\r\ntheir punishment, which had been decreed by Providence, is only delayed\r\nby my present determination, and although they escape it in this world,\r\nit awaits them in another, and that they are only exchanging time for\r\neternity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile he was thus agitated by gloomy uncertainties,\xe2\x80\x94wretched waking\r\ndreams of grief,\xe2\x80\x94the first rays of morning pierced his windows, and\r\nshone upon the pale blue paper on which he had just inscribed his\r\njustification of Providence.\r\n\r\nIt was just five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning when a slight noise like a\r\nstifled sigh reached his ear. He turned his head, looked around him,\r\nand saw no one; but the sound was repeated distinctly enough to\r\nconvince him of its reality.\r\n\r\nHe arose, and quietly opening the door of the drawing-room, saw Hayd\xc3\xa9e,\r\nwho had fallen on a chair, with her arms hanging down and her beautiful\r\nhead thrown back. She had been standing at the door, to prevent his\r\ngoing out without seeing her, until sleep, which the young cannot\r\nresist, had overpowered her frame, wearied as she was with watching.\r\nThe noise of the door did not awaken her, and Monte Cristo gazed at her\r\nwith affectionate regret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe remembered that she had a son,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cand I forgot I had a\r\ndaughter.\xe2\x80\x9d Then, shaking his head sorrowfully, \xe2\x80\x9cPoor Hayd\xc3\xa9e,\xe2\x80\x9d said he;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cshe wished to see me, to speak to me; she has feared or guessed\r\nsomething. Oh, I cannot go without taking leave of her; I cannot die\r\nwithout confiding her to someone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe quietly regained his seat, and wrote under the other lines:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI bequeath to Maximilian Morrel, captain of Spahis,\xe2\x80\x94and son of my\r\nformer patron, Pierre Morrel, shipowner at Marseilles,\xe2\x80\x94the sum of\r\ntwenty millions, a part of which may be offered to his sister Julie and\r\nbrother-in-law Emmanuel, if he does not fear this increase of fortune\r\nmay mar their happiness. These twenty millions are concealed in my\r\ngrotto at Monte Cristo, of which Bertuccio knows the secret. If his\r\nheart is free, and he will marry Hayd\xc3\xa9e, the daughter of Ali Pasha of\r\nYanina, whom I have brought up with the love of a father, and who has\r\nshown the love and tenderness of a daughter for me, he will thus\r\naccomplish my last wish. This will has already constituted Hayd\xc3\xa9e\r\nheiress of the rest of my fortune, consisting of lands, funds in\r\nEngland, Austria, and Holland, furniture in my different palaces and\r\nhouses, and which without the twenty millions and the legacies to my\r\nservants, may still amount to sixty millions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n40241m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHe was finishing the last line when a cry behind him made him start,\r\nand the pen fell from his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHayd\xc3\xa9e,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cdid you read it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy are you writing thus at such an hour? Why\r\nare you bequeathing all your fortune to me? Are you going to leave me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going on a journey, dear child,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, with an\r\nexpression of infinite tenderness and melancholy; \xe2\x80\x9cand if any\r\nmisfortune should happen to me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count stopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the young girl, with an authoritative tone the count had\r\nnever observed before, and which startled him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if any misfortune happen to me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish\r\nmy daughter to be happy.\xe2\x80\x9d Hayd\xc3\xa9e smiled sorrowfully, and shook her\r\nhead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think of dying, my lord?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe wise man, my child, has said, \xe2\x80\x98It is good to think of death.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if you die,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cbequeath your fortune to others, for if\r\nyou die I shall require nothing;\xe2\x80\x9d and, taking the paper, she tore it in\r\nfour pieces, and threw it into the middle of the room. Then, the effort\r\nhaving exhausted her strength, she fell, not asleep this time, but\r\nfainting on the floor.\r\n\r\nThe count leaned over her and raised her in his arms; and seeing that\r\nsweet pale face, those lovely eyes closed, that beautiful form\r\nmotionless and to all appearance lifeless, the idea occurred to him for\r\nthe first time, that perhaps she loved him otherwise than as a daughter\r\nloves a father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he, with intense suffering, \xe2\x80\x9cI might, then, have been\r\nhappy yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he carried Hayd\xc3\xa9e to her room, resigned her to the care of her\r\nattendants, and returning to his study, which he shut quickly this\r\ntime, he again copied the destroyed will. As he was finishing, the\r\nsound of a cabriolet entering the yard was heard. Monte Cristo\r\napproached the window, and saw Maximilian and Emmanuel alight. \xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid he; \xe2\x80\x9cit was time,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and he sealed his will with three seals.\r\n\r\nA moment afterwards he heard a noise in the drawing-room, and went to\r\nopen the door himself. Morrel was there; he had come twenty minutes\r\nbefore the time appointed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am perhaps come too soon, count,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I frankly\r\nacknowledge that I have not closed my eyes all night, nor has anyone in\r\nmy house. I need to see you strong in your courageous assurance, to\r\nrecover myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo could not resist this proof of affection; he not only\r\nextended his hand to the young man, but flew to him with open arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMorrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cit is a happy day for me, to feel that I am beloved\r\nby such a man as you. Good-morning, Emmanuel; you will come with me\r\nthen, Maximilian?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you doubt it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the young captain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if I were wrong\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI watched you during the whole scene of that challenge yesterday; I\r\nhave been thinking of your firmness all night, and I said to myself\r\nthat justice must be on your side, or man\xe2\x80\x99s countenance is no longer to\r\nbe relied on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Morrel, Albert is your friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSimply an acquaintance, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou met on the same day you first saw me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is true; but I should not have recollected it if you had not\r\nreminded me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, Morrel.\xe2\x80\x9d Then ringing the bell once, \xe2\x80\x9cLook.\xe2\x80\x9d said he to\r\nAli, who came immediately, \xe2\x80\x9ctake that to my solicitor. It is my will,\r\nMorrel. When I am dead, you will go and examine it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cyou dead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; must I not be prepared for everything, dear friend? But what did\r\nyou do yesterday after you left me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI went to Tortoni\xe2\x80\x99s, where, as I expected, I found Beauchamp and\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. I own I was seeking them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, when all was arranged?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, count; the affair is serious and unavoidable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you doubt it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; the offence was public, and everyone is already talking of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I hoped to get an exchange of arms,\xe2\x80\x94to substitute the sword for\r\nthe pistol; the pistol is blind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you succeeded?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo quickly, with an imperceptible\r\ngleam of hope.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; for your skill with the sword is so well known.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh?\xe2\x80\x94who has betrayed me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe skilful swordsman whom you have conquered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you failed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey positively refused.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMorrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9chave you ever seen me fire a pistol?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we have time; look.\xe2\x80\x9d Monte Cristo took the pistols he held in\r\nhis hand when Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s entered, and fixing an ace of clubs against the\r\niron plate, with four shots he successively shot off the four sides of\r\nthe club. At each shot Morrel turned pale. He examined the bullets with\r\nwhich Monte Cristo performed this dexterous feat, and saw that they\r\nwere no larger than buckshot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is astonishing,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cLook, Emmanuel.\xe2\x80\x9d Then turning towards\r\nMonte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cin the name of all that is dear to\r\nyou, I entreat you not to kill Albert!\xe2\x80\x94the unhappy youth has a mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cand I have none.\xe2\x80\x9d These words were\r\nuttered in a tone which made Morrel shudder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are the offended party, count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless; what does that imply?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat you will fire first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fire first?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I obtained, or rather claimed that; we had conceded enough for\r\nthem to yield us that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd at what distance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty paces.\xe2\x80\x9d A smile of terrible import passed over the count\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMorrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not forget what you have just seen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe only chance for Albert\xe2\x80\x99s safety, then, will arise from your\r\nemotion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suffer from emotion?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr from your generosity, my friend; to so good a marksman as you are,\r\nI may say what would appear absurd to another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBreak his arm\xe2\x80\x94wound him\xe2\x80\x94but do not kill him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you, Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I do not need\r\nentreating to spare the life of M. de Morcerf; he shall be so well\r\nspared, that he will return quietly with his two friends, while I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will be another thing; I shall be brought home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Maximilian, quite unable to restrain his feelings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I told you, my dear Morrel, M. de Morcerf will kill me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel looked at him in utter amazement. \xe2\x80\x9cBut what has happened, then,\r\nsince last evening, count?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same thing that happened to Brutus the night before the battle of\r\nPhilippi; I have seen a ghost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that ghost\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTold me, Morrel, that I had lived long enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMaximilian and Emmanuel looked at each other. Monte Cristo drew out his\r\nwatch. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us go,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cit is five minutes past seven, and the\r\nappointment was for eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA carriage was in readiness at the door. Monte Cristo stepped into it\r\nwith his two friends. He had stopped a moment in the passage to listen\r\nat a door, and Maximilian and Emmanuel, who had considerately passed\r\nforward a few steps, thought they heard him answer by a sigh to a sob\r\nfrom within. As the clock struck eight they drove up to the place of\r\nmeeting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are first,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, looking out of the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Baptistin, who had followed his master with\r\nindescribable terror, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I think I see a carriage down there under\r\nthe trees.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo sprang lightly from the carriage, and offered his hand to\r\nassist Emmanuel and Maximilian. The latter retained the count\xe2\x80\x99s hand\r\nbetween his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cto feel a hand like this, when its owner relies on\r\nthe goodness of his cause.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmanuel, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I see two young men down there,\r\nwho are evidently, waiting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo drew Morrel a step or two behind his brother-in-law.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9care your affections disengaged?\xe2\x80\x9d Morrel looked\r\nat Monte Cristo with astonishment. \xe2\x80\x9cI do not seek your confidence, my\r\ndear friend. I only ask you a simple question; answer it;\xe2\x80\x94that is all I\r\nrequire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love a young girl, count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you love her much?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMore than my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother hope defeated!\xe2\x80\x9d said the count. Then, with a sigh, \xe2\x80\x9cPoor\r\nHayd\xc3\xa9e!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo tell the truth, count, if I knew less of you, I should think that\r\nyou were less brave than you are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I sigh when thinking of someone I am leaving? Come, Morrel, it\r\nis not like a soldier to be so bad a judge of courage. Do I regret\r\nlife? What is it to me, who have passed twenty years between life and\r\ndeath? Moreover, do not alarm yourself, Morrel; this weakness, if it is\r\nsuch, is betrayed to you alone. I know the world is a drawing-room,\r\nfrom which we must retire politely and honestly; that is, with a bow,\r\nand our debts of honor paid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to the purpose. Have you brought your arms?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x94what for? I hope these gentlemen have theirs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will inquire,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo; but make no treaty\xe2\x80\x94you understand me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou need not fear.\xe2\x80\x9d Morrel advanced towards Beauchamp and\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, who, seeing his intention, came to meet him. The three\r\nyoung men bowed to each other courteously, if not affably.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I do not see M. de Morcerf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe sent us word this morning,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he would\r\nmeet us on the ground.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel. Beauchamp pulled out his watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is only five minutes past eight,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cthere is not\r\nmuch time lost yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I made no allusion of that kind,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a carriage coming,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. It advanced rapidly\r\nalong one of the avenues leading towards the open space where they were\r\nassembled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are doubtless provided with pistols, gentlemen? M. de Monte Cristo\r\nyields his right of using his.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe had anticipated this kindness on the part of the count,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nBeauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cand I have brought some weapons which I bought eight or ten\r\ndays since, thinking to want them on a similar occasion. They are quite\r\nnew, and have not yet been used. Will you examine them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, M. Beauchamp, if you assure me that M. de Morcerf does not know\r\nthese pistols, you may readily believe that your word will be quite\r\nsufficient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not Morcerf coming in that\r\ncarriage;\xe2\x80\x94faith, it is Franz and Debray!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two young men he announced were indeed approaching. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat chance\r\nbrings you here, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, shaking hands with\r\neach of them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cAlbert sent this morning to request us to\r\ncome.\xe2\x80\x9d Beauchamp and Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud exchanged looks of astonishment. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nthink I understand his reason,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYesterday afternoon I received a letter from M. de Morcerf, begging me\r\nto attend the Opera.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I also,\xe2\x80\x9d said Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd we, too,\xe2\x80\x9d added Beauchamp and Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHaving wished you all to witness the challenge, he now wishes you to\r\nbe present at the combat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young men; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have probably guessed right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, after all these arrangements, he does not come himself,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. \xe2\x80\x9cAlbert is ten minutes after time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere he comes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9con horseback, at full gallop,\r\nfollowed by a servant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow imprudent,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cto come on horseback to fight a\r\nduel with pistols, after all the instructions I had given him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd besides,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cwith a collar above his cravat, an open\r\ncoat and white waistcoat! Why has he not painted a spot upon his\r\nheart?\xe2\x80\x94it would have been more simple.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMeanwhile Albert had arrived within ten paces of the group formed by\r\nthe five young men. He jumped from his horse, threw the bridle on his\r\nservant\xe2\x80\x99s arms, and joined them. He was pale, and his eyes were red and\r\nswollen; it was evident that he had not slept. A shade of melancholy\r\ngravity overspread his countenance, which was not natural to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cfor having complied with my\r\nrequest; I feel extremely grateful for this mark of friendship.\xe2\x80\x9d Morrel\r\nhad stepped back as Morcerf approached, and remained at a short\r\ndistance. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd to you also, M. Morrel, my thanks are due. Come, there\r\ncannot be too many.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40248m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are not perhaps aware that I am M. de\r\nMonte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was not sure, but I thought it might be so. So much the better; the\r\nmore honorable men there are here the better I shall be satisfied.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you apprise the Count of Monte\r\nCristo that M. de Morcerf is arrived, and we are at his disposal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel was preparing to fulfil his commission. Beauchamp had meanwhile\r\ndrawn the box of pistols from the carriage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cI have two words to say to the Count\r\nof Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn private?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir; before all who are here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert\xe2\x80\x99s witnesses looked at each other. Franz and Debray exchanged\r\nsome words in a whisper, and Morrel, rejoiced at this unexpected\r\nincident, went to fetch the count, who was walking in a retired path\r\nwith Emmanuel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does he want with me?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know, but he wishes to speak to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI trust he is not going to tempt me by some\r\nfresh insult!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think that such is his intention,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel.\r\n\r\nThe count advanced, accompanied by Maximilian and Emmanuel. His calm\r\nand serene look formed a singular contrast to Albert\xe2\x80\x99s grief-stricken\r\nface, who approached also, followed by the other four young men.\r\n\r\nWhen at three paces distant from each other, Albert and the count\r\nstopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cApproach, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert; \xe2\x80\x9cI wish you not to lose one word of\r\nwhat I am about to have the honor of saying to the Count of Monte\r\nCristo, for it must be repeated by you to all who will listen to it,\r\nstrange as it may appear to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProceed, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, at first with a tremulous voice, but which\r\ngradually became firmer, \xe2\x80\x9cI reproached you with exposing the conduct of\r\nM. de Morcerf in Epirus, for guilty as I knew he was, I thought you had\r\nno right to punish him; but I have since learned that you had that\r\nright. It is not Fernand Mondego\xe2\x80\x99s treachery towards Ali Pasha which\r\ninduces me so readily to excuse you, but the treachery of the fisherman\r\nFernand towards you, and the almost unheard-of miseries which were its\r\nconsequences; and I say, and proclaim it publicly, that you were\r\njustified in revenging yourself on my father, and I, his son, thank you\r\nfor not using greater severity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHad a thunderbolt fallen in the midst of the spectators of this\r\nunexpected scene, it would not have surprised them more than did\r\nAlbert\xe2\x80\x99s declaration. As for Monte Cristo, his eyes slowly rose towards\r\nheaven with an expression of infinite gratitude. He could not\r\nunderstand how Albert\xe2\x80\x99s fiery nature, of which he had seen so much\r\namong the Roman bandits, had suddenly stooped to this humiliation. He\r\nrecognized the influence of Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, and saw why her noble heart had\r\nnot opposed the sacrifice she knew beforehand would be useless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cif you think my apology sufficient, pray give\r\nme your hand. Next to the merit of infallibility which you appear to\r\npossess, I rank that of candidly acknowledging a fault. But this\r\nconfession concerns me only. I acted well as a man, but you have acted\r\nbetter than man. An angel alone could have saved one of us from\r\ndeath\xe2\x80\x94that angel came from heaven, if not to make us friends (which,\r\nalas, fatality renders impossible), at least to make us esteem each\r\nother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo, with moistened eye, heaving breast, and lips half open,\r\nextended to Albert a hand which the latter pressed with a sentiment\r\nresembling respectful fear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cM. de Monte Cristo receives my apology. I had\r\nacted hastily towards him. Hasty actions are generally bad ones. Now my\r\nfault is repaired. I hope the world will not call me cowardly for\r\nacting as my conscience dictated. But if anyone should entertain a\r\nfalse opinion of me,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, drawing himself up as if he would\r\nchallenge both friends and enemies, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall endeavor to correct his\r\nmistake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat happened during the night?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Beauchamp of Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwe appear to make a very sorry figure here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn truth, what Albert has just done is either very despicable or very\r\nnoble,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the baron.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can it mean?\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray to Franz.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Count of Monte Cristo acts dishonorably to M. de Morcerf, and is\r\njustified by his son! Had I ten Yaninas in my family, I should only\r\nconsider myself the more bound to fight ten times.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs for Monte Cristo, his head was bent down, his arms were powerless.\r\nBowing under the weight of twenty-four years\xe2\x80\x99 reminiscences, he thought\r\nnot of Albert, of Beauchamp, of Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, or of any of that\r\ngroup; but he thought of that courageous woman who had come to plead\r\nfor her son\xe2\x80\x99s life, to whom he had offered his, and who had now saved\r\nit by the revelation of a dreadful family secret, capable of destroying\r\nforever in that young man\xe2\x80\x99s heart every feeling of filial piety.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProvidence still,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he; \xe2\x80\x9cnow only am I fully convinced of\r\nbeing the emissary of God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 91. Mother and Son\r\n\r\nThe Count of Monte Cristo bowed to the five young men with a melancholy\r\nand dignified smile, and got into his carriage with Maximilian and\r\nEmmanuel. Albert, Beauchamp, and Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud remained alone. Albert\r\nlooked at his two friends, not timidly, but in a way that appeared to\r\nask their opinion of what he had just done.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, my dear friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp first, who had either the most\r\nfeeling or the least dissimulation, \xe2\x80\x9callow me to congratulate you; this\r\nis a very unhoped-for conclusion of a very disagreeable affair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert remained silent and wrapped in thought. Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud contented\r\nhimself with tapping his boot with his flexible cane.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre we not going?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, after this embarrassing silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you please,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9callow me only to compliment M.\r\nde Morcerf, who has given proof today of rare chivalric generosity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is magnificent,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cto be able to exercise so\r\nmuch self-control!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAssuredly; as for me, I should have been incapable of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, with most significant coolness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Albert, \xe2\x80\x9cI think you did not understand that\r\nsomething very serious had passed between M. de Monte Cristo and\r\nmyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly, possibly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp immediately; \xe2\x80\x9cbut every simpleton\r\nwould not be able to understand your heroism, and sooner or later you\r\nwill find yourself compelled to explain it to them more energetically\r\nthan would be convenient to your bodily health and the duration of your\r\nlife. May I give you a friendly counsel? Set out for Naples, the Hague,\r\nor St. Petersburg\xe2\x80\x94calm countries, where the point of honor is better\r\nunderstood than among our hot-headed Parisians. Seek quietude and\r\noblivion, so that you may return peaceably to France after a few years.\r\nAm I not right, M. de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40252m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is quite my opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gentleman; \xe2\x80\x9cnothing induces\r\nserious duels so much as a duel forsworn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert, with a smile of indifference;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall follow your advice\xe2\x80\x94not because you give it, but because I had\r\nbefore intended to quit France. I thank you equally for the service you\r\nhave rendered me in being my seconds. It is deeply engraved on my\r\nheart, and, after what you have just said, I remember that only.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud and Beauchamp looked at each other; the impression was\r\nthe same on both of them, and the tone in which Morcerf had just\r\nexpressed his thanks was so determined that the position would have\r\nbecome embarrassing for all if the conversation had continued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye, Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp suddenly, carelessly extending his\r\nhand to the young man. The latter did not appear to arouse from his\r\nlethargy; in fact, he did not notice the offered hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud in his turn, keeping his little cane in\r\nhis left hand, and saluting with his right.\r\n\r\nAlbert\xe2\x80\x99s lips scarcely whispered \xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye,\xe2\x80\x9d but his look was more\r\nexplicit; it expressed a whole poem of restrained anger, proud disdain,\r\nand generous indignation. He preserved his melancholy and motionless\r\nposition for some time after his two friends had regained their\r\ncarriage; then suddenly unfastening his horse from the little tree to\r\nwhich his servant had tied it, he mounted and galloped off in the\r\ndirection of Paris.\r\n\r\nIn a quarter of an hour he was entering the house in the Rue du Helder.\r\nAs he alighted, he thought he saw his father\xe2\x80\x99s pale face behind the\r\ncurtain of the count\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom. Albert turned away his head with a\r\nsigh, and went to his own apartments. He cast one lingering look on all\r\nthe luxuries which had rendered life so easy and so happy since his\r\ninfancy; he looked at the pictures, whose faces seemed to smile, and\r\nthe landscapes, which appeared painted in brighter colors. Then he took\r\naway his mother\xe2\x80\x99s portrait, with its oaken frame, leaving the gilt\r\nframe from which he took it black and empty. Then he arranged all his\r\nbeautiful Turkish arms, his fine English guns, his Japanese china, his\r\ncups mounted in silver, his artistic bronzes by Feuch\xc3\xa8res or Barye;\r\nexamined the cupboards, and placed the key in each; threw into a drawer\r\nof his secretaire, which he left open, all the pocket-money he had\r\nabout him, and with it the thousand fancy jewels from his vases and his\r\njewel-boxes; then he made an exact inventory of everything, and placed\r\nit in the most conspicuous part of the table, after putting aside the\r\nbooks and papers which had collected there.\r\n\r\nAt the beginning of this work, his servant, notwithstanding orders to\r\nthe contrary, came to his room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, with a more sorrowful than angry tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the valet; \xe2\x80\x9cyou had forbidden me to disturb\r\nyou, but the Count of Morcerf has called me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not like to go to him without first seeing you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause the count is doubtless aware that I accompanied you to the\r\nmeeting this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40254m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is probable,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd since he has sent for me, it is doubtless to question me on what\r\nhappened there. What must I answer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I shall say the duel did not take place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will say I apologized to the Count of Monte Cristo. Go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe valet bowed and retired, and Albert returned to his inventory. As\r\nhe was finishing this work, the sound of horses prancing in the yard,\r\nand the wheels of a carriage shaking his window, attracted his\r\nattention. He approached the window, and saw his father get into it,\r\nand drive away. The door was scarcely closed when Albert bent his steps\r\nto his mother\xe2\x80\x99s room; and, no one being there to announce him, he\r\nadvanced to her bedchamber, and distressed by what he saw and guessed,\r\nstopped for one moment at the door.\r\n\r\nAs if the same idea had animated these two beings, Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s was doing\r\nthe same in her apartments that he had just done in his. Everything was\r\nin order,\xe2\x80\x94laces, dresses, jewels, linen, money, all were arranged in\r\nthe drawers, and the countess was carefully collecting the keys. Albert\r\nsaw all these preparations and understood them, and exclaiming, \xe2\x80\x9cMy\r\nmother!\xe2\x80\x9d he threw his arms around her neck.\r\n\r\nThe artist who could have depicted the expression of these two\r\ncountenances would certainly have made of them a beautiful picture. All\r\nthese proofs of an energetic resolution, which Albert did not fear on\r\nhis own account, alarmed him for his mother. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nasked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat were you doing?\xe2\x80\x9d replied she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my mother!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Albert, so overcome he could scarcely speak;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cit is not the same with you and me\xe2\x80\x94you cannot have made the same\r\nresolution I have, for I have come to warn you that I bid adieu to your\r\nhouse, and\xe2\x80\x94and to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI also,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cam going, and I acknowledge I had depended\r\non your accompanying me; have I deceived myself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Albert with firmness. \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot make you share the fate\r\nI have planned for myself. I must live henceforth without rank and\r\nfortune, and to begin this hard apprenticeship I must borrow from a\r\nfriend the loaf I shall eat until I have earned one. So, my dear\r\nmother, I am going at once to ask Franz to lend me the small sum I\r\nshall require to supply my present wants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, my poor child, suffer poverty and hunger? Oh, do not say so; it\r\nwill break my resolutions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut not mine, mother,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Albert. \xe2\x80\x9cI am young and strong; I\r\nbelieve I am courageous, and since yesterday I have learned the power\r\nof will. Alas, my dear mother, some have suffered so much, and yet\r\nlive, and have raised a new fortune on the ruin of all the promises of\r\nhappiness which heaven had made them\xe2\x80\x94on the fragments of all the hope\r\nwhich God had given them! I have seen that, mother; I know that from\r\nthe gulf in which their enemies have plunged them they have risen with\r\nso much vigor and glory that in their turn they have ruled their former\r\nconquerors, and have punished them. No, mother; from this moment I have\r\ndone with the past, and accept nothing from it\xe2\x80\x94not even a name, because\r\nyou can understand that your son cannot bear the name of a man who\r\nought to blush for it before another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert, my child,\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, \xe2\x80\x9cif I had a stronger heart, that is\r\nthe counsel I would have given you; your conscience has spoken when my\r\nvoice became too weak; listen to its dictates. You had friends, Albert;\r\nbreak off their acquaintance. But do not despair; you have life before\r\nyou, my dear Albert, for you are yet scarcely twenty-two years old; and\r\nas a pure heart like yours wants a spotless name, take my father\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94it\r\nwas Herrera. I am sure, my dear Albert, whatever may be your career,\r\nyou will soon render that name illustrious. Then, my son, return to the\r\nworld still more brilliant because of your former sorrows; and if I am\r\nwrong, still let me cherish these hopes, for I have no future to look\r\nforward to. For me the grave opens when I pass the threshold of this\r\nhouse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will fulfil all your wishes, my dear mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I share your hopes; the anger of Heaven will not pursue us, since\r\nyou are pure and I am innocent. But, since our resolution is formed,\r\nlet us act promptly. M. de Morcerf went out about half an hour ago; the\r\nopportunity is favorable to avoid an explanation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am ready, my son,\xe2\x80\x9d said Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s.\r\n\r\nAlbert ran to fetch a carriage. He recollected that there was a small\r\nfurnished house to let in the Rue des Saints-P\xc3\xa8res, where his mother\r\nwould find a humble but decent lodging, and thither he intended\r\nconducting the countess. As the carriage stopped at the door, and\r\nAlbert was alighting, a man approached and gave him a letter.\r\n\r\nAlbert recognized the bearer. \xe2\x80\x9cFrom the count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bertuccio. Albert\r\ntook the letter, opened, and read it, then looked round for Bertuccio,\r\nbut he was gone.\r\n\r\nHe returned to Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s with tears in his eyes and heaving breast, and\r\nwithout uttering a word he gave her the letter. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert,\xe2\x80\x94While showing you that I have discovered your plans, I hope\r\nalso to convince you of my delicacy. You are free, you leave the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s house, and you take your mother to your home; but reflect,\r\nAlbert, you owe her more than your poor noble heart can pay her. Keep\r\nthe struggle for yourself, bear all the suffering, but spare her the\r\ntrial of poverty which must accompany your first efforts; for she\r\ndeserves not even the shadow of the misfortune which has this day\r\nfallen on her, and Providence is not willing that the innocent should\r\nsuffer for the guilty. I know you are going to leave the Rue du Helder\r\nwithout taking anything with you. Do not seek to know how I discovered\r\nit; I know it\xe2\x80\x94that is sufficient.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, listen, Albert. Twenty-four years ago I returned, proud and\r\njoyful, to my country. I had a betrothed, Albert, a lovely girl whom I\r\nadored, and I was bringing to my betrothed a hundred and fifty louis,\r\npainfully amassed by ceaseless toil. This money was for her; I destined\r\nit for her, and, knowing the treachery of the sea I buried our treasure\r\nin the little garden of the house my father lived in at Marseilles, on\r\nthe All\xc3\xa9es de Meilhan. Your mother, Albert, knows that poor house well.\r\nA short time since I passed through Marseilles, and went to see the old\r\nplace, which revived so many painful recollections; and in the evening\r\nI took a spade and dug in the corner of the garden where I had\r\nconcealed my treasure. The iron box was there\xe2\x80\x94no one had touched\r\nit\xe2\x80\x94under a beautiful fig-tree my father had planted the day I was born,\r\nwhich overshadowed the spot. Well, Albert, this money, which was\r\nformerly designed to promote the comfort and tranquillity of the woman\r\nI adored, may now, through strange and painful circumstances, be\r\ndevoted to the same purpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, feel for me, who could offer millions to that poor woman, but who\r\nreturn her only the piece of black bread forgotten under my poor roof\r\nsince the day I was torn from her I loved. You are a generous man,\r\nAlbert, but perhaps you may be blinded by pride or resentment; if you\r\nrefuse me, if you ask another for what I have a right to offer you, I\r\nwill say it is ungenerous of you to refuse the life of your mother at\r\nthe hands of a man whose father was allowed by your father to die in\r\nall the horrors of poverty and despair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert stood pale and motionless to hear what his mother would decide\r\nafter she had finished reading this letter. Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s turned her eyes\r\nwith an ineffable look towards heaven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI accept it,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9che has a right to pay the dowry, which I\r\nshall take with me to some convent!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPutting the letter in her bosom, she took her son\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and with a\r\nfirmer step than she even herself expected she went downstairs.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 92. The Suicide\r\n\r\nMeanwhile Monte Cristo had also returned to town with Emmanuel and\r\nMaximilian. Their return was cheerful. Emmanuel did not conceal his joy\r\nat the peaceful termination of the affair, and was loud in his\r\nexpressions of delight. Morrel, in a corner of the carriage, allowed\r\nhis brother-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s gayety to expend itself in words, while he felt\r\nequal inward joy, which, however, betrayed itself only in his\r\ncountenance.\r\n\r\nAt the Barri\xc3\xa8re du Tr\xc3\xb4ne they met Bertuccio, who was waiting there,\r\nmotionless as a sentinel at his post. Monte Cristo put his head out of\r\nthe window, exchanged a few words with him in a low tone, and the\r\nsteward disappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmanuel, when they were at the end of the Place Royale,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cput me down at my door, that my wife may not have a single moment of\r\nneedless anxiety on my account or yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it were not ridiculous to make a display of our triumph, said\r\nMorrel, I would invite the count to our house; besides that, he\r\ndoubtless has some trembling heart to comfort. So we will take leave of\r\nour friend, and let him hasten home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cdo not let me lose both my\r\ncompanions. Return, Emmanuel, to your charming wife, and present my\r\nbest compliments to her; and do you, Morrel, accompany me to the\r\nChamps-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWillingly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian; \xe2\x80\x9cparticularly as I have business in that\r\nquarter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we wait breakfast for you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Emmanuel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man. The door was closed, and the carriage\r\nproceeded. \xe2\x80\x9cSee what good fortune I brought you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, when he\r\nwas alone with the count. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you not thought so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cfor that reason I wished to keep you near\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is miraculous!\xe2\x80\x9d continued Morrel, answering his own thoughts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has just happened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Count, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are right\xe2\x80\x94it is miraculous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor Albert is brave,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery brave,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI have seen him sleep with a sword\r\nsuspended over his head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I know he has fought two duels,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel. \xe2\x80\x9cHow can you\r\nreconcile that with his conduct this morning?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll owing to your influence,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well for Albert he is not in the army,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn apology on the ground!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young captain, shaking his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count mildly, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not entertain the prejudices of\r\nordinary men, Morrel! Acknowledge, that if Albert is brave, he cannot\r\nbe a coward; he must then have had some reason for acting as he did\r\nthis morning, and confess that his conduct is more heroic than\r\notherwise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless, doubtless,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I shall say, like the\r\nSpaniard, \xe2\x80\x98He has not been so brave today as he was yesterday.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will breakfast with me, will you not, Morrel?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, to\r\nturn the conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I must leave you at ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour engagement was for breakfast, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\nMorrel smiled, and shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill you must breakfast somewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if I am not hungry?\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cI only know two things which destroy the\r\nappetite,\xe2\x80\x94grief\xe2\x80\x94and as I am happy to see you very cheerful, it is not\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x94and love. Now after what you told me this morning of your heart, I\r\nmay believe\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, count,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel gayly, \xe2\x80\x9cI will not dispute it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you will not make me your confidant, Maximilian?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count,\r\nin a tone which showed how gladly he would have been admitted to the\r\nsecret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI showed you this morning that I had a heart, did I not, count?\xe2\x80\x9d Monte\r\nCristo only answered by extending his hand to the young man. \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued the latter, \xe2\x80\x9csince that heart is no longer with you in the\r\nBois de Vincennes, it is elsewhere, and I must go and find it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count deliberately; \xe2\x80\x9cgo, dear friend, but promise me if\r\nyou meet with any obstacle to remember that I have some power in this\r\nworld, that I am happy to use that power in the behalf of those I love,\r\nand that I love you, Morrel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40260m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will remember it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cas selfish children\r\nrecollect their parents when they want their aid. When I need your\r\nassistance, and the moment arrives, I will come to you, count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I rely upon your promise. Good-bye, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye, till we meet again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey had arrived in the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es. Monte Cristo opened the\r\ncarriage-door, Morrel sprang out on the pavement, Bertuccio was waiting\r\non the steps. Morrel disappeared down the Avenue de Marigny, and Monte\r\nCristo hastened to join Bertuccio.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is going to leave her house,\xe2\x80\x9d said the steward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd her son?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFlorentin, his valet, thinks he is going to do the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome this way.\xe2\x80\x9d Monte Cristo took Bertuccio into his study, wrote the\r\nletter we have seen, and gave it to the steward. \xe2\x80\x9cGo,\xe2\x80\x9d said he quickly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut first, let Hayd\xc3\xa9e be informed that I have returned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young girl, who at the sound of the carriage had\r\nrun downstairs and whose face was radiant with joy at seeing the count\r\nreturn safely. Bertuccio left. Every transport of a daughter finding a\r\nfather, all the delight of a mistress seeing an adored lover, were felt\r\nby Hayd\xc3\xa9e during the first moments of this meeting, which she had so\r\neagerly expected. Doubtless, although less evident, Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s joy\r\nwas not less intense. Joy to hearts which have suffered long is like\r\nthe dew on the ground after a long drought; both the heart and the\r\nground absorb that beneficent moisture falling on them, and nothing is\r\noutwardly apparent.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo was beginning to think, what he had not for a long time\r\ndared to believe, that there were two Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s in the world, and he\r\nmight yet be happy. His eye, elate with happiness, was reading eagerly\r\nthe tearful gaze of Hayd\xc3\xa9e, when suddenly the door opened. The count\r\nknit his brow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Morcerf!\xe2\x80\x9d said Baptistin, as if that name sufficed for his\r\nexcuse. In fact, the count\xe2\x80\x99s face brightened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich,\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe viscount or the count?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Hayd\xc3\xa9e, \xe2\x80\x9cis it not yet over?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know not if it is finished, my beloved child,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo,\r\ntaking the young girl\xe2\x80\x99s hands; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I do know you have nothing more to\r\nfear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it is the wretched\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat man cannot injure me, Hayd\xc3\xa9e,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cit was his son\r\nalone that there was cause to fear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what I have suffered,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young girl, \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall never know,\r\nmy lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cBy my father\xe2\x80\x99s tomb,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, extending his hand\r\nover the head of the young girl, \xe2\x80\x9cI swear to you, Hayd\xc3\xa9e, that if any\r\nmisfortune happens, it will not be to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe you, my lord, as implicitly as if God had spoken to me,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the young girl, presenting her forehead to him. Monte Cristo\r\npressed on that pure beautiful forehead a kiss which made two hearts\r\nthrob at once, the one violently, the other secretly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the count, \xe2\x80\x9cshall I then be permitted to love again? Ask\r\nM. de Morcerf into the drawing-room,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Baptistin, while he\r\nled the beautiful Greek girl to a private staircase.\r\n\r\nWe must explain this visit, which although expected by Monte Cristo, is\r\nunexpected to our readers. While Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, as we have said, was making\r\na similar inventory of her property to Albert\xe2\x80\x99s, while she was\r\narranging her jewels, shutting her drawers, collecting her keys, to\r\nleave everything in perfect order, she did not perceive a pale and\r\nsinister face at a glass door which threw light into the passage, from\r\nwhich everything could be both seen and heard. He who was thus looking,\r\nwithout being heard or seen, probably heard and saw all that passed in\r\nMadame de Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s apartments. From that glass door the pale-faced man\r\nwent to the count\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom and raised with a constricted hand the\r\ncurtain of a window overlooking the courtyard. He remained there ten\r\nminutes, motionless and dumb, listening to the beating of his own\r\nheart. For him those ten minutes were very long. It was then Albert,\r\nreturning from his meeting with the count, perceived his father\r\nwatching for his arrival behind a curtain, and turned aside. The\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s eye expanded; he knew Albert had insulted the count dreadfully,\r\nand that in every country in the world such an insult would lead to a\r\ndeadly duel. Albert returned safely\xe2\x80\x94then the count was revenged.\r\n\r\nAn indescribable ray of joy illumined that wretched countenance like\r\nthe last ray of the sun before it disappears behind the clouds which\r\nbear the aspect, not of a downy couch, but of a tomb. But as we have\r\nsaid, he waited in vain for his son to come to his apartment with the\r\naccount of his triumph. He easily understood why his son did not come\r\nto see him before he went to avenge his father\xe2\x80\x99s honor; but when that\r\nwas done, why did not his son come and throw himself into his arms?\r\n\r\nIt was then, when the count could not see Albert, that he sent for his\r\nservant, who he knew was authorized not to conceal anything from him.\r\nTen minutes afterwards, General Morcerf was seen on the steps in a\r\nblack coat with a military collar, black pantaloons, and black gloves.\r\nHe had apparently given previous orders, for as he reached the bottom\r\nstep his carriage came from the coach-house ready for him. The valet\r\nthrew into the carriage his military cloak, in which two swords were\r\nwrapped, and, shutting the door, he took his seat by the side of the\r\ncoachman. The coachman stooped down for his orders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es,\xe2\x80\x9d said the general; \xe2\x80\x9cthe Count of Monte\r\nCristo\xe2\x80\x99s. Hurry!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe horses bounded beneath the whip; and in five minutes they stopped\r\nbefore the count\xe2\x80\x99s door. M. de Morcerf opened the door himself, and as\r\nthe carriage rolled away he passed up the walk, rang, and entered the\r\nopen door with his servant.\r\n\r\nA moment afterwards, Baptistin announced the Count of Morcerf to Monte\r\nCristo, and the latter, leading Hayd\xc3\xa9e aside, ordered that Morcerf be\r\nasked into the drawing-room. The general was pacing the room the third\r\ntime when, in turning, he perceived Monte Cristo at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, it is M. de Morcerf,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo quietly; \xe2\x80\x9cI thought I had\r\nnot heard aright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it is I,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, whom a frightful contraction of the\r\nlips prevented from articulating freely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I know the cause which procures me the pleasure of seeing M. de\r\nMorcerf so early?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad you not a meeting with my son this morning?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the general.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I know my son had good reasons to wish to fight with you, and to\r\nendeavor to kill you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, he had very good ones; but you see that in spite of them he\r\nhas not killed me, and did not even fight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet he considered you the cause of his father\xe2\x80\x99s dishonor, the cause of\r\nthe fearful ruin which has fallen on my house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo with his dreadful calmness; \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nsecondary cause, but not the principal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless you made, then, some apology or explanation?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI explained nothing, and it is he who apologized to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut to what do you attribute this conduct?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the conviction, probably, that there was one more guilty than I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who was that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat may be,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, turning pale; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you know the guilty\r\ndo not like to find themselves convicted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it, and I expected this result.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou expected my son would be a coward?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Albert de Morcerf is no coward!\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man who holds a sword in his hand, and sees a mortal enemy within\r\nreach of that sword, and does not fight, is a coward! Why is he not\r\nhere that I may tell him so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo coldly, \xe2\x80\x9cI did not expect that you had come\r\nhere to relate to me your little family affairs. Go and tell M. Albert\r\nthat, and he may know what to answer you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said the general, smiling faintly, \xe2\x80\x9cI did not come for\r\nthat purpose; you are right. I came to tell you that I also look upon\r\nyou as my enemy. I came to tell you that I hate you instinctively; that\r\nit seems as if I had always known you, and always hated you; and, in\r\nshort, since the young people of the present day will not fight, it\r\nremains for us to do so. Do you think so, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly. And when I told you I had foreseen the result, it is the\r\nhonor of your visit I alluded to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better.
