Are you prepared?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know that we shall fight till one of us is dead,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ngeneral, whose teeth were clenched with rage.\r\n\r\n40262m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUntil one of us dies,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Monte Cristo, moving his head slightly\r\nup and down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us start, then; we need no witnesses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cit is unnecessary, we know each other\r\nso well!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cwe know so little of each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, with the same indomitable coolness; \xe2\x80\x9clet\r\nus see. Are you not the soldier Fernand who deserted on the eve of the\r\nbattle of Waterloo? Are you not the Lieutenant Fernand who served as\r\nguide and spy to the French army in Spain? Are you not the Captain\r\nFernand who betrayed, sold, and murdered his benefactor, Ali? And have\r\nnot all these Fernands, united, made Lieutenant-General, the Count of\r\nMorcerf, peer of France?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the general, as if branded with a hot iron, \xe2\x80\x9cwretch,\xe2\x80\x94to\r\nreproach me with my shame when about, perhaps, to kill me! No, I did\r\nnot say I was a stranger to you. I know well, demon, that you have\r\npenetrated into the darkness of the past, and that you have read, by\r\nthe light of what torch I know not, every page of my life; but perhaps\r\nI may be more honorable in my shame than you under your pompous\r\ncoverings. No\xe2\x80\x94no, I am aware you know me; but I know you only as an\r\nadventurer sewn up in gold and jewellery. You call yourself, in Paris,\r\nthe Count of Monte Cristo; in Italy, Sinbad the Sailor; in Malta, I\r\nforget what. But it is your real name I want to know, in the midst of\r\nyour hundred names, that I may pronounce it when we meet to fight, at\r\nthe moment when I plunge my sword through your heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Count of Monte Cristo turned dreadfully pale; his eye seemed to\r\nburn with a devouring fire. He leaped towards a dressing-room near his\r\nbedroom, and in less than a moment, tearing off his cravat, his coat\r\nand waistcoat, he put on a sailor\xe2\x80\x99s jacket and hat, from beneath which\r\nrolled his long black hair. He returned thus, formidable and\r\nimplacable, advancing with his arms crossed on his breast, towards the\r\ngeneral, who could not understand why he had disappeared, but who on\r\nseeing him again, and feeling his teeth chatter and his legs sink under\r\nhim, drew back, and only stopped when he found a table to support his\r\nclenched hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFernand,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, \xe2\x80\x9cof my hundred names I need only tell you one, to\r\noverwhelm you! But you guess it now, do you not?\xe2\x80\x94or, rather, you\r\nremember it? For, notwithstanding all my sorrows and my tortures, I\r\nshow you today a face which the happiness of revenge makes young\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94a face you must often have seen in your dreams since your\r\nmarriage with Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s, my betrothed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40268m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe general, with his head thrown back, hands extended, gaze fixed,\r\nlooked silently at this dreadful apparition; then seeking the wall to\r\nsupport him, he glided along close to it until he reached the door,\r\nthrough which he went out backwards, uttering this single mournful,\r\nlamentable, distressing cry:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdmond Dant\xc3\xa8s!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen, with sighs which were unlike any human sound, he dragged himself\r\nto the door, reeled across the courtyard, and falling into the arms of\r\nhis valet, he said in a voice scarcely intelligible,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHome, home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe fresh air and the shame he felt at having exposed himself before\r\nhis servants, partly recalled his senses, but the ride was short, and\r\nas he drew near his house all his wretchedness revived. He stopped at a\r\nshort distance from the house and alighted. The door was wide open, a\r\nhackney-coach was standing in the middle of the yard\xe2\x80\x94a strange sight\r\nbefore so noble a mansion; the count looked at it with terror, but\r\nwithout daring to inquire its meaning, he rushed towards his apartment.\r\n\r\nTwo persons were coming down the stairs; he had only time to creep into\r\nan alcove to avoid them. It was Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s leaning on her son\xe2\x80\x99s arm and\r\nleaving the house. They passed close by the unhappy being, who,\r\nconcealed behind the damask curtain, almost felt Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s dress brush\r\npast him, and his son\xe2\x80\x99s warm breath, pronouncing these words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCourage, mother! Come, this is no longer our home!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe words died away, the steps were lost in the distance. The general\r\ndrew himself up, clinging to the curtain; he uttered the most dreadful\r\nsob which ever escaped from the bosom of a father abandoned at the same\r\ntime by his wife and son. He soon heard the clatter of the iron step of\r\nthe hackney-coach, then the coachman\xe2\x80\x99s voice, and then the rolling of\r\nthe heavy vehicle shook the windows. He darted to his bedroom to see\r\nonce more all he had loved in the world; but the hackney-coach drove on\r\nand the head of neither Merc\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa8s nor her son appeared at the window to\r\ntake a last look at the house or the deserted father and husband.\r\n\r\nAnd at the very moment when the wheels of that coach crossed the\r\ngateway a report was heard, and a thick smoke escaped through one of\r\nthe panes of the window, which was broken by the explosion.\r\n\r\n40270m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 93. Valentine\r\n\r\nWe may easily conceive where Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s appointment was. On leaving Monte\r\nCristo he walked slowly towards Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s; we say slowly, for Morrel\r\nhad more than half an hour to spare to go five hundred steps, but he\r\nhad hastened to take leave of Monte Cristo because he wished to be\r\nalone with his thoughts. He knew his time well\xe2\x80\x94the hour when Valentine\r\nwas giving Noirtier his breakfast, and was sure not to be disturbed in\r\nthe performance of this pious duty. Noirtier and Valentine had given\r\nhim leave to go twice a week, and he was now availing himself of that\r\npermission.\r\n\r\nHe arrived; Valentine was expecting him. Uneasy and almost crazed, she\r\nseized his hand and led him to her grandfather. This uneasiness,\r\namounting almost to frenzy, arose from the report Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s adventure\r\nhad made in the world, for the affair at the Opera was generally known.\r\nNo one at Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s doubted that a duel would ensue from it.\r\nValentine, with her woman\xe2\x80\x99s instinct, guessed that Morrel would be\r\nMonte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s second, and from the young man\xe2\x80\x99s well-known courage and\r\nhis great affection for the count, she feared that he would not content\r\nhimself with the passive part assigned to him. We may easily understand\r\nhow eagerly the particulars were asked for, given, and received; and\r\nMorrel could read an indescribable joy in the eyes of his beloved, when\r\nshe knew that the termination of this affair was as happy as it was\r\nunexpected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, motioning to Morrel to sit down near her\r\ngrandfather, while she took her seat on his footstool,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cnow let us talk\r\nabout our own affairs. You know, Maximilian, grandpapa once thought of\r\nleaving this house, and taking an apartment away from M. de\r\nVillefort\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cI recollect the project, of which I highly\r\napproved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cyou may approve again, for grandpapa is again\r\nthinking of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian.\r\n\r\n40272m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat reason grandpapa gives for\r\nleaving this house.\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier looked at Valentine to impose silence,\r\nbut she did not notice him; her looks, her eyes, her smile, were all\r\nfor Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, whatever may be M. Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s reason,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cI can\r\nreadily believe it to be a good one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn excellent one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine. \xe2\x80\x9cHe pretends the air of the\r\nFaubourg Saint-Honor\xc3\xa9 is not good for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cin that M. Noirtier may be right; you have not\r\nseemed to be well for the last fortnight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot very,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd grandpapa has become my physician, and\r\nI have the greatest confidence in him, because he knows everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you then really suffer?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel quickly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it must not be called suffering; I feel a general uneasiness, that\r\nis all. I have lost my appetite, and my stomach feels as if it were\r\nstruggling to get accustomed to something.\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier did not lose a\r\nword of what Valentine said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what treatment do you adopt for this singular complaint?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA very simple one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine. \xe2\x80\x9cI swallow every morning a\r\nspoonful of the mixture prepared for my grandfather. When I say one\r\nspoonful, I began by one\xe2\x80\x94now I take four. Grandpapa says it is a\r\npanacea.\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine smiled, but it was evident that she suffered.\r\n\r\nMaximilian, in his devotedness, gazed silently at her. She was very\r\nbeautiful, but her usual pallor had increased; her eyes were more\r\nbrilliant than ever, and her hands, which were generally white like\r\nmother-of-pearl, now more resembled wax, to which time was adding a\r\nyellowish hue.\r\n\r\nFrom Valentine the young man looked towards Noirtier. The latter\r\nwatched with strange and deep interest the young girl, absorbed by her\r\naffection, and he also, like Morrel, followed those traces of inward\r\nsuffering which was so little perceptible to a common observer that\r\nthey escaped the notice of everyone but the grandfather and the lover.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cI thought this mixture, of which you now take four\r\nspoonfuls, was prepared for M. Noirtier?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it is very bitter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cso bitter, that all I\r\ndrink afterwards appears to have the same taste.\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier looked\r\ninquiringly at his granddaughter. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, grandpapa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cit\r\nis so. Accustomed, however, as he was to\r\nthe work, he had to repeat most of the letters of the alphabet and to\r\nfind every word in the dictionary, so that it was ten minutes before\r\nthe thought of the old man was translated by these words,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFetch the glass of water and the decanter from Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel rang immediately for the servant who had taken Barrois\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsituation, and in Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s name gave that order. The servant soon\r\nreturned. The decanter and the glass were completely empty. Noirtier\r\nmade a sign that he wished to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are the glass and decanter empty?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he; \xe2\x80\x9cValentine said she\r\nonly drank half the glassful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe translation of this new question occupied another five minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know,\xe2\x80\x9d said the servant, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the housemaid is in\r\nMademoiselle Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s room: perhaps she has emptied them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsk her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, translating Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s thought this time by his\r\nlook. That is why Valentine passed through her\r\nroom, which was on a level with Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s, and only separated from it\r\nby Edward\xe2\x80\x99s. The two ladies entered the drawing-room with that sort of\r\nofficial stiffness which preludes a formal communication. Among worldly\r\npeople manner is contagious. Valentine entered at this moment, and the formalities\r\nwere resumed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the baroness, while the two young people were\r\nshaking hands, \xe2\x80\x9cI and Eug\xc3\xa9nie are come to be the first to announce to\r\nyou the approaching marriage of my daughter with Prince Cavalcanti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nDanglars kept up the title of prince. The popular banker found that it\r\nanswered better than count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me to present you my sincere congratulations,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Madame de\r\nVillefort. \xe2\x80\x9cPrince Cavalcanti appears to be a young man of rare\r\nqualities.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40276m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the baroness, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cspeaking to you as a friend I\r\ncan say that the prince does not yet appear all he will be. Besides, he\r\ngives evidence of great kindness of disposition, much keenness of wit,\r\nand as to suitability, M. Maximilian\xe2\x80\x99s Avowal\r\n\r\nAt the same moment M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s voice was heard calling from his\r\nstudy, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel looked at Noirtier who had recovered his self-command, and with\r\na glance indicated the closet where once before under somewhat similar\r\ncircumstances, he had taken refuge. Two persons passed\r\nnear me\xe2\x80\x94allow me to conceal their names for the present; they were\r\nspeaking in an undertone, and yet I was so interested in what they said\r\nthat I did not lose a single word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a gloomy introduction, if I may judge from your pallor and\r\nshuddering, Morrel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, very gloomy, my friend. Count, what am I bound to do, being in\r\npossession of this secret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cyou appear to be relating an\r\nadventure which we all know by heart. D\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny followed the invalid,\r\nwrote a prescription, ordered Villefort to take a cabriolet, go in\r\nperson to a chemist\xe2\x80\x99s to get the prescribed medicine, bring it himself,\r\nand wait for him in his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s room. Then, having renewed his\r\ninjunction not to give Valentine anything, he went down again to\r\nNoirtier, shut the doors carefully, and after convincing himself that\r\nno one was listening:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cknow anything of this young lady\xe2\x80\x99s illness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have no time to lose; I will question, and do you answer me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nNoirtier made a sign that he was ready to answer. \xe2\x80\x9cDid you anticipate\r\nthe accident which has happened to your granddaughter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d D\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny reflected a moment; then approaching Noirtier:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon what I am going to say,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut no indication should be\r\nneglected in this terrible situation. Did you see poor Barrois die?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nNoirtier raised his eyes to heaven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know of what he died!\xe2\x80\x9d asked d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, placing his hand on\r\nNoirtier\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think he died a natural death?\xe2\x80\x9d A sort of smile was discernible\r\non the motionless lips of Noirtier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have thought that Barrois was poisoned?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think the poison he fell a victim to was intended for him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think the same hand which unintentionally struck Barrois has\r\nnow attacked Valentine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen will she die too?\xe2\x80\x9d asked d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, fixing his penetrating gaze\r\non Noirtier. He watched the effect of this question on the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he with an air of triumph which would have puzzled the\r\nmost clever diviner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you hope?\xe2\x80\x9d said d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, with surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you hope?\xe2\x80\x9d The old man made him understand with his eyes that\r\nhe could not answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes, it is true,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny. Then, turning to\r\nNoirtier,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDo you hope the assassin will be tried?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you hope the poison will take no effect on Valentine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is no news to you,\xe2\x80\x9d added d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, \xe2\x80\x9cto tell you that an attempt\r\nhas been made to poison her?\xe2\x80\x9d The old man made a sign that he\r\nentertained no doubt upon the subject. \xe2\x80\x9cThen how do you hope Valentine\r\nwill escape?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoirtier kept his eyes steadfastly fixed on the same spot. D\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny\r\nfollowed the direction and saw that they were fixed on a bottle\r\ncontaining the mixture which he took every morning. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, struck with a sudden thought, \xe2\x80\x9chas it occurred to\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Noirtier did not let him finish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo prepare her system to resist poison?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy accustoming her by degrees\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noirtier, delighted to be understood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course. I had told you that there was brucine in the mixture I give\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd by accustoming her to that poison, you have endeavored to\r\nneutralize the effect of a similar poison?\xe2\x80\x9d Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s joy continued.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have succeeded,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny. \xe2\x80\x9cWithout that precaution\r\nValentine would have died before assistance could have been procured.\r\nThe dose has been excessive, but she has only been shaken by it; and\r\nthis time, at any rate, Valentine will not die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA superhuman joy expanded the old man\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, which were raised towards\r\nheaven with an expression of infinite gratitude. At this moment\r\nVillefort returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, doctor,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cis what you sent me for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas this prepared in your presence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the procureur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you not let it go out of your hands?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny took the bottle, poured some drops of the mixture it\r\ncontained in the hollow of his hand, and swallowed them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9clet us go to Valentine; I will give instructions to\r\neveryone, and you, M. de Villefort, will yourself see that no one\r\ndeviates from them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n40294m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAt the moment when d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny was returning to Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s room,\r\naccompanied by Villefort, an Italian priest, of serious demeanor and\r\ncalm and firm tone, hired for his use the house adjoining the hotel of\r\nM. de Villefort. No one knew how the three former tenants of that house\r\nleft it. About two hours afterwards its foundation was reported to be\r\nunsafe; but the report did not prevent the new occupant establishing\r\nhimself there with his modest furniture the same day at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\r\nThe lease was drawn up for three, six, or nine years by the new tenant,\r\nwho, according to the rule of the proprietor, paid six months in\r\nadvance.\r\n\r\nThis new tenant, who, as we have said, was an Italian, was called Il\r\nSignor Giacomo Busoni. Workmen were immediately called in, and that\r\nsame night the passengers at the end of the faubourg saw with surprise\r\nthat carpenters and masons were occupied in repairing the lower part of\r\nthe tottering house.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 95. Father and Daughter\r\n\r\nWe saw in a preceding chapter how Madame Danglars went formally to\r\nannounce to Madame de Villefort the approaching marriage of Eug\xc3\xa9nie\r\nDanglars and M. Andrea Cavalcanti. This formal announcement, which\r\nimplied or appeared to imply, the approval of all the persons concerned\r\nin this momentous affair, had been preceded by a scene to which our\r\nreaders must be admitted. We beg them to take one step backward, and to\r\ntransport themselves, the morning of that day of great catastrophes,\r\ninto the showy, gilded salon we have before shown them, and which was\r\nthe pride of its owner, Baron Danglars.\r\n\r\nIn this room, at about ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, the banker himself\r\nhad been walking to and fro for some minutes thoughtfully and in\r\nevident uneasiness, watching both doors, and listening to every sound.\r\nWhen his patience was exhausted, he called his valet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xc3\x89tienne,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9csee why Mademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie has asked me to meet\r\nher in the drawing-room, and why she makes me wait so long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaving given this vent to his ill-humor, the baron became more calm;\r\nMademoiselle Danglars had that morning requested an interview with her\r\nfather, and had fixed on the gilded drawing-room as the spot. The\r\nsingularity of this step, and above all its formality, had not a little\r\nsurprised the banker, who had immediately obeyed his daughter by\r\nrepairing first to the drawing-room. \xc3\x89tienne soon returned from his\r\nerrand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle\xe2\x80\x99s lady\xe2\x80\x99s maid says, sir, that mademoiselle is finishing\r\nher toilette, and will be here shortly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars nodded, to signify that he was satisfied. To the world and to\r\nhis servants Danglars assumed the character of the good-natured man and\r\nthe indulgent father. This was one of his parts in the popular comedy\r\nhe was performing,\xe2\x80\x94a make-up he had adopted and which suited him about\r\nas well as the masks worn on the classic stage by paternal actors, who\r\nseen from one side, were the image of geniality, and from the other\r\nshowed lips drawn down in chronic ill-temper. Let us hasten to say that\r\nin private the genial side descended to the level of the other, so that\r\ngenerally the indulgent man disappeared to give place to the brutal\r\nhusband and domineering father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy the devil does that foolish girl, who pretends to wish to speak to\r\nme, not come into my study? and why on earth does she want to speak to\r\nme at all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was turning this thought over in his brain for the twentieth time,\r\nwhen the door opened and Eug\xc3\xa9nie appeared, attired in a figured black\r\nsatin dress, her hair dressed and gloves on, as if she were going to\r\nthe Italian Opera.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Eug\xc3\xa9nie, what is it you want with me? and why in this solemn\r\ndrawing-room when the study is so comfortable?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI quite understand why you ask, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eug\xc3\xa9nie, making a sign that\r\nher father might be seated, \xe2\x80\x9cand in fact your two questions suggest\r\nfully the theme of our conversation. I will answer them both, and\r\ncontrary to the usual method, the last first, because it is the least\r\ndifficult. I have chosen the drawing-room, sir, as our place of\r\nmeeting, in order to avoid the disagreeable impressions and influences\r\nof a banker\xe2\x80\x99s study. Those gilded cashbooks, drawers locked like gates\r\nof fortresses, heaps of bank-bills, come from I know not where, and the\r\nquantities of letters from England, Holland, Spain, India, China, and\r\nPeru, have generally a strange influence on a father\xe2\x80\x99s mind, and make\r\nhim forget that there is in the world an interest greater and more\r\nsacred than the good opinion of his correspondents. I have, therefore,\r\nchosen this drawing-room, where you see, smiling and happy in their\r\nmagnificent frames, your portrait, mine, my mother\xe2\x80\x99s, and all sorts of\r\nrural landscapes and touching pastorals. I rely much on external\r\nimpressions; perhaps, with regard to you, they are immaterial, but I\r\nshould be no artist if I had not some fancies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. Danglars, who had listened to all this preamble\r\nwith imperturbable coolness, but without understanding a word, since\r\nlike every man burdened with thoughts of the past, he was occupied with\r\nseeking the thread of his own ideas in those of the speaker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is, then, the second point cleared up, or nearly so,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie, without the least confusion, and with that masculine\r\npointedness which distinguished her gesture and her language; \xe2\x80\x9cand you\r\nappear satisfied with the explanation. Now, let us return to the first.\r\nYou ask me why I have requested this interview; I will tell you in two\r\nwords, sir; I will not marry count Andrea Cavalcanti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars leaped from his chair and raised his eyes and arms towards\r\nheaven.\r\n\r\n40298m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Eug\xc3\xa9nie, still quite calm; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are\r\nastonished, I see; for since this little affair began, I have not\r\nmanifested the slightest opposition, and yet I am always sure, when the\r\nopportunity arrives, to oppose a determined and absolute will to people\r\nwho have not consulted me, and things which displease me. However, this\r\ntime, my tranquillity, or passiveness as philosophers say, proceeded\r\nfrom another source; it proceeded from a wish, like a submissive and\r\ndevoted daughter\xe2\x80\x9d (a slight smile was observable on the purple lips of\r\nthe young girl), \xe2\x80\x9cto practice obedience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Eug\xc3\xa9nie, \xe2\x80\x9cI have tried to the very last and now\r\nthat the moment has come, I feel in spite of all my efforts that it is\r\nimpossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, whose weak mind was at first quite overwhelmed\r\nwith the weight of this pitiless logic, marking evident premeditation\r\nand force of will, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is your reason for this refusal, Eug\xc3\xa9nie? what\r\nreason do you assign?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy reason?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young girl. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, it is not that the man is\r\nmore ugly, more foolish, or more disagreeable than any other; no, M.\r\nAndrea Cavalcanti may appear to those who look at men\xe2\x80\x99s faces and\r\nfigures as a very good specimen of his kind. It is not, either, that my\r\nheart is less touched by him than any other; that would be a\r\nschoolgirl\xe2\x80\x99s reason, which I consider quite beneath me. I actually love\r\nno one, sir; you know it, do you not? I do not then see why, without\r\nreal necessity, I should encumber my life with a perpetual companion.\r\nHas not some sage said, \xe2\x80\x98Nothing too much\xe2\x80\x99? and another, \xe2\x80\x98I carry all\r\nmy effects with me\xe2\x80\x99? I have been taught these two aphorisms in Latin\r\nand in Greek; one is, I believe, from Ph\xc3\xa6drus, and the other from Bias.\r\nWell, my dear father, in the shipwreck of life\xe2\x80\x94for life is an eternal\r\nshipwreck of our hopes\xe2\x80\x94I cast into the sea my useless encumbrance, that\r\nis all, and I remain with my own will, disposed to live perfectly\r\nalone, and consequently perfectly free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnhappy girl, unhappy girl!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Danglars, turning pale, for he\r\nknew from long experience the solidity of the obstacle he had so\r\nsuddenly encountered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnhappy girl,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Eug\xc3\xa9nie, \xe2\x80\x9cunhappy girl, do you say, sir? No,\r\nindeed; the exclamation appears quite theatrical and affected. Happy,\r\non the contrary, for what am I in want of? The world calls me\r\nbeautiful. It is something to be well received. I like a favorable\r\nreception; it expands the countenance, and those around me do not then\r\nappear so ugly. I possess a share of wit, and a certain relative\r\nsensibility, which enables me to draw from life in general, for the\r\nsupport of mine, all I meet with that is good, like the monkey who\r\ncracks the nut to get at its contents. I am rich, for you have one of\r\nthe first fortunes in France. I am your only daughter, and you are not\r\nso exacting as the fathers of the Porte Saint-Martin and Ga\xc3\xaet\xc3\xa9, who\r\ndisinherit their daughters for not giving them grandchildren. Besides,\r\nthe provident law has deprived you of the power to disinherit me, at\r\nleast entirely, as it has also of the power to compel me to marry\r\nMonsieur This or Monsieur That. And so\xe2\x80\x94being, beautiful, witty,\r\nsomewhat talented, as the comic operas say, and rich\xe2\x80\x94and that is\r\nhappiness, sir\xe2\x80\x94why do you call me unhappy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars, seeing his daughter smiling, and proud even to insolence,\r\ncould not entirely repress his brutal feelings, but they betrayed\r\nthemselves only by an exclamation. Under the fixed and inquiring gaze\r\nlevelled at him from under those beautiful black eyebrows, he prudently\r\nturned away, and calmed himself immediately, daunted by the power of a\r\nresolute mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly, my daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are all you boast\r\nof being, excepting one thing; I will not too hastily tell you which,\r\nbut would rather leave you to guess it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie looked at Danglars, much surprised that one flower of her crown\r\nof pride, with which she had so superbly decked herself, should be\r\ndisputed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the banker, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have perfectly explained to\r\nme the sentiments which influence a girl like you, who is determined\r\nshe will not marry; now it remains for me to tell you the motives of a\r\nfather like me, who has decided that his daughter shall marry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie bowed, not as a submissive daughter, but as an adversary\r\nprepared for a discussion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen a father asks his daughter to\r\nchoose a husband, he has always some reason for wishing her to marry.\r\nSome are affected with the mania of which you spoke just now, that of\r\nliving again in their grandchildren. This is not my weakness, I tell\r\nyou at once; family joys have no charm for me. I may acknowledge this\r\nto a daughter whom I know to be philosophical enough to understand my\r\nindifference, and not to impute it to me as a crime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is not to the purpose,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eug\xc3\xa9nie; \xe2\x80\x9clet us speak candidly,\r\nsir; I admire candor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI can, when circumstances render it desirable,\r\nadopt your system, although it may not be my general practice. I will\r\ntherefore proceed. I have proposed to you to marry, not for your sake,\r\nfor indeed I did not think of you in the least at the moment (you\r\nadmire candor, and will now be satisfied, I hope); but because it\r\nsuited me to marry you as soon as possible, on account of certain\r\ncommercial speculations I am desirous of entering into.\xe2\x80\x9d Eug\xc3\xa9nie became\r\nuneasy.\r\n\r\n40302m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is just as I tell you, I assure you, and you must not be angry with\r\nme, for you have sought this disclosure. I do not willingly enter into\r\narithmetical explanations with an artist like you, who fears to enter\r\nmy study lest she should imbibe disagreeable or anti-poetic impressions\r\nand sensations. But in that same banker\xe2\x80\x99s study, where you very\r\nwillingly presented yourself yesterday to ask for the thousand francs I\r\ngive you monthly for pocket-money, you must know, my dear young lady,\r\nthat many things may be learned, useful even to a girl who will not\r\nmarry. There one may learn, for instance, what, out of regard to your\r\nnervous susceptibility, I will inform you of in the drawing-room,\r\nnamely, that the credit of a banker is his physical and moral life;\r\nthat credit sustains him as breath animates the body; and M. de Monte\r\nCristo once gave me a lecture on that subject, which I have never\r\nforgotten. There we may learn that as credit sinks, the body becomes a\r\ncorpse, and this is what must happen very soon to the banker who is\r\nproud to own so good a logician as you for his daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Eug\xc3\xa9nie, instead of stooping, drew herself up under the blow.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRuined?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly, my daughter; that is precisely what I mean,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars,\r\nalmost digging his nails into his breast, while he preserved on his\r\nharsh features the smile of the heartless though clever man;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cruined\xe2\x80\x94yes, that is it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eug\xc3\xa9nie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, ruined! Now it is revealed, this secret so full of horror, as the\r\ntragic poet says. Now, my daughter, learn from my lips how you may\r\nalleviate this misfortune, so far as it will affect you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Eug\xc3\xa9nie, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are a bad physiognomist, if you imagine I\r\ndeplore on my own account the catastrophe of which you warn me. I\r\nruined? and what will that signify to me? Have I not my talent left?\r\nCan I not, like Pasta, Malibran, Grisi, acquire for myself what you\r\nwould never have given me, whatever might have been your fortune, a\r\nhundred or a hundred and fifty thousand livres per annum, for which I\r\nshall be indebted to no one but myself; and which, instead of being\r\ngiven as you gave me those poor twelve thousand francs, with sour looks\r\nand reproaches for my prodigality, will be accompanied with\r\nacclamations, with bravos, and with flowers? And if I do not possess\r\nthat talent, which your smiles prove to me you doubt, should I not\r\nstill have that ardent love of independence, which will be a substitute\r\nfor wealth, and which in my mind supersedes even the instinct of\r\nself-preservation? No, I grieve not on my own account, I shall always\r\nfind a resource; my books, my pencils, my piano, all the things which\r\ncost but little, and which I shall be able to procure, will remain my\r\nown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think that I sorrow for Madame Danglars? Undeceive yourself\r\nagain; either I am greatly mistaken, or she has provided against the\r\ncatastrophe which threatens you, and, which will pass over without\r\naffecting her. She has taken care for herself,\xe2\x80\x94at least I hope so,\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nher attention has not been diverted from her projects by watching over\r\nme. She has fostered my independence by professedly indulging my love\r\nfor liberty. Oh, no, sir; from my childhood I have seen too much, and\r\nunderstood too much, of what has passed around me, for misfortune to\r\nhave an undue power over me. From my earliest recollections, I have\r\nbeen beloved by no one\xe2\x80\x94so much the worse; that has naturally led me to\r\nlove no one\xe2\x80\x94so much the better\xe2\x80\x94now you have my profession of faith.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, pale with anger, which was not at all due to\r\noffended paternal love,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthen, mademoiselle, you persist in your\r\ndetermination to accelerate my ruin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour ruin? I accelerate your ruin? What do you mean? I do not\r\nunderstand you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better, I have a ray of hope left; listen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am all attention,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eug\xc3\xa9nie, looking so earnestly at her father\r\nthat it was an effort for the latter to endure her unrelenting gaze.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. Cavalcanti,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cis about to marry you, and will\r\nplace in my hands his fortune, amounting to three million livres.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is admirable!\xe2\x80\x9d said Eug\xc3\xa9nie with sovereign contempt, smoothing\r\nher gloves out one upon the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think I shall deprive you of those three millions,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut do not fear it. They are destined to produce at least ten. I and a\r\nbrother banker have obtained a grant of a railway, the only industrial\r\nenterprise which in these days promises to make good the fabulous\r\nprospects that Law once held out to the eternally deluded Parisians, in\r\nthe fantastic Mississippi scheme. As I look at it, a millionth part of\r\na railway is worth fully as much as an acre of waste land on the banks\r\nof the Ohio. We make in our case a deposit, on a mortgage, which is an\r\nadvance, as you see, since we gain at least ten, fifteen, twenty, or a\r\nhundred livres\xe2\x80\x99 worth of iron in exchange for our money. Well, within a\r\nweek I am to deposit four millions for my share; the four millions, I\r\npromise you, will produce ten or twelve.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut during my visit to you the day before yesterday, sir, which you\r\nappear to recollect so well,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Eug\xc3\xa9nie, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw you arranging a\r\ndeposit\xe2\x80\x94is not that the term?\xe2\x80\x94of five millions and a half; you even\r\npointed it out to me in two drafts on the treasury, and you were\r\nastonished that so valuable a paper did not dazzle my eyes like\r\nlightning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but those five millions and a half are not mine, and are only a\r\nproof of the great confidence placed in me; my title of popular banker\r\nhas gained me the confidence of charitable institutions, and the five\r\nmillions and a half belong to them; at any other time I should not have\r\nhesitated to make use of them, but the great losses I have recently\r\nsustained are well known, and, as I told you, my credit is rather\r\nshaken. That deposit may be at any moment withdrawn, and if I had\r\nemployed it for another purpose, I should bring on me a disgraceful\r\nbankruptcy. I do not despise bankruptcies, believe me, but they must be\r\nthose which enrich, not those which ruin. Now, if you marry M.\r\nCavalcanti, and I get the three millions, or even if it is thought I am\r\ngoing to get them, my credit will be restored, and my fortune, which\r\nfor the last month or two has been swallowed up in gulfs which have\r\nbeen opened in my path by an inconceivable fatality, will revive. Do\r\nyou understand me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly; you pledge me for three millions, do you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe greater the amount, the more flattering it is to you; it gives you\r\nan idea of your value.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you. One word more, sir; do you promise me to make what use you\r\ncan of the report of the fortune M. Cavalcanti will bring without\r\ntouching the money? This is no act of selfishness, but of delicacy. I\r\nam willing to help rebuild your fortune, but I will not be an\r\naccomplice in the ruin of others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut since I tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthat with these three\r\nmillion\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you expect to recover your position, sir, without touching those\r\nthree million?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope so, if the marriage should take place and confirm my credit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall you be able to pay M. Cavalcanti the five hundred thousand\r\nfrancs you promise for my dowry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe shall receive them on returning from the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s20.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat next? what more do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish to know if, in demanding my signature, you leave me entirely\r\nfree in my person?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbsolutely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, as I said before, sir,\xe2\x80\x94very well; I am ready to marry M.\r\nCavalcanti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what are you up to?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that is my affair. What advantage should I have over you, if\r\nknowing your secret I were to tell you mine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars bit his lips. \xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are ready to pay the\r\nofficial visits, which are absolutely indispensable?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Eug\xc3\xa9nie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to sign the contract in three days?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, in my turn, I also say, very well!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars pressed his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s hand in his. But, extraordinary to\r\nrelate, the father did not say, \xe2\x80\x9cThank you, my child,\xe2\x80\x9d nor did the\r\ndaughter smile at her father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the conference ended?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Eug\xc3\xa9nie, rising.\r\n\r\nDanglars motioned that he had nothing more to say. Five minutes\r\nafterwards the piano resounded to the touch of Mademoiselle d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfingers, and Mademoiselle Danglars was singing Brabantio\xe2\x80\x99s malediction\r\non Desdemona. At the end of the piece \xc3\x89tienne entered, and announced to\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie that the horses were to the carriage, and that the baroness was\r\nwaiting for her to pay her visits. We have seen them at Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s;\r\nthey proceeded then on their course.\r\n\r\n40306m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVOLUME FIVE\r\n\r\n50009m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n50011m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n50019m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 96. The Contract\r\n\r\nThree days after the scene we have just described, namely towards five\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock in the afternoon of the day fixed for the signature of the\r\ncontract between Mademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie Danglars and Andrea Cavalcanti,\r\nwhom the banker persisted in calling prince, a fresh breeze was\r\nstirring the leaves in the little garden in front of the Count of Monte\r\nCristo\xe2\x80\x99s house, and the count was preparing to go out. While his horses\r\nwere impatiently pawing the ground, held in by the coachman, who had\r\nbeen seated a quarter of an hour on his box, the elegant phaeton with\r\nwhich we are familiar rapidly turned the angle of the entrance-gate,\r\nand cast out on the doorsteps M. Andrea Cavalcanti, as decked up and\r\ngay as if he were going to marry a princess.\r\n\r\nHe inquired after the count with his usual familiarity, and ascending\r\nlightly to the first story met him at the top of the stairs.\r\n\r\nThe count stopped on seeing the young man. As for Andrea, he was\r\nlaunched, and when he was once launched nothing stopped him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, good morning, my dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, M. Andrea,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, with his half-jesting tone; \xe2\x80\x9chow do\r\nyou do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCharmingly, as you see. I am come to talk to you about a thousand\r\nthings; but, first tell me, were you going out or just returned?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was going out, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, in order not to hinder you, I will get up with you if you please\r\nin your carriage, and Tom shall follow with my phaeton in tow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, with an imperceptible smile of contempt, for he\r\nhad no wish to be seen in the young man\xe2\x80\x99s society,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cno; I prefer\r\nlistening to you here, my dear M. Andrea; we can chat better in-doors,\r\nand there is no coachman to overhear our conversation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count returned to a small drawing-room on the first floor, sat\r\ndown, and crossing his legs motioned to the young man to take a seat\r\nalso. Andrea assumed his gayest manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know, my dear count,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe ceremony is to take place this\r\nevening. At nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock the contract is to be signed at my\r\nfather-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat; is it news to you? Has not M. Danglars informed you of the\r\nceremony?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cI received a letter from him yesterday, but\r\nI do not think the hour was mentioned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly my father-in-law trusted to its general notoriety.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are fortunate, M. Cavalcanti; it is a\r\nmost suitable alliance you are contracting, and Mademoiselle Danglars\r\nis a handsome girl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed she is,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cavalcanti, in a very modest tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbove all, she is very rich,\xe2\x80\x94at least, I believe so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte\r\nCristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery rich, do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless; it is said M. Danglars conceals at least half of his\r\nfortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he acknowledges fifteen or twenty millions,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea with a\r\nlook sparkling with joy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout reckoning,\xe2\x80\x9d added Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he is on the eve of\r\nentering into a sort of speculation already in vogue in the United\r\nStates and in England, but quite novel in France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, I know what you mean,\xe2\x80\x94the railway, of which he has obtained\r\nthe grant, is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely; it is generally believed he will gain ten millions by that\r\naffair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTen millions! Do you think so? It is magnificent!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cavalcanti,\r\nwho was quite confounded at the metallic sound of these golden words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout reckoning,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cthat all his fortune will\r\ncome to you, and justly too, since Mademoiselle Danglars is an only\r\ndaughter. Besides, your own fortune, as your father assured me, is\r\nalmost equal to that of your betrothed. But enough of money matters. Do\r\nyou know, M. Andrea, I think you have managed this affair rather\r\nskilfully?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot badly, by any means,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man; \xe2\x80\x9cI was born for a\r\ndiplomatist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you must become a diplomatist; diplomacy, you know, is something\r\nthat is not to be acquired; it is instinctive. Have you lost your\r\nheart?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, I fear it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Andrea, in the tone in which he had heard\r\nDorante or Val\xc3\xa8re reply to Alceste21 at the Th\xc3\xa9\xc3\xa2tre Fran\xc3\xa7ais.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs your love returned?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea with a triumphant smile, \xe2\x80\x9csince I am\r\naccepted. But I must not forget one grand point.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I have been singularly assisted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have, indeed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy circumstances?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; by you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy me? Not at all, prince,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo laying a marked stress\r\non the title, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat have I done for you? Are not your name, your social\r\nposition, and your merit sufficient?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cno; it is useless for you to say so, count. I\r\nmaintain that the position of a man like you has done more than my\r\nname, my social position, and my merit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are completely mistaken, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo coldly, who felt\r\nthe perfidious man\xc5\x93uvre of the young man, and understood the bearing of\r\nhis words; \xe2\x80\x9cyou only acquired my protection after the influence and\r\nfortune of your father had been ascertained; for, after all, who\r\nprocured for me, who had never seen either you or your illustrious\r\nfather, the pleasure of your acquaintance?\xe2\x80\x94two of my good friends, Lord\r\nWilmore and the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni. What encouraged me not to become your\r\nsurety, but to patronize you?\xe2\x80\x94your father\xe2\x80\x99s name, so well known in\r\nItaly and so highly honored. Personally, I do not know you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis calm tone and perfect ease made Andrea feel that he was, for the\r\nmoment, restrained by a more muscular hand than his own, and that the\r\nrestraint could not be easily broken through.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, then my father has really a very large fortune, count?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears so, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know if the marriage settlement he promised me has come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been advised of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the three millions?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe three millions are probably on the road.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I shall really have them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not think you have yet known the want\r\nof money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea was so surprised that he pondered the matter for a moment. Then,\r\narousing from his reverie:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, sir, I have one request to make to you, which you will\r\nunderstand, even if it should be disagreeable to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProceed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have formed an acquaintance, thanks to my good fortune, with many\r\nnoted persons, and have, at least for the moment, a crowd of friends.\r\nBut marrying, as I am about to do, before all Paris, I ought to be\r\nsupported by an illustrious name, and in the absence of the paternal\r\nhand some powerful one ought to lead me to the altar; now, my father is\r\nnot coming to Paris, is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is old, covered with wounds, and suffers dreadfully, he says, in\r\ntravelling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand; well, I am come to ask a favor of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd pray what may it be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, to take his part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear sir! What?\xe2\x80\x94after the varied relations I have had the\r\nhappiness to sustain towards you, can it be that you know me so little\r\nas to ask such a thing? Ask me to lend you half a million and, although\r\nsuch a loan is somewhat rare, on my honor, you would annoy me less!\r\nKnow, then, what I thought I had already told you, that in\r\nparticipation in this world\xe2\x80\x99s affairs, more especially in their moral\r\naspects, the Count of Monte Cristo has never ceased to entertain the\r\nscruples and even the superstitions of the East. I, who have a seraglio\r\nat Cairo, one at Smyrna, and one at Constantinople, preside at a\r\nwedding?\xe2\x80\x94never!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you refuse me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDecidedly; and were you my son or my brother I would refuse you in the\r\nsame way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what must be done?\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, disappointed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said just now that you had a hundred friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery true, but you introduced me at M. Danglars\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all! Let us recall the exact facts. You met him at a dinner\r\nparty at my house, and you introduced yourself at his house; that is a\r\ntotally different affair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but, by my marriage, you have forwarded that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x94not in the least, I beg you to believe. Recollect what I told you\r\nwhen you asked me to propose you. \xe2\x80\x98Oh, I never make matches, my dear\r\nprince, it is my settled principle.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Andrea bit his lips.\r\n\r\n50025m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, at least, you will be there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill all Paris be there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, certainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, like all Paris, I shall be there too,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd will you sign the contract?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see no objection to that; my scruples do not go thus far.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, since you will grant me no more, I must be content with what you\r\ngive me. But one word more, count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdvice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe careful; advice is worse than a service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you can give me this without compromising yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me what it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs my wife\xe2\x80\x99s fortune five hundred thousand livres?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the sum M. Danglars himself announced.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMust I receive it, or leave it in the hands of the notary?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the way such affairs are generally arranged when it is wished\r\nto do them stylishly: Your two solicitors appoint a meeting, when the\r\ncontract is signed, for the next or the following day; then they\r\nexchange the two portions, for which they each give a receipt; then,\r\nwhen the marriage is celebrated, they place the amount at your disposal\r\nas the chief member of the alliance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, with a certain ill-concealed uneasiness, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nthought I heard my father-in-law say that he intended embarking our\r\nproperty in that famous railway affair of which you spoke just now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cit will be the way, everybody says, of\r\ntrebling your fortune in twelve months. Baron Danglars is a good\r\nfather, and knows how to calculate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9ceverything is all right, excepting your\r\nrefusal, which quite grieves me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must attribute it only to natural scruples under similar\r\ncircumstances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, \xe2\x80\x9clet it be as you wish. This evening, then, at\r\nnine o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu till then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNotwithstanding a slight resistance on the part of Monte Cristo, whose\r\nlips turned pale, but who preserved his ceremonious smile, Andrea\r\nseized the count\xe2\x80\x99s hand, pressed it, jumped into his phaeton, and\r\ndisappeared.\r\n\r\nThe four or five remaining hours before nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock arrived, Andrea\r\nemployed in riding, paying visits,\xe2\x80\x94designed to induce those of whom he\r\nhad spoken to appear at the banker\xe2\x80\x99s in their gayest\r\nequipages,\xe2\x80\x94dazzling them by promises of shares in schemes which have\r\nsince turned every brain, and in which Danglars was just taking the\r\ninitiative.\r\n\r\nIn fact, at half-past eight in the evening the grand salon, the gallery\r\nadjoining, and the three other drawing-rooms on the same floor, were\r\nfilled with a perfumed crowd, who sympathized but little in the event,\r\nbut who all participated in that love of being present wherever there\r\nis anything fresh to be seen. An Academician would say that the\r\nentertainments of the fashionable world are collections of flowers\r\nwhich attract inconstant butterflies, famished bees, and buzzing\r\ndrones.\r\n\r\n50025m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNo one could deny that the rooms were splendidly illuminated; the light\r\nstreamed forth on the gilt mouldings and the silk hangings; and all the\r\nbad taste of decorations, which had only their richness to boast of,\r\nshone in its splendor. Mademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie was dressed with elegant\r\nsimplicity in a figured white silk dress, and a white rose half\r\nconcealed in her jet black hair was her only ornament, unaccompanied by\r\na single jewel. Her eyes, however, betrayed that perfect confidence\r\nwhich contradicted the girlish simplicity of this modest attire.\r\n\r\nMadame Danglars was chatting at a short distance with Debray,\r\nBeauchamp, and Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. Debray was admitted to the house for\r\nthis grand ceremony, but on the same plane with everyone else, and\r\nwithout any particular privilege. M. Danglars, surrounded by deputies\r\nand men connected with the revenue, was explaining a new theory of\r\ntaxation which he intended to adopt when the course of events had\r\ncompelled the government to call him into the ministry. Andrea, on\r\nwhose arm hung one of the most consummate dandies of the Opera, was\r\nexplaining to him rather cleverly, since he was obliged to be bold to\r\nappear at ease, his future projects, and the new luxuries he meant to\r\nintroduce to Parisian fashions with his hundred and seventy-five\r\nthousand livres per annum.\r\n\r\nThe crowd moved to and fro in the rooms like an ebb and flow of\r\nturquoises, rubies, emeralds, opals, and diamonds. As usual, the oldest\r\nwomen were the most decorated, and the ugliest the most conspicuous. If\r\nthere was a beautiful lily, or a sweet rose, you had to search for it,\r\nconcealed in some corner behind a mother with a turban, or an aunt with\r\na bird-of-paradise.\r\n\r\nAt each moment, in the midst of the crowd, the buzzing, and the\r\nlaughter, the door-keeper\xe2\x80\x99s voice was heard announcing some name well\r\nknown in the financial department, respected in the army, or\r\nillustrious in the literary world, and which was acknowledged by a\r\nslight movement in the different groups. But for one whose privilege it\r\nwas to agitate that ocean of human waves, how many were received with a\r\nlook of indifference or a sneer of disdain!\r\n\r\nAt the moment when the hand of the massive time-piece, representing\r\nEndymion asleep, pointed to nine on its golden face, and the hammer,\r\nthe faithful type of mechanical thought, struck nine times, the name of\r\nthe Count of Monte Cristo resounded in its turn, and as if by an\r\nelectric shock all the assembly turned towards the door. The count was\r\ndressed in black and with his habitual simplicity; his white waistcoat\r\ndisplayed his expansive noble chest and his black stock was singularly\r\nnoticeable because of its contrast with the deadly paleness of his\r\nface. His only jewellery was a chain, so fine that the slender gold\r\nthread was scarcely perceptible on his white waistcoat.\r\n\r\nA circle was immediately formed around the door. The count perceived at\r\none glance Madame Danglars at one end of the drawing-room, M. Danglars\r\nat the other, and Eug\xc3\xa9nie in front of him. He first advanced towards\r\nthe baroness, who was chatting with Madame de Villefort, who had come\r\nalone, Valentine being still an invalid; and without turning aside, so\r\nclear was the road left for him, he passed from the baroness to\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie, whom he complimented in such rapid and measured terms, that\r\nthe proud artist was quite struck. Near her was Mademoiselle Louise\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99Armilly, who thanked the count for the letters of introduction he had\r\nso kindly given her for Italy, which she intended immediately to make\r\nuse of. On leaving these ladies he found himself with Danglars, who had\r\nadvanced to meet him.\r\n\r\nHaving accomplished these three social duties, Monte Cristo stopped,\r\nlooking around him with that expression peculiar to a certain class,\r\nwhich seems to say, \xe2\x80\x9cI have done my duty, now let others do theirs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea, who was in an adjoining room, had shared in the sensation\r\ncaused by the arrival of Monte Cristo, and now came forward to pay his\r\nrespects to the count. He found him completely surrounded; all were\r\neager to speak to him, as is always the case with those whose words are\r\nfew and weighty. The solicitors arrived at this moment and arranged\r\ntheir scrawled papers on the velvet cloth embroidered with gold which\r\ncovered the table prepared for the signature; it was a gilt table\r\nsupported on lions\xe2\x80\x99 claws. One of the notaries sat down, the other\r\nremained standing. They were about to proceed to the reading of the\r\ncontract, which half Paris assembled was to sign. All took their\r\nplaces, or rather the ladies formed a circle, while the gentlemen (more\r\nindifferent to the restraints of what Boileau calls the _style\r\n\xc3\xa9nergique_) commented on the feverish agitation of Andrea, on M.\r\nDanglars\xe2\x80\x99 riveted attention, Eug\xc3\xa9nie\xe2\x80\x99s composure, and the light and\r\nsprightly manner in which the baroness treated this important affair.\r\n\r\nThe contract was read during a profound silence. But as soon as it was\r\nfinished, the buzz was redoubled through all the drawing-rooms; the\r\nbrilliant sums, the rolling millions which were to be at the command of\r\nthe two young people, and which crowned the display of the wedding\r\npresents and the young lady\xe2\x80\x99s diamonds, which had been made in a room\r\nentirely appropriated for that purpose, had exercised to the full their\r\ndelusions over the envious assembly.\r\n\r\nMademoiselle Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 charms were heightened in the opinion of the\r\nyoung men, and for the moment seemed to outvie the sun in splendor. As\r\nfor the ladies, it is needless to say that while they coveted the\r\nmillions, they thought they did not need them for themselves, as they\r\nwere beautiful enough without them. Andrea, surrounded by his friends,\r\ncomplimented, flattered, beginning to believe in the reality of his\r\ndream, was almost bewildered. The notary solemnly took the pen,\r\nflourished it above his head, and said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, we are about to sign the contract.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe baron was to sign first, then the representative of M. Cavalcanti,\r\nsenior, then the baroness, afterwards the \xe2\x80\x9cfuture couple,\xe2\x80\x9d as they are\r\nstyled in the abominable phraseology of legal documents.\r\n\r\nThe baron took the pen and signed, then the representative. The\r\nbaroness approached, leaning on Madame de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, as she took the pen, \xe2\x80\x9cis it not vexatious? An\r\nunexpected incident, in the affair of murder and theft at the Count of\r\nMonte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s, in which he nearly fell a victim, deprives us of the\r\npleasure of seeing M. de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said M. Danglars, in the same tone in which he would have\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cOh, well, what do I care?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs a matter of fact,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, approaching, \xe2\x80\x9cI am much\r\nafraid that I am the involuntary cause of his absence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, you, count?\xe2\x80\x9d said Madame Danglars, signing; \xe2\x80\x9cif you are, take\r\ncare, for I shall never forgive you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea pricked up his ears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it is not my fault, as I shall endeavor to prove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEveryone listened eagerly; Monte Cristo who so rarely opened his lips,\r\nwas about to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou remember,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, during the most profound silence, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nthe unhappy wretch who came to rob me died at my house; the supposition\r\nis that he was stabbed by his accomplice, on attempting to leave it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn order that his wounds might be examined he was undressed, and his\r\nclothes were thrown into a corner, where the police picked them up,\r\nwith the exception of the waistcoat, which they overlooked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea turned pale, and drew towards the door; he saw a cloud rising in\r\nthe horizon, which appeared to forebode a coming storm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, this waistcoat was discovered today, covered with blood, and\r\nwith a hole over the heart.\xe2\x80\x9d The ladies screamed, and two or three\r\nprepared to faint. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was brought to me. No one could guess what the\r\ndirty rag could be; I alone suspected that it was the waistcoat of the\r\nmurdered man. My valet, in examining this mournful relic, felt a paper\r\nin the pocket and drew it out; it was a letter addressed to you,\r\nbaron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo me?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed, to you; I succeeded in deciphering your name under the\r\nblood with which the letter was stained,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, amid\r\nthe general outburst of amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Madame Danglars, looking at her husband with uneasiness,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chow could that prevent M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn this simple way, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cthe waistcoat and\r\nthe letter were both what is termed circumstantial evidence; I\r\ntherefore sent them to the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney. You understand, my dear\r\nbaron, that legal methods are the safest in criminal cases; it was,\r\nperhaps, some plot against you.\xe2\x80\x9d Andrea looked steadily at Monte Cristo\r\nand disappeared in the second drawing-room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cwas not this murdered man an old\r\ngalley-slave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50025m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count; \xe2\x80\x9ca felon named Caderousse.\xe2\x80\x9d Danglars turned\r\nslightly pale; Andrea reached the anteroom beyond the little\r\ndrawing-room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut go on signing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI perceive that my story has\r\ncaused a general emotion, and I beg to apologize to you, baroness, and\r\nto Mademoiselle Danglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe baroness, who had signed, returned the pen to the notary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrince Cavalcanti,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter; \xe2\x80\x9cPrince Cavalcanti, where are\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAndrea, Andrea,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated several young people, who were already on\r\nsufficiently intimate terms with him to call him by his Christian name.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCall the prince; inform him that it is his turn to sign,\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nDanglars to one of the floorkeepers.\r\n\r\nBut at the same instant the crowd of guests rushed in alarm into the\r\nprincipal salon as if some frightful monster had entered the\r\napartments, _qu\xc3\xa6rens quem devoret_. There was, indeed, reason to\r\nretreat, to be alarmed, and to scream. An officer was placing two\r\nsoldiers at the door of each drawing-room, and was advancing towards\r\nDanglars, preceded by a commissary of police, girded with his scarf.\r\nMadame Danglars uttered a scream and fainted. Danglars, who thought\r\nhimself threatened (certain consciences are never calm),\xe2\x80\x94Danglars even\r\nbefore his guests showed a countenance of abject terror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo, advancing to meet the\r\ncommissioner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich of you gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the magistrate, without replying to the\r\ncount, \xe2\x80\x9canswers to the name of Andrea Cavalcanti?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA cry of astonishment was heard from all parts of the room. They\r\nsearched; they questioned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who then is Andrea Cavalcanti?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Danglars in amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA galley-slave, escaped from confinement at Toulon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what crime has he committed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is accused,\xe2\x80\x9d said the commissary with his inflexible voice, \xe2\x80\x9cof\r\nhaving assassinated the man named Caderousse, his former companion in\r\nprison, at the moment he was making his escape from the house of the\r\nCount of Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo cast a rapid glance around him. Andrea was gone.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 97. The Departure for Belgium\r\n\r\nA few minutes after the scene of confusion produced in the salons of M.\r\nDanglars by the unexpected appearance of the brigade of soldiers, and\r\nby the disclosure which had followed, the mansion was deserted with as\r\nmuch rapidity as if a case of plague or of cholera morbus had broken\r\nout among the guests.\r\n\r\nIn a few minutes, through all the doors, down all the staircases, by\r\nevery exit, everyone hastened to retire, or rather to fly; for it was a\r\nsituation where the ordinary condolences,\xe2\x80\x94which even the best friends\r\nare so eager to offer in great catastrophes,\xe2\x80\x94were seen to be utterly\r\nfutile. There remained in the banker\xe2\x80\x99s house only Danglars, closeted in\r\nhis study, and making his statement to the officer of gendarmes; Madame\r\nDanglars, terrified, in the boudoir with which we are acquainted; and\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie, who with haughty air and disdainful lip had retired to her\r\nroom with her inseparable companion, Mademoiselle Louise d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly.\r\n\r\nAs for the numerous servants (more numerous that evening than usual,\r\nfor their number was augmented by cooks and butlers from the Caf\xc3\xa9 de\r\nParis), venting on their employers their anger at what they termed the\r\ninsult to which they had been subjected, they collected in groups in\r\nthe hall, in the kitchens, or in their rooms, thinking very little of\r\ntheir duty, which was thus naturally interrupted. Of all this\r\nhousehold, only two persons deserve our notice; these are Mademoiselle\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie Danglars and Mademoiselle Louise d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly.\r\n\r\nThe betrothed had retired, as we said, with haughty air, disdainful\r\nlip, and the demeanor of an outraged queen, followed by her companion,\r\nwho was paler and more disturbed than herself. On reaching her room\r\nEug\xc3\xa9nie locked her door, while Louise fell on a chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, what a dreadful thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young musician; \xe2\x80\x9cwho would have\r\nsuspected it? M. Andrea Cavalcanti a murderer\xe2\x80\x94a galley-slave escaped\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nconvict!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn ironical smile curled the lip of Eug\xc3\xa9nie. \xe2\x80\x9cIn truth, I was fated,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid she. \xe2\x80\x9cI escaped the Morcerf only to fall into the Cavalcanti.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do not confound the two, Eug\xc3\xa9nie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue! The men are all infamous, and I am happy to be able\r\nnow to do more than detest them\xe2\x80\x94I despise them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall we do?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Louise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall we do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, the same we had intended doing three days since\xe2\x80\x94set off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x94although you are not now going to be married, you intend\r\nstill\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, Louise. I hate this life of the fashionable world, always\r\nordered, measured, ruled, like our music-paper. What I have always\r\nwished for, desired, and coveted, is the life of an artist, free and\r\nindependent, relying only on my own resources, and accountable only to\r\nmyself. Remain here? What for?\xe2\x80\x94that they may try, a month hence, to\r\nmarry me again; and to whom?\xe2\x80\x94M. Debray, perhaps, as it was once\r\nproposed. No, Louise, no! This evening\xe2\x80\x99s adventure will serve for my\r\nexcuse. I did not seek one, I did not ask for one. God sends me this,\r\nand I hail it joyfully!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow strong and courageous you are!\xe2\x80\x9d said the fair, frail girl to her\r\nbrunette companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you not yet know me? Come, Louise, let us talk of our affairs. The\r\npost-chaise\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas happily bought three days since.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you had it sent where we are to go for it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur passport?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Eug\xc3\xa9nie, with her usual precision, opened a printed paper, and\r\nread:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. L\xc3\xa9on d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly, twenty years of age; profession, artist; hair\r\nblack, eyes black; travelling with his sister.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapital! How did you get this passport?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I went to ask M. de Monte Cristo for letters to the directors of\r\nthe theatres at Rome and Naples, I expressed my fears of travelling as\r\na woman; he perfectly understood them, and undertook to procure for me\r\na man\xe2\x80\x99s passport, and two days after I received this, to which I have\r\nadded with my own hand, \xe2\x80\x98travelling with his sister.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50035m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eug\xc3\xa9nie cheerfully, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have then only to pack up our\r\ntrunks; we shall start the evening of the signing of the contract,\r\ninstead of the evening of the wedding\xe2\x80\x94that is all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut consider the matter seriously, Eug\xc3\xa9nie!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I am done with considering! I am tired of hearing only of market\r\nreports, of the end of the month, of the rise and fall of Spanish\r\nfunds, of Haitian bonds. Instead of that, Louise\xe2\x80\x94do you\r\nunderstand?\xe2\x80\x94air, liberty, melody of birds, plains of Lombardy, Venetian\r\ncanals, Roman palaces, the Bay of Naples. How much have we, Louise?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young girl to whom this question was addressed drew from an inlaid\r\nsecretaire a small portfolio with a lock, in which she counted\r\ntwenty-three bank-notes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty-three thousand francs,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd as much, at least, in pearls, diamonds, and jewels,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eug\xc3\xa9nie.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are rich. With forty-five thousand francs we can live like\r\nprincesses for two years, and comfortably for four; but before six\r\nmonths\xe2\x80\x94you with your music, and I with my voice\xe2\x80\x94we shall double our\r\ncapital. Come, you shall take charge of the money, I of the jewel-box;\r\nso that if one of us had the misfortune to lose her treasure, the other\r\nwould still have hers left. Now, the portmanteau\xe2\x80\x94let us make haste\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nportmanteau!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop!\xe2\x80\x9d said Louise, going to listen at Madame Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you fear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat we may be discovered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe door is locked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey may tell us to open it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey may if they like, but we will not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a perfect Amazon, Eug\xc3\xa9nie!\xe2\x80\x9d And the two young girls began to\r\nheap into a trunk all the things they thought they should require.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eug\xc3\xa9nie, \xe2\x80\x9cwhile I change my costume do you lock the\r\nportmanteau.\xe2\x80\x9d Louise pressed with all the strength of her little hands\r\non the top of the portmanteau.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I cannot,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cI am not strong enough; do you shut it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you do well to ask,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eug\xc3\xa9nie, laughing; \xe2\x80\x9cI forgot that I was\r\nHercules, and you only the pale Omphale!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the young girl, kneeling on the top, pressed the two parts of the\r\nportmanteau together, and Mademoiselle d\xe2\x80\x99Armilly passed the bolt of the\r\npadlock through. When this was done, Eug\xc3\xa9nie opened a drawer, of which\r\nshe kept the key, and took from it a wadded violet silk travelling\r\ncloak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cyou see I have thought of everything; with this\r\ncloak you will not be cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I am never cold, you know! Besides, with these men\xe2\x80\x99s clothes\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you dress here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall you have time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not be uneasy, you little coward! All our servants are busy,\r\ndiscussing the grand affair. Besides, what is there astonishing, when\r\nyou think of the grief I ought to be in, that I shut myself up?\xe2\x80\x94tell\r\nme!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, truly\xe2\x80\x94you comfort me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome and help me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom the same drawer she took a man\xe2\x80\x99s complete costume, from the boots\r\nto the coat, and a provision of linen, where there was nothing\r\nsuperfluous, but every requisite. Then, with a promptitude which\r\nindicated that this was not the first time she had amused herself by\r\nadopting the garb of the opposite sex, Eug\xc3\xa9nie drew on the boots and\r\npantaloons, tied her cravat, buttoned her waistcoat up to the throat,\r\nand put on a coat which admirably fitted her beautiful figure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that is very good\xe2\x80\x94indeed, it is very good!\xe2\x80\x9d said Louise, looking\r\nat her with admiration; \xe2\x80\x9cbut that beautiful black hair, those\r\nmagnificent braids, which made all the ladies sigh with envy,\xe2\x80\x94will they\r\ngo under a man\xe2\x80\x99s hat like the one I see down there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Eug\xc3\xa9nie.
