During this short time Valentine must have held her breath, or\r\nmoved in some slight degree, for the woman, disturbed, stopped and\r\nleaned over the bed, in order the better to ascertain whether Valentine\r\nslept: it was Madame de Villefort.\r\n\r\nOn recognizing her step-mother, Valentine could not repress a shudder,\r\nwhich caused a vibration in the bed. Madame de Villefort instantly\r\nstepped back close to the wall, and there, shaded by the bed-curtains,\r\nshe silently and attentively watched the slightest movement of\r\nValentine. The latter recollected the terrible caution of Monte Cristo;\r\nshe fancied that the hand not holding the phial clasped a long sharp\r\nknife. Then collecting all her remaining strength, she forced herself\r\nto close her eyes; but this simple operation upon the most delicate\r\norgans of our frame, generally so easy to accomplish, became almost\r\nimpossible at this moment, so much did curiosity struggle to retain the\r\neyelid open and learn the truth. Madame de Villefort, however,\r\nreassured by the silence, which was alone disturbed by the regular\r\nbreathing of Valentine, again extended her hand, and half hidden by the\r\ncurtains succeeded in emptying the contents of the phial into the\r\nglass. Then she retired so gently that Valentine did not know she had\r\nleft the room. She only witnessed the withdrawal of the arm\xe2\x80\x94the fair\r\nround arm of a woman but twenty-five years old, and who yet spread\r\ndeath around her.\r\n\r\n50077m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIt is impossible to describe the sensations experienced by Valentine\r\nduring the minute and a half Madame de Villefort remained in the room.\r\n\r\nThe grating against the library-door aroused the young girl from the\r\nstupor in which she was plunged, and which almost amounted to\r\ninsensibility. She raised her head with an effort. The noiseless door\r\nagain turned on its hinges, and the Count of Monte Cristo reappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you still doubt?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the young girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you seen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you recognize?\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine groaned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes;\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw, but I cannot believe!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you rather die, then, and cause Maximilian\xe2\x80\x99s death?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the young girl, almost bewildered, \xe2\x80\x9ccan I not leave the\r\nhouse?\xe2\x80\x94can I not escape?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine, the hand which now threatens you will pursue you\r\neverywhere; your servants will be seduced with gold, and death will be\r\noffered to you disguised in every shape. You will find it in the water\r\nyou drink from the spring, in the fruit you pluck from the tree.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut did you not say that my kind grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s precaution had\r\nneutralized the poison?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but not against a strong dose; the poison will be changed, and\r\nthe quantity increased.\xe2\x80\x9d He took the glass and raised it to his lips.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is already done,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cbrucine is no longer employed, but a\r\nsimple narcotic! I can recognize the flavor of the alcohol in which it\r\nhas been dissolved. If you had taken what Madame de Villefort has\r\npoured into your glass, Valentine\xe2\x80\x94Valentine\xe2\x80\x94you would have been\r\ndoomed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the young girl, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy am I thus pursued?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x94are you so kind\xe2\x80\x94so good\xe2\x80\x94so unsuspicious of ill, that you cannot\r\nunderstand, Valentine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I have never injured her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you are rich, Valentine; you have 200,000 livres a year, and you\r\nprevent her son from enjoying these 200,000 livres.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so? The fortune is not her gift, but is inherited from my\r\nrelations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; and that is why M. and Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran have died;\r\nthat is why M. Noirtier was sentenced the day he made you his heir;\r\nthat is why you, in your turn, are to die\xe2\x80\x94it is because your father\r\nwould inherit your property, and your brother, his only son, succeed to\r\nhis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdward? Poor child! Are all these crimes committed on his account?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, then you at length understand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeaven grant that this may not be visited upon him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine, you are an angel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why is my grandfather allowed to live?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was considered, that you dead, the fortune would naturally revert\r\nto your brother, unless he were disinherited; and besides, the crime\r\nappearing useless, it would be folly to commit it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is it possible that this frightful combination of crimes has been\r\ninvented by a woman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you recollect in the arbor of the H\xc3\xb4tel des Postes, at Perugia,\r\nseeing a man in a brown cloak, whom your stepmother was questioning\r\nupon _aqua tofana_? Well, ever since then, the infernal project has\r\nbeen ripening in her brain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, then, indeed, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the sweet girl, bathed in tears, \xe2\x80\x9cI see\r\nthat I am condemned to die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Valentine, for I have foreseen all their plots; no, your enemy is\r\nconquered since we know her, and you will live, Valentine\xe2\x80\x94live to be\r\nhappy yourself, and to confer happiness upon a noble heart; but to\r\ninsure this you must rely on me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCommand me, sir\xe2\x80\x94what am I to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must blindly take what I give you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, were it only for my own sake, I should prefer to die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must not confide in anyone\xe2\x80\x94not even in your father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father is not engaged in this fearful plot, is he, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nValentine, clasping her hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; and yet your father, a man accustomed to judicial accusations,\r\nought to have known that all these deaths have not happened naturally;\r\nit is he who should have watched over you\xe2\x80\x94he should have occupied my\r\nplace\xe2\x80\x94he should have emptied that glass\xe2\x80\x94he should have risen against\r\nthe assassin. Spectre against spectre!\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured in a low voice, as\r\nhe concluded his sentence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cI will do all I can to live, for there are two\r\nbeings who love me and will die if I die\xe2\x80\x94my grandfather and\r\nMaximilian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will watch over them as I have over you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir, do as you will with me;\xe2\x80\x9d and then she added, in a low\r\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x9coh, heavens, what will befall me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhatever may happen, Valentine, do not be alarmed; though you suffer;\r\nthough you lose sight, hearing, consciousness, fear nothing; though you\r\nshould awake and be ignorant where you are, still do not fear; even\r\nthough you should find yourself in a sepulchral vault or coffin.\r\nReassure yourself, then, and say to yourself: \xe2\x80\x98At this moment, a\r\nfriend, a father, who lives for my happiness and that of Maximilian,\r\nwatches over me!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, alas, what a fearful extremity!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine, would you rather denounce your stepmother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather die a hundred times\xe2\x80\x94oh, yes, die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you will not die; but will you promise me, whatever happens, that\r\nyou will not complain, but hope?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will think of Maximilian!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are my own darling child, Valentine! I alone can save you, and I\r\nwill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine in the extremity of her terror joined her hands,\xe2\x80\x94for she felt\r\nthat the moment had arrived to ask for courage,\xe2\x80\x94and began to pray, and\r\nwhile uttering little more than incoherent words, she forgot that her\r\nwhite shoulders had no other covering than her long hair, and that the\r\npulsations of her heart could be seen through the lace of her\r\nnightdress. Monte Cristo gently laid his hand on the young girl\xe2\x80\x99s arm,\r\ndrew the velvet coverlet close to her throat, and said with a paternal\r\nsmile:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy child, believe in my devotion to you as you believe in the goodness\r\nof Providence and the love of Maximilian.\xe2\x80\x9d Valentine gave him a look\r\nfull of gratitude, and remained as docile as a child.\r\n\r\nThen he drew from his waistcoat-pocket the little emerald box, raised\r\nthe golden lid, and took from it a pastille about the size of a pea,\r\nwhich he placed in her hand. She took it, and looked attentively on the\r\ncount; there was an expression on the face of her intrepid protector\r\nwhich commanded her veneration. She evidently interrogated him by her\r\nlook.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\nValentine carried the pastille to her mouth, and swallowed it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, my dear child, adieu for the present. I will try and gain a\r\nlittle sleep, for you are saved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9cwhatever happens, I promise you not to fear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo for some time kept his eyes fixed on the young girl, who\r\ngradually fell asleep, yielding to the effects of the narcotic the\r\ncount had given her. Then he took the glass, emptied three parts of the\r\ncontents in the fireplace, that it might be supposed Valentine had\r\ntaken it, and replaced it on the table; then he disappeared, after\r\nthrowing a farewell glance on Valentine, who slept with the confidence\r\nand innocence of an angel at the feet of the Lord.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 102. Valentine\r\n\r\nThe night-light continued to burn on the chimney-piece, exhausting the\r\nlast drops of oil which floated on the surface of the water. The globe\r\nof the lamp appeared of a reddish hue, and the flame, brightening\r\nbefore it expired, threw out the last flickerings which in an inanimate\r\nobject have been so often compared with the convulsions of a human\r\ncreature in its final agonies. A dull and dismal light was shed over\r\nthe bedclothes and curtains surrounding the young girl. All noise in\r\nthe streets had ceased, and the silence was frightful.\r\n\r\nIt was then that the door of Edward\xe2\x80\x99s room opened, and a head we have\r\nbefore noticed appeared in the glass opposite; it was Madame de\r\nVillefort, who came to witness the effects of the drink she had\r\nprepared. She stopped in the doorway, listened for a moment to the\r\nflickering of the lamp, the only sound in that deserted room, and then\r\nadvanced to the table to see if Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s glass were empty. It was\r\nstill about a quarter full, as we before stated. Madame de Villefort\r\nemptied the contents into the ashes, which she disturbed that they\r\nmight the more readily absorb the liquid; then she carefully rinsed the\r\nglass, and wiping it with her handkerchief replaced it on the table.\r\n\r\nIf anyone could have looked into the room just then he would have\r\nnoticed the hesitation with which Madame de Villefort approached the\r\nbed and looked fixedly on Valentine. The dim light, the profound\r\nsilence, and the gloomy thoughts inspired by the hour, and still more\r\nby her own conscience, all combined to produce a sensation of fear; the\r\npoisoner was terrified at the contemplation of her own work.\r\n\r\nAt length she rallied, drew aside the curtain, and leaning over the\r\npillow gazed intently on Valentine. The young girl no longer breathed,\r\nno breath issued through the half-closed teeth; the white lips no\r\nlonger quivered\xe2\x80\x94the eyes were suffused with a bluish vapor, and the\r\nlong black lashes rested on a cheek white as wax. Madame de Villefort\r\ngazed upon the face so expressive even in its stillness; then she\r\nventured to raise the coverlet and press her hand upon the young girl\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nheart. It was cold and motionless. She only felt the pulsation in her\r\nown fingers, and withdrew her hand with a shudder. One arm was hanging\r\nout of the bed; from shoulder to elbow it was moulded after the arms of\r\nGermain Pillon\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cGraces,\xe2\x80\x9d23 but the fore-arm seemed to be slightly\r\ndistorted by convulsion, and the hand, so delicately formed, was\r\nresting with stiff outstretched fingers on the framework of the bed.\r\nThe nails, too, were turning blue.\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort had no longer any doubt; all was over\xe2\x80\x94she had\r\nconsummated the last terrible work she had to accomplish. There was no\r\nmore to do in the room, so the poisoner retired stealthily, as though\r\nfearing to hear the sound of her own footsteps; but as she withdrew she\r\nstill held aside the curtain, absorbed in the irresistible attraction\r\nalways exerted by the picture of death, so long as it is merely\r\nmysterious and does not excite disgust.\r\n\r\nThe minutes passed; Madame de Villefort could not drop the curtain\r\nwhich she held like a funeral pall over the head of Valentine. She was\r\nlost in reverie, and the reverie of crime is remorse.\r\n\r\nJust then the lamp again flickered; the noise startled Madame de\r\nVillefort, who shuddered and dropped the curtain. Immediately\r\nafterwards the light expired, and the room was plunged in frightful\r\nobscurity, while the clock at that minute struck half-past four.\r\n\r\nOverpowered with agitation, the poisoner succeeded in groping her way\r\nto the door, and reached her room in an agony of fear. The darkness\r\nlasted two hours longer; then by degrees a cold light crept through the\r\nVenetian blinds, until at length it revealed the objects in the room.\r\n\r\nAbout this time the nurse\xe2\x80\x99s cough was heard on the stairs and the woman\r\nentered the room with a cup in her hand. To the tender eye of a father\r\nor a lover, the first glance would have sufficed to reveal Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncondition; but to this hireling, Valentine only appeared to sleep.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, approaching the table, \xe2\x80\x9cshe has taken part of\r\nher draught; the glass is three-quarters empty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen she went to the fireplace and lit the fire, and although she had\r\njust left her bed, she could not resist the temptation offered by\r\nValentine\xe2\x80\x99s sleep, so she threw herself into an armchair to snatch a\r\nlittle more rest. The clock striking eight awoke her. Astonished at the\r\nprolonged slumber of the patient, and frightened to see that the arm\r\nwas still hanging out of the bed, she advanced towards Valentine, and\r\nfor the first time noticed the white lips. She tried to replace the\r\narm, but it moved with a frightful rigidity which could not deceive a\r\nsick-nurse. She screamed aloud; then running to the door exclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp, help!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50083m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d asked M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, at the foot of the stairs, it\r\nbeing the hour he usually visited her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Villefort, rushing from his room. \xe2\x80\x9cDoctor, do you\r\nhear them call for help?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes; let us hasten up; it was in Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut before the doctor and the father could reach the room, the servants\r\nwho were on the same floor had entered, and seeing Valentine pale and\r\nmotionless on her bed, they lifted up their hands towards heaven and\r\nstood transfixed, as though struck by lightening.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCall Madame de Villefort!\xe2\x80\x94Wake Madame de Villefort!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the\r\nprocureur from the door of his chamber, which apparently he scarcely\r\ndared to leave. But instead of obeying him, the servants stood watching\r\nM. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, who ran to Valentine, and raised her in his arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x94this one, too?\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, where will be the end?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort rushed into the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you saying, doctor?\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, raising his hands to\r\nheaven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say that Valentine is dead!\xe2\x80\x9d replied d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, in a voice terrible\r\nin its solemn calmness.\r\n\r\n50085m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort staggered and buried his head in the bed. On the\r\nexclamation of the doctor and the cry of the father, the servants all\r\nfled with muttered imprecations; they were heard running down the\r\nstairs and through the long passages, then there was a rush in the\r\ncourt, afterwards all was still; they had, one and all, deserted the\r\naccursed house.\r\n\r\nJust then, Madame de Villefort, in the act of slipping on her\r\ndressing-gown, threw aside the drapery and for a moment stood\r\nmotionless, as though interrogating the occupants of the room, while\r\nshe endeavored to call up some rebellious tears. On a sudden she\r\nstepped, or rather bounded, with outstretched arms, towards the table.\r\nShe saw d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny curiously examining the glass, which she felt certain\r\nof having emptied during the night. It was now a third full, just as it\r\nwas when she threw the contents into the ashes. The spectre of\r\nValentine rising before the poisoner would have alarmed her less. It\r\nwas, indeed, the same color as the draught she had poured into the\r\nglass, and which Valentine had drunk; it was indeed the poison, which\r\ncould not deceive M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, which he now examined so closely; it\r\nwas doubtless a miracle from heaven, that, notwithstanding her\r\nprecautions, there should be some trace, some proof remaining to reveal\r\nthe crime.\r\n\r\nWhile Madame de Villefort remained rooted to the spot like a statue of\r\nterror, and Villefort, with his head hidden in the bedclothes, saw\r\nnothing around him, d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny approached the window, that he might the\r\nbetter examine the contents of the glass, and dipping the tip of his\r\nfinger in, tasted it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cit is no longer brucine that is used; let me see\r\nwhat it is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he ran to one of the cupboards in Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s room, which had been\r\ntransformed into a medicine closet, and taking from its silver case a\r\nsmall bottle of nitric acid, dropped a little of it into the liquor,\r\nwhich immediately changed to a blood-red color.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, in a voice in which the horror of a judge\r\nunveiling the truth was mingled with the delight of a student making a\r\ndiscovery.\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort was overpowered; her eyes first flashed and then\r\nswam, she staggered towards the door and disappeared. Directly\r\nafterwards the distant sound of a heavy weight falling on the ground\r\nwas heard, but no one paid any attention to it; the nurse was engaged\r\nin watching the chemical analysis, and Villefort was still absorbed in\r\ngrief. M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny alone had followed Madame de Villefort with his\r\neyes, and watched her hurried retreat. He lifted up the drapery over\r\nthe entrance to Edward\xe2\x80\x99s room, and his eye reaching as far as Madame de\r\nVillefort\xe2\x80\x99s apartment, he beheld her extended lifeless on the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to the assistance of Madame de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the nurse.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame de Villefort is ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50087m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Mademoiselle de Villefort\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d stammered the nurse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle de Villefort no longer requires help,\xe2\x80\x9d said d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csince she is dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead,\xe2\x80\x94dead!\xe2\x80\x9d groaned forth Villefort, in a paroxysm of grief, which\r\nwas the more terrible from the novelty of the sensation in the iron\r\nheart of that man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated a third voice. \xe2\x80\x9cWho said Valentine was dead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two men turned round, and saw Morrel standing at the door, pale and\r\nterror-stricken. This is what had happened. At the usual time, Morrel\r\nhad presented himself at the little door leading to Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s room.\r\nContrary to custom, the door was open, and having no occasion to ring\r\nhe entered. He waited for a moment in the hall and called for a servant\r\nto conduct him to M. Noirtier; but no one answered, the servants\r\nhaving, as we know, deserted the house. Morrel had no particular reason\r\nfor uneasiness; Monte Cristo had promised him that Valentine should\r\nlive, and so far he had always fulfilled his word. Every night the\r\ncount had given him news, which was the next morning confirmed by\r\nNoirtier. Still this extraordinary silence appeared strange to him, and\r\nhe called a second and third time; still no answer. Then he determined\r\nto go up. Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s room was opened, like all the rest. The first\r\nthing he saw was the old man sitting in his armchair in his usual\r\nplace, but his eyes expressed alarm, which was confirmed by the pallor\r\nwhich overspread his features.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel, with a sickness of heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the old man, by closing his eyes; but his appearance\r\nmanifested increasing uneasiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are thoughtful, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cyou want something; shall\r\nI call one of the servants?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Noirtier.\r\n\r\nMorrel pulled the bell, but though he nearly broke the cord no one\r\nanswered. He turned towards Noirtier; the pallor and anguish expressed\r\non his countenance momentarily increased.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy do they not come? Is anyone ill in the\r\nhouse?\xe2\x80\x9d The eyes of Noirtier seemed as though they would start from\r\ntheir sockets. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter? You alarm me. Valentine?\r\nValentine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d signed Noirtier.\r\n\r\nMaximilian tried to speak, but he could articulate nothing; he\r\nstaggered, and supported himself against the wainscot. Then he pointed\r\nto the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d continued the old man.\r\n\r\n50089m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMaximilian rushed up the little staircase, while Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s eyes seemed\r\nto say,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cQuicker, quicker!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn a minute the young man darted through several rooms, till at length\r\nhe reached Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\nThere was no occasion to push the door, it was wide open. A sob was the\r\nonly sound he heard. He saw as though in a mist, a black figure\r\nkneeling and buried in a confused mass of white drapery. A terrible\r\nfear transfixed him. It was then he heard a voice exclaim \xe2\x80\x9cValentine is\r\ndead!\xe2\x80\x9d and another voice which, like an echo repeated:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead,\xe2\x80\x94dead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50090m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 103. Maximilian\r\n\r\nVillefort rose, half-ashamed of being surprised in such a paroxysm of\r\ngrief. The terrible office he had held for twenty-five years had\r\nsucceeded in making him more or less than man. His glance, at first\r\nwandering, fixed itself upon Morrel. \xe2\x80\x9cWho are you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d he asked,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat forget that this is not the manner to enter a house stricken with\r\ndeath? Go, sir, go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Morrel remained motionless; he could not detach his eyes from that\r\ndisordered bed, and the pale corpse of the young girl who was lying on\r\nit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo!\xe2\x80\x94do you hear?\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, while d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny advanced to lead\r\nMorrel out. Maximilian stared for a moment at the corpse, gazed all\r\naround the room, then upon the two men; he opened his mouth to speak,\r\nbut finding it impossible to give utterance to the innumerable ideas\r\nthat occupied his brain, he went out, thrusting his hands through his\r\nhair in such a manner that Villefort and d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, for a moment\r\ndiverted from the engrossing topic, exchanged glances, which seemed to\r\nsay,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHe is mad!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut in less than five minutes the staircase groaned beneath an\r\nextraordinary weight. Morrel was seen carrying, with superhuman\r\nstrength, the armchair containing Noirtier upstairs. When he reached\r\nthe landing he placed the armchair on the floor and rapidly rolled it\r\ninto Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s room. This could only have been accomplished by means\r\nof unnatural strength supplied by powerful excitement. But the most\r\nfearful spectacle was Noirtier being pushed towards the bed, his face\r\nexpressing all his meaning, and his eyes supplying the want of every\r\nother faculty. That pale face and flaming glance appeared to Villefort\r\nlike a frightful apparition. Each time he had been brought into contact\r\nwith his father, something terrible had happened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee what they have done!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morrel, with one hand leaning on the\r\nback of the chair, and the other extended towards Valentine. \xe2\x80\x9cSee, my\r\nfather, see!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort drew back and looked with astonishment on the young man, who,\r\nalmost a stranger to him, called Noirtier his father. At this moment\r\nthe whole soul of the old man seemed centred in his eyes which became\r\nbloodshot; the veins of the throat swelled; his cheeks and temples\r\nbecame purple, as though he was struck with epilepsy; nothing was\r\nwanting to complete this but the utterance of a cry. And the cry issued\r\nfrom his pores, if we may thus speak\xe2\x80\x94a cry frightful in its silence.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny rushed towards the old man and made him inhale a powerful\r\nrestorative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Morrel, seizing the moist hand of the paralytic, \xe2\x80\x9cthey ask\r\nme who I am, and what right I have to be here. Oh, you know it, tell\r\nthem, tell them!\xe2\x80\x9d And the young man\xe2\x80\x99s voice was choked by sobs.\r\n\r\nAs for the old man, his chest heaved with his panting respiration. One\r\ncould have thought that he was undergoing the agonies preceding death.\r\nAt length, happier than the young man, who sobbed without weeping,\r\ntears glistened in the eyes of Noirtier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel in a hoarse voice, \xe2\x80\x9ctell them that I am her\r\nbetrothed. Tell them\xe2\x80\x94oh, tell them, that corpse belongs to\r\nme!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young man overwhelmed by the weight of his anguish, fell heavily on\r\nhis knees before the bed, which his fingers grasped with convulsive\r\nenergy. D\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, unable to bear the sight of this touching emotion,\r\nturned away; and Villefort, without seeking any further explanation,\r\nand attracted towards him by the irresistible magnetism which draws us\r\ntowards those who have loved the people for whom we mourn, extended his\r\nhand towards the young man.\r\n\r\nBut Morrel saw nothing; he had grasped the hand of Valentine, and\r\nunable to weep vented his agony in groans as he bit the sheets. For\r\nsome time nothing was heard in that chamber but sobs, exclamations, and\r\nprayers. At length Villefort, the most composed of all, spoke:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cyou say you loved Valentine, that you\r\nwere betrothed to her. I knew nothing of this engagement, of this love,\r\nyet I, her father, forgive you, for I see that your grief is real and\r\ndeep; and besides my own sorrow is too great for anger to find a place\r\nin my heart. But you see that the angel whom you hoped for has left\r\nthis earth\xe2\x80\x94she has nothing more to do with the adoration of men. Take a\r\nlast farewell, sir, of her sad remains; take the hand you expected to\r\npossess once more within your own, and then separate yourself from her\r\nforever. Valentine now requires only the ministrations of the priest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50093m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Morrel, raising himself on one knee,\r\nhis heart pierced by a more acute pang than any he had yet felt\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nare mistaken; Valentine, dying as she has, not only requires a priest,\r\nbut an avenger. _You_, M. de Villefort, send for the priest; _I_ will\r\nbe the avenger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Villefort, trembling at the new idea\r\ninspired by the delirium of Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you, sir, that two persons exist in you; the father has mourned\r\nsufficiently, now let the procureur fulfil his office.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe eyes of Noirtier glistened, and d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny approached.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, reading all that passed through the minds of\r\nthe witnesses to the scene, \xe2\x80\x9cI know what I am saying, and you know as\r\nwell as I do what I am about to say\xe2\x80\x94Valentine has been assassinated!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort hung his head, d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny approached nearer, and Noirtier said\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x9d with his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cin these days no one can disappear by\r\nviolent means without some inquiries being made as to the cause of her\r\ndisappearance, even were she not a young, beautiful, and adorable\r\ncreature like Valentine. I tell you\r\nthat the dose has been double, the poison changed, and that this time\r\nit has succeeded. M. de Villefort\r\nwas therefore obliged to request M. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny to superintend all the\r\narrangements consequent upon a death in a large city, more especially a\r\ndeath under such suspicious circumstances.\r\n\r\nIt was something terrible to witness the silent agony, the mute despair\r\nof Noirtier, whose tears silently rolled down his cheeks. Come and watch by the dead, and all the\r\nwretched family will be grateful to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going, sir; and I do not hesitate to say that no prayers will be\r\nmore fervent than mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny took the priest\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and without meeting Villefort, who\r\nwas engaged in his study, they reached Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s room, which on the\r\nfollowing night was to be occupied by the undertakers. On entering the\r\nroom, Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s eyes met those of the abb\xc3\xa9, and no doubt he read some\r\nparticular expression in them, for he remained in the room. D\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny\r\nrecommended the attention of the priest to the living as well as to the\r\ndead, and the abb\xc3\xa9 promised to devote his prayers to Valentine and his\r\nattentions to Noirtier.\r\n\r\nIn order, doubtless, that he might not be disturbed while fulfilling\r\nhis sacred mission, the priest rose as soon as d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny departed, and\r\nnot only bolted the door through which the doctor had just left, but\r\nalso that leading to Madame de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s room.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 104. Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 Signature\r\n\r\nThe next morning dawned dull and cloudy. During the night the\r\nundertakers had executed their melancholy office, and wrapped the\r\ncorpse in the winding-sheet, which, whatever may be said about the\r\nequality of death, is at least a last proof of the luxury so pleasing\r\nin life. This winding-sheet was nothing more than a beautiful piece of\r\ncambric, which the young girl had bought a fortnight before.\r\n\r\nDuring the evening two men, engaged for the purpose, had carried\r\nNoirtier from Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s room into his own, and contrary to all\r\nexpectation there was no difficulty in withdrawing him from his child.\r\nThe Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni had watched till daylight, and then left without\r\ncalling anyone. D\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny returned about eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning;\r\nhe met Villefort on his way to Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s room, and accompanied him to\r\nsee how the old man had slept. They found him in the large armchair,\r\nwhich served him for a bed, enjoying a calm, nay, almost a smiling\r\nsleep. They both stood in amazement at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee,\xe2\x80\x9d said d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny to Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cnature knows how to alleviate the\r\ndeepest sorrow. No one can say that M. Noirtier did not love his child,\r\nand yet he sleeps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you are right,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Villefort, surprised; \xe2\x80\x9che sleeps, indeed!\r\nAnd this is the more strange, since the least contradiction keeps him\r\nawake all night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrief has stunned him,\xe2\x80\x9d replied d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny; and they both returned\r\nthoughtfully to the procureur\xe2\x80\x99s study.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee, I have not slept,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, showing his undisturbed bed;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgrief does not stun me. I have not been in bed for two nights; but\r\nthen look at my desk; see what I have written during these two days and\r\nnights. I have filled those papers, and have made out the accusation\r\nagainst the assassin Benedetto. Oh, work, work,\xe2\x80\x94my passion, my joy, my\r\ndelight,\xe2\x80\x94it is for thee to alleviate my sorrows!\xe2\x80\x9d and he convulsively\r\ngrasped the hand of d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you require my services now?\xe2\x80\x9d asked d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9conly return again at eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock; at twelve\r\nthe\xe2\x80\x94the\xe2\x80\x94oh, Heavens, my poor, poor child!\xe2\x80\x9d and the procureur again\r\nbecoming a man, lifted up his eyes and groaned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall you be present in the reception-room?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I have a cousin who has undertaken this sad office. I shall work,\r\ndoctor\xe2\x80\x94when I work I forget everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, indeed, no sooner had the doctor left the room, than he was again\r\nabsorbed in work. On the doorsteps d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny met the cousin whom\r\nVillefort had mentioned, a personage as insignificant in our story as\r\nin the world he occupied\xe2\x80\x94one of those beings designed from their birth\r\nto make themselves useful to others. He was punctual, dressed in black,\r\nwith crape around his hat, and presented himself at his cousin\xe2\x80\x99s with a\r\nface made up for the occasion, and which he could alter as might be\r\nrequired.\r\n\r\nAt eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock the mourning-coaches rolled into the paved court, and\r\nthe Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honor\xc3\xa9 was filled with a crowd of idlers,\r\nequally pleased to witness the festivities or the mourning of the rich,\r\nand who rush with the same avidity to a funeral procession as to the\r\nmarriage of a duchess.\r\n\r\nGradually the reception-room filled, and some of our old friends made\r\ntheir appearance\xe2\x80\x94we mean Debray, Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, and Beauchamp,\r\naccompanied by all the leading men of the day at the bar, in\r\nliterature, or the army, for M. de Villefort moved in the first\r\nParisian circles, less owing to his social position than to his\r\npersonal merit.\r\n\r\nThe cousin standing at the door ushered in the guests, and it was\r\nrather a relief to the indifferent to see a person as unmoved as\r\nthemselves, and who did not exact a mournful face or force tears, as\r\nwould have been the case with a father, a brother, or a lover. Those\r\nwho were acquainted soon formed into little groups. One of them was\r\nmade of Debray, Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, and Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor girl,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, like the rest, paying an involuntary tribute\r\nto the sad event,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cpoor girl, so young, so rich, so beautiful! Could\r\nyou have imagined this scene, Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, when we saw her, at the\r\nmost three weeks ago, about to sign that contract?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you know her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI spoke to her once or twice at Madame de Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s, among the rest;\r\nshe appeared to me charming, though rather melancholy. Where is her\r\nstepmother? Do you know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is spending the day with the wife of the worthy gentleman who is\r\nreceiving us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50105m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe gentleman who receives us? Is he a deputy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no. I am condemned to witness those gentlemen every day,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nBeauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9cbut he is perfectly unknown to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you mentioned this death in your paper?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt has been mentioned, but the article is not mine; indeed, I doubt if\r\nit will please M. Villefort, for it says that if four successive deaths\r\nhad happened anywhere else than in the house of the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney, he\r\nwould have interested himself somewhat more about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cDr. d\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny, who attends my mother,\r\ndeclares he is in despair about it. But whom are you seeking, Debray?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am seeking the Count of Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI met him on the boulevard, on my way here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp. \xe2\x80\x9cI think\r\nhe is about to leave Paris; he was going to his banker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis banker? Danglars is his banker, is he not?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud\r\nof Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the secretary with slight uneasiness. \xe2\x80\x9cBut\r\nMonte Cristo is not the only one I miss here; I do not see Morrel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMorrel? Do they know him?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. \xe2\x80\x9cI think he has only\r\nbeen introduced to Madame de Villefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill, he ought to have been here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray; \xe2\x80\x9cI wonder what will\r\nbe talked about tonight; this funeral is the news of the day. But hush,\r\nhere comes our minister of justice; he will feel obliged to make some\r\nlittle speech to the cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d and the three young men drew near to\r\nlisten.\r\n\r\nBeauchamp told the truth when he said that on his way to the funeral he\r\nhad met Monte Cristo, who was directing his steps towards the Rue de la\r\nChauss\xc3\xa9e d\xe2\x80\x99Antin, to M. Danglars\xe2\x80\x99. The banker saw the carriage of the\r\ncount enter the courtyard, and advanced to meet him with a sad, though\r\naffable smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, extending his hand to Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you\r\nhave come to sympathize with me, for indeed misfortune has taken\r\npossession of my house. When I perceived you, I was just asking myself\r\nwhether I had not wished harm towards those poor Morcerfs, which would\r\nhave justified the proverb of \xe2\x80\x98He who wishes misfortunes to happen to\r\nothers experiences them himself.\xe2\x80\x99 Well, on my word of honor, I\r\nanswered, \xe2\x80\x98No!\xe2\x80\x99 I wished no ill to Morcerf; he was a little proud,\r\nperhaps, for a man who like myself has risen from nothing; but we all\r\nhave our faults. Do you know, count, that persons of our time of\r\nlife\xe2\x80\x94not that you belong to the class, you are still a young man,\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nas I was saying, persons of our time of life have been very unfortunate\r\nthis year. For example, look at the puritanical procureur, who has just\r\nlost his daughter, and in fact nearly all his family, in so singular a\r\nmanner; Morcerf dishonored and dead; and then myself covered with\r\nridicule through the villany of Benedetto; besides\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides what?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, do you not know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat new calamity?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy daughter\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEug\xc3\xa9nie has left us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood heavens, what are you telling me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe truth, my dear count. Oh, how happy you must be in not having\r\neither wife or children!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so Mademoiselle Danglars\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe could not endure the insult offered to us by that wretch, so she\r\nasked permission to travel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is she gone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe other night she left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith Madame Danglars?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, with a relation. But still, we have quite lost our dear Eug\xc3\xa9nie;\r\nfor I doubt whether her pride will ever allow her to return to France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill, baron,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cfamily griefs, or indeed any other\r\naffliction which would crush a man whose child was his only treasure,\r\nare endurable to a millionaire. Philosophers may well say, and\r\npractical men will always support the opinion, that money mitigates\r\nmany trials; and if you admit the efficacy of this sovereign balm, you\r\nought to be very easily consoled\xe2\x80\x94you, the king of finance, the focus of\r\nimmeasurable power.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars looked at him askance, as though to ascertain whether he spoke\r\nseriously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, \xe2\x80\x9cif a fortune brings consolation, I ought to be\r\nconsoled; I am rich.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo rich, dear sir, that your fortune resembles the pyramids; if you\r\nwished to demolish them you could not, and if it were possible, you\r\nwould not dare!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars smiled at the good-natured pleasantry of the count. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\r\nreminds me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat when you entered I was on the point of\r\nsigning five little bonds; I have already signed two: will you allow me\r\nto do the same to the others?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a moment\xe2\x80\x99s silence, during which the noise of the banker\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npen was alone heard, while Monte Cristo examined the gilt mouldings on\r\nthe ceiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre they Spanish, Haitian, or Neapolitan bonds?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cthey are bonds on the bank of France,\r\npayable to bearer. Stay, count,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cyou, who may be called the\r\nemperor, if I claim the title of king of finance, have you many pieces\r\nof paper of this size, each worth a million?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count took into his hands the papers, which Danglars had so proudly\r\npresented to him, and read:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98To the Governor of the Bank. Please pay to my order, from the fund\r\ndeposited by me, the sum of a million, and charge the same to my\r\naccount.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBaron Danglars.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne, two, three, four, five,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cfive millions\xe2\x80\x94why\r\nwhat a Cr\xc5\x93sus you are!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is how I transact business,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is really wonderful,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cabove all, if, as I suppose,\r\nit is payable at sight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, indeed, said Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a fine thing to have such credit; really, it is only in France\r\nthese things are done. Five millions on five little scraps of paper!\xe2\x80\x94it\r\nmust be seen to be believed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not doubt it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say so with an accent\xe2\x80\x94stay, you shall be convinced; take my clerk\r\nto the bank, and you will see him leave it with an order on the\r\nTreasury for the same sum.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo folding the five notes, \xe2\x80\x9cmost decidedly not;\r\nthe thing is so curious, I will make the experiment myself. I am\r\ncredited on you for six millions. I have drawn nine hundred thousand\r\nfrancs, you therefore still owe me five millions and a hundred thousand\r\nfrancs. I will take the five scraps of paper that I now hold as bonds,\r\nwith your signature alone, and here is a receipt in full for the six\r\nmillions between us. I had prepared it beforehand, for I am much in\r\nwant of money today.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Monte Cristo placed the bonds in his pocket with one hand, while\r\nwith the other he held out the receipt to Danglars. If a thunderbolt\r\nhad fallen at the banker\xe2\x80\x99s feet, he could not have experienced greater\r\nterror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat,\xe2\x80\x9d he stammered, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you mean to keep that money? Excuse me,\r\nexcuse me, but I owe this money to the charity fund,\xe2\x80\x94a deposit which I\r\npromised to pay this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, well, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not particular about these\r\nfive notes, pay me in a different form; I wished, from curiosity, to\r\ntake these, that I might be able to say that without any advice or\r\npreparation the house of Danglars had paid me five millions without a\r\nminute\xe2\x80\x99s delay; it would have been remarkable. But here are your bonds;\r\npay me differently;\xe2\x80\x9d and he held the bonds towards Danglars, who seized\r\nthem like a vulture extending its claws to withhold the food that is\r\nbeing wrested from its grasp.\r\n\r\nSuddenly he rallied, made a violent effort to restrain himself, and\r\nthen a smile gradually widened the features of his disturbed\r\ncountenance.\r\n\r\n50109m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyour receipt is money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh dear, yes; and if you were at Rome, the house of Thomson & French\r\nwould make no more difficulty about paying the money on my receipt than\r\nyou have just done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, count, pardon me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I may keep this money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, while the perspiration started from the roots of\r\nhis hair. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, keep it\xe2\x80\x94keep it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo replaced the notes in his pocket with that indescribable\r\nexpression which seemed to say, \xe2\x80\x9cCome, reflect; if you repent there is\r\nstill time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cno, decidedly no; keep my signatures. But you\r\nknow none are so formal as bankers in transacting business; I intended\r\nthis money for the charity fund, and I seemed to be robbing them if I\r\ndid not pay them with these precise bonds. How absurd\xe2\x80\x94as if one crown\r\nwere not as good as another. Excuse me;\xe2\x80\x9d and he began to laugh loudly,\r\nbut nervously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, I excuse you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo graciously, \xe2\x80\x9cand pocket\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d And he placed the bonds in his pocket-book.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is still a sum of one hundred thousand\r\nfrancs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, a mere nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cThe balance would come to\r\nabout that sum; but keep it, and we shall be quits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9care you speaking seriously?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never joke with bankers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo in a freezing manner,\r\nwhich repelled impertinence; and he turned to the door, just as the\r\nvalet de chambre announced:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. de Boville, Receiver-General of the charities.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cI think I arrived just in time to\r\nobtain your signatures, or they would have been disputed with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars again became pale, and hastened to conduct the count out.\r\nMonte Cristo exchanged a ceremonious bow with M. de Boville, who was\r\nstanding in the waiting-room, and who was introduced into Danglars\xe2\x80\x99\r\nroom as soon as the count had left.\r\n\r\nThe count\xe2\x80\x99s serious face was illumined by a faint smile, as he noticed\r\nthe portfolio which the receiver-general held in his hand. At the door\r\nhe found his carriage, and was immediately driven to the bank.\r\nMeanwhile Danglars, repressing all emotion, advanced to meet the\r\nreceiver-general. We need not say that a smile of condescension was\r\nstamped upon his lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-morning, creditor,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I wager anything it is the\r\ncreditor who visits me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, baron,\xe2\x80\x9d answered M. de Boville; \xe2\x80\x9cthe charities present\r\nthemselves to you through me; the widows and orphans depute me to\r\nreceive alms to the amount of five millions from you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet they say orphans are to be pitied,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, wishing to\r\nprolong the jest. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor things!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere I am in their name,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Boville; \xe2\x80\x9cbut did you receive my\r\nletter yesterday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have brought my receipt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50111m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear M. de Boville, your widows and orphans must oblige me by\r\nwaiting twenty-four hours, since M. de Monte Cristo whom you just saw\r\nleaving here\xe2\x80\x94you did see him, I think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; well?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, M. de Monte Cristo has just carried off their five millions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count has an unlimited credit upon me; a credit opened by Thomson\r\n& French, of Rome; he came to demand five millions at once, which I\r\npaid him with checks on the bank. My funds are deposited there, and you\r\ncan understand that if I draw out ten millions on the same day it will\r\nappear rather strange to the governor. Two days will be a different\r\nthing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Boville, with a tone of entire incredulity, \xe2\x80\x9cfive millions\r\nto that gentleman who just left, and who bowed to me as though he knew\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps he knows you, though you do not know him; M. de Monte Cristo\r\nknows everybody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive millions!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is his receipt. Believe your own eyes.\xe2\x80\x9d M. de Boville took the\r\npaper Danglars presented him, and read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReceived of Baron Danglars the sum of five million one hundred\r\nthousand francs, to be repaid on demand by the house of Thomson &\r\nFrench of Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is really true,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Boville.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know the house of Thomson & French?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I once had business to transact with it to the amount of 200,000\r\nfrancs; but since then I have not heard it mentioned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is one of the best houses in Europe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, carelessly\r\nthrowing down the receipt on his desk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he had five millions in your hands alone! Why, this Count of Monte\r\nCristo must be a nabob?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed I do not know what he is; he has three unlimited credits\xe2\x80\x94one on\r\nme, one on Rothschild, one on Lafitte; and, you see,\xe2\x80\x9d he added\r\ncarelessly, \xe2\x80\x9che has given me the preference, by leaving a balance of\r\n100,000 francs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Boville manifested signs of extraordinary admiration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must visit him,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand obtain some pious grant from him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you may make sure of him; his charities alone amount to 20,000\r\nfrancs a month.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is magnificent! I will set before him the example of Madame de\r\nMorcerf and her son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat example?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey gave all their fortune to the hospitals.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat fortune?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTheir own\xe2\x80\x94M. de Morcerf\xe2\x80\x99s, who is deceased.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor what reason?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause they would not spend money so guiltily acquired.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what are they to live upon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe mother retires into the country, and the son enters the army.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50113m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I must confess, these are scruples.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI registered their deed of gift yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how much did they possess?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, not much\xe2\x80\x94from twelve to thirteen hundred thousand francs. But to\r\nreturn to our millions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, in the most natural tone in the world. \xe2\x80\x9cAre\r\nyou then pressed for this money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; for the examination of our cash takes place tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow? Why did you not tell me so before? Why, it is as good as a\r\ncentury! At what hour does the examination take place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt two o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSend at twelve,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, smiling.\r\n\r\nM. de Boville said nothing, but nodded his head, and took up the\r\nportfolio.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I think of it, you can do better,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe receipt of M. de Monte Cristo is as good as money; take it to\r\nRothschild\xe2\x80\x99s or Lafitte\xe2\x80\x99s, and they will take it off your hands at\r\nonce.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, though payable at Rome?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; it will only cost you a discount of 5,000 or 6,000 francs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe receiver started back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi!_\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI prefer waiting till tomorrow. What a\r\nproposition!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars with supreme impertinence, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nyou had a deficiency to make up?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said the receiver.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if that were the case it would be worth while to make some\r\nsacrifice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, no, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it will be tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but without fail.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you are laughing at me; send tomorrow at twelve, and the bank\r\nshall be notified.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will come myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter still, since it will afford me the pleasure of seeing you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThey shook hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the way,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Boville, \xe2\x80\x9care you not going to the funeral of\r\npoor Mademoiselle de Villefort, which I met on my road here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said the banker; \xe2\x80\x9cI have appeared rather ridiculous since that\r\naffair of Benedetto, so I remain in the background.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah, you are wrong. How were you to blame in that affair?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen\xe2\x80\x94when one bears an irreproachable name, as I do, one is rather\r\nsensitive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverybody pities you, sir; and, above all, Mademoiselle Danglars!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Eug\xc3\xa9nie!\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars; \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know she is going to embrace a\r\nreligious life?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, it is unhappily but too true. The day after the event, she\r\ndecided on leaving Paris with a nun of her acquaintance; they are gone\r\nto seek a very strict convent in Italy or Spain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is terrible!\xe2\x80\x9d and M. de Boville retired with this exclamation,\r\nafter expressing acute sympathy with the father. But he had scarcely\r\nleft before Danglars, with an energy of action those can alone\r\nunderstand who have seen Robert Macaire represented by Fr\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa9rick,24\r\nexclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFool!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen enclosing Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s receipt in a little pocket-book, he\r\nadded:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYes, come at twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock; I shall then be far away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he double-locked his door, emptied all his drawers, collected\r\nabout fifty thousand francs in bank-notes, burned several papers, left\r\nothers exposed to view, and then commenced writing a letter which he\r\naddressed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Madame la Baronne Danglars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will place it on her table myself tonight,\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured. Then taking\r\na passport from his drawer he said,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGood, it is available for two\r\nmonths longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 105. The Cemetery of P\xc3\xa8re-Lachaise\r\n\r\nM. de Boville had indeed met the funeral procession which was taking\r\nValentine to her last home on earth. The weather was dull and stormy, a\r\ncold wind shook the few remaining yellow leaves from the boughs of the\r\ntrees, and scattered them among the crowd which filled the boulevards.\r\nM. de Villefort, a true Parisian, considered the cemetery of\r\nP\xc3\xa8re-Lachaise alone worthy of receiving the mortal remains of a\r\nParisian family; there alone the corpses belonging to him would be\r\nsurrounded by worthy associates. He had therefore purchased a vault,\r\nwhich was quickly occupied by members of his family. On the front of\r\nthe monument was inscribed: \xe2\x80\x9cThe families of Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran and\r\nVillefort,\xe2\x80\x9d for such had been the last wish expressed by poor Ren\xc3\xa9e,\r\nValentine\xe2\x80\x99s mother. The pompous procession therefore wended its way\r\ntowards P\xc3\xa8re-Lachaise from the Faubourg Saint-Honor\xc3\xa9. Having crossed\r\nParis, it passed through the Faubourg du Temple, then leaving the\r\nexterior boulevards, it reached the cemetery. More than fifty private\r\ncarriages followed the twenty mourning-coaches, and behind them more\r\nthan five hundred persons joined in the procession on foot.\r\n\r\n50117m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThese last consisted of all the young people whom Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s death had\r\nstruck like a thunderbolt, and who, notwithstanding the raw chilliness\r\nof the season, could not refrain from paying a last tribute to the\r\nmemory of the beautiful, chaste, and adorable girl, thus cut off in the\r\nflower of her youth.\r\n\r\nAs they left Paris, an equipage with four horses, at full speed, was\r\nseen to draw up suddenly; it contained Monte Cristo. The count left the\r\ncarriage and mingled in the crowd who followed on foot. Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud\r\nperceived him and immediately alighting from his _coup\xc3\xa9_, joined him;\r\nBeauchamp did the same.\r\n\r\nThe count looked attentively through every opening in the crowd; he was\r\nevidently watching for someone, but his search ended in disappointment.\r\n\r\n50119m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is Morrel?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked; \xe2\x80\x9cdo either of these gentlemen know where\r\nhe is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have already asked that question,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cfor none\r\nof us has seen him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count was silent, but continued to gaze around him. At length they\r\narrived at the cemetery. The piercing eye of Monte Cristo glanced\r\nthrough clusters of bushes and trees, and was soon relieved from all\r\nanxiety, for seeing a shadow glide between the yew-trees, Monte Cristo\r\nrecognized him whom he sought.\r\n\r\nOne funeral is generally very much like another in this magnificent\r\nmetropolis. Black figures are seen scattered over the long white\r\navenues; the silence of earth and heaven is alone broken by the noise\r\nmade by the crackling branches of hedges planted around the monuments;\r\nthen follows the melancholy chant of the priests, mingled now and then\r\nwith a sob of anguish, escaping from some woman concealed behind a mass\r\nof flowers.\r\n\r\nThe shadow Monte Cristo had noticed passed rapidly behind the tomb of\r\nAb\xc3\xa9lard and H\xc3\xa9lo\xc3\xafse, placed itself close to the heads of the horses\r\nbelonging to the hearse, and following the undertaker\xe2\x80\x99s men, arrived\r\nwith them at the spot appointed for the burial. Each person\xe2\x80\x99s attention\r\nwas occupied. Monte Cristo saw nothing but the shadow, which no one\r\nelse observed. Twice the count left the ranks to see whether the object\r\nof his interest had any concealed weapon beneath his clothes. When the\r\nprocession stopped, this shadow was recognized as Morrel, who, with his\r\ncoat buttoned up to his throat, his face livid, and convulsively\r\ncrushing his hat between his fingers, leaned against a tree, situated\r\non an elevation commanding the mausoleum, so that none of the funeral\r\ndetails could escape his observation.\r\n\r\nEverything was conducted in the usual manner. A few men, the least\r\nimpressed of all by the scene, pronounced a discourse, some deploring\r\nthis premature death, others expatiating on the grief of the father,\r\nand one very ingenious person quoting the fact that Valentine had\r\nsolicited pardon of her father for criminals on whom the arm of justice\r\nwas ready to fall\xe2\x80\x94until at length they exhausted their stores of\r\nmetaphor and mournful speeches, elaborate variations on the stanzas of\r\nMalherbe to Du P\xc3\xa9rier.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo heard and saw nothing, or rather he only saw Morrel, whose\r\ncalmness had a frightful effect on those who knew what was passing in\r\nhis heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, pointing out Morrel to Debray. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is he doing\r\nup there?\xe2\x80\x9d And they called Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud\xe2\x80\x99s attention to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow pale he is!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, shuddering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is cold,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, slowly; \xe2\x80\x9cI think he is violently\r\nagitated. He is very susceptible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray; \xe2\x80\x9che scarcely knew Mademoiselle de Villefort; you\r\nsaid so yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue. Still I remember he danced three times with her at Madame de\r\nMorcerf\xe2\x80\x99s. Do you recollect that ball, count, where you produced such\r\nan effect?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50121m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I do not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, without even knowing of what or\r\nto whom he was speaking, so much was he occupied in watching Morrel,\r\nwho was holding his breath with emotion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe discourse is over; farewell, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count,\r\nunceremoniously.\r\n\r\nAnd he disappeared without anyone seeing whither he went.\r\n\r\nThe funeral being over, the guests returned to Paris. Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud\r\nlooked for a moment for Morrel; but while they were watching the\r\ndeparture of the count, Morrel had quitted his post, and\r\nCh\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, failing in his search, joined Debray and Beauchamp.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo concealed himself behind a large tomb and awaited the\r\narrival of Morrel, who by degrees approached the tomb now abandoned by\r\nspectators and workmen. Morrel threw a glance around, but before it\r\nreached the spot occupied by Monte Cristo the latter had advanced yet\r\nnearer, still unperceived. The young man knelt down. The count, with\r\noutstretched neck and glaring eyes, stood in an attitude ready to\r\npounce upon Morrel upon the first occasion. Morrel bent his head till\r\nit touched the stone, then clutching the grating with both hands, he\r\nmurmured:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Valentine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count\xe2\x80\x99s heart was pierced by the utterance of these two words; he\r\nstepped forward, and touching the young man\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was looking for you, my friend.\xe2\x80\x9d Monte Cristo expected a burst of\r\npassion, but he was deceived, for Morrel turning round, said calmly,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see I was praying.\xe2\x80\x9d The scrutinizing glance of the count searched\r\nthe young man from head to foot. He then seemed more easy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I drive you back to Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, thank you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you wish anything?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave me to pray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count withdrew without opposition, but it was only to place himself\r\nin a situation where he could watch every movement of Morrel, who at\r\nlength arose, brushed the dust from his knees, and turned towards\r\nParis, without once looking back. He walked slowly down the Rue de la\r\nRoquette. The count, dismissing his carriage, followed him about a\r\nhundred paces behind. Maximilian crossed the canal and entered the Rue\r\nMeslay by the boulevards.\r\n\r\nFive minutes after the door had been closed on Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s entrance, it\r\nwas again opened for the count. Julie was at the entrance of the\r\ngarden, where she was attentively watching Penelon, who, entering with\r\nzeal into his profession of gardener, was very busy grafting some\r\nBengal roses. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, count,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, with the delight manifested\r\nby every member of the family whenever he visited the Rue Meslay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian has just returned, has he not, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count.\r\n\r\n50123m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I think I saw him pass; but pray, call Emmanuel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, madame, but I must go up to Maximilian\xe2\x80\x99s room this\r\ninstant,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cI have something of the greatest\r\nimportance to tell him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, then,\xe2\x80\x9d she said with a charming smile, which accompanied him until\r\nhe had disappeared.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo soon ran up the staircase conducting from the ground floor\r\nto Maximilian\xe2\x80\x99s room; when he reached the landing he listened\r\nattentively, but all was still. Like many old houses occupied by a\r\nsingle family, the room door was panelled with glass; but it was\r\nlocked, Maximilian was shut in, and it was impossible to see what was\r\npassing in the room, because a red curtain was drawn before the glass.\r\nThe count\xe2\x80\x99s anxiety was manifested by a bright color which seldom\r\nappeared on the face of that imperturbable man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall I do!\xe2\x80\x9d he uttered, and reflected for a moment; \xe2\x80\x9cshall I\r\nring? No, the sound of a bell, announcing a visitor, will but\r\naccelerate the resolution of one in Maximilian\xe2\x80\x99s situation, and then\r\nthe bell would be followed by a louder noise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo trembled from head to foot and as if his determination had\r\nbeen taken with the rapidity of lightning, he struck one of the panes\r\nof glass with his elbow; the glass was shivered to atoms, then\r\nwithdrawing the curtain he saw Morrel, who had been writing at his\r\ndesk, bound from his seat at the noise of the broken window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg a thousand pardons,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is nothing the\r\nmatter, but I slipped down and broke one of your panes of glass with my\r\nelbow. Since it is opened, I will take advantage of it to enter your\r\nroom; do not disturb yourself\xe2\x80\x94do not disturb yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd passing his hand through the broken glass, the count opened the\r\ndoor. Morrel, evidently discomposed, came to meet Monte Cristo less\r\nwith the intention of receiving him than to exclude his entry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, rubbing his elbow, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s all your\r\nservant\xe2\x80\x99s fault; your stairs are so polished, it is like walking on\r\nglass.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you hurt, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d coldly asked Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe not. But what are you about there? You were writing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour fingers are stained with ink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, true, I was writing. I do sometimes, soldier though I am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo advanced into the room; Maximilian was obliged to let him\r\npass, but he followed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were writing?\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo with a searching look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have already had the honor of telling you I was,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel.\r\n\r\nThe count looked around him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour pistols are beside your desk,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, pointing with\r\nhis finger to the pistols on the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am on the point of starting on a journey,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel\r\ndisdainfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Monte Cristo in a tone of exquisite sweetness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend, my dear Maximilian, do not make a hasty resolution, I\r\nentreat you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI make a hasty resolution?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, shrugging his shoulders; \xe2\x80\x9cis\r\nthere anything extraordinary in a journey?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50125m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9clet us both lay aside the mask we have\r\nassumed. You no more deceive me with that false calmness than I impose\r\nupon you with my frivolous solicitude. You can understand, can you not,\r\nthat to have acted as I have done, to have broken that glass, to have\r\nintruded on the solitude of a friend\xe2\x80\x94you can understand that, to have\r\ndone all this, I must have been actuated by real uneasiness, or rather\r\nby a terrible conviction. Morrel, you are going to destroy yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, shuddering; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat has put this into your\r\nhead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you that you are about to destroy yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the\r\ncount, \xe2\x80\x9cand here is proof of what I say;\xe2\x80\x9d and, approaching the desk, he\r\nremoved the sheet of paper which Morrel had placed over the letter he\r\nhad begun, and took the latter in his hands.\r\n\r\nMorrel rushed forward to tear it from him, but Monte Cristo perceiving\r\nhis intention, seized his wrist with his iron grasp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wish to destroy yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have written it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, changing his expression of calmness for one of\r\nviolence\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwell, and if I do intend to turn this pistol against myself,\r\nwho shall prevent me\xe2\x80\x94who will dare prevent me? All my hopes are\r\nblighted, my heart is broken, my life a burden, everything around me is\r\nsad and mournful; earth has become distasteful to me, and human voices\r\ndistract me. It is a mercy to let me die, for if I live I shall lose my\r\nreason and become mad. When, sir, I tell you all this with tears of\r\nheartfelt anguish, can you reply that I am wrong, can you prevent my\r\nputting an end to my miserable existence? Tell me, sir, could you have\r\nthe courage to do so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, with a calmness which contrasted\r\nstrangely with the young man\xe2\x80\x99s excitement; \xe2\x80\x9cyes, I would do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Morrel, with increasing anger and reproach\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyou, who\r\nhave deceived me with false hopes, who have cheered and soothed me with\r\nvain promises, when I might, if not have saved her, at least have seen\r\nher die in my arms! You, who pretend to understand everything, even the\r\nhidden sources of knowledge,\xe2\x80\x94and who enact the part of a guardian angel\r\nupon earth, and could not even find an antidote to a poison\r\nadministered to a young girl! Ah, sir, indeed you would inspire me with\r\npity, were you not hateful in my eyes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMorrel\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; you tell me to lay aside the mask, and I will do so, be\r\nsatisfied! When you spoke to me at the cemetery, I answered you\xe2\x80\x94my\r\nheart was softened; when you arrived here, I allowed you to enter. But\r\nsince you abuse my confidence, since you have devised a new torture\r\nafter I thought I had exhausted them all, then, Count of Monte Cristo\r\nmy pretended benefactor\xe2\x80\x94then, Count of Monte Cristo, the universal\r\nguardian, be satisfied, you shall witness the death of your friend;\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand Morrel, with a maniacal laugh, again rushed towards the pistols.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I again repeat, you shall not commit suicide.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrevent me, then!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel, with another struggle, which, like\r\nthe first, failed in releasing him from the count\xe2\x80\x99s iron grasp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will prevent you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50127m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who are you, then, that arrogate to yourself this tyrannical right\r\nover free and rational beings?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho am I?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cListen; I am the only man in the\r\nworld having the right to say to you, \xe2\x80\x98Morrel, your father\xe2\x80\x99s son shall\r\nnot die today;\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d and Monte Cristo, with an expression of majesty and\r\nsublimity, advanced with arms folded toward the young man, who,\r\ninvoluntarily overcome by the commanding manner of this man, recoiled a\r\nstep.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you mention my father?\xe2\x80\x9d stammered he; \xe2\x80\x9cwhy do you mingle a\r\nrecollection of him with the affairs of today?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I am he who saved your father\xe2\x80\x99s life when he wished to destroy\r\nhimself, as you do today\xe2\x80\x94because I am the man who sent the purse to\r\nyour young sister, and the _Pharaon_ to old Morrel\xe2\x80\x94because I am the\r\nEdmond Dant\xc3\xa8s who nursed you, a child, on my knees.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel made another step back, staggering, breathless, crushed; then\r\nall his strength give way, and he fell prostrate at the feet of Monte\r\nCristo. Then his admirable nature underwent a complete and sudden\r\nrevulsion; he arose, rushed out of the room and to the stairs,\r\nexclaiming energetically, \xe2\x80\x9cJulie, Julie\xe2\x80\x94Emmanuel, Emmanuel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo endeavored also to leave, but Maximilian would have died\r\nrather than relax his hold of the handle of the door, which he closed\r\nupon the count. Julie, Emmanuel, and some of the servants, ran up in\r\nalarm on hearing the cries of Maximilian. Morrel seized their hands,\r\nand opening the door exclaimed in a voice choked with sobs:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn your knees\xe2\x80\x94on your knees\xe2\x80\x94he is our benefactor\xe2\x80\x94the saviour of our\r\nfather! He is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe would have added \xe2\x80\x9cEdmond Dant\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x9d but the count seized his arm and\r\nprevented him.\r\n\r\nJulie threw herself into the arms of the count; Emmanuel embraced him\r\nas a guardian angel; Morrel again fell on his knees, and struck the\r\nground with his forehead. Then the iron-hearted man felt his heart\r\nswell in his breast; a flame seemed to rush from his throat to his\r\neyes, he bent his head and wept. For a while nothing was heard in the\r\nroom but a succession of sobs, while the incense from their grateful\r\nhearts mounted to heaven. Julie had scarcely recovered from her deep\r\nemotion when she rushed out of the room, descended to the next floor,\r\nran into the drawing-room with childlike joy and raised the crystal\r\nglobe which covered the purse given by the unknown of the All\xc3\xa9es de\r\nMeilhan. Meanwhile, Emmanuel in a broken voice said to the count:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, count, how could you, hearing us so often speak of our unknown\r\nbenefactor, seeing us pay such homage of gratitude and adoration to his\r\nmemory,\xe2\x80\x94how could you continue so long without discovering yourself to\r\nus? Oh, it was cruel to us, and\xe2\x80\x94dare I say it?\xe2\x80\x94to you also.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI may call you so since we have\r\nreally been friends for the last eleven years\xe2\x80\x94the discovery of this\r\nsecret has been occasioned by a great event which you must never know.\r\nI wished to bury it during my whole life in my own bosom, but your\r\nbrother Maximilian wrested it from me by a violence he repents of now,\r\nI am sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen turning around, and seeing that Morrel, still on his knees, had\r\nthrown himself into an armchair, he added in a low voice, pressing\r\nEmmanuel\xe2\x80\x99s hand significantly, \xe2\x80\x9cWatch over him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the young man, surprised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot explain myself; but watch over him.\xe2\x80\x9d Emmanuel looked around\r\nthe room and caught sight of the pistols; his eyes rested on the\r\nweapons, and he pointed to them. Monte Cristo bent his head. Emmanuel\r\nwent towards the pistols.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.
