Madame de Villefort was sitting on an ottoman and\r\nimpatiently turning over the leaves of some newspapers and pamphlets\r\nwhich young Edward, by way of amusing himself, was tearing to pieces\r\nbefore his mother could finish reading them. She was dressed to go out,\r\nher bonnet was placed beside her on a chair, and her gloves were on her\r\nhands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, here you are, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d she said in her naturally calm voice;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut how pale you are! Have you been working all night? Why did you not\r\ncome down to breakfast? Well, will you take me, or shall I take\r\nEdward?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort had multiplied her questions in order to gain one\r\nanswer, but to all her inquiries M. de Villefort remained mute and cold\r\nas a statue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdward,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort, fixing an imperious glance on the child, \xe2\x80\x9cgo\r\nand play in the drawing-room, my dear; I wish to speak to your mamma.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort shuddered at the sight of that cold countenance,\r\nthat resolute tone, and the awfully strange preliminaries. Edward\r\nraised his head, looked at his mother, and then, finding that she did\r\nnot confirm the order, began cutting off the heads of his leaden\r\nsoldiers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdward,\xe2\x80\x9d cried M. de Villefort, so harshly that the child started up\r\nfrom the floor, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you hear me?\xe2\x80\x94Go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe child, unaccustomed to such treatment, arose, pale and trembling;\r\nit would be difficult to say whether his emotion were caused by fear or\r\npassion. His father went up to him, took him in his arms, and kissed\r\nhis forehead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said: \xe2\x80\x9cgo, my child.\xe2\x80\x9d Edward ran out.\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort went to the door, which he closed behind the child, and\r\nbolted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman, endeavoring to read her husband\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninmost thoughts, while a smile passed over her countenance which froze\r\nthe impassibility of Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame, where do you keep the poison you generally use?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nmagistrate, without any introduction, placing himself between his wife\r\nand the door.\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort must have experienced something of the sensation of\r\na bird which, looking up, sees the murderous trap closing over its\r\nhead.\r\n\r\nA hoarse, broken tone, which was neither a cry nor a sigh, escaped from\r\nher, while she became deadly pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x94I do not understand you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, in her first paroxysm of terror, she had raised herself from the\r\nsofa, in the next, stronger very likely than the other, she fell down\r\nagain on the cushions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI asked you,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Villefort, in a perfectly calm tone, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere\r\nyou conceal the poison by the aid of which you have killed my\r\nfather-in-law, M. de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran, my mother-in-law, Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran, Barrois, and my daughter Valentine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Madame de Villefort, clasping her hands, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do\r\nyou say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not for you to interrogate, but to answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it to the judge or to the husband?\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Madame de Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the judge\xe2\x80\x94to the judge, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d It was terrible to behold the\r\nfrightful pallor of that woman, the anguish of her look, the trembling\r\nof her whole frame.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she muttered, \xe2\x80\x9cah, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d and this was all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not answer, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the terrible interrogator. Then\r\nhe added, with a smile yet more terrible than his anger, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is true,\r\nthen; you do not deny it!\xe2\x80\x9d She moved forward. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you cannot deny it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nadded Villefort, extending his hand toward her, as though to seize her\r\nin the name of justice. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have accomplished these different crimes\r\nwith impudent address, but which could only deceive those whose\r\naffections for you blinded them. Since the death of Madame de\r\nSaint-M\xc3\xa9ran, I have known that a poisoner lived in my house. M.\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99Avrigny warned me of it. After the death of Barrois my suspicions\r\nwere directed towards an angel,\xe2\x80\x94those suspicions which, even when there\r\nis no crime, are always alive in my heart; but after the death of\r\nValentine, there has been no doubt in my mind, madame, and not only in\r\nmine, but in those of others; thus your crime, known by two persons,\r\nsuspected by many, will soon become public, and, as I told you just\r\nnow, you no longer speak to the husband, but to the judge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50165m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe young woman hid her face in her hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she stammered, \xe2\x80\x9cI beseech you, do not believe appearances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you, then, a coward?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Villefort, in a contemptuous voice.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I have always observed that poisoners were cowards. Can you be a\r\ncoward, you, who have had the courage to witness the death of two old\r\nmen and a young girl murdered by you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir! sir!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you be a coward?\xe2\x80\x9d continued Villefort, with increasing excitement,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou, who could count, one by one, the minutes of four death agonies?\r\n_You_, who have arranged your infernal plans, and removed the beverages\r\nwith a talent and precision almost miraculous? Have you, then, who have\r\ncalculated everything with such nicety, have you forgotten to calculate\r\none thing\xe2\x80\x94I mean where the revelation of your crimes will lead you to?\r\nOh, it is impossible\xe2\x80\x94you must have saved some surer, more subtle and\r\ndeadly poison than any other, that you might escape the punishment that\r\nyou deserve. You have done this\xe2\x80\x94I hope so, at least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort stretched out her hands, and fell on her knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou confess; but a confession made to the\r\njudges, a confession made at the last moment, extorted when the crime\r\ncannot be denied, diminishes not the punishment inflicted on the\r\nguilty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe punishment?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Madame de Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9cthe punishment,\r\nmonsieur? Twice you have pronounced that word!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly. Did you hope to escape it because you were four times\r\nguilty? Did you think the punishment would be withheld because you are\r\nthe wife of him who pronounces it?\xe2\x80\x94No, madame, no; the scaffold awaits\r\nthe poisoner, whoever she may be, unless, as I just said, the poisoner\r\nhas taken the precaution of keeping for herself a few drops of her\r\ndeadliest poison.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort uttered a wild cry, and a hideous and\r\nuncontrollable terror spread over her distorted features.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do not fear the scaffold, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the magistrate; \xe2\x80\x9cI will\r\nnot dishonor you, since that would be dishonor to myself; no, if you\r\nhave heard me distinctly, you will understand that you are not to die\r\non the scaffold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I do not understand; what do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d stammered the unhappy\r\nwoman, completely overwhelmed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean that the wife of the first magistrate in the capital shall not,\r\nby her infamy, soil an unblemished name; that she shall not, with one\r\nblow, dishonor her husband and her child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no\xe2\x80\x94oh, no!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, madame, it will be a laudable action on your part, and I will\r\nthank you for it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will thank me\xe2\x80\x94for what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor what you have just said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did I say? Oh, my brain whirls; I no longer understand anything.\r\nOh, my God, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she rose, with her hair dishevelled, and her lips foaming.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you answered the question I put to you on entering the\r\nroom?\xe2\x80\x94where do you keep the poison you generally use, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort raised her arms to heaven, and convulsively struck\r\none hand against the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d she vociferated, \xe2\x80\x9cno, you cannot wish that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50169m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I do not wish, madame, is that you should perish on the scaffold.\r\nDo you understand?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, mercy, mercy, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I require is, that justice be done. I am on the earth to punish,\r\nmadame,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, with a flaming glance; \xe2\x80\x9cany other woman, were it the\r\nqueen herself, I would send to the executioner; but to you I shall be\r\nmerciful. To you I will say, \xe2\x80\x98Have you not, madame, put aside some of\r\nthe surest, deadliest, most speedy poison?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50170m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, pardon me, sir; let me live!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is cowardly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReflect that I am your wife!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a poisoner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of Heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of the love you once bore me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of our child! Ah, for the sake of our child, let me live!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50167m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, no, I tell you; one day, if I allow you to live, you will\r\nperhaps kill him, as you have the others!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x94I kill my boy?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the distracted mother, rushing toward\r\nVillefort; \xe2\x80\x9cI kill my son? Ha, ha, ha!\xe2\x80\x9d and a frightful, demoniac laugh\r\nfinished the sentence, which was lost in a hoarse rattle.\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort fell at her husband\xe2\x80\x99s feet. He approached her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink of it, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cif, on my return, justice has not been\r\nsatisfied, I will denounce you with my own mouth, and arrest you with\r\nmy own hands!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe listened, panting, overwhelmed, crushed; her eye alone lived, and\r\nglared horribly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you understand me?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI am going down there to pronounce\r\nthe sentence of death against a murderer. If I find you alive on my\r\nreturn, you shall sleep tonight in the conciergerie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame de Villefort sighed; her nerves gave way, and she sunk on the\r\ncarpet. The king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney seemed to experience a sensation of pity;\r\nhe looked upon her less severely, and, bowing to her, said slowly:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell, madame, farewell!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat farewell struck Madame de Villefort like the executioner\xe2\x80\x99s knife.\r\nShe fainted. The procureur went out, after having double-locked the\r\ndoor.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 109. The Assizes\r\n\r\nThe Benedetto affair, as it was called at the Palais, and by people in\r\ngeneral, had produced a tremendous sensation. Frequenting the Caf\xc3\xa9 de\r\nParis, the Boulevard de Gand, and the Bois de Boulogne, during his\r\nbrief career of splendor, the false Cavalcanti had formed a host of\r\nacquaintances. The papers had related his various adventures, both as\r\nthe man of fashion and the galley-slave; and as everyone who had been\r\npersonally acquainted with Prince Andrea Cavalcanti experienced a\r\nlively curiosity in his fate, they all determined to spare no trouble\r\nin endeavoring to witness the trial of M. Benedetto for the murder of\r\nhis comrade in chains.\r\n\r\nIn the eyes of many, Benedetto appeared, if not a victim to, at least\r\nan instance of, the fallibility of the law. M. Cavalcanti, his father,\r\nhad been seen in Paris, and it was expected that he would re-appear to\r\nclaim the illustrious outcast. Many, also, who were not aware of the\r\ncircumstances attending his withdrawal from Paris, were struck with the\r\nworthy appearance, the gentlemanly bearing, and the knowledge of the\r\nworld displayed by the old patrician, who certainly played the nobleman\r\nvery well, so long as he said nothing, and made no arithmetical\r\ncalculations.\r\n\r\nAs for the accused himself, many remembered him as being so amiable, so\r\nhandsome, and so liberal, that they chose to think him the victim of\r\nsome conspiracy, since in this world large fortunes frequently excite\r\nthe malevolence and jealousy of some unknown enemy.\r\n\r\nEveryone, therefore, ran to the court; some to witness the sight,\r\nothers to comment upon it. From seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning a crowd\r\nwas stationed at the iron gates, and an hour before the trial commenced\r\nthe hall was full of the privileged. Before the entrance of the\r\nmagistrates, and indeed frequently afterwards, a court of justice, on\r\ndays when some especial trial is to take place, resembles a\r\ndrawing-room where many persons recognize each other and converse if\r\nthey can do so without losing their seats; or, if they are separated by\r\ntoo great a number of lawyers, communicate by signs.\r\n\r\nIt was one of the magnificent autumn days which make amends for a short\r\nsummer; the clouds which M. de Villefort had perceived at sunrise had\r\nall disappeared as if by magic, and one of the softest and most\r\nbrilliant days of September shone forth in all its splendor.\r\n\r\nBeauchamp, one of the kings of the press, and therefore claiming the\r\nright of a throne everywhere, was eying everybody through his monocle.\r\nHe perceived Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud and Debray, who had just gained the good\r\ngraces of a sergeant-at-arms, and who had persuaded the latter to let\r\nthem stand before, instead of behind him, as they ought to have done.\r\nThe worthy sergeant had recognized the minister\xe2\x80\x99s secretary and the\r\nmillionnaire, and, by way of paying extra attention to his noble\r\nneighbors, promised to keep their places while they paid a visit to\r\nBeauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall see our friend!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Debray. \xe2\x80\x9cThat worthy prince. Deuce take those\r\nItalian princes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man, too, who could boast of Dante for a genealogist, and could\r\nreckon back to the _Divina Comedia_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA nobility of the rope!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud phlegmatically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will be condemned, will he not?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Debray of Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow, I think we should ask you that question; you know such\r\nnews much better than we do. Did you see the president at the\r\nminister\xe2\x80\x99s last night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did he say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething which will surprise you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, make haste and tell me, then; it is a long time since that has\r\nhappened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, he told me that Benedetto, who is considered a serpent of\r\nsubtlety and a giant of cunning, is really but a very commonplace,\r\nsilly rascal, and altogether unworthy of the experiments that will be\r\nmade on his phrenological organs after his death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9che played the prince very well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, for you who detest those unhappy princes, Beauchamp, and are\r\nalways delighted to find fault with them; but not for me, who discover\r\na gentleman by instinct, and who scent out an aristocratic family like\r\na very bloodhound of heraldry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you never believed in the principality?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x94in the principality, but not in the prince.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so bad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9cstill, I assure you, he passed very well\r\nwith many people; I saw him at the ministers\xe2\x80\x99 houses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud. \xe2\x80\x9cThe idea of thinking ministers\r\nunderstand anything about princes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is something in what you have just said,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp,\r\nlaughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray to Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cif I spoke to the president, _you_\r\nmust have been with the procureur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was an impossibility; for the last week M. de Villefort has\r\nsecluded himself. It is natural enough; this strange chain of domestic\r\nafflictions, followed by the no less strange death of his daughter\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrange? What do you mean, Beauchamp?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes; do you pretend that all this has been unobserved at the\r\nminister\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, placing his eye-glass in his eye, where he\r\ntried to make it remain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9callow me to tell you that you do\r\nnot understand that man\xc5\x93uvre with the eye-glass half so well as Debray.\r\nGive him a lesson, Debray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9csurely I am not deceived.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is she!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey said she had left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMademoiselle Eug\xc3\xa9nie?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9chas she returned?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but her mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame Danglars? Nonsense! Impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9conly ten\r\ndays after the flight of her daughter, and three days from the\r\nbankruptcy of her husband?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDebray colored slightly, and followed with his eyes the direction of\r\nBeauchamp\xe2\x80\x99s glance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cit is only a veiled lady, some foreign princess,\r\nperhaps the mother of Cavalcanti. But you were just speaking on a very\r\ninteresting topic, Beauchamp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; you were telling us about the extraordinary death of Valentine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes, so I was. But how is it that Madame de Villefort is not\r\nhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor, dear woman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cshe is no doubt occupied in\r\ndistilling balm for the hospitals, or in making cosmetics for herself\r\nor friends. Do you know she spends two or three thousand crowns a year\r\nin this amusement? But I wonder she is not here. I should have been\r\npleased to see her, for I like her very much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I hate her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know. Why do we love? Why do we hate? I detest her, from\r\nantipathy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr, rather, by instinct.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps so. But to return to what you were saying, Beauchamp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, do you know why they die so multitudinously at M. de\r\nVillefort\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Multitudinously\xe2\x80\x99 is good,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy good fellow, you\xe2\x80\x99ll find the word in Saint-Simon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the thing itself is at M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s; but let\xe2\x80\x99s get back to\r\nthe subject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTalking of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray, \xe2\x80\x9cMadame was making inquiries about that\r\nhouse, which for the last three months has been hung with black.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is Madame?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe minister\xe2\x80\x99s wife, _pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, your pardon! I never visit ministers; I leave that to the\r\nprinces.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally, you were only before sparkling, but now you are brilliant;\r\ntake compassion on us, or, like Jupiter, you will wither us up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not speak again,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud; \xe2\x80\x9cpray have compassion\r\nupon me, and do not take up every word I say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, let us endeavor to get to the end of our story, Beauchamp; I\r\ntold you that yesterday Madame made inquiries of me upon the subject;\r\nenlighten me, and I will then communicate my information to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, gentlemen, the reason people die so multitudinously (I like the\r\nword) at M. de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s is that there is an assassin in the house!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two young men shuddered, for the same idea had more than once\r\noccurred to them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who is the assassin;\xe2\x80\x9d they asked together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYoung Edward!\xe2\x80\x9d A burst of laughter from the auditors did not in the\r\nleast disconcert the speaker, who continued,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYes, gentlemen; Edward,\r\nthe infant phenomenon, who is quite an adept in the art of killing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are jesting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all. I yesterday engaged a servant, who had just left M. de\r\nVillefort\xe2\x80\x94I intend sending him away tomorrow, for he eats so\r\nenormously, to make up for the fast imposed upon him by his terror in\r\nthat house. Well, now listen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are listening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears the dear child has obtained possession of a bottle\r\ncontaining some drug, which he every now and then uses against those\r\nwho have displeased him. First, M. and Madame de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran incurred\r\nhis displeasure, so he poured out three drops of his elixir\xe2\x80\x94three drops\r\nwere sufficient; then followed Barrois, the old servant of M. Noirtier,\r\nwho sometimes rebuffed this little wretch\xe2\x80\x94he therefore received the\r\nsame quantity of the elixir; the same happened to Valentine, of whom he\r\nwas jealous; he gave her the same dose as the others, and all was over\r\nfor her as well as the rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what nonsense are you telling us?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it is an extraordinary story,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp; \xe2\x80\x9cis it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is absurd,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9cyou doubt me? Well, you can ask my servant, or\r\nrather him who will no longer be my servant tomorrow, it was the talk\r\nof the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this elixir, where is it? what is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe child conceals it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where did he find it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn his mother\xe2\x80\x99s laboratory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes his mother then, keep poisons in her laboratory?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I tell? You are questioning me like a king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney. I only\r\nrepeat what I have been told, and like my informant I can do no more.\r\nThe poor devil would eat nothing, from fear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is incredible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my dear fellow, it is not at all incredible. You saw the child\r\npass through the Rue Richelieu last year, who amused himself with\r\nkilling his brothers and sisters by sticking pins in their ears while\r\nthey slept. The generation who follow us are very precocious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Beauchamp,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cI will bet anything you do not\r\nbelieve a word of all you have been telling us. But I do not see the\r\nCount of Monte Cristo here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is worn out,\xe2\x80\x9d said Debray; \xe2\x80\x9cbesides, he could not well appear in\r\npublic, since he has been the dupe of the Cavalcanti, who, it appears,\r\npresented themselves to him with false letters of credit, and cheated\r\nhim out of 100,000 francs upon the hypothesis of this principality.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the way, M. de Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9chow is Morrel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi_, I have called three times without once seeing him. Still,\r\nhis sister did not seem uneasy, and told me that though she had not\r\nseen him for two or three days, she was sure he was well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, now I think of it, the Count of Monte Cristo cannot appear in the\r\nhall,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause he is an actor in the drama.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he assassinated anyone, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, on the contrary, they wished to assassinate him. You know that it\r\nwas in leaving his house that M. de Caderousse was murdered by his\r\nfriend Benedetto. You know that the famous waistcoat was found in his\r\nhouse, containing the letter which stopped the signature of the\r\nmarriage-contract. Do you see the waistcoat? There it is, all\r\nblood-stained, on the desk, as a testimony of the crime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, very good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush, gentlemen, here is the court; let us go back to our places.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA noise was heard in the hall; the sergeant called his two patrons with\r\nan energetic \xe2\x80\x9chem!\xe2\x80\x9d and the door-keeper appearing, called out with that\r\nshrill voice peculiar to his order, ever since the days of\r\nBeaumarchais:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe court, gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 110. The Indictment\r\n\r\nThe judges took their places in the midst of the most profound silence;\r\nthe jury took their seats; M. de Villefort, the object of unusual\r\nattention, and we had almost said of general admiration, sat in the\r\narmchair and cast a tranquil glance around him. Everyone looked with\r\nastonishment on that grave and severe face, whose calm expression\r\npersonal griefs had been unable to disturb, and the aspect of a man who\r\nwas a stranger to all human emotions excited something very like\r\nterror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGendarmes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president, \xe2\x80\x9clead in the accused.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words the public attention became more intense, and all eyes\r\nwere turned towards the door through which Benedetto was to enter. The\r\ndoor soon opened and the accused appeared.\r\n\r\nThe same impression was experienced by all present, and no one was\r\ndeceived by the expression of his countenance. His features bore no\r\nsign of that deep emotion which stops the beating of the heart and\r\nblanches the cheek. His hands, gracefully placed, one upon his hat, the\r\nother in the opening of his white waistcoat, were not at all tremulous;\r\nhis eye was calm and even brilliant. Scarcely had he entered the hall\r\nwhen he glanced at the whole body of magistrates and assistants; his\r\neye rested longer on the president, and still more so on the king\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattorney.\r\n\r\nBy the side of Andrea was stationed the lawyer who was to conduct his\r\ndefence, and who had been appointed by the court, for Andrea disdained\r\nto pay any attention to those details, to which he appeared to attach\r\nno importance. The lawyer was a young man with light hair whose face\r\nexpressed a hundred times more emotion than that which characterized\r\nthe prisoner.\r\n\r\n50181m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe president called for the indictment, revised as we know, by the\r\nclever and implacable pen of Villefort. During the reading of this,\r\nwhich was long, the public attention was continually drawn towards\r\nAndrea, who bore the inspection with Spartan unconcern. Villefort had\r\nnever been so concise and eloquent. The crime was depicted in the most\r\nvivid colors; the former life of the prisoner, his transformation, a\r\nreview of his life from the earliest period, were set forth with all\r\nthe talent that a knowledge of human life could furnish to a mind like\r\nthat of the procureur. Benedetto was thus forever condemned in public\r\nopinion before the sentence of the law could be pronounced.\r\n\r\nAndrea paid no attention to the successive charges which were brought\r\nagainst him. M. de Villefort, who examined him attentively, and who no\r\ndoubt practiced upon him all the psychological studies he was\r\naccustomed to use, in vain endeavored to make him lower his eyes,\r\nnotwithstanding the depth and profundity of his gaze. At length the\r\nreading of the indictment was ended.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAccused,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president, \xe2\x80\x9cyour name and surname?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAndrea arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, Mr. President,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in a clear voice, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I see you\r\nare going to adopt a course of questions through which I cannot follow\r\nyou. I have an idea, which I will explain by and by, of making an\r\nexception to the usual form of accusation. Allow me, then, if you\r\nplease, to answer in different order, or I will not do so at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe astonished president looked at the jury, who in turn looked at\r\nVillefort. The whole assembly manifested great surprise, but Andrea\r\nappeared quite unmoved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour age?\xe2\x80\x9d said the president; \xe2\x80\x9cwill you answer that question?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will answer that question, as well as the rest, Mr. President, but\r\nin its turn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour age?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the president.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am twenty-one years old, or rather I shall be in a few days, as I\r\nwas born the night of the 27th of September, 1817.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort, who was busy taking down some notes, raised his head\r\nat the mention of this date.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere were you born?\xe2\x80\x9d continued the president.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Auteuil, near Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort a second time raised his head, looked at Benedetto as\r\nif he had been gazing at the head of Medusa, and became livid. As for\r\nBenedetto, he gracefully wiped his lips with a fine cambric\r\npocket-handkerchief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour profession?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFirst I was a forger,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Andrea, as calmly as possible; \xe2\x80\x9cthen I\r\nbecame a thief, and lately have become an assassin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA murmur, or rather storm, of indignation burst from all parts of the\r\nassembly. The judges themselves appeared to be stupefied, and the jury\r\nmanifested tokens of disgust for a cynicism so unexpected in a man of\r\nfashion. M. de Villefort pressed his hand upon his brow, which, at\r\nfirst pale, had become red and burning; then he suddenly arose and\r\nlooked around as though he had lost his senses\xe2\x80\x94he wanted air.\r\n\r\n50183m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you looking for anything, Mr. Procureur?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Benedetto, with\r\nhis most ingratiating smile.\r\n\r\nM. de Villefort answered nothing, but sat, or rather threw himself down\r\nagain upon his chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, prisoner, will you consent to tell your name?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\npresident. \xe2\x80\x9cThe brutal affectation with which you have enumerated and\r\nclassified your crimes calls for a severe reprimand on the part of the\r\ncourt, both in the name of morality, and for the respect due to\r\nhumanity. You appear to consider this a point of honor, and it may be\r\nfor this reason, that you have delayed acknowledging your name. You\r\nwished it to be preceded by all these titles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is quite wonderful, Mr. President, how entirely you have read my\r\nthoughts,\xe2\x80\x9d said Benedetto, in his softest voice and most polite manner.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is, indeed, the reason why I begged you to alter the order of the\r\nquestions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe public astonishment had reached its height. There was no longer any\r\ndeceit or bravado in the manner of the accused. The audience felt that\r\na startling revelation was to follow this ominous prelude.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president; \xe2\x80\x9cyour name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot tell you my name, since I do not know it; but I know my\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s, and can tell it to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA painful giddiness overwhelmed Villefort; great drops of acrid sweat\r\nfell from his face upon the papers which he held in his convulsed hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRepeat your father\xe2\x80\x99s name,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president.\r\n\r\nNot a whisper, not a breath, was heard in that vast assembly; everyone\r\nwaited anxiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father is king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Andrea calmly.\r\n\r\n50179m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKing\xe2\x80\x99s attorney?\xe2\x80\x9d said the president, stupefied, and without noticing\r\nthe agitation which spread over the face of M. de Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9cking\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nattorney?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; and if you wish to know his name, I will tell it,\xe2\x80\x94he is named\r\nVillefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe explosion, which had been so long restrained from a feeling of\r\nrespect to the court of justice, now burst forth like thunder from the\r\nbreasts of all present; the court itself did not seek to restrain the\r\nfeelings of the audience. The exclamations, the insults addressed to\r\nBenedetto, who remained perfectly unconcerned, the energetic gestures,\r\nthe movement of the gendarmes, the sneers of the scum of the crowd\r\nalways sure to rise to the surface in case of any disturbance\xe2\x80\x94all this\r\nlasted five minutes, before the door-keepers and magistrates were able\r\nto restore silence. In the midst of this tumult the voice of\r\nthepresident was heard to exclaim:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you playing with justice, accused, and do you dare set your\r\nfellow-citizens an example of disorder which even in these times has\r\nnever been equalled?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSeveral persons hurried up to M. de Villefort, who sat half bowed over\r\nin his chair, offering him consolation, encouragement, and\r\nprotestations of zeal and sympathy. Order was re-established in the\r\nhall, except that a few people still moved about and whispered to one\r\nanother. A lady, it was said, had just fainted; they had supplied her\r\nwith a smelling-bottle, and she had recovered. During the scene of\r\ntumult, Andrea had turned his smiling face towards the assembly; then,\r\nleaning with one hand on the oaken rail of the dock, in the most\r\ngraceful attitude possible, he said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, I assure you I had no idea of insulting the court, or of\r\nmaking a useless disturbance in the presence of this honorable\r\nassembly. They ask my age; I tell it. They ask where I was born; I\r\nanswer. They ask my name, I cannot give it, since my parents abandoned\r\nme. But though I cannot give my own name, not possessing one, I can\r\ntell them my father\xe2\x80\x99s. Now I repeat, my father is named M. de\r\nVillefort, and I am ready to prove it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was an energy, a conviction, and a sincerity in the manner of the\r\nyoung man, which silenced the tumult. All eyes were turned for a moment\r\ntowards the procureur, who sat as motionless as though a thunderbolt\r\nhad changed him into a corpse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrea, commanding silence by his voice and manner;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI owe you the proofs and explanations of what I have said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said the irritated president, \xe2\x80\x9cyou called yourself Benedetto,\r\ndeclared yourself an orphan, and claimed Corsica as your country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said anything I pleased, in order that the solemn declaration I have\r\njust made should not be withheld, which otherwise would certainly have\r\nbeen the case. I now repeat that I was born at Auteuil on the night of\r\nthe 27th of September, 1817, and that I am the son of the procureur, M.\r\nde Villefort. Do you wish for any further details? I will give them. I\r\nwas born in No. 28, Rue de la Fontaine, in a room hung with red damask;\r\nmy father took me in his arms, telling my mother I was dead, wrapped me\r\nin a napkin marked with an H and an N, and carried me into a garden,\r\nwhere he buried me alive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA shudder ran through the assembly when they saw that the confidence of\r\nthe prisoner increased in proportion to the terror of M. de Villefort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how have you become acquainted with all these details?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the\r\npresident.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you, Mr. President. A man who had sworn vengeance against\r\nmy father, and had long watched his opportunity to kill him, had\r\nintroduced himself that night into the garden in which my father buried\r\nme. He was concealed in a thicket; he saw my father bury something in\r\nthe ground, and stabbed him; then thinking the deposit might contain\r\nsome treasure he turned up the ground, and found me still living. The\r\nman carried me to the foundling asylum, where I was registered under\r\nthe number 37. Three months afterwards, a woman travelled from Rogliano\r\nto Paris to fetch me, and having claimed me as her son, carried me\r\naway. Thus, you see, though born in Paris, I was brought up in\r\nCorsica.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a moment\xe2\x80\x99s silence, during which one could have fancied the\r\nhall empty, so profound was the stillness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProceed,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, I might have lived happily amongst those good people, who\r\nadored me, but my perverse disposition prevailed over the virtues which\r\nmy adopted mother endeavored to instil into my heart. I increased in\r\nwickedness till I committed crime. One day when I cursed Providence for\r\nmaking me so wicked, and ordaining me to such a fate, my adopted father\r\nsaid to me, \xe2\x80\x98Do not blaspheme, unhappy child, the crime is that of your\r\nfather, not yours,\xe2\x80\x94of your father, who consigned you to hell if you\r\ndied, and to misery if a miracle preserved you alive.\xe2\x80\x99 After that I\r\nceased to blaspheme, but I cursed my father. That is why I have uttered\r\nthe words for which you blame me; that is why I have filled this whole\r\nassembly with horror. If I have committed an additional crime, punish\r\nme, but if you will allow that ever since the day of my birth my fate\r\nhas been sad, bitter, and lamentable, then pity me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut your mother?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the president.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mother thought me dead; she is not guilty. I did not even wish to\r\nknow her name, nor do I know it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJust then a piercing cry, ending in a sob, burst from the centre of the\r\ncrowd, who encircled the lady who had before fainted, and who now fell\r\ninto a violent fit of hysterics. She was carried out of the hall, the\r\nthick veil which concealed her face dropped off, and Madame Danglars\r\nwas recognized. Notwithstanding his shattered nerves, the ringing\r\nsensation in his ears, and the madness which turned his brain,\r\nVillefort rose as he perceived her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe proofs, the proofs!\xe2\x80\x9d said the president; \xe2\x80\x9cremember this tissue of\r\nhorrors must be supported by the clearest proofs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe proofs?\xe2\x80\x9d said Benedetto, laughing; \xe2\x80\x9cdo you want proofs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, look at M. de Villefort, and then ask me for proofs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEveryone turned towards the procureur, who, unable to bear the\r\nuniversal gaze now riveted on him alone, advanced staggering into the\r\nmidst of the tribunal, with his hair dishevelled and his face indented\r\nwith the mark of his nails. The whole assembly uttered a long murmur of\r\nastonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather,\xe2\x80\x9d said Benedetto, \xe2\x80\x9cI am asked for proofs, do you wish me to\r\ngive them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, it is useless,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered M. de Villefort in a hoarse voice;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cno, it is useless!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow useless?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the president, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean that I feel it impossible to struggle against this deadly\r\nweight which crushes me. Gentlemen, I know I am in the hands of an\r\navenging God! We need no proofs; everything relating to this young man\r\nis true.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA dull, gloomy silence, like that which precedes some awful phenomenon\r\nof nature, pervaded the assembly, who shuddered in dismay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, M. de Villefort,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the president, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you yield to an\r\nhallucination? What, are you no longer in possession of your senses?\r\nThis strange, unexpected, terrible accusation has disordered your\r\nreason. Come, recover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe procureur dropped his head; his teeth chattered like those of a man\r\nunder a violent attack of fever, and yet he was deadly pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am in possession of all my senses, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cmy body alone\r\nsuffers, as you may suppose. I acknowledge myself guilty of all the\r\nyoung man has brought against me, and from this hour hold myself under\r\nthe authority of the procureur who will succeed me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd as he spoke these words with a hoarse, choking voice, he staggered\r\ntowards the door, which was mechanically opened by a door-keeper. The\r\nwhole assembly were dumb with astonishment at the revelation and\r\nconfession which had produced a catastrophe so different from that\r\nwhich had been expected during the last fortnight by the Parisian\r\nworld.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp, \xe2\x80\x9clet them now say that drama is unnatural!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Ma foi!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Ch\xc3\xa2teau-Renaud, \xe2\x80\x9cI would rather end my career like M.\r\nde Morcerf; a pistol-shot seems quite delightful compared with this\r\ncatastrophe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd moreover, it kills,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beauchamp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to think that I had an idea of marrying his daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nDebray. \xe2\x80\x9cShe did well to die, poor girl!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe sitting is adjourned, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the president; \xe2\x80\x9cfresh\r\ninquiries will be made, and the case will be tried next session by\r\nanother magistrate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs for Andrea, who was calm and more interesting than ever, he left the\r\nhall, escorted by gendarmes, who involuntarily paid him some attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what do you think of this, my fine fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Debray of the\r\nsergeant-at-arms, slipping a louis into his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere will be extenuating circumstances,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 111. Expiation\r\n\r\nNotwithstanding the density of the crowd, M. de Villefort saw it open\r\nbefore him. There is something so awe-inspiring in great afflictions\r\nthat even in the worst times the first emotion of a crowd has generally\r\nbeen to sympathize with the sufferer in a great catastrophe. Many\r\npeople have been assassinated in a tumult, but even criminals have\r\nrarely been insulted during trial. Thus Villefort passed through the\r\nmass of spectators and officers of the Palais, and withdrew. Though he\r\nhad acknowledged his guilt, he was protected by his grief. There are\r\nsome situations which men understand by instinct, but which reason is\r\npowerless to explain; in such cases the greatest poet is he who gives\r\nutterance to the most natural and vehement outburst of sorrow. Those\r\nwho hear the bitter cry are as much impressed as if they listened to an\r\nentire poem, and when the sufferer is sincere they are right in\r\nregarding his outburst as sublime.\r\n\r\nIt would be difficult to describe the state of stupor in which\r\nVillefort left the Palais. Every pulse beat with feverish excitement,\r\nevery nerve was strained, every vein swollen, and every part of his\r\nbody seemed to suffer distinctly from the rest, thus multiplying his\r\nagony a thousand-fold. He made his way along the corridors through\r\nforce of habit; he threw aside his magisterial robe, not out of\r\ndeference to etiquette, but because it was an unbearable burden, a\r\nveritable garb of Nessus, insatiate in torture. Having staggered as far\r\nas the Rue Dauphine, he perceived his carriage, awoke his sleeping\r\ncoachman by opening the door himself, threw himself on the cushions,\r\nand pointed towards the Faubourg Saint-Honor\xc3\xa9; the carriage drove on.\r\n\r\nAll the weight of his fallen fortune seemed suddenly to crush him; he\r\ncould not foresee the consequences; he could not contemplate the future\r\nwith the indifference of the hardened criminal who merely faces a\r\ncontingency already familiar.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nGod was still in his heart. \xe2\x80\x9cGod,\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured, not knowing what he\r\nsaid,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGod\xe2\x80\x94God!\xe2\x80\x9d Behind the event that had overwhelmed him he saw the\r\nhand of God. The carriage rolled rapidly onward. Villefort, while\r\nturning restlessly on the cushions, felt something press against him.\r\nHe put out his hand to remove the object; it was a fan which Madame de\r\nVillefort had left in the carriage; this fan awakened a recollection\r\nwhich darted through his mind like lightning. He thought of his wife.\r\n\r\n50189m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, as though a red-hot iron were piercing his heart.\r\n\r\nDuring the last hour his own crime had alone been presented to his\r\nmind; now another object, not less terrible, suddenly presented itself.\r\nHis wife! He had just acted the inexorable judge with her, he had\r\ncondemned her to death, and she, crushed by remorse, struck with\r\nterror, covered with the shame inspired by the eloquence of _his_\r\nirreproachable virtue,\xe2\x80\x94she, a poor, weak woman, without help or the\r\npower of defending herself against his absolute and supreme will,\xe2\x80\x94she\r\nmight at that very moment, perhaps, be preparing to die!\r\n\r\nAn hour had elapsed since her condemnation; at that moment, doubtless,\r\nshe was recalling all her crimes to her memory; she was asking pardon\r\nfor her sins; perhaps she was even writing a letter imploring\r\nforgiveness from her virtuous husband\xe2\x80\x94a forgiveness she was purchasing\r\nwith her death! Villefort again groaned with anguish and despair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cthat woman became criminal only from associating\r\nwith me! I carried the infection of crime with me, and she has caught\r\nit as she would the typhus fever, the cholera, the plague! And yet I\r\nhave punished her\xe2\x80\x94I have dared to tell her\xe2\x80\x94_I_ have\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Repent and die!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nBut no, she must not die; she shall live, and with me. We will flee\r\nfrom Paris and go as far as the earth reaches. I told her of the\r\nscaffold; oh, Heavens, I forgot that it awaits me also! How could I\r\npronounce that word? Yes, we will fly; I will confess all to her,\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nwill tell her daily that I also have committed a crime!\xe2\x80\x94Oh, what an\r\nalliance\xe2\x80\x94the tiger and the serpent; worthy wife of such as I am! She\r\n_must_ live that my infamy may diminish hers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Villefort dashed open the window in front of the carriage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFaster, faster!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, in a tone which electrified the coachman.\r\nThe horses, impelled by fear, flew towards the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Villefort, as he approached his home\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyes, that\r\nwoman must live; she must repent, and educate my son, the sole\r\nsurvivor, with the exception of the indestructible old man, of the\r\nwreck of my house. She loves him; it was for his sake she has committed\r\nthese crimes. We ought never to despair of softening the heart of a\r\nmother who loves her child. She will repent, and no one will know that\r\nshe has been guilty. The events which have taken place in my house,\r\nthough they now occupy the public mind, will be forgotten in time, or\r\nif, indeed, a few enemies should persist in remembering them, why then\r\nI will add them to my list of crimes. What will it signify if one, two,\r\nor three more are added? My wife and child shall escape from this gulf,\r\ncarrying treasures with them; she will live and may yet be happy, since\r\nher child, in whom all her love is centred, will be with her. I shall\r\nhave performed a good action, and my heart will be lighter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the procureur breathed more freely than he had done for some time.\r\n\r\n50191m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe carriage stopped at the door of the house. Villefort leaped out of\r\nthe carriage, and saw that his servants were surprised at his early\r\nreturn; he could read no other expression on their features. Neither of\r\nthem spoke to him; they merely stood aside to let him pass by, as\r\nusual, nothing more. As he passed by M. Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s room, he perceived\r\ntwo figures through the half-open door; but he experienced no curiosity\r\nto know who was visiting his father; anxiety carried him on further.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he ascended the stairs leading to his wife\xe2\x80\x99s room,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnothing is changed here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then closed the door of the landing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one must disturb us,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cI must speak freely to her, accuse\r\nmyself, and say\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he approached the door, touched the crystal handle,\r\nwhich yielded to his hand. \xe2\x80\x9cNot locked,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he entered the little room in which Edward slept; for though the\r\nchild went to school during the day, his mother could not allow him to\r\nbe separated from her at night. With a single glance Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s eye\r\nran through the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cdoubtless she is in her bedroom.\xe2\x80\x9d He rushed\r\ntowards the door, found it bolted, and stopped, shuddering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cH\xc3\xa9lo\xc3\xafse!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. He fancied he heard the sound of a piece of\r\nfurniture being removed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cH\xc3\xa9lo\xc3\xafse!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is there?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the voice of her he sought. He thought that\r\nvoice more feeble than usual.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOpen the door!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Villefort. \xe2\x80\x9cOpen; it is I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut notwithstanding this request, notwithstanding the tone of anguish\r\nin which it was uttered, the door remained closed. Villefort burst it\r\nopen with a violent blow. At the entrance of the room which led to her\r\nboudoir, Madame de Villefort was standing erect, pale, her features\r\ncontracted, and her eyes glaring horribly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cH\xc3\xa9lo\xc3\xafse, H\xc3\xa9lo\xc3\xafse!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is the matter? Speak!\xe2\x80\x9d The young\r\nwoman extended her stiff white hands towards him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is done, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d she said with a rattling noise which seemed to\r\ntear her throat. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat more do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d and she fell full length on\r\nthe floor.\r\n\r\nVillefort ran to her and seized her hand, which convulsively clasped a\r\ncrystal bottle with a golden stopper. Madame de Villefort was dead.\r\nVillefort, maddened with horror, stepped back to the threshhold of the\r\ndoor, fixing his eyes on the corpse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy son!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed suddenly, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere is my son?\xe2\x80\x94Edward, Edward!\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nhe rushed out of the room, still crying, \xe2\x80\x9cEdward, Edward!\xe2\x80\x9d The name was\r\npronounced in such a tone of anguish that the servants ran up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is my son?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Villefort; \xe2\x80\x9clet him be removed from the house,\r\nthat he may not see\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaster Edward is not downstairs, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the valet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he must be playing in the garden; go and see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50193m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir; Madame de Villefort sent for him half an hour ago; he went\r\ninto her room, and has not been downstairs since.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA cold perspiration burst out on Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s brow; his legs trembled,\r\nand his thoughts flew about madly in his brain like the wheels of a\r\ndisordered watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn Madame de Villefort\xe2\x80\x99s room?\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured and slowly returned, with\r\none hand wiping his forehead, and with the other supporting himself\r\nagainst the wall. To enter the room he must again see the body of his\r\nunfortunate wife. To call Edward he must reawaken the echo of that room\r\nwhich now appeared like a sepulchre; to speak seemed like violating the\r\nsilence of the tomb. His tongue was paralyzed in his mouth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdward!\xe2\x80\x9d he stammered\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cEdward!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe child did not answer. Where, then, could he be, if he had entered\r\nhis mother\xe2\x80\x99s room and not since returned? He stepped forward. The\r\ncorpse of Madame de Villefort was stretched across the doorway leading\r\nto the room in which Edward must be; those glaring eyes seemed to watch\r\nover the threshold, and the lips bore the stamp of a terrible and\r\nmysterious irony. Through the open door was visible a portion of the\r\nboudoir, containing an upright piano and a blue satin couch. Villefort\r\nstepped forward two or three paces, and beheld his child lying\xe2\x80\x94no doubt\r\nasleep\xe2\x80\x94on the sofa. The unhappy man uttered an exclamation of joy; a\r\nray of light seemed to penetrate the abyss of despair and darkness. He\r\nhad only to step over the corpse, enter the boudoir, take the child in\r\nhis arms, and flee far, far away.\r\n\r\nVillefort was no longer the civilized man; he was a tiger hurt unto\r\ndeath, gnashing his teeth in his wound. He no longer feared realities,\r\nbut phantoms. He leaped over the corpse as if it had been a burning\r\nbrazier. He took the child in his arms, embraced him, shook him, called\r\nhim, but the child made no response. He pressed his burning lips to the\r\ncheeks, but they were icy cold and pale; he felt the stiffened limbs;\r\nhe pressed his hand upon the heart, but it no longer beat,\xe2\x80\x94the child\r\nwas dead.\r\n\r\nA folded paper fell from Edward\xe2\x80\x99s breast. Villefort, thunderstruck,\r\nfell upon his knees; the child dropped from his arms, and rolled on the\r\nfloor by the side of its mother. He picked up the paper, and,\r\nrecognizing his wife\xe2\x80\x99s writing, ran his eyes rapidly over its contents;\r\nit ran as follows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know that I was a good mother, since it was for my son\xe2\x80\x99s sake I\r\nbecame criminal. A good mother cannot depart without her son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort could not believe his eyes,\xe2\x80\x94he could not believe his reason;\r\nhe dragged himself towards the child\xe2\x80\x99s body, and examined it as a\r\nlioness contemplates its dead cub. Then a piercing cry escaped from his\r\nbreast, and he cried,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill the hand of God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe presence of the two victims alarmed him; he could not bear solitude\r\nshared only by two corpses. Until then he had been sustained by rage,\r\nby his strength of mind, by despair, by the supreme agony which led the\r\nTitans to scale the heavens, and Ajax to defy the gods. He now arose,\r\nhis head bowed beneath the weight of grief, and, shaking his damp,\r\ndishevelled hair, he who had never felt compassion for anyone\r\ndetermined to seek his father, that he might have someone to whom he\r\ncould relate his misfortunes,\xe2\x80\x94someone by whose side he might weep.\r\n\r\n50195m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nHe descended the little staircase with which we are acquainted, and\r\nentered Noirtier\xe2\x80\x99s room. The old man appeared to be listening\r\nattentively and as affectionately as his infirmities would allow to the\r\nAbb\xc3\xa9 Busoni, who looked cold and calm, as usual. Villefort, perceiving\r\nthe abb\xc3\xa9, passed his hand across his brow. The past came to him like\r\none of those waves whose wrath foams fiercer than the others.\r\n\r\nHe recollected the call he had made upon him after the dinner at\r\nAuteuil, and then the visit the abb\xc3\xa9 had himself paid to his house on\r\nthe day of Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s death.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou here, sir!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed; \xe2\x80\x9cdo you, then, never appear but to act\r\nas an escort to death?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBusoni turned around, and, perceiving the excitement depicted on the\r\nmagistrate\xe2\x80\x99s face, the savage lustre of his eyes, he understood that\r\nthe revelation had been made at the assizes; but beyond this he was\r\nignorant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI came to pray over the body of your daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now why are you here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI come to tell you that you have sufficiently repaid your debt, and\r\nthat from this moment I will pray to God to forgive you, as I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood heavens!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Villefort, stepping back fearfully, \xe2\x80\x9csurely\r\nthat is not the voice of the Abb\xc3\xa9 Busoni!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d The abb\xc3\xa9 threw off his wig, shook his head, and his hair, no\r\nlonger confined, fell in black masses around his manly face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the face of the Count of Monte Cristo!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the procureur,\r\nwith a haggard expression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are not exactly right, M. Procureur; you must go farther back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat voice, that voice!\xe2\x80\x94where did I first hear it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou heard it for the first time at Marseilles, twenty-three years ago,\r\nthe day of your marriage with Mademoiselle de Saint-M\xc3\xa9ran. Refer to\r\nyour papers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are not Busoni?\xe2\x80\x94you are not Monte Cristo? Oh, heavens! you are,\r\nthen, some secret, implacable, and mortal enemy! I must have wronged\r\nyou in some way at Marseilles. Oh, woe to me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; you are now on the right path,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, crossing his arms\r\nover his broad chest; \xe2\x80\x9csearch\xe2\x80\x94search!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what have I done to you?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Villefort, whose mind was\r\nbalancing between reason and insanity, in that cloud which is neither a\r\ndream nor reality; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat have I done to you? Tell me, then! Speak!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou condemned me to a horrible, tedious death; you killed my father;\r\nyou deprived me of liberty, of love, and happiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you, then? Who are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am the spectre of a wretch you buried in the dungeons of the Ch\xc3\xa2teau\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99If. God gave that spectre the form of the Count of Monte Cristo when\r\nhe at length issued from his tomb, enriched him with gold and diamonds,\r\nand led him to you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, I recognize you\xe2\x80\x94I recognize you!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the king\xe2\x80\x99s attorney;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou are\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Villefort, seizing the count by the\r\nwrist; \xe2\x80\x9cthen come here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd up the stairs he dragged Monte Cristo; who, ignorant of what had\r\nhappened, followed him in astonishment, foreseeing some new\r\ncatastrophe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, pointing to the bodies of his wife and\r\nchild, \xe2\x80\x9csee, are you well avenged?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo became pale at this horrible sight; he felt that he had\r\npassed beyond the bounds of vengeance, and that he could no longer say,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod is for and with me.\xe2\x80\x9d With an expression of indescribable anguish\r\nhe threw himself upon the body of the child, reopened its eyes, felt\r\nits pulse, and then rushed with him into Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s room, of which he\r\ndouble-locked the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy child,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Villefort, \xe2\x80\x9che carries away the body of my child! Oh,\r\ncurses, woe, death to you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe tried to follow Monte Cristo; but as though in a dream he was\r\ntransfixed to the spot,\xe2\x80\x94his eyes glared as though they were starting\r\nthrough the sockets; he griped the flesh on his chest until his nails\r\nwere stained with blood; the veins of his temples swelled and boiled as\r\nthough they would burst their narrow boundary, and deluge his brain\r\nwith living fire. This lasted several minutes, until the frightful\r\noverturn of reason was accomplished; then uttering a loud cry followed\r\nby a burst of laughter, he rushed down the stairs.\r\n\r\nA quarter of an hour afterwards the door of Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s room opened,\r\nand Monte Cristo reappeared. Pale, with a dull eye and heavy heart, all\r\nthe noble features of that face, usually so calm and serene, were\r\novercast by grief. In his arms he held the child, whom no skill had\r\nbeen able to recall to life. Bending on one knee, he placed it\r\nreverently by the side of its mother, with its head upon her breast.\r\nThen, rising, he went out, and meeting a servant on the stairs, he\r\nasked:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is M. de Villefort?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe servant, instead of answering, pointed to the garden. Monte Cristo\r\nran down the steps, and advancing towards the spot designated beheld\r\nVillefort, encircled by his servants, with a spade in his hand, and\r\ndigging the earth with fury.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not here!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not here!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50197m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd then he moved farther on, and began again to dig.\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo approached him, and said in a low voice, with an\r\nexpression almost humble:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, you have indeed lost a son; but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVillefort interrupted him; he had neither listened nor heard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I _will_ find it,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried; \xe2\x80\x9cyou may pretend he is not here, but\r\nI _will_ find him, though I dig forever!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo drew back in horror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9che is mad!\xe2\x80\x9d And as though he feared that the walls of\r\nthe accursed house would crumble around him, he rushed into the street,\r\nfor the first time doubting whether he had the right to do as he had\r\ndone. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, enough of this,\xe2\x80\x94enough of this,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried; \xe2\x80\x9clet me save the\r\nlast.\xe2\x80\x9d On entering his house, he met Morrel, who wandered about like a\r\nghost awaiting the heavenly mandate for return to the tomb.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrepare yourself, Maximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d he said with a smile; \xe2\x80\x9cwe leave Paris\r\ntomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you nothing more to do there?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9cGod grant I may not have done too much\r\nalready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe next day they indeed left, accompanied only by Baptistin. Hayd\xc3\xa9e\r\nhad taken away Ali, and Bertuccio remained with Noirtier.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 112. The Departure\r\n\r\nThe recent events formed the theme of conversation throughout all\r\nParis. Emmanuel and his wife conversed with natural astonishment in\r\ntheir little apartment in the Rue Meslay upon the three successive,\r\nsudden, and most unexpected catastrophes of Morcerf, Danglars, and\r\nVillefort. Maximilian, who was paying them a visit, listened to their\r\nconversation, or rather was present at it, plunged in his accustomed\r\nstate of apathy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Julie, \xe2\x80\x9cmight we not almost fancy, Emmanuel, that those\r\npeople, so rich, so happy but yesterday, had forgotten in their\r\nprosperity that an evil genius\xe2\x80\x94like the wicked fairies in Perrault\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nstories who present themselves unbidden at a wedding or baptism\xe2\x80\x94hovered\r\nover them, and appeared all at once to revenge himself for their fatal\r\nneglect?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a dire misfortune!\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmanuel, thinking of Morcerf and\r\nDanglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat dreadful sufferings!\xe2\x80\x9d said Julie, remembering Valentine, but\r\nwhom, with a delicacy natural to women, she did not name before her\r\nbrother.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf the Supreme Being has directed the fatal blow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emmanuel, \xe2\x80\x9cit\r\nmust be that he in his great goodness has perceived nothing in the past\r\nlives of these people to merit mitigation of their awful punishment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you not form a very rash judgment, Emmanuel?\xe2\x80\x9d said Julie. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen my\r\nfather, with a pistol in his hand, was once on the point of committing\r\nsuicide, had anyone then said, \xe2\x80\x98This man deserves his misery,\xe2\x80\x99 would\r\nnot that person have been deceived?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but your father was not allowed to fall. A being was commissioned\r\nto arrest the fatal hand of death about to descend on him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEmmanuel had scarcely uttered these words when the sound of the bell\r\nwas heard, the well-known signal given by the porter that a visitor had\r\narrived. Nearly at the same instant the door was opened and the Count\r\nof Monte Cristo appeared on the threshold. The young people uttered a\r\ncry of joy, while Maximilian raised his head, but let it fall again\r\nimmediately.\r\n\r\n50201m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, without appearing to notice the different\r\nimpressions which his presence produced on the little circle, \xe2\x80\x9cI come\r\nto seek you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo seek me?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Morrel, as if awakening from a dream.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo; \xe2\x80\x9chas it not been agreed that I should take\r\nyou with me, and did I not tell you yesterday to prepare for\r\ndeparture?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am ready,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian; \xe2\x80\x9cI came expressly to wish them\r\nfarewell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhither are you going, count?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Julie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first instance to Marseilles, madame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Marseilles!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the young couple.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and I take your brother with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, count.\xe2\x80\x9d said Julie, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you restore him to us cured of his\r\nmelancholy?\xe2\x80\x9d Morrel turned away to conceal the confusion of his\r\ncountenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou perceive, then, that he is not happy?\xe2\x80\x9d said the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young woman; \xe2\x80\x9cand fear much that he finds our home\r\nbut a dull one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will undertake to divert him,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am ready to accompany you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian. \xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, my kind\r\nfriends! Emmanuel\xe2\x80\x94Julie\xe2\x80\x94farewell!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow farewell?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Julie; \xe2\x80\x9cdo you leave us thus, so suddenly,\r\nwithout any preparations for your journey, without even a passport?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNeedless delays but increase the grief of parting,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand Maximilian has doubtless provided himself with everything\r\nrequisite; at least, I advised him to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a passport, and my clothes are ready packed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel in\r\nhis tranquil but mournful manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cin these prompt arrangements we\r\nrecognize the order of a well-disciplined soldier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you leave us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Julie, \xe2\x80\x9cat a moment\xe2\x80\x99s warning? you do not give\r\nus a day\xe2\x80\x94no, not even an hour before your departure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy carriage is at the door, madame, and I must be in Rome in five\r\ndays.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut does Maximilian go to Rome?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Emmanuel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going wherever it may please the count to take me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel,\r\nwith a smile full of grief; \xe2\x80\x9cI am under his orders for the next month.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, heavens, how strangely he expresses himself, count!\xe2\x80\x9d said Julie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian goes with _me_,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, in his kindest and most\r\npersuasive manner; \xe2\x80\x9ctherefore do not make yourself uneasy on your\r\nbrother\xe2\x80\x99s account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnce more farewell, my dear sister; Emmanuel, adieu!\xe2\x80\x9d Morrel repeated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis carelessness and indifference touch me to the heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said Julie.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Maximilian, Maximilian, you are certainly concealing something\r\nfrom us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPshaw!\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will see him return to you gay,\r\nsmiling, and joyful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMaximilian cast a look of disdain, almost of anger, on the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must leave you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo.\r\n\r\n50203m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBefore you quit us, count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Julie, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you permit us to express\r\nto you all that the other day\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the count, taking her two hands in his, \xe2\x80\x9call that\r\nyou could say in words would never express what I read in your eyes;\r\nthe thoughts of your heart are fully understood by mine. Like\r\nbenefactors in romances, I should have left you without seeing you\r\nagain, but that would have been a virtue beyond my strength, because I\r\nam a weak and vain man, fond of the tender, kind, and thankful glances\r\nof my fellow-creatures. On the eve of departure I carry my egotism so\r\nfar as to say, \xe2\x80\x98Do not forget me, my kind friends, for probably you\r\nwill never see me again.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever see you again?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Emmanuel, while two large tears rolled\r\ndown Julie\xe2\x80\x99s cheeks, \xe2\x80\x9cnever behold you again? It is not a man, then,\r\nbut some angel that leaves us, and this angel is on the point of\r\nreturning to heaven after having appeared on earth to do good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay not so,\xe2\x80\x9d quickly returned Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9csay not so, my friends;\r\nangels never err, celestial beings remain where they wish to be. Fate\r\nis not more powerful than they; it is they who, on the contrary,\r\novercome fate. No, Emmanuel, I am but a man, and your admiration is as\r\nunmerited as your words are sacrilegious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd pressing his lips on the hand of Julie, who rushed into his arms,\r\nhe extended his other hand to Emmanuel; then tearing himself from this\r\nabode of peace and happiness, he made a sign to Maximilian, who\r\nfollowed him passively, with the indifference which had been\r\nperceptible in him ever since the death of Valentine had so stunned\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRestore my brother to peace and happiness,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Julie to Monte\r\nCristo. And the count pressed her hand in reply, as he had done eleven\r\nyears before on the staircase leading to Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s study.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou still confide, then, in Sinbad the Sailor?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d was the ready answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, sleep in peace, and put your trust in the Lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs we have before said, the post-chaise was waiting; four powerful\r\nhorses were already pawing the ground with impatience, while Ali,\r\napparently just arrived from a long walk, was standing at the foot of\r\nthe steps, his face bathed in perspiration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count in Arabic, \xe2\x80\x9chave you been to see the old man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAli made a sign in the affirmative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd have you placed the letter before him, as I ordered you to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe slave respectfully signalized that he had.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did he say, or rather do?\xe2\x80\x9d Ali placed himself in the light,\r\nso that his master might see him distinctly, and then imitating in his\r\nintelligent manner the countenance of the old man, he closed his eyes,\r\nas Noirtier was in the custom of doing when saying \xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood; he accepts,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo. \xe2\x80\x9cNow let us go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50205m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThese words had scarcely escaped him, when the carriage was on its way,\r\nand the feet of the horses struck a shower of sparks from the pavement.\r\nMaximilian settled himself in his corner without uttering a word. Half\r\nan hour had passed when the carriage stopped suddenly; the count had\r\njust pulled the silken check-string, which was fastened to Ali\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfinger. The Nubian immediately descended and opened the carriage door.\r\nIt was a lovely starlight night\xe2\x80\x94they had just reached the top of the\r\nhill Villejuif, from whence Paris appears like a sombre sea tossing its\r\nmillions of phosphoric waves into light\xe2\x80\x94waves indeed more noisy, more\r\npassionate, more changeable, more furious, more greedy, than those of\r\nthe tempestuous ocean,\xe2\x80\x94waves which never rest as those of the sea\r\nsometimes do,\xe2\x80\x94waves ever dashing, ever foaming, ever ingulfing what\r\nfalls within their grasp.\r\n\r\nThe count stood alone, and at a sign from his hand, the carriage went\r\non for a short distance. With folded arms, he gazed for some time upon\r\nthe great city. When he had fixed his piercing look on this modern\r\nBabylon, which equally engages the contemplation of the religious\r\nenthusiast, the materialist, and the scoffer,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGreat city,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he, inclining his head, and joining his hands as\r\nif in prayer, \xe2\x80\x9cless than six months have elapsed since first I entered\r\nthy gates. I believe that the Spirit of God led my steps to thee and\r\nthat he also enables me to quit thee in triumph; the secret cause of my\r\npresence within thy walls I have confided alone to him who only has had\r\nthe power to read my heart. God only knows that I retire from thee\r\nwithout pride or hatred, but not without many regrets; he only knows\r\nthat the power confided to me has never been made subservient to my\r\npersonal good or to any useless cause. Oh, great city, it is in thy\r\npalpitating bosom that I have found that which I sought; like a patient\r\nminer, I have dug deep into thy very entrails to root out evil thence.\r\nNow my work is accomplished, my mission is terminated, now thou canst\r\nneither afford me pain nor pleasure. Adieu, Paris, adieu!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis look wandered over the vast plain like that of some genius of the\r\nnight; he passed his hand over his brow, got into the carriage, the\r\ndoor was closed on him, and the vehicle quickly disappeared down the\r\nother side of the hill in a whirlwind of dust and noise.\r\n\r\nTen leagues were passed and not a single word was uttered. Morrel was\r\ndreaming, and Monte Cristo was looking at the dreamer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMorrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count to him at length, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you repent having\r\nfollowed me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, count; but to leave Paris\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I thought happiness might await you in Paris, Morrel, I would have\r\nleft you there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine reposes within the walls of Paris, and to leave Paris is\r\nlike losing her a second time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cthe friends that we have lost do not\r\nrepose in the bosom of the earth, but are buried deep in our hearts,\r\nand it has been thus ordained that we may always be accompanied by\r\nthem. I have two friends, who in this way never depart from me; the one\r\nwho gave me being, and the other who conferred knowledge and\r\nintelligence on me. Their spirits live in me. I consult them when\r\ndoubtful, and if I ever do any good, it is due to their beneficent\r\ncounsels. Listen to the voice of your heart, Morrel, and ask it whether\r\nyou ought to preserve this melancholy exterior towards me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cthe voice of my heart is very sorrowful,\r\nand promises me nothing but misfortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the way of weakened minds to see everything through a black\r\ncloud. The soul forms its own horizons; your soul is darkened, and\r\nconsequently the sky of the future appears stormy and unpromising.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat may possibly be true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, and he again subsided\r\ninto his thoughtful mood.\r\n\r\nThe journey was performed with that marvellous rapidity which the\r\nunlimited power of the count ever commanded. Towns fled from them like\r\nshadows on their path, and trees shaken by the first winds of autumn\r\nseemed like giants madly rushing on to meet them, and retreating as\r\nrapidly when once reached.
