Danglars knew\r\nthat he was heard, so he redoubled his blows.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Che cosa?_\xe2\x80\x9d asked the bandit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, tapping his fingers against the door, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nthink it is quite time to think of giving me something to eat!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut whether he did not understand him, or whether he had received no\r\norders respecting the nourishment of Danglars, the giant, without\r\nanswering, went on with his dinner. Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 feelings were hurt, and\r\nnot wishing to put himself under obligations to the brute, the banker\r\nthrew himself down again on his goat-skin and did not breathe another\r\nword.\r\n\r\nFour hours passed by and the giant was replaced by another bandit.\r\nDanglars, who really began to experience sundry gnawings at the\r\nstomach, arose softly, again applied his eye to the crack of the door,\r\nand recognized the intelligent countenance of his guide. It was,\r\nindeed, Peppino who was preparing to mount guard as comfortably as\r\npossible by seating himself opposite to the door, and placing between\r\nhis legs an earthen pan, containing chick-peas stewed with bacon. Near\r\nthe pan he also placed a pretty little basket of Villetri grapes and a\r\nflask of Orvieto. Peppino was decidedly an epicure. Danglars watched\r\nthese preparations and his mouth watered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, \xe2\x80\x9clet me try if he will be more tractable\r\nthan the other;\xe2\x80\x9d and he tapped gently at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_On y va_,\xe2\x80\x9d (coming) exclaimed Peppino, who from frequenting the house\r\nof Signor Pastrini understood French perfectly in all its idioms.\r\n\r\nDanglars immediately recognized him as the man who had called out in\r\nsuch a furious manner, \xe2\x80\x9cPut in your head!\xe2\x80\x9d But this was not the time\r\nfor recrimination, so he assumed his most agreeable manner and said\r\nwith a gracious smile:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, sir, but are they not going to give me any dinner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes your excellency happen to be hungry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHappen to be hungry,\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s pretty good, when I haven\xe2\x80\x99t eaten for\r\ntwenty-four hours!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Danglars. Then he added aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir,\r\nI am hungry\xe2\x80\x94very hungry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd your excellency wants something to eat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt once, if possible\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing easier,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peppino. \xe2\x80\x9cHere you can get anything you want; by\r\npaying for it, of course, as among honest folk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Danglars. \xe2\x80\x9cAlthough, in justice, the people who\r\narrest and imprison you, ought, at least, to feed you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not the custom, excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peppino.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA bad reason,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Danglars, who reckoned on conciliating his\r\nkeeper; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I am content. Let me have some dinner!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt once! What would your excellency like?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Peppino placed his pan on the ground, so that the steam rose\r\ndirectly under the nostrils of Danglars. \xe2\x80\x9cGive your orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you kitchens here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKitchens?\xe2\x80\x94of course\xe2\x80\x94complete ones.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd cooks?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcellent!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, a fowl, fish, game,\xe2\x80\x94it signifies little, so that I eat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs your excellency pleases. You mentioned a fowl, I think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a fowl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPeppino, turning around, shouted, \xe2\x80\x9cA fowl for his excellency!\xe2\x80\x9d His\r\nvoice yet echoed in the archway when a handsome, graceful, and\r\nhalf-naked young man appeared, bearing a fowl in a silver dish on his\r\nhead, without the assistance of his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could almost believe myself at the Caf\xc3\xa9 de Paris,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured\r\nDanglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peppino, taking the fowl from the young\r\nbandit and placing it on the worm-eaten table, which with the stool and\r\nthe goat-skin bed formed the entire furniture of the cell. Danglars\r\nasked for a knife and fork.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peppino, offering him a little blunt knife and\r\na boxwood fork. Danglars took the knife in one hand and the fork in the\r\nother, and was about to cut up the fowl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peppino, placing his hand on the banker\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nshoulder; \xe2\x80\x9cpeople pay here before they eat. They might not be\r\nsatisfied, and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ha,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is not so much like Paris, except\r\nthat I shall probably be skinned! Never mind, I\xe2\x80\x99ll fix that all right.\r\nI have always heard how cheap poultry is in Italy; I should think a\r\nfowl is worth about twelve sous at Rome.\xe2\x80\x94There,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, throwing a\r\nlouis down.\r\n\r\nPeppino picked up the louis, and Danglars again prepared to carve the\r\nfowl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay a moment, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peppino, rising; \xe2\x80\x9cyou still owe\r\nme something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said they would skin me,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Danglars; but resolving to resist\r\nthe extortion, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cCome, how much do I owe you for this fowl?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency has given me a louis on account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA louis on account for a fowl?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; and your excellency now owes me 4,999 louis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars opened his enormous eyes on hearing this gigantic joke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery droll,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, \xe2\x80\x9cvery droll indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d and he again began to\r\ncarve the fowl, when Peppino stopped the baron\xe2\x80\x99s right hand with his\r\nleft, and held out his other hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it not a joke?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe never joke,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Peppino, solemn as a Quaker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! A hundred thousand francs for a fowl!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, excellency, you cannot imagine how hard it is to rear fowls in\r\nthese horrible caves!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, this is very droll\xe2\x80\x94very amusing\xe2\x80\x94I allow; but, as I am very\r\nhungry, pray allow me to eat. Stay, here is another louis for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen that will make only 4,998 louis more,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peppino with the same\r\nindifference. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall get them all in time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, as for that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, angry at this prolongation of the\r\njest,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cas for that you won\xe2\x80\x99t get them at all. Go to the devil! You do\r\nnot know with whom you have to deal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50253m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nPeppino made a sign, and the youth hastily removed the fowl. Danglars\r\nthrew himself upon his goat-skin, and Peppino, reclosing the door,\r\nagain began eating his peas and bacon. Though Danglars could not see\r\nPeppino, the noise of his teeth allowed no doubt as to his occupation.\r\nHe was certainly eating, and noisily too, like an ill-bred man.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrute!\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars. Peppino pretended not to hear him, and without\r\neven turning his head continued to eat slowly. Danglars\xe2\x80\x99 stomach felt\r\nso empty, that it seemed as if it would be impossible ever to fill it\r\nagain; still he had patience for another half-hour, which appeared to\r\nhim like a century. He again arose and went to the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, sir, do not keep me starving here any longer, but tell me what\r\nthey want.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, your excellency, it is you who should tell us what you want. Give\r\nyour orders, and we will execute them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen open the door directly.\xe2\x80\x9d Peppino obeyed. \xe2\x80\x9cNow look here, I want\r\nsomething to eat! To eat\xe2\x80\x94do you hear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you hungry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, you understand me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would your excellency like to eat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA piece of dry bread, since the fowls are beyond all price in this\r\naccursed place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBread? Very well. Holloa, there, some bread!\xe2\x80\x9d he called. The youth\r\nbrought a small loaf. \xe2\x80\x9cHow much?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFour thousand nine hundred and ninety-eight louis,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peppino; \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nhave paid two louis in advance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50255m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat? One hundred thousand francs for a loaf?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne hundred thousand francs,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Peppino.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you only asked 100,000 francs for a fowl!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have a fixed price for all our provisions. It signifies nothing\r\nwhether you eat much or little\xe2\x80\x94whether you have ten dishes or one\xe2\x80\x94it is\r\nalways the same price.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, still keeping up this silly jest? My dear fellow, it is\r\nperfectly ridiculous\xe2\x80\x94stupid! You had better tell me at once that you\r\nintend starving me to death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear, no, your excellency, unless you intend to commit suicide.\r\nPay and eat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what am I to pay with, brute?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, enraged. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you\r\nsuppose I carry 100,000 francs in my pocket?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency has 5,050,000 francs in your pocket; that will be\r\nfifty fowls at 100,000 francs apiece, and half a fowl for the 50,000.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars shuddered. The bandage fell from his eyes, and he understood\r\nthe joke, which he did not think quite so stupid as he had done just\r\nbefore.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cif I pay you the 100,000 francs, will you be\r\nsatisfied, and allow me to eat at my ease?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peppino.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how can I pay them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing easier; you have an account open with Messrs. Thomson &\r\nFrench, Via dei Banchi, Rome; give me a draft for 4,998 louis on these\r\ngentlemen, and our banker shall take it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars thought it as well to comply with a good grace, so he took the\r\npen, ink, and paper Peppino offered him, wrote the draft, and signed\r\nit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9chere is a draft at sight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd here is your fowl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars sighed while he carved the fowl; it appeared very thin for the\r\nprice it had cost. As for Peppino, he examined the paper attentively,\r\nput it into his pocket, and continued eating his peas.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 116. The Pardon\r\n\r\nThe next day Danglars was again hungry; certainly the air of that\r\ndungeon was very provocative of appetite. The prisoner expected that he\r\nwould be at no expense that day, for like an economical man he had\r\nconcealed half of his fowl and a piece of the bread in the corner of\r\nhis cell. But he had no sooner eaten than he felt thirsty; he had\r\nforgotten that. He struggled against his thirst till his tongue clave\r\nto the roof of his mouth; then, no longer able to resist, he called\r\nout. The sentinel opened the door; it was a new face. He thought it\r\nwould be better to transact business with his old acquaintance, so he\r\nsent for Peppino.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere I am, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said Peppino, with an eagerness which\r\nDanglars thought favorable to him. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething to drink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency knows that wine is beyond all price near Rome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen give me water,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Danglars, endeavoring to parry the blow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, water is even more scarce than wine, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x94there has\r\nbeen such a drought.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cit is the same old story.\xe2\x80\x9d And while he\r\nsmiled as he attempted to regard the affair as a joke, he felt his\r\ntemples get moist with perspiration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, seeing that he made no impression on\r\nPeppino, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will not refuse me a glass of wine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have already told you that we do not sell at retail.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, let me have a bottle of the least expensive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are all the same price.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty-five thousand francs a bottle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Danglars, in a tone whose bitterness Harpagon30 alone\r\nhas been capable of revealing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ctell me that you wish to despoil me of\r\nall; it will be sooner over than devouring me piecemeal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is possible such may be the master\xe2\x80\x99s intention.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe master?\xe2\x80\x94who is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe person to whom you were conducted yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me see him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the next moment Luigi Vampa appeared before Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou sent for me?\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the prisoner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you, sir, the chief of the people who brought me here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your excellency. What then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much do you require for my ransom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerely the 5,000,000 you have about you.\xe2\x80\x9d Danglars felt a dreadful\r\nspasm dart through his heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this is all I have left in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cout of an immense\r\nfortune. If you deprive me of that, take away my life also.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are forbidden to shed your blood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd by whom are you forbidden?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy him we obey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do, then, obey someone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a chief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought you said you were the chief?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I am of these men; but there is another over me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did your superior order you to treat me in this way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut my purse will be exhausted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProbably.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you take a million?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo millions?\xe2\x80\x94three?\xe2\x80\x94four? Come, four? I will give them to you on\r\ncondition that you let me go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you offer me 4,000,000 for what is worth 5,000,000? This is a\r\nkind of usury, banker, that I do not understand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake all, then\xe2\x80\x94take all, I tell you, and kill me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, calm yourself. You will excite your blood, and that would\r\nproduce an appetite it would require a million a day to satisfy. Be\r\nmore economical.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut when I have no more money left to pay you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the infuriated\r\nDanglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you must suffer hunger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuffer hunger?\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, becoming pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost likely,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Vampa coolly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you say you do not wish to kill me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet you will let me perish with hunger?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that is a different thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, wretches,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Danglars, \xe2\x80\x9cI will defy your infamous\r\ncalculations\xe2\x80\x94I would rather die at once! You may torture, torment, kill\r\nme, but you shall not have my signature again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs your excellency pleases,\xe2\x80\x9d said Vampa, as he left the cell.\r\n\r\nDanglars, raving, threw himself on the goat-skin. Who could these men\r\nbe? Who was the invisible chief? What could be his intentions towards\r\nhim? And why, when everyone else was allowed to be ransomed, might he\r\nnot also be? Oh, yes; certainly a speedy, violent death would be a fine\r\nmeans of deceiving these remorseless enemies, who appeared to pursue\r\nhim with such incomprehensible vengeance. But to die? For the first\r\ntime in his life, Danglars contemplated death with a mixture of dread\r\nand desire; the time had come when the implacable spectre, which exists\r\nin the mind of every human creature, arrested his attention and called\r\nout with every pulsation of his heart, \xe2\x80\x9cThou shalt die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars resembled a timid animal excited in the chase; first it flies,\r\nthen despairs, and at last, by the very force of desperation, sometimes\r\nsucceeds in eluding its pursuers. Danglars meditated an escape; but the\r\nwalls were solid rock, a man was sitting reading at the only outlet to\r\nthe cell, and behind that man shapes armed with guns continually\r\npassed. His resolution not to sign lasted two days, after which he\r\noffered a million for some food. They sent him a magnificent supper,\r\nand took his million.\r\n\r\nFrom this time the prisoner resolved to suffer no longer, but to have\r\neverything he wanted. At the end of twelve days, after having made a\r\nsplendid dinner, he reckoned his accounts, and found that he had only\r\n50,000 francs left. Then a strange reaction took place; he who had just\r\nabandoned 5,000,000 endeavored to save the 50,000 francs he had left,\r\nand sooner than give them up he resolved to enter again upon a life of\r\nprivation\xe2\x80\x94he was deluded by the hopefulness that is a premonition of\r\nmadness.\r\n\r\nHe, who for so long a time had forgotten God, began to think that\r\nmiracles were possible\xe2\x80\x94that the accursed cavern might be discovered by\r\nthe officers of the Papal States, who would release him; that then he\r\nwould have 50,000 remaining, which would be sufficient to save him from\r\nstarvation; and finally he prayed that this sum might be preserved to\r\nhim, and as he prayed he wept. Three days passed thus, during which his\r\nprayers were frequent, if not heartfelt. Sometimes he was delirious,\r\nand fancied he saw an old man stretched on a pallet; he, also, was\r\ndying of hunger.\r\n\r\nOn the fourth, he was no longer a man, but a living corpse. He had\r\npicked up every crumb that had been left from his former meals, and was\r\nbeginning to eat the matting which covered the floor of his cell. Then\r\nhe entreated Peppino, as he would a guardian angel, to give him food;\r\nhe offered him 1,000 francs for a mouthful of bread. But Peppino did\r\nnot answer. On the fifth day he dragged himself to the door of the\r\ncell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you not a Christian?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, falling on his knees. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you wish\r\nto assassinate a man who, in the eyes of Heaven, is a brother? Oh, my\r\nformer friends, my former friends!\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured, and fell with his face\r\nto the ground. Then rising in despair, he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cThe chief, the\r\nchief!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Vampa, instantly appearing; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake my last gold,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Danglars, holding out his pocket-book,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand let me live here; I ask no more for liberty\xe2\x80\x94I only ask to live!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you suffer a great deal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, yes, cruelly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill, there have been men who suffered more than you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; those who have died of hunger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars thought of the old man whom, in his hours of delirium, he had\r\nseen groaning on his bed. He struck his forehead on the ground and\r\ngroaned. \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthere have been some who have suffered more\r\nthan I have, but then they must have been martyrs at least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you repent?\xe2\x80\x9d asked a deep, solemn voice, which caused Danglars\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhair to stand on end. His feeble eyes endeavored to distinguish\r\nobjects, and behind the bandit he saw a man enveloped in a cloak, half\r\nlost in the shadow of a stone column.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf what must I repent?\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Danglars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf the evil you have done,\xe2\x80\x9d said the voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes; oh, yes, I do indeed repent.\xe2\x80\x9d And he struck his breast with\r\nhis emaciated fist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I forgive you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, dropping his cloak, and advancing\r\nto the light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Count of Monte Cristo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Danglars, more pale from terror than\r\nhe had been just before from hunger and misery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken\xe2\x80\x94I am not the Count of Monte Cristo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen who are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50261m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am he whom you sold and dishonored\xe2\x80\x94I am he whose betrothed you\r\nprostituted\xe2\x80\x94I am he upon whom you trampled that you might raise\r\nyourself to fortune\xe2\x80\x94I am he whose father you condemned to die of\r\nhunger\xe2\x80\x94I am he whom you also condemned to starvation, and who yet\r\nforgives you, because he hopes to be forgiven\xe2\x80\x94I am Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars uttered a cry, and fell prostrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRise,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cyour life is safe; the same good fortune has\r\nnot happened to your accomplices\xe2\x80\x94one is mad, the other dead. Keep the\r\n50,000 francs you have left\xe2\x80\x94I give them to you. The 5,000,000 you stole\r\nfrom the hospitals has been restored to them by an unknown hand. And\r\nnow eat and drink; I will entertain you tonight. Vampa, when this man\r\nis satisfied, let him be free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDanglars remained prostrate while the count withdrew; when he raised\r\nhis head he saw disappearing down the passage nothing but a shadow,\r\nbefore which the bandits bowed.\r\n\r\nAccording to the count\xe2\x80\x99s directions, Danglars was waited on by Vampa,\r\nwho brought him the best wine and fruits of Italy; then, having\r\nconducted him to the road, and pointed to the post-chaise, left him\r\nleaning against a tree. He remained there all night, not knowing where\r\nhe was. When daylight dawned he saw that he was near a stream; he was\r\nthirsty, and dragged himself towards it. As he stooped down to drink,\r\nhe saw that his hair had become entirely white.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n Chapter 117. The Fifth of October\r\n\r\nIt was about six o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening; an opal-colored light, through\r\nwhich an autumnal sun shed its golden rays, descended on the blue\r\nocean. The heat of the day had gradually decreased, and a light breeze\r\narose, seeming like the respiration of nature on awakening from the\r\nburning siesta of the south. A delicious zephyr played along the coasts\r\nof the Mediterranean, and wafted from shore to shore the sweet perfume\r\nof plants, mingled with the fresh smell of the sea.\r\n\r\nA light yacht, chaste and elegant in its form, was gliding amidst the\r\nfirst dews of night over the immense lake, extending from Gibraltar to\r\nthe Dardanelles, and from Tunis to Venice. The vessel resembled a swan\r\nwith its wings opened towards the wind, gliding on the water. It\r\nadvanced swiftly and gracefully, leaving behind it a glittering stretch\r\nof foam. By degrees the sun disappeared behind the western horizon; but\r\nas though to prove the truth of the fanciful ideas in heathen\r\nmythology, its indiscreet rays reappeared on the summit of every wave,\r\nas if the god of fire had just sunk upon the bosom of Amphitrite, who\r\nin vain endeavored to hide her lover beneath her azure mantle.\r\n\r\nThe yacht moved rapidly on, though there did not appear to be\r\nsufficient wind to ruffle the curls on the head of a young girl.\r\nStanding on the prow was a tall man, of a dark complexion, who saw with\r\ndilating eyes that they were approaching a dark mass of land in the\r\nshape of a cone, which rose from the midst of the waves like the hat of\r\na Catalan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that Monte Cristo?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the traveller, to whose orders the yacht\r\nwas for the time submitted, in a melancholy voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have reached it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have reached it!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the traveller in an accent of\r\nindescribable sadness.\r\n\r\nThen he added, in a low tone, \xe2\x80\x9cYes; that is the haven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd then he again plunged into a train of thought, the character of\r\nwhich was better revealed by a sad smile, than it would have been by\r\ntears. A few minutes afterwards a flash of light, which was\r\nextinguished instantly, was seen on the land, and the sound of firearms\r\nreached the yacht.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, \xe2\x80\x9cthat was the land signal, will\r\nyou answer yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat signal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe captain pointed towards the island, up the side of which ascended a\r\nvolume of smoke, increasing as it rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as if awaking from a dream. \xe2\x80\x9cGive it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe captain gave him a loaded carbine; the traveller slowly raised it,\r\nand fired in the air. Ten minutes afterwards, the sails were furled,\r\nand they cast anchor about a hundred fathoms from the little harbor.\r\nThe gig was already lowered, and in it were four oarsmen and a\r\ncoxswain. The traveller descended, and instead of sitting down at the\r\nstern of the boat, which had been decorated with a blue carpet for his\r\naccommodation, stood up with his arms crossed. The rowers waited, their\r\noars half lifted out of the water, like birds drying their wings.\r\n\r\n50265m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive way,\xe2\x80\x9d said the traveller. The eight oars fell into the sea\r\nsimultaneously without splashing a drop of water, and the boat,\r\nyielding to the impulsion, glided forward. In an instant they found\r\nthemselves in a little harbor, formed in a natural creek; the boat\r\ngrounded on the fine sand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill your excellency be so good as to mount the shoulders of two of\r\nour men, they will carry you ashore?\xe2\x80\x9d The young man answered this\r\ninvitation with a gesture of indifference, and stepped out of the boat;\r\nthe sea immediately rose to his waist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, your excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the pilot, \xe2\x80\x9cyou should not have done\r\nso; our master will scold us for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young man continued to advance, following the sailors, who chose a\r\nfirm footing. Thirty strides brought them to dry land; the young man\r\nstamped on the ground to shake off the wet, and looked around for\r\nsomeone to show him his road, for it was quite dark. Just as he turned,\r\na hand rested on his shoulder, and a voice which made him shudder\r\nexclaimed:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-evening, Maximilian; you are punctual, thank you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, is it you, count?\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, in an almost joyful accent,\r\npressing Monte Cristo\xe2\x80\x99s hand with both his own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; you see I am as exact as you are. But you are dripping, my dear\r\nfellow; you must change your clothes, as Calypso said to Telemachus.\r\nCome, I have a habitation prepared for you in which you will soon\r\nforget fatigue and cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo perceived that the young man had turned around; indeed,\r\nMorrel saw with surprise that the men who had brought him had left\r\nwithout being paid, or uttering a word. Already the sound of their oars\r\nmight be heard as they returned to the yacht.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are looking for the sailors.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I paid them nothing, and yet they are gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind that, Maximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo, smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cI have made\r\nan agreement with the navy, that the access to my island shall be free\r\nof all charge. I have made a bargain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel looked at the count with surprise. \xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are\r\nnot the same here as in Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere you laugh.\xe2\x80\x9d The count\xe2\x80\x99s brow became clouded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right to recall me to myself, Maximilian,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cI was\r\ndelighted to see you again, and forgot for the moment that all\r\nhappiness is fleeting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, no, count,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Maximilian, seizing the count\xe2\x80\x99s hands, \xe2\x80\x9cpray\r\nlaugh; be happy, and prove to me, by your indifference, that life is\r\nendurable to sufferers. Oh, how charitable, kind, and good you are; you\r\naffect this gayety to inspire me with courage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are wrong, Morrel; I was really happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you forget me, so much the better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; for as the gladiator said to the emperor, when he entered the\r\narena, \xe2\x80\x98He who is about to die salutes you.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you are not consoled?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count, surprised.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Morrel, with a glance full of bitter reproach, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you\r\nthink it possible that I could be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you understand the meaning of my words?\r\nYou cannot take me for a commonplace man, a mere rattle, emitting a\r\nvague and senseless noise. When I ask you if you are consoled, I speak\r\nto you as a man for whom the human heart has no secrets. Well, Morrel,\r\nlet us both examine the depths of your heart. Do you still feel the\r\nsame feverish impatience of grief which made you start like a wounded\r\nlion? Have you still that devouring thirst which can only be appeased\r\nin the grave? Are you still actuated by the regret which drags the\r\nliving to the pursuit of death; or are you only suffering from the\r\nprostration of fatigue and the weariness of hope deferred? Has the loss\r\nof memory rendered it impossible for you to weep? Oh, my dear friend,\r\nif this be the case,\xe2\x80\x94if you can no longer weep, if your frozen heart be\r\ndead, if you put all your trust in God, then, Maximilian, you are\r\nconsoled\xe2\x80\x94do not complain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, in a firm and at the same time soft voice,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clisten to me, as to a man whose thoughts are raised to heaven, though\r\nhe remains on earth; I come to die in the arms of a friend. Certainly,\r\nthere are people whom I love. I love my sister Julie,\xe2\x80\x94I love her\r\nhusband Emmanuel; but I require a strong mind to smile on my last\r\nmoments. My sister would be bathed in tears and fainting; I could not\r\nbear to see her suffer. Emmanuel would tear the weapon from my hand,\r\nand alarm the house with his cries. You, count, who are more than\r\nmortal, will, I am sure, lead me to death by a pleasant path, will you\r\nnot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50267m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cI have still one doubt,\xe2\x80\x94are you weak\r\nenough to pride yourself upon your sufferings?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed,\xe2\x80\x94I am calm,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, giving his hand to the count; \xe2\x80\x9cmy\r\npulse does not beat slower or faster than usual. No, I feel that I have\r\nreached the goal, and I will go no farther. You told me to wait and\r\nhope; do you know what you did, unfortunate adviser? I waited a month,\r\nor rather I suffered for a month! I did hope (man is a poor wretched\r\ncreature), I did hope. What I cannot tell,\xe2\x80\x94something wonderful, an\r\nabsurdity, a miracle,\xe2\x80\x94of what nature he alone can tell who has mingled\r\nwith our reason that folly we call hope. Yes, I did wait\xe2\x80\x94yes, I did\r\nhope, count, and during this quarter of an hour we have been talking\r\ntogether, you have unconsciously wounded, tortured my heart, for every\r\nword you have uttered proved that there was no hope for me. Oh, count,\r\nI shall sleep calmly, deliciously in the arms of death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel uttered these words with an energy which made the count shudder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cyou named the fifth of October as the\r\nend of the period of waiting,\xe2\x80\x94today is the fifth of October,\xe2\x80\x9d he took\r\nout his watch, \xe2\x80\x9cit is now nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x94I have yet three hours to\r\nlive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9ccome.\xe2\x80\x9d Morrel mechanically followed the\r\ncount, and they had entered the grotto before he perceived it. He felt\r\na carpet under his feet, a door opened, perfumes surrounded him, and a\r\nbrilliant light dazzled his eyes. Morrel hesitated to advance; he\r\ndreaded the enervating effect of all that he saw. Monte Cristo drew him\r\nin gently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should we not spend the last three hours remaining to us of life,\r\nlike those ancient Romans, who when condemned by Nero, their emperor\r\nand heir, sat down at a table covered with flowers, and gently glided\r\ninto death, amid the perfume of heliotropes and roses?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cAs you please,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cdeath is always death,\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nis forgetfulness, repose, exclusion from life, and therefore from\r\ngrief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe sat down, and Monte Cristo placed himself opposite to him. They were\r\nin the marvellous dining-room before described, where the statues had\r\nbaskets on their heads always filled with fruits and flowers. Morrel\r\nhad looked carelessly around, and had probably noticed nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us talk like men,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking at the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are the epitome of all human knowledge, and\r\nyou seem like a being descended from a wiser and more advanced world\r\nthan ours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is something true in what you say,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, with that\r\nsmile which made him so handsome; \xe2\x80\x9cI have descended from a planet\r\ncalled grief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50269m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe all you tell me without questioning its meaning; for\r\ninstance, you told me to live, and I did live; you told me to hope, and\r\nI almost did so. I am almost inclined to ask you, as though you had\r\nexperienced death, \xe2\x80\x98is it painful to die?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo looked upon Morrel with indescribable tenderness. \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said, \xe2\x80\x9cyes, doubtless it is painful, if you violently break the\r\nouter covering which obstinately begs for life. If you plunge a dagger\r\ninto your flesh, if you insinuate a bullet into your brain, which the\r\nleast shock disorders,\xe2\x80\x94then certainly, you will suffer pain, and you\r\nwill repent quitting a life for a repose you have bought at so dear a\r\nprice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I know that there is a secret of luxury and pain in death, as\r\nwell as in life; the only thing is to understand it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have spoken truly, Maximilian; according to the care we bestow\r\nupon it, death is either a friend who rocks us gently as a nurse, or an\r\nenemy who violently drags the soul from the body. Some day, when the\r\nworld is much older, and when mankind will be masters of all the\r\ndestructive powers in nature, to serve for the general good of\r\nhumanity; when mankind, as you were just saying, have discovered the\r\nsecrets of death, then that death will become as sweet and voluptuous\r\nas a slumber in the arms of your beloved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if you wished to die, you would choose this death, count?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel extended his hand. \xe2\x80\x9cNow I understand,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy you had me\r\nbrought here to this desolate spot, in the midst of the ocean, to this\r\nsubterranean palace; it was because you loved me, was it not, count? It\r\nwas because you loved me well enough to give me one of those sweet\r\nmeans of death of which we were speaking; a death without agony, a\r\ndeath which allows me to fade away while pronouncing Valentine\xe2\x80\x99s name\r\nand pressing your hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you have guessed rightly, Morrel,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is what\r\nI intended.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks; the idea that tomorrow I shall no longer suffer, is sweet to\r\nmy heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you then regret nothing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot even me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the count with deep emotion. Morrel\xe2\x80\x99s clear eye\r\nwas for the moment clouded, then it shone with unusual lustre, and a\r\nlarge tear rolled down his cheek.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you still regret anything in the world, and\r\nyet die?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I entreat you,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Morrel in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not speak\r\nanother word, count; do not prolong my punishment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe count fancied that he was yielding, and this belief revived the\r\nhorrible doubt that had overwhelmed him at the Ch\xc3\xa2teau d\xe2\x80\x99If.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am endeavoring,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cto make this man happy; I look upon\r\nthis restitution as a weight thrown into the scale to balance the evil\r\nI have wrought. Now, supposing I am deceived, supposing this man has\r\nnot been unhappy enough to merit happiness. Alas, what would become of\r\nme who can only atone for evil by doing good?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50271m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThen he said aloud: \xe2\x80\x9cListen, Morrel, I see your grief is great, but\r\nstill you do not like to risk your soul.\xe2\x80\x9d Morrel smiled sadly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI swear to you my soul is no longer my own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaximilian, you know I have no relation in the world. I have\r\naccustomed myself to regard you as my son: well, then, to save my son,\r\nI will sacrifice my life, nay, even my fortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean, that you wish to quit life because you do not understand all\r\nthe enjoyments which are the fruits of a large fortune. Morrel, I\r\npossess nearly a hundred millions and I give them to you; with such a\r\nfortune you can attain every wish. Are you ambitious? Every career is\r\nopen to you. Overturn the world, change its character, yield to mad\r\nideas, be even criminal\xe2\x80\x94but live.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCount, I have your word,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel coldly; then taking out his\r\nwatch, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is half-past eleven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMorrel, can you intend it in my house, under my very eyes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen let me go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Maximilian, \xe2\x80\x9cor I shall think you did not love\r\nme for my own sake, but for yours;\xe2\x80\x9d and he arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Monte Cristo whose countenance brightened at these\r\nwords; \xe2\x80\x9cyou wish it\xe2\x80\x94you are inflexible. Yes, as you said, you are\r\nindeed wretched and a miracle alone can cure you. Sit down, Morrel, and\r\nwait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMorrel obeyed; the count arose, and unlocking a closet with a key\r\nsuspended from his gold chain, took from it a little silver casket,\r\nbeautifully carved and chased, the corners of which represented four\r\nbending figures, similar to the Caryatides, the forms of women, symbols\r\nof the angels aspiring to heaven.\r\n\r\nHe placed the casket on the table; then opening it took out a little\r\ngolden box, the top of which flew open when touched by a secret spring.\r\nThis box contained an unctuous substance partly solid, of which it was\r\nimpossible to discover the color, owing to the reflection of the\r\npolished gold, sapphires, rubies, emeralds, which ornamented the box.\r\nIt was a mixed mass of blue, red, and gold.\r\n\r\nThe count took out a small quantity of this with a gilt spoon, and\r\noffered it to Morrel, fixing a long steadfast glance upon him. It was\r\nthen observable that the substance was greenish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is what you asked for,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand what I promised to give\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you from the depths of my heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, taking\r\nthe spoon from the hands of Monte Cristo. The count took another spoon,\r\nand again dipped it into the golden box. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you going to do, my\r\nfriend?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel, arresting his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the fact is, Morrel, I was thinking that I too am weary of life,\r\nand since an opportunity presents itself\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man. \xe2\x80\x9cYou who love, and are beloved; you, who\r\nhave faith and hope,\xe2\x80\x94oh, do not follow my example. In your case it\r\nwould be a crime. Adieu, my noble and generous friend, adieu; I will go\r\nand tell Valentine what you have done for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd slowly, though without any hesitation, only waiting to press the\r\ncount\xe2\x80\x99s hand fervently, he swallowed the mysterious substance offered\r\nby Monte Cristo. Then they were both silent. Ali, mute and attentive,\r\nbrought the pipes and coffee, and disappeared. By degrees, the light of\r\nthe lamps gradually faded in the hands of the marble statues which held\r\nthem, and the perfumes appeared less powerful to Morrel. Seated\r\nopposite to him, Monte Cristo watched him in the shadow, and Morrel saw\r\nnothing but the bright eyes of the count. An overpowering sadness took\r\npossession of the young man, his hands relaxed their hold, the objects\r\nin the room gradually lost their form and color, and his disturbed\r\nvision seemed to perceive doors and curtains open in the wall.\r\n\r\n50273m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, \xe2\x80\x9cI feel that I am dying; thanks!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe made a last effort to extend his hand, but it fell powerless beside\r\nhim. Then it appeared to him that Monte Cristo smiled, not with the\r\nstrange and fearful expression which had sometimes revealed to him the\r\nsecrets of his heart, but with the benevolent kindness of a father for\r\na child. At the same time the count appeared to increase in stature,\r\nhis form, nearly double its usual height, stood out in relief against\r\nthe red tapestry, his black hair was thrown back, and he stood in the\r\nattitude of an avenging angel. Morrel, overpowered, turned around in\r\nthe armchair; a delicious torpor permeated every vein. A change of\r\nideas presented themselves to his brain, like a new design on the\r\nkaleidoscope. Enervated, prostrate, and breathless, he became\r\nunconscious of outward objects; he seemed to be entering that vague\r\ndelirium preceding death. He wished once again to press the count\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhand, but his own was immovable. He wished to articulate a last\r\nfarewell, but his tongue lay motionless and heavy in his throat, like a\r\nstone at the mouth of a sepulchre. Involuntarily his languid eyes\r\nclosed, and still through his eyelashes a well-known form seemed to\r\nmove amid the obscurity with which he thought himself enveloped.\r\n\r\nThe count had just opened a door. Immediately a brilliant light from\r\nthe next room, or rather from the palace adjoining, shone upon the room\r\nin which he was gently gliding into his last sleep. Then he saw a woman\r\nof marvellous beauty appear on the threshold of the door separating the\r\ntwo rooms. Pale, and sweetly smiling, she looked like an angel of mercy\r\nconjuring the angel of vengeance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it heaven that opens before me?\xe2\x80\x9d thought the dying man; \xe2\x80\x9cthat angel\r\nresembles the one I have lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo pointed out Morrel to the young woman, who advanced\r\ntowards him with clasped hands and a smile upon her lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValentine, Valentine!\xe2\x80\x9d he mentally ejaculated; but his lips uttered no\r\nsound, and as though all his strength were centred in that internal\r\nemotion, he sighed and closed his eyes. Valentine rushed towards him;\r\nhis lips again moved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is calling you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9che to whom you have confided your\r\ndestiny\xe2\x80\x94he from whom death would have separated you, calls you to him.\r\nHappily, I vanquished death. Henceforth, Valentine, you will never\r\nagain be separated on earth, since he has rushed into death to find\r\nyou. Without me, you would both have died. May God accept my atonement\r\nin the preservation of these two existences!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nValentine seized the count\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and in her irresistible impulse of\r\njoy carried it to her lips.\r\n\r\n50275m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, thank me again!\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9ctell me till you are weary, that\r\nI have restored you to happiness; you do not know how much I require\r\nthis assurance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, yes, I thank you with all my heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cand if\r\nyou doubt the sincerity of my gratitude, oh, then, ask Hayd\xc3\xa9e! ask my\r\nbeloved sister Hayd\xc3\xa9e, who ever since our departure from France, has\r\ncaused me to wait patiently for this happy day, while talking to me of\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou then love Hayd\xc3\xa9e?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Monte Cristo with an emotion he in vain\r\nendeavored to dissimulate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, with all my soul.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, listen, Valentine,\xe2\x80\x9d said the count; \xe2\x80\x9cI have a favor to ask\r\nof you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf me? Oh, am I happy enough for that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; you have called Hayd\xc3\xa9e your sister,\xe2\x80\x94let her become so indeed,\r\nValentine; render her all the gratitude you fancy that you owe to me;\r\nprotect her, for\xe2\x80\x9d (the count\xe2\x80\x99s voice was thick with emotion)\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chenceforth she will be alone in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlone in the world!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated a voice behind the count, \xe2\x80\x9cand why?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMonte Cristo turned around; Hayd\xc3\xa9e was standing pale, motionless,\r\nlooking at the count with an expression of fearful amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause tomorrow, Hayd\xc3\xa9e, you will be free; you will then assume your\r\nproper position in society, for I will not allow my destiny to\r\novershadow yours. Daughter of a prince, I restore to you the riches and\r\nname of your father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHayd\xc3\xa9e became pale, and lifting her transparent hands to heaven,\r\nexclaimed in a voice stifled with tears, \xe2\x80\x9cThen you leave me, my lord?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHayd\xc3\xa9e, Hayd\xc3\xa9e, you are young and beautiful; forget even my name, and\r\nbe happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hayd\xc3\xa9e; \xe2\x80\x9cyour order shall be executed, my lord; I\r\nwill forget even your name, and be happy.\xe2\x80\x9d And she stepped back to\r\nretire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, heavens,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Valentine, who was supporting the head of\r\nMorrel on her shoulder, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you not see how pale she is? At length she felt his\r\nheart beat, a faint breath played upon his lips, a slight shudder,\r\nannouncing the return of life, passed through the young man\xe2\x80\x99s frame. At\r\nlength his eyes opened, but they were at first fixed and\r\nexpressionless; then sight returned, and with it feeling and grief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, in an accent of despair, \xe2\x80\x9cthe count has deceived me; I\r\nam yet living;\xe2\x80\x9d and extending his hand towards the table, he seized a\r\nknife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDearest,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Valentine, with her adorable smile, \xe2\x80\x9cawake, and\r\nlook at me!\xe2\x80\x9d Morrel uttered a loud exclamation, and frantic, doubtful,\r\ndazzled, as though by a celestial vision, he fell upon his knees.\r\n\r\nThe next morning at daybreak, Valentine and Morrel were walking\r\narm-in-arm on the seashore, Valentine relating how Monte Cristo had\r\nappeared in her room, explained everything, revealed the crime, and,\r\nfinally, how he had saved her life by enabling her to simulate death.\r\n\r\nThey had found the door of the grotto opened, and gone forth; on the\r\nazure dome of heaven still glittered a few remaining stars.\r\n\r\nMorrel soon perceived a man standing among the rocks, apparently\r\nawaiting a sign from them to advance, and pointed him out to Valentine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, it is Jacopo,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe captain of the yacht;\xe2\x80\x9d and she\r\nbeckoned him towards them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you wish to speak to us?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Morrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a letter to give you from the count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the count!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the two young people.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; read it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50281m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nMorrel opened the letter, and read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Dear Maximilian,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a felucca for you at anchor. Jacopo will carry you to\r\nLeghorn, where Monsieur Noirtier awaits his granddaughter, whom he\r\nwishes to bless before you lead her to the altar. All that is in this\r\ngrotto, my friend, my house in the Champs-\xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9es, and my ch\xc3\xa2teau at\r\nTr\xc3\xa9port, are the marriage gifts bestowed by Edmond Dant\xc3\xa8s upon the son\r\nof his old master, Morrel. Mademoiselle de Villefort will share them\r\nwith you; for I entreat her to give to the poor the immense fortune\r\nreverting to her from her father, now a madman, and her brother who\r\ndied last September with his mother. Tell the angel who will watch over\r\nyour future destiny, Morrel, to pray sometimes for a man, who, like\r\nSatan, thought himself for an instant equal to God, but who now\r\nacknowledges with Christian humility that God alone possesses supreme\r\npower and infinite wisdom. Perhaps those prayers may soften the remorse\r\nhe feels in his heart. As for you, Morrel, this is the secret of my\r\nconduct towards you. There is neither happiness nor misery in the\r\nworld; there is only the comparison of one state with another, nothing\r\nmore. He who has felt the deepest grief is best able to experience\r\nsupreme happiness. We must have felt what it is to die, Morrel, that we\r\nmay appreciate the enjoyments of living.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLive, then, and be happy, beloved children of my heart, and never\r\nforget that until the day when God shall deign to reveal the future to\r\nman, all human wisdom is summed up in these two words,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98_Wait and\r\nhope_.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94Your friend,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdmond Dant\xc3\xa8s, _Count of Monte Cristo_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n50282m\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDuring the perusal of this letter, which informed Valentine for the\r\nfirst time of the madness of her father and the death of her brother,\r\nshe became pale, a heavy sigh escaped from her bosom, and tears, not\r\nthe less painful because they were silent, ran down her cheeks; her\r\nhappiness cost her very dear.\r\n\r\nMorrel looked around uneasily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe count\xe2\x80\x99s generosity is too overwhelming; Valentine\r\nwill be satisfied with my humble fortune. Where is the count, friend?\r\nLead me to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nJacopo pointed towards the horizon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Valentine. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the count?\xe2\x80\x94where is\r\nHayd\xc3\xa9e?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook!\xe2\x80\x9d said Jacopo.\r\n\r\nThe eyes of both were fixed upon the spot indicated by the sailor, and\r\non the blue line separating the sky from the Mediterranean Sea, they\r\nperceived a large white sail.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGone,\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel; \xe2\x80\x9cgone!\xe2\x80\x94adieu, my friend\xe2\x80\x94adieu, my father!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGone,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Valentine; \xe2\x80\x9cadieu, my sweet Hayd\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x94adieu, my sister!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho can say whether we shall ever see them again?\xe2\x80\x9d said Morrel with\r\ntearful eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDarling,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Valentine, \xe2\x80\x9chas not the count just told us that all\r\nhuman wisdom is summed up in two words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98_Wait and hope_ (Fac et spera)!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFOOTNOTES:\r\n\r\n\r\n[1] \xe2\x80\x9cThe wicked are great drinkers of water; By diplomacy and\r\nsuccess in arms he became almost supreme ruler of Albania, Epirus, and\r\nadjacent territory. Having aroused the enmity of the Sultan, he was\r\nproscribed and put to death by treachery in 1822, at the age of\r\neighty.\xe2\x80\x94Ed.\r\n\r\n[14] Greek militiamen in the war for independence.\xe2\x80\x94Ed.\r\n\r\n[15] A Turkish pasha in command of the troops of a province.\xe2\x80\x94Ed.\r\n\r\n[16] The god of fruitfulness in Grecian mythology. In Crete he was\r\nsupposed to be slain in winter with the decay of vegetation and to\r\nrevive in the spring. Hayd\xc3\xa9e\xe2\x80\x99s learned reference is to the behavior of\r\nan actor in the Dionysian festivals.\xe2\x80\x94Ed.\r\n\r\n[17] The Genoese conspirator.\r\n\r\n[18] Lake Maggiore.\r\n\r\n[19] In the old Greek legend the Atreidae, or children of Atreus, were\r\ndoomed to punishment because of the abominable crime of their father.\r\nThe _Agamemnon_ of Aeschylus is based on this legend.\r\n\r\n[20] The performance of the civil marriage.\r\n\r\n[21] In Moli\xc3\xa8re\xe2\x80\x99s comedy, _Le Misanthrope_.\r\n\r\n[22] Literally, \xe2\x80\x9cthe basket,\xe2\x80\x9d because wedding gifts were originally\r\nbrought in such a receptacle.\r\n\r\n[23] Germain Pillon was a famous French sculptor (1535-1598). His best\r\nknown work is \xe2\x80\x9cThe Three Graces,\xe2\x80\x9d now in the Louvre.\r\n\r\n[24] Fr\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa9rick Lema\xc3\xaetre\xe2\x80\x94French actor (1800-1876).
